description: Bargain hunters and program traders lifted the market out of a slump yesterday. After dipping as much as 11 points by shortly after noon, the market turned around and the Dow Jones industrial average rose briskly, ending the day at 2,656.76, up 11.71 points.

title: Ex-Banker Tells of Secret Marcos Accounts
description: A former Philippine bank employee testified yesterday that between 1982 and 1986, at least $83 million in cash was deposited in secret accounts that prosecutors say belonged to Ferdinand and Imelda Marcos.

title: Excitement With Poker Realism And Sound
description: IT'S Friday night, and you sit down at the card table with four other members of your poker club: Harry, a used-car dealer; Mary, a real-estate broker; Pete, an airline pilot, and Chen, who owns a first-class Chinese restaurant. The house dealer drones as dealers do. ''Bullet.'' (An ace.) ''Lady.'' (Queen.) ''Possible flush for Pete.'' The atmosphere is realistic, the play fast and good, the opponents all too human. They are skilled, but not the poker equivalents of grand masters. They make mistakes, and they can be bluffed.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Conde Nast Chooses New Magazine's Name
description: The new beauty magazine planned by Conde Nast Publications Inc. finally has a name: Allure. The magazine, scheduled to be released next March, will have a rate base of 200,000 and a cover price of $2.50.

title: Citizens Confront Watkins on Secrecy Over Atomic Plant Troubles
description: Leaders of citizens' groups in 17 states criticized Energy Secretary James D. Watkins today, saying his department was not doing enough to include the public in decisions about the future of the nation's nuclear weapons industry.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: In Coup-Prone Nigeria, 2 Halves Make a Crisis
description: When army officers tried recently to overthrow Nigeria's Government, they renewed a conflict that has bedeviled the West African nation since independence: coexistence of the relatively wealthy, largely Christian south and the poorer but politically dominant Muslim north.

title: I.B.M. Chairman Sees New Markets
description: The chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation said the company sees significant untapped markets for computer systems, with less than 15 percent of worldwide businesses using computers. But John Akers also said at I.B.M.'s annual shareholders' meeting that increased competition among computer makers was putting more pressure on profits.

title: Review/Television;   Show About Black People, With Winfrey in Charge
description: Although off to a sluggish start, ''Brewster Place'' represents an Olympics-sized leap in prime-time programming. Television has had dramas and dramatic series about black people and for black people. Now it has one controlled by a black person. The star of ''Brewster Place'' is Oprah Winfrey. More important, she is one of the executive producers. The show is being filmed on location in Chicago at Ms. Winfrey's Harpo (spell that backwards) Studios, also the production center for ''The Oprah Winfrey Show.'' ABC is broadcasting special presentations of ''Brewster Place'' tonight and next Tuesday at 9:30, before the series settles into its regular slot Wednesdays at 9:30.

title: Government Says Dioxin From Paper Mills Poses No Major Danger
description: Responding to questions about the release of the toxic chemical dioxin from pulp and paper mills, Government officials said today that the health risks were generally small. But they added that they would act to reduce the threat further.

title: Talking Business; with Robles Ortega of Osborne;   Effects in Spain Of Liberalization
description: In a program of broad economic liberalization, the Spanish Government has taken the country into the European Community and ended a tradition of protectionism that has endured virtually unchallenged since 1715. Manuel Robles Ortega recently discussed how this has affected his company. He is the managing director of Osborne y Cia., the large Spanish producer of Osborne sherry, Conde de Osborne brandy and gourmet ham. Founded in 1772, Osborne has 800 employees and had sales last year of $363 million.

title: Squeezing the Slorc

Washington has suspended official aid. But Myanmar's ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council, or Slorc, has found a new way to pay for its brutal military operations. It recently opened Myanmar's long-closed economy to foreign commerce.

title: Our Towns;   Quiz Contestants Find the Agony Of - Just Agony
description: Adults look at smart high school students and think, ''The best years of their lives! Why don't they smile more?'' Adults forget. Last Wednesday Bill Delfyett competed in the Knowledge Master Open, a national computer quiz bowl. Friday he had the state Citizen Bee in Albany. Saturday was Buffalo and the state science Olympiad. No wonder he was sitting in his Ramada Inn room here Friday morning, watching Alvin and the Chipmunks. ''I needed a break,'' he said.

title: Bulgarian Bank Planned
description: Business executives in Bulgaria have decided to set up the country's first private bank, the ruling Socialist Party newspaper Douma said today. The bank would have capital of 10 million leva, or $3.3 million, and would offer low-interest loans to stimulate private enterprise, the newspaper said. Bulgaria's private business association, the Citizens' Union for Economic Initiative, set the price of the bank's shares, which foreigners would be permitted to buy, at 1,000 leva, or $330, each.

title: Lava From Kilauea Continues to Flow; Community in Peril

Sri Lanka Growth Slows
description: Sri Lanka's gross domestic product rose by 2.3 percent in 1989, down from 2.7 percent the previous year, as the economy was affected by civil conflict and bad weather, the central bank said in its 1989 report released today. title: Chronicle

He will get one more opportunity to pass the grueling 12 1/2-hour, two-day test, said COLLEEN ROCHE, a spokeswoman for the district attorney's office. If he fails, he will be asked to resign from his $30,000-a-year post.

Consider, for example, the exposed pipes in the ceiling, a design statement usually associated with young, downtown agencies, not a 13-year-old shop. And instead of doors with hinges and knobs, the offices feature metal doors that slide and lock like bank vaults.

description: The United States Supreme Court ruled today that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey can be sued in Federal court. title: Renault Dividend
description: The French state-owned car maker Renault said it would pay its shareholders - the French Government and its own employees - their first dividend since 1980. The payout will be 750 million francs, or $133.4 million. Of this, 742 million francs, or $131.9 million, will be for the state. Renault's status as a state agency was altered last week by legislation that allows it to enter into a partnership with Volvo A.B. of Sweden.

title: Chronicle
description: A piano recital by VLADIMIR FELTSMAN ended on a sour note last Thursday at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association of North Jersey, in Wayne. He cut off his program of Bach, Mozart and Liszt at intermission, complaining that the piano was out of tune. Mr. Feltsman, whose contracts stipulate that he be provided with a Steinway piano, was playing on the group's Baldwin because he didn't like the Steinway that it had rented.

title: Chronicle
description: Their careers are widely varied, but they share one common experience: each spent at least a school year at International House, which has housed about 700 graduate students at New York-area colleges each year since its founding in 1924. Five International House alumni will be honored Wednesday night at a dinner at the Pierre, the first such honors ever bestowed. They are: MARK EYSKENS, the Belgian Foreign Minister; ERZY KOSINSKI, the writer; FLORA LEWIS, a columnist for The New York Times; the soprano LEONTYNE PRICE, and TATSURO TOYODA, an executive vice president and member of the founding family of the Toyota Motor Company.

title: Gerber Ends Plant Tour
description: The Gerber Products Company will end tours of its baby food plant here this week after providing such visits for 78 years. A Gerber spokesman, Steve Poole, said: ''We know our competition has been through the tour because we've spotted their sales reps. We can't afford to take any chances.'' Some 15,000 visitors a year have taken the free tour, which covers about 10 percent of the one-million-square-foot plant. At first they walked, but in recent years battery-operated carts were brought in.

The smiling De Firmian evidently enjoyed confronting it, too, and dispatched it with businesslike precision.

With the retirement of Mainbocher in 1972, the only remaining couture designer of stature in New York was Arnold Scaasi. The designation ''couture'' was being bastardized, with the word frequently used to describe expensive ready-to-wear.

Trump, 55 years old, was rescued Sunday after he was seen walking on a snowbound road in Mount Rainier National Park and was was treated for sunburn and blurred vision. He had begun what was intended as an overnight trip to the 14,410-foot peak April 21. The next morning, a blizzard disoriented him, he told the authorities.

title: Baby Found Dead in Garbage
description: A newborn boy was found dead in a plastic garbage bag last night in Brooklyn and a 24-year-old woman who had given birth to the infant was placed under police observation at a hospital. The baby's body was found in front of 182 East 32d Street in the East Flatbush section. The mother, Marie Kapley Moliere, was taken to Kings County Medical Center pending the outcome of an autopsy to determine whether the infant had died after birth, the police said. Ms. Moliere's family called the police after finding the infant's body.

The truck will haul franked mail between rented warehouse space and the House mail room.

title: Jennifer Graham Is Wed in Florida
description: Jennifer Smith Graham, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Graham of New York was married yesterday in Palm Beach, Fla., to Daniel Peter Brunson, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Marion Pete Brunson of Charlotte, N.C. The Very Rev. Dr. Ralph R. Warren Jr., the dean of the North Palm Beach Deanery of the Diocese of Southeast Florida, performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of Bethesda-by-the-Sea. The bride, 25 years old, and her husband, 27, are actors. Mrs. Brunson graduated from the Middlesex School and summa cum laude from the University of Michigan, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. She was a member of the 1982 Junior Assembly in New York and was presented at the Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball. Her father is the director of planning at the Midatlantic Telecom Inc. in New York.

title: Found Horizons
description: A New Yorker, back in the city after a long absence, has been making a survey of the evening skyline, passing judgment on the way the tops of buildings are lighted. First place goes to the Empire State Building for the brashness and variety of its colors for all occasions -deep red for Valentine's Day, bright green for St. Patrick's and a familiar trio rearranged to serve both the Fourth of July and Bastille Day. He gives high marks to the elegant green and white Woolworth peak and the rosy-hued tiers of Metropolitan Life.

title: For Family of Ex-Hostage, The End of 'an Awful Hurt'
description: A jubilant Fahima Reed shouted, ''He's out! He's out!'' today when she received a phone call from the State Department notifying her that her husband, Frank Herbert Reed, had just been released in Beirut by his Islamic captors.

description: The Contemporary Arts Museum and its director asked a court in Cincinnati today to dismiss obscenity charges brought against them because of an exhibition that includes pictures by the photographer Robert Mapplethorpe showing nude children and homosexual acts.

description: Leaders of the conservative movement, who have been placated by President Bush's relentless courting and occasional policy concessions, are for the first time threatening to break their uneasy peace with the White House.

description: b-Net income MLX attributed the loss in the 1989 fourth quarter and year to non-recurring charges of $10.5 million related to the company's debt restructuring, of which $6 million reduced operating earnings, and a $4.7 million increase in interest expense.

title: Hershey Net Up 18.6%
description: Buoyed by sales of chocolate and pasta products, the Hershey Foods Corporation said today that its first-quarter earnings rose 18.6 percent. Company officials said earnings for the quarter that ended on April 1 rose to $47 million, or 52 cents a share, up from $39.6 million, or 44 cents a share, in the comparable period last year. Its sales rose 19 percent, to $681.2 million, from $572.2 million. Richard A. Zimmerman, Hershey's chairman and chief executive, said sales were spurred by the performance of Hershey Chocolate U.S.A. and the Hershey Pasta Group, along with the acquisition in February of the Ronzoni Foods Corporation.

title: Maxtor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest year was comprised of 53 weeks. The latest fourth quarter revenue and pre-tax income from ongoing operations were augmented by about $2 million, representing payments from a supplier under a product discontinuance agreement, less estimated costs of discontinuing and replacing those products. The company said results have been restated due to issuance of 208,450 common shares in settlement of a class action lawsuit against the company arising out of its acquisition of Design Corp.

title: Speedy Justice - At What Cost?
description: Federal habeas corpus may become a dinosaur on the legal landscape unless Congress acts quickly to preserve its existence. Recent Supreme Court decisions have cut back the scope of the writ, and a bill circulating in Congress would further limit its availability.

title: Heritage Bankcorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $252,000 for the quarter and 9 months. Reflecting the year-ago periods, the company closed its initial stock offering on Aug. 10.

title: Bridge
description: Husband-and-wife partnerships tend to be difficult, and particularly tricky for newlyweds: Even a raised eyebrow has been known to cause trouble. A careful safety-play was devised last Thursday by Amy Shavick Treitel, who was playing with David Treitel for the first time in their eight-day marriage.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, said its shareholders overwhelmingly defeated a proposal that would have banned the company from selling infant formula directly to the public.

title: Baxter Denial On Blacklist
description: The world's largest hospital supply company, Baxter International Inc., denied today that it had sold a plant in Israel and agreed to build one in Syria to get off the Arab League's blacklist of companies doing business with the Jewish state.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, named Michael Halloran executive vice president and general counsel. He will succeed George Coombe Jr., who will retire.

title: Broker Is Sentenced To a Six-Year Term For H.U.D. Thefts
description: A real estate broker who stole $2 million in Government housing money and used it to buy sports cars, furs and jewelry was sentenced by a Federal district judge today to six years in prison and ordered to pay $4 million in fines and restitution.

title: Japan Computer Lead Seen
description: The head of the Intel Corporation, whose popular 386 microprocessor is used in computer systems worldwide, said today that he expects Japan to overtake the United States as the dominant world supplier of computers by 1992.

title: Review/Television;   New Film on Achille Lauro Hijacking
description: ''Voyage of Terror: The Achille Lauro Affair'' is the second television movie based on the 1985 hijacking by four Palestinians of an Italian cruise ship in the Mediterranean. This one, starring Burt Lancaster and Eva-Marie Saint as the American passengers Leon and Marilyn Klinghoffer, makes its own special claims to authenticity. Actually filmed aboard the Achille Lauro, it retraces the ship's route from Genoa, Italy, to Alexandria and Port Said, Egypt. Gerardo De Rosa, the ship's captain at the time of the hijacking, served as consultant.

title: About New York;   Gay Dentists? Flirting Advice? Call the Hot Line
description: Things hummed along at the Gay and Lesbian Switchboard.

title: As South African Rivals Spar, Political Violence Mushrooms
description: An abatement of political violence appears crucial to the ultimate success of talks scheduled to begin here on Wednesday between the Government and its leading anti-apartheid opponent, the African National Congress.

title: Book Notes
description: Executive Shifts

title: Obscenity Law Used In Alabama Breaks New York Company
description: Two months ago the Home Dish Satellite Corporation was a flourishing New York City company, beaming hard-core sex films to 30,000 subscribers around the country and soft-core ones to 1.2 million customers.

title: To the Aztecs, the Coyote Was God's Dog
description: To the Editor:

title: Lessons
description: Barbara Staples, who teaches seventh grade at Conway Middle School here, returned from summer vacation several years ago to find her professional world turned upside down.

title: At the End of The Polls
description: ''There's light at the end of the tunnel,'' a New York politician said the other day upon learning that capital punishment may finally be returning to the Empire State. What did he have in mind? Burning at the stake? Not likely. Politicians receiving big news tend to grasp for the nearest cliche, and ''light at the end of the tunnel'' happened to be lying around when he heard the cheery news.

title: Henry Gregory 3d, 54, Senior Minister AT Shiloh in Capital
description: The Rev. Henry C. Gregory 3d, for 17 years senior minister of Shiloh Baptist Church, Washington's historic activist church, died of cancer on Sunday at the Greenbriar, a resort in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va., where he was resting. He was 54 years old. Mr. Gregory's sermons at Shiloh, nationally known for its program of pursuing social and political causes, were taped and broadcast on radio every Sunday.

title: As the Twig Is Bent
description: To The Living Section:

title: Suicides of Four Teen-Agers Stun School in Small Arkansas Town
description: A 17-year-old boy died of a gunshot wound to the head today, becoming the third student at the high school here to commit suicide in the last two days and the fourth in the last month.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Lithuanian Leader, on 'Private' Visit, to Meet Bush
description: President Bush will meet with the Lithuanian Prime Minister on Thursday, the White House announced today. It will be the first time that an American President has met with a leader of the Baltic republic since it was forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940.

title: KEY RATES
Eurocom Head Is Quitting
description: Tim Breene has said he would resign as chief executive of Eurocom WCRS Della Femina Ball, the parent agency of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS in New York.

title: Expos Win in the 13th On Pitcher's Pinch-Hit
description: The pitcher Zane Smith, in a rare pinch-hitting role, doubled in the winning run in the 13th inning tonight, giving the Montreal Expos a 2-1 victory over the Houston Astros.

title: Switch Seen as Station Agrees to Show Debate
description: The CBS television network affiliate in Los Angeles, KCBS, announced yesterday that it had agreed to broadcast a debate between the contenders for the Democratic nomination for governor of California, Dianne Feinstein and John K. Van de Kamp, on Sunday afternoon, May 20.

title: Dancer Leaves City Ballet
description: Robert Hill, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, has left the company. The termination of the contract was by mutual agreement, said a spokeswoman for City Ballet and Mr. Hill, a former member of American Ballet Theater. Mr. Hill, who joined City Ballet last year, said he had commitments to dance with the Royal Ballet of London and the Scottish Ballet as a guest artist starting in July, and would have had to be away from New York for much of the winter.

title: Chevron Is Selling Some Oil Reserves
description: Chevron U.S.A. Inc. agreed to sell certain Gulf of Mexico oil reserves for about $150 million to a New Orleans-based partnership. Chevron U.S.A., the domestic oil and gas subsidiary of the Chevron Corporation, said it was selling its Main Pass 299 shallow oil reserves.

title: At Old City Site, Just 20 Jews Are Left
description: All but 20 of the Jewish settlers at a four-building complex in the Christian Quarter of Jerusalem's walled Old City left the building by noon today, when an eviction order took effect.

title: WHITE HOUSE SEEKS A 'NEW LEADERSHIP' AT SAVINGS AGENCY
description: The outspoken head of the Federal savings and loan bailout came under White House pressure today, with the President's chief spokesman saying that ''we are interested in getting new leadership'' in the rescue effort.

title: U.N. GROUP SEEKS MONEY FOR HEALTH
description: Many of the 40 million deaths caused by disease around the world each year could be prevented by a small shifting of resources to health care, the World Health Organization says.

title: Purchasers' Economic Index Rises
description: After an 11-month decline, the nation's manufacturing economy expanded in April, stimulated by strong levels of new orders, particularly from foreign customers, the nation's purchasing managers reported yesterday.

title: Walter Kendall Jr., 75, Retired Police Official
description: Walter J. Kendall Jr., a retired chief of personnel in the New York City Police Department, died of congestive heart failure on Sunday at Suburban General Hospital in Norristown, Pa. He was 75 years old and lived in Ridge, L.I.

title: Review/Music;   Castanets and a Quintet
description: As castanet players go, Lucero Tena is a consummate virtuoso. Of that, her concert with the Andres Segovia Quintet at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening left no doubt. Effortlessly, it seems, she can play with blinding speed or evenly measured slowness, shattering intensity or delicate stillness; she can achieve any gradation between, and progress smoothly from one to another.

title: Antoine Vitez, 59, the Director Of the Comedie Francaise, Dies
description: Antoine Vitez, an actor, director and teacher who capped a distinguished theatrical career by becoming chief administrator of the Comedie Francaise, died of a brain hemorrhage on Monday. He was 59 years old.

title: House Backs $24 Billion in Cuts From Bush's Plans for Pentagon
description: The House today narrowly approved the Democratic majority's $1.2 trillion budget for 1991, calling for $24 billion less for the military than President Bush proposed and $5.6 billion more for domestic programs.

title: Scores of Filipinos Are Hurt in Clashes At Anti-U.S. Rallies
description: Scores of people were hurt today when anti-American demonstrators clashed with policemen outside a United States Air Force base north of Manila, as Filipino militants carried out nationwide May Day protests against the American military.

title: The Pop Life
description: Voice to Melodies

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a case of adultery being prosecuted in Wisconsin misattributed an article listing states in which adultery was still prohibited by law in 1987. It was in The Harvard Journal of Law and Public Policy, not The Harvard Law Review.

title: Chrysler Net Falls By 79.8%
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that its first-quarter profit declined 79.8 percent, reflecting an industrywide sales slowdown and the high cost of discount programs.

title: Year of Classes Canceled at Marine Lab
description: Fairleigh Dickinson University's hurricane-ravaged West Indies Laboratory for Underwater Research in St. Croix, V.I., has canceled classes for the 1990-91 academic year, on the recommendation of a special committee of the trustees.

title: Fed Official On Inflation
description: A Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, said today that the nation's high inflation rate in the first quarter might have been an aberration.

title: George H. Beebe, 80, Newspaper Executive
description: George H. Beebe, a former managing editor and associate publisher of The Miami Herald, died of cancer on Monday at the Miami Heart Institute. He was 80 years old.

title: Washington at Work;   Two Unlikely Voices That Find Harmony On the Military Budget
description: It took Sam Nunn three months of research to pronounce the Bush Administration's 1991 military budget irrelevant. His series of carefully timed speeches on the Senate floor was front-page news.

title: Pete Rose Might Go To Prison
description: Clang. It is a sound unlike any other sound: Not just metal on metal, but the definitive sequence of locks and bolts settling into place. Even a reporter on assignment cannot escape shuddering when the prison doors go clang.

title: Ireland Bans Smoking In Buses and Movies
description: The Irish Government outlawed smoking in theaters and buses today and ordered segregated smoking areas to be set up in Government buildings, trains, schools, libraries, hospitals, airports, supermarkets, restaurants and art galleries.

title: AIDS Researcher Suspended Over Finances
description: A Government AIDS researcher is under suspension while a grand jury considers whether he hid a financial interest in a company that contracted with the laboratory where he worked.

title: Alzheimer's and Architecture: A Search for Order
description: In the hills of Geauga County, 22 miles east of Cleveland, a tiny rest home is doing research that may help the nation's four million Alzheimer's patients, and the families and nursing homes that care for them, get through the daily crises of memory loss, disorientation, wandering and incontinence that mark their decline into dementia.

title: Would-Be Payers Fight New York Sales Tax Plan
description: The tentative agreement between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders to extend the New York State sales tax to magazines and a number of service industries was attacked by representatives of those industries yesterday. They said that it would drive many businesses out of the state.

title: Maybe the Key To Long-Term Care
description: Solving the problem of financing long-term health care for the elderly is a pressing national priority. Connecticut has taken steps to address that problem, and is awaiting action by Congress that would help put its plan into action.

title: 'It Is Now Time' for Voices To 'Rise From the Grave'
description: Following are excerpts from the sentencing of John Emil List for the murder of his wife, mother and three children by Judge William L'E. Wertheimer in Superior Court.

title: National Ads Are Sought By Enquirer
description: THE National Enquirer has started a new push to get more national consumer-product advertisers to follow its success with Procter & Gamble. The Enquirer's owner, the G. P. Group Inc., recently acquired the rival Star in March, which will aid the effort. The company plans to offer a combination advertising package in the tabloids that it says will deliver more than 30 million readers a week to advertisers.

title: $375 Million Contract Given to MCI by U.S.
description: The MCI Communications Corporation announced yesterday that it had won its largest contract ever, a five-year, $375 million agreement to provide long-distance services for pay phones at United States Navy, Marine Corps and Coast Guard sites.

title: Keith Haring Memorial
description: A memorial service for the artist Keith Haring is to be held on Friday at 2 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Amsterdam Avenue at West 112th Street.

title: Carter's President Leaving; Layoffs Planned to Cut Costs
description: The Carter Organization, a leading proxy solicitation firm, told its employees yesterday that about 25 of them, including the company's president, Art Ross, would be let go to trim costs.

title: Dinkins Names 3 More Community Directors
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins named directors of homosexual, veteran and Asian-American affairs yesterday, the last of his ''constituency'' office appointments.

title: Corrections
description: The Metro Matters column on April 19, about a dentist facing sentencing for burglary, referred to her incorrectly. She is Marsha Cohen.

title: Civility and Bus Doors: The Real Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Tillman's No Tyson, But Who's at Fault?
description: Henry Tillman beat Mike Tyson twice when they were amateurs, victories that led to Tillman winning a spot on the 1984 United States Olympic team. But as a professional, Tillman saw his career go south while Tyson's star, and financial worth, ascended.

title: Innovative Details In Kruger's Pact
description: He paid his dues for four years as head coach at Pan American University and for four more at Kansas State, and now, as Lon Kruger gets ready for his first season coaching at the University of Florida, he is truly in a bonus situation.

title: Review/Television;   Nixon On His Ups and Downs and Ups
description: For about 40 years, off and on, America has been treated to a new Richard Nixon, a newer Richard Nixon, the newest Richard Nixon. This marvel of recycling is back again this week, on NBC's ''Today'' show, the occasion being his latest account of his triumphs and his troubles, ''In the Arena: A Memoir of Victory, Defeat and Renewal,'' recently published by Simon & Schuster. Bryant Gumbel engaged him for a few minutes on Monday and Tuesday and will be continuing the conversation this morning and tomorrow.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on the Media Business page on Monday headed ''Magazine Growth, Gains and Losses'' referred incorrectly to the growth in the number of general interest magazines.

title: Fluffy Matzoh Balls
description: To The Living Section:

title: Ferrell Looks to Canada
description: The Phoenix Cardinals have granted free-agent status to their retired fullback Earl Ferrell, who is 32 years old and wants to play in the Canadian Football League.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a study issued by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching misstated the title. The study is ''Campus Life: In Search of Community.''

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Science Watch column of Science Times yesterday about research on latex gloves misstated a finding about leakage. Eighteen percent of 2,900 gloves leaked water, not viruses.

title: Market Place;   Investors See Star In Vintage Group
description: THE penny-stock market has had its share of bad publicity and regulatory action of late, with the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking to bar Blinder, Robinson & Company, once the largest penny-stock firm, from the securities business for 45 days.

title: Reviews/Music;   Sincerity and the Old West
description: About halfway through his show at the Meadowlands tonight, the singer Don Henley introduced a tune of his, ''Sunset Grill,'' with a little talk. The song was about a person named Joe who owned a hamburger stand on Sunset Boulevard, Mr. Henley said. If someone didn't like the hamburgers, he could go and talk to Joe, who wasn't afraid of this responsibility. The song was about sense of place, responsibility and accountability, he rambled on. All this talk, logically, bothered people in the audience. They yelled, ''Shut up and sing!,'' which was pretty good advice.

title: Bianchi Still in Jackson's Corner
description: Al Bianchi, in the final year of a three-year contract, expects to return as the Knicks' general manager next season. And if Bianchi returns, Stu Jackson will return as head coach.

title: Campbell Cutting 364 From Staff
description: The new chief executive of the Campbell Soup Company yesterday cut nearly 19 percent, or 364 jobs, from its headquarters staff in Camden, N.J.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Troops Kill 2 at Zaire Dissident Rally
description: Government forces killed at least two people in an attack on members of a leading dissident group at a political rally Monday evening, less than a week after President Mobutu Sese Seko promised to lift a ban on opposition parties, diplomats and witnesses said today.

title: Review/Theater;   Providing a Reason To Keep On Living In a Terrible World
description: ''The world's a really terrible place - it's too precarious,'' says Rita, the young heroine of ''Prelude to a Kiss,'' the Craig Lucas play newly arrived on Broadway. Rita (Mary-Louise Parker), a bartender aspiring to be a graphics designer, lives in a modern city whose ills are all too depressingly recognizable. Crack dealers approach first graders, unspeakable diseases consume the bodies of the young and old, and there is never any escape from ''the constant fear of being blown up.'' As Rita warns Peter (Timothy Hutton), the young man with whom she has found love at first sight, the world is so rotten she couldn't even think of bringing children into it.

title: Marrying the PC and Fax Machine
description: The personal computer and the facsimile machine are converging in a number of ways visible in products now reaching the market. But how the two technologies will ultimately be combined is anything but certain.

title: Munsingwear Gets Offer From Jacobs
description: Munsingwear Inc. said the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs had offered to make a ''significant cash investment'' in the clothing maker in exchange for an 80 percent equity stake. It said the proposal was conditioned on the company's ability to redeem $34 million of 8 percent bonds at no more than 25 percent of face value.

title: G.O.P. Campaign Finance Bill Would End PAC's
description: Responding to Democratic proposals on campaign financing, Senate Republicans today introduced an alternative that shifts the focus from limiting spending to eliminating political action committees and barring political activity by any tax-exempt organization.

title: New Dates Disclosed for Restarting Nuclear Plants
description: The first of three reactors that are the nation's only source of a gas needed to make nuclear weapons will not be restarted until December, but the plant that is the only source of plutonium triggers may be ready to resume production by July, Energy Secretary James D. Watkins said today.

title: When Cycle of Lava Flow Changed, Danger Increased
description: The lava flows besieging Hawaii's coastal community of Kalapana are far more damaging than some earlier eruptions of the Kilauea volcano because the lava is moving continuously.

title: Construction Spending Falls by 1.4%
description: Construction spending fell 1.4 percent in March, the steepest decline in more than a year, the Government said today in a report that indicated renewed weakness in the building industry.

title: Winfield Seeking the Key To Finding His Old Form
description: Has it come to this? Dave Winfield, role player, out with the coaches and the manager, Bucky Dent, taking advantage of the time allowed in the batting cage for the extra players.

title: A Color Fax Machine Will Make Debut in Japan
description: The Sharp Corporation of Japan says it will soon introduce a desktop machine for full-color facsimiles in that country, but has not decided whether to sell the device in the United States because of concerns that American business will find it too expensive and lack needed high-quality telephone lines.

title: Some Indignities to End for Koreans in Japan
description: Removing a longtime irritant in its relations with South Korea, Japan has agreed to abolish fingerprinting requirements and enhance the legal status for the youngest descendants of Koreans forcibly brought to this country to do hard labor before World War II.

title: 'Twin Peaks' Finale To Be on a New Night
description: The season's final episode of the most talked about new television series of the year, ''Twin Peaks,'' is to be moved to 10 P.M. on May 23, ABC announced yesterday.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After living together for 15 years, CLAIRE BLOOM and PHILIP ROTH were married on Sunday at the Manhattan home of BARBARA EPSTEIN, a co-editor of The New York Review of Books. ''We just thought it was about time,'' Miss Bloom said.

title: Why So Slow on S & L Thieves?
description: The savings and loan bailout is already a mess. Why does the Bush Administration seem so determined to make the cleanup even slower? Now it is not so subtly nudging out the man who is managing the bailout. That comes hard on the heels of Congressional hearings showing Administration stinginess in prosecuting S & L thieves.

title: Georgia-Pacific
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said that in the wake of its recent acquisition of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, it was exploring the sale of some assets that might not fit its long-term strategy. It said no final decision had been made on the sale of the assets, which include a linerboard mill at Valdosta, Ga.; a paper mill at Tomahawk, Wis., and certain box plants.

title: Hawkins Falters Again And Gets Little Help
description: It's now getting so that the Yankees do not know what to fix first.

title: To Our Readers
description: Because of a malfunction in the computer system that receives and transmits financial market data at The Associated Press, several tables reflecting yesterday's trading in options on futures were not available.

title: A Guilty Plea by Emerson
description: The Emerson Electric Company pleaded guilty today to making inflated cost estimates for electronic equipment it sold the Pentagon and agreed to pay a $40,000 fine and a $14 million civil settlement, the Justice Department said.

title: Quake Hits Southern Alaska
description: A strong earthquake measuring 6.0 on the Richter scale struck the coast of southern Alaska this morning, the United States Geological Survey said. Lu Page, a spokeswoman for the agency, said the temblor occurred at 8:12 A.M. The epicenter was near King Salmon, a small community about 290 miles southwest of Anchorage. She said there were no immediate reports of damage.

title: The Spira and Steinbrenner Relationship Is Confirmed by Their Telephone Records
description: The reason for George Steinbrenner's $40,000 payment to Howard Spira in January might be in dispute, but telephone records leave no doubt that an ongoing relationship between the two existed for three years, primarily through Steinbrenner's chief aide.

title: Court Victory For Torchmark
description: A Federal district court in Tennessee cleared the way yesterday for shareholders of the American General Corporation to vote today on the Torchmark Corporation's attempt to win a third of the 15 seats on American General's board.

title: 2 Mohawks Killed in Feud Over Reservation Gambling
description: Two Mohawk Indians were killed today by snipers' bullets in separate shootings on the Canadian side of the St. Regis Indian Reservation. They were the first known fatalities in the bitter confrontation there over casino gambling.

title: As Lava and Flame Lap at the Door, Dazed Neighbors Flee a Fire Goddess
description: The historic Painted Church was propped on timbers to be moved today. Barbara Allen returned one last time to the small house she had built in a coconut grove to rescue Grayson, her cat. Fidelie Sweezey sniffled as she watched the house in which she was born 65 years ago and raised six children start to smolder.

title: '88 Bailout Is Criticized
description: Purchasers in the biggest savings and loan bailout of 1988 are enjoying millions of dollars of risk-free profits and regulators should renegotiate the deal, Senator Howard Metzenbaum said today.

title: Timing May Be Right for Thirty Six Red
description: Only four months ago, Thirty Six Red was a candidate for racing's unkindest cut.

title: Critic's Notebook;   In Philadelphia, 3 Arts Centers, 2 or One?
description: For the last half-century, Philadelphia has had only one major downtown performing-arts center, the venerable Academy of Music, but now the city is struggling over the fate of two others.

title: Well-Aged O.J.
description: To The Living Section:

title: Maxwell Is Ready to Start European 'National' Paper
description: The leaders of the European Community may still be uncertain about what a united Europe will mean, but that does not faze Robert Maxwell, as he prepares to introduce what he calls ''Europe's first national weekend newspaper.''

title: Chief Judge Presses Lawyers On Legal Work for the Poor
description: New York's Chief Judge today declined to force private lawyers to donate free legal services to the poor immediately but warned that he would impose such a program in two years.

title: Bush to Meet With Lithuanian
description: The White House announced that President Bush would meet with the prime minister of the Lithuanian independence government. Page A10.

title: Iran-Contra's Unfollowed Leads
description: ''I think I shredded most of that. Did I get them all?'' Oliver North asked the Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra scandal in 1987. He needn't have worried. The committees were letting damning documents and other evidence slip through their fingers.

title: Knicks Must Produce A Team Effort to Win
description: Gerald Wilkins says, ''We need to play better defense.''

title: Offer for Kinark
description: The Kinark Corporation, a chemical and metals company, said it had received a buyout offer of $7 a share from Steel Partners L.P. The bid is subject to the arrangement of financing and other conditions. One of the conditions is the completion of the previously announced sale of Kinark's hotel properties for at least $12 million. Kinark said that it would consider the offer in due course but that it had previously informed Steel Partners it intended to stay independent. The stock of Kinark, which has about 3.5 million shares outstanding, slipped 25 cents today, to $5.625, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: New Publisher for McCall's
description: Michael Golden was named publisher of McCall's magazine yesterday by William T. Kerr, president of The New York Times Magazine Group, which owns the publication. Mr. Golden had been general manager of Child magazine, also a member of the group, since January 1988.

title: Treasuries Fall in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds sagged in thin trading yesterday, pushed down by a report from the National Association of Purchasing Managers that the economy's manufacturing sector had improved in April.

title: Soprano Is Recipient Of Richard Tucker Prize
description: Renee Fleming, a soprano, is the recipient of this year's Richard Tucker Award. The $25,000 cash prize is the largest cash award in United States music competitions. There were 38 applicants.

title: Health-Care Bonds In Minnesota Cities
description: A $159.4 million tax-exempt bond issue by Minneapolis and the Housing and Redevelopment Authority of St. Paul was priced yesterday through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: A School Windfall, Misused
description: As they struggle to finish the state's overdue budget, New York's legislators threaten in one stroke both to distort the already flawed system of financing local school districts and to compound the state's financial woes.

title: A Mother, a Daughter, a Bond in Codfish
description: THIS is the tale of a mother, a daughter and codfish puffs.

title: 2 Antennas on Telescope Tested; Steady Flow of Data Is Expected
description: Engineers have successfully completed tests of the Hubble Space Telescope's two high-power antennas and both are expected to provide a steady if somewhat restricted flow of communications, the space agency said yesterday.

title: A Pool Finds a New Life as a Wine Cellar
description: IN his backyard overlooking Indian Creek, Norman Braman walks down the steps of his empty swimming pool, opens the watertight door, and descends into his kidney-shaped wine cellar.

title: Food Notes
description: Foie Gras Shortage

title: New Coke Conquest: Burger King
description: Just in time for summer, the Cola Wars sizzled again yesterday, as Burger King announced it was switching to Coke from Pepsi as its soft-drink supplier.

title: A Wright House Is Facing a New Threat
description: A quarter of a century ago, a house that Frank Lloyd Wright designed in the 1940's as part of an experiment in affordable middle-class living, was moved, board by board, to a new site near here to save it from bulldozers that were clearing ground for a superhighway. Now the house is threatened again. The villain this time is the earth on which the house sits, a short distance from George Washington's home. It has proved to be unstable, and the L-shaped structure, the Pope-Leighey House, with its once ultramodern clean lines, picture windows, recessed lighting, flat roof and carport, has developed cracks in its wooden walls and cement foundation and sags in its ceilings.

title: Sim Son, Khmer Rouge Official
description: Sim Son, who was in charge of civilian affairs for the Khmer Rouge, was killed April 25 when a tree fell on him near the Thai border in Cambodia during a storm, Khmer Rouge officials said today. His age was not disclosed.

title: Economic Scene;   Capital Squeeze: Guess Who Pays
description: IT has never been much fun at the bottom of the third world's economic pecking order, and for millions in Latin America, Africa and the backwaters of Asia, it is grimmer than ever. Cut off by private lenders in the 1980's, most poor countries have been forced to make ends meet without much help from the industrialized economies. The flow of capital actually reversed direction in the last decade, with rich countries reabsorbing $20 billion to $40 billion in resources each year from their impoverished neighbors.

title: F.D.A. Approves the Irradiation of Poultry
description: THE Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the irradiation of poultry to control salmonella and other bacteria that are responsible for an increase in food-borne illnesses in this country.

title: Bones Are Identified as Those Of Missing Harvard Student
description: Human remains unearthed in a wooded area here were identified on Monday as those of Joan Webster, a Harvard graduate student from Glen Ridge, N.J., missing since 1981, the Essex County District Attorney said.

title: Old May Days Fade Away, and Fun Arrives
description: The countries of Eastern Europe yesterday marked the first May Day since they emerged from Communist rule without public parades and with few speeches, concentrating largely on private pursuits like picnics and shopping.

title: Bache Cutting Jobs in Britain
description: Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said today that it was eliminating 20 of the 30 jobs in its British equities operation.

title: Land of Promise Seizes the Moment
description: THE highway runs down from Santiago toward Punta Arenas and, yes, the South Pole, but we weren't going that far, my leathery-faced driver and I. We were turning right near San Fernando, about three hours south of the capital, and heading into the Colchagua Valley to Peralillo. It was the fourth day of a weeklong trip through what is probably the most exciting wine region in the world right now.

title: Real Estate;   A Developer Says Smaller Can Be Better
description: IN a city where bigger often translates as better, four brothers operating a development company in Queens say they have found that smaller commercial projects sometimes make more sense.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: News Summary
description: International A2-12

title: Compaq Computer
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation cut the retail prices of its notebook-sized computers in a bid to make the line more accessible to a wider audience. The Houston-based computer maker said the suggested retail price of its LTE/286 model 40 had been reduced to $4,799, from $4,999, and its LTE/286 model 20 cut to $3,999, from $4,499. Compaq's stock fell $1.625 a share today, to $97.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Top Editor Is Named At Times News Service
description: Peggy Walsh, the San Francisco bureau chief of The Associated Press for the last four years, will become executive editor of The New York Times News Service on June 1. She will be in charge of the news, photo and graphics operations for the news service, which transmits breaking news and feature stories, photographs and graphics to more than 650 newspapers and other clients in more than 50 countries.

title: Ellery Gordon Married To Marjorie Anne Reed
description: Marjorie Anne Reed and Ellery Gordon were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York by Caroline K. Simon, a retired judge of the State Court of Claims.

title: Religion Based on Sex Gets a Judicial Review
description: A Federal district judge here is considering a novel extension of First Amendment rights to a religion based primarily on ''absolution'' through sex and ''sacrifice'' through a payment of money.

title: Feel Irritated? Dial 1. Still Irritated? Dial 2.
description: LEAD: You have reached the Acme Rubber Duck Company. If you wish to speak to someone in billing, press 1. If you wish to speak to someone in the cooing department, press 2. If you wish to speak to someone in the old wing, press 3. If you do not know whom you wish to speak to, press 4.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Elias H. Gerchick, Psychiatrist, 74
description: Dr. Elias H. Gerchick, a former chief of psychiatry at White Plains Hospital and a specialist in the treatment of children, died of heart failure at Montefiore Hospital on Saturday. He was 74 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Blame the Bishops, but Not Public Relations;   Rockefeller's Dimes
description: To the Editor:

title: Airline Industry Raises Ante on Terrorism Tips
description: The United States airline industry offered today to pay up to $1 million for information about terrorist attacks against American airliners.

title: CHRONICLE
description: IRVING BERLIN wrote the words and music to ''Call Me Madam,'' the musical based on President HARRY S. TRUMAN'S appointment of PERLE MESTA as Ambassador to Luxembourg, in his five-story town house at 17 Beekman Place in Manhattan. Forty years ago, ''Call Me Madam'' opened on Broadway. Yesterday, the Government of Luxembourg bought the building, where the composer died on Sept. 12 at the age of 101.

title: A Council Panel Back Harsh Fire-Code Fines
description: A New York City Council committee yesterday unanimously approved a bill to stiffen penalties for people responsible for buildings with fire-safety violations, including illegal social clubs. The bill would also create a temporary commission to study how the city can help clubs run by legitimate community groups comply with safety laws.

title: Edwina Dumm, Cartoonist, 96
description: Edwina Dumm, a syndicated newspaper cartoonist, died on Saturday at her home in Manhattan. She was 96 years old.

title: Outsider Is Brought In To Run Signal Apparel
description: Roger Holland, who as chief executive of Champion Products Inc. engineered its success as a maker of athletic apparel, hopes to do the same for the Signal Apparel Company, where he was named president and chief executive yesterday.

title: Evolution in Europe;   GORBACHEV JEERED AT MAY DAY RALLY
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and the Kremlin leadership were jeered today by throngs of protesters who were allowed to march through Red Square at the end of the annual May Day parade.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Met Opera Announces Season in the Parks
description: A performance of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' on June 12 on the Great Lawn of Central Park is to open the Metropolitan Opera's 24th season of free outdoor performances. The opera will alternate with another Verdi work, ''La Traviata,'' during the three-week series, which is sponsored by Chemical Bank.

title: Family Killer Sentenced to 5 Life Terms; No Parole for 75 Years
description: John Emil List was sentenced today to five consecutive life terms for the murders of his wife, mother and three children 18 years ago, and as he was led away, the packed courtroom burst into applause.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: IN the three years since it opened its doors, the tiny Twelve Pine takeout store has become increasingly crowded with patrons hungry for the mix of Greek, Asian, Italian, Mexican, French and American dishes crammed into display cases and onto counters.

title: Kariwalla Journal;   In a Pakistan Village, Democracy of a Feudal Kind
description: The farmers hitched their horses to trees near the little brick schoolhouse on a prairie rich in golden grain. Under a canvas in kaleidoscopic colors, strung on poles for shade, they assembled for a town meeting.

title: 9% Notes Priced By Philip Morris
description: The Philip Morris Companies yesterday priced a $150 million note issue through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Books of The Times;   Gay Men and Lesbians Serving in World War II
description: Coming Out Under Fire

title: Evolution in Europe;   Baker Is Off to Europe, Ready to Sell Soviets on United Germany in NATO
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d leaves for Europe on Wednesday for the first six-nation talks about the future of a united Germany, carrying a briefcase full of ideas that he hopes will help the Soviets accept what the United States sees as inevitable: a unified Germany in NATO.

title: Blame the Bishops, but Not Public Relations
description: To the Editor:

title: The Teacher Salaries Gap
description: The average salary of classroom teachers will pass the $30,000 mark for the first time this year but the gap in teachers' pay among states is still huge, according to statistics compiled by the National Education Association. The average teacher salary rose to $31,304 for the 1989-90 school year, 5.9 percent higher in current dollars than the previous year's figure of $29,547. Alaska had the highest state salary average with $43,153, while South Dakota showed the lowest at $21,300 -a gap of 104 percent.

title: Japanese Tunes With Vigor
description: Yosuke Yamashita, a pianist, devoted most of his first set on Wednesday night at Sweet Basil to adaptations of Japanese folk tunes. But if he hadn't said so, listeners might never have guessed, because he recast the melodies with the spiky harmonies and assertive rhythms of 1960's jazz.

title: Israel Reports an April Influx Of 10,000 Jews From U.S.S.R.
description: For the 16th month in a row, the number of Soviet Jews arriving in Israel increased sharply in April and for the first time exceeded 10,000, Israeli immigration officials said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The blunt fact is that both the Democratic budget and the President's budget are hopelessly obsolete.''

title: Personal Ecology
description: To The Living Section:

title: INSIDE
description: Lawyers Told to Help Poor

title: Senate Approves $720 Million in Aid for Panama and Nicaragua
description: In a spur to the Bush Administration's Latin America policy, the Senate today approved giving $720 million in economic aid to Panama and Nicaragua after an impasse of several days over an assortment of unrelated amendments.

title: Texas Gets More Time On School Financing
description: A court-imposed deadline for revision of the way Texas finances public education passed today without action by the state, but a judge gave Gov. William P. Clements Jr. and the Legislature 30 days more to arrive at a plan.

title: Review/Film;   A Brutal, Elegiac 'Last Exit,' Unrelieved by Hope
description: Uli Edel's ''Last Exit to Brooklyn'' is a good, dark, uncommonly evocative screen adaptation of Hubert Selby Jr.'s teeming novel, published in 1964, about life on the edge in the Red Hook section in the early 1950's.

title: School Mergers Build Bridges From Japan to U.S.
description: The first volunteers in an unusual educational experiment have just landed in this tiny Appalachian town - an eager, slightly bewildered group of 183 Japanese students who represent the first full-fledged merger between an American and Japanese college.

title: Officer Shot After Stopping Car in Brooklyn
description: A veteran police officer was shot in the neck and critically wounded early yesterday by a man he had stopped for driving a stolen car the wrong way on a one-way street in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Hewlett-Actel Chip Venture
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company and the Actel Corporation said today that they would cooperate in developing and manufacturing a new family of computer chips.

title: Former Houston Officer Gets 7 Years in Killing of Woman
description: A former Houston police officer has been sentenced to seven years in prison for shooting a black woman to death along a Houston freeway last October.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Rules to Live By
description: To The Living Section:

title: Yields on Some C.D.'s Up
description: Yields on some certificates of deposit were slightly up, while those offered on money market accounts were unchanged in the week ended yesterday.

title: Defense Blocked on Evidence in Bensonhurst Trial
description: The judge in the Bensonhurst murder case blocked the lawyer for Joseph Fama yesterday from introducing evidence considered important by the defense.

title: Police and Protesters Clash in Tompkins Sq. Park
description: Police officers in riot helmets entered Tompkins Square Park last night after a Parks Department enforcement patrol officer was injured by a bottle thrown during a May Day concert for affordable housing that erupted into a night of disturbances, the police and parks officials said.

title: Ford Announces Sales Incentives
description: The Ford Motor Company announced new sales incentives for cars and light trucks, with rebates ranging from $500 to $4,000 and financing rates from 6.9 percent to 10.9 percent. The program, in effect until May 31, applies to 20 of Ford's 1990 cars and trucks as well as a 1989 model of the Mercury Tracer and 1988 and 1989 models of the Merkur XR4Ti.

title: Warning on 'Risk-o-Phobia'
description: Budget Director Richard G. Darman said tonight that the United States should not abandon its market economy and economic growth to clean up the environment.

title: 14 Muslim Militants Killed In Clash With Egypt's Police
description: Egyptian paramilitary policemen killed 14 Muslim militants on Monday in a gunfight in which 13 people were also wounded, including 7 policemen, security officials said today.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: EVOLUTION

title: Equipment Is Missing From 2 School Districts
description: Auditors who visited two New York City school districts could not trace thousands of dollars worth of computer equipment, the City Comptroller's office said yesterday.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: RESTAURANTS around the country are taking liberties with the traditional salade nicoise, adding anything from sun-dried tomatoes to sliced potatoes and beets. Dishes that are called ''nicoise'' usually include Provencal products like garlic, olives, anchovies, tomatoes and green beans; salade nicoise usually contains tuna, too.

title: Pistons Sweep the Pacers To Start Defense of Title
description: Isiah Thomas scored 23 points and Bill Laimbeer had 12 points and 19 rebounds tonight to lead the Detroit Pistons over the Indiana Pacers, 108-96, for a three-game sweep in the first round of the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: Lockhart B. McGuire, Cardiologist, 55
description: Dr. Lockhart B. McGuire, a cardiologist and professor of medicine at the University of Virginia School of Medicine, died of colon cancer on Sunday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 55 years old.

title: Blame the Bishops, but Not Public Relations;   No Defense Required
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution in Europe;   What's in a Slogan?
description: The May Day parade in Red Square today was opened to public participation for the first time. Here is a sampling of the official May Day slogans, approved by the Communist Party, and the unofficial slogans shouted by the unofficial demonstrators or appearing on their signs:

title: In Germany: 4 + 2 - 5
description: A year after Hungary opened the gates and set off an East German stampede to the West, diplomats face the reality of German unification. But the talks that begin Saturday among the U.S., the Soviet Union, France and Britain - the four - plus the two Germanys concern the Soviet Union's future in Europe as much as the future of Germany.

title: Panel Warned on Banks
description: A trade group representing the securities industry asked Congress today to assure more protection for bank depositors before allowing banks to further expand into the securities business.

title: Elkington Speaks Up
description: Steve Elkington, who won the Greater Greensboro Open two weeks ago, yesterday disqualified himself from a 21st-place finish last weekend in the USF&G Classic in New Orleans and forfeited $10,000.

title: Trusty, Profitable Jeep Faces New Challenge
description: While the auto-industry sales slump eroded the Chrysler Corporation's overall market share and profitability, the company's Jeep line remained a trusty and profitable product. Jeeps, along with mini-vans, now account for nearly all of the company's automotive profits, some analysts say.

title: St. John's of Many Minds On Sex-Assault Case
description: At a time when college students are usually preoccupied with final examinations and graduation, many at St. John's University in Queens are also focusing on the case of three students who have been accused of sexual assault and suspended from school.

title: British Layoffs Foreseen
description: Thousands of jobs will be cut as British factories struggle to stay competitive in the face of rising costs, the Confederation of British Industry predicted today in its latest survey of industrial companies. Profits are being squeezed by rising labor costs and high interest rates, and domestic demand has been falling, the confederation said.

title: Penny Stock Plan Approval
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has approved a proposal to create an electronic system for trading penny stocks, an official at the regulatory agency said today.

title: Doctors in Brooklyn Developed Crucial Technique
description: As a wounded police officer was bleeding to death from a bullet wound that severed an artery in his neck, doctors at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn inserted a tube in his leg yesterday, guided it to the torn artery and released a coil at the tip of the tube to stop the bleeding.

title: Eating Well
description: THERE are always questions and comments from readers that are of general interest. It is not possible to answer those questions individually, so from time to time they are gathered together to produce a column.

title: Legislative Elections in Bronx Won by Korman and Rosado
description: Jeffrey R. Korman, a Democrat, easily won a special election yesterday in the Bronx for the State Senate seat of Abraham Bernstein, a Democrat, who died in March.

title: 3 Indicted in a Scheme for 'Friars' to Evade Taxes
description: The Church and Order of St. Matthew called its members friars who took a vow of poverty, but a Federal grand jury said yesterday that they were tax cheats.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: IN the back of the lobby of the California Federal Building on the west side of Los Angeles is Panache, where Philippe Marcelis has toiled with little recognition for more than six years, serving foods low in cholesterol, low in fat and without sugar and salt. Nonetheless, he perseveres. ''I believe in it,'' he says.

title: Gerard Schwarz to Open Waterloo's 15th Season
description: The 15th season of music at Waterloo Village in Stanhope, N.J., is to begin on July 7 at 8:30 P.M. with a performance by the Festival Orchestra, conducted by Gerard Schwarz. The program includes David Diamond's Symphony No. 3, Mussorgsky's ''Night on Bald Mountain'' and Rachmaninoff's Concerto No. 2. Alexander Toradze is to be the pianist.

title: Complying With City Charter's Letter and Spirit
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Merrill Executive To Head Reuters Unit
description: Michael O. Sanderson, a former chief of Merrill Lynch-Canada, has been named president and chief executive of the Instinet Corporation, an electronic equities trading operation owned by Reuters Holdings P.L.C. of London.

title: Grants Rule Testimony By Arts Chief
description: Representative Sidney R. Yates, the Chicago Democrat who has been a vigorous champion of the arts, chided the chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts today for his decision to require recipients of endowment grants to sign a pledge that the funds will not be used to produce obscene works of art.

title: Wine Talk
description: THERE have been vines in Volnay, in Burgundy, for a thousand years. Many of the vineyards in Volnay, which lies just two miles south of the city of Beaune, have had the same names for at least 700 years. Les Caillerets, one of the most famous of the Volnay vineyards today, was partly owned by the Knights of Malta in the 13th century.

title: Capitalists and Socialists Both Hurt Environment
description: To the Editor:

title: Hostage Sleight of Hand
description: After celebrating the release of the second hostage in two weeks, President Bush is turning his attention to the delicate diplomatic task of obtaining the freedom of more American captives without breaking his pledge not to negotiate with Iran.

title: Professional Rules Undergo Change
description: For all the television specials, movies and ice shows Brian Boitano has appeared in since winning the men's skating title at the Calgary Olympics two years ago, the opportunity he wanted most was a chance to compete in the Olympics again. Now, he can't. Representatives of the International Skating Union, the world governing body for figure and speed skating, adopted proposals yesterday in Christchurch, New Zealand, that relaxed eligibility rules for skaters who intend to skate professionally, enabling them to return to competition, so long as they gain approval from their national federation.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Jean Marie Gee, 87, Dancer and Teacher
description: Jean Marie Gee, a dance teacher and ballerina who created the title role in Sir Frederick Ashton's ''Pomona,'' died on April 18 at the M. B. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. She was 87 years old.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a proxy fight being waged by the Torchmark Corporation for seats on the board of the American General Corporation referred incorrectly to the company that derives most of its premiums from life and health policies sold primarily in the rural Southeast. It is Torchmark, not American General.

title: Utility Names New Managers
description: Northeast Utilities has appointed a team of senior managers to take over the Public Service Company of New Hampshire, the operator of the long-delayed Seabrook nuclear power plant.

title: U.S. Steel Output Falls
description: Domestic steel production totaled 1,929,000 net tons for the week that ended on Saturday, down 1.3 percent from the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported on Monday. The week's production represented 85.8 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said. Domestic steel production so far this year totals 32,309,000 net tons, 4.4 percent below last year's production at this time, the institute said.

title: Rich and Poor Lands Agree On Path to Economic Growth
description: Rich and poor countries reached agreement today on a declaration setting out new priorities for speeding up economic growth in the developing world in the 1990's after a difficult debate that ran longer than expected.

title: Albert Pyle, 94, Engineer
description: Albert Jocelyn Pyle, an electrical engineer, died of pneumonia on April 25 at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Elsmere, Del. He was 94 years old and had lived in Manhattan most of his life before returning to his native Wilmington, Del., about six years ago.

title: Darling Gives Up 4 Homers to Braves
description: It was distressing on Sunday, ugly on Monday and depressing tonight. The Mets, who have found imaginative ways to lose in the last few days, discovered another one against the lowly Braves this evening.

title: There's a Parody On My Plate!
description: AND now, monsieur and madame, here are today's specials: One neon-blue catfish. One half of a cow. Blackened pork chops, frozen. Fake caviar, 150 gallons of it. A platter of ham bones: no ham; just the bones. Eyeballs on baked potatoes. Nine all-white entrees on all-white plates in an all-white restaurant. Is this Satan's carte du jour? No no no, Mr. Bill. This is the cuisine of ''Saturday Night Live.''

title: Deadline Eased on Order Voiding Sale of a U.S. Company to China
description: The Bush Administration today granted a three-month extension of a Presidential order that voided the sale of a company based in Seattle to a Chinese Government agency with ties to the military, officials said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In Tokyo yesterday, the Imperial Household Agency said PRINCE AYA, the second son of EMPEROR AKIHITO, would marry KIKO KAWASHIMA on June 29.

title: Berkeley Journal;   Finding the Right Dog For a Left-Leaning City
description: In many cities, what comes to mind when people think of a police dog is the kind of animal that becomes the canine equivalent of the business end of a .357 magnum when it bares its teeth.

title: City U.'s Newest Campus Is in Japan
description: The latest campus of the City University of New York sits on a mountaintop in Japan. The branch opened this month in Chiyoda, a suburb about 25 miles southwest of Hiroshima.

title: Rare Beers Of Belgium Find Way To the U.S.
description: WITH names like kriek, framboise, gueuze and trappiste, it's hardly surprising that these highly unusual beers produced by Belgium's 100 active breweries incite equal measures of excitement and confusion among beer lovers.

title: Jerrico Is Selling Restaurant Chains
description: Jerrico Inc. agreed to sell two restaurant chains, Jerry's and Fazoli's, for undisclosed amounts so that it could concentrate on its Long John Silver's Seafood Shoppes. Jerry's has 46 restaurants, mainly in Kentucky and Indiana, and Fazoli's has five restaurants in Kentucky.

title: Review/Music;   19 Avant-Garde Premieres From West German Radio
description: American avant-gardists have always found West German radio open to experimental works, and over the last 10 years several composers have forged strong links to the Westdeutscher Rundfunk, or the West German Broadcasting Network.

title: Report Cites Racial Discrepancies in Medical Care
description: An ethics panel for the nation's largest organization of doctors says that blacks get less frequent, less aggressive medical care than whites in the United States and that the disparities are unacceptable.

title: OPEC Will Meet Today
description: OPEC needs to cut oil production by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day to help crude prices recover from their recent slide, OPEC's president said today as the organization's ministers arrived for an emergency meeting.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: THE warm greetings, big hugs and kisses, souvenirs and, when appropriate, birthday candles on the biscuits are Eunice Merrell's special brand of Alabama hospitality. And it all happens over breakfast.

title: David G. Fernald, 66, Rockefeller Treasurer
description: David G. Fernald, a former treasurer of Rockefeller Family and Associates, died of complications of leukemia on Monday at Mountainside Hospital in Montclair, N.J. He was 66 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: Germany, In NATO Only
description: As the ''2 plus 4'' talks on Germany's future approach, the proposal that a united Germany remain a member of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact is gaining momentum. However ingenious, the proposal is ill-advised both for American interests and European peace.

title: Amgen Has Profit in Period
description: Spurred by sales of its anemia drug, Amgen Inc. today reported substantial sales and earnings. Sold under the name Epogen, erythropoeitin is Amgen's first product approved for sale by the Food and Drug Administration.

title: Citicorp Rates Up for 3d Week
description: Interest rates rose yesterday for the third consecutive week at Citicorp's auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper, following the general rise in rates for most debt securities in the same period.

title: Martin Shwartz, Press Agent, 66
description: Martin Shwartz, a theater press agent for more than 40 years, died of heart failure on Sunday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 66 years old.

title: The Trifle and the Teapot
description: To The Living Section:

title: Everglades Fire Is Contained After Blackening 5,500 Acres
description: A drought-fed brush fire was contained today after it burned 5,500 acres of Everglades grassland, a park spokeswoman said.

title: Hudson's Toxic Striped Bass Disrupt the Season for Shad
description: It is spring and the Hudson River is bursting with striped bass, a species once prized in New York by sportsmen and chefs. But for one band of fishermen, this is bad news.

title: Coalition Seeks to Compel Closing of Armory Shelters
description: Charging that New York City's homeless shelters have deteriorated under Mayor David N. Dinkins and ''are in absolute chaos,'' the Coalition for the Homeless said yesterday that it would ask a state judge to close all shelters in state armories.

title: Yields Put at 9.3% and 9.8% On Offerings by Fannie Mae
description: Two debenture issues by the Federal National Mortgage Association were priced yesterday through a nationwide group of securities dealers.

title: Dow Surprises Some by Rising 12.16 Points
description: Stock prices rose yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 12.16 points, to 2,668.92.

title: U.S. Letting Aides Leave Liberia As Pace of the Rebellion Quickens
description: The United States has suspended the Peace Corps program in Liberia and told American diplomats they and their families could leave the country if they chose as fighting between the Liberian Army and rebel forces increased, the State Department said today.

title: RELEASED HOSTAGE RESTS IN GERMANY
description: Frank Herbert Reed, released from three and a half years of captivity in Beirut, arrived at the United States Air Force hospital here today for a reunion with his wife and son and a big, medium-rare steak.

title: A Call to End Phone Fraud
description: Federal and state officials urged Congress today to expand regulations to combat telemarketing fraud, which costs consumers as much as $1 billion a year.

title: Parent & Child
description: UNTIL they reach the age at which they can get a driver's license, children are notoriously poor travelers. Pastoral scenes, sweeping vistas and art museums interest them far less than gift shops at truck stops.

title: Taiwan's President Chooses General as Prime Minister
description: President Lee Teng-hui picked the country's top military official today to be Prime Minister. Defense Minister Hau Pei-tsun, the country's only four-star general, said he accepted the offer to head the Government at a meeting with the President. General Hau, 71 years old, would replace Lee Huan, 73, in about two weeks.

title: Stake Is Reduced By United Capital
description: The United Capital Corporation, a New York-based real estate concern, has lowered its stake in the General Development Corporation, the bankrupt Miami-based housing developer, to 11 percent, from 12.4 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, United Capital gave no reason for the sale of 144,400 General Development shares for $1.50 to $1.75 a share.

title: Timid, and Destructive, in Albany
description: In a year rich with examples of poor judgment in Albany, for New York's political leaders to agree on a patchwork of nuisance taxes offers the most disappointing and dangerous news yet.

title: Chronicle
description: The Soviet politician BORIS YELTSIN, who had an emergency back operation in Spain earlier this week, was walking yesterday and should be able to leave the hospital within two days, a hospital official said.

title: TBS Plans In-Store Service
description: The Turner Broadcasting System today will announce a new venture with Act Media, an electronic in-store marketing company.

title: Chronicle
description: MARVIN MITCHELSON, the celebrity divorce lawyer, has conceded misconduct in seven allegations involving client relations, but the California bar has dismissed more serious charges involving misappropriation of funds.

title: Sergio Franchi, 57, An Opera Aspirant Who Won Pop Fame
description: Sergio Franchi, a singer with operatic ambitions who gained fame in nightclubs and on recordings, died of a brain tumor on Tuesday at his home in Stonington. He never publicly revealed his age, although some sources list it as 57.

title: Chief Picks Successor At General Housewares
description: John H. Muller Jr., who founded the General Housewares Corporation 23 years ago, announced yesterday that now that he had reached age 65 he was handing over operation of the company to Paul A. Saxton, who will become chief executive effective July 1.

title: No Budget? Dock Officials 878>
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that the governor, lieutenant governor and state legislators should be treated like all other working people - if they are not doing their jobs, they should not get paid.

title: Man Arrested in Virginia in Slaying of Gypsy-Cab Driver in Bronx
description: A 26-year-old man was arrested in Newport News, Va., yesterday and was charged with killing a gypsy-cab driver in the Bronx 11 days ago, the police said.

title: Economy Improving, Data Show
description: Having avoided recession, the economy is gradually picking up strength, with the long-suppressed industrial sector setting the pace, private analysts said today after publication of another batch of Government economic data.

title: Senate Committees And Campaign Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a proposed New York State sales tax referred incorrectly to an industry that would be affected. It is janitorial cleaning services, not dry cleaning.

title: Greyhound and Union Agree on New Talks
description: Greyhound Lines Inc. and the union representing its striking drivers agreed today to hold contract talks this week, for the first time in more than a month.

title: Edgardo Contini, 76, California Architect
