description: Edgardo Contini, a California architect and urban designer, died of cancer on Saturday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 76 years old.

title: Vestar Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lincoln Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: National Pizza Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: The company said that Skipper's, acquired on Nov. 26, 1989, contributed revenues of $27,166,000 toward latest year figures.

title: New Loews Chairman Held 'Ideally Qualified'
description: A. Alan Friedberg, a longtime member of the motion picture theater industry, has been named chairman of the Loews Theater Management Company, a unit of Columbia Pictures Entertainment.

title: Elzbieta and Auschwitz
description: Auschwitz.

title: Southern Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Futuristic Fun House For a New Times Square
description: NOW that the redevelopment of Times Square appears to be moving ahead, 1 Times Square, that wedge-shaped tower at 42d Street and Broadway, may be supplanted by a new building.

title: Calendar of Events: From Baskets to Jewelry
description: Park Avenue Crafts, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street; 212-686-2291.

title: Jacor Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Brazil and Argentina Seeking Aid
description: Despite a backlog of more than $11 billion in interest owed to commercial bankers, Brazil and Argentina will be negotiating for new official aid when the International Monetary Fund and World Bank meet in Washington next week.

title: U.S. SEEKS TO EASE TECHNOLOGY SALES IN EASTERN EUROPE
description: The Bush Administration today proposed a relaxation of restrictions on the export of advanced technological products to the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, including computers, precision machine tools and telecommunications equipment.

title: Koger Properties reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Urban AIDS Trouble Spots Found
description: A nationwide study of hospital patients suggests that one of every four men 25 to 44 years old in the area served by a northern New Jersey hospital is infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Total Energold reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: North Hills Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
All Forgiven, Jamaican Will See Bush Today
description: When he visits the White House on Thursday, Prime Minister Michael N. Manley will be welcomed as a friend of Vice President Dan Quayle and a partner of the Bush Administration.

title: Trimedyne reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $300,000 reserve for potentially excess inventory resulting from declining sales levels. c-Net income

title: 'Twin Peaks' Freaks
description: Is there an overbooked restaurant you've been longing to get into? Try tonight around 9. Lots of folks will be staying home to watch ''Twin Peaks,'' the program ABC hopes will pull it ahead in the ratings race. ''Twin Peaks,'' from the film maker David Lynch, who favors slow pacing, odd lighting and hypnotic music, has been hailed as revolutionary TV. It has become, in any case, a phenomenon.

title: World's Legislators Urge 'Marshall Plan' For the Environment
description: Legislators from 42 countries called today for a ''global Marshall plan'' under which industrial nations would help less developed countries grow economically while still protecting the environment.

title: Akorn Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Homicide Rate Figures Paint Lurid Picture
description: To the Editor:

title: Plum Creek Timber reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures for 1989 are not available. The company was spun off as a separate, publicly traded company from Burlington Resources Inc. in June 1989. Results included depreciation and amortization costs of $9,189,000. The company said income per unit figures included 14,352,500 units diluted by 1,250,000 deferred participation interests.

title: Cambior Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Personal Health
description: The problems may have cute names, like housemaid's knee, trigger finger, tailor's seat and tennis elbow, but the discomfort and the inconvenience they can cause are anything but cute. At times, in fact, the pain can be so bad that the sufferer may be unwilling or unable to move the affected joint.

title: Kodak Profit Down by 6.1%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the big photographic products and chemicals company that has been streamlining its organization, said today that its first-quarter earnings fell 6.1 percent.

title: Scientist Who Managed to 'Shock the World' on Atomic Workers' Health
description: It was in September 1975 that Dr. Alice Stewart, a 68-year-old British epidemiologist, first saw statistical evidence that radiation was killing workers at the Hanford nuclear weapons plant in Washington State.

title: Dentist Draws Prison in Burglaries But Is Freed Pending an Appeal
description: A Brooklyn dentist convicted of participating in three burglaries to support her heroin habit was sentenced to 1 1/2 to 4 1/2 years in prison yesterday.

title: Brazil Blows Up Miners' Airstrip, Pressing Its Drive to Save Indians
description: Launching an operation to destroy 110 airstrips built by gold miners in Indian lands, Brazilian Army explosives experts dynamited a dirt strip in the northern Amazon jungle today.

title: Virco Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included income from an accounting adjustment of $338,000 and $895,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and losses from discontinued operations of $216,000 and $873,000 for the same periods, respectively; and an extraordinary loss of $1,307,000 for both periods. c-Included losses from discountinued operations of $408,000 and $908,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $421,000 for both periods. d-Net income The extraordinary item is a loss on sale of the company's juvenile furniture business.

title: Crown Crafts reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split distributed Jan. 11, 1990.

title: Burmese Rights Abuses Are Said to Continue
description: Amnesty International has charged in a report that ''severe human rights violations'' have continued to be frequent in Myanmar, formerly Burma, under the current military Government.

title: Mechanical Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $412,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $671,000, or 19 cents a share, for the 6 months; the 6 months also included $286,000 related to accounting adjustment. c-Net income

title: Derlan Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,311,000, or 7 cents a share. The company said in the latest quarter, it had a gain on the sale of its subsidiary, Brite Vue Glass Systems Inc., of $1,311,000, net of income taxes of $596,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mitsubishi Buying Control Of U.S. Rental Car Concern
description: The Mitsubishi Motors Corporation plans to acquire a controlling interest in Value Rent-A-Car Inc., making Mitsubishi the first Japanese auto maker to buy an equity interest in an American car rental company.

title: Pro-Rebel Ship Nears China
description: The Goddess of Democracy, the converted trawler from which pro-democracy campaigners intend to broadcast into China, arrived today for provisions. The 1,200-ton ship, which sailed from France after being outfitted, is to be positioned in international waters off the Taiwanese coast, said Christophe Nick, a French journalist and an organizer. The Beijing Government has refused to rule out the use of force to stop the planned broadcasts.

title: Review/Theater;   Warm and Defiant in a Nuclear Winter
description: In Y York's futuristic comedy, ''Rain. Some Fish. No Elephants.,'' genetic engineering has produced a submissive nation of clones and drones. Everything is gene coded so that all individuality can be obliterated, except for one stubbornly old-fashioned family trying to thaw the perpetual nuclear winter. That winter is actually an endless floodlike rainy season.

title: Pacificare Health Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
House Panel Stalls on Member's Conduct
description: The House ethics committee, which has met periodically for the last seven months on the case of Representative Barney Frank, appears to have reached an impasse over how to deal with his involvement with a male prostitute.

title: LACROSSE: Notebook;   Victory Might Change Coach's Plans
description: Dick Garber has been the lacrosse coach at Massachusetts for 36 years, and he is supposed to retire after this season's last game, which will be Sunday. But if his team can win then, it may not be his last game.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   'thirtysomething' Brings Fame to Another O'Neill
description: Kevin B. O'Neill may be the creative director of Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners, but he is not the only creative member of his family, nor the only one with a grasp of advertising. His brother Hugh, a former editor at Times Books, a Random House imprint, wrote the script for Tuesday's episode of the ABC television series ''thirtysomething.'' In the show, Elliot Weston, the bearded ad agency art director, is given his first crack at directing a commercial.

title: Merchants Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Evolution in Europe;   BUSH IS READYING AN ARMS INITIATIVE
description: President Bush is set to announce an arms-control initiative that would accelerate talks on short-range nuclear weapons based in Europe and remove at least some nuclear artillery from the Continent, senior Administration officials said today.

title: CNA Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed the decrease in earnings to a drop in realized investment gains. The company said that for the 1990 first quarter net realized investment gains were $6 million, compared to $36.2 million in the year-ago period.

title: St. John's Head Defends Handling of a Sex Case
description: The president of St. John's University yesterday defended the way the school handled a woman's complaint of sexual assault by a group of students and said the university's reputation should not be sullied by allegations against a few people.

title: First Federal S&L Assn of S.C.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Furniture Designed by and for Children
description: Michael Johnson, an 8-year-old designer, has some passionate thoughts about furniture. ''Most parents won't let their babies near furniture, because they don't want it spilled on. I don't think that's very fair.''

title: Indiana Energy Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Guilin Journal;   China's Arms Wide Open for Army From Taiwan
description: For years, Chinese have treated Western visitors to a glimpse of the Li River, which spills through a landscape of jutting mountains and misty skies that have inspired poets and painters for centuries.

title: Albany Budget Talks Now Mired In Suburb-City School Aid Battle
description: After a month of delay, negotiations over a new state budget appear to have devolved into a regional battle over school aid that pits Democratic legislators from New York City against Republican lawmakers from the suburbs.

title: Talking Deals;   Wariness at USX Over Icahn Moves
description: THE latest maneuver by the financier Carl C. Icahn in his effort to urge the management of the USX Corporation to separate its steel and energy operations has drawn skepticism from more than a few few investors.

title: Wilander Holds Out
description: Mats Wilander of Sweden, the former No. 1 men's singles player in the world, said yesterday at a news conference in Stockholm he would pass up this month's French Open, which he has won three times, and probably not play this summer at Wimbledon. Wilander, who has dropped out of the top 10 ranking, has not played competitively since March and will not be in condition to compete in Paris at the end of the month. ''I need at least two or three weeks' hard training to compete,'' said Wilander. ''After that, 15 to 20 matches are needed to reach peak form.''(AP)

title: OPEC's Talks Hit a Snag
description: OPEC ministers ran into roadblocks today in their emergency talks to cut oil output, delaying efforts to reduce a surplus in the market and support prices.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Students in the Science of Love
description: ''Basic Dating,'' one of the wittier sketches in the new comedy revue ''Love Lemmings,'' imagines an amatory boot camp where young singles are mercilessly drilled in the dos and don'ts of courtship.

title: Mitek Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Marc 31
A Way to Pressure Beijing
description: LEAD: President Bush is doubtless hoping that the final moments of his summit meeting with Mikhail Gorbachev on June 3 will distract Americans from the first anniversary of Tiananmen Square - and his Administration's failed China policy. But even Mr. Gorbachev's visit will not eclipse the fact that exactly one year after the People's Liberation Army massacred hundreds of peaceful demonstrators, Mr.

title: Home Improvement
description: ALUMINUM siding requires no maintenance to prolong its life. But to keep it looking its best, many manufacturers recommend washing siding twice a year, and more often in areas with severe air pollution. Naturally, damaged siding should be promptly repaired. For washing, a hard spray from a garden hose is usually sufficient.

title: Lee Sievan; Photographer, 82
description: Lee Sievan, a photographer, died of a cerebral hemorrhage on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan. She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: New York Nuclear Accident Outlook Worsens
description: To the Editor:

title: For Children, Tips On Rescuing Planet
description: Children hear about the problems all the time: the greenhouse effect, oil spills, acid rain. But do children understand what it all means? Not really, say the publishers of a new environmental magazine for children.

title: Lifetime Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
LCS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $42,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $66,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net income Results included writeoffs for the latest periods of $10,500 for the quarter, and $259,400 for the 6 months, related to the closing of a division.

title: New Charge for Umpire
description: Bob Engel, the National League umpire suspended indefinitely after being accused of stealing baseball cards from a Target store in Bakersfield, Calif., on April 21, faces a new charge of trying to shoplift cards from another store in Bakersfield, his hometown. The umpire pleaded not guilty on Tuesday to misdemeanor counts of stealing seven boxes containing 4,180 Score baseball cards from the Target store and of attempting to steal 50 packs of baseball cards from Costco in January. A pretrial hearing in Municipal Court in Bakersfield was scheduled for May 25.

title: Diamond Sales Outlook
description: Diamonds are headed for an eighth consecutive year of record sales, the world's biggest producer, De Beers Consolidated Mines Ltd., said today. The South African-based company's chairman, Julian Ogilvie Thompson, said that world retail sales rose 4 percent in 1989 in terms of United States dollars. Growth was particularly strong last year in Europe, where economies were buoyant, and in Japan, where a tax concession on jewelry purchases helped to increase sales. In the United States, the world's largest market for polished diamonds, growth was modest because of an easing in economic activity, Mr. Ogilvie Thompson told thr De Beers shareholders.

title: Hartford Shifts Revenue in Move to Adopt Budget
description: The General Assembly today moved toward adoption of a $7.05 billion budget that would solve the state's financial problems for the next year by using a series of short-term infusions of tax revenue, postponed payments to the state pension plan and shifts in budget accounting.

title: Keating Describes U.S. Seizure
description: Testimony at the court hearing on the challenge by Charles H. Keating Jr. of the Government's seizure of his Lincoln Savings and Loan ended today with Mr. Keating reasserting that his company had been unfairly put in default by the Government.

Chateau Stores reports earnings for Year to Jan 27

description: An article on Tuesday about Kaunas, Lithuania's second city, reversed the sequence of the Soviet annexation of Lithuania and the Nazi invasion of the republic. The annexation was in 1940 and the invasion in 1941.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: John C. Willey, the former editor in chief of William Morrow & Company, died of pneumonia on April 27 at Southwest Washington Medical Center in Vancouver, Wash., where he had lived for six years. He was 75 years old and had undergone surgery for a bleeding gastric ulcer.

title: In the Age of Astrodecor, Any Night Can Be Starry
description: LEAD: THE sun, moon and stars may be the world's longest-running decorating theme. And now they seem to rising again in the American home, along with telescopes, astrolabes, globes and all the other paraphernalia of celestial and terrestrial scanning and measuring.

His resignation came after the company's board of directors in New York City voted to establish a nine-member operating committee for the Joffrey, which faces a deficit of about $2 million.

description: Tim Leary did everything a starting pitcher is supposed to do last night, giving his team a good opportunity to win. But Leary could only pitch for the Yankees, not hit. Unfortunately for the right-hander, neither could his teammates, as the Yankees once again went quietly, losing to the Oakland A's, 2-0.

title: A Clash of Nonopposites: Bruins and the Capitals

title: Review/Jazz;   Mary Lou Williams Tribute
description: The unflagging influence of Mary Lou Williams through five decades of jazz, from the 1930's until her death in 1981, was summarized brilliantly by the American Jazz Orchestra in a concert at Cooper Union on Friday evening. The program featured arrangements from the repertories of the Artie Shaw and Bunny Berigan orchestras, and Ms. Williams's arrangements and compositions for Andy Kirk's orchestra in the 1930's. Her participation in the be-bop movement in the 40's and the free jazz movement of the 60's showed a consistent creative involvement on the cutting edge of jazz that sets her apart from musicians and groups that could work comfortably in only a single area of jazz.

Amtrak officials said that 27 people were taken to a local hospital and that all but three were treated and released.

His work took him to 69 countries to disseminate information about agricultural innovations.

title: Q&A
description: An Inside Vapor Barrier Q.Our house was built in 1921 with tongue-and-groove and clapboard siding, and with blown-in cellulose insulation in the walls. I am having vinyl siding and an insulating barrier installed on the outside, and since there is no vapor barrier on the inside of these walls I am concerned about moisture being trapped in the hollow wall spaces. What do you think? A.Lack of a vapor barrier could cause problems, but you can solve this by covering the inner faces of outside walls with a vapor barrier paint like the one made by Glidden. Or you can apply a wall covering that will act as a vapor barrier; most vinyl and foil wall coverings are good vapor barriers.

The job keeps him out of jail under a work-release program, and for the moment he is speaking more like a social worker than a rock star.

description: Following are excerpts from statements today by President F. W. de Klerk and Nelson Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, at the start of talks on political change in South Africa. The official translation was used for the parts of Mr. de Klerk's remarks uttered in Afrikaans. Mr. Mandela also spoke part of the time in Afrikaans, but those remarks are not excerpted here.

title: 5 White Supremacists Draw Prison Terms for Hate Crimes
description: Five members of the Confederate Hammerskins, a group of white supremacist ''skinheads,'' were sentenced by a Federal district judge today to prison terms ranging from 4 to almost 10 years for conspiring to violate the civil rights of minorities.

title: Everything About the Holocaust
description: ''Encyclopedia of the Holocaust'' is monumental in two respects: because of its subject and because of its sheer size, 1,905 pages.

title: Feud Over Futures Trading
description: Top Federal regulators continued a bitter public battle today over which agency should control futures trading in a new breed of financial products.

title: Macy's Expects 5th Straight Deficit
description: In what will be its fifth straight quarterly deficit, R. H. Macy & Company will report a loss for the quarter ended April 28, but it will be lower than the $64 million deficit it had in the period the year before, Macy's has told investors in its 1986 leveraged buyout.

title: Senators Seek Military Budget Leaner Than Bush's
description: After weeks of dispute, the Senate Budget Committee today approved a $1.2 trillion budget for 1991 that cuts $21 billion more from the Pentagon than President Bush has recommended.

title: Wheelabrator Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fabricland Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings reflected 20 percent dividend declared in December 1989.

title: Review/Television;   Brotherly Competition At a Fledgling Airline
description: With all of the fuss about ABC's ''Twin Peaks,'' there has been precious little attention left over for a new NBC sitcom called ''Wings,'' which is running directly opposite ''Twin Peaks'' on Thursdays at 9:30 and is quietly chalking up a far more impressive ratings record. Of course, it helps enormously that ''Wings'' immediately follows ''Cheers,'' one of NBC's most popular series. And, as it happens, the new show has been created by three Emmy Award-winning former ''Cheers'' staffers: David Angell, Peter Casey and David Lee, all producers and writers. They are the executive producers of ''Wings.''

title: North Stars Near Deal
description: Howard Baldwin, a founder of the Hartford Whalers, and Morris Belzberg have reached an agreement to buy the Minnesota North Stars from George and Gordon Gund and will keep the team in Minnesota. Baldwin would not give details, except to say that the deal was subject to National Hockey League approval at the meeting of the league's board of governors in Chicago next Tuesday.(AP)

title: Rally's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $68,000, or 2 cents a share, and $342,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Figures for 1989 have been restated to include results from the franchised restaurants which were acquired in October.

title: South Africans Open Black-White Talks
description: The South African Government today opened its first formal talks with the African National Congress, which has been struggling since 1912 to rid the country of white minority domination.

title: Student Sues SUNY on Frog Dissection
description: Jennifer Routh did not protest the dissection of the spinach plant and the sea urchin in her introductory biology class last fall. But when her professor said the dissection of a frog was required and would not offer an alternative, Ms. Routh, a sophomore at the State University here, sued.

title: Cognex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Florida Rock Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-The company said that second quarter operating results were generally comparable to year-ago results, except for a one-time expense of $1,160,000 from an early retirement program at Arundle, a wholly owned subsidiary. The decreases in sales and profits for the 6 months were primarily attributed to the bad weather in December.

title: Long Talks to Rams
description: With contract terms reportedly agreed upon between the Los Angeles Rams and Chuck Long, the Rams are now believed close to working out a trade for the backup quarterback from the Detroit Lions, said Jim Mills, an attorney in Boulder, Colo., who is Long's agent. The deal for Long, 27 years old, whose contract expired at the end of last season, was supposed to be an $850,000, two-year agreement, according to The Detroit Free Press, which quoted an unidentified source as saying that the Lions would receive a third-round draft choice as compensation.(AP)

title: Three-Five Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter net and share-earnings results do not reflect results of operations of outstanding shares of the recently acquired Electronics Research Associates, which will be reflected in operating results beginning May 1, the effective merger date.

title: Charles D. Ewart, Ex-Football Official, 74
description: Charles D. Ewart, the general manager of the Philadelphia Eagles when they won their first National Football League championship in 1948, died on Monday after a long illness. He was 74 years old.

title: GTI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dawson's Hits Pull Cubs Past Giants, 9-6
description: Andre Dawson extended his hitting streak to 11 games today with 3 hits and 3 runs batted in, powering the Chicago Cubs to a 9-6 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

title: Providence & Worcester Rail reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Revenues for 1988 included $4,339,000 related to a condemnation award.

title: Musburger Signs Contract With ABC
description: One month after his final assignment for CBS-TV Sports, the final game of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, Brent Musburger was hired yesterday by ABC Sports.

title: Dutch Unit of Ford Makes U.S. Offering
description: Ford Capital B.V., a Netherlands-based company created in the last six months by the Ford Motor Company to gain access to world capital markets, is making its first offering in the United States.

title: Corporate Relocations
description: Dallas and Houston were the two top cities for corporate relocations in 1989, as cheaper costs made the Southwest an attractive destination, according to a study of 37,000 corporate moves by PHH Homequity. New York slipped to fourth place from second last year, and Chicago slipped to fifth place from third.

title: Highland Superstores reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included pre-tax restructuring charge of $16.5 million, which equaled $8,935,000, after tax, for the quarter and year. c-Net income

title: Topics of The Times;   Bronx Bonfire
description: Finding himself in a perfect position to play to the crowd - a Bronx crowd - Mayor David Dinkins of New York City has instead chosen statesmanship. The issue involves the filming of ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' the Tom Wolfe novel, which is none too complimentary toward either the Bronx or the city as a whole. Borough President Fernando Ferrer accuses the film makers of Bronx-bashing. He even insisted they add a pro-Bronx disclaimer. Nothing doing, said Mr. Dinkins. Mindful of film-making's contribution to the city's economy, the Mayor sent a statement to film industry trade papers saying that ''any attempt to influence the artistic content of the work of others, however minor, would be repugnant.'' The city wants to encourage production, ''not to participate in script review or alteration,'' he said; while Mr. Ferrer is entitled to his opinions, the Borough President does not speak for the city.

title: Santa Anita Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. and Soviets on New Tack In Effort to End Afghan War
description: The United States and the Soviet Union are exploring a new approach to ending the Afghan conflict, under which Moscow would accept elections to choose a new government and Washington would let the current leader, Najibullah, run for president if he first surrendered power.

title: An Insider Conviction Is Overturned on Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday overturned the conviction of a stockbroker who had been charged with trading on non-public information, saying it amounted to little more than gossip.

title: Economy Will Miss Cash Paid in Thrifts Bailout
description: To the Editor:

title: Outlook for G.O.P.: Senate Gains in '90, A Showdown in '92
description: As Senate races shape up around the country, officials in both parties say Republicans are bucking the usual trend in midterm elections: they are in good position to pick up several seats this fall and narrow the gap with Democrats.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of New England Corp., Boston, a bank holding company, appointed John C. Martin executive vice president responsible for technology and operations, and head of the bank's corporate information systems group, BNE Information Services Co.

title: NL Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included about $11 million in pretax expenses associated with NL's proxy battle for control of Lockheed Corp.'s board. c-Included a tax credit of $2,800,000, or 4 cents a share, and a $8.5 million pretax gain from sale of a unit.

title: Freed U.S. Hostage Tells of Four Others
description: Frank Herbert Reed, the American hostage freed in Beirut on Monday, said today that he was held for months at a time with at least four other Westerners, including two Americans, and that he was angry they had not been released.

title: Wounded Officer Listed in Stable Condition
description: The condition of Police Officer Harold Ortiz, who the police said was shot in the neck early Tuesday by a man he had stopped for driving the wrong way on a one-way street, was upgraded to stable from critical yesterday.

title: Corby Distillieries reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain on sale of Robert Macnish & Co. subsidiary of $4,809,000, or 69 cents a share. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $8,005,000, or $1.16 a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Singular Auction: Sad Sale of Upbeat Memories
description: Justin Ross had a singular sensation yesterday: he discovered that his old costume still fits, the shiny gold one he wore 14 years ago when he took his place in ''A Chorus Line.''

title: Independent Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue represented premium revenue.

title: Germanys Expect Joint Team by '92
description: The political developments bringing West Germany and East Germany together are occurring so rapidly, it now appears certain the countries will have a combined Olympic team by 1992, the next Olympic year.

title: Maritrans Partners L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chronicle
description: A man who is accused of sending threatening letters to GEORGE HARRISON was arrested yesterday, the police in London said. The 47-year-old former Beatle received the letters at his mansion in Friar Park near Henley, about 35 miles west of London, where he lives with his wife and son.

title: Washington Talk;   Bailout Chief's Future Stirs Debate on Process
description: The day after the White House said that while it wasn't pushing, it wouldn't stop L. William Seidman from jumping, the question in town is: Why now? Isn't this the time to hold on to Mr. Seidman, who is not only head of the savings and loan bailout, but perhaps its most credible spokesman?

title: Tuckahoe Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

Belvedere Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter's net income and share earnings showed break-even results. Year-ago results included the company's Bermuda subsidiaries, which were sold in December 1989. Year-ago revenues included revenues of $6,920,000 from Bermuda subsidiaries. The company said net investment income for the latest quarter increased to $1,518,000 from $1,126,000 (excluding $1,404,000 from the Bermuda subsidiaries) in the year-ago quarter.

title: Unocal to Buy Energy Tracts
description: The Unocal Corporation said today that a subsidiary, Union Exploration Partners Ltd., had agreed to acquire a crude oil and natural gas subsidiary of Placer Dome Inc. in a deal valued at $336 million.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising
description: NOT long ago, Alan J. Gottesman, an advertising analyst for Paine Webber Inc., was musing about the agencies best positioned for global expansion. A list of the public advertising companies he studies was proffered. Mr. Gottesman gave a noncommittal shrug, and then with a sly smile said, ''You guys always forget'' about a private agency he does not analyze: TBWA.

title: Chronicle
description: OSKAR LAFONTAINE, the West German opposition's candidate for Chancellor almost killed in an assassination attempt last week, left a hospital in Cologne on Wednesday, and his doctors recommended that he give campaigning a rest, Reuters said.

description: b-Included writeoff of $19.4 million from the recent New Mexico Public Service Commission decision on the company's electric rate case. c-Net income

title: Not Enough Plants? How to Have More
description: EVERYONE loves to get something for nothing, and gardeners can: plants are easily multiplied in many ways since each plant cell has the potential of developing a whole new self.

title: G.M. Units Had Mixed First Period
description: Military spending cuts and a sharp drop in demand for automotive components reduced first-quarter profits by 15.8 percent for the GM Hughes Electronics Corporation, the military and electronics subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation's said today.

title: Asia Bank Chief Sees 90's Challenge
description: The president of the Asian Development Bank warned today that the political and economic changes in Eastern Europe may divert attention from this region throughout the 1990's, forcing Asians to rely on their own momentum for further growth.

title: Bush Pays Additional $7,497 In Amending His Tax Return
description: President Bush had to pay an additional $7,497 in Federal income taxes today in correcting an error in the reporting of his 1989 income, said his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater.

title: Prices Are Mixed in Light Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday. The Government released a number of economic reports, but they were in line with market expectations, as was the size of the quarterly refunding auctions announced by the Treasury.

title: Six, the Magic Number
description: In the unlikely but not impossible event that the Democrats lose control of the Senate this year, they'd do well if they gave up only five seats, no more, no less. That would result in a party tie at 50-50, and give the Republicans control only by virtue of Vice President Quayle's tie-breaking vote.

description: Shares earnings are fully diluted.

description: b-Net loss Latest quarter figures included $2,550,000 in costs related to legal and other matters at the ompany's consumer and professional products group. Year-ago quarter figures included $60,000 of such costs. Latest 9 months included $2,935,000 of these costs from the group, while year-ago period included $885,000 of the costs. The latest 9 months also included a gain of $10 million from Grow Group's the sale of its U.S. Paints division and a gain of $680,000 related to the sale of its Polymer Technology.

title: C.P. Shareholders Back Stock Plan
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd. said its shareholders had overwhelmingly approved a proposal to spin off 80 percent of its Marathon Realty Company into a separate company. Under the plan, C.P. is offering one Marathon share for every four C.P. shares, for a total issue of 79 million shares.

title: I.B.M. Investment In Valid Noted
description: Valid Logic Systems Inc. said the International Business Machines Corporation would acquire a minority equity interest in Valid, a developer of integrated electronic design-automation software. Under the agreement, I.B.M. would make an initial investment of $11.2 million in the form of newly issued voting convertible preferred stock representing an interest in Valid of between 5 percent and 8.3 percent.

title: Mormons Drop Rites Opposed by Women
description: The Mormon Church has changed some of its most sacred rituals, eliminating parts of the largely secret ceremonies that have been viewed as offensive to women and to members of some other faiths.

title: Review/Theater;   A Comedy From London Reopens With Changes
description: Richard Nelson's ''Some Americans Abroad,'' which reopened last night on the main stage in the Vivian Beaumont Theater, remains a felicitous comedy about the American penchant for all things English. Mr. Nelson is scathing in his satire, mocking arrogant intellectuals as well as pence-pinching tourists (same people).

title: Threatened Democratic Senate Seats
description: RHODE ISLAND - Both parties call this a top battleground. Representative Claudine Schneider, a Republican whose district covers half the state, , is almost as well known as Senator Claiborne Pell, who has held the seat since 1961. His chairmanship of the Foreign Relations Committee is of less interest to Rhode Islanders than the condition of their schools and roads. Polls show Ms. Schneider within striking distance, running strongly among women.

title: Commodore International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Alliance Capital Management reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are in units. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Suns Gain Playoff Edge
description: Kevin Johnson shook off a lingering case of intestinal flu, scoring 16 of his 29 points in the third period as the Phoenix Suns beat the Utah Jazz, 120-105, tonight and took a 2-1 lead in their first-round playoff.

title: Indian Reservation Sealed Off After 2 Killings
description: Hundreds of New York and Canadian police officers sealed off this Mohawk reservation on the St. Lawrence River today after violence left two Mohawks dead and forced thousands of others to barricade themselves in their homes or flee.

title: 4th-Grade Lament: 'Everyone's Dating'
description: BETSY DAVIS knew she would be having this conversation with her elder son one day. After all, it goes with the job of being a parent.

description: Is Household International Inc. headed for a big fall?

title: Reviews/Dance;   Something for Everyone In City Ballet's 'Coppelia'
description: ''Coppelia'' is one of the sunniest ballets in the New York City Ballet repertory, and it received a bright and bounding performance on Saturday afternoon at the New York State Theater.

title: Soviet Racer Seems Man to Beat in Tour de Trump
description: You look at Vyacheslav Ekimov's cycling credentials and you wonder if they belong to one man or a team or a nation.

title: SECURITY IS TIGHT IN INDIA'S CAPITAL
description: A series of bus bombings and mysterious fires over the last few weeks has led to the imposition of new public security measures in the Indian capital.

description: The American General Corporation's chairman and chief executive, Harold S. Hook, told shareholders and employees today that the company appeared to have turned back a proxy challenge by the Torchmark Corporation, then stunned them by saying that it would, nevertheless, put itself up for sale.

title: Simon Group Gets Aid For Savings Institution
description: A group headed by William E. Simon, the former Treasury Secretary, said today that it had raised $50 million from a private investor to bolster the financial strength of one of its savings institutions.

title: Kansas City Life Insurance Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Runaway Car Hits 5, Killing Girl in Midtown
description: A 3-year-old girl was killed and four other people were hit yesterday afternoon by a speeding sedan that careered through a midtown Manhattan intersection, mounted two sidewalks and sent hundreds of pedestrians running for cover, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: U.S.-Mexico Drug Effort to Continue
description: The Attorney General of Mexico said today that his Government would continue cooperative narcotics-control efforts with the United States, despite tensions caused by the capture of a Mexican doctor brought to the United States to face charges of aiding in the killing of an American drug agent in 1985.

title: States Are Criticized Over Insurance for the Elderly
description: In a dispute over what he called ''outrageous practices'' involving the sale of long-term-care insurance to the elderly, a Congressional chairman contended today that most state insurance commissioners were ineffective because they were ''understaffed and under-informed.''

title: Eyeglasses to Fit Any Need or Taste
description: PEOPLE with large heads or very fine features often have trouble finding eyeglass frames that fit properly. Some adults have bridges so small that only children's glasses will fit, said Joel Name, a Manhattan optician who has been designing frames for 18 years.

title: Futures Trader Fined
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said a futures trader had agreed to a $50,000 fine and a six-month suspension of floor privileges to settle charges of a significant trading offense. The exchange said in a statement on Tuesday that the trader, Lloyd D. Gabbert, had directed the proceeds last October of certain trades of stock index futures into two accounts, improperly creating a loss in one and a profit in the other. The Merc said Mr. Gabbert had agreed to the penalty while neither admitting nor denying the allegation.

title: The Question Al Bianchi Hates to Hear
description: While the Knicks struggled to earn a reprieve last night in the National Basketball Association playoffs, their general manager, Al Bianchi, struggled to comprehend why anybody would wonder if his contract would be renewed for next season.

title: SNC Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Mexico Plans To Privatize Bank System
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari sent the Mexican Congress a constitutional amendment today that would reprivatize the country's banking system, which has been in state hands since 1982, and allow private interests to set up new financial institutions.

title: Middleby Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter's sales rose largely due to the July 1989 acquisition of Hussman Corp.'s foodservice equipment group.

title: Zenith National Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: This year's first quarter net is after a loss after taxes of $1.7 million associated with reinsurance of storm damage in Europe.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Omnicom Net Up 21%
description: The Omnicom Group, whose holdings include BBDO Worldwide, DDB Needham Worldwide, Diversified Agency Services and Tracy-Locke, said its net income for the first quarter rose 21 percent over the period last year. Omnicom reported a net income of $10.8 million, or 40 cents a share, on revenues of $274.3 million for the period that ended on March 31. For the 1989 period, its net income was $9 million, or 34 cents a share, on revenues of $226.2 million. Omnicom also said it would seek to have its common stock listed on the New York Stock Exchange. It is now traded over the counter.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Our ultimate goal is a new, democratic dispensation for South Africa and all its people.

description: A House subcomittee has decided to offer the ''junk bond'' financier Michael R. Milken, who admitted he illegally manipulated financial markets, immunity from prosecution so that he will testify before Congress, a panel staff member said today.

title: Kentucky Derby;   Summer Squall Is Undersized Overachiever
description: If the Kentucky Derby were a beauty contest instead of a horse race, Summer Squall would be the 100-1 long shot Saturday instead of the 7-5 favorite.

description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: U.S. Approves Test to Screen Blood for Hepatitis C
description: The Food and Drug Administration today approved a test to screen the nation's blood supply for the major remaining source of hepatitis infections related to blood transfusions.

description: President Bush's new arms control proposals for Europe were a bow to the inevitable, intended to hold together a Western alliance and avert the possibility that NATO could lose its primacy as the Continent's binding political and military force.

title: Dixie Yarns reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tribune Chief To Step Down
description: Stanton Cook said today that he would step down as chief executive of the Tribune Company, which publishes The Daily News in New York, The Chicago Tribune and other newspapers.

title: The Involuntary Heroes
description: Ignore for a moment the vexed question of how best to free the 16 remaining Western hostages in Lebanon. What sears the conscience is the drawn face and the unselfish anger of Frank Herbert Reed after three and a half years of captivity.

description: Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks rose 2.4 percent in the last 10 days of April, compared with a year earlier, the auto makers reported today.

title: Film Schedule
description: The Museum of Modern Art section of the series Internal Exile: New Films and Videos From Chile runs today through Monday. All the films have English subtitles. Tickets to screenings are included in the price of museum admission: $6 ($3.50 for students, $3 for the elderly). Information: 708-9490. A free video program, featuring seven short pieces, will be shown May 11 and 12 at Exit Art, 578 Broadway, near Prince Street. Information: 966-7745 or 947-9277. Here is a schedule for the film festival at the museum (11 West 53d Street).

title: Metro Datelines;  $1 Million in Art Taken From Gallery
description: Five bandits wearing ski masks stole more than $1 million in art from a Soho gallery early yesterday. Three were later arrested.

title: BUSH NAMES CHOICE TO SUCCEED CHIEF OF SAVINGS RESCUE
description: President Bush said today that he wanted William Taylor, the Federal Reserve Board's top banking regulator, to succeed L. William Seidman as head of the Government's savings and loan bailout when Mr. Seidman steps down.

title: Cenvill Investors Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included provision for losses of $8,250,000 and a gain on sale of a shopping center of $5,976,000, or 87 cents a share. c-Net income

title: Dickerson Seeks Team
description: Eric Dickerson said yesterday that he did not want to play for the Indianapolis Colts but that he did want to play in the National Football League this year.

title: Western Publishing Group reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: Results for 1989 are for the fourth quarter and year ended Jan. 28, 1989.

title: The Sound of the Middle Ages, Through Research and Intuition
description: ''We have no way of knowing how close our sound is to the sound and technique of Middle Ages,'' said Johanna Rose, one of the sopranos in Anonymous 4, a vocal quartet that specializes in medieval music. ''But there is a sizable difference between the way we sing and the way opera singers sing. And if you listen to singers from other traditions, you hear entirely different kinds of sounds. We are open to those differences. We like knowing that there are many viable ways to use the voice. We don't always have to sound like opera singers.''

title: Washington Post Co. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Ex-Nazi Is Sent to Germany In Extradition by Argentina
description: Josef Schwammberger was returned to West Germany today, the first known Nazi war criminal to be extradited from Argentina.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Armenia Votes to Halt Spring Draft
description: The Parliament of Soviet Armenia voted today to follow the example of rebel Lithuania and suspend the spring draft of young men into the Soviet armed forces, the unofficial news agency Interfax said.

title: Correction
description: A brief Associated Press article in some copies yesterday about President Bush's Federal income taxes incorrectly described the Zapata Corporation, which Mr. Bush once headed. Zapata, an offshore oil drilling and commercial fishing company, is still in operation in Houston.

title: Ex-Retail Official Tries Investment Banking
description: M. Ronald Ruskin, who has headed Gimbels and other big department stores, is teaming with two financial executives, Bruce Zenkel and Lester Schoenfeld, in an investment banking venture that hopes to attract middle-sized businesses as clients.

title: Trump Criticized on Late Payments
description: Less than a week after Forbes magazine marked him down a notch from a billionaire to a mere half-billionaire, Donald J. Trump is under fire from a handful of contractors who say he has been slow to pay money he owes them, possibly because of a cash squeeze.

title: Review/Film;   Between Revealing Wit And Opaque Contempt
description: ''Sarah Bernhardt,'' as Sandra Bernhard allows herself to be called periodically during ''Without You I'm Nothing,'' does something at the end of this film that few other performers would have the temerity to try. She stands revealed in the tiniest star-spangled-banner G-string, and does an abject, dispirited go-go dance to the tune of Prince's ''Little Red Corvette,'' before a nightclub audience that has dwindled down to only one impassive-looking woman.

title: Salvadoran Announces Talks, but Adds Warning
description: President Alfredo Cristiani announced today that peace talks with leftist rebels would begin in about 10 days but warned that a cut in United States military aid would diminish the talks' chance of success.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Buenos Aires Journal;   Billions Flow to Dam (and Billions Down Drain?)
description: A giant hydroelectric power project conceived in a time of big dreams and easy credit for Argentina has turned into a nightmare of delays and cost overruns that President Carlos Saul Menem says make it ''a monument to corruption.''

title: Japan Auto Inquiry Set
description: The Federal Trade Commission said today that it was investigating Japanese car makers operating in the United States to see if they were violating antitrust laws by restricting competition for parts.

title: Review/Film;   2 Families Turn Their Petty Feud Into a War
description: Thomas Berger's novels - mordant, visual and episodic - seem to have movie written all over them. Sometimes that works, as in ''Little Big Man.'' Sometimes you get ''Neighbors,'' an unfunny comedy.

title: Congress Told of Abuses in Stock Index Futures Trading
description: James Coxon, head of stock investments for the Cigna Corporation, told Congress today that some traders used advance knowledge of customer plans to make profitable trades on the stock index futures market.

title: Review/Dance;   Growing Up Detached, Part of a Lonely Crowd
description: ''Curbs and Corridors,'' by Christopher Gillis, goes beyond the brief dances that Paul Taylor has asked selected members of his troupe to choreograph for four successive seasons.

title: State Suggests Sharpton Used Youth Group to Lure Promotional Deal
description: The personal manager of the entertainer Pia Zadora testified yesterday that he gave $15,000 to the Rev. Al Sharpton for promotional services shortly before Mr. Sharpton's National Youth Movement gave a special music video award to Miss Zadora and Jermaine Jackson.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Ex-Party Aide to Lead New Latvia
description: A former Latvian Communist Party official who once denounced pro-independence demonstrators was re-elected by Parliament today to lead the Baltic republic out of the Soviet Union.

title: A&E's New 'Revue' Offers An Old-Style Cultural Mix
description: ''Arts & Entertainment Revue,'' the product of an unlikely marriage between King World Productions, the boisterous company that ''Wheel of Fortune'' built, and the tony Arts & Entertainment cable network, will have its debut tonight from 8 P.M. to 9 P.M.

title: GATT Talks Seem Stalled
description: Trade negotiators reported no significant breakthroughs after the second day of talks among the United States, Japan, Canada and the 12-nation European Community.

title: Subway Police Patrols for Students to Begin
description: Transit Authority police officers will begin escorting high school students next week on designated subway cars in Brooklyn in a demonstration project that will try to insure students' safety traveling from school, school and transit officials said yesterday.

title: Labor Party Makes Big Gains In Local Elections in Britain
description: The governing Conservative Party suffered another setback today as British voters gave strong support to the opposition Labor Party in nationwide local elections.

title: Fund American Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included ''fresh start'' benefits of $6.8 million for latest first quarter and $9 million for year-ago period.

title: Owner of News Rejects Proposal on New Plants
description: The president of the company that owns The New York Daily News today formally rejected a proposal by the newspaper's unions that The News guarantee the construction of new plants in exchange for labor concessions.

title: Dicterow Violin Recital
description: Glenn Dicterow, the concertmaster of the New York Philharmonic, will give a recital with the pianist Gerald Robbins at the Juilliard Theater, 155 West 65th Street, on Sunday at 3 P.M. The program includes Stravinsky's ''Suite Italienne,'' Brahms's Sonata No. 1 in G (Op. 78), the Saint-Saens Fantasy for Harp and Violin (Op. 124).

title: Cigna Net Falls by Half
description: The Cigna Corporation said today that its earnings fell by half in the first quarter, partly because of large claims resulting from severe winter storms in Europe. The big insurance company said profits fell to $42 million, or 54 cents a share, from $85 million, or $1.02 a share, in 1989. Revenues fell slightly, to $3.8 billion, from $3.6 billion. Net income for the 1989 quarter included $13 million from operations that have been sold or discontinued.

title: Cobe Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
US Facilities reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $262,000, or 7 cents a share, and $125,000, or 4 cents a share, for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Moog Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a pre-tax charge of $1.8 million for inventory obsolescence.

title: Summer Squall Draws Post 14
description: Summer Squall will start from post No. 14 as the 7-5 favorite and Mister Frisky will break from post No. 5 as the 8-5 second choice in a 16-horse field drawn today for the 116th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs on Saturday.

title: Review/Art;   Donald Judd's Spare Boxes Full of Color and Light
description: Donald Judd is nothing if not consistent in his vision; nor is he running out of things to do, however incremental his progress may sometimes seem. In his exhibition at the Paula Cooper Gallery in SoHo, his involvement with the tetrad of color, space, scale and material continues to unfold, and with new clarity.

title: Consolidated Natural Gas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Canadian Tire reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Pan Am Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The single largest expense increase for Pan Am was fuel and oil, which increased from $126.2 million in the first quarter last year to $171.1 million this year.

title: Philips Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $42,815,000 of after-tax restructuring costs and $7,500,000 of after-tax merger related costs. c-Net income

title: Profit Drops at Philips N.V.
description: The Dutch electronics giant Philips N.V. reported a 26 percent drop in first-quarter operating profits today, a much steeper drop than brokers had expected.

title: 'Poems From Africa'
description: The composer Bernadette Speach and the poet Thulani Davis are to perform some of their recent collaborative works tomorrow at 8 P.M. at the Cadman Memorial Church, 350 Clinton Avenue, at Lafayette Avenue, in the Fort Greene section of Brooklyn. The program includes ''Poems From Africa,'' ''Telepathy Suite'' and ''A Set of Five.'' Ms. Davis will read her poetry, and Ms. Speach will conduct an ensemble: J. D. Parran, saxophonist; Alfred Patterson, trombonist; Myra Melford, pianist; Jeffrey Schanzer, guitarist, and Lindsey Horner, bassist. Tickets are $6. Information: (718) 972-3085.

title: Rules Waived to Permit Use Of AIDS Drug by Children
description: Waiving its usual rules for drug testing for the first time, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved AZT as a treatment for AIDS virus infections in children.

title: Metro Datelines;   O.K., It's Fiction, Movie Will Note
description: Warner Brothers, responding to accusations of Bronx-bashing in its film adaptation of ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' has agreed to tack on a standard disclaimer at the end of the movie.

title: Baruch College, Proud of Its Record, Seeks Minority Faculty
description: To the Editor:

title: Capital Holding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included realized investment losses of $30,877,000 in the latest quarter and $11,320,000 a year-earlier. c-Net loss and after a loss of $56,021,000 from a cumulative effect of a change in accounting for post-retirement employee life and health costs. The company said its first quarter net income, excluding investment gains and losses and related amortization, was $56,087,000, or $1.16 a share, compared with $46,293,000, or 98 cents a share, a year-ago.

title: Enstar Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $196,000 for the latest quarter and $4,370,000, or 8 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. The company said the latest revenues include American Savings & Loan Association of Florida up until March 6. However, the revenues do not include American Savings subsequent to the March 6 distribution of one-half of the common stock of American Savings to a trust for the benefit of Enstar shareholders.

title: Air Express International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Researchers Succeed in Growing Brain Cells
description: Surmounting a barrier that has long stymied efforts to plumb many complexities and disorders of the human brain, scientists have for the first time grown an important type of human brain cell in the laboratory.

title: Germany's K.H.D. To Spin Off Unit
description: The West German machinery maker Kloeckner-Humboldt-Deutz A.G. agreed to spin off its American farm machinery subsidiary, the Deutz-Allis Corporation, to the division's management and an unidentified ''financial group.'' No other details were disclosed. K.H.D. acquired Deutz-Allis in 1985. The Atlanta-based farm equipment maker had sales of $307 million last year.

title: American Water Works reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Genentech Stock Trades Investigated
description: The wife of Genentech's chief executive officer is the focus of an insider trading investigation being conducted by the Securities and Exchange Commission, the company disclosed today.

title: Memories of Tyranny, in Chilean Films
description: A CHILEAN photographer is called to a dangerous political rendezvous where he may find a trace of information about his brother, who disappeared a dozen years before. If he refuses the meeting, he asks himself, ''What will save me from suicide?'' Yet how can he carry on a normal life with his wife and small son if he is obsessed with his brother's disappearance? The disappeared live in our memories, he says, but we must ''kill them inside ourselves in order to live.''

title: I.M.F. Sees Slower Growth, but No Slump
description: In a less optimistic assessment than it made in October, the International Monetary Fund projected today that world economic growth would slow to 2 1/4 percent in 1990, but it said that ''no recession is in sight.''

title: Reviews/Music;   Belated New York Debut for Sharon Sweet in 'Trovatore'
description: Sharon Sweet's introduction to New York has been a year late. Scheduled to sing in the Verdi Requiem with the Collegiate Chorale last season, Miss Sweet was dismissed during rehearsals by the chorale's director, Robert Bass, who alleged she was unreasonable, setting off one of the juicier casting imbroglios of recent memory. The American soprano has resurfaced as Leonora in the Metropolitan Opera's production of ''Il Trovatore,'' and made her house debut last Friday night.

title: Chili and Dish Washing At Aqueduct Cook-Off
description: For fans of chili, horse racing and dish washing, a chili cook-off will be held this weekend at Aqueduct Race Track, 108th Street and Rockaway Boulevard, in Ozone Park, Queens.

title: BMW-Rolls-Royce Jet-Engine Deal
description: Bayerischen Motoren Werke A.G., the West German maker of luxury cars, said it would acquire an aerospace technology line from Kloeckner-Humboldt-Deutz A.G. and then merge the company into a venture with Rolls-Royce P.L.C. of Britain. BMW said the return to the aircraft engine business after 31 years reflected the company's desire to expand into new, though related, industries. No other details were disclosed.

title: PWA Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for the latest period include those of Wardair Inc., which was acquired in April 1989. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: American International Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said insured losses associated with the freeze losses in the Southeastern United States, as well as the European storms, amounted to approximately $13 million in the quarter. Net of tax, these catastrophic losses reduced per share earnings for the quarter by about 5 cents.

title: Children's Tours
description: Free walking tours of midtown Manhattan, designed for those 8 to 14 years old, will be sponsored for the next three Saturdays by the Grand Central Partnership. The tour, with commentary geared to a child's perspective, will include the Chrysler Building, the Empire State Building and Grand Central Terminal. Tours begin at 11 A.M. at the Philip Morris Building, 42d Street and Park Avenue. Information: 986-9217.

title: Iraq's U.S. Support
description: At 4:15 on a recent Friday afternoon - which, in the nation's capital, is the news equivalent of the dead of night - the Department of Agriculture put out a short release: a team of its officials had left for Iraq to look into ''possible irregularities'' in our Government guarantees of bank loans to finance purchase of U.S. commodities.

title: Mandela Ally Speaks of Broader Talks
description: As talks between the South African Government and the African National Congress continued for a second day, a senior official of the Congress said today that other organizations should be represented at eventual negotiations on the country's future.

title: The Pride Of the Knicks
description: rrAfter Patrick Ewing, the lately bedeviled Knick ace, faked, spun, drove the baseline and scored a sweepingly denunciatory dunk on Robert Parish of the Celtics late in the fourth quarter Wednesday night, he turned to his nearby bench and, with a soupcon of a sneer, pointed with long finger on a long arm in the direction of Paul Silas, the Knick assistant coach in charge of muscle and menace.

title: T.W.A. Unions Get Icahn Plan
description: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., outlined a plan this week to union leaders under which America West Airlines Inc. would take over T.W.A.'s domestic routes, including the hub at St. Louis.

title: Review/Art;   Images of Third-World Dislocation
description: What is called political art has achieved a renewed currency of late, for reasons that are not difficult to grasp. The controversy over Robert Mapplethorpe's photographs and attempts to restrict the latitude of the National Endowment for the Arts have left artists feeling more embattled than usual. The controversies have also raised awareness of the political possibilities of art.

title: OPEC Pact Reached on Output Cut
description: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed at an emergency meeting today to stop producing oil above their previously agreed upon quotas, hoping to end the oversupply that has driven prices down 25 percent this year.

title: U.S. Aid to Peru Military Is Blow to Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Della Femina's Andy Victory
description: The Boston office of Della Femina, McNamee WCRS suffered a sharp blow in March when it lost the Parker Brothers account to Grey Advertising, but the agency's showing at last night's Andy Awards at the Waldorf-Astoria should restore much of its pride.

title: Chipwich Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $288,000, or 3 cents a share. c-Net loss and included a loss from dicontinued operations of $2,503,000 and a loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $1,357,000. The company said the latest year results included the operations of Peltz Food for the 11 months following its merger with Chipwich on Feb. 1, 1989.

title: INSIDE
description: Deaths in Uprising Decline

title: Weingarten Realty Investors reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Euro Disneyland Spending Is Raised
description: Euro Disneyland said it was increasing investment in its theme park near Paris because it was confident of strong demand in Europe, spurred by a wave of tourists from the former Communist East. Spending on the Magic Kingdom park, to open in spring 1992, will rise by 9.4 percent, to a total 16.3 billion francs, or about $2.9 billion, said Euro Disney's chief financial officer, John Forsgren.

title: Ford Motor of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Texas Air Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Economic Scene;   Can U.S. Recover In Electronics?
description: THE Japanese Government's reported plan to organize an industrial effort to develop an advanced computer technology known as massively parallel processing, in which the United States now holds a substantial lead, heightens American anxieties. Some Americans already believe that Japan has a master strategy for achieving dominance in all areas of electronics technology and thereby becoming the world's greatest industrial power.

title: MBIA Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the acquisition of Bond Investors Group Inc. was effective Dec. 31, 1989 and accordingly the results for 1989 do not include Bond Investors.

title: BHC Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that about $358 million of the latest quarter net income reflects BHC's gain, after income taxes and minority interest, on the disposition of its remaining interest in Warner Communications Inc.

title: Council to Consider Ban On Cigarette Machines
description: New York City's Health and Consumer Affairs Commissioners called yesterday for a ban on cigarette vending machines.

title: Claim of Church Based on Sex Is Ruled Out
description: A Federal judge today rejected a couple's claim that their Church of the Most High Goddess, a religion based on sex, was protected by the Constitution and was thus immune from the enforcement of vice laws.

title: TV Weekend;   Teen-Ager's Tour of Another World
description: Continuing its consistently impressive run of programming for young audiences, public television's ''Wonderworks'' is starting a three-part series this weekend called ''African Journey.'' The hourlong episodes are to be broadcast at 10 A.M. on Sundays on Channel 13.

title: Angami Phizo, 83; Fought for Secession In North India State
description: Angami Zapu Phizo, who fought for independence for the northeastern Indian state of Nagaland and was condemned to death in absentia, died in British exile on Monday, officials at the Indian High Commission said today. He was 83 years old.

title: Astec Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Doctors Strike for Union Recognition at Hospital in Bronx
description: Resident doctors at the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center went on strike yesterday, seeking recognition for a new union. But attending physicians who filled in for the striking doctors said that services at the 565-bed hospital continued to function normally all day.

title: From First Lady's Husba
description: Following is President Bush's exchange with reporters today about the Wellesley College dispute involving his wife, Barbara, as provided by the Federal News Service, a transcription company:

title: Reds Get Back Speedily As Mets Lose Messily
description: The Mets did not lose to the Cincinnati Reds last night because of what unfolded in a tortuous eighth inning. But there was enough crammed into a series of errors, Reds stolen bases and Met pratfalls to give more than a good indication why the team is now in a last-place tie with the St. Louis Cardinals in the National League East.

title: In Colorado, a Furor Over Computer Mail
description: For more than a year, the Mayor of Colorado Springs read the electronic messages about city business that members of the City Council sent to one another from computers at their homes.

title: Senate Ethics Committee Planning Public Hearings on Durenberger
description: The Senate Ethics Committee announced today that it had scheduled two weeks of public hearings next month into whether Senator Dave Durenberger violated Senate rules in a book publishing deal.

title: Treasury Bonds Stage Advance
description: Treasury bond prices posted their best gains in nearly a month yesterday, as dealers positioned themselves for the release this morning of April employment data.

title: Review/Film;   When Love's Ties Are Real Ropes
description: Pedro Almodovar's ''Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!'' is a surprisingly tame comedy to be made by the same Spanish director responsible for ''Matador,'' ''Law of Desire'' and ''Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown.''

title: Ellington Sculpture Puts Some Critics in a Mood Indigo
description: The art critics on 110th Street - some of them passers-by, others taking afternoon breaks on the benches - gave mixed reviews yesterday to a two-story-high sculpture of Duke Ellington standing on the heads of nine nude women that is planned for the northeast corner of Central Park.

title: Evolution in Europe;   NATO ADOPTS PLAN TO REVAMP ITSELF FOR GERMAN UNITY
description: NATO adopted a package of proposals today for transforming the Western military alliance into more of a political organization and making membership in NATO by a unified Germany acceptable to the Soviet Union and the German people.

title: Chronicle
description: An opera star, an actor, a dance director and a Chicago Democrat whom some have called the best friend the arts have in Congress will receive honorary doctorates May 18 from the Juilliard School.

title: The Unscientific Charm of the Big Bang
description: To the Editor:

Titan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Market Place;   A Big Loophole In Insider Cases
description: FOUR years ago, when Ivan Boesky was a respected stock trader and Michael Milken a powerful investment banker, a prevalent theory on Wall Street held that insider trading was a relatively safe way to make money.

title: Tap at Columbia
description: A tap-dancing celebration, produced by the Black Patti Project in honor of the 102d anniversary of the birth of Bill (Bojangles) Robinson, will be held on Sunday at 5 P.M. at Wollman Hall at Columbia University, 115th Street and Broadway. It features by Buster Brown, Leslie (Bubba) Gaines, Mable Lee and Tina Pratt, as well as excerpts from movie musicals. Admission: $12. Information: 964-8411.

title: Loss in Quarter For Texas Air
description: The Texas Air Corporation, parent of the faltering Eastern Airlines and Continental Airlines, said today that it lost $107.1 million in the year's first quarter.

title: U.S. Aid to Peru Military Is Blow to Democracy;   Asians in the Andes
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bang & Olufsen A.S., Denmark, which makes audio-visual products, said Philips Consumer Electronics International B.V., the Netherlands, would buy 25 percent of the total capital shares of Bang & Olufsen Holding A.S. for $50 million, double the shares' face value.

title: On Legal Pundits and How They Got That Way
description: LEAD: Supreme Court Justices aren't the only lawyers whose opinions play in the press.

title: Long Island City Artists Open Studios for Tours
description: Artists living and working in Long Island City, Queens, will open their work spaces to the public this weekend. More than 70 artists are taking part in free tours and exhibitions that will run from noon to 6 P.M. today through Sunday.

title: Fuji Agrees to Buy Rest of Subaru in U.S.
description: Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., the Japanese maker of Subaru cars, said today that it had agreed to buy the half of Subaru of America Inc. it did not own in a deal valued at $412.2 million.

Lattice Semiconductor reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net operating loss carryforwards which reduced tax provisions.

title: Reliance Group Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $1,425,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Included pretax gains of $42.9 million from the sales of investments.

title: Review/Art;   The Power of Whimsy: Jean Arp's Later Work
description: Sculptor, collagist, poet, painter and maker of famously whimsical drawings and bas-reliefs, Jean (he also went by the name Hans) Arp had already secured a place for himself in the history of 20th-century art before his 30th birthday, in 1916. Arp was among the pioneers of abstraction. By 1912, he had exhibited with Henri Matisse, Paul Klee, Robert Delaunay and Wassily Kandinsky, who was one of his early enthusiasts. Amedeo Modigliani drew his portrait around the same time, and Arp could count among his friends many of the most interesting French, German and Swiss artists.

title: L.S. Starrett Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
4 Errors by Blowers Yield 7 Runs for Indians
description: Mike Blowers, a 25-year-old rookie, staged an unforgettable performance at Yankee Stadium yesterday; he only hopes he can forget it before too long.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: Mary Lea Johnson Richards, 63, Founder of Production Company
description: Mary Lea Johnson Richards, a founder and partner of the Producer Circle, a New York film and theatrical production company, died yesterday at Presbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh, where she had a liver transplant two weeks ago. She was 63 years old and had homes in New York, Southampton, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Amgen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company said that during the latest quarter it advanced amounts to an affiliate to fund its share of research and development costs resulting in a $3 million charge to operations.

title: Fleet Norstar Posts a Loss
description: The Fleet Norstar Financial Group said today that it had a loss of $98.1 million in the first quarter.

title: Telesphere Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Hecla Mining reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $2 million gain on sale of Golden Dome property. c-Net loss and included non-recurring $1.6 million payment for reclamation costs at the Old Reliable Cooper mine in Arizona. The company also said its latest quarter benefited from increased income from the Republic unit in Washington.

title: Bush Asks Budget Talks With 4 Top Lawmakers
description: President Bush said today that he had invited the four top Congressional leaders to the White House on Sunday for discussions on the budget, a move lawmakers view as an effort by the President to regain control of a process on which Congressional Democrats seem to have the upper hand.

title: Rangers' Erixon Has Surgery on Sore Back
description: Jan Erixon, the accomplished checking forward for the Rangers, underwent surgery on Wednesday to partially remove a herniated disk in his back, the team announced yesterday.

description: Postwar Works

title: Evolution in Europe;   Conservative Asked to Form New Government in Hungary
description: Hungary's interim head of state, Arpad Goncz, chose Jozsef Antall, a 58-year-old museum director, today to form Hungary's first freely elected government in more than four decades.

title: New Pair on N.B.A.
description: Marv Albert and Bob Costas will be NBC's primary announcers on National Basketball Association telecasts, the network said yesterday. Costas and Albert will split play-by-play and host assignments during the regular season and playoffs.

title: The fleecing of the client, a cautionary report about the lawyer's conflict of interest.
description: ''Tell me a man is dishonest, and I will answer he is no lawyer,'' Daniel Webster told the Charleston, S.C., bar in 1847. ''He cannot be, because he is careless and reckless of justice; the law is not in his heart, is not the standard and rule of his conduct.''

title: Chili's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the results for the 1990 third quarter and 9 months have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Romano's Macaroni Grill Inc.

title: Surgery for Sutcliffe
description: Rick Sutcliffe will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his right pitching shoulder, the Chicago Cubs said yesterday. The exploratory surgery on the former National League 1984 Cy Young Award winner is scheduled for Monday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago.(AP)

title: Paxar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $12,000 and income from an accounting adjustment of $139,000, or 3 cents a share.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;

Training 'Subversives' as Teachers
description: LEAD: A measure of the heart of a community is how it treats and educates its children. For the last few years I have been teaching high school in a poverty-ridden, predominantly Mexican-American community in south Texas. I have come to believe that we as a nation are suffering from heart failure.

title: SCI Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the primary factor contributing to the latest nine- month loss was the declaration in the first quarter of bankruptcy under Chapter 11 by a disc drive industry customer which caused SCI to reserve for a related multimillion dollar loss exposure.

BRIEFS
