title: European Utility Plan
description: The European Community Executive Commission said on Wednesday that it planned to spend $363 million to improve and expand natural gas and electricity systems. The projects in the three-year plan include introducing natural gas in Portugal and Greece, connecting gas networks in Ireland and Britain, and linking electricity networks in Italy and Greece.

title: Waxman Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $320,000, or 3 cents a share, related to retirement of debt. Figures for 1990 included results from Ideal Plumbing Group Inc., acquired May 1, 1989.

title: Criminal Justice, Arrested
description: After a police officer arrested Robert Johnson for hustling tokens from subway passengers, it took New York City's criminal justice agencies the better part of three days to charge him with misdemeanors that carry only brief sentences. His case typifies thousands that prompted Justice Brenda Soloff to rule in favor of a Legal Aid lawsuit asking for more prompt arraignments.

title: Galway and Quartet
description: The flutist James Galway and the Tokyo String Quartet will play Mozart's Flute Quartets in C (K. 285b), A (K. 298) and D (K. 285) and Anton Reicha's Flute Quintet in A (Op. 105) at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts at Lehman College, Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue, in the Bronx. The program, on Sunday afternoon at 3, also includes Beethoven's String Quartet No. 16 in F (Op. 135). Tickets are $17.50 to $25. Information: 965-2700.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: General Motors Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rebuilding Neighborhoods;   Old Trenton Warehouse Will Now Hold Condos
description: A 19th-century brick warehouse in one of Trenton's oldest sections has become a symbol of this city's industrial past and of its future as a contemporary urban address.

title: LeMond Stays Too Busy to Train
description: Success may not have spoiled Greg LeMond, bicycle racing's first $5 million man, but it has certainly messed up his daily life.

title: Trainer Is Suspended
description: Robert Lake was suspended for 60 days by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board because two of the horses he trains tested positive for a banned substance after races on the same day last month.

title: Hanover Insurance Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net realized investment gains of $2,107,000 and a ''fresh start'' income tax benefit of $1,493,000, or 7 cents a share. c-Net income and included net realized investment gains of $2,432,000 and a ''fresh start'' income tax benefit of $1,286,000, or 6 cents a share.

Westair Holding reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chronicle
description: MOTHER TERESA, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979 for her care of the poor and sick in India, said yesterday that she will open a mission in Bucharest. The 79-year-old missionary, who has been in the Romanian capital since Monday accompanied by four other nuns, told reporters that she came ''to spread tender, loving care.''

title: Democrats Propose Bill on Campaign Finance
description: An article yesterday about a Democratic proposal to change the financing of political campaigns overstated contributions that five Senators received from Charles H. Keating Jr. Mr. Keating gave more than $1 million altogether to their re-election campaigns.

title: Atlas Consolidated Mining reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,660,000, or 3 cents a share, which reflects tax loss carryforward of $2,662,000. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $5,666,000, or 7 cents a share, which reflected tax loss carryforward of $3,644,000 and $2,022,000 gain from extinguishment of debt, net of tax effect.

title: Joffrey and Choreographer Agree to Negotiate
description: The Joffrey Ballet plans to start negotiations today with Gerald Arpino and his lawyer, Harold Messing, on whether the company can stage Mr. Arpino's ballets. The dances were withdrawn by Mr. Arpino when he resigned as artistic director of the Joffrey on Tuesday.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Tony Williams

title: Fires at Mecham's Offices
description: The campaign headquarters of former Gov. Evan Mecham were damaged early today by the second suspicious fire there in the last two days, the police said. Mr. Mecham, who is again running for governor after his removal from office by the Legislature two years ago, was not present, and no one was injured.

description: A Hoskins Gumshoe

title: Topics of The Times;   Unique Merit in California
description: ''Some titles in this sale,'' said the catalogue from the University of California Press, ''are so special, or such a 'good read,' or such a bargain that we want to call attention to them. Why not start with our Books of Unique Merit?'' There were six of them, and the first title brought a twinge of disappointment: ''Vulture Biology and Management.'' At $10, marked down from $47.50, for 554 pages, it was surely a bargain. But a good read?

title: New President Chosen At Deprenyl of Toronto
description: Deprenyl Research Ltd., a Toronto company that has received approval to market a drug to treat Parkinson's disease in Canada, has named James P. Doherty, a seasoned pharmaceutical industry executive, as its new president and chief operating officer.

title: William Cahalan, Judge, 64
description: William Cahalan, a judge who was a former Michigan Racing Commissioner and Wayne County prosecutor, died of cancer on Wednesday at his home. He was 64 years old.

description: LEAD: Three related events concerning Iraq have recently attracted a good deal of attention in the United States.

description: Shun Lee

title: Everglades Fire Leaps Canal, Imperiling a Wildlife Preserve
description: A four-mile-wide brush fire raced through dry Everglades sawgrass today, jumping a canal where officials had hoped to stop it and threatening 150,000 acres of a wildlife preserve.

title: Outdoors;   May Is Best Time for Striped Bass in the Hudson
description: rrThis is the prime month for those who fish in the Hudson River for striped bass, the adult populations of which are making their annual spawning runs.

title: Data Switch Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain from debenture exchange of $2,213,000, or 19 cents a share. c-Net loss

title: Liqui-Box Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the sales increase reflected the acquisition of B-Bar-B in the middle of last year.

title: The Killing Fields
description: Suppose a Nazi army had stayed intact at the end of World War II, and held out in a remote area with Hitler, Goering and Himmler. Then imagine an American Government insisting that the Nazis must be included in arrangements for a German political settlement.

title: Patriarch Pimen, 79, the Leader Of the Russian Church Since '71
description: Patriarch Pimen, who presided over the Russian Orthodox Church from the repressions of the Brezhnev era to a new era of official tolerance, died today, the church announced. He was 79 years old.

title: Bruins Use Discipline to Offset Mistakes
description: Discipline, the quality that becomes such an enormous factor in the Stanley Cup playoffs, surfaces in a variety of forms. It means knowing when not to fight and when not to panic. And once in a while, it can mean nothing so much as taking your time when you've been given the advantage.

title: Books of The Times;   An Awful Time Living a Perfect Life
description: Goodbye Without Leaving

title: L. Nicholas Ruwe, Ex-Ambassador, 56; Assisted Presidents
description: L. Nicholas Ruwe, a former United States Ambassador to Iceland and a Republican Party stalwart, died of cancer on Wednesday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn. He was 56 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Topics of The Times;   Lessons From the First Lady
description: What can you learn from Barbara Bush? Not much, in the view of 150 young women graduating from Wellesley College. They are protesting her selection as this year's commencement speaker. Since ''Wellesley teaches that we will be rewarded on the basis of our own merit, not on that of a spouse,'' they say the First Lady is an unworthy choice. As one young woman bluntly put it: ''If Barbara Bush hadn't been married to this guy who happens to be President, we never would have heard of her.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Freedom, like a genie that's been let out of the bottle, doesn't necessarily want to listen to the dictates of the person who uncorked the bottle.''

title: Vitronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Boole & Babbage reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary net non- recurring gains from sale of a product family of $732,00, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months. Year-ago revenues included $3.2 million in revenue from the sale of a product's distribution rights in Japan.

title: Washington Post's Net Off
description: The Washington Post Company today reported a 6 percent decline in first-quarter earnings, attributing the weaker results to lower advertising sales at three important divisions.

title: Corporate-Tax Shortfall in Dispute
description: Congress's chief economist testified today that leveraged buyouts and other measures that increased corporate debt were an important factor in the Government's receiving less tax revenue from corporations than had been expected.

title: Review/Film;   Of AIDS, Frustration And Fury
description: At the start of ''Silence Equals Death,'' one of two new documentaries by Rosa von Praunheim about the range of responses to the AIDS plague, a man tells the camera he has tested HIV positive for the AIDS virus. He talks briefly and angrily about his feelings, then suddenly lowers his pants and seems to shoot himself anally with a pistol at very close camera range. Though this proves to be a work of performance art rather than a real suicide, it is deadly all the same, insofar as it defines and limits Mr. von Praunheim's approach to reaching his audience.

title: Southam Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pretax unusual gain of $2,954,000. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $2,241,000, or 4 cents a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Windmere Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Arnold Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $1,322,329, or 20 cents a share, from a cumulative effect of change in accounting for income tax.

title: Disney Stores: Magic in Retail?
description: The Walt Disney Company's latest retail store here is not Disneyland, but like the company's theme parks and other stores, it has enough of the magical Disney marketing touch to keep children enraptured and their parents spending freely.

title: Money for Show
description: A selection of top athletes and their 1990 earnings from endorsement contracts. Figures for golfers and tennis players include exhibitions but not appearance fees. Salaries and prize money are not included.

title: Where and When to See the Shows
description: For fans of avant-garde music, many shows can be found around New York City this weekend. Here is a sampling.

title: As Viewers Seem to Vanish, CBS Seeks Rating Changes
description: A senior CBS executive said yesterday that his network had decided to seek a ''better television measurement system'' because the A. C. Nielsen Company was unable to explain the sudden decline in national television viewing it had reported over the last three months.

title: 20th Anniversary at Kent State
description: Residents of Kent and the surrounding community flocked to the Kent State University campus today to see a new memorial that is to be dedicated on Friday, the 20th anniversary of the slaying of four students by Ohio National Guardsmen. Speakers at the dedication of the abstract memorial - four granite slabs flanked by a walkway - will include Florence Schroeder, whose son was among those slain, and Dean Kahler, now an Athens County Commissioner, who was among the nine wounded by the guardsmen's gunfire.

title: Pratt & Lambert Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Recent relocation of its Miracle Adhesives division from Bellmore, N.Y., to Buffalo, N.Y., represented a significant one-time cost incurred early this year. The company did not specify the amount of the cost.

title: Greyhound Lines of Canada Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Household International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $11 million, or 32 cents a share.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Lithuania Premier Sees Bush, But There's No Red Carpet
description: Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania was not expecting the White House driveway to be lined with her nation's gold, green and red flags. She was not expecting an honor guard or an Oval Office lunch or a joint departure statement with President Bush on the South Lawn.

title: Gaetti's Home Run In the 10th Beats Tigers
description: Gary Gaetti continued his home-run binge today, but just barely.

title: Oklahoma Gas & Elec reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MCN Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Coastal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,700,000. Year-ago results are restated for trucking segment which was accounted for as a discontinued operation as of Oct. 1, 1989.

title: Colt Changes Name to Coltec
description: It has been several years since Colt Industries decided to sharply reduce the role its firearms operation played in its overall business. Nonetheless, company officials say that Colt, which has become a diversified manufacturing company, was still saddled with the image of being a firearms maker.

title: Kentucky Central Life Insurnce Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Illinois Death Penalty Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the state's death penalty law, opening the way for Illinois's first execution in 28 years.

title: Afghan's Chief Vows to Stay in Office
description: President Najibullah, Kabul's Soviet-backed leader, vowed today to stay in office, scorning any suggestion that he turn over power to an interim government while competing in internationally supervised elections that the United States and the Soviet Union have discussed as the centerpiece of a possible peace settlement.

title: A Philatelist's Panama
description: LEAD: This week's frenzied sesquicentennial of the British Penny Black has overshadowed postal issues that in other weeks would cause involuntary shivers of anticipation throughout the collectibles community. Most egregiously overlooked has been Panama's two-centesimo ''Los Parachutos'' (fig. 6), a khaki-and-teal offering timed to coincide with President Guillermo Endara's state visit.

title: Newspaper Family Group Acts to Block Dissident
description: The majority owners of Freedom Newspapers Inc. have solidified their defenses against a dissident family member by turning over control of the two-thirds of the company's stock they own to a voting committee and agreeing to sell shares only to each other for five years, The Orange County Register, Freedom's flagship newspaper in Santa Ana, Calif., disclosed today.

title: G.M. and Ford Profits Off Sharply for Quarter
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company, the nation's two biggest auto makers, each posted sharply lower first-quarter profits today.

title: Kelley Oil & Gas Partners reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
First Brands Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $792,000 for the quarter and 9 months, related to purchase of debt. c-After an extraordinary loss in the quarter of $137,000 from a charge related to adjustments made related to use of carryforwards, and the 9 months included an extraordinary credit of $4,889,000, or 24 cents a share, related to benefits from tax loss carryforwards. The year-ago net from operations figures included a pre-tax gain of $25.6 million related to the sale of its European home products businesses.

title: Worthy Helps Lakers Eliminate Rockets
description: James Worthy scored 10 of his 20 points in the final 7 minutes 37 seconds tonight to lead the Los Angeles Lakers to a 109-88 victory that eliminated the Houston Rockets from the playoffs.

title: BARRY WINS TEST OF POLITICAL WILL
description: In a narrow victory for Marion S. Barry Jr., the Mayor's supporters tonight beat back an effort by the city's Democratic leadership to keep him from seeking re-election because of his personal and legal problems.

title: Our Towns;   One Great Scorer Marks How They Play the Game
description: The Army game the other day was a crucial contest for Adelphi's lacrosse squad. It didn't start well. After a quarter, Adelphi, a perennial top 20 team, trailed 4 to 3. The players huddled, listening as coaches mapped strategy. It was unseasonably hot. Already they were drenched in sweat. Players yanked off helmets, sucking wind.

title: Emulex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Net income The company said that $1.8 million of the loss in the latest third quarter was related to special charges.

title: William L. Dawson, Composer, 90
description: William L. Dawson, a composer and choral arranger, died of pneumonia on Wednesday. He was 90 years old.

title: Philadelphia Inquirer Loses Libel Suit
description: A jury decided today that The Philadelphia Inquirer had recklessly defamed one of the city's most prominent lawyers and must pay him $34 million. Experts said the award was the largest ever handed up by a jury in a libel case against an American news organization.

title: Executone Information SysFtems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $173,000. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the discontinuance of the payphone division in 1989.

title: Debut for Handel and Haydn Ensemble
description: The Handel and Haydn Society Chamber Ensemble will give its first New York performace on Sunday at 4 P.M. at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street. The period-instrument group from Boston will play an all-Bach program featuring the harpsichordists, John Finney and James David Christie (the group's director) and John Finney in the double harpsichord concertos in C (BWV 1061) and C minor (BWV 1062). Also on the program is the Suite in B minor (BWV 1067) for flute and strings, with Christopher Krueger as soloist, and the ''Brandenburg'' Concerto No. 5. Tickets are $10. Information: 666-0675.

title: Albany Tentatively Agrees To a $1 Billion Tax Package
description: As a part of a package of tax increases that could total more than $1 billion, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders have tentatively agreed to raise the levies on several consumer and luxury items, including alcohol, cigarettes and many hotel rooms.

title: Manhattan-Brooklyn Shuttle Bus in Operation
description: A regular shuttle-bus service from midtown Manhattan to the Brooklyn Museum and Brooklyn Botanic Garden is now in operation. Buses depart Wednesdays through Sundays at 10 A.M. from several locations - the Plaza and Waldorf-Astoria Hotels and Grand Central Terminal on the East Side, and the Hilton and Penta Hotels and 330 West 42d Street on the West Side.

title: Armatron International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Included extraordinary tax benefits of $50,000, 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $91,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 6 months. Year-ago income from continuing operations of $188,000, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months included a pretax gain on the sale of a building of $584,000.

title: Loews Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net gain on the sale of three oil tankers amounting to $70.4 million, or 94 cents a share, and included realized investment gains of $23.9 million, or 32 cents share. c-Included realized investment gains of $32.6 million, or 43 cents a share.

title: Metro Datelines;   Fallen Debris Ties Up Traffic on Bridge
description: A few empty boxes, barrels and some dirt from a chemical plant fell off a truck at the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge toll plaza on Staten Island yesterday morning, turning the rush hour into a commuter's nightmare.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: New York State Revenue Bonds
description: The State of New York Mortgage Agency, which issues bonds to create a pool of funds for loans to first-time home buyers, is offering $48.4 million in homeowner mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Thorn Apple Valley reports earnings for Qtr to March 2
description: b-Net income

title: National Gypsum Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain from debt repurchase of $6,935,000.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Ties for Israel and Bulgaria
description: Israel and Bulgaria restored diplomatic relations today after a 23-year break and signed an agreement that covers air transportation, telecommunications, tourism, agriculture, mutual protection of investments and dealings between banks. Bulgaria and other Eastern bloc countries broke relations with Israel after the 1967 war. With the changes that have swept Eastern Europe, only Moscow has not restored diplomatic ties.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 509 money market mutual funds decreased by $2.14 billion, to $385.72 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 161 institutional funds increased by $1.71 billion, to $92.32 billion. The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were down by $912.60 million, to $132.70 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds decreased by $2.94 billion, to $160.70 billion, the institute said.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: 'Love Lemmings'

title: Senate Debates Lifting Curb on Political Action
description: The Senate is debating legislation that would allow Federal workers to participate for the first time in 50 years in partisan political activities, from soliciting contributions to serving as delegates at Presidential nominating conventions.

title: Schult Homes reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included an extraordinary credit of $52,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Sampling the Brew

title: Mohawk Reserve Quiet as Officials Meet
description: A wary quiet settled over this Mohawk territory today as Canadian and American officials met in Montreal to explore ways to bring more lasting peace to the troubled community, where a dispute over gambling claimed two lives this week.

title: Hope Williams, 92, Actress, Dies; Starred in Philip Barry Comedies
description: Hope Williams, a debutante with a carefree manner, boyishly clipped blond hair and a humorous walk, who was a leading Broadway actress in the late 1920's and 30's, died of cardiac arrest last night at her home in Manhattan. She was 92 years old.

title: Stutter-Step Democracy in Korea
description: Thousands of riot police storm the world's largest shipyard, at Ulsan, South Korea, to break up a strike and sit-in by workers. Two days later, they club strikers at the Government-run Korean Broadcasting System. Is this the new democratic South Korea?

title: At Wellesley, a Furor Over Barbara Bush
description: A seemingly harmless invitation by Wellesley College to have Barbara Bush serve as its commencement speaker has ignited a dispute that has roiled the campus and raised questions around the country about the nature of feminism. Today it led President Bush to defend Mrs. Bush's role as a wife and mother.

title: U.S. Aid to Peru Military Is Blow to Democracy;   Stop It Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Venerable School for Women Is Going Co-ed
description: Trustees of Mills College, one of the nation's oldest schools for women, voted today to admit male undergraduates for the first time in its 138-year history.

title: Injured Behrens Cancels Final Brunnhilde at Met
description: The soprano Hildegard Behrens has withdrawn from tomorrow night's performance of Wagner's ''Gotterdammerung'' at the Metropolitan Opera. The company said a replacement for the role of Brunnhilde would be named today.

title: Moore Medical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included a $1.5 million charge for a litigation settlement.

title: Encore Computer reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Net loss Year-ago figures are pro forma; Encore acquired the Computer Systems business of Gould Inc. on April 27, 1989. Year-ago quarter results reflect the acquisition as if it occurred at the beginning of that period.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Europe Picks Its Lodestar
description: The NATO alliance and the European Community are now making all their major decisions about the future in the shadow of German strength and Soviet weakness.

title: Deutsch's Campaign For Ikea Furniture
description: Deutsch's first major campaign for Ikea, the Swedish furniture maker, tries to show what is wrong with the other stores. The agency constructed a series of television commercials out of bites of film shot at the other furniture retailers. As edited by Deutsch, other stores look silly: they specialize to a fault, bore kids to death, always run ''sales'' and hire goofy salesmen and inept truckers.

title: Rockefeller Center Properties reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Traffic Alert
description: Because of a parade honoring the the New York City Fire Department, the Avenue of the Americas will be closed tomorrow from Spring Street to 14th Street from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M.

title: Soviet Venture Set For Bicoastal Unit
description: The Link-Miles Simulation Corporation will build control-room simulators for Soviet nuclear power plants in a joint venture to improve nuclear safety in the Soviet Union. Link-Miles, a subsidiary of the Bicoastal Corporation of Tampa, has formed the partnership with N.P.O. Energia, a division of the Soviet Ministry of Atomic Energy. The venture is called General Energy Technologies.

title: Aztar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $3,496,000, or 8 cents a share. c-Net loss Latest quarter results included a pretax gain of $6.8 million from the company's share of the sale of the Tropicana Country Club in Las Vegas. Year-ago quarter results included an operating loss before net rent of $900,000 at Eddie's Fabulous 50's Casino in Reno, Nev., which the company closed in mid-1989. The year- earlier quarter also included $1.5 million in restructuring costs.

title: Study Says Lasix Improves a Horse's Speed but Not Its Health
description: A long-awaited study of Lasix, a drug administered to many race horses across the country ostensibly to prevent bleeding from their lungs, has concluded that the medication makes horses run faster without necessarily helping the problem it is prescribed to treat.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Excerpts From Session By Bush on Arms Talks
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's White House news conference yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Newark's New Image Buoys Mayor on Eve of Election
description: Every city has its symbol, and Newark's may still be the 1967 riots that scorched the city and left 23 people dead. But Sharpe James, a believer in the strength of symbols, has spent as much time over his four years as mayor trying to change that image as he has trying to solve the most serious problems.

title: Gemini Partners In Healthco Stake
description: Gemini Partners L.P., a New York-based investment partnership, has acquired 9.96 percent of Healthco International Inc. and said it might seek control of the Boston-based distributor of dental equipment. Gemini is led by Emanuel R. Pearlman, the 30-year-old former protege of the takeover specialist Asher B. Edelman. Healthco's shares rose 87.5 cents each today, to $14.625, in over-the-counter trading, giving the company a value of $113 million.

title: Cascade Natural Gas reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Senator to Finance Panel
description: Senator John Breaux, a Louisiana Democrat, was chosen on Wednesday to succeed the late Senator Spark M. Matsunaga of Hawaii on the Senate Finance Committee. The panel has jurisdiction over taxes, trade, Social Security and half of Government spending.

title: Chandris Review
description: Chandris Celebrity Cruises has narrowed the review for its advertising account to include McCann-Erickson, Della Femina McNamee WCRS, Korey, Kay & Partners, Bozell and the incumbent, Grey Entertainment and Media, agencies involved in the review said yesterday. Final presentations are scheduled for next week. The size of the account is estimated at $5 million to $10 million.

title: Oakland Journal;   New Spirit Flourishes In Quake's Aftermath
description: The Montana Standard, Il Giornale, Vegetarian Times, and Muscle and Fitness magazine are again on sale at DeLauer's Super Newsstand, a round-the-clock fixture here for 83 years until last October's earthquake sent a hail of bricks through the roof from an unstable building next door.

title: Morocco Plans Offshore Bank
description: Morocco plans to create an offshore banking system and a large industrial free zone to capitalize on its proximity to the European Community, the Finance Minister, Mohamed Berrada, said Wednesday night.

title: Millard Pleads Guilty
description: Keith Millard, the Minnesota Vikings All-Pro defensive lineman, pleaded guilty yesterday to careless driving in connection with a January incident in which he was arrested on a drunken driving charge. Hennepin County District Judge Herbert Worlner sentenced the 28-year-old Millard to 48 hours of community service and 12 months probation. He also fined him $625 and ordered him to be evaluated for chemical dependency at the Hazelden treatment center in Center City, Minn. (AP)

title: Review/Theater;   2 Caryl Churchill Plays Show Dark Side of 80's
description: Attending a Caryl Churchill play is asking to get one's face slapped, repeatedly, frequently and with vicious force. ''Ice Cream With Hot Fudge,'' as the English writer calls her new pair of one-act comedies at the Public Theater, is short in length but bottomless in its cynicism about citizens of the Thatcher-Reagan 1980's on both sides of the Atlantic. Ms. Churchill doesn't like Americans very much. She may like the English less. ''Ice Cream With Hot Fudge'' is a livid, nasty piece of work.

title: China Sees a Big Crop
description: Chinese agricultural officials predict a bumper grain harvest in 1990 and foreign analysts said this could lead to a reduction in imports, especially from the United States. China, the biggest buyer of American wheat, has purchased nearly 14 million metric tons of grain from the United States in the last two years. ''This year's grain output could top that of last year,'' the official China Daily newspaper today quoted officials as saying. Grain output reached a record 407 million tons in 1989, according to official figures.

title: Ford Motor Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cigna Corp.(M) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $13,000,000, or 16 cents a share. Results for 1989 have been restated to reflect implementation of Statement of Position 89-5. First quarter 1990 results reflect unusually severe winter storms in Europe, which reduced earnings by $34 million aftertax. Results also were affected by continued inadequate property and casualty pricing.

title: Developers Offer a Garden to Sell the Kitchen Sink
description: With huge inventories of unsold homes in the New York region and New England, home hunters this spring are being offered an array of offbeat incentives and promotions.

title: Retailer Is Taken Off Block
description: Bloomingdale's was formally taken off the auction block yesterday, after the fashionable department store chain apparently failed to draw an attractive enough bid.

title: France Enacts Penalties for Inciting Racism
description: Apparently in reponse to an increase in violence against Arab immigrants, the French National Assembly approved a bill today that would bar anyone found guilty of inciting race hatred from holding elected office or Government jobs.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Review/Film;   2 Weeks to Die, and Ready
description: As the hero of ''Short Time,'' Dabney Coleman could have saved himself some trouble if he had only seen ''Lethal Weapon.'' Here, Mr. Coleman is a policeman named Burt, days away from retirement. And though he has a partner (Matt Frewer, the former Max Headroom), he nonetheless does turns as both the Danny Glover careful cop and the Mel Gibson mad-dog cop.

title: On Stage
description: Dissension Over 'Salome'

title: Slain Judges and Lawyers
description: More than 270 lawyers, judges and other legal professionals worldwide were killed or persecuted last year, in part because of their association with unpopular causes or because they championed human rights, a legal watchdog group said Tuesday.

title: Phone Policy Upsets Fehr
description: Concerned about privacy rights and a change in working conditions, Donald Fehr said yesterday that baseball officials have overreacted to the Pete Rose affair in their new policy on telephone calls to and from clubhouses.

title: Copperweld Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
News Summary
description: International A3-10

title: Palestinian Revolt's Violence Declines
description: It is 1 P.M. and Manger Square is swarming with tourists in search of souvenirs. But with the calm nonchalance born of routine, one by one all the Palestinian merchants show the customers out, then close and padlock their doors.

title: Equitable of Iowa Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
G.O.P. Short of Time, and a Candidate
description: Less than four weeks before their state convention, Republican leaders are intensifying their politically embarrassing search for a candidate to oppose Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: A Rush to Stardom
description: He doesn't look fast when he walks. On the contrary, with his short, tapered legs and stocky, overstuffed torso, each step seems a struggle, as if he is sloshing through deep snow beneath a heavy backpack.

title: Avant Garde Music, The Bouquet of May
description: A picture caption in Weekend last Friday, with an article about avant-garde music, misidentified the musician and instrument shown. Adam Weisman was playing the surrogate kithara. Section C; Page 1, Column 3; Weekend Desk

title: Great Northern Nekoosa Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income On March 8, the Georgia-Pacific Corp. completed the purchase of its controlling stock interest in Great Northern Nekoosa. Georgia-Pacific acquired 53,235,413 of the outstanding shares of common stock of Great Northern, which, together with the 349,900 shares it already owned, represented about 96.5 percent of Great Northern's outstanding shares. During the 67-day period ended March 8, 1990, Great Northern recorded non-recurring expenses of $106.9 million related to the tender offer defense and change in control. Additionally, there was a charge of about $24 million for certain asset writeoffs and liability reserve accruals. Results for the 23-day period ended March 31 reflected additional depreciation, depletion, goodwill amortization and interest expense resulting from the preliminary allocation of Georgia-Pacific's purchase cost.

title: Throwing Caution Aside, Oakley Saves the Knicks
description: Early in the second period, during a timeout in Wednesday night's game, Charles Oakley tore off the plastic soft cast that protected the healing bone in his left hand and tossed it at Tim Walsh, the Knicks' assistant trainer.

title: Slower Rise In Costs of Commercials
description: THE days of skyrocketing commercial production costs appear to be ending, as lavish song-and-dance ads, high production-company markups and competitive bidding among producers fade from view, according to a new study by the American Association of Advertising Agencies.

title: Stokely USA reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Toromont Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Reviews/Music;   Flair Amid the Sobriety
description: Beneath a carefully cultivated glamorous image, the West German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter is a serious and thoughtful artist, as she demonstrated again in her recital with the pianist Lambert Orkis at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening.

title: Stocks Up; Dow Rises 6.53 Points
description: Stocks advanced yesterday in cautious trading for the fourth day in a row, falling back from a strong gain to end the day only slightly ahead.

title: Bush Says He Will Help Iran To Aid Release of Hostages
description: President Bush said today that he was trying to encourage the release of American hostages by helping Iran determine the fate of four Iranians who disappeared in Lebanon in 1982.

title: Emcon Associates reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
David Rappaport, Character Actor, 38, Seen on 'L.A. Law'
description: David Rappaport, a dwarf who played a win-at-any-cost lawyer known as ''Mighty Mouth'' in the television series ''L.A. Law,'' was found dead in a park of what appeared to be a self-inflicted gunshot wound, the police said. He was 38 years old. The police found his body on Wednesday evening at Laurel Canyon Park in the San Fernando Valley, said Sgt. William Davidson. Mr. Rappaport's manager, Frankie Leigh, had filed a missing persons report on Monday, saying the actor was depressed.

title: Mexican Receives U.S. Account of Abduction
description: Mexico's Attorney General said today that United States officials told him that senior Mexican police officers initiated the plan to abduct a Mexican doctor charged in the death of an American drug agent. But the Mexican official, Enrique Alvarez del Castillo, expressed skepticism about the account.

title: Precision Castparts reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Boeing Co., Seattle, promoted Boyd E. Givan to senior vice president and chief financial officer. He replaces Harold W. Haynes, who retired.

title: Defense Loses Bid to Shift Killing Blame
description: The judge in the Bensonhurst trial indicated yesterday that he would limit defense efforts to link the killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins to Gina Feliciano, the white girl who had invited black and Hispanic friends to the predominantly white neighborhood.

title: KEY RATES
3 Ex-Policemen Are Convicted In Texas Killing
description: Three former police officers, all of them white, were found guilty today of murdering a black man who was severely beaten in an East Texas jail more than two years ago in a case that provoked sharp racial tensions in the region.

title: Evolution in Europe: Reporter's Notebook;   Praise for Gorbachev From a Lithuanian Admirer
description: Everyone thought she had come to bury Mikhail Gorbachev, not to praise him.

title: Long Docile, Haitian-Americans Turn Militant
description: Deeply angered at being treated as suspected AIDS carriers, illiterates and unwanted black immigrants, Haitian-Americans are abandoning years of quiet acceptance and sharply demanding redress for what they charge is a pattern of prejudice and abuse.

title: Southern Mineral Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter results included a gain of $167,000 from a pricing settlement.

title: Medical Properties reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Echo Bay Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After previously announced $42.4 million writeoff of its investment in the Muscocho Group of Companies. c-Net income

title: Cascades Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds. Year-ago quarter restated.

title: Prime Motor Inns L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: S.E.C. Chief Concerned About Futures Debate
description: Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that there were ''disturbing parallels'' between the debate about who should have regulatory jurisdiction over stock index futures and the debate before the savings and loan crisis.

title: Support for Unesco Advances Free Speech

title: Flowers as a Double Gift
description: A bouquet of flowers for Mother's Day can express more than just affection. It can become an act of charity. A Manhattan floral service will donate 10 percent of the purchase price of any floral arrangement to a customer's favorite charity, for Mother's Day or any other day.

title: Record Time Rejected
description: A clocking of 45.04 seconds for the 400-meter run by Danny Everett of the United States in February has been rejected as a possible indoor world record because the race had an improperly staggered start and the runners stayed in their lanes for the entire race.

description: b-Net loss and included special charge of $1.75 million. Share earnings and shares outstanding are in units.

title: Douglas Computer Bankruptcy Filing
description: Douglas Computer filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, after one of its banks decided against giving it more credit. The Salt Lake City-based company said that it was in talks for financing with other individuals to allow it to continue operations but that there was no guarantee any arrangement would be reached.

title: New Jersey School Boards Director Resigns
description: The executive director of the New Jersey School Boards Association resigned under pressure of being dismissed tonight in a controversy over accusations that he abused his expense account and squandered association money on poor investments.

title: Computer Intruder Is Put on Probation And Fined $10,000
description: Saying the punishment of prison did not fit the crime, a Federal judge today placed a 24-year-old computer science student on three years' probation for intentionally disrupting a nationwide computer network. The student, Robert Tappan Morris, was also fined $10,000 and ordered to perform 400 hours of community service.

title: Mets Are Confused, Howard Johnson Says
description: Howard Johnson hid in the clubhouse at Shea Stadium Thursday night and avoided the media after making three errors as the Mets lost to the Cincinnati Reds, 5-0.

title: The Slow but Steady Progress In Stopping Tap-Water Burns
description: Every day, safety experts say, about 300 young children are taken to emergency rooms around the country suffering from burns caused by household water that is too hot. And annually, about 3,000 children are injured seriously enough in such accidents to require hospitalization.

title: Traffic Alert

title: Alan H. Shure Dies; Manufacturer Was 59
description: Alan H. Shure, co-founder, chairman and chief executive of the International Components Corporation, an electronics manufacturer based in Chicago, died Wednesday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, after a brief illness. He was 59 years old and lived in Chicago and Nederland, Colo.

Tony Lambert, 47, Sportswear Designer
description: Lionel Lambert, a clothing designer known professionally as Tony Lambert, died of complications from AIDS on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 47 years old. Mr. Lambert was born in Woonsocket, R.I., and began his fashion career as director of merchandising and design at Beaunit Textiles in New York City. In 1977, he formed Anton Knits, an independent production house, to manufacture knitwear for Seventh Avenue houses. Two years later he founded T/J Knit Enterprises to produce his own designs, which featured graphic sweaters in cotton, silk and linen.

title: Dressmaker, Make Me a . . . Tie
description: Some of the hottest-selling ties in the United States right now were created by a women's clothing maker that backed into what has become a $2 million business after deciding there had to be a way to use some leftover dress fabrics. And after circumstances both fortuitous and fortunate, the company, Nicole Miller Inc., found itself with a profitable sideline.

title: It's Down the Stretch for the Derby's Cordial Julep

title: Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.67 percent this week, their highest rate since May 1989, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. Last week they were at 10.56 percent. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.62 percent this week, up from 8.56 percent the week before.

title: Dr. Morris Stroud, 76, Specialist in Geriatrics
description: Dr. Morris Wistar Stroud 3d, a physician who developed new ways to help elderly patients recover from illness, died of cancer on Monday at his home. He was 76 years old. In the 1940's Dr. Stroud was among the first physicians to form teams of professionals, including counselors, to work with the family to improve a patient's life.

title: Knicks, Led by Ewing, Storm Past the Celtics
description: The Boston Celtics showed their age last night.

title: Interest Rates Fall On Job Data
description: Interest rates plunged yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities soared in response to news of an unexpectedly small increase in nonfarm employment in April. Only 64,000 non-farm jobs were added in April, and the unemployment rate rose by two-tenths of 1 percent, to 5.4 percent, its highest level in 15 months.

Friends Memorialize Keith Haring In Song and Playful Reminiscence
description: The artist Keith Haring was remembered by friends, other artists, performers and public officials during a memorial service yesterday afternoon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine. Mr. Haring died of AIDS on Feb. 16 at the age of 31.

title: The Americanization of Australia
description: LEAD: The newest talk show on Australian television features a host who jiggles his lapels, gets a drum roll whenever he waves his arm and likes to bring his staff on camera. He also reads a ''Top Seven'' list every night. He is, in other words, a David Letterman clone, right down to the coffee mug on his desk.

title: Another James Brady
description: The first James Brady has earned wide public respect. Working as President Reagan's press secretary in 1981, he stopped a bullet fired at Mr. Reagan by John Hinckley. The wound left Mr. Brady paralyzed, a condition he has struggled bravely to overcome.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Statesman Elected in Greece
description: Parliament elected Constantine Karamanlis as President today, making the 83-year-old conservative elder statesman the head of state for the next five years. Mr. Karamanlis mustered the support of 153 of the 300 deputies in Parliament - 2 more than the required minimum of 151. His New Democracy Party, now led by Constantine Mitsotakis, won a thin working majority in Parliament in elections last month. This is Mr. Karamanlis's second time as President, a post that under the Greek Constitution is largely ceremonial.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article in some copies yesterday about the Korean War Veterans Memorial in Washington misstated the way the project's sculptor will be chosen. The selection will be made by the architect, not the Army Corps of Engineers.

title: Dexter Gordon Memorial
description: A memorial tribute to the jazz saxophonist Dexter Gordon is to be held tomorrow from 4 to 6 P.M. at the Oberia Dempsey Community Center, 128 West 128th Street. Mr. Gordon died of kidney failure on April 25 at the age of 67.

title: Racial Graffiti Found on Walls At Wesleyan U.
description: A basement dining room in the building that houses Wesleyan University's Center for Afro-American Studies was defaced today by vandals who spray-painted racial slurs on its walls, further raising tensions on a campus that has had two firebombings in the last month.

title: Review/Music;   For a Forgotten Romantic
description: ''The Music of Forgotten Romantics'' is a slightly misleading title for the three-concert series that began Thursday night at Town Hall. This is a showcase primarily for the music of Emil Nikolaus Freiherr von Reznicek (1860-1945) and secondarily for the concert's conductor, Gordon Wright. Both emerge with distinction, although Mr. Wright may have a more promising future than Reznicek.

Switzerland's Figini Retires After Feud
description: Michela Figini of Switzerland, the youngest woman to win an Olympic downhill title and a two-time World Cup champion, has retired from racing after a bitter row with her coach, Jan Tischhauser. Figini, 24 years old, is the third prominent Swiss skier to give up the sport recently, following Maria Walliser and Pirmin Zurbriggen into retirement.

title: Red Sox Get Brunansky
description: The Boston Red Sox, badly in need of right-handed power, acquired Tom Brunansky from St. Louis yesterday for Lee Smith, who is expected to plug a hole in the Cardinals' bullpen.

title: Retarded Girl in Assault Case Was Taped
description: A mildly retarded teen-ager who the authorities say was sexually assaulted by a group of classmates in Glen Ridge 14 months ago has been tape-recorded, apparently secretly, while discussing the incident with a female acquaintance of two of the suspects.

title: The Talk of Little Italy;   A CHANGING LITTLE ITALY SAYS NO TO A HOTEL
description: Squeezed between Chinatown, SoHo and the tip of the government zone of lower Manhattan, Little Italy has always fought to hold its distinctive head high, acknowledging that parking on its narrow streets is next to impossible but proud that its crime rate is low and that the neighbors still know one another, usually three or four generations back.

title: Pulaski Furniture Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 15
description: Latest quarter comprises 12 weeks, and 6-month period, 24 weeks.

title: Kent State: In Memory of 4 Slain, 1970
description: Twenty years to the day after a 13-second burst of gunfire by Ohio National Guardsmen killed four students, injured nine others and became a landmark event in American history, Kent State University quietly dedicated a monument to the dead and wounded.

title: Mills Students Protesting Admission of Men
description: Enraged students took control of Mills College today, staging sit-ins and blockades that they vowed would continue until the trustees of the 138-year-old women's school reverse their decision, made Thursday, to admit men as undergraduates.

description: b-Net loss The company said last year's quarter was adversely affected by a one- time restructuring charge for STV-MichaelLynn Associates of $2,013,000.

title: We Russian Jews Fear for Our Lives
description: LEAD: Well, the moment that I have thought about all the time and expected to come has come. The Jews are in danger! Life has become fearful as never before.

title: 4 Quit Drug-Test Panel Of Athletics Congress
description: Just seven months after The Athletics Congress stepped up its vigilance against drug use in track and field by initiating a year-round testing program, four members of the organization's drug-testing committee, including the chairman, Edwin Moses, have resigned.

description: b-Included a $895,000 gain on the sale of Transtec Environmental, a specialized transportation company. c-Net loss

title: U.S. Denies Role in Trafficker's Death
description: The United States gave intelligence and training to the Colombian police officers who killed the leader of a cocaine trafficking ring in a raid in December, the Bush Administration said today. But officials denied a published report that American forces took part in that mission.

title: Review/Music;   Rediscovered Liszt Work in Premiere
description: In our musicology-minded age, Europe's libraries have been host to a benign infestation of bookworms. For the most part, these scholars burrow through dusty stacks in quest of information about past performance styles or evidence of how acknowledged masterworks came to be. Occasionally, the search yields an unexpected dividend in the form of a lost or unknown work by a great composer.

title: North Canadian Oils reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Banner Industries, Cleveland, a diversified industrial company, said it would sell its Thompson Aircraft Tire Corp. subsidiary for an undisclosed sum. Further details were not disclosed.

title: Review/Music;   Murray in Franck Marathon
description: Cesar Franck will be remembered in part as the man who brought the dreams and grandeur of the Romantic movement to the organ. Grandiloquence was always the instrument's second nature, but Franck's drifting, languid expository style and the richness of his chromatic harmony transformed ceremonial brilliance into something more personal.

title: ST. JOHN'S STUDENTS DENY ASSAULTING WOMAN
description: Three St. John's University students charged with sexually assaulting another student told the police that they were with the woman in the house where she says she was attacked, police reports obtained yesterday said. But they denied that any sexual assault took place, the reports said.

title: Polaris Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jean S. Picker, 69; Delegate to the U.N. In the 60's and 70's
description: Jean Sovatkin Picker, a former United States delegate to the United Nations, died yesterday at her home in Camden, Me., after a long illness. She was 69 years old.

title: Knick Defense Makes Celtics' Offense Wilts
description: The Knicks' defense was dreadful a week ago, but it was dominant last night. They harassed the Boston Celtics into 26 turnovers. They made 18 steals. And their constant pressure transformed Boston, a team that prides itself on poise, into a frazzled team that unraveled before a delirious crowd at Madison Square Garden.

title: About New York;   Saving a Species, Nest by Nest, On Breezy Point
description: The morning sun hasn't yet burned off the fog. The Empire State Building and the other wonders of the skyline remain undefined hulks somewhere in the middle distance.

title: Northeast Savings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary losses of $110,287,000 for the quarter and $109,351,000 for the year. Both periods included voluntary reduction of supervisory goodwill by $109.35 million, which resulted from recent regulatory and legislative actions that reduced the value of the company's Connecticut and Massachusetts franchises, including passage of the Connecticut interstate banking law; passage of Firrea by Congress and the associated OTS regulations that require a deduction from regulatory capital of all supervisory goodwill, and the deteriorating condition of the New England banking industry. The latest periods also reflected tax loss carryforwards. c-Net income d-After extraordinary tax loss carryforwards of $501,000, or 9 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,254,000, or 57 cents a share, for the year.

Results for 1989 have been reclassified to show ownership of Baroid Corp. by the equity method of accounting. The company said its earnings decline was due to a $6.2 million pretax gain in the first quarter of 1989 from the sale of business units, an $11 million expense in the latest quarter related to its solicitation of proxies for Lockheed Corp.'s annual meeting, an increase in interest expense in the latest quarter primarily due to new deutsche mark financing by NL Industries Inc., and a decline in NL earnings. NL is 66-percent owned by Valhi. The company said it recorded a $23.1 million charge to stockholders equity resulting from a decline in market value of the company's 19 percent holding in Lockheed.

description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $50,000 and income from an extraordinary credit of $503,000, or 1 cent a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: 2d Man Held in Bronx Killing
description: A second suspect was arrested yesterday in the killing of a gypsy-cab driver in the Bronx two weeks ago, the police said. The cabby, Mian Mohammed Salim, 48 years old, was the sixth gypsy-cab driver slain in the Bronx in seven weeks. He was shot in the head, apparently in a robbery. The suspect, Orlando Hernandez, 22, of 1197 Grand Concourse in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, turned himself in to the police in Miami.He is charged with second-degree murder.

title: Caught With $4 Million, Probationer Tied to Mob Gets 10-Year Term
description: A former private detective who has been linked to organized crime was given a 10-year prison sentence yesterday because he violated probation by taking a mysterious trip with almost $4 million.

title: Power Struggle Said to Surround Redistricting of New York City
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins's seven appointees on the commission that is to re-draw district lines next year for an expanded New York City Council are trying to wrest the chairmanship of the commission from the eight Council appointees, people involved in the struggle said yesterday.

title: Gibson Greetings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sotheby's Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Lagging African Economies Perplex Aid Organizations
description: Even though aid programs pump $15 billion a year into sub-Saharan Africa, the living standards of the region's 450 million people have declined in the 30-odd years since its independence.

title: Dovima, a Regal Model of the 50's, Is Dead at 63
description: Dovima, the model whom Richard Avedon called ''the most remarkable and unconventional beauty of her time,'' died of cancer on Thursday at her home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 63 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: America's first astronauts were men in their 30's. By the late 1960's men in their 40's were making space voyages and with the joint American-Soviet space rendezvous in 1975, the first astronaut in his 50's went into space. Now the 60-year-old age barrier is on the verge of falling. On Wednesday, VANCE BRAND will be 59 years old; one week later, he is to command the space shuttle Columbia for a 9- or 10-day space trip during which he and other astronauts will put into orbit telescopes to retrieve scientific data on the universe as part of the $100 million Astro program.

title: Northstar Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/City Ballet;   New From Martins: 'Symmetries'
description: How can a ballet company dance so unbelievably well? Somebody must be doing something right at the New York City Ballet - providing, for instance, blazing challenges to the dancers in new ballets like ''Fearful Symmetries.''

title: Blackhawks Tie Series
description: Doug Wilson's tie-breaking goal with 1 minute 59 seconds remaining led the Chicago Blackhawks to a 4-3 victory over the Edmonton Oilers tonight, tying their four-of-seven-game National Hockey League playoff series at a game apiece.

title: Milton S. Gelman, 70, A Writer of TV Shows
description: Milton S. Gelman, a writer and producer for television and film, died on Wednesday after complications from heart surgery at Sherman Oaks Community Hospital in Sherman Oaks, Calif., where he lived. He was 70 years old.

title: Germain Bazin Dead; Ex-Louvre Curator, 88
description: Germain Bazin, an art historian and the former chief curator of paintings at the Louvre, died on Thursday, the Academie des Beaux Arts announced. He was 88 years old.

title: Sun to Present New Computer
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. is expected to announce on May 15 a new computer work station priced below $5,000.

title: Reed Huppman Weds Miss Wolfe
description: Susan Terrell Wolfe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. Wolfe of New Orleans, was married there yesterday at the St. Charles Avenue Presbyterian Church to Louis Reed Huppman Jr., a son of Mrs. Kenneth B. Marty of Ruxton, Md., and the late Mr. Huppman. The Rev. Dr. James Leighton Carter performed the ceremony.

title: Greyhound Lines Has Large Loss
description: Hobbled by a drivers' strike now in its ninth week, Greyhound Lines Inc. said today that it lost $55.8 million in the quarter ended March 31, forcing it to postpone certain debt payments and to tighten operations to conserve cash.

title: Hughes Suit Withdrawn
description: The Hughes Aircraft Company, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said today that a former Defense Department official had withdrawn a $360 million ''whistle blower'' lawsuit, contending that the company overcharged the Government for work done by a division that builds air military and air traffic control systems.

title: George H. Armacost, Educator, 84
description: George H. Armacost, who was president of the University of Redlands in California from 1945 to 1970, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Bay Front Medical Center in St. Petersburg, Fla. He was 84 years old and lived in St. Petersburg.

title: Time To Be Steady
description: It is hard to account for the dramatic shifts in American moods.

title: Vote at Rorer
description: Shareholders of Rorer Group Inc., fulfilling a condition of Rorer's planned merger with Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France, voted to exempt the company from certain antitakeover provisions. In addition, Rhone-Poulenc's $78-a-share offer, worth a total of $3.2 billion, for 50.1 percent of Rorer, based in Fort Washington, Pa., was extended until Saturday from today.

title: Lawyers, Not Slaves, for the Poor
description: Ideally the law is a calling, not just a business run by and for lawyers. The ethical canons of the bar are designed in part to self-govern the profession and stave off government regulation. As one way of doing so they call on lawyers to represent not only paying clients but also those who can't afford their fees. Many lawyers and firms do that, but most do nothing, prompting New York to consider becoming the first state to turn that admonition into a binding legal duty.

title: George W. Latimer IS Dead at 89; Lawyer In My Lai Massacre Trial
description: George W. Latimer, a former Justice of the Utah Supreme Court who defended Lieut. William L. Calley Jr. in the court-martial arising from the My Lai massacre in Vietnam, died on Wednesday in a Salt Lake City nursing home. He was 89 years old. In 1946, Mr. Latimer was elected to the Utah Supreme Court, where he served five years until he was appointed by President Harry S. Truman to a 10-year term as an associate judge on the United States Court of Military Appeals in Washington.

title: Celebrations For Lennon Start Tonight
description: Celebrations of what would have been John Lennon's 50th birthday, on Oct. 9, and commemorations of the 10th anniversary of his murder, on Dec. 8, are being planned by Yoko Ono, Lennon's widow, and Cynthia Lennon, the musician's first wife. Their separate endeavors have reportedly strained relations between the two Mrs. Lennons, who have been on cordial terms in recent years, although both insist that stories of bitterness are exaggerated.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Smorgasbord Of a Jazzfest
description: Tens of thousands of people descend on the New Orleans Fairgrounds each year for the Jazz and Heritage Festival. The Jazzfest, as everyone here calls it, comprises two weekends of music on a dozen stages around the field. Between the stages, stands sell the greatest fast food in America, including Creole stuffed bread (smoky with Acadian andouille sausage), alligator gumbo, crayfish etouffe and oyster po' boy sandwiches. The 21st annual festival winds up this Sunday, and its last six hours, from 2 to 8 P.M. Eastern daylight time, are to be broadcast live on many public radio stations in a program distributed by WGBH in Boston. (It is not being broadcast live in the New York area.) The radio people will need a detailed itinerary, fast footwork and considerable serendipity to capture the joyful abundance of a festival that's intended to be simply too much of many good things. On the opening weekend, I found the festival to be its usual mixture of easy pleasures and tough choices. From 11:30 A.M. to 7 P.M. there are continually overlapping sets of brass-band music, zydeco, jazz, blues, rock, Caribbean music, rhythm-and-blues, Mardi Gras Indian chants, country, Cajun music, African rock, even rap - all the strands of Louisiana's popular music along with selected offshoots and influences.

title: Review/Music;   Van Cliburn Medalist At Carnegie
description: Winning a major competition at an early age can be a blessing for a musician who possesses enough talent to take immediate advantage of the glaring light that shines on such success. There is also a danger, however, that too much will be expected of the young artist, too soon. In most instances, the contest winner's chief concerns as a student and contestant have been to play the notes in the right sequence and to impress teachers and judges with a fluent technique. That is a first step on a long road.

description: Perhaps one of the oldest and most wrongheaded cliches to gain popularity is that ''necessity is the mother of invention.'' Reality, more often than not, is almost exactly the reverse: Invention is the mother of necessity.

He died four hours later.

title: Sheldon D. Murphy, Toxicologist, 56

He was 56 years old, Professor Murphy, who joined the university faculty in 1983, was chairman of environmental health at its School of Public Health and Community Medicine. He received a doctorate in pharmacology at the University of Chicago and had been an official with the National Public Health Service.

title: Volkert to Replace Behrens

Miss Behrens was injured by falling scenery at the end of last Saturday night's performance of the same opera and had to withdraw from ''Die Walkure'' on Tuesday night and ''Siegfried'' on Thursday. Miss Volkert replaced her in both operas.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Investment Mixtures
description: Individual investment portfolios should be reviewed regularly because market conditions and individual goals change. In general, stocks increase immediate wealth, while debt securities like bonds, certificates of deposit and debentures, provide future income. Now, in the second quarter of the year, many strategists still favor stocks for the lead component in portfolios. Rising interest rates, however, have made debt securities a little more attractive in relation to stocks in this quarter. Triumph of Spite, Retribution and a Cat
description: ''Tales From the Darkside'' is subtitled ''The Movie'' because tales like these are so familiar in other forms: as campfire stories, horror comics, television shows (with less gruesome special effects) and novels by Stephen King, one of whose stories is the basis for an episode here. So nothing about ''Tales From the Darkside'' is likely to give anyone much of a scare. But thanks to casting that is savvier than the horror norm, and to direction by John Harrison that is workmanlike and sometimes even witty, at least it's fun.
