title: U.S. Tobacco Ads in Asia Faulted
description: American cigarettes are advertised illegally in Asia, including ads on the covers of children's school notebooks, on kites and on chewing gum packages, witnesses told the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today.

title: Special Retail Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $26,000 and $32,000, or 1 cent a share, for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Chaus (Bernard) Inc (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included $2.5 million tax credit.

title: In Europe: What's America's Place?
description: President Bush faced up to the inevitable this week - but it's barely a start if he's to meet the two great challenges in Europe, a rising Germany and a declining Soviet Union.

title: 3 GET JAIL TERMS IN PRISON KILLING
description: A jury today sentenced three former law enforcement officers, all of them white, to prison sentences ranging from 10 to 28 years for the murder of a black man who was severely beaten in an East Texas jail.

title: Claim of Church Based on Sex Is Ruled Out
description: A Federal judge on Thursday rejected a couple's contention that their Church of the Most High Goddess, a religion based on sex, was protected by the Constitution and was thus immune from the enforcement of vice laws.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-6

title: Yankees, Regaining Some Punch, Beat Langston
description: They left home without much more than a horrendous losing streak, but tonight the Yankees momentarily stopped their dive. On the first night of a nine-game trip through the West, they beat Mark Langston and appeared to regain their power. But how long will it last?

title: Mason Hale, 61, Dies; Smithsonian Botanist
description: Mason E. Hale, a botanist at the Smithsonian Institution who was known internationally, died of cancer on Monday at his home in Arlington, Va. He was 61 years old.

title: Eagle Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Eagle Financial said its second quarter earnings included a writeoff of $272,000 from a foreclosed participation loan and expenses of $450,000 related to termination of a proposed merger agreement with Webster Financial Corp.

title: Brazil Vows To Be Firm In Debt Talks
description: Presenting a tough negotiating stance on the eve of a visit to Washington, Brazil's new Economy Minister has ruled out paying overdue interest payments to smooth talks with private creditor banks.

title: Merrily We Role Along
description: First, you had to have a hero.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Millions of people are expected to attend as POPE JOHN PAUL II celebrates the first mass of his Mexican trip tomorrow at the Basilicia of Our Lady of Guadalupe in Mexico City. PLACIDO DOMINGO is to sing two songs at the mass, during which the Pope will beatify several Mexicans. ''Placido offered and his offer to sing was gladly accepted,'' said a seminary student at the church. After about 24 hours in the Mexican capital, the Pope will begin a tour of 10 Mexican cities before leaving the country May 13.

title: Dallas Waives Dantley
description: In accordance with an agreement reached in January, the Dallas Mavericks yesterday placed Adrian Dantley, the 10th-highest scorer in National Basketball Association history, on waivers. Dantley, who is 34 years old and has scored 23,120 points in 14 seasons, is now an unrestricted free agent and free to sign with any club without compensation to the Mavericks.(AP)

title: North Stars Lose Coach
description: Pierre Page, coach of the Minnesota North Stars, was named general manager of the Quebec Nordiques yesterday, replacing Maurice Filion, who was hired on an interim basis last Feb. 2, when Martin Madden was let go.

title: KEY RATES
Ignorance of 'L.A. Law' Is No Excuse for Lawyers
description: One Friday last December, David F. Ennis, a lawyer in Miami Beach, Fla., found himself with a novel but serious problem: The case he was handling was about to go to the jury, and Mr. Ennis had just learned, to his consternation, that the episode of NBC's ''L.A. Law'' broadcast the night before was strikingly similar to his client's malpractice suit. Given ''L.A. Law's'' consistently high ratings in its four years on the air, Mr. Ennis knew it was a good bet that several of the jurors had watched the episode. Worse still, for him at least, the fictitious doctor defendant in the show had been acquitted.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Town Houses in Suffolk for the Affluent
description: LEAD: THE well-to-do homeowner wishing to sell a large house and move into a self-contained community providing services and security, and the affluent professional couple looking for the same thing, have been the mainstays of the high-priced town-house market in Nassau County.

title: 'Free' Europe Embraces That Radio and Its Mate
description: The waves that have swept the countries that until last fall formed the Soviet bloc are also touching a deceptively simple-looking squat building that faces the Englische Garten, a well-tended park here.

title: Miss Betts Marries Michael Woolaway
description: Catherine Williams Betts and Michael Wayne Woolaway were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Portola Valley, Calif. The bride's father, the Venerable Darby W. Betts, a retired Archdeacon of the Diocese of California, performed the ceremony.

title: Flowers That Are Not for Picking
description: Recent regulations restrict the sale of ivory in hopes of saving the elephants. Wildlife biologists raise black-footed ferrets in an attempt to restore an almost extinct species. But what of the plight of wild plants?

title: Reviews/Dance;   La Fosse In 'Square Dance' Solo
description: All balletomanes have their lists of irrevocable losses. The mother's first-act mime in ''Giselle'' seems to have gone by the wayside, for instance, and so have renverse turns with a true deep backward dip. Another loss is the caller in George Balanchine's 1957 ''Square Dance,'' whose lilting rhymes to the Vivaldi music underscored the wit of the choreographer's juxtaposition of American vernacular dance with classical music and ballet.

title: His Editor, Not His Agent
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Run for Your Wife,' an Off-Color Joke
description: IN ''Run for Your Wife,'' the English farce by Ray Cooney now at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, John Smith, a taxi driver, is having a very, very bad morning.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Chester
description: ''CHESTER is not chic; that's why I like it,'' said Morley Safer, correspondent and co-editor of television's ''60 Minutes,'' who spends weekends at his home in Chester. ''It really is in so many ways rural America. My greatest fear is of seeing a candle shop open.''

title: A New Europe Comes Into Focus For George Bush
description: LIKE a man running to catch a train that is accelerating out of the station, President Bush keeps falling behind the breathtaking pace of events in Europe. To catch up, he has had to keep altering his ideas on the future of that continent, and the role the United States can play there in the decades to come.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Wrestling Offers Wagnerian Drama (Body Slams, Too)
description: LEAD: I WAS browsing through the jazz section in Strawberry's Music Store one Saturday afternoon ago with my friend Pete, a high school history teacher and a shameless fan of professional wrestling. He was laying it on thick about pile drivers and muscle tone and real athletes. I didn't say anything, but I was thinking: ''This is pathetic.

title: Life and Death On 129th Street    A special report.;   In Harlem, Death Is an Old and Busy Neighbor
description: Fred Quinn, a butcher when he can find work, has lost three brothers to the Harlem streets before they reached middle age.

title: Tech Notes;   Envisioning Peak Performance
description: For years coaches have used high-speed motion pictures as training aids. Now, video technology has been combined with computers and tiny sensors that monitor muscle movements to give a far more detailed analysis of human motion. According to Gary L. Scheirman, manager of biomechanics at Peak Performance Technologies Inc. in Englewood, Colo., a new system developed by his company uses a high-speed shutter and a video camera to capture images of an athlete in action. At 2,000 frames a second, the camera is fast enough to divide the video image of a movement into hundreds of sequential pictures. The computer digitally converts these pictures into simplified stick figures (left, person lifting box) to make it easier to follow the movements of the various muscle groups. Data from electromyographic sensors attached to the body are fed into the computer and matched to the image on the screen. This provides information about whether the muscles are contracting or lengthening at precisely the right times for peak performance. The system, which costs $20,000 to $60,000, depending on its configuration, can also be used to monitor muscle performance during rehabilitation programs and to fit artificial limbs.

title: Survivors Of Crash Fight To Regain Normal Lives
description: PLACIDO CRUZ MARTIN does not remember much of the night of Jan. 25, when the Avianca passenger jet crashed in Cove Neck.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Will Dent And Johnson Last the Season?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title: R. M. Hecht Weds Beth A. Posnack
description: At the Pearl River (N.Y.) Hilton yesterday evening, Beth Allyson Posnack, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Posnack of Airmont, N.Y., was married to Robert Morris Hecht, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Hecht of Grand Rapids, Mich., and Vail, Colo. Rabbi Louis Frishman performed the ceremony.

title: ACCEPTANCE OF FATNESS IS SOUGHT
description: LEAD: Maryann Sorby weighs 285 pounds. She said she was ''happy and healthy'' and secure in her position as a quality-assurance controller at a local hospital.

title: THE BACTERIA WRITE THEIR OWN TICKET
description: A GUIDE TO GAIA

title: For G.M., The Bad News Is Pretty Good
description: When is a 54 percent cut in profits good news? When it's from General Motors.

title: Taking His Ballet Home
description: Gerald Arpino said he was resigning as artistic director of the Joffrey Ballet on Tuesday, and taking his dances with him. Mr. Arpino also withdrew from the repertory the works of Robert Joffrey, the company's founder, who died in 1988, naming Mr. Arpino executor of his ballets. By the end of the week, Mr. Arpino was negotiating with the Joffrey's representatives, and his lawyer said that the company, which is in the midst of its Los Angeles season, could continue staging the Arpino works currently on the program while the talks continued. Mr. Arpino resigned after the board of directors in New York City voted to establish a nine-member operating committee for the Joffrey, which has a deficit of $2 million. The proposal would effectively strip Mr. Arpino and the 55-member board of power. Some board members felt the streamlining was a precondition to the Joffrey's receiving assistance from its co-chairman, David H. Murdock, who has agreed to meet the deficit by gifts, loans and fund raising during the next three years.

title: Charlene Corbett Weds Victor Tosi
description: The marriage of Charlene Denise Corbett and Victor Steven Tosi took place yesterday at Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church on Gun Hill Road in the Bronx. The Rev. Robert Grix performed the ceremony.

title: If the World's a Stage, A Theater Can Be Home
description: A few Friday nights ago, Erik La Prade climbed three flights of stairs to the West 30th Street loft that is both home and theater for Doloris Holmes. For a contribution ($6 was suggested), he and some four dozen others saw ''Fish Joy and the Goddess of Red Mud,'' a play written by, directed by and starring Miss Holmes. The next Friday, Mr. La Prade, who is 38 years old, journeyed farther down Manhattan to Duane Street and up five flights of stairs to the home-cabaret of Tom Weiss. For his $4 contribution, Mr. La Prade joined some 60 or so others who got to hear Louis X's Nightmare, a three-piece (guitar, bass and percussion) group; a two-piece blues act, and an orator-poet. Guests wandered into the kitchen for free munchies; they were on the honor system when it came to paying for beverages - beer, wine and soft drinks.

title: Social Events
description: Evening at Juilliard

title: Does Affirmative Action Work?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ann Gibbons Marries
description: Ann Eileen Gibbons, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James T. Gibbons of Mantoloking, N.J., was married yesterday to Gregg Peter Helbock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James W. Helbock of Cold Spring, N.Y. Msgr. William E. Maguire performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Bay Head, N.J. Mrs. Helbock, 32 years old, graduated from Rosemont College and is an assistant vice president in the direct investment department at Paine Webber in Weehawken, N.J. The bridegroom, 30, is a vice president of research sales at Paine Webber in New York. He graduated from Haverford College.

title: The Pleasures of Poland
description: Later on we'll get to the problems of Poland but for at least a few paragraphs, let's just talk about the pleasures of Poland.

title: Allison J. Bloom Wed in Stamford
description: Allison Joy Bloom, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Bloom of New York and Easton, Conn., was married yesterday to Dick K. Murchison Jr., a son of Donna Murchison of Melbourne, Fla., and Dick K. Murchison Sr. of Danbury, Conn. The Rev. Walter H. Everett performed the ceremony at the Stamford (Conn.) Marriott Hotel.

title: The Fight for a Place on the Beach Is Getting Rougher and Rougher
description: AS waterfront condominiums and marinas spread along the sandy beaches and rocky shores of the New York metropolitan region, the battle to broaden public access to the beachfront has become a fight over a shrinking and highly coveted natural resource. It pits property owners against day trippers and shoreline residents against inland dwellers. With the summer season fast approaching, the fighting once again is kicking up sand in several places.

title: Brighteners For Beachgoers
description: Exuberant accessories that celebrate themselves will be turning up at the water's edge this summer.

title: PUTTING DOWN ROOTS
description: FOR A WHILE NOW, I'VE been thinking about planting a tree - a real tree. It's not that I haven't planted trees before, but all of these have been minor ones, lightweights really, the kind of trees you can justify in the short term: white pines to screen the road, dwarf fruit trees, a crab apple or two, a tree hydrangea and a pair of Salix babylonica, the Tree of Immediate Gratification, otherwise known as the weeping willow. This, for a long time, was my idea of a tree: something I could pick up for $29.99 at the nursery, stuff in the rear of the hatchback, jam into any old hole, and then just about watch the thing grow. In less than three years my hatchback-sized willows had blown themselves up to the size of hot-air balloons.

title: Ms. Mok Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Laura Mok, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Yuen Mok of New York, to Dr. Mark Richard Anderson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard A. Anderson of Katonah, N.Y., took place yesterday at the Stonehenge Inn in Ridgefield, Conn. Deborah O. Stiewing, a justice of the peace of Newtown, Conn., officiated. Mrs. Anderson, 31 years old and a graduate of Barnard College, was until recently a vice president and shareholder at Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York. The bridegroom, 31, is a fellow in cardiology at St. Elizabeth's Hospital in Boston. He graduated from Harvard University and the Albert Einstein College of Medicine at Yeshiva University.

title: Even in Connecticut, There's Gold in the Hills
description: LEAD: WHEN John Hiller prospects for gold in Connecticut streams, he depends on nature's clues, topographical maps and 20 years' experience finding promising sites.

title: Walking on the Trail of Lord Byron
description: FROM childhood, I have loved walking and reading, ideally in close conjunction. A loaf of bread, a jug of wine? For me, a book and a backpack are enough. Especially if I can walk in the footsteps of one of my favorite authors.

title: Shadow on Arms Talks: Threat of Soviet Turmoil
description: While NATO ministers meeting in Europe this week have tried to maintain a business-as-usual demeanor toward Moscow, they are privately whispering about the possibilty that the Soviet Union could collapse into political turmoil before new arms-control deals are completed.

title: The Maggots in Communism's Decay
description: A specter of unbridled bigotry haunts the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Ethnic Turks face persecution in Bulgaria. So do gypsies in Hungary; so does Transylvania's Hungarian community in Romania.

title: A FEMINIST TAKES STOCK
description: Judging from your cover photograph (five white women), and the article's straight, white, New York orientation, one could draw the mistaken conclusion that feminism has not had an impact on public consciousness about homophobia, ageism, class, racism.

title: Elton H. Rule, 73, ABC President Who Led Network to Dominance
description: Elton H. Rule, a former president of the American Broadcasting Companies whose management pioneered mini-series, made-for-television movies and Monday night football and led the ailing company to network dominance in the late 1970's, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif. He was 73 years old.

title: A Soviet Appetite for U.S. Knowhow
description: I have been doing business in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe for more than 20 years. I know the Soviet Union quite well. Last October, when I was in Moscow trying to sell American computer technology to the Soviets, the director of one of the large departments of a ministry chastised me by saying: ''You Americans are late. Two Europeans have already submitted their bids.''

title: A Case for Selling N.Y.C.'s Airports
description: In its current economic mess, New York City can learn a lesson from the corner bodega owner. He will tell you: ''You need cash? The worst thing to do is raise prices and cut services. The best thing to do is trim inventory.'' The city should heed that advice and sell two major city-owned assets: John F. Kennedy and La Guardia airports.

title: David Nixon to Wed Elizabeth Johnson
description: Elizabeth Cooke Johnson and David Christopher Nixon, 1982 graduates of Princeton University, are planning a September wedding, the parents of the bride-to-be, Mr. and Mrs. Hallett Johnson Jr. of Princeton, N.J., have announced. Mr. Nixon is a son of James T. Nixon of Kansas City, Mo., and Dorothy Jane Nixon of Prairie Village, Kan.

title: A Medical Wonder That Isn't - Yet
description: A few years back, investors were flocking to a new medical technology involving microscopic bubbles called liposomes. Composed of molecules of fatty acids, liposomes promised a way to administer drugs that ordinarily are too toxic to take in heavy doses.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Water seeps through the concrete floor of my basement. This problem has developed near where valving was installed for an automatic sprinkling system. The system, buried two feet deep near where the puddling occurs, does not leak. Applying a waterproof sealer to the floor did not help. Any suggestions?

title: Kristin Kylander Wed To Eric Douglas Adams
description: Kristin Anne Kylander and Eric Douglas Adams, medical students at the University of Pittsburgh, were married yesterday at the Pilgrim Congregational Church in Duxbury, Mass. The Rev. Kenneth Landall and the Rev. Stephen Turrell performed the ceremony.

title: IS IT TRUE WHAT HE SAYS ABOUT DIXIE?
description: Peter Applebome seems to miss the point. Grizzard's ''shtick'' is not ''that he's the ultimate confused man, trying to live by old values in a changing world.'' Grizzard is no more or less confused than any active alcoholic. He's stuck. He doesn't express what he feels, which is one reason Pat Conroy had to ''translate'' what he meant.

title: A Soviet Crew Gains Support
description: Twenty-two resplendent yachts, ready for racing after a three-and-a-half week layover in balmy Florida, set off for England today in the last leg of the Whitbred Round the World Race.

title: Meg Ehrenkranz Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ira F. Ehrenkranz have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Meg Ehrenkranz, and David S. Eiten, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Myles Eiten of Great Neck, L.I. Miss Ehrenkranz, 26 years old, graduated from Syracuse University and is the office manager at Harmat Homes, a building company in Westhampton Beach, L.I. Her fiance, 27, is the vice president of Harmat. He received an undergraduate degree and an M.B.A. from George Washington University.

title: Cuomo, to Break Impasse, Holds Up Checks
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo moved today to force action on a new state budget that is already five weeks late by refusing to approve emergency legislation authorizing paychecks for 150,000 state workers.

title: BRIDGE
description: The next world team championships for the Bermuda Bowl, scheduled in Yokohama, Japan, in September 1991 will have an enlarged format: 16 teams. For most of its early years there were just two teams. Eight months ago in Perth, Australia, there were 10 teams. The Venice Trophy contest for Women's Teams will be similarly enlarged. The championships will also eliminate a bias in favor of Europeans and Americans that caused some discord. Until Brazil was victorious in Perth, European and American teams won every Bermuda Bowl.This was due in part because the top European team and the top American team were exempt from qualifying play.

title: Innovative Southwestern Fare at Its Best
description: AN unlikely, almost unbelievable adobe hacienda, complete with views of the water, has taken root in Island Park. Coyote Grill is unbelievable in another respect: its food is almost too good to be true.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT'S been 28 years since Rachel Carson published ''Silent Spring,'' the book that forced a reluctant public to see the dark side of chemical insect control. A chemical agent, DDT, was being used to control agricultural pests and nuisance insects (like mosquitoes). It was also quietly and inexorably killing off birds, moving the world closer to the ''silent spring.

title: Earth Day Puffery and Hubris
description: To the Editor:

title: Overcharges Found on Extended Car-Repair Deals
description: Automobile dealers in New York State are overcharging consumers more than $25 million a year by selling them extended-service contracts at prices substantially above those suggested by car manufacturers, State Attorney General Robert Abrams says.

title: Review/Recital;   From Bach to Schnittke By Heinrich Schiff, a Cellist
description: Heinrich Schiff is a cellist of reassuring solidity. There is no part of his technique not firmly in place. Intonation, color, steadiness of bow - all gave Wednesday's audience at the 92d Street Y the feeling that no matter how trying the technical problems, how exhausting the demands of concentration, the music would emerge whole and satisfying.

title: Traveling Isn't Child's Play
description: I TAPED a big road map of Italy to our kitchen wall. Each day I asked our children to point out the spots where we would be staying. Roma, Gubbio, Sicilia. Friends warned us that the kids were a little young for a backpacking adventure - Rhodes, just 3, and Metthea, 5. But Ali and I were eager to get back to the country that had intoxicated us on an earlier, childless trip.

title: Q and A
description: Cruising the Amazon

title: For This Class On Shakespeare, Play's the Thing
description: Hugh Richmond gives no midterms or final exams in his ''Shakespeare in the Theater'' class at the University of California at Berkeley. For this English professor's students, all the world's a stage, and his students are the players.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article on April 22 about the Childrenswear Center in A. & S. Plaza misidentified its architect. It was Carol Groh & Associates.

title: COLONEL BASHOV'S RAGE
description: THE HAND

title: PLAYING TO OUR STRENGTHS
description: AMERICA'S ECONOMIC RESURGENCE

title: Math Professor Fights University Over Class Load
description: Frank Cannonito is a 63-year-old math professor at the University of California at Irvine, and he has not published much lately. But he is not about to let his career perish either.

title: Susan Beth Cohen Wed in Minnesota
description: Susan Beth Cohen, a freelance writer and editor in New York, and Thomas Barry Ginsberg, an editor with The Associated Press in New York, were married last evening in Minneapolis. Rabbi Daniel Wolk, a cousin of the bride, and Rabbi Stephen Pinsky officiated at Temple Israel.

title: Purchase Campus Plays Host to Broadway Stars
description: Since the middle of March, the State University of New York at Purchase has been astir with the sounds of a big, splashy musical. That was when rehearsals began for ''Kiss of the Spider Woman,'' and now the well-known theatrical names connected with the show have become familiar figures on the campus here.

title: Wall Street;   The Fearless Analyst, Following the Chart
description: Remember Marvin Roffman, the fearless analyst at Janney Montgomery Scott who was dismissed after Donald Trump protested his cautious views on the Atlantic City gaming industry? It's time for the first Marvin Roffman Award, and it goes to Jeffrey W. Casdin of Oppenheimer & Company.

title: After 50 Years, Her First Derby Victory
description: Frances A. Genter received her marching orders this winter in Florida. Or rather her flying orders. Carl Nafzger, the man who trains her race horses, gave her this ultimatum: ''We will get you a box with a television, but you are going to the Kentucky Derby,'' with the emphasis on the ''are.''

title: Autumn Wedding For Miss Travers
description: The engagement of Constance Lynn Travers to Robert Andrew Masinter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edgar M. Masinter of White Plains, has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Arthur Travers and Mrs. Rodman Smythe, both of Boulder, Colo. An October wedding is planned.

title: Beauty/Fashion;   Shades Of Difference
description: Something had to give. After years of living with brown lipstick, taupe eyeshadow, imperceptible blusher and transparent mascara, a little visible makeup comes as a relief. Pale, powdery pink, faint peach, light banana and - would you believe it - light blue are being revived in fashion and in makeup. Just as all-black uniform dressing suddenly looks dour, brown and beige lipstick seems unnecessarily dreary. Makeup artists are turning to Doris Day in ''That Touch of Mink,'' Jane Fonda in ''Barbarella,'' Faye Dunaway in ''Bonnie and Clyde'' and other spunky stars of the 1960's as inspiration. ''It's the 60's brought into the 90's,'' says Sonia Kashuk, a makeup artist based in New York. These new makeup colors are pale, but not overly white. Most are matte rather than frosted. Their names - heliotrope, saffron, mango, banana, tender blue, pink dawn, rose caprice - float like a fresh spring breeze.

title: The Skill and Excitement of Car Racing, on a Small Scale
description: TWO brothers from Browns Mills in Burlington County, Ed and Tony Angiuoli, have found a new way of making friends.

title: Complaints Rising Against Lawyers
description: LEAD: MORE Long Islanders are complaining about lawyers than ever before, and they have more reason to grumble, according to a state watchdog committee that has been fielding complaints for 14 years.

title: No Headline
description: The harsh plains of North Dakota, with their sparse population and conservative sensibilities, have always presented a hostile landscape for women seeking abortions.

title: Corrections
description: A review on April 22 about the exhibition ''Theater on Paper'' at the Drawing Center misstated the closing date. It is July 21.

title: Lessons to Learn From Vietnam
description: Our involvement in Vietnam must be a subject in every school and college [''What Should Schools Teach About Vietnam?'' March 25] . However, I would suggest that the instructor begin and end the course on Vietnam with the fact that our Government and people were abysmally ignorant of the subject when the decision was made to get involved.

title: Layne S. Ridley Marries
description: Layne Schmidt Ridley and Deane Mann Evans Jr. were married yesterday at the Tabard Inn in Washington. Judith Toth, a leader of the Washington Ethical Society, officiated. Mrs. Evans is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Willard Schmidt of Norman, Okla. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Evans of Darien, Conn. The bride, a graduate of the University of Oklahoma, is a writer. The bridegroom is an architect and the director of the Council on Architectural Research of the American Institute of Architects in Washington. He graduated from Yale University and received a master's degree in architecture from Columbia University.

title: Fossils to Footwear In Santa Monica
description: SANTA MONICA is moving up in the world. Once a sleepy little city at the beach end of the freeway, it's now the site of some of the most expensive real estate in Southern California. The past five years have brought a rush of high-gloss development projects like the Santa Monica Museum of Art, Loews Santa Monica Beach Hotel and the newly renovated Third Street Promenade.

title: 60 Miles From Broadway, History Trod the Boards
description: JESSICA TANDY and Marlon Brando sent regrets. But Mary Martin accepted the invitation. And when the Shubert Theater in New Haven celebrates its 75th anniversary on Saturday, Ms. Martin is expected to enter grandly, singing ''My Heart Belongs to Daddy.''

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Can One Pet Replace Another?
description: LEAD: THREE days after Julie died, I decided to buy a fish. A bird would be too jumpy. Julie had been a self-contained presence, like a fish.

title: Anti-Semitic Slogans Painted On Brecht's Grave in Berlin
description: The graves of Bertolt Brecht and his wife have been vandalized and smeared with anti-Semitic slogans, the official East German press agency said today.

title: THE FABULOUS BUSH & BAKER BOYS
description: SCENE 1: THE OVAL OFFICE - A foreign leader is about to arrive at the White House. The flags of the visiting nation ripple down Pennsylvania Avenue. The Secretary of State hurries in to brief the President.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: LOS ANGELES;

Review Board Scuttles Design
description: LEAD: THE rejection of a high-rise condominium proposal because of its design has focused attention on the growing influence here of citizen review panels. The Westwood Design Review Board turned down three designs as inappropriate for the neighborhood and now the developer, Paul Amir, has decided to sell the site.

title: STAMPS
description: With the flood of new issues from new countries in recent years, many hobbyists have drifted away from the old routine of collecting one copy of every stamp as it comes out. Two new handbooks can help enliven a collection of new issues: ''Linn's U.S. Stamp Yearbook 1989'' and ''Topical New Issues of 1989'' from the American Topical Association.

title: Ability to Pay Becomes Factor in Admissions
description: Smith College has ended its system of admitting students without regard to their ability to pay.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a review on April 8 about recordings of English music misstated the relationship between Ralph Vaughan Williams and Hubert Parry and misattributed the composition ''Toward the Unknown Region.'' Parry was Vaughan Williams's teacher, not the reverse. The composition is by Vaughan Williams.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: HEALTH AND BLACK MEN

title: 'Summit' on Balderdash Mountain
description: Today is shaping up to be a witches' sabbath here. The top Congressional leaders will huddle with President Bush and numbers wizard Richard Darman to attempt to spike the budget brew. If past experience is any guide, the objective of this non-summit ''summit'' conference will be to concoct the right mix of lizard's tail and newt's eye to put the American people to sleep until after the election. We must not allow that to happen.

title: Summertime, and the Learning Is Easy
description: LEAD: In looking ahead to summer, Westchester parents can choose from among many activities for children and young people to fill the summer break. In addition to general-interest camps, community-sponsored recreation programs and day camps, there is a wide variety of specialized programs in which young people can learn new skills or hone existing ones.

title: Miss McLoughlin Becomes a Bride
description: The wedding of Marianne McLoughlin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. McLoughlin of Rye, N.Y., and John Michael Marquardt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Marquardt of Glencoe, Ill., took place yesterday at the Union Church in Pocantico Hills, N.Y. The Rev. Robert F. Dorer, a minister of the Reformed Church in America, performed a Presbyterian ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John J. Foley, a Roman Catholic priest..

title: Lifting Restraints on TV Networks Would Kill Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: Hard Time
description: It may be a government of laws and not men, but New York's interest in the sentencing of Marsha Cohen had almost everything to do with who she is. Marsha Cohen is a dentist who treats AIDS patients and who, in a detour from middle-class life, slept on rooftops and helped break into apartments to support her heroin habit. Those circumstances were enough to give a judge pause, but then there was also the question of what would happen to her patients, many of whom have been turned away by other dentists, if Dr. Cohen was behind bars. Last week, Acting Justice Joan C. Sudolnik of State Supreme Court in Manhattan gave Dr. Cohen 1 1/2 to 4 1/2 years for participating in three burglaries with her abusive, persistently criminal lover. Some questions of justice, penitence and retribution await Dr. Cohen's appeal and application for a work-release program, but inmates must serve several months before they are eligible for work release. After the sentencing, Dr. Cohen, who is 35 years old and lives in Flatbush, said it was a tough day, but not as tough as Riker's Island had been.

title: Child Abductions by Parents Found to Be Far Higher Than Estimates
description: In a surprising sign of the bitter conflicts stemming from divorce, about 350,000 children are abducted every year by family members, says a new survey ordered by Congress.

title: Club Blends Friendship and Melody
description: GLADYS JOHNSON'S social life revolves around her love of music, as does that of many members of the Schubert Club of Fairfield County. The soprano, a nursery school teacher by profession and a biochemist by training, was one of the musicians who took part recently in a morning performing workshop sponsored by the club at the home of Anne Parmelee in Greenwich.

title: In the Takeover Game, Haste Makes Profits
description: When it comes to takeovers, the prevailing view among consultants and top executives is that haste is more likely to make profits than waste. That assumption is currently being put to the test here at what used to be Combustion Engineering Inc.

title:
MUSIC;

Young Winners Get Career Preview
description: LEAD: EVERY year since 1975, the final round of the New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's Young Artists Auditions has presented four young musicians in a public concert with the ensemble, at the conclusion of which a panel of judges determines the order of winners, first through fourth place. The finalists share a total of $6,500 in prizes, and the top prizewinner also performs as soloist with the orchestra next season.

title: HELL'S ANGELS IN PURGATORY
description: HOMEBOY

title: Finding Jobs for Relocated Spouses
description: To the Editor:

title: At Planting Time, Nature Needs Help
description: THE planting season is in full swing. Everything is going into the ground: shrubs, perennials, wildflowers and annuals. But there are important exceptions, the most tender plants like tomatoes and impatiens. Wait another week or so before putting them in, because killing frosts may still occur in this region. These tender plants are subject to severe damage, and could die, if they are put out too soon.

title: Afghans Seek Direct Talks With U.S. on Elections
description: With the United States and the Soviet Union discusssing the possibility of internationally supervised elections as part of an Afghan settlement, the Afghan Government appealed to the Bush Administration today to widen the diplomacy by dropping the embargo that it imposed on contacts with Kabul when Soviet forces withdrew from Afghanistan 15 months ago.

title: Review/Recital;   A Violinist From France
description: Christophe Boulier, a French violinist born in 1965, made an auspicious debut on Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y. French violinists, like French musicians in general, are sometimes praised, sometimes dismissed for a supposedly wispy elegance, a tendency to skate sensuously over music's surface rather than plumbing its Germanic depths.

title: Landmarking
description: To the Editor:

title: SHADES OF WHITE
description: White. It's the most basic of colors, yet the most complex. Indeed, the very word conjures up a host of contrasts. White connotes purity and cleanliness, simplicity and elegance. It also represents the harsh, crisp lines of modern architecture as well as the almost chalk-like quality of rustic rooms. ''People think of white as the absence of color,'' says Donald Kaufman, the Manhattan-based color specialist. ''It is actually the presence of the whole color spectrum.'' As a result, white is a particularly hard color to formulate. The minutest change of pigmentation can produce a whole different shade. For this reason, Kaufman has created about 15,000 different variations of white over the years. ''It's the toughest of all shades to work with,'' he says.

title: 'Extraordinary' Flood Ravages Rural Area South of Dallas
description: A rural area south of Dallas was swept today by what the National Weather Service described as ''an extraordinary, record-breaking flood.''

title: Gail May Marries
description: Gail Lyn May and Alfred Benjamin Engelberg were married last evening at the Plaza in New York by Rabbi Helene Ferris. Mrs. Engelberg is the daughter of Carol May of Sausalito, Calif., and the late William L. May. Her husband is the son of Gusti Engleberg of Atlantic City.

title: More to the Slurs Than Meets the Ear
description: There are two audiences for Nick Nolte's electrifying monologue at the start of Sidney Lumet's ''Q & A,'' one in the movie theater and one on the screen. The latter is a group of black, white and Hispanic police personnel that stands by raptly as Mr. Nolte, playing a New York police detective named Mike Brennan, tells a long, scatological story of having humiliated a suspect named Mr. Calabrese. This onscreen group soaks up every detail of Mike Brennan's account and appears to find it richly amusing. But reaction in the theater is bound to be different. Moviegoers aren't accustomed to hearing ethnic prejudices voiced as robustly and unashamedly as they are here.

title: THE FEAR CALLED POLIO
description: PATENTING THE SUN

title: On the Street;   When Pucci Met Lycra, It Was Love At First Sight
description: A couple of decades ago an Italian designer named Emilio Pucci slipcovered the fashion world with wild and colorful patterns that looked as if they had just floated up from the bottom of the sea. So guess what's bobbed back up? Pucci's dazzling designs. They are with us once more, on silk and cotton shirts, dresses, scarfs, handbags, and on something that wasn't around in the 50's and 60's - Lycra stretch tights. Somehow, Lycra and Pucci seem made for each other; the former's skin-tight fit provides the ideal canvas for the latter's swirling blobs and splashes.

title: 10 in the Running
description: One was the first man to clear 7 feet in the high jump. The other was the first to run an indoor mile in less than four minutes. The high-jumping Charles Dumas and the speedy Jim Beatty are among 10 candidates for a minimum of 3 places in the National Track and Field Hall of Fame in Indianapolis.

title: Homes Due in Wetlands
description: LEAD: PART of the last remaining undeveloped tidal wetlands on the 10-mile-long Long Beach barrier island at Lido Beach in Nassau County may be developed for 60 single-family homes on 12.7 acres of the land.

title: Neil T. Maffeo, TV Producer, 55
description: Neil T. Maffeo, a television producer, died of cancer on Tuesday at his home in Sherman Oaks, Calif. He was 55 years old.

title: 'Big Sisters' Aid Pregnant Teen-Agers
description: LEAD: THE pregnant teen-ager from Bridgeport and the marketing manager from Fairfield might never have met. But 18-year-old Nichol Martinez needed a friend with a positive outlook, and Libby Knapik, 30, wanted to help.

title: TriBeCa Yawns Hello to Film Studio
description: Trumpeted as Hollywood on the Hudson and organized by Robert De Niro, a former coffee warehouse in lower Manhattan opened this year as the TriBeCa Film Center, with production centers on seven floors and a stylish restaurant on the ground floor. Yet for all the attention people in the neighborhood are paying to it, it might still be the warehouse.

title: Correction
description: Because of a plan change by the publishers, a review of ''Landscapes of a New Land: Fiction by Latin American Women'' last Sunday misstated the book's format. It is available from White Pine Press in paperback only.

title: 15 Rounds For Title Bouts
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ethical Issues In Medicine
description: ''Hospitals Grapple With Ethical Issues'' (March 4) stated that Long Island Jewish and Albert Einstein Hospitals are discussing forming a regional ethics committee network to help train ethics committee members and act as a clearinghouse on hospital policies. The Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre has already done this for its hospitals in Nassau and Suffolk Counties. Upon recommendation from Bishop McGann and through the work of Monsignor Mattei of Dix Hills, a Diocesan Medical Ethics Commission was established in 1978.

title: Is Super-VHS Headed For Popular Acceptance?
description: Since its launching three years ago, Super-VHS - an improved method of home video recording - has made little headway. Though welcomed by serious videophiles as a major advance, Super-VHS has met only indifference on the part of the larger public. However, thanks to the recent rise of the United States dollar vis-a-vis the Japanese yen, this may soon change.

title: Mean Streets and Fresh Air
description: The meadow had a lot of flowers and bees. There was a big hill, and you could roll down it and just sit there and look at the flowers. - Rosalina, age 9.

title: CASEY AT THE MIKE
description: A FEW FACTS ABOUT Kemal Amen Kasem: As the voice behind the pop music countdown radio show ''Casey's Top Forty,'' he may be the most-listened-to person on radio except for the commentator Paul Harvey. He is of Lebanese Druse parentage, the son of a grocer, born and raised in Detroit. His first radio job was playing Scoop Ryan, Cub Reporter. He subsequently had roles on ''The Lone Ranger'' and ''Sergeant Preston of the Yukon.'' He was a disk jockey in Detroit, Cleveland, Buffalo, Oakland and Los Angeles. He was the voice of Robin on the ''Superfriends'' cartoon series, Shaggy on ''Scooby Doo,'' Waldo on ''Mr. Magoo'' and various letters of the alphabet on ''Sesame Street.'' He has been heard, he says, on some 10,000 television and radio commercials. He was the exclusive promo announcer for NBC-TV from 1977 to 1981.

title: Immigration Project Frees the First of 200 Political Detainees
description: The first of 200 political detainees participating in an experimental parole project of the Immigration and Naturalization Service was released on Friday.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about music festivals in Europe misidentified an orchestra performing in Prague; it was the Cleveland Orchestra. The caption also rendered the name of the conductor incorrectly; it is Christoph von Dohnanyi.

title: Using New Varieties of Fish That Turn Up at the Market
description: LATELY there is more seafood than ever on the table. The list of fish and shellfish that consumers have come to appreciate has lengthened to include many previously ignored varieties.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

Groping for Revisions on Impact Fees
description: LEAD: THE 1980's building boom that changed the face of New Jersey can be seen in a drive along any of its highways: Office buildings dot the landscape and residential subdivisions blanket once-open fields.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;

Dial O for Clubhouse Overkill
description: LEAD: The new restraints being placed on telephone calls to and from major league clubhouses represents an overreaction by the owners to the Pete Rose gambling affair.

title: A Master Marketer
description: To the Editor:

title: Jodie Lutzner Weds
description: Jodie Lutzner, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herman H. Lutzner of Havertown, Pa., was married last evening to Diego Garay, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Mariano Garay of Buenos Aires. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at the Lotos Club in Manhattan. Mrs. Lutzner Garay, as the bride will be known, is a freelance writer. She graduated from Bard College and received a master's degree in literature from New York University. The bridegroom is an associate at Walker Group/CNI, a New York architectural firm. He graduated from the Universidad Nacional de La Plata,, where he also received a master's degree in architecture and urban studies.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Dr. Gregory G. Schwartz Is Wed to Brenda F. Biren
description: Brenda F. Biren, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Biren of Sacramento, Calif., was married last evening to Dr. Gregory G. Schwartz, the son of Werner W. Schwartz and Gladys Schwartz of Jackson Heights, Queens. Rabbi Martin Weiner, assisted by Cantor Martin Feldman, officiated at Congregation Sherith Israel in San Francisco.

title: Salzburg
description: To the Editor: Your special music festivals issue (Travel, April 29) was extremely interesting, but your readers should know that last year in Salzburg, so well known for its festival, when my husband and I attended a Palace Concert (at the Residenz) - an event billed as a chamber orchestra playing Haydn, Mozart and Dvorak - the orchestra turned out to be a group of young people (teen-agers, early 20's), who, while showing promise, were in no way professional musicians. The young man who struggled valiantly through a cello concerto was to be commended for his attempts; however, the performance was embarrassing.

title: After 19 Months, All Roads Led to Kurt Masur
description: The 19-month search to find a new music director for the New York Philharmonic had a drama all its own, with disappointments, frustration, good and bad luck and healthy contention playing their parts. Kurt Masur may have initially been the fourth or fifth choice, but the Philharmonic's officers and musicians suggest that in the 62-year-old East German the process eventually produced the best conductor anyway.

title: 2 Top Achievers
description: After giving out an achievement award each year since 1983, the Canadian Society of New York decided to break with tradition this year by honoring two hockey greats at one clip. The joint recipients of the 1990 award will be Ken Dryden, the former goaltender for the Montreal Canadiens, and Vladislav Tretiak, the great Soviet goaltender. They will receive the award at a dinner June 7. . . . After being released by the San Francisco 49ers last month, Riki Ellison, an inside linebacker who spent the 1989 season on the injured reserve list, has been signed by the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: In This Painter's World, Everything Is Several Things
description: Susan Rothenberg is back. With her blood-red heads stuck at both ends of a jump-rope-length bone, so that the two-headed figure becomes a gigantic baby rattle; with her dancers, gymnasts and acrobats so elastic that they can curve their bodies into O's and U's and put their feet behind their heads without bending their backs, and with her horses' heads as long as snakes and as rubbery as hoses, this 45-year-old painter has re-established herself as one of the most compelling artists of her generation.

title: Voice of Experience
description: He is hardly the only baseball player scrambling up the minor league alphabet ladder in hopes of reaching the major leagues, but Jerry Reuss, a left-handed pitcher who was promoted last week from the Houston Astros' Class AA farm club in Columbus, Ga., to Houston's Class AAA club in Tucson, Ariz., thinks he has an edge. He has been there before.

title:
IN SHORT: FICTION;

A WILDCAT IN THE FAMILY
description: LEAD:

title: Miss Pierson Wed To David T. Mead
description: At the Presbyterian Church in Morristown, N.J., Alexandra Beach Pierson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert D. Pierson of Mendham, N.J., was married yesterday to David Thomas Mead, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence F. Mead of Morristown. The Rev. Thomas C. Sheffield performed the ceremony.

title: AIDS Groups Feel the Fiscal Crisis
description: Despite rising caseloads, New York's nonprofit AIDS agencies say they may be forced to reduce services because the government support they depend on is being curtailed by the budget problems of the city and state.

title: FICTION
description: THE SALT POINT. By Paul Russell. (Dutton, $18.95.) Pull up another stool to the bar at Club Angst. The newest addition to the decadent hip ranks of Jay McInerney, Bret Easton Ellis and Tama Janowitz is Paul Russell, founder of the Hudson River Ennui School. In his first novel, ''The Salt Point,'' Mr. Russell introduces his readers to the bruised souls of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., a tangled web of friends who compulsively shred the ties that bind them, willing their milieu into corruption out of sheer alienated boredom. Anatole and Lydia grew up together; both are in love with Chris, a self-exile punishing himself for an earlier three-way disaster. Enter Leigh, the enigmatic drifter with the perfect profile. It's not long before Leigh has moved into Anatole's apartment and, with his touch ''at once electric and neutral,'' wreaked his own personal brand of havoc on everyone around him. The book takes its title from that indefinable, ever-shifting spot in the Hudson where the river changes from fresh to salt water. Perhaps a similarly balanced place exists in the emotions, a place where true friends can meet as equals, but it's clearly beyond reach in the bars of Poughkeepsie; these characters seem doomed to endless moral fumbling as they despair over how nice it would be ''not to exist for a while.'' Waiting for someone or something to save them from themselves, they casually torment one another and beg mutely for deliverance from ''this impossible present tense.'' In a disturbing way, these people are actually very good at what they do, and Mr. Russell's slightly numb prose style, though occasionally heavy-handed, is perfectly suited to their hollow search for affirmation.

title: COINS
description: Russian fur traders ranged through the Bering Sea during the first part of the 19th century. They were mandated by the csar to trade along the coasts of Japan, China and the Americas. These hunters brought home skins of thousands of seals, walruses and sea otters. And at least one of the trading companies issued its own currency.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;

A First Step For Riverwalk
description: LEAD: MORE than 10 years after it was conceived by the City Planning Commission, work was completed late last month on the first 800-foot phase of Riverwalk, designed to link the many sections of this city's Delaware riverfront.

title: Searching for Eve
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Bias Incidents Provide Lessons For Class on Race
description: Since 1986, a popular class, ''Black and White,'' at Southern Methodist University has tried to teach a new philosophy of race relations: simply put, it is not that blacks need to change but that whites must accept them socially.

title: K. C. Hnat Becomes Bride In a Ceremony at Rutgers
description: Katherine Cox Hnat, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard F. Hnat of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday to John Christopher Bradshaw, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Virgil G. Bradshaw of Ramona, Calif. The Rev. Ronald Stanley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at the Kirkpatrick Chapel of Rutgers University in New Brunswick, N.J.

title: Cape May Journal;   Facing the Tourist Season With Mixed Feelings
description: FOR now, life in Cape May is redolent of that in a small town, not a tourist haven. Streets aren't clogged with cars, and parking is as easy to find as solitude on an oceanfront jog. Best sellers still sit on shelves at the library, and there's no waiting anywhere, not at the Ugly Mug bar and restaurant, not at the Lobster House in Cape May Harbor.

title: A NEW LOOK AT A MAJOR MINIMALIST
description: During the heady days of psychedelia and flower power in the 1960's, Terry Riley suddenly found himself leading the life of a famous composer. His ''In C'' (1964) garnered Minimalism its first public acclaim. And his ''Rainbow in Curved Air'' (1968), with its brightly-colored electric keyboard arpeggios and wide-eyed hippie sentiments, attained genuine crossover status, linking classically oriented new music and progressive rock into a promising new synthesis.

title:
FICTION: NEW GUYS ON THE BLOCK;

SECRETS DEEPER THAN A BROTHER'S DEATH
description: LEAD:

title: Ms. Jeffee Wed To Gerry Cohen
description: Gail Susan Jeffee and Gerry Cohen were married last evening in the Pegasus Suite at the Rainbow Room in New York. Rabbi Tom Weiner and Cantor Richard Botton officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul Jeffee of New York. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ellis Cohen of Lido Beach, L.I.

title: POSTINGS: 182 Manhattan Units;   Housing The Poor
description: Three new construction projects that will use $15 million in state funds to build 182 apartments in Manhattan have been approved by the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal as part of its $128 million program for fast-track housing for low-income and homeless people. The program was started last year as an effort to cut red tape and accelerate the development of new apartment projects in areas lacking affordable housing. Some of the units are earmarked for the elderly and the disabled.

title: Where All-Powerful Central Government Lives On
description: IS Britain really a democracy?

title: Clear Message
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: 528 Town House Units;   23 Versts To Red Sq.
description: Now that McDonald's hamburgers and Pepsi-Cola are a hit with Moscow residents, American-style suburban town houses are on their way there too. Construction of the first 132 of 528 units planned for Krasnagorsk, a suburb about 23 versts - 15 miles - northwest of Red Square, will begin in August.

title:
Your Own Account;

When Women Manage Money
description: LEAD: According to Esther M. Berger, who specializes in financial planning for women, at least 90 percent of American women will be making their own financial decisions at some point in their lives. She can rattle off the statistics: 48 percent of all women will be widowed in their lifetime; 36 percent will be divorced and about 6 percent will remain single.

title: A Campground With a Credo
description: ''EACH cabin comes equipped with fresh linens, towels, an ice chest, propane stove, pots, pans, necessary utensils and two lizards. If any of these items are missing when you leave, we won't refund your $30 deposit.'' These were among the first instructions we received as we checked into the Maho Bay Campground in the Caribbean late one night in midwinter.

title: Study Finds 'Astonishing' Indifference to Elections
description: American democracy is being undermined by citizens who are so indifferent to national elections that an ''astonishing'' number of them did not even know who the candidates for Vice President were in 1988, a commission said today after a two-year study of Presidential politics.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: The government's report on consumer credit for March.

title: A FEMINIST TAKES STOCK
description: Living abroad and working with European feminists brought home to me that a singular failing of American feminism is its inability to come to grips with the concept of ''family.'' Vivian Gornick's article poignantly underscores this point, beginning with an argument based on the rejection of intimacy and ending with a description of the ''new woman of the 70's and 80's'' who lives with ''intermittent erotic connection and the company of intelligent women.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

title: UNEASY ABOUT THE GERMANS
description: DO GERMANS ACCEPT RESPONSIBILITY FOR THE CRIMES OF the Nazi era? Is their repentance such that they can be trusted never to repeat the past? When people worry about the unification of Germany, these are the usual questions. But for me there is a deeper mystery, and it concerns the idea of nationhood itself in the German mind.

title: Port Jefferson Considers Cultural Center
description: LEAD: DOES Long Island need another cultural center?

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $1.3 million

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: Style Makers;   Vima de Marchi Micheli: NEEDLEWORK ARTIST
description: As a child in New York, Vima de Marchi Micheli learned classic Italian stitchery from her mother, grandmother and three aunts. ''I always considered needlework an art form, never a craft,'' she said.

title: Where the Darker Myths Live
description: THERE are limits to travel. You cannot sail up and down the River Styx with Charon, the boatman who took the dead to Hades in Greek myth, as your tour guide. Whatever your prospects for permanent residence there in the future, you cannot buy round-trip tickets to the place that the Greeks knew as Tartarus and we sometimes call Hell. On the other hand, it is perfectly possible to go to the very edge of that subterranean world, and to do so without feeling particularly imperiled or sinful. There are places in Greece where you can enjoy the sunlight, the scenery, the sense of the past and the lack of tourists - and know that some antique darkness is not far away. Take Troezen, take parts of Patmos, take Eleusis.

title: Patching Concrete Steps
description: CONCRETE outdoor steps are durable, and ordinarily will last the life of a house. But concrete is inherently brittle, and so corners and sharp edges of such steps are vulnerable to chipping.

title: Contras Will Begin Disarming as Army Is Cut
description: Nicaraguan rebels today agreed with the new Government to begin disarming next week, and President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro pledged to start reducing the size of the Sandinista-controlled army. If carried out, the agreement will mean an end to a decade-old civil war between thousands of United States-backed contra rebels and the leftist Sandinista Government.

title: IS IT TRUE WHAT HE SAYS ABOUT DIXIE?
description: Peter Applebome nearly touches an important truth about the New South (''Is It True What He Says About Dixie?'' April 8). As he observes, Lewis Grizzard is selling ''the South as nostalgia,'' a land of charm and gentility. But many of the people who pine most deeply for the Old South have spent their adult lives escaping it.

title: Question Of the Week;   Why Is The Triple Crown Won So Rarely?
description: In May of a thoroughbred's third year, the horse has not yet fully matured physically. With the Triple Crown races running close together, it is difficult for a young horse to run three strong races consecutively. Also, the Triple Crown closes with the Belmont Stakes at a mile and a half. This grueling distance often proves too much for even the best of horses. Between 1979 and 1986, Swale (the ill-fated 1984 winner) was the only Belmont winner to compete in all three Triple Crown events.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Belmar $125,000

title:
ART;

When High and Middle Brows Meet
description: LEAD: THE crossover between fine art and popular culture - a subject to be explored in depth this coming fall in the Museum of Modern Art's much-heralded ''High and Low'' exhibition - is now being given a preliminary airing at the Wunsch Arts Center's Sabbeth Art Gallery in Glen Cove.

title: Ballet Theater's Challenge: To Reclaim Its Soul
description: Paradise regained? Anyone who thinks - as many do - that American Ballet Theater misplaced its soul during the decade that Mikhail Baryshnikov was its artistic director will now be closely watching a new regime determined to redefine the company's identity. Tomorrow's opening of the troupe's 50th-anniversary season in New York at the Metropolitan Opera House begins an era in which Jane Hermann and Oliver Smith, the recently named co-directors, promise to restore certain names and policies identified with Ballet Theater's past. They must, of course, go forward without appearing to step backward.

title: LIFE IN A SPIRITUAL TOWAWAY ZONE
description: THE GOLDEN ORANGE

title: In Texas Race, Richards Reflects on Negativism
description: In the aftermath of a brutal primary campaign, Ann Richards smoothly combines the roles of victim and victor.

title: Can't Anybody in the City Play This Game?
description: In 1987, as part of the lingering celebration of their championship, the Mets adorned Shea Stadium with a sign that read, ''Baseball Like It Oughta Be.''

title: The Case of the Telltale Passport
description: A READER asks about getting the Government to omit the birthplace listing on a passport. ''My wife, Ruth, born in Israel, became a naturalized citizen in 1962, in as short a period after our marriage as possible,'' Harry J. Hartz writes. ''Nevertheless, her passport continues to contain the information, 'Place of birth - Israel.' While this is a current legal requirement, it represents a clear and present danger during international travel with the constant threat of hijackings or other terrorist actions . . . My question is whether and how an exception might be generated in order to avoid the major risk this information represents in today's unsettled world.''

title: Laws of the Land vs. the Laws of Prime Time
description: As devotees of ''L.A. Law'' are aware, there's been a change at the top at McKenzie, Brackman, Chaney, Kuzak & Becker. Leland McKenzie (played by Richard Dysart), the firm's guiding eminence grise and the show's moral weathervane, stunned his colleagues by stepping down earlier this season as senior partner. In the subsequent election among the partners, the surprising winner was Rosalind Shays (Diana Muldaur), brand new to the firm, a corporate specialist with a lust for power and a gift for internecine battling. In the last few weeks, Rosalind's nettlesome tactics have threatened to scatter the firm's viewer-friendly ensemble of attorneys. As the season draws to a close on Thursday night, a heartsick but determined Leland is in the midst of staging a coup, attempting to reclaim the top seat and save the spirit of the firm he founded.

title: Democrats Plan to Gain Elusive Board Majority
description: When John A. Marino, the state Democratic chairman, accepted an invitation last January from Dennis Mehiel, the new Westchester Democratic leader, to ''energize the troops'' at the party's yearly victory breakfast, he did not realize that his job would be only half done.

title: New Concern Voiced on Spread of AIDS
description: A SHARP rise since 1987 in the incidence of syphilis and a form of gonorrhea that is resistant to penicillin has prompted concern among health officials that education programs promoting safe sex are not working and that the spread of AIDS among heterosexuals may also rise.

title: Town In Hawaii Cut Off by Lava
description: Lava from Kilauea Volcano cut the last road out of this coastal town today and nearly encircled a church and the town's store in the heart of the village.

title: Wall Street;   Remember Petrodollars? They're Back
description: The stock market responded in predictable fashion to the news of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Country's latest effort to stem the flow of oil onto the world market. It bid up the price of some major oil companies a bit, anticipating that the pact might produce stronger earnings.

title: U.S. Ordered to List Assets It Seized From Noriega
description: A Federal district judge has ordered Government prosecutors to provide a list of $20 million in assets seized from Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, saying that at least some of the money must have come from legitimate activities of the deposed Panamanian ruler.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Collaborative Efforts By New Repertory Group
description: James Garland founded the New Repertory Dance Theater last year to encourage collaborations between choreographers and composers. Judging from the group's debut at the Triplex Theater last Sunday night, its ambitions remain more laudable than its achievements.

title: 'WITTIER THAN ANYBODY'
description: RANDALL JARRELL

title: Kris DeRose Is Wed To John Felice Jr. in Rye
description: Kristine Elizabeth DeRose, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James DeRose of Rye, N.Y., was married yesterday to John Richard Felice Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Felice Sr. of Rye. Msgr. Donald Pryor performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Resurrection in Rye.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Lenox, Mass.;

Mixed Signals in Berkshires
description: LEAD: IT took a year longer to sell the first 20 condominium units at Winden Hill than Thomas Spencer projected in November 1987, when he started redeveloping the former Berkshire Christian College campus on a hilltop above Stockbridge Bowl here.

title:
DINING OUT;

A Shore Place That's Open All Year
description: LEAD: WITH the approach of summer, most restaurants along the Shore are gearing up for the season, but the Ocean Gate House, in the Ocean County community of Ocean Gate, stays open and fairly busy all year. That's because the Nogiewich family, who operate the attractive Williamsburg-style dining spot, know their market.

title: A LIFELONG QUARREL WITH GOD
description: Fifteen years ago, I took part in a large conference on the ''lessons of the Holocaust.'' The meeting was held in New York but organized from Jerusalem by the Hebrew University. The participants included almost everyone in Israel and the United States who was then engaged in research or reflection about the murder of the Jews during the Nazi years. The conferees talked mostly about history, but they could not avoid, and they did not want to avoid, moral judgment. Despite the passage of a decade or so, Hannah Arendt, in her account of ''Eichmann in Jerusalem'' (1963), had raised a question that was still painful: Had the Jews, and especially their leaders, done enough to save themselves? Arendt had maintained that the Jewish organizations in Europe should have dissolved and burned their records. Some kept registers that the Nazi authorities used, and others were even forced to choose whom to send to the ''labor camps.'' It would have been better, so Arendt had argued, if the Jews had been left with no leaders. ''There would have been chaos and plenty of misery,'' she wrote, but more Jews could have escaped identification and more would have survived.

title: Sunday Menu;   Steamed Fish, Asparagus And a Pinch of Color
description: The original version of this menu was created after this year's first purchase of local asparagus, scallions and what the vendor called black fish.

title: Miss Storey Wed To David Feher
description: Gwendolen M. Storey and David G. Feher were married yesterday at the Wharton Sinkler Estate in Philadelphia by the Rev. Judith T. Beck, an Episcopal priest. The bride's parents are Dr. and Mrs. Bayard T. Storey of Philadelphia. Her husband is a son of Teresa M. Feher of Pittsburgh and the late James Feher.

title: Caroline Clayton Planning to Wed
description: The engagement of Caroline Cornelius Clayton to Christopher R. Tufts, a son of Margaret Baker Tufts of Marblehead, Mass., and the late Robert Rider Tufts, has been announced by the mother of the future bride, Dr. Loretta Cornelius of Virginia Beach, Va. A December wedding is planned.

title: Study Urges Recycling Ash From Municipal Incinerators
description: LEAD: ASH residue from municipal incinerators must be mixed with cement and recycled if towns are to avoid staggering disposal costs, the Long Island Regional Planning Board has warned.

title: Simple And Short Party Dresses
description: Keep it simple, and keep it short. That's the way to go for spring and summer parties. Unless it's a white-tie affair, a long dress simply looks old this year. Short dresses look young and modern, especially when they bare the arms and shoulders.

title: Review/Music;   Harry Partch's Visions In Bang on a Can Series
description: It would be too cute to claim that the fourth annual Bang on a Can Festival got under way with a bang Friday night. More like a gentle sigh, a wheeze, eerie twangs and rattling runs of woody clunks.

title: Two More G.I.'s Charged With Murder in Panama
description: One month after the Army said that it had charged a paratrooper with premeditated murder in Panama, the service has disclosed that it has filed murder charges against two other soldiers who took part in the invasion.

title: London Will Divide Its Telephone Prefix, Fraying Composure
description: London telephones jangle to new numbers on Sunday, when city codes 71 and 81 replace the simple No. 1. If only it were that simple. ''I am totally confident that all the necessary adjustments will be made as planned on Sunday,'' said Millie Banerjee, general manager of British Telecom's London network.

He goes on to concede his embarrassment because he admits that he never gave the people of Eastern Europe the respect for self-determination they have proved to deserve.

description: THERESA AMMIRATI tells of the woman who applied for a job as a tutor at the Writing Center at Connecticut College in New London. The woman was startled when she was asked if she could work with learning-disabled students.

Ms. Knopf Wed To Chip Insinger
description: Alison Laine Knopf, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Knopf Jr. of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Thomas Christopher Insinger, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas H. Insinger of Philadelphia. The Rev. Peter F. Bannan performed the ceremony at Corpus Christi Roman Catholic Church in New York.

description: LEAD: The once-ubiquitous diaper truck had all but disappeared in the county. But now white vans decorated with a diapered baby in a trefoil hat and brandishing a sword are visiting the neighborhoods.

title: NONFICTION
description: COVERING THE PLAGUE: AIDS and the American Media. By James Kinsella. (Rutgers University, $22.95.) The AIDS epidemic is an enormously significant social phenomenon, and the general public's recognition of the outbreak, its attitudes toward the disease's victims, its perception of the threat - and the limits of that threat -and its responses to it are important aspects of the social history. Since the news media are among the most powerful determinants of what the public knows and feels about AIDS, a balanced and thoughtful history of press coverage as the epidemic unfolded throughout the 1980's would be welcome. Sadly, this book does not provide it - surprisingly, since James Kinsella, the former editorial pages editor of The Los Angeles Herald Examiner, is a seasoned journalist. ''Covering the Plague'' recounts in useful and often compelling detail the skimpy, floundering and often misleading early coverage of AIDS, the long periods in which major newspapers paid little attention and the reporting ''errors'' that in fact faithfully reflected the early years of medical and scientific confusion about the disease. But Mr. Kinsella is single-mindedly determined to prove that it was solely a matter of bias - that ''members of the media . . . refused to believe that the deaths of gay men and drug addicts were worth reporting,'' either because of prejudice or because they personally knew no one in those groups. Newspapers and television did not consider AIDS a big story until it posed a threat to the average American, he contends. But of course that is true; by definition, general significance is what makes an event newsworthy. ''Covering the Plague'' does record the dreadful silence from the Reagan White House and the confusion and delays in the medical community, although its observations are generally illuminated by hindsight. The early years of the epidemic are much more clearly understood now than they were then. But the book is replete with egregious overstatements, like the claim that ''no one is writing,'' even today, about preventable tragedies afflicting the poor, minorities and the homeless.

title: Europe's Try for a One-Stop Merger
description: Mergers are surging in the European Community in anticipation of a more unified market in 1992. But the regulatory path is not an easy one. Parties must weave through a thicket of overlapping antitrust laws, filing requirements and waiting periods. American acquisitions in Europe have been blocked for protectionist reasons. Transactions can require negotiations not only with Brussels, headquarters of the community, but also with individual countries.

title: Correction
description: Headlines last Sunday with an article about politics in Afghanistan referred incorrectly in some copies to the anniversary being observed there. It was the 12th anniversary of the coup that brought a Communist Government to power.

title: Sunday Outing;   A Blanket That Blooms in the Spring
description: It's apple blossom time in the Hudson Valley - more than a week earlier than usual because of a heat wave late last month. Many of the area's apple trees are burgeoning with white blossoms, a harbinger of a good apple crop, if they are not hit by a cold spell this week or next.

title: On the Road: Honoring Students With Extra Drive
description: About 15 University of Kansas students gathered last week to roast hot dogs and to honor several graduating seniors for their hard work, determination and drive. Especially their drive.

title: Fresh Mark For Minoso?
description: HE has six names and once played for the master baseball showman Bill Veeck, so it should come as no real surprise that at the age of 67, Saturnino Orestes Arrieta Armas (Minnie) Minoso will be called out of retirement for the third time to extend his claim on major league history by playing in his sixth decade as a major leaguer. No one else has played in more than four decades.

ART;

Experimentation in Still Lifes
description: LEAD: AS a way of testing their own originality, artists have always liked the challenge of trying new approaches to traditional themes.

title: Review/Jazz;   Steve Lacy, Saxophonist
description: Steve Lacy, the expatriate American saxophonist, is a master of stasis. Where most jazz musicians bull their way through tunes, leaving notes as a motorboat leaves a wake, Mr. Lacy mulls each phrase over and over. He will play an idea, then repeat it, bending the last note. Or he will add a few notes, or drop some. When he decides to leave the maze he has just constructed, he refuses the obvious way out; instead of ripping off a tension-clearing line, he jumps right into building a new geometry of notes.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Family Drama and Hymns In Works by Marta Renzi
description: Marta Renzi and the Project Company mixed choreographic pleasures with theatrical blunders on Tuesday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

description: Christine Louise Dibble and Cameron Cohick, lawyers in Washington, were married yesterday at St. Mark Presbyterian Church in Rockville, Md. The Rev. James Macdonnell performed the ceremony.

description: In his 20's he was known as D. D. Dominick, designing sweaters and colorful sportswear for his contemporaries and selling them in his own New York boutique, first on East 51st Street then on 60th Street. Now he is 45 years old and using his full name, Dominick Avellino, for a line of light-hearted sportswear that he is designing for the company Worlds Apart.
