Reston of Washington. The Rev. William E. Basom, a United Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the weekend home of the bridegroom's family.

title: For Michael Blakemore, a Twofold Task
description: ''I've had an amazing year, absolutely,'' Michael Blakemore said enthusiastically, as he sipped coffee one recent morning on the top floor of the renovated north London almshouse where he lives. The 61-year-old Australian director is currently represented on Broadway by two hits - ''City of Angels'' at the Virginia Theater and ''Lettice and Lovage'' at the Ethel Barrymore - and if he seemed exultant, who could blame him? After all, two decades ago the word around Broadway was that he didn't exist.

title: Crumbling Cuba Still Loves to Rumba
description: RECENTLY I found myself fondling a dollar bill of such limp antiquity that it called the entire concept of cash into question. This tattered, pale greenback had been in circulation since the late 60's, but were it not for its privileged isolation on the island of Cuba, it would long ago have been incinerated. Its edges were thin, its corners rounded, and George Washington had faded to near anonymity. Yet here it was, in a Havana diplotienda - a shop open only to foreigners - being passed from hand to hand and enjoying the esteem of its bearers.

title: 2 MAYORS DEPLORE MOVE IN JERUSALEM
description: In separate visits to New York last week, the Mayors of Jerusalem and Bethlehem strongly endorsed American religious leaders' opposition to the recent occupation of a 72-room complex in Jerusalem's Christian quarter by Jewish settlers.

title: Amanda Mullally Is Married on L.I.
description: Amanda Mandeville Mullally and Matthew Bouvy Drake were married yesterday at Trinity St. John's Episcopal Church in Hewlett, L.I. The Rev. Earle W. Pratt Jr. and the Rev. Edyth Baker officiated.

title: Documentaries Struggle Out of the Straitjacket
description: One of the main problems in assessing film documentaries can be found in the French word for the camera lens: l'objectif. With its implications of objectivity, it crystallizes what most viewers assume about a documentary - that it is more ''real'' than a fiction film.

title: U.S. Envoy Steps Into Political Firestorm in Kenya
description: The United States Ambassador has found himself in the middle of a fierce political debate about whether this East African nation and ally of Washington should replace its one-party state with a multiparty system.

title: Corrections
description: A map on April 15 with an article about San Cristobal de las Casas, Mexico, omitted the identity of the country bounded by Mexico and Guatemala. It is Belize.

title: Mamaroneck Praises Modified Thruway Plan
description: Traffic conditions on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway interchange adjacent to their village may be dangerous, but last winter nearly 250 Mamaroneck residents and village officials filled the Emelin Theater to demand that state highway officials solve their own problems without adding to the already heavy burden on local roads or without taking private property.

title: All About/Shipbuilding;   After a Long Slump, World Shipping Is Embarking on a Modest Recovery
description: As owner of one of the world's largest fleets, P. N. Tsakos, the president of a Greek shipping line that bears his name, should be relishing his industry's recovery from a decade-long depression in shipping and shipbuilding. Instead, he frets about whether to place large new orders for ships. If he hesitates, prices may rise and shipyards may be booked for years, keeping him from expanding. But if he buys, he risks taking delivery in two or three years - perhaps just as the boom collapses.

title: NEW HEALTH TEST: THE OREGON PLAN
description: For the last nine months, Oregon residents from all walks of life have been working to rank medical procedures so that government health insurance could benefit the greatest number of people, knowing their decisions might contribute to somebody's death or cause prolonged suffering.

The Derby usually attracts 15-20 horses and the post positions and traffic problems experienced on the Churchill Downs oval can play a big role in the outcome.

title: FICTION
description: THE EVENING NEWS. By Arthur Hailey. (Doubleday, $21.95.) Arthur Hailey's 10th novel is a literary example of an old boxing adage: if you don't have the fistic power, dazzle them with footwork. ''The Evening News'' is painstakingly researched, convolutedly plotted, peopled with poster-paint characters and written in a relentlessly breathless style. Its central characters are a television anchorman, Crawford Sloane, and his wife, Jessica, who live an opulent Ken-and-Barbie life in Larchmont, N.Y., until some nasty Shining Path terrorists come north to stage a kidnapping. The plot revolves around the efforts of the network folks to free Sloane's captive family. The settings are the New York corporate offices and newsrooms of the network and the Peruvian jungle, with flashbacks to Vietnam thrown in for good measure. There are the obligatory steamy sex scenes (one between a network correspondent and a flight attendant on the papal aircraft, no less) and a couple of plugs for Mr. Hailey's favorite Manhattan restaurants. So far, so good: at first ''The Evening News'' looks like yet another quick-paced novel written with an eye on movie or mini-series rights. But Mr. Hailey irks as he embellishes the telling of a reasonably good story that has some reasonably interesting characters. He manages to condescend to nearly all his women (the head of the network, for example, makes Medea look like Mary Poppins) and he downshifts into low stylistic gear with depressing regularity. We learn, whether we want to know it or not, how Opa Locka, Fla., and White Plains, N.Y., got their names. We also get, between quotation marks, lectures on the past, present and future of the television and print news business, including a prediction that The New York Times will soon be using full-color photographs on page 1.

description: Mike Boddicker pitched seven strong innings and Dwight Evans hit a three-run homer today as the Boston Red Sox beat Oakland, 5-1, and ended the Athletics' winning streak at five games.

title: 'BOYS NEXT DOOR': IN A GROUP HOUSE
description: Less than four years after a premiere at the McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., ''The Boys Next Door'' has become a small regional theater favorite. That's a wonder - and it's no wonder. For here is just the sort of play some people resist, misunderstand or find threatening, but its emotional pull and entertainment value besides are considerable. In a less than satisfactory staging, the Emelin Theater production here nevertheless attests to the play's appeal and suggests that it will endure.

Gadsden of Gladwyne, Pa., and the late Mr. Gadsden. The Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr. performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I.

'Memorizing Is Always Valuable'

Ronald Salafia, a professor of psychology at Fairfield University who has given numerous workshops and lectures on memory improvement, some of the chief factors are inattention, information overload and aging.

title: The Best Gift a Grandparent Can Give a Grandchild
description: LEAD: THERE are those who would have us believe that ''they don't make grandmas the way they used to,'' that the present breed of grandparents have become selfish and think only of traipsing all over the world, enjoying themselves. Utter nonsense. Just another form of the popular pastime of bashing the elderly.

description: The Knicks and the Boston Celtics are even at two games each in their three-of-five-game opening-round playoff series. The deciding game will be played today in the ancient Boston Garden, where 16 Celtic championship banners hang from the dusty rafters.

title: Benjamin Ellis Tenzer, Engineer, 54
description: Benjamin Ellis Tenzer, a metallurgical engineer who was involved in reform Democratic politics in Brooklyn, died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis at his home in Brooklyn last Wednesday. He was 54 years old.

title: In a Freer State, a Cultural Heritage at Risk
description: The flush of excitement with which most of the world has greeted political change in Eastern Europe obscures the reality about artistic life in cities like this: If improvements are to come here, they are far off and will be hard earned.

title: Nurses Get V.I.P. Treatment, Easing Shortage
description: Betsey Vernizzi, an orthopedic nurse at St. Anthony Medical Center here, recalled a course she took nearly 20 years ago in nursing school. ''It was called ethics,'' she said. ''I was taught to say 'Yes, sir, no sir.' If a doctor walked into the nurse's station, you gave him your chair. I called them 'Doctor.' They called me Betsey.' '' At St. Anthony now, there is a doctor whose first name is Louis. ''We call him 'Louie,' '' she said.

title: Comeback of Sorts Emerging at VW
description: You have seen the word: Fahrvergnugen.

title: When Three Beats to a Bar Became Magic
description: What makes Johann Strauss' waltzes so irresistible? Melody? Offenbach and Emil Waldteufel composed melodies that are often as memorable as Strauss'. Harmony? Strauss' vocabulary is notably rich, sometimes implied in the melodies themselves, sometimes exhibited for its own sake in piquant, Schubertian key progressions within and between the sections of a waltz set. Yet Franz Lehar's harmony is even more sophisticated, though fewer of his waltzes are as endearing. Rhythm? They all played with those three beats to a bar. The quality that sets Strauss apart from his colleagues is rooted in his ambition to ennoble dance music, which led him to treat it with the seriousness of a symphonic poet. In the unforgettable introduction to ''The Blue Danube,'' a masterpiece of romantic tone painting, Strauss, with high tremolando strings, solo horn and divided cellos, gradually presents the primary theme, builds to a climax and descends from it while maintaining a sufficient atmosphere of expectancy to go on to the waltz proper. The evocation is comparable with the opening of Bruckner's Fourth (''Romantic'') Symphony. With such introductions and extended codas Strauss bridged the gap between the ballroom and the concert hall.

title: POSTINGS: Landmarks-Plus;   A Bronx Booklet
description: Landmarks in the Bronx, as well as suggestions for additional Bronx properties that might be landmarked, are the subject of a 96-page booklet just published by the Bronx County Historical Society. Titled ''Landmarks of the Bronx,'' it describes 52 individual structures already landmarked plus the five Bronx historic districts.

title: Nancy Ambrose Wed in Carolina
description: Nancy Joy Ambrose, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Ambrose of Pinehurst, N.C., was married yesterday to Scott Gregory Armstrong, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald S. Armstrong of Manhasset, L.I. Msgr. Frederick A. Koch performed the ceremony at the Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Pinehurst.

title: View of Game 1 Called Bizarre
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: STREETSCAPES: The Harlem Courthouse;   A New Tack for the City on a Landmark
description: HOW can a building be preserved? By landmark designation? By careful, expensive restoration? By finding appropriate new uses?

title: U.S. Trying Lease-Purchases on Its New Buildings
description: An office building under construction here is the first of a dozen Federal projects throughout the United States that will use a development method that involves long-term leases rather than outright purchases of new buildings the Government commissions for its own occupancy.

title: 9 People Arrested in Protest Of Staten I. Navy Home Port
description: Nine demonstrators were arrested yesterday in the Stapleton section of Staten Island during an otherwise peaceful protest by about 125 people against the construction of a Navy home port there, the police said.

title: The Stark Reality That Racial Theorists Miss
description: To the Editor:

title: Brookhaven Is Favored as Weather Radar Site
description: National Weather Service officials, rebuffed by residents of Sayville, L.I., say they now hope to place a new weather radar system for the New York metropolitan region on the 5,600-acre home of Brookhaven National Laboratory on Long Island.

title: Needed: A Longer School Year
description: AMERICANS are now working longer and harder than at perhaps any time in this century. We have to in order to compete with Asians and Europeans in the new global economy.

title: BIG, RICH AND USEFUL
description: SCALE AND SCOPE

title: I.M.F. IS EXPECTING BIG FUND INCREASE
description: Finance ministers and central bank governors representing most countries of the world are expected shortly to approve at least a 50 percent increase in the $120 billion resources of the International Monetary Fund.

title: New Leader Carries On Sherlockian Tradition
description: LEAD: IT'S elementary, Thomas Stix said when asked to describe the purpose of the Baker Street Irregulars. Mr. Stix is the leader of this Sherlock Holmes society, whose main goal is, as he puts it, ''to keep alive the memory of the master.''

title: LONG LAYOFF TAKES TOLL ON RIGHETTI
description: In the first few minutes after the game, Dave Righetti seemed like a solitary figure sitting in front of his locker. He was slumped over, his elbows resting on his knees, his hands clasped tightly, his head down, his eyes still lost in the events of the night.

title: U.S. Paid Romania for Soviet Arms, Report Says
description: Through a complex series of transactions involving two brothers of the deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, the United States paid more than $40 million to Romania for Soviet military technology over a 10-year period, The Washington Post reported today.

title: Jobs Program for Students Is Lagging
description: A JOBS program that was supposed to place 10,000 urban high school graduates into upwardly mobile positions by 1992 is falling far short of its goal, prompting state officials to re-examine the program to see if it can be structured more effectively.

title: NONFICTION
description: MY LIFE IN THREE ACTS. By Helen Hayes with Katherine Hatch. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) Anyone who wants to know what the American theater would say if it could talk need only read ''My Life in Three Acts'' by Helen Hayes. In her memoir, written with the freelance journalist Katherine Hatch, Miss Hayes reflects on her towering life and career as the first lady of the American theater, beginning with her Broadway debut in 1909, when she was 9 years old, and continuing through her retirement from the stage in 1972 and her occasional film assignments and philanthropic work since. The predictably becoming modesty of a grande dame is offset by Miss Hayes's surprising candor, divulging a wry and accurate perception of her public image. ''People assume that I am a strong person. We all have to develop strength, backbone, to survive, but in my case that was a slow process,'' she writes in a discussion of her early years, when she had to contend with her mother's love of both the theater and alcohol. Throughout the book, she makes no secret of her animosity toward Hollywood (''It's depressing to think that such an artificial and unbalanced community exerts so much influence on our country''), which she blames for a deterioration in more than just acting standards. She can be equally outspoken on the many peers and colleagues who bring vinegar to these pages even as they added spice to her life. Lynn Fontanne ''had no class whatsoever'' before her alignment with Alfred Lunt. Clifford Odets was ''a crashing bore'' and a hypocrite. Richard Burton ''cared only for himself.'' Harold Clurman ''talked too much.'' Gloria Swanson, Katharine Cornell, F. Scott Fitzgerald and Charlie Chaplin are among the others who make brief but vivid appearances. With anecdotes, insights and advice, Miss Hayes captures the history of the American theater by merely focusing on her own story.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

My Career as Huck Finn at the Picket Fence
description: LEAD: ''DON'T start,'' my husband warned. ''It's an endless job.'' That was last summer when I announced my intention of painting our picket fence. We'd only recently bought the house and were living in Sag Harbor almost full time.

title: JOHN PAUL ARRIVES IN MEXICO TODAY
description: Pope John Paul II is scheduled to arrive here Sunday to begin a weeklong visit to a country whose people are overwhelmingly Roman Catholic but whose Government maintains no diplomatic relations with the Vatican and has a tense relationship with the local church.

title: In Vitro Fertilization Comes of Age
description: EIGHTEEN months ago, when her gynecologist gave her the option of having tubal reconstruction or in vitro fertilization to help overcome her infertility problems, Linda Comcowich of Lynbrook was anxious.

title: Plenty of Horn
description: BEN NEILL SAYS THE MUSIC HE makes has the qualities of a conversation, not a new idea in ensemble playing, which Neill, 32, who was trained as a classical trumpet player, does a fair amount of. But he is speaking of solo work, talking with himself, as it were, which was the inspiration for the instrument he designed and built and is shown playing above. He calls it, appropriately, a mutantrumpet.

title: REKINDLING THE FIRES OF UTOPIAN MODERNISM
description: To most visitors who stroll into the downtown branch of the Whitney Museum in lower Manhattan, if stroll is the word to describe the act of descending into this subterranean white chamber beneath an office building, the work by Tod Williams and Billie Tsien that is now on view will appear avant-garde. Entitled ''Domestic Arrangements: A Lab Report,'' the exhibition is a kind of rumination on living patterns and their architectural expression. If it looks at first like a model for a new, highly abstract kind of residential interior, it turns out instead to be more a series of separate but related experiments in which plain, industrial materials are used in new ways, to yield new kinds of furniture, new kinds of walls, new kinds of spaces. The whole thing comes off as a plea for an architecture of restraint, discipline and serenity - for an architecture that is in many ways the opposite of the opulent forms that have had so conspicuous a presence in the lavish 80's.

title: With Overtime, Electrician Out-Earns Mayor
description: Led by a supervising electrician in the Department of Correction who was paid more than the Mayor, New York City employees made $426 million in overtime last year, a city report says.

title: OLD RECORDS LIVE BY THE NUMBERS
description: As the triumphant CD edged its vinyl predecessors off the shelves, there was initial concern that treasured recordings of earlier times might vanish forever. The present flood of CD reissues of vintage recordings has proved such fears groundless.

title: Bert J. DeLeeuw , Organizer, 44
description: Bert Jay DeLeeuw, an organic farmer who was a former official of the National Welfare Rights Organization, died of a gunshot wound on Wednesday at J. C. Blair Hospital in Huntingdon, Pa. He was 44 years old and lived in Walker Township, Pa. The police arrested a neighbor and charged him with homicide.

title: On Language;   Lay Down Your Marker
description: THESE POLITICIANS want Bush to lay down a marker for all the world to see,'' wrote the columnists Evans and Novak in their muscular style, ''no matter how much discomfort it brings Gorbachev and his trading pals in Bonn.''

title: Review/Cabaret;   'D'Oyly 'Carte Blanche,' a Cinema Sendup
description: Near the end of ''A D'Oyly Carte Blanche,'' an amusing set piece in Barry Keating's cabaret musical ''Hollywood Opera,'' Mary Cleere Haran, impersonating Viven Leigh as Blanche DuBois, tiptoes to the edge of the stage and borrows a menu from a ringside table. ''I'm always dependent on the wine lists of strangers,'' she announces, taking a break from a breathless Gilbert and Sullivan-style patter song in which the Tennessee Williams character from ''A Streetcar Named Desire'' tells her unhappy story in witty rhymed verses.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: JAN STAUBER;

A Club for Anyone, With a High I.Q.
description: LEAD: WHAT bothers her the most, says Jan Stauber, who represents the northern New Jersey chapter of Mensa, an organization for extraordinarily intelligent people, is that its members are considered snobs by many in the general population. That is a far cry from the truth, she says, because members come from every walk of life.

description: gfsubhead>ON THE CAROUSEL

title: Russian Leads in Tour
description: Vyacheslav Bobrik, a 19-year-old member of the Soviet amateur team, won the third stage of the Tour de Trump bicycle race today after a bold move. The victory made him the overall leader in the 11-day stage race. After 27 miles of the 87.7-mile road race from Fredericksburg to Richmond, three riders broke away from the 129 others. The first was Mike McCarthy, a 21-year-old amateur from New York and the SubaruMontgomery team. He was joined by 23-year-old Thierry Bock of Belgium and Bobrik.

title: BRAINY BLONDES
description: Their roots may spring from Marilyn Monroe, Jayne Mansfield and Jean Harlow, but the new generation of blondes is not breathless and bawdy. They are the brainy blondes, and their hair color has no relation to their I.Q.'s.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Cosmetics From the West Help to Change the Face of China
description: Gu Jibao, her eyes sparkling beneath a soft shadow of purple on the eyelids, fussed with a small jar of face cream, frowned, smiled, and then plunked nearly a week's worth of her salary on the counter.

title: Celtics Stung By Loss
description: Robert Parish, his pride evidently still stinging, brusquely left practice here today, waving away reporters in what seemed part of a larger attempt to erase all reminders of the debacle the Celtics had endured less than 24 hours earlier at the hands of the Knicks.

title: NEVER WOULD VIOLET TIRE OF LIFE
description: SEPTEMBER

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: For This Week: In colder regions it is still too early to plant tomatoes, eggplants, seed of any beans particularly limas, or squash, seedlings of impatiens and begonias; wait for another week or two because the soil and nights must be warm. Snap old flowers from pansy plants to keep them blooming. Continue planting shrubs and perennials. Start composting; for the first layer use vegetable row thinnings and faded flowers from spring bulbs.

title: Buying a Home May Still Beat Renting
description: CARL COCHRANE was introduced to the hard realities of today's sagging real estate market when he decided to sell his town house in Edison, N.J., and take a new job in Dallas.

title: First Lady: Role Or Role Model?
description: She may not be known as a public speaker but Barbara Bush's commencement speech at Wellesley College had a lot of people speaking up last week, a month before she is scheduled to give it.

title: Dr. Golfinopoulos Weds
description: Dr. Olga Golfinopoulos and Dr. Marinos Anthony Petratos were married yesterday at the Greek Orthodox Archdiocesan Cathedral of the Holy Trinity in New York. Bishop Philotheos of Meloa and the Rev. Dr. Robert Stephanopoulos, Dean of the cathedral, officiated. The bride, who will keep her name professionally, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Golfinopoulos of Fort Lee, N.J. She graduated from William Paterson College and received a medical degree from the University of Athens. The bridegroom, a dermatologist, is a son of Vasiliki Petratos of New York and the late Anthony Petratos. He is a graduate of New York University and the Seton Hall University College of Medicine.

title: Let's Have A White Market
description: To the Editor:

title: Homeless, but Not Helpless
description: Homeless families are often baffled by New York City's maze of services. Now 11 women from midtown Manhattan welfare hotels offer help: ''The Survival Manual (Useful Information for People Who Have to Live in the Hotels for Displaced Families).''

title: Health-Insurance Law Needs Fine Tuning
description: To the Editor:

description: LEAD: How long will it take for an object dropped from a height of 100 feet to reach the ground? What official document contains the German ''war guilt'' clause? In marriage, what does the roundness of the ring represent?

title: STUDIOUS STITCHES OF ANOTHER TIME LIVE ON AS ART
description: Betty Ring's exquisitely stitched 18th- and 19th-century American samplers and embroideries abound with aphorisms and images copied from engravings. Mrs. Ring began collecting in 1960 and owns more than 400 pieces of needlework.

title: The Executive Computer;   Handy Tools for Taming an Unruly Operating System
description: Utility programs can tame unruly operating systems, find lost files, back up and protect data, speed up the operation of hard disks, guard against computer viruses, prolong the life of a monitor, add new functions, and more. Last week's column discussed utilities that combine major functions into a single package for users of I.B.M. PC, PS/2 and compatible computers, such as Central Point Software's PC Tools Deluxe 6.0.This week's column looks at utilities packages for businesses that use Macintosh or Unix systems.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Builders Trim Bids on Public Projects
description: WHEN the State Department of Transportation sought bids earlier this year for repairs to the Saugatuck River bridge on Route 1 in Westport, officials expected to pay $11.8 million for the work. But the low bid, from the George A. Tomasso Construction Corporation in New Britain, was 24 percent lower than that, $8.9 million, said Susan Reynolds, a spokeswoman for the department.

title: WOMAN DIES AFTER BEATING OVER RADIO THEFT
description: A woman who tried to sell a stolen car radio to people in a Brooklyn restaurant died yesterday morning after a man who was having breakfast there said the radio was his and attacked her with a club, the police said.

title: WHAT PRICE GLORY? TOO HIGH
description: Make no mistake, rare wine is money, as Frank J. Prial indicates in his wine column ''What Price Glory?: Too High'' (March 25). I know of people who have gone broke and been saved by their wine collections. Recently, a young stockbroker lost his job. He was also divorced. All he had was a nifty cellar that had cost him $100,000 in the late 1970's. He sold the wines at auction and received a net of $455,000. Enough to keep him going, I would say. Conservatively, rare wine can appreciate at the rate of 15 percent per annum. Drink $7 bottles of Chilean wines; they are delicious. Save your Petrus and Lafite for appreciation. You will not regret it.

title: MICKEY MOUSE BUILDINGS
description: It occurred to me, after reading Patricia Leigh Brown's article ''Disney Deco'' (April 8), that the architects for Disney could save considerable effort and expense if they were to construct a giant set of portable mouse ears that could be affixed to existing buildings. Say, Disney needs some office space in New York City. Just slap the ears on top of the Empire State Building. India? They'd look pretty good gracing the domes of the Taj Mahal. France? No doubt they could be bolted to the Eiffel Tower. The possibilities abound.

title: An AIDS Memoir
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Spirit Of Humanity And the Arts
description: The 96-year-old American Academy in Rome celebrated the Year of the Landscape Artist on Wednesday evening at Tavern on the Green. Three artists were honored: Millicent Johnsen, Rachel (Bunny) Mellon and Daniel U. Kiley.

title: Katharine Ross Is Wed in Greenwich
description: The marriage of Katharine Hudson Ross, a daughter of Mrs. Andrew Rockefeller of Greenwich, Conn., and Henry L. Ross of Rancho Mirage, Calif., to Charles Lee Johnson, a son of Judge Robertson L. Johnson of Portland, Ore., and the late Dorothy Johnson, took place yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich. The Rev. Terence L. Elsberry officiated.

title: Blossoming From Trios To Tributes,
description: ''I am so happy and proud to participate in the 60th Anniversary of the Westchester Conservatory of Music,'' said Cab Calloway, the jazz great and White Plains resident whose children once studied at the school. ''It is so gratifying that young people here in Westchester have the opportunity to avail themselves of the wonderful world of music, guided by the dedicated and superbly qualified faculty of the conservatory.''

title: In 'Tod,' a Journey in the Maze of the Mind
description: AT the end of a tortuous odyssey to reclaim his soul and realize his black identity, Tod, the very model of establishment success - white establishment success - reaches an epiphanic moment. It sounds all too obvious, contrived and even ambiguous, but the message of solidarity he arrives at has the intimations of idealism and a hint of inspiration. One's impulse is to stand up and cheer.

title: The Thin-Mint Theory of Forecasting
description: The senior vice president rested a hand on my shoulder. ''You sure don't look like a Girl Scout,'' he said. ''We're changing with the times,'' I answered. ''Now, are you going to order or not?''

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Friendship's Invisible Link
description: LEAD: WE met in our third year of undergraduate school. There were four girls: two sets of roommates; two sets of best friends crisscrossing the abyss of the stark wooden hallway in an old house the college converted into a small dormitory.

title: G. W. Vreeland And Miss Lucas Exchange Vows
description: Elizabeth Ann Lucas, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Brainard Lucas Jr. of Watchung and Mantoloking, N.J., was married yesterday to Garret Walker Vreeland, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Walker Vreeland of Summit, N.J., and Mantoloking. The Rev. William Dowd performed the ceremony at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church in Bay Head, N.J.

title: Review/Theater;   When 2 Worlds Met in Washington Heights
description: The name of the play, ''New York 1937,'' sets the scene for Jose Yglesias's recollective piece being staged at the Jewish Repertory Theater.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on the television page last Sunday about the series ''Cheers'' misidentified the character played by Kirstie Alley. She is the manager of the bar, not a waitress. c

title: Rallies Opposing Gay Students Disrupt Campuses
description: An antihomosexual rall by a student group at the University of Massachusetts to show what demonstrators called ''straight pride'' has touched off heated exchanges with the homosexual and bisexual community.

title: A FEMINIST TAKES STOCK
description: Your article caught my eye, especially the paragraph referring to ''All About Eve.'' This amused me very much.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Water seeps through the concrete floor of my basement. This problem has developed near where valving was installed for an automatic sprinkling system. The system, buried two feet deep near where the puddling occurs, does not leak. Applying a waterproof sealer to the floor did not help. Any suggestions?

title: Disbelieving and Defiant, Students Vow: No Men
description: Tears of sorrow have turned to shouts of defiance at Mills College, where students have vowed to shut the school until the trustees reverse their decision to end the institution's 138-year tradition as a women's college.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Trading Fauna For Flora, Wistfully
description: LEAD: All over Eastern and Central Europe barriers both physical and political are toppling. People once corraled behind the borders of their countries are now free to roam. I rejoice, as do all lovers of freedom, as the reports of yet another chunk of wall crumbling or piece of metaphorical chain link parting appear on the evening news.

title: When They Hear That Old Fire Bell Ring, They're Liable to Buy It
description: As a rookie firefighter in Brooklyn in the 1950's, Ceaser William Sansevero had no idea what his first top-to-bottom firehouse inspection would lead to: a lifelong hobby collecting firefighting equipment.

title: Spring Sounds: Ping! Thud! 'Play Ball!'
description: LEAD: THE ping of baseballs hit with aluminum bats and the thud as they fall into freshly oiled gloves are being heard again around the state. Once more, Little League fields are filled with players who dream of home runs and coaches who remember their own youthful exploits.

title: A FEMINIST TAKES STOCK
description: Apparently, Vivian Gornick has been living in an ivory tower for so long that she considers conversations with fellow academics to represent the public at large (''Who Says We Haven't Made a Revolution?'' April 15). Even comments about the tribulations of welfare mothers come (secondhand) from doctoral students at Harvard. Her brief encounter with real, working, ''pink collar'' people is an overheard conversation in downtown Manhattan.

title: One Landmark, As Is. We Don't Deliver
description: A pink granite fountain, New York City's first large monument honoring a woman, sits in regal if dusty disrepair at the western end of Bryant Park. It needs extensive restoration and new plumbing and electrical equipment that will cost about $175,000.

title: 'What Lisa Knew'
description: To the Editor:

title: HOLY OBSESSIONS
description: The so-called outsider artist is usually driven by an obsession that is inaccessible to the general population. As a result, his work communicates arcane truth, when it manages to communicate anything at all. Howard Finster is different. Since 1976, when he was inspired by a vision to ''paint sacred art,'' Mr. Finster has created thousands of paintings and sculptures that preach his version of Christian truth and salvation. His chef d'oeuvre is Paradise Garden, a biblical theme park in his hometown of Pennville, Ga., that attracts thousands of visitors every year. Mr. Finster, who is 74 years old, is often called a folk artist, but the persistence and intensity of his compulsion to save mankind from eternal damnation through art is more consistent with outsider art. Topical references to celebrities like Elvis Presley aside, his work is self-referential and egocentric. J. F. Turner, a curator at the San Francisco Craft and Folk Art Museum, has produced in HOWARD FINSTER: Man of Visions (Knopf, $40) a book that is essentially a running monologue in which Mr. Finster, a gifted storyteller, rambles on about his life before and after art. The book's strength is not so much what Mr. Finster says (he's more entertaining as a raconteur than believable as an autobiographer) as the spirit in which he says it. Mr. Turner conveys the passion and single-mindedness of Mr. Finster's artistic zeal. However, by letting Mr. Finster sing his own song, he has produced only half a book. The more one listens to the self-proclaimed ''man of visions,'' the more one needs someone to provide a reasoned exegesis of his art. Mr. Turner does not attempt to place Mr. Finster within a broad socioreligious context informed by Southern folk traditions.

title: Mutual Funds;   Fee Cut May Be a Trojan Horse
description: Any cap on mutual fund fees should be good news for investors. But the recent proposal by the National Association of Securities Dealers, which aims to save investors money by revamping rules for how funds finance their sales operations, may not work that way.

title: Ireland
description: To the Editor: Travelers planning to visit Ireland might benefit from my experience in car rental, the cost of which was included in our seven-day package.

title: A FEMINIST TAKES STOCK
description: I am troubled by Vivan Gornick's assumption that young women today are unwilling to be labeled ''feminist.'' This implies that they are not grateful or even aware of the sacrifices and gains made by pioneer feminists. I am a 26-year-old professional woman and I proudly call myself a feminist. I recognize the relative privilege of my position compared to women of the past, and I am grateful for the women's movement and the opportunities it has created for me.

title: In South Africa, Foes Are Humanized
description: An elderly black woman stood outside the airport terminal this morning, awaiting the arrival of Albie Sachs, a veteran of the African National Congress who was returning home after 24 years in exile.

title: Bush's English Connection
description: IF President Bush goes back to his ancestral roots he will find himself in a rustic corner of England, where many things remain as they were when his Puritan forefather, Reynold Bush, set sail for America in 1631, settling in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Unbridled Wins the Derby in an Upset
description: Unbridled soared past Summer Squall through the stretch to score a surprising 3 1/2-length victory today in the 116th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.

title: Padres' Jack Clark Becomes No. 00
description: Jack Clark, the San Diego Padres first baseman, has received permission from the National League to change his uniform number for the fifth time in his 14-year major league career. He will now wear 00.

title: Unfair to Frogs
description: A would-be biochemistry major has moved the debate over frog dissection from its familiar high-school forum to the university. Jennifer Routh, a sophomore at the State University of New York at Stony Brook who is considering a career in medicine, is suing the school over the frog dissection requirement in an introductory biology course. Ms. Routh, a vegetarian, also rejected the option of observing a partner's work. The course is a requirement for biology and biochemistry majors. In her suit, Ms. Routh argues that the requirement violates her First Amendment right to exercise her moral and religious beliefs. Ms. Routh's lawyer, Gary Francione, said the lawsuit is the first time a university has been sued over participation in dissection, although many high schools have been successfully sued. Mr. Francione said he hoped the case ''would finally crystalize what is a clear rule of law, that the state can never make a person engage in conduct inimical to religious and moral beliefs under these sorts of circumstances.''

Reflections on the Chinese experience during the past quarter-century by a writer who was born in China, raised in America. 11 10 107 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 12 13 14 THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Clifford Stoll. (Doubleday, $19.95.) An astrophysicist tells how he stalked a computer hacker. 13 * 8 11 WHAT I SAW AT THE REVOLUTION, by Peggy Noonan. (Random House, $19.95.) The memoirs of a former Presidential speechwriter. 14 1 THE BROKEN CORD, by Michael Dorris. (Harper & Row, $18.95.) The struggle of a family to cope with the fetal alcohol syndrome of an adopted son. 15 1 FLASHBACKS, by Morley Safer. (Random House, $18.95.) The observations of a journalist on revisiting Vietnam 25 years later. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 2 64 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's financial advice. 2 1 21 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a ubiquitous chap named Waldo. 3 3 10 SECRETS ABOUT MEN EVERY WOMAN SHOULD KNOW, by Barbara De Angelis. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Ways by which women can improve their relationships with men. 4 4 11 BEWARE THE NAKED MAN WHO OFFERS YOU HIS SHIRT, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $19.95.) Advice on how to get ahead in business. 5 2 THE BETTER HOMES AND GARDENS NEW COOKBOOK. (Meredith, $19.95.) A ring-bound version of the 10th edition.

title: Crime Weakens Support for Bhutto, Even in Her Traditional Power Base
description: Summer is coming to Sind. The dry earth and stones are baked by a white sun that fires temperatures up to 120 degrees. In the farming villages along the Indus River, the political base of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto, it should be the start of an outdoor season, a time to stray from small mudbrick houses to search the dark evenings for a less suffocating place to rest. Not this year.

title: A Restaurant Feeds A Shelter's Hungry
description: Frank Miller looks forward to dinner every night, but Saturdays are special. On a recent Saturday, Mr. Miller dined on duck stew prepared by the chef at Livanos restaurant at 200 Central Avenue in White Plains. But Mr. Miller was not a patron of the restaurant. He and 76 other homeless people ate their gourmet meal at the shelter for the homeless at the Westchester County Airport.

title: Outdoor Film Is Defended
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Survivability Of Weapons Begins At Home
description: JUST in case Congress had any doubt that cutting billions of dollars from the Pentagon budget might be easier in theory than reality, some imaginative defense contractors left a little reminder at the foot of the Capitol a few weeks ago: a gleaming white aircraft, not quite plane and not quite helicopter, known as the V-22 Osprey.

title: 'IS THAT A JOKE, DEAR?'
description: IN A FATHER'S PLACE

title: South Africans Discover A Patch of Common Ground
description: GROOTE Schuur, the residence of the late patriarch of colonialism, Cecil Rhodes, provided the backdrop of a drama last week that played to the bedrock hopes and fears of South Africans. After three days of talks in Mr. Rhodes's elegant dining room, the South African Government and the African National Congress announced that they had made substantial progress toward resolving obstacles to full-fledged negotiations on a new constitution that would extend political power to blacks.

title: Ensembles Preparing Season Finales
description: THE Hartford Symphony is winding down its season this week with regular subscription programs, its last pair of pops, and a final family concert, all at the Bushnell in Hartford.

title: High Asbestos Exposure Seen in School Custodians
description: Doctors have found lung scarring consistent with exposure to asbestos in more than a quarter of the veteran school custodians examined for a Board of Education study, indicating that the workers are at a high risk of developing cancer and other asbestos-related diseases.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE BABY WHO WOULD NOT COME DOWN

title: Question Of the Week;   Why Is The Triple Crown Won So Rarely?
description: One difficult factor in winning the Triple Crown is that unlike other tournaments, new participants may enter during later rounds. But during the Triple Crown, a fresh contender may enter the Belmont only. That horse is in a much better position to win the final jewel than a horse that has raced and moved twice before the last leg.

title: FICTION
description: WILD AT HEART: The Story of Sailor and Lula. By Barry Gifford. (Grove Weidenfeld, $15.95.) Barry Gifford's fourth novel (which David Lynch, the director of ''Blue Velvet,'' is bringing to the screen) is made up mostly of conversations in cars, Southern variety. In ''Wild at Heart,'' Sailor Ripley, fresh from two years in a North Carolina prison farm, breaks parole and hits the road for dream-bright California. Along for the ride is his girlfriend, Lula Pace Fortune. On their tail is a private investigator, Johnnie Farragut, who's trying to win the affections of Lula's disapproving mother, Marietta. Sailor is thoughtful but spacey, a sweet boy who nonetheless suffers an amoral lack of judgment. Lula, barely out of her teens, is the one to reckon with - dreamy, poetic, persevering, meditative, perspicacious, heartsore and practical to boot. Her past is disturbing, too. When the others are on stage, Barry Gifford's brief gab-driven novel offers a tangy low-life farce, spiced by eccentricities but never quite achieving full novelistic pungency. The lovelorn tracker Farragut, a bit of a writer himself, seems likable, but he's a desultory detective at best. The man never figures out enough of what's going on to deserve genuine sympathy. And Bobby Peru, the bad boy who comes to threaten Sailor and Lula's flight, has some awfully familiar elements: bigotry, misogyny, bloodlust left over from Vietnam, even steel-toed boots. Whenever Lula is at the center of events, however, the drawling sideways talk can hurt like fine fiction should hurt; she delivers surprises at once artful and humane. Not for nothing does Mr. Gifford give her the novel's title line: ''The world is really wild at heart and weird on top.''

title: Patricia Schlegel Becomes a Bride
description: Patricia Kim Schlegel, a lawyer, and Anthony John Pasquale Bosco, an Assistant Manhattan District Attorney, were married yesterday at the United Methodist Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew in New York. The Rev. Edward C. Horne and the Rev. James F. Karpen officiated. The bride, who will keep her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Wesley P. Schlegel of Ness City, Kan. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Bosco of Berkeley Heights, N.J.

title: Greyhound Talks Reopened A Day After Loss Is Reported
description: Striking Greyhound drivers and the bus line resumed negotiations today, their first contract talks since mid-March. The action came a day after the company reported a $56 million loss for the first three months this year.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: State Street Penitent;   A Taste of the Past to Emend a Builder's Blunder
description: FROM the ground up - indeed, from beneath the ground up - 17 State Street has proved at almost every turn to be troubled. But there are new signs of life at the largely empty 42-story tower overlooking the Battery, which will soon be distinguished by one of the more unusual examples of a developer's ''penance'' for running afoul of New York City land-use procedure.

title: U.S. Trying Lease-Purchases on Its New Buildings
description: An office building under construction here is the first of a dozen Federal projects throughout the United States that will use a development method that involves long-term leases rather than outright purchases of new buildings the Government commissions for its own occupancy.

title: An Icon of the Good Life Ends Up On a Crowded Planet's Hit Lists
description: FOR generations, dairy has been synonomous with ''pure,'' beef with ''strong.'' And cattle have ranged over the soul of America, a symbol of wide-open spaces, broncobuster spirit and the bucolic life on the family farm.

title: FORMALISTS, LOOSELY SPEAKING
description: BEFORE IT VANISHES

title: INSIDE
description: Crime Threatens Bhutto Increasing lawlessness seems to be

title: For a Dutch Treat, Sweet Pancakes
description: IN the United States, practically every fairground, boardwalk and carnival has a cotton candy stand; until not so long ago similar places in the Netherlands had a poffertjes pavilion. Pronounced POF-er-jiz, these humble pancakes are silver dollar size, have a wafflelike taste and the texture of chewy brownies. Tradition calls for a topping of butter and powdered sugar but preserves, whipped cream, fresh fruit, liqueurs and ice cream are also found.

title: Industrial Yard Plan Upsets Southampton
description: LEAD: IN many parts of Long Island, residential neighborhoods and business and light-industrial sites exist in uneasy proximity because they were established before planning and zoning laws were enacted.

title: Cloud Haunts Mets, Come Rain or Shine
description: The weather can be drizzly or sunny, mild or chilly. The opponent can be the Cincinnati Reds, one of the finest teams in the league, or the Atlanta Braves, one of the worst. It can happen in the Astrodome, in Atlanta or at Shea Stadium.

title: Word Has It They'll Raise The Rent
description: No one knows for sure yet, but rentals for movies at the video store - now in the $2.50 to $3 range - could take a jump in the next few months. Rent is connected to price, both retail and wholesale. Blaming higher costs and a soft rental market, four major studios - Warner, Paramount, MCA/Universal and RCA/Columbia - are raising the retail list prices of rental ''A titles'' (the best-known movies) from the $89.95 level prevalent since 1986 to $92.95 or thereabouts. In many cases these studios no longer list any retail price for rental titles, an indication that prices have gone up. Some observers predict that by year's end the price will be at $99.95.

title: New Milk Rules Face Challenge in New Jersey
description: For a time it appeared that the long New York-New Jersey milk war was over, settled by a Federal court ruling that set aside New Jersey's protectionist milk regulations. But new rules quickly imposed by New Jersey are bringing the dispute back into court.

title: LIVE FROM AMERICA ...
description: SATURDAY NIGHT

title: Review/Concert;   Rondi Charleston Wins Art Song Vocal Competition
description: Rondi Charleston's concert on Monday night at Weill Recital Hall was not an ordinary song recital. It was the culmination of a new American Art Song Vocal Competition sponsored by the New York chapter of the National Association of Teachers of Singing. And it was preceded by an hour's worth of mini-recitals by the two runners-up. That meant 3 sopranos, 3 pianists and 13 American composers of American songs.

title: RECOVERY REVISED
description: LEAD:

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Helping the Island Helps the State
description: LEAD: MAYBE having been a Long Islander all my life helps, but I have found it easy to operate on the assumption that helping Long Island's economy is good for the whole state. So we have done a lot to strengthen the Island's ability to do business and create jobs. New York provides low-cost energy to large Long Island employers like Grumman and Computer Associates

title: Question Of the Week;   Why Is The Triple Crown Won So Rarely?
description: As one who saw Citation win the Triple Crown and who waited 25 years to see Secretariat complete the next Triple Crown, I would suggest that immature, injury-prone 3-year-olds (equivalent in age to a human teen-ager), competing on three different and widely differing race tracks within a short span of time, face a daunting challenge. Beyond sheer ability, luck must also play a large part.

title: Diane Goldsmith to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Victor Goldsmith of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Diane J. Goldsmith, and Carleton J. Schade, a son of Capt. Calvin Schade, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Schade of Ozark, Ala.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

War and Memory, 20 Years Later
description: LEAD: THE small cedar box had lived in the medium-sized piece of luggage along with other memorabilia of the war. Boxes of photo slides, a Chinese-made magazine from an automatic rifle, a topographical map, a beret, some leather-boxed medals.

title:
Style Makers;

David Picon: SCARF DESIGNER
description: LEAD: When is a scarf more than a scarf? When it is designed and hand-painted on silk chiffon by David Picon, then draped and tied to make original skirts, tops, sarongs, cummerbunds and even full-length evening wear.

title: The Stark Reality That Racial Theorists Miss;   Unequal Treatment
description: To the Editor:

title: A FEMINIST TAKES STOCK
description: My thanks to Vivian Gornick for her splendid article. I have been taking two steps forward and one back as a feminist, along with the movement, for the last 30 years. Having been forced into marriage by an unplanned pregnancy at the age of 18 and after spending years on welfare, working at sundry low-paying jobs, raising my son by myself, I have managed to get a B.A., M.F.A. and J.D. This year (at the age of 46), I was admitted to the New York State bar.

title: Elm Saplings Promise a Green Future
description: CONNECTICUT communities are joining a nationwide effort to bring elm trees back to their streets and parks. Most of the American elms that once graced the greens of the state's towns were wiped out decades ago by Dutch elm disease. But now, a nonprofit institute, led by a former Connecticut resident, is distributing disease-resistant elm saplings that can grow to provide beauty and shade in decades to come.

title: Studying Pitchers May Provide Answers on Shoulder Injuries
description: Pitchers and pitching coaches sprinkle their conversations with terms like split-fingered fastball and knuckle-curve and straight change. They never talk about anterior subluxation, nor any kind of subluxation, for that matter.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: T. B. Higginson Is Wed in Illinois To Ms. Schwartz
description: Sally Roslyn Schwartz and Timothy Bowditch Higginson were married yesterday at Temple Am Shalom in Glencoe, Ill. Rabbis Harold Kudan and Scott Looper officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alan G. Schwartz of Highland Park, Ill. Mr. Higginson is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Higginson of Cohasset, Mass., and Washington.

title: U.S. Military Cancels Leave After Slaying in Philippines
description: The United States military canceled off-post leaves today for American servicemen in the Philippines after a Marine was shot and killed outside the Subic Bay naval base. Officials said that Communist rebels probably were responsible for the slaying.

title: A Show of 3 Contemporaries In an Old English Setting
description: Concordia was founded as a school in 1861, then in 1865 was transformed into a liberal arts college that has since developed a reputation for music education. Its red and white brick building makes an imposing landmark at 171 White Plains Post Road and, the Tudor facade with its leaded windows and the quadrangle behind speak of Old England, roast beef and all. But the style was flourishing when Luther was establishing his form of Protestantism in the German states, and Lutheranism according to the rules of the Missouri Synod is the faith behind Concordia.

title: Nina Hyde, 57, a Fashion Editor Who Became a Pacesetter, Is Dead
description: Nina Hyde, the fashion editor of The Washington Post and a pacesetter in the fields of style and fashion, died Friday night after a long bout with breast cancer at the Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. She was 57 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Water seeps through the concrete floor of my basement. This problem has developed near where valving was installed for an automatic sprinkling system. The system, buried two feet deep near where the puddling occurs, does not leak. Applying a waterproof sealer to the floor did not help. Any suggestions?

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Opting for Preschool Instead of a Partnership
description: LEAD: I often drive a neighbor's two daughters to school in the morning. The girls stand by the driveway and then hop in the car with my two daughters. I never mind. I love hearing the giggles and silly talk than comes easily when there are four young girls together.

title: World Markets;   Canada's Market Timing Puzzle
description: Canada is an opportunity waiting to happen. The opportunities center on commodities stocks, from copper to paper products, which play a major role in the economy and are expected to benefit from both an expected rebound in the Canadian economy and the recent rise in commodities prices.

title: Movie Music Concerts: Roll Over, Beethoven
description: ''STAR WARS'' is still playing in some of the biggest halls in Connecticut. Concert halls, that is. And so are ''Lawrence of Arabia,'' ''Psycho'' and ''Platoon.''

title: Q and A
description: Gains Tax for a Foreigner

title:
DINING OUT;

An International Menu in Scarsdale
description: LEAD: In the two short years since its opening, Cafe L. A. has managed both to elude the blahs that often set in after initial accolades and to maintain high quality in both ingredients and performance. David Shakin, Cafe L. A.'s creative chef, has designed a distinctive menu for this restaurant, an appealing international mix that he calls contemporary Italian-American (erstwhile California).

title: Proposals Sought for Neglected Gas Stations
description: For nearly a decade, commuters driving through Westchester County on the Saw Mill River Parkway have noticed a pair of handsomely built but abandoned gas stations in Yonkers, vestiges of a more leisurely past.

title: THE GUIDE
description: BURR SISTERS

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Water seeps through the concrete floor of my basement. This problem has developed near where valving was installed for an automatic sprinkling system. The system, buried two feet deep near where the puddling occurs, does not leak. Applying a waterproof sealer to the floor did not help. Any suggestions?

title: Donald MacArthur, Sears, Roebuck Executive, 88
description: Donald MacArthur, a former treasurer of Sears, Roebuck & Company, died Thursday of heart failure at the Lansing Holiday Inn, outside Chicago, while traveling to Wisconsin. He was 88 years old and a resident of Sarasota, Fla., and Antigo, Wis.

title: Tactics in Wall Street Cases Troubling Some Lawyers
description: AFTER spending 11 months in a prison cell convicted of insider trading, Robert Chestman was a free man last week, his sentence cut short by a Federal appeals court that threw out his conviction. In its decision, the court reached several surprising conclusions, but one seemed to stand out: the Government had failed to provide sufficient evidence that Mr. Chestman was given any inside information before he purchased stock in Waldbaum Inc. the day before it announced it would be taken over.

title: Bloomingdale's Lease May Be Challenged
description: The landlord of Bloomingdale's flagship store in Manhattan has filed preliminary court papers that could lead to eviction proceedings.

title: A LONG WAY FROM TOKYO
description: FOREIGN STUDIES

title: Technology;   Sensing the Presence Of Potential Problems
description: When people get bruised, cut or fatigued, their nervous systems send signals of pain and soreness that effectively warn them to address the problem before it leads to more serious damage.

title: Currency;   Surprise Figures Shake the Dollar
description: THE employment numbers for April took the market by surprise on Friday and knocked the dollar lower. The surprise was that the report showed a weaker economy than expected. Rather than declining, the unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.4 percent. After adjusting for an influx of census workers, non-farm payroll jobs declined. Because the employment figures run counter to other recent data showing the economy to be relatively strong, the betting is now likely to change on the Federal Reserve's next move on interest rates. In recent weeks, as economic reports indicated that inflation was resisting pressure to decline, many analysts had decided that the Fed was on the verge of pushing rates slightly higher.

title: New Course Offers Grammar Skills
description: LAST year, when the A. T. Cross Company of Lincoln, R.I., wanted some of its employees to improve their writing and grammar skills, the company explored two options. A local college offered a grammar course, but it did not include a writing program. Barry Tarshis, of Westport, taught a writing course, but he did not teach the basics of English grammar.

title: Bruins Finish Strong to Defeat Capitals
description: The victory was surgical in its precision, thorough in all its aspects, perfect to the extent that it was untarnished by so much as a single blemish on the scoreboard. And so it was hard not to sense, amid the smoky haze, acrid warmth and general euphoria of Boston Garden, the air of inevitability.

title: Man Cleared of Lying in Remarks On Reagan Aides and 52 Hostages
description: A Federal jury has acquitted a businessman of charges that he lied to a judge two years ago when he said Reagan-Bush campaign officials asked Iran in October 1980 not to free 52 American hostages until after the Presidential election.

title: Bonnie Walters Weds Kurt A. Koehler
description: Bonnie Elizabeth Walters, the daughter of David Charles Walters of Memphis and Elizabeth Park Walters of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church to Kurt Alan Koehler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon Koehler of Annandale, N.J. The Rev. Lynne Dawson performed the ceremony.

title: Italian Gangs Killing Local Candidates
description: As Italy prepares for nationwide local elections this weekend, the death toll among politicians has reached grim dimensions in the troubled South, where organized-crime clans are intent on asserting their primacy.

title: R.O.T.C. Under Siege for Ousting Homosexuals
description: The Pentagon's ban on gay men and lesbians in the armed forces, upheld by the courts and unchanged by Congress, is facing attack on a new front: the nation's college campuses.

title: SERVICE HELPS SOLVE INSURANCE PUZZLES
description: ''We're getting more inquiries than ever before from patients who don't understand their bills,'' said Maureen Nemeth, the coordinator of credit and collection for inpatient accounts at Northern Westchester Hospital Center in Mount Kisco. ''Filing medical insurance claims has become very confusing for the public, especially as benefits keep changing.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: ATHENS
description: Somehow, despite the chaos, life in Athens makes sense. For those who can't unplug completely even when they've escaped to an island retreat, Athens is a crash course in relaxation without the deprivation of city amenities. Here, people don't ask what you do for a living until well into the conversation, sometimes never at all. Running through daily life is an undercurrent of hedonism, a tendency to excess.

title: Sidney Kalikow, Developer, 70
description: Sidney Kalikow, a Queens real-estate developer, died on Friday in Long Island Jewish Hospital after a 36-year battle with Parkinson's disease. He was 70 years old.

title: A New Caribbean Generation Sets Listeners to Swaying
description: Fusion - of rhythms, ethnic groups and cultures - has vitalized Caribbean music for hundreds of years. A generation ago, the musical import-export trade proceeded at a steady but gradual pace. A Haitian group would tour Cuba and return with Latin songs in their set. Cuban records trickled down to Trinidad, influencing the horn arrangements of the calypsos.

title: Police in South Korea Raid Network, Seize Union Leader
description: The police raided the headquarters of South Korea's second-largest broadcast network and seized a fugitive union leader.

title: Why Near The City Is Too Far
description: After living in the county all my life I have developed an inferiority complex. Although I can brag to people from Maine or Ohio that I am from New York (which is enough to impress someone from Maine or Ohio), whenever I meet people from Manhattan they treat me as if I am a country bumpkin.

title: Is the Fight On Drugs Eroding Civil Rights?
description: MANY Americans are taking a kind of patriotic pride in submitting to roadblocks and airport questioning aimed at snaring drug smugglers; few are raising objections to the proliferation of urine testing and recent Supreme Court rulings that permit the police to hover over backyards in helicopters and poke into garbage cans without the old requirement of at least a glimmer of suspicion. And Americans seem even more enthusiastic about prosecuting the drug war in Latin America, whether that means going after a Panamanian leader or kidnapping a Mexican doctor.

title: Representatives Call for Expansion of Special Prosecutor's Power in H.U.D. Inquiry
description: Lawmakers from both parties are calling for a broad expansion of the authority of the independent prosecutor appointed to investigate Ronald Reagan's Housing Secretary, Samuel R. Pierce Jr. Responding to what they describe as startling new testimony from an imprisoned former deputy of Mr. Pierce, House members say they are convinced that senior aides to Mr. Pierce may have also violated Federal law and that Mr. Pierce was far more involved in potentially illegal activities than had previously been known.

title: THE WONDER YEARS
description: ASTOUNDING DAYS: A Science Fictional Autobiography. By Arthur C. Clarke. (Spectra/Bantam, Paper, $8.95.) Science fiction is sometimes closer to and often farther ahead of the truth than hard, cold reality. In 1990, it is difficult to remember just how new and mind-boggling were some of the concepts in Arthur C. Clarke's 1968 novel ''2001: A Space Odyssey.'' Mr. Clarke was in on the early, golden-age days of science fiction, from 1930 through 1971, the period covered in his curious ''science fictional autobiography,'' ''Astounding Days.'' Each of the book's three sections is dedicated to a science fiction magazine editor (and friend) who influenced Mr. Clarke's writing and thinking. Mr. Clarke gives a chatty, anecdotal account of science fiction, his career and his famous friends through the years. Parenthetical reminiscences and asides are included with references to and quotes from the author's works. Science fiction in the early days, he writes, was neither science nor fantasy, but a world of action, adventure, romance - a realm of the imagination. If the pulp magazine covers featured lurid monsters and damsels in distress, much of the old science fiction writing presaged today's hard science. Many of the creative, speculative writings of the 1930's and 40's are little dated, even now; even the fourth dimension, Mr. Clarke writes, suddenly became quite respectable after Einstein announced his theory of relativity. In this world of curiosity and wonder, even the creators of imaginary worlds don't know in advance what the endings in real life will be. Even Arthur C. Clarke will have to wait to find out what really happens in 2001.

title: Correction
description: A report in the Long Island Journal column last Sunday about an AIDS essay contest misstated the rules. Only high schools that submit winning entries will receive $250 grants.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: AN EXPOSURE OF THE HEART, by Rebecca Busselle. (Penguin, $8.95.) A photographer spends a year at a state institution for the retarded, learning that some truths cannot be captured on film. ''Her words force a reader beyond the barrier of invisibility that usually separates the rest of us from those beings whose damaged minds represent a largely arbitrary and therefore infinitely terrifying human possibility,'' Susan Jacoby said here last year. ''This enforced awareness makes the book as impossible to put down as it is to read without intense distress.''

title: TALES OF HAMLETS THEN AND NOW
description: Lending himself to a host of needs, generous in his willingness to do what's wanted of him, Hamlet is the supremely adaptable dramatic character. Though the occasion of his crisis is the need to avenge his father's murder, something far less specific is involved: a universality of dilemma and anguish; a noble soul forced to act ignobly, an honest one forced to lie. Compelled to ''play'' at the edge of an abyss, fatally intelligent, he sways between thought and action as he enacts a drama of will and its afflictions. For to will anything, the play tells us, is to bring about the unforeseen; to act is to injure, not to act is to be sterile. Creatureliness, the risk of being, the painfulness of choice, ardor and despair: no other play incorporates so much of our humanity.

title: POSTINGS: New Flower District?;   Transplant Study Set
description: The New York State Urban Development Corporation is going to spend $65,000 to study the feasibility of moving Manhattan's century-old flower district to the Bronx. Vincent Tese, the corporation's chairman, said ''as the Bronx continues to show signs of economic vitality, U.D.C. is pleased to assist with studies to help industries to relocate there.'' The site under consideration would be the Terminal Market at Hunts Point, now a major food-distribution center.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: DENVER;

A Mix of Uses For 1889 Store
description: LEAD: THE 101-year-old Denver Dry Goods Company building is to be converted by 1992 into 62 loft apartments, 93,000 square feet of retail space and a 1,500-seat theater.

title: Question Of the Week;   Why Is The Triple Crown Won So Rarely?
description: Why is the Triple Crown won so rarely? It's because few horses can hit for both power and average.

title: Gorbachev Speaks of Retaliation Over Latvia's Independence Move
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has condemned Latvia's declaration of independence as a ''violation of constitutional norms'' and held out the possibility of economic or political retaliation, the official press agency Tass said early today.

title: The Indispensability of Surrealism
description: THE photograph is dead; long live the photograph! This is the implication of ''Constructed Reality'' at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts in Summit. Other, more specific messages are worded by Anne Hoy, the show's organizer and a curator at the International Center of Photography in Manhattan.

title: When Willis Reed's 4 Points Won a Title
description: Twenty years later, it's remembered for Willis Reed trying not to limp when he finally walked onto the court to a roar that shook Madison Square Garden. It's remembered for the 6-foot-9-inch center hitting his first two shots, detonating other roars that shook the Lakers. And it's remembered for the Knicks sweeping to a 113-99 victory for the 1970 National Basketball Association championship.

title:
ART;

Aldrich Shows a Proud Art Form: The Black-and-White
description: LEAD: ALONGSIDE the byword of less is more should be color is more. At least that's the way American culture has been heading. But advocates of coloring old black-and-white films should consider a visit to ''Black and White Since 1960'' at the Aldrich Museum of Contemporary Art in Ridgefield. Art prints have depended heavily on color for about 30 years, and this exhibition is a satisfying corrective.

title: EVEN THE MUSIC WAS RECYCLED
description: Amid the Earth Day festivities in New York's Central Park, some of the most ingenious recycling took place in the music on stage. Many of the performers made the effort to do something more than flog their latest hits; they gave at least a passing thought to the cause.

title: MORE COPS, MORE JAILS, MORE CRIME
description: THE JUSTICE JUGGERNAUT

title: At Japan Inc., The Melody Changes, The Harmony Stays
description: AMERICA'S worries about Japanese technological prowess have long been tightly linked to the myths about ''Japan Inc.,'' particularly the fearsome power of big, Government-industry research projects in subjects from superconductivity to software, biotechnology, aerospace and supercomputers.

title: Besieged Palaces
description: For Donald J. Trump embarrassing revelations keep coming, and they no longer have to do solely with Ivana. First came the report in Forbes magazine demoting him from a billionaire to a half billionaire and estimating that because of debt payments he might actually have a shortfall of almost $40 million a year. He disputed the gloomy assessment, but several days later he announced that he might sell the Trump Shuttle to raise money for other ventures. Last week rumors circulated about just where some of the money might go. According to a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the cash flow fell sharply last year at two of Mr. Trump's Atlantic City casinos, the Castle and the Plaza. The problems are expected to be compounded by competition from his own Taj Mahal, which opened in April. Last week a group of contractors complained that Mr. Trump still owed them $30 million for building the casino billed as ''the eighth wonder of the world.'' Mr. Trump said he was delaying payment simply because of a billing dispute. ''It's ridiculous,'' he said. ''I have a lot of money, and the Taj has a lot of money in the bank.''

title: 76ers Go to Round 2 By Beating Cavs
description: For Hersey Hawkins, who scored a career-high 39 points, the playoff victory today was the highlight of his young career. For Charles Barkley, the victory represented another inspirational performance when his team needed it. And for the Philadelphia 76ers, the victory clinched a spot in the Eastern Conference semifinals, the farthest they have advanced in the National Basketball Association playoffs since 1986.

title: California Court Orders Reporters' Testimony
description: The California Supreme Court has ruled that reporters can be required to testify in a criminal case they know about from their reporting if their testimony would help the defense.

title: Review/Music;   One-Woman Pop Memoir
description: For Shelley Hirsch, the past is less a story told than a pastiche of surviving impressions. Her one-woman show, ''O Little Town of East New York,'' may begin in the neighborhood of her childhood and end with the wreckage it is today, but in between is a rich jumble of friends, family, scenes and situations remembered.

title: TALKING: Solar Energy;   Systems Making a Comeback
description: REMEMBER the late 70's, when designs for solar systems like rooftop collectors, greenhouses and heat pumps were pouring off the drawing boards as fast as fuel prices rose? Fuel shortages were predicted and tax credits for renewable-energy installations tempted homeowners.

title: Travel Watch
description: To the Editor: I've found your Travel Watch section a useful guide for the business traveler, but I would like to point out an error in the $1 Equals . . . section.

title: With Easing of Soviet Police State, Crime Against Foreigners Is Rising
description: Crime against foreigners in the Soviet Union has dramatically increased in the last year, as outsiders, long isolated from Soviet society, find that their new ability to move freely has exposed them to greater danger.

title: Hotly Contested Press Proposal Fades in U.N.
description: One of the most debated ideas that the United Nations has ever put forward - its call for a ''new world information and communications order,'' which would sanction government control of news organizations - is slowly fading away.

title: Taking Mother Out To Dine
description: LEAD: ''MOTHER'S DAY is by far the most popular dining-out occasion of the year,'' said Tanya Dobbs of the New Jersey Restaurant Association. ''Even the more casual restaurants move everything up a notch on this day with fresh flowers and a special menu.''

title: 25,000-Acre Everglades Fire Halted With the Help of Rain
description: A four-day-old fire that had already charred 25,000 acres of the Everglades and threatened a Federal wildlife preserve was brought under control late Friday with the help of scattered showers.

title: SHEDDING LOTS OF FRESH LIGHT ON WAGNER'S 'RING'
description: Some reflections on Wagner and ''Der Ring des Nibelungen'' after another weeklong seance at the Metropolitan Opera:

title: Record Dishonesty
description: Representative Bob Walker has a worthy pet cause. The Pennsylvania Republican wants to restore the integrity of the Congressional Record, the official chronicle of both houses' proceedings. Last month he saw anew why reform is needed. It occurred when Mr. Walker tried to offer an amendment to a G.O.P. crime bill that would force floor consideration. This provoked Jack Brooks, the Texas Democrat who heads the committee that controls the bill. ''All of us have voted for crime bills almost every year for the last few years,'' he said. ''We have almost as many crime bills passed as they have crimes committed.''

title: ARTS GROUPS ASK HOW LONG THEY CAN RELY ON SUNY THEATERS
description: The New Orchestra of Westchester will give its season finale this afternoon at the State University of New York campus here without part of the acoustical shell that the group purchased for Theater A last year.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Science Redefines Mental Illnesses
description: LEAD: ON Jan. 1, California became the first state to recognize officially that the biologically based brain diseases, currently called mental illnesses, are medical illnesses caused by malfunctions and malformations of the brain.

NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;

Union Station Office Boom
description: LEAD: A SPECULATIVE office building is under construction in the 10-square-block Union Station area, which has become the city's development frontier.
