description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some suggestions for Mother's Day dining next Sunday. Early reservations are recommended.

title: Terry Van Tell Weds
description: Terry Van Tell and Gilbert R. Gabriel Jr. were married yesterday at their home in New York by the Rev. Richard L. Leonard, a Unitarian minister. The bride, who will keep her name, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Vantella of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. The bride, who took the last name of Van Tell when she was a radio and television actress, attended Vassar College and the Juilliard School. She is the president of the Terry Van Tell & Associates and Communiverse, which are communications training concerns in New York. Her first marriage ended in divorce, as did the bridegroom's. A Dartmouth College alumnus, the bridegroom is the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel of New York. He is the president of Gil Gabriel Creative Services, which provides marketing services for publishers in New York.

title: Town Meetings: History in Action
description: AS the crowd filed into the assembly room of the Harwinton Town Hall on a recent Tuesday evening, Lawrence Connors anxiously scanned their faces. He was relieved, he said, to see many of those who supported the establishment of the town's first historic districts. But he also saw many neighbors who he thought were opposed to the plan.

title: A. G. Reeves Jr. And Sarah West Exchange Vows
description: Sarah Gatewood West, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Harrell West Jr. of Richmond, and Alexander Garden Reeves Jr., a son of Dr. and Mrs. Reeves of Hanover, N.H., were married yesterday. The Rev. William Sachs officiated at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

title: Rush for Asian Resources Prompts A Race for Weapons and Security
description: With the humbling of Vietnam in Cambodia, political and ideological tensions in Southeast Asia have been significantly reduced. But an arms race in the Asian and Pacific region is eating up the potential benefits from peace.

title: Sidekicks: Dimmer Than the Stars, Yet . . .
description: The return of Chief Inspector Morse in the latest offering from ''Mystery!,'' which began Thursday on PBS, also means the return of his indulgent, intelligent, uninspired, unflappable sidekick, Sergeant Lewis. The second banana is a staple of the detective story in its classic British form, for very practical reasons. The brilliant sleuth, after all, needs somebody to show off to and to shine beside. Yes, he can exhibit his stuff in the good old final scene in the drawing room before a gallery of suspects, but a large ego requires expression along the way, too. And as the red herrings begin to spawn, ''Mystery!'' fans need a surrogate to lead them in fishy directions.

title: HOT AND COLD
description: THE COMBINATION IS AS CLASSIC AND familiar as hot fudge sauce thickening on a scoop of ice cream, or cool sour cream melting in a bowl of steaming borscht. There is the simple cup of hot cocoa dabbed with cold whipped cream, and the flamboyant baked Alaska - ice cream and cake wrapped in meringue and flambeed. The pairing of hot and cold food has always been arresting, but many chefs today are exploring this contrast in novel creations.

title: A Greek Island That Resists Change
description: COMING upon the island of Patmos in darkness, the presence of the church is merely a whisper in the traveler's ear. There is something different about Patmos, even in the evening hours. No loud throbbing beat of American pop greets you at the dock, no desperate hotel representatives shove photographs of their accommodations in your face. Following the long boat ride from Piraeus (and it is long, 11 hours) one steps down to find a momentary rush of people greeting friends and relatives and a few cabs patiently prospecting for fares. But in the morning, when the boat-weary traveler walks outside into the peaceful streets, the power of the Greek Orthodox church on Patmos cannot be overlooked. From anywhere on the island one looks up to see the Monastery of St. John the Theologian. For a cool minute, pre-coffee, one is suddenly pitched into the storybooks of childhood. The walls of the monastery resemble a castle where kind-hearted kings waged war with villains.

title: GIFTED CHILDREN'S PROGRAMS: A MATTER OF CLASS
description: RECENTLY, A CLASS OF kindergartners and first graders at Hunter College Elementary School for the gifted in Manhattan were discussing with their teacher what Mayor David N. Dinkins might do for the city's 5- and 6-year-olds.

title: Baseball;   The Game That Is Forever Young
description: The middle-aged men stood along the first-base line on Opening Day, soon after the parade that led all the children to the start of the 1990 Little League season at Michael Yatsko Field. Beyond the center-field fence, the electronic scoreboard had been set to the moment that connected the lives of those men and this town three decades before; the home team winning, 5-0, in the final inning of the championship game of the 14th Little League World Series.

title: Stylish Spot for French and Italian Fare
description: THE setting at Bellini is elegant, and the restaurant's management has seemingly worked a miracle, turning the long, narrow first floor of a modest three-story house in a disheveled neighborhood into an intimate dining room. It is a study in gray silk moire, with a beveled mirror centerpiece wall, Art Deco lighting, stylish blinds that screen the street and taped opera.

description: POLITICIANS in Texas, California and other key states are quietly arming for a series of battles in which there are new rules and new prizes. When state governments redraw the boundaries of Congressional and state legislative districts next year, changes in Federal law will virtually obligate them to create districts with predominantly black or Hispanic populations whenever possible.

title: Craig McCaw's High-Risk Phone Bet
description: When Craig McCaw's father died in 1969, the McCaw children and their mother discovered that the elder McCaw had so buried his media business in debt that only a single cable-television system remained when all the creditors had been paid off. John Elroy McCaw had had big dreams about building a media empire and he had taken big risks. In the end, the risks were too great and his family was left to pick up the pieces.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE HOLLOW DOLL: A Little box of Japanese Shocks. by William Bohnaker. (Available/Ballantine, Paper, $8.95.) It comes as no surprise to a reader of William Bohnaker's lively and gracefully written book that he is a student of Zen. He peppers ''The Hollow Doll'' with pronouncements that resemble Zen Koans, or parables, that he clearly knows so well - alternately insightful, maddening, profound and simplistic. Mr. Bohnaker, a teacher and freelance writer, has a keen eye for the absurdities and tragedies that underlie Japan's widely publicized success. In prose that is sometimes exquisite and sometimes wickedly funny, he identifies the tensions trapped under the surface of Japan's industrial machine. His central thesis is perceptive: the Japanese do not live by a set of principles, but by a rigid collection of formulas, which allows them to behave in ways that often seem contradictory and violate Western notions of right and wrong. But like a koan, ''The Hollow Doll'' can seem too telegraphic and one-sided. At times, the picture is too bleak. Mr. Bohnaker does not discuss the rewards that bolster the Japanese system and so far appear to have kept most Japanese from rebelling - the acceptance and companionship a group provides, for example. Sometimes he presents oddities without perspective, which is like analyzing American culture after a romp through a tacky souvenir store. Finally, he does not explain why the Japanese have failed to act on their demonstrable frustrations. Despite these flaws, however, ''The Hollow Doll'' is a provocative and interesting glimpse under the veil that cloaks modern Japan.

title:
The Executive Life;

The Serious Business of Executive Amusements

Whole rows of traveling executives can be found hunched for hours over what looks like a slightly bulky walkie-talkie with a tiny video screen. At first glance, it might appear that these businessmen and women, their gaze intent, their fingers punching away furiously at the buttons on their miniature keyboards, are working on some exciting business plan or project that must be completed before they land.

title: Achievement: The Key To Self-Esteem
description: Recently two letter writers opposed giving grades in an attempt to improve pupils' self-esteem. Do they really think children can be kept from knowing how well or poorly they are doing? Children know. The absence of marks, if anything, would make achievement less important in their eyes. Also, promoting an unprepared child would quickly destroy what was left of his self-confidence.

title: FIlM;   It's Back to Nigeria For Bruce Beresford

Several miles down a dirt road in the high jungle of Nigeria's northern plateau, within the snug confines of an old-fashioned general store, a raucous party is going on. A tightly packed group of people in tribal costume dance and sway to hypnotically rhythmic music, played by a small group on strange-looking instruments.

title: Chronicle
description: In 1960, EILEEN FULTON was one of about 200 young actresses trying out for the role of Lisa, a sweet, uncomplicated ingenue in the CBS television soap opera ''As the World Turns.'' She got the role and has kept it for 30 years, a perhaps unmatched tenure for an actor in one role. Miss Fulton is 56 years old now, and as Lisa has gone through six husbands, dozens of affairs and innumerable personal crises including rape, the death of two children, a phantom pregnancy and menopause. The character quickly developed into a conniving one that audiences apparently love to hate. ''Lisa has matured, not mellowed,'' said Miss Fulton, who has been divorced three times while playing Lisa. Three other actors in the soap, HELEN WAGNER, PATRICIA BRUDER and DON HASTINGS are also approaching their 30th anniversaries.

description: Greg Powell agrees with the ads that say the military is ''a great place to start,'' but for now he is washing dishes at an Atlanta hotel and hoping he will get the opportunity to start his career in the Army.

title: Cerner Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Centercore Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jersey Resort Holding Up Beach Funds
description: A long-running battle over how much this popular Jersey Shore resort can charge day-trippers to use its beaches intensified this week when the Borough Commissioners voted to withhold funds for operating the beaches in the summer.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Snapple Campaign
description: ''The all-natural taste of Snapple beverages is so good,'' says its first ad campaign from Buckley/DeCerchio, ''it makes some people forget themselves.'' In one television commercial a family of five guzzles the drink as they motor across the desert singing ''Row, Row, Row Your Boat.'' But they have been drinking without thinking; a road sign notes that the next rest area - and by implication the next bathroom - is 115 miles away. The campaign begins today.

title: Review/Theater;   The Soaring Hopes Of Those Chained Down
description: The impoverished lives of black Southern sharecroppers in the 1920's were periodically brightened by visits from black minstrel troupes. It is Leslie Lee's idea, in his play ''Ground People,'' that the nomadic entertainers shared misfortunes similar to those of their rural kinsmen. The farmers and the minstrels were being drawn away from their roots to the opportunities of the industrial North, where they would face inevitable disillusionments.

title: The Message-in-the-Bottle Report
description: The furor over New York State's budget problems diverted attention from a recent report on the ''Returnable Container Act.'' The bottle bill, as it is called, requires a five-cent deposit on soft drink and beer bottles or cans, to be refunded on return.

title: Leslie Barbara Caust Wed
description: Leslie Barbara Caust, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Melvin Caust of Lake Worth, Fla., was married yesterday to David Jerome Brazda, a son of Jane Brazda of Winchester, Va., and Jerome Brazda of Alexandria, Va. Cantor Bernard Fitch performed the ceremony at Le Chateau in South Salem, N.Y. Mrs. Brazda, 30 years old, is the director of executive services at Mastercard International in New York. She is a graduate of Vassar College where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa. The bridegroom, 35, is the director of marketing and sales at the Mallory Factor public relations company in New York. He is a graduate of George Mason University and the Circle in the Square Graduate Theater Program in New York.

title: Bay Meadows-Calif Jockey Club reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $367,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Health Equity Properties reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hana Biologics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflected gain on sale of cell biology and diagnostic product lines, as well as income tax incurred from that gain and restructuring expenditure of $1.64 million from the first quarter. c-Net loss

title: INSIDE
description: Hostage's Days of Terror

title: 'Jackal' Tells of Plan To Kidnap de Gaulle
description: Rebel French Army officers who opened fire on President Charles de Gaulle's car near Paris in 1962 planned to kidnap him and try him for high treason for giving independence to Algeria, the man who led the attack said.

title: H. Harris Funkenstein, Neurologist, Dies at 50
description: Dr. H. Harris Funkenstein, a neurologist and a specialist in Alzheimer's disease, drowned while swimming off Miami Beach on Friday. He was 50 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: American Vanguard reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $119,600 and also included negative effects of certain start-up costs related to a major plant expansion underway to produce pentachloronitrobenzene, as well as certain research and development costs. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $4,000. Year-ago results for 1989 were restated to reflect the sale of American Vanguard's Absco distributing unit in October 1989.

title: VHC Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New Rules Set For Handling Emergencies
description: New York City's Police and Fire Departments agreed yesterday to put to rest their longstanding feud over who is in charge at various life-or-death emergencies.

title: Identix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cool Sign of the 1960's Glows Again
description: In the groovy 1960's, the Beatles and bell bottoms were the rage, and really cool people owned these far-out lamps that glowed with psychedelic glob and made you mellow.

title: Some Expect Lower Rates Soon
description: The evidence is far from conclusive, but some portfolio managers and analysts are beginning to say the bond market's performance so far this year is strikingly similar to the first four months of 1989.

title: Family Steak Houses of Fla.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   USA Today Promotion
description: USA Today's new advertising campaign, created by the New York office of Babbit & Reiman Advertising, toys with the newspaper's reputation. ''The paper people love to tear apart,'' says the ad's headline. The copy, however, explains that it refers not to any criticism of USA Today's editorial content, but simply to the claim that people often clip and save the paper's articles. The paper's ad appeared in New York magazine last week, and a national campaign begins today.

title: Fickle Tastes and Prices Idle Onion Farmers
description: The bright green shoots have poked through the rich black soil of Stanley Labanowski Jr.'s 100-acre onion farm here, the same farm that his grandfather began in 1914 and that his father, at 83 years old, still plows and harrows with care. But this season will be their last.

title: Kyle Moran Married To Glenn D. Bellitto
description: Kyle Anne Moran, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Moran Jr. of Trumbull, Conn., was married yesterday at Our Lady of Grace Roman Catholic Church in Stratford, Conn., to Glenn Daniel Bellitto, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Joseph Bellitto of Yonkers, N.Y. The Rev. George W. Hommel performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. Stanley G. Mathews.

title: Heavy Schedule of Treasury Financings
description: Treasury financings will dominate the bond market this week, as the Government begins its quarterly refunding with the auction of new 3-year notes tomorrow, new 10-year notes on Wednesday, and 30-year bonds on Thursday. Besides the quarterly refunding, the Treasury will also hold its regular weekly Treasury bill auction of three- and six-month bills today.

title: Serv-Tech Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $319,000.

title: Hundreds Rally in Mongolia As Their Leader Tours China
description: About 1,000 Mongolians demonstrated today in support of pro-democracy protesters staging a sit-in in the capital, and hunger strikers in other parts of the country fasted through an eighth day.

title: Black Political Figures Stress Similarities
description: For months, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and Gov. L. Douglas Wilder of Virginia have been portrayed as combatants locked in a competition for the title of the nation's premier black political figure. This weekend, the two got together here not only to dispel such notions but also to stress the similarities rather than the differences in their goals and approaches.

title: Congressman Certified As Owing Ohio Taxes
description: Representative Donald E. Lukens, who faces a tough primary election because of his conviction on a sex charge, has been certified as a tax delinquent by the State of Ohio, according to a published report.

title: Protest by 500 Aimed at Chief Of Daily News
description: The continuing impasse in contract negotiations led 500 pressmen and drivers from The Daily News to gather yesterday outside the Gramercy Park apartment building of the newspaper's publisher, James Hoge.

title: United Dominion Realty reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gain of $1,254,000, or 15 cents a share, from the sale of a shopping center.

title: Stacey Mattiace Becomes a Bride
description: Stacey L. Mattiace and Steven F. Binder were married yesterday at the St. Moritz Hotel in Manhattan. Rabbi Joel Goor of the Metropolitan Synagogue in New York performed the ceremony.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Brown & Root Braun, Houston, a petroleum and chemical unit of the Halliburton Co., named Jack Brent a vice president and also president of its CF Braun division, Alhambra, Calif.

title: Advanced Polymer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ms. Frye Is Married in Dobbs Ferry
description: Robin Lynne Frye, a daughter of Anne L. Frye of Pinehurst, N.C., and the late John R. Frye, was married yesterday to David Julian Luftig, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Luftig of Larchmont, N.Y. The Rev. James B. Frye, a Presbyterian minister and an uncle of the bride, and Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at Estherwood in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: GWC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Blackhawks Rout Oilers and Lead, 2-1
description: Seemingly fresh despite a fatiguing playoff schedule and unruffled by recent displays of dissension, the Chicago Blackhawks beat the Edmonton Oilers by 5-1 tonight to take a two-games-to-one lead in the four-of-seven-game Campbell Conference championship.

title: Discount Warehouses Get A New Best Seller: Books
description: Beside rows of deck chairs and fluorescent shorts, the books are piled on metal skids in a warehouse big enough to be an aircraft hangar. Shoppers browse through the selection, which includes best sellers, cookbooks and coffee-table books. Occasionally, they drop one into their cavernous shopping carts, along with asparagus, kitchen paper and M&M's.

title: Biopharmaceutics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,433 and $1,676 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and after losses from discontinued operations of $13,501 for the quarter and $11,991 for the 6 months.

title: Soviets' Price On Germany
description: If the opening session of the ''two plus four'' talks made one thing clear, it was that the real bargaining would be not between the victors and losers of World War II, but between a fairly unified West - now including both a prosperous West Germany and a democratized East Germany - and a battered, weakened and troubled Soviet Union using one of its last levers of power in Europe to exact the highest possible price for its final exit from the scene.

title: U.S. Joins Peru's Dirty War
description: LEAD: Under the guise of drug interdiction in Peru, the U.S. is rushing headlong into one of the dirtiest wars being fought anywhere in the world today. If past experience in Vietnam and El Salvador is any guide, the U.S. presence will exercise virtually no restraint on the murder, torture and other human rights abuses that are now routine in Peru.

title: Fielder Belts 3 Out But the Tigers Lose
description: Detroit's Cecil Fielder hit three home runs and Chet Lemon hit two, but the Toronto Blue Jays also hit five homers today to power past the Tigers, 11-7.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Saatchi Chief Gives Show Of Strength
description: WHEN Robert Louis-Dreyfus was appointed chief executive of the Saatchi & Saatchi Company last November, advertising people wondered whether he would be able to take control from the brothers who founded the giant advertising conglomerate 20 years ago. After all, Mr. Louis-Dreyfus was not an ad man. Worse, from the perspective of British advertising executives, he was French.

title: Befouled to Its Romantic Depths, Danube Reaches a Turning Point
description: Swollen and pearly gray, the Danube makes a spectacular turn here, pushing into gentle woodlands as it surges south toward Budapest. It is the river at its most seductive: winding through the valleys of Central Europe, where it has inspired poets and composers and generations of painters who still work on its banks today.

title: Karen Lee Young Is a Bride
description: Karen Lee Young and Barry Stewart Dirkin were married yesterday at their home in Tabernacle, N.J., by Mayor Wayne Smith of Tabernacle. The bride, 28 years old, is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Young of Clifton, N.J. A graduate of Union College, she received a master's degree in agronomy from Cornell University. She is an environmental specialist at the New Jersey Pinelands Commission in New Lisbon, N.J. The bridegroom, 34, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Dirkin of Woodbury, N.J. A graduate of the University of Wisconsin, he is an associate at Lord, Anderson, Worrel & Barnett, engineers and environmental consultants in Burlington, N.J.

title: Democrats Send Connecticut Budget to Governor
description: Democrats in the House gave final passage today to a revenue plan that takes money from two reserve funds and changes state tax laws to raise $339 million to erase this year's budget deficit and balance next year's budget without a tax increase.

title: Student Said to Agree To Testify in Sex Case
description: A St. John's University student suspected of having participated in a sexual assault on another student has agreed to testify against others accused in the incident in exchange for immunity from prosecution, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: New Urgency Fuels Effort To Improve Safety of Food
description: With new urgency, consumer groups, public officials and the food industry are pressing for changes to make the nation's food safer.

title: United Insurance Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Few to Try Unbridled May 19
description: Only 4 or 5 of the 15 colts who ran in the Kentucky Derby here Saturday will return in the Preakness Stakes on May 19, and it isn't difficult to understand why.

title: Fewer German Jobless
description: The number of people out of work in West Germany, which is riding an economic boom, fell again in April to 1.91 million, or 7.3 percent of the work force, according to Labor Office figures released Friday.

title: Janet L. Johnson Wed in California
description: Janet Louise Johnson, an actress known professionally as Janet Julian, was married yesterday in Venice, Calif., to Michael Bruce Lansbury, a program executive at the Fox Broadcasting Company in Los Angeles. The Rev. William McNabb, a Presbyterian minister, performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home.

title: Question Box
description: 2-Team Pitching Stars

title: Premier's Party Leads In East German Voting
description: East Germany's governing parties kept their grip on the country's politics today in local elections, projections showed, although they lost a significant portion of the vote to grass-roots groups and independent candidates.

title: Celtics Show Their Age As Well as Their Agony
description: Walking into the Boston Celtics' locker room this afternoon was like walking into a funeral parlor. Some players, such as Robert Parish, refused to talk. Others, such as John Bagley, spoke so softly they could hardly be heard. But as usual, Larry Bird, the team's legend and leader, summed up the Celtics' mood best following the Knicks' memorable 121-114 victory at Boston Garden that eliminated Boston from the playoffs.

title: Egypt Butane Price Up
description: Egypt said last week that it had more than doubled domestic prices for butane gas, in the latest move to meet International Monetary Fund demands for economic changes and cuts in state subsidies. The new price of home-delivered gas cylinders is 57 cents, up from 25 cents. Two weeks ago the price of locally manufactured cigarettes was raised as much as 20 percent. Opposition newspapers have predicted more price rises as protracted negotiations with the I.M.F. on economic changes seem to be producing results.

title: Review/Music;   A Program Steeped in the Soviet Union
description: Yuri Temirkanov of the Leningrad Philharmonic devoted his second week this season with the New York Philharmonic to a mixed program still stocked with Soviet specialties. (His first program consisted entirely of Shostakovich's ''Leningrad'' Symphony.) The program, Friday afternoon at Avery Fisher Hall, led with a curiosity, Sergei Slonimsky's ''Concerto Buffo'' for chamber orchestra (1965). The opening up of Eastern Europe should increasingly familiarize Western listeners with recent music from that part of the world, but it was still a surprise to hear a score composed 25 years ago in a 12-tone idiom by a composer described as enjoying consistent success in the Soviet Union.

title: Penn Varsity Wins Burk Cup
description: Penn's varsity heavyweight crew rowed with dominating finesse today to capture the 21st annual Burk Cup in a dual regatta with Northeastern.

title: Catherine Tscoucalas Becomes Bride in Tenafly
description: Catherine Tscoucalas was married yesterday at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. John the Theologian in Tenafly, N.J., to Dr. George James Florakis. Bishop Philip Koutoufas, the Rev. Nicholas Pilavas and the Rev. Ernest Blougouras officiated. Mrs. Florakis is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael C. Tscoucalas of Bergenfield, N.J. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Florakis of Yonkers.

title: Congress St. Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $119,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Marsam Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: 21 Little Sailors Join the U.N. and See the World
description: Until everyone calmed down and listened to the speakers, Children's Day at the United Nations yesterday looked like a sort of wild World's Fair, with more than a thousand young delegates in costumes from their native countries running through the General Assembly hall, the adults straggling behind.

title: Dorothy Bambach Married
description: Dorothy Elsa Bambach and Matthew Joseph Ryan 3d were married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. David Fountain. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Bambach of East Hampton, L.I. The bridegroom is a son of May Ryan of Somerville, Mass., and the late Mr. Ryan.

title: Chronicle
description: BOBBY FISCHER, the American chess genius who went into seclusion 15 years ago after defeating BORIS SPASSKY of the Soviet Union for the world chess championship, spent four days in Brussels last week discussing his future.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Executive of Wetterau Named Richfood's Head
description: LEAD: Richfood Holdings Inc., a leading wholesale food distributor in the mid-Atlantic region, has announced that Donald D. Bennett will join the company as president and chief executive.

title: Mass Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: Creative Technologies reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Mandela Hardens Line on White Rights
description: Nelson Mandela, the African National Congress leader, told supporters today that he would urge President F. W. de Klerk to abandon his insistence on guarantees for South Africa's white minority before the Government and the congress next held talks on the nation's future.

title: Self-Help for Cleaner Streets
description: New York City's budget crisis portends ugly consequences for the city's streets. Mayor David Dinkins, beset by demands from every quarter, proposes to save money with more cutbacks in the Sanitation Department's street-sweeping forces. Once, the sweepers numbered 1,382; now they are down to 282, and another round of cutting might eliminate them entirely.

title: Review/Ballet;   Its Repertory in Turmoil, the Joffrey Dances On
description: It would have been hard to tell that the Joffrey Ballet was in turmoil from the way its dancers performed on Friday and Saturday nights. True, there were few bright smiles as the dancers took their curtain calls here following each ballet on Friday but that was mostly the program's fault.

title: MTV's International Beat Brings a Sound of Dollars
description: MTV's chairman, Tom Freston, likes to refer to English as the ''lingua franca'' of rock and roll. More importantly for MTV, the American dollar is the ''currency franca'' of rock and roll.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Fisons to Jordan
description: Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor has been awarded the consumer-advertised brands of Fisons Consumer Health, a division of Fisons Pharmaceuticals. The brands include Desenex, Cruex, Allerest and Sinarest. Fisons' professionally promoted products go to the Sutton Healthcare Group. The accounts had been at Levy, King & White, the Buffalo agency that recently agreed to be acquired by Eric Mower & Associates.

title: Cardinal Says Father Ritter May Get Archdiocesan Job
description: John Cardinal O'Connor suggested yesterday that the Rev. Bruce Ritter, who stepped down as head of Covenant House amid allegations of sexual and financial misconduct, might be leaving his religious order to take an unspecified job with the Archdiocese of New York.

title: Maurice Blond; Insurance Executive, 73
description: Maurice Blond, an insurance execu-tive who helped many charities, died of colon cancer Saturday at Beth Israel Medical Center. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Morden & Helwig reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

Arista Investors Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Frontier Adjusters reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Health-Mor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
6 Are Dead as the Northwest Is Swept by 60-m.p.h. Winds
description: Six people were killed and four were missing today after a weekend of wind up to 60 miles an hour capsized boats, tore down power lines and fanned fires in the Pacific Northwest.

title: Atomic Waste Reported Leaking in Ocean Sanctuary Off California
description: Barrels of radioactive waste are leaking plutonium and cesium into one of the West Coast's richest ocean wildlife sanctuaries, a Federal study has found.

title: Chalone Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Carbon Dioxide Warming Is Good for the Planet
description: To the Editor:

title: Grubb & Ellis REIT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Austin Journal;   Outlook Of the 60's On Issues Of the 90's
description: Toni Luckett is too young to be nostalgic or regretful about the rebellious 1960's, but she sincerely hopes a new era of campus protests is about to begin.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Speed a Key Step To Stronger Tennis
description: LEAD: THE quickest way to improve your tennis game may be to improve your quickness.

title: Kingston Journal;   Where Reggae Was Born, a Foreboding Silence
description: A sullen mood hangs over Trenchtown, the slum neighborhood that gave birth to reggae, one of the most original and internationally popular musical movements of recent times.

title: Service Master's Chief Adds Job in Revamping
description: C. William Pollard, president and chief executive of Service Master Limited Partnership, has been named to the additional post of chairman of the cleaning and services company.

title: Sage Broadcasting Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Futures Trial Set to Start
description: Three former futures traders accused in the Federal Government's undercover investigation of trading fraud in Chicago's futures markets are scheduled to go on trial here on Tuesday.

title: Criticare Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a non-cash loss on real estate investment of $480,000.

title: United Peaks
description: ADRIAN CRANE says that he is a computer-systems analyst by profession: ''I guess, but it gets pushed out of the way sometimes,'' he said. What he calls adventure keeps getting in the way.

title: Gun-Twirling Ends In a Woman's Death
description: A Long Island man was arrested early yesterday on manslaughter charges after a gun he was playing with accidentally discharged, killing his girlfriend, Suffolk County police said. Brenda Jackson, 31 years old, was pronounced dead at her home at 49 Lakewood Street, the police said.

title: North Canadian Oils reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: L.B.J.'s Great Society
description: ''This country,'' President Lyndon Johnson once said, ''is rich enough to do anything it has the guts to do and the vision to do and the will to do.'' You'd never catch Ronald Reagan or George Bush expressing that kind of confidence in America, despite the patriotism they so fulsomely extol.

title: Birtcher Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Gibraltar Mines reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

description: b-Net loss and after a loss of $389,000 from discontinued operations. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Sarah Harbutt, Editor, Is Wed
description: Sarah Harbutt and Kenneth Joel Kerbs were married yesterday at the Picnic House in Prospect Park in Brooklyn by Dr. Paul R. Migliore, a leader of the American Ethical Union. Mrs. Kerbs is the daughter of Alberta Steves Harbutt of Brooklyn and Charles H. Harbutt Jr. of New York. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Kerbs of Glen Rock, N.J.

title: Docucon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Discovery West reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Latvian, Warned by Gorbachev, Adopts the Soft Line
description: The Latvian President sought today to strike a conciliatory line toward Moscow, saying in a television broadcast that his republic would not suspend the Soviet Constitution during its quest for independence.

title: Talley Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lifecore Biomedical reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: From Bolivia, Good News on Drugs
description: President Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia arrives in Washington this week with startling information: The market for raw coca leaves in his country has collapsed. He considers that a powerful reason for the U.S. to speed up economic aid to help Bolivia's antidrug campaign, and he's right.

title: Hong Kong's Future Scares An Industry
description: This powerhouse of world fashion is facing a crisis of confidence. With the events in Tiananmen Square still vivid, Hong Kong apparel executives are uncertain whether they should remain in this outpost of empire and free enterprise, which Britain will turn over to the People's Republic of China on July 1, 1997.

title: Kamenstein (M.) Inc.(O) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Geraghty & Miller reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Alatenn Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $307,000 related to operations of End Devices Inc. which were discontinued as of Dec. 31, 1989. Year-ago revenues included $36.1 million in revenues from Colony Energy Corp. which was sold by the company effective Dec. 31, 1989. Year-ago income from continuing operations of $890,000, or 39 cents a share, included $310,000, or 13 cents a share, for Colony Energy Corp.

title: Aircoa Hospitality Services reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: The Goal for Moog Is the Stanley Cup
description: The announcement from the National Hockey League was no sooner released than word of it had made its way into the locker room of the Bruins and then into its farthest corner. There, Andy Moog, his mask in his hand and his modesty on his sleeve, handled the news like one might suspect a goaltender would: he turned it aside.

title: Reginald Goodall, 84, Conductor Who Mastered Wagner, Is Dead
description: Sir Reginald Goodall, sometimes called the last link in a chain of legendary Wagnerian conductors stretching back to Wagner himself, died on Saturday in a nursing home near Canterbury, England. He was 84 years old.

title: F.B.I. Said to Foil Missile Smuggling to Colombia
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation broke up a plot to smuggle 24 Stinger antiaircraft missiles to Colombian drug traffickers by arresting several Colombians in Florida on Saturday, a senior Federal law enforcement official said today.

title: Imtec Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Upper Peninsula Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bolivian Chief to Ask Bush for More Aid on Drugs
description: President Jaime Paz Zamora plans to appeal to President Bush in Washington this week for a major increase in financial aid to help Bolivia get out of the cocaine business.

title: More Corn for Soviets
description: Private exporting companies have sold an additional 600,000 metric tons of United States corn to the Soviet Union for delivery this year under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Friday. Orders since Oct. 1 now total 13.9 million tons of corn, 3.3 million tons of wheat, 342,300 tons of soybeans and 1.2 million tons of soybean meal. In addition, sales of barley total 7,300 tons.

title: Delusions Marked Saigon Pullout to the End
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: The busiest entrepreneur dealing in unusual bridge events is certainly Kathie Wei, who shuttles between Houston and New York in the interests of the shipping business of her late husband, Charles Wei. In the last year she has promoted a match between the Senate and the House of Representatives, a match between the Congress and Corporate America, and a match between Corporate America and the British Parliament. The British won that match, and also the earlier encounters with Congress. All the matches have raised substantial amounts for charity.

title: Croatians Vote in Final Round As Independence Party Leads
description: Voters in Yugoslavia's second-largest republic, Croatia, went to the polls today in the second round of free parliamentary elections that could lead to a secessionist movement.

title: I.M.F. Pact On Fund Rise And Voting
description: Finance ministers of the leading industrial countries agreed today on the difficult question of rankings in the voting hierarchy of the International Monetary Fund, clearing away one of the last main obstacles to an increase in the fund's $120 billion of resources.

title: Judith Markewich Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Judith Mary Markewich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Markewich of New York, to Robert Stuchiner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Stuchiner of New York, took place yesterday at the Town Club in New York. Rabbi Marshall Meyer performed the ceremony.

title: Betsy Silver Marries Dr. Daniel M. Jacobs
description: Betsy Silver and Dr. Daniel Morris Jacobs were married yesterday at the Sheraton Hotel in Needham, Mass., by Rabbi Samuel Kenner. Mrs. Jacobs is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth A. Silver of Newton, Mass. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Jacobs of Long Beach, L.I.

title: McCarthy Racing to the Top, Even as an Amateur Rider
description: Mike McCarthy is a 21-year-old amateur bicycle racer. He is not yet in the class of a Greg LeMond or a Steve Bauer or a Vyacheslav Ekimov or a Raul Alcala, for they are among the best professionals in the world, but on Saturday, he beat them all.

title: Pavichevich Brewing reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: The company had no sales in 1989 because it was in its first year.

title: Cerprobe Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Business Scene;   Argentina's Zest For Privatization
description: PRIVATIZATION, the process of turning a state enterprise into a private one, is all the rage in Eastern Europe. But perhaps nowhere in the world is it more popular than in Argentina, where the rush to sell off state companies is producing bargain-basement deals to lure reluctant foreign buyers.

title: Paper Reveals Keating Report
description: The court-appointed examiner of the bankrupt American Continental Corporation told a judge that Charles H. Keating Jr., the company's chairman, and others defrauded investors for personal gain, according to a report published today.

title: Hope Brook Gold reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $556,000, or 1 cent a share, for the latest first quarter and $647,000, or 2 cents a share, for year-ago period. Year-ago period was restated. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Nepal Seeks Less Reliance On Foreign Economic Aid
description: Nepal's new Government, swept to power last month by a pro-democracy movement, hopes to reduce this impoverished nation's dependence on foreign aid and credit, but officials admit it will be a difficult task.

title: Republic Capital Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Security Investments Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $300,000, or 6 cents a share, and $140,000, or 3 cents a share, for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively. Year-ago earnings per common share have been restated for the effect of a 5 percent stock dividend.

title: Black-Korean Who-Pushed-Whom Festers
description: It started over some plantains and peppers, and maybe some limes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: State Urged to Help Elderly Pedestrians
description: More than a third of all pedestrian deaths in New York State in 1988 involved people who were 65 years old or older, the Legislature's Commission on Critical Transportation Choices reported yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The future of life on this planet urgently requires the most sophisticated research and teaching to increase our understanding of the biosphere in all its complexity and diversity.''

title: Emily Remler Dies On Australia Tour; Guitarist Was 32
description: Emily Remler, a jazz guitarist in the be-bop tradition, died of a heart attack on Friday while on tour in Sydney, Australia, the Associated Press reported yesterday. She was 32 years old.

title: Business and Health;   California Plans Divide Insurers
description: THE health insurance industry is in disarray in California, where popular support is growing for measures that would require all employers to provide health coverage for their employees.

title: Strike Ends At Hyundai
description: Production lines at South Korea's largest car maker, the Hyundai Motor Company, started up again today after a one-week strike.

title: A Dead Horse Is Floating in the Hudson
description: To the Editor:

title: Spring Series of Art Auctions May Top $1 Billion in Sales
description: A 13-day series of auctions that may, for the first time, produce more than $1 billion in art sales got under way last night at Christie's in New York.

title: Katy Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a credit of $1,291,000, or 2 cents a share, from a cumulative effect of an accounting change resulting from an increase in ownership of an investee company. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,729,000. Latest quarter's continuing operations of $18,347,000, or $2.76 a share included $14,250,000, or $2.19 a share, net gain on sale of subsidiary stock. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations in 1989.

title: Hard-to-Please Females May Be Neglected Evolutionary Force
description: WHAT do females want? Every man who has ever rolled his eyes heavenward in apparent bafflement at this great enigma might do well to follow the example of evolutionary biologists: stop speculating and start paying attention to the evidence at hand.

title: Huge Study Of Diet Indicts Fat And Meat
description: EARLY findings from the most comprehensive large study ever undertaken of the relationship between diet and the risk of developing disease are challenging much of American dietary dogma. The study, being conducted in China, paints a bold portrait of a plant-based eating plan that is more likely to promote health than disease.

title: Bigger Fluor Stake In Lead Producer
description: The Fluor Corporation agreed to buy the 42.5 percent stake of the Doe Run Company, North America's largest lead producer, that it does not already own from the Homestake Mining Company for $125 million. Completion of the transaction is subject to Government approval. Fluor said it planned to expand its activities in the secondary or recycled lead market.

title: Minority Journalists Want Newsday to Suspend Breslin
description: Two groups of minority journalists yesterday called for the suspension of Jimmy Breslin, a columnist for New York Newsday, because of racial slurs Mr. Breslin used about a Korean-American colleague.

title: Ocean Predator Is Preyed Upon; Sharks Need Help, Officials Say
description: SHARKS, the skillful and storied hunters of the deep, are being threatened by even tougher predators - people.

title: Jewelmasters Inc. reports earnings for 14wks to Feb 3
description: b-Included $250,000 charge against earnings, representing amounts owned to Jewelmasters by Bonwit Teller, which entered into federal bankruptcy protection in August 1989. c-Included a tax benefit of $897,000. d-Net income and included a gain from an accounting adjustment $106,000, or 5 cents a share. The company said the year-ago results included a 13-week period and 52- week period ended Jan. 28, 1989.

title: Qaddafi Tells of Plan to Attack U.S. Bases
description: The Libyan leader, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, said today that after the American air raid on Libya in 1986 he planned a missile attack on the two United States bases on the Greek island of Crete.

title: Evolution in Europe;   600 Balkan Emigrants Call A Berlin Rail Station Home
description: So far there is no name for them like the boat people of Indochina, but 600 Romanian citizens who have made their way in recent weeks to the Lichtenberg Station here might be called ''train people.''

title: 2d Trial Opens in Preschool Molestation Case
description: The second trial in the McMartin Preschool child molesting case opened today with a prosecutor telling jurors that he had not interviewed the three former pupils who say they were molested and could not predict how they would testify.

title: Jordan Dazzles 76ers as Bulls Win
description: Given the man-to-man defense that is mandated in the National Basketball Association, you rarely see a matchup featuring a beefy forward like Charles Barkley of the Philadelphia 76ers against a slender guard like Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls.

title: Limits Seen for Cancer Treatment That Was Hailed as Breakthrough
description: A CANCER treatment that was hailed as a breakthrough when it was announced five years ago has failed to live up to its initial promise but is nevertheless proving valuable for certain patients, some experts say.

title: Gay Men's Crisis Unit To Shun AIDS Session
description: The Gay Men's Health Crisis, a large private AIDS service agency, announced yesterday that it had joined a boycott of the annual international AIDS conference in San Francisco to protest a Federal immigration ban on foreign travelers infected with the virus.

title: Pace to Great Scott
description: Pace University has awarded its advertising account, formerly at AC&R Advertising, to Great Scott Advertising. The account has a budget of $4 million. Great Scott also said it had won two $1 million real estate accounts, one from the Zucker Company and the other from World-Wide Holdings and Nelson Equities.

title: Leon M. Prince, Chemist, 79
description: Leon M. Prince, a research chemist who specialized in microemulsions, the study of the chemical reaction of oil and water, died of heart failure on Saturday at his home in Larchmont, N.Y. He was 79 years old and had been a longtime resident of Westfield, N.J., until 1985.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Nortek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from debt retirement of $1,700,000, or 13 cents a share, and $1,250,000, or 9 cents a share, for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively. Results for 1989 were restated to reflect discontinued operations. The company said in first quarter 1990, it recorded an aftertax charge of about $800,000, or 6 cents a share, in connection with various litigation matters.

title: Rebecca C. Bradford, Teacher, 86
description: Rebecca Crowninshield Bradford, a teacher of French and a trustee of the Buckingham Browne and Nichols School in Cambridge, Mass., died of cancer on Sunday at the Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. She was 86 years old and lived in Cambridge.

title: Don't Judge Zaire by European Standards
description: To the Editor:

title: E&B Marine Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The loss for the year-ago quarter and prior year ended reflect extraordinary charges including: restructuring charges of $2,302,933: the writeoff of goodwill of $5,359,257, additional mailing list amortization of $600,000; a $1,028,605 reserve against amounts owned the company by a former officer and director; a provision of $1,450,000 for slow-moving and discontinued inventory; and a loss of $277,000 pertaining to disposal of fixed assets related to replacement of retail point of sale systems. Latest quarter included extraordinary charges of $117,000. Latest year included extraordinary gains tataling $4,773,000. Both extraordinary items are comprised of a gain of $4,693,000 recorded in connection with the restructuring of the company's debt and $80,000 from tax loss carryforwards.

title: Brazil Ready to Discuss Late Payments to Banks
description: Brazil's Economy Minister said today that the Government was ready to make payments on overdue interest to its commercial bank lenders but that the final decision on when and how much would depend on the state of the country's economy, reserves and budget.

title: BRIEFS
description: * ACF Holding N.V., a diversified Dutch pharmaceutical company, said it was looking for foreign pharmaceutical companies to take a stake of up to 20 percent in the company through a private placement of new shares.

title: Burlington Industries Capital Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $14.1 million on repurchase of debt securities for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income Burlington Industries Capital is the holding company for the capital stock of Burlington Holdings Inc., which acquired Burlington Industries Inc. in 1987.

title: Rudy's Restaurant Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said that latest quarter results included a non-recurring loss of $237,200 related to the recent settlement of Chemical Bank's lawsuit against Bright Star Holding Inc., holder of 59.1 percent of Rudy's Restaurant common stock. The company said the loss is the result of the transfer to Chemical Bank of a certificate of deposit of approximtely $580,000 previously pledged to Chemical Bank offset by an accounting evaluation of the value of the Rudy's trademarks and licenses acquired from Bright Star Holding under the settlement.

title: Bass Family Gives Yale $20 Million for Ecology Institute
description: The Bass family of Fort Worth, Tex., gave Yale University $20 million today to establish an Institute of Biospheric Studies that will greatly expand the university's research into environmental issues.

title: Evolution in Europe;   GERMAN OFFICIALS SEE REUNIFICATION AS ECONOMIC BOON
description: German reunification will spur economic growth in Europe and the world, and contrary to widespread expectations, should not set off more world inflation and higher interest rates, West German officials said at a global monetary conference here today. ''The stability of the D-Mark and the soundness of public finances remain safeguarded,'' Theo Waigel, the West German Finance Minister, said at the policy-making Interim Committee meeting of the 152-nation International Monetary Fund.

title: Ex-Officer of Bear, Stearns And 3 Other Men Indicted
description: A former executive of Bear, Stearns & Company and three other men have been indicted on charges of conspiracy, perjury and obstruction of justice as the result of a seven-year investigation into practices in the stock-lending business.

title: Taxes and Political Peril
description: Most people in Washington now think some kind of tax increase is inevitable, and the holdouts, President Bush included, are finding it harder and harder to hold the line as the deficit soars.

title: ARCO Net Drops 22.3%
description: ARCO said today that its first-quarter earnings fell 22.3 percent from last year's first quarter, when the company had a gain of $634 million from the initial public offering of the Lyondell Petrochemical Company.

title: CANDIDATES REACH FUND-RAISING PEAK
description: As the Senate prepares to begin debate on legislation to restrict political fund-raising, the Government released figures today showing that candidates for Congress in the 1990 elections have collected and spent record amounts of money.

title: Buyers Find More Than Art in New Mexico
description: Indian artists from around the state are hoping that buyers from a national chain of department stores who visited here last week will return not just with the arts and crafts they came to buy, but also with a better understanding of Indian culture.

title: Court Battle Over Rights To Bloomingdale's Store
description: A bankruptcy court battle has broken out over the rights to the Bloomingdale's flagship store in Manhattan, with the Bloomingdale family, which no longer owns any part of the store but does own the land under it, seeking to evict the store by May 17.

title: Liggett Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said earnings in the latest periods declined due to non-operating expenses.

title: Rodman Is the Key to Piston Defense
description: Dennis Rodman stood on a podium this afternoon, fighting a losing battle with his emotions. He tried desperately to hold back the tears, but soon they were streaming down his face. Eventually he was sobbing with such force that he could no longer speak. Finally, Jack McCloskey, the Detroit Pistons' general manager, put a comforting arm around Rodman and led him away, giving Rodman a much-needed chance to regain his composure.

title: Transcapital Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its provision for loan losses has increased by $2.8 million compared with 1989's first quarter due to an increase in non-performing loans. The company also incurred losses of approximately $1.3 million on our non-investment grade corporate bond portfolio. The company continues its program to dispose of all those securities. At March 31, 1990, the market value of such securities totaled $11.3 million, or two-tentsh of one percent of total assets. Transcapital Financial is a majority-owned subsidiary of American Capital Corp.

title: Yale Star Sets Sights On Rival Get-Together
description: Jon Reese, the Yale midfielder who set a record for goals scored in a single lacrosse season, has neither met Gary Gait, the Syracuse star whose standard he eclipsed, nor seen him play. But he would like to.

title: Researchers Use Robot For Hip Surgery on Dog
description: Researchers have used a robotic arm similar to those that assemble automobiles and television sets to help implant an artifical joint in a dog.

title: Nepal Party Chief Warns King to Turn Over Power
description: The King of Nepal has been warned by the country's leading political party that if he does not turn over substantial powers to the interim Government, the party will call crowds back into the streets to force the issue.

title: Reviews/Music;   Bulgarian Folk Songs, Rendered Efficiently
description: Le Mystere des Voix Bulgares is the exotic title attached to a Bulgarian women's choir that has stirred popular enthusiasm in recent world tours and recordings. The singers brought their startling ensemble sound to Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night, joined from time to time by two intrumental quartets. One was a collection of braying folk instruments, the other the Kronos Quartet.

title: Fitzsimmons Longing for Special Victory
description: The last time Lowell (Cotton) Fitzsimmons was able to smile after playing the Lakers here, the building didn't have ''Great Western'' in front of the ''Forum'' and there were 21 teams in the National Basketball Association.

title: Freddie Mac reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share amounts for 1989 are restated to reflect the retirement of all 100,000 shares of non-voting common stock in February 1990. The company also reported a $400 million before-tax and a $300 million after-tax increase in its mark-to-market net worth between the fourth quarter of 1989 and the first quarter of 1990. This increase is due to growth in the total mortgage portfolio and an increase in the value of the company's servicing portfolio as a result of slightly higher interest rates during the first three months of 1990. The before taxes was $5.5 billion at March 31, 1990, compared with accepted accounting principles (GAAP) for the same time period. The most significant difference between GAAP and estimated mark-to-market equity is the value of Freddie Mac's off-balance sheet servicing portfolio, or the net cash flows generated by the mortgages that the company has securitized.

title: Sonny Carson, Koreans and Racism
description: A minor scuffle in January in a Korean-American grocery in Brooklyn has turned into an ugly boycott aimed at driving all Korean merchants out of a largely black neighborhood in Flatbush. The boycott rides on a tide of ugly, unmistakably racist rhetoric that warrants condemnation from every fair-minded New Yorker, starting with Mayor David Dinkins.

title: Man Who Was Judged Insane Is Held in Attempted Break-In
description: A retarded man whose release to a group home after three decades in a mental hospital set off a public outcry was arrested and jailed over the weekend after a report of an attempted break-in about seven blocks from the home.

title: VGM Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $33,840, or 4 cents a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Interleaf Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $13.5 million related to restructuring. c-Net income

title: Saudis Laud OPEC Pact
description: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, said today that last week's OPEC agreement to cut oil output was an essential move to keep prices from collapsing.

title: Fort Worth Rejects Tax for a Crime Agency
description: Voters have overwhelmingly rejected a proposed half-cent increase in the sales tax to pay for a new crime-fighting agency.

title: TBS Executive Joins Whittle
description: Farrell Reynolds, president of Turner Broadcasting Sales, is joining Whittle Communications as chairman and chief executive of its newly restructured Whittle Educational Network.

title: BUSH EASES STAND, SAYING NEW TAXES CAN BE DISCUSSED
description: The White House committed itself today to discuss new taxes in budget negotiations with Congress but stopped short of saying that President Bush is now prepared to accept higher taxes to reduce the deficit.

title: O.E.C.D. Chief On Textiles
description: The international drive to reform the world's trading system will fail unless industrial nations agree to scrap their barriers to textile imports from developing countries, the head of the O.E.C.D. said today.

title: Review/Ice Skating;   Sliding, Gliding and Acting Oh So Glamorous
description: All the skating was virtuosic in ''Brian Boitano and Katarina Witt Skating,'' the ice revue directed and choreographed by Sandra Bezic that was presented on Saturday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: 'Graveyard' Fuels Geological Debate
description: DATA suggest that trenches ringing much of the Pacific Ocean mark places where great slabs that once formed the ocean floor have slid 1,600 miles to the earth's core, a team of geologists says.

title: American Healthcare Management reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $168,000, or 1 cent a share for the latest quarter and $2,395,000, or 20 cents a share for the year-earlier period.

title: Tokos Medical Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Driver Shot From Passing Car
description: A motorist was shot in the head and killed early today by someone in a passing car, and the authorities closed down the Harbor Freeway, about five miles south of downtown, for nearly an hour to search for clues. The police said two motorists reporting from car phones told them that the shots had come from a car occupied by two men.

title: TW Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $775,000. Results for 1989 are for the predecessor company; TW Holdings Inc. acquired TW Services Inc. on Dec. 6, 1989. This year's first quarter loss is after amortization and depreciation related tothe merger of $17,756,000 and interest and debt expense of $73,850,000.

title: Reader's Digest Official
description: The Reader's Digest Association said today that its president and chief operating officer, Richard F. McLoughlin, who is 61 years old, will retire early, effective June 30, to spend more time with his ailing wife.

title: Gulf Air Orders CFM Jet Engines
description: Gulf Air, the airline of four Middle Eastern countries, has ordered CFM International jet engines worth $225 million to power Airbus Industrie A320 jetliners, the engine maker said. CFM said the CFM56-5 engines would power 12 Airbus jetliners, with an option for six more. Delivery is to begin in 1992 and continue through 1994.

title: Major Witness Tries to Recant At Fama Trial
description: Lawyers in the Bensonhurst murder case against Joseph Fama delivered summations yesterday, but much of the attention was on a last-minute effort by a major prosecution witness to recant.

title: Driver Survives 30-Foot Fall
description: An 80-year-old man suffered only minor cuts and bruises today when his car plunged off a bridge, narrowly missing two 60,000-volt electrical lines and landing upside down on train tracks 30 feet below. The police said the car driven by Andrew Amato of New Haven, who was wearing his seat belt, crashed through a fence after being rammed by a car that had gone through a stop sign.

title: Council Bill Would Limit Mass Shelters
description: In a compromise that upset Mayor David N. Dinkins and some advocates for the homeless, a New York City Council committee yesterday unanimously approved a bill intended to force the city to stop housing homeless families in barracks-style shelters in 16 months.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Crisp Is Dismissed As Coach of Flames
description: Terry Crisp was dismissed yesterday as coach of the defending champion Calgary Flames, who were eliminated in the first round of the National Hockey League playoffs this spring after finishing the regular season with the league's second-best record.

title: Historian Links Birth Order To Innovation
description: COPERNICUS, who shattered traditional cosmology by contending that the Earth revolves around the Sun, was the second of four children. His bitter opponent, Tycho Brahe, was an only child.

title: Fred Lessing, 75, Dies; Led a Metals Company
description: Fred W. Lessing, a retired executive and philanthropist, died of a heart attack on Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 75 years old.

title: Seidman Denies That U.S. Erred on Lincoln
description: Charles F. Keating Jr. is ''full of baloney'' to say that bungling by Federal regulators led to the collapse of his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, the nation's top savings and loan regulator said today.

title: President Named Chief Of Dime Savings Bank
description: The Dime Savings Bank, one of the strongest of New York's large savings banks, yesterday named Richard D. Parsons, a 42-year-old lawyer, as its new chief executive, effective July 1. He will succeed Harry W. Albright Jr., 65, who has headed the bank for 15 years and will continue as chairman.

title: Francis X. Fay, 92, Former F.B.I. Agent And Executive, Dies
description: Francis X. Fay, an F.B.I. agent active in the investigation of the kidnapping of the son of Charles A. Lindbergh in the early 30's, died of pneumonia on Saturday at the Little Company of Mary Pavilion in Torrance, Calif. He was 92 years old and lived in Norwalk, Conn.

title: Our Towns;   At 98, If That Van Hadn't Hit Him, He'd Be Running
description: Jack Horwitz may be 98, but when he gives a tour of his 20-room home here, he hates skipping a thing. Finishing inside, he insisted on a walk through his English-style gardens. ''Are we going out?'' he said, impatiently. ''O.K., let's go, O.K.?''

title: Harvard Law Declines Jackson Offer of Help
description: Harvard Law School said today that it had rejected an offer from the Rev. Jesse Jackson to mediate a dispute in which a black professor has threatened to step down unless a black woman was hired for the faculty.

title: INSIDE
description: $20 Million Yale Gift

title: Cranston Backer Guilty in Campaign Finance Case
description: In an intensified effort by Federal prosecutors to take on criminal cases involving campaign finance, a California businessman has been convicted of exceeding the limit on individual donations to help Senator Alan Cranston win re-election in 1986.

title: Burlington Journal;   A Library For People With Tales To Tell
description: For a fee of $25, to cover the cost of binding the manuscript and entering it into the computerized catalogue, anyone can place a piece of work in the Brautigan Library, which shares a building here in downtown Burlington with a massage therapy institute. There are no judgments made as to the quality of the submission; all manuscripts are accepted.

title: Building Wardrobes Around Jackets
description: The jacket is the style of the hour - and of the immediate future, too. Designers checking on orders for their fall collections find that retailers are picking the jackets first and then planning the rest of their purchases to go with them. The fall styles will be in stores starting next month.

title: Faster, Better Concorde Is Planned
description: The British and French aircraft makers that built the Concorde are expected to announce on Wednesday an agreement to study and design a second-generation supersonic aircraft to carry twice as many passengers as the Concorde and have almost twice its range.

title: Pope, Amid Mexico's Poor, Laments
description: While from his altar the Pope lamented poverty, hardly a stranger to this muddy, ramshackle settlement just outside Mexico City, a young priest strained today to catch the message.

title: Czechoslovakia In a Trade Pact
description: Czechoslovakia signed a trade and economic cooperation accord today with the European Community that its Prime Minister called an important step toward full membership by the year 2000.

title: Kenan Transport Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Unicorp American reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago results restated to reflect real estate operations as discontinued operations. The company also announced the sale of a residential property in Mill Neck, N.Y., for gross proceeds of $3,525,000. It said that net proceeds of $1,570,000 will be used to fund the company's short-term capital needs. Additionally, the company said that on April 27 it sold an office building in Cincinnati for gross proceeds of $3,250,000 and net proceeds of $900,000. Under terms of interim agreements between the company and Coscan Inc., net proceeds from the sale will be used to fund operating deficits relating to the properties subject to the previously announced transaction between the company and Coscan Inc.

title: Dow Up 11.26; Skittish Bond Market Cited
description: Stocks rose yesterday for the sixth day in a row, holding on to a thin gain in light trading heavily influenced by a skittish bond market.

title: KEY RATES
Martin Seeks National Recognition
description: HAVING weathered the departure of its founder, the hostile takeover of its parent company's parent company and an apparent renaissance in New York advertising, all in the last two years, the Martin Agency, one of the hot regional ad agencies of the 1980's, is asking, ''What next?''

title: African National Congress Wins Most Homeland Leaders' Support
description: The African National Congress, in seeking to widen its support, has scored a success in winning the backing of most of the leaders of the Government-created black homelands that have long formed a key element of the apartheid system.

title: Seaboard S&L reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the primary cause of the reported losses was the effect of non-earning assets on its interest margin. Interest income not recorded on the non-earning assets forthe first quarter totaled about $190,000. The reduction in interest income was partially offset by a gain on the dispostion of land totaling about $56,000.

title: Move to Ease Trust Law
description: In a move meant to strengthen the competitiveness of United States business, the Bush Administration proposed legislation today that would ease antitrust restrictions on joint production ventures between American companies.

title: Japan Builds East Asia Links, Gaining Labor and Markets
description: After having built its economic miracle on strong links with the industrialized West, Japan is now increasing its trade and investment in the buoyant economies of East Asia, creating a highly efficient manufacturing bloc in this vital region.

title: Brokers Seek Aid by Belgium
description: Stockbrokers want the Government to compensate them for the losses they expect to incur as a result of planned changes at the Brussels stock exchange.

title: Topics of The Times;   Hacker's License
description: Robert Tappan Morris is the Oliver North of computer abuse. The graduate student whiz committed a felony punishable by prison: tying up 6,000 computers with an electronic ''worm'' that spread wildly through interconnected machines. Yet Federal Judge Howard Munson in Syracuse sentenced him only to 400 hours of community service and a $10,000 fine. That light penalty won't deter other hackers from trespassing on information systems.

title: Capital Flight In Hong Kong
description: Hong Kong's main financial institution said it had detected a significant increase in capital flight from the jittery British colony, which will revert to Chinese rule in 1997.

title: Manville Reorganizes To Be More 'Natural'
description: ''This is a 130-year-old company,'' said W. Thomas Stephens, president and chief executive of the Manville Corporation, as he explained a management reorganization yesterday. ''We had a tendency to get kind of centralized and organized around technology and assets rather than the outside world.''

title: Ex-Koch Aide Investigated on 'Gifts'
description: Prosecutors are investigating assertions that a former New York City official asked for $110,000 in election campaign contributions in 1985 and 1986 to help a contractor obtain a plant to produce concrete for the city.

title: Cuba Starts Jamming Radio Marti Full Time
description: Cuba today started 24-hour jamming in Havana of Radio Marti, the United States's Spanish-language station transmitted from Miami, and said it would extend the jamming to the whole island.

title: Coach Finally Gets Word To Knicks
description: Stu Jackson, sitting on a rickety chair and yelling above the din of the noisy Boston Garden crowd Sunday afternoon, constantly reminded his Knicks during every time out to ''make the extra pass, push the ball up and battle for every offensive rebound.''

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * CBS Records Inc., New York, a unit of Sony Corp., promoted David H. Johnson to senior vice president, general counsel and secretary.

title: Poco Petroleums reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Borg in Libel Action
description: Bjorn Borg, the five-time Wimbledon champion from Sweden, appeared in court in Stockholm yesterday to open a $58,000 libel action stemming from allegations that he abused drugs.

title: Wellington Leisure Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
People
description: * Steve Bayer has joined Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners as senior vice president and director of account services.

title: Ben Holt, 34, Singer Of Malcolm X Role In Davis's '85 Opera
description: Ben Holt, a baritone who sang with the Metropolitan and New York City Opera companies and who created the title role in the opera ''X (The Life and Times of Malcolm X),'' died of Hodgkin's disease Saturday at Presbyterian Hospital in Albuquerque, N.M. He was 34 years old and had homes in New York City and Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: Grand Slam Changes?
description: The Australian Open, the least prestigious of the four major titles, could lose its Grand Slam status unless prize money is increased, the tournament's general manager said yesterday in Melbourne.

title: Immunex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflected $9 million in one-time fees from Hoffman-La Roche Inc. and Behringwerke Ag due to repurchase by Roche of an Immunex option to manufacture IL-2 for sale by Roche in the United States, and the licensing by Behringwerke of Manufacturing and Marketing rights in Japan to a package of Immunex's soluble cytokine-receptor products. c-Net loss

title: CHRONICLE
description: Updating the sick list:

title: Steel of West Virginia reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Soviets Lift Grain Price
description: The Soviet Government today nearly doubled the price paid to grain farmers in hopes of stimulating this year's harvest at the risk of a substantial increase in its budget deficit. The price paid for top-quality soft grain will rise to 500 rubles a ton from 260 rubles under today's order from the Council of Ministers, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. The price paid for other grains will rise by 30 percent to nearly 100 percent.

title: The Army Isn't Running Gorbachev
description: LEAD: In his news conference last week, President Bush added to recent speculation that the Soviet military is reasserting its influence over Mikhail Gorbachev. Nevertheless, there is nothing to suggest that the trend of declining military influence in recent years has been reversed.

title: New York City's Construction Approval Process Is Unsound
description: To the Editor:

title: Adirondack Acid Harm Revised
description: A TEAM of researchers has reported that damage from acid rain in Adirondack lakes is not as great as was once thought.

title: EMC Insurance Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pegasus Gold reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it produced 56,100 ounced in gold in the latest quarter, up from 51,200 ounces a year earlier. The realized gold price was $414 an ounce, compared with $416. The company also said higher exploration expenditures and lower interest income reduced earnings by $1.4 million in the latest quarter from a year earlier.

title: I.B.M. Europe Pact
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has received a $400 million contract for 55,000 of its PS/2 personal computers for use in the Amadeus European travel agent network. The award, one of I.B.M's largest ever, was made to the company's West German subsidiary, I.B.M. Deutschland G.m.b.H., which will supply the computers over three years. The travel system is headquartered in Madrid. Amadeus is a partnership of 21 European airlines, the French and West German national railroads and a West German tour operator.

title: Ashley Lawrence; Orchestra Director For Ballets Was 55
description: Ashley Lawrence, the music director of the Stuttgart Ballet of West Germany and the recently appointed principal guest conductor of the New York City Ballet, died of an aneurysm yesterday at the Metropolitan Hiroo Hospital in Tokyo, The Associated Press reported. He was 55 years old.

title: Insurer Fined $115.5 Million
description: A Federal judge has imposed a $115.5 million penalty on officers of the collapsed Champion Insurance Company, but the judge warned state officials that they might have difficulty collecting the money.

title: Ads for Chrysler Say Buyers Prefer Its Cars Over Honda's
