description: Suffering from a steep decline in its share of the United States vehicle market, the Chrysler Corporation is intensifying a two-month-old media blitz with new advertising based on a surprising finding that new-car buyers prefer Chrysler cars over those of the highly rated Honda Motor Company.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Will Cuomo's Style on TV Work Nationally?
description: If, as the common wisdom has it, a candidate rises or falls on his television performance and if, as so many people say, Mario M. Cuomo is the last best hope of the Democratic Party for 1992, then he must be in training for his trial by television. How is he doing? New Yorkers have an opportunity to assess their Governor's tubeworthiness three times a year, when he appears on all the state's public television stations to answer an hour's worth of calls from constituents.

title: Steuben County Police Kill Rabid Raccoon
description: The first rabid raccoon ever identified by state authorities has been killed in Addison in Steuben County.

title: India Balks At U.S. Move
description: India will not change its economic policies to please Washington, which has called the country an unfair trader, the Commerce Minister, Arun Nehru, said last week.

title: Soviet Union Buys Corn
description: Private exporting companies have sold the Soviet Union an additional 1.75 million metric tons of United States corn for delivery this year under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today. Officials said that 1.15 million tons were new sales, while 600,000 tons were previously reported but were shifted from ''unknown'' destinations to the Soviet Union. Large sales are reported daily to the Agriculture Department by exporters.

title: Sallie Mae Issue
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday priced a $500 million issue of short-term floating-rate notes due Nov. 8, 1990. The federally chartered, stockholder-owned corporation generally issues these types of securities each month through various securities dealers with Sallie Mae as the lead manager. Priced at par, the floating-rate notes yield about 30 basis points more than the bond- equivalent rate of the 91-day Treasury bill auction rate. Interest will be adjusted on the day after each weekly Treasury bill auction and will be paid at maturity.

title: Singapore Journal;   'Nightmare Death' Fells Thais, and Nations Bicker
description: A medical mystery about why young workers from Thailand should be dying in their sleep in Singapore has turned into an emotional debate about their living conditions in this wealthy city-state, straining relations between the countries.

title: Safeguard Scientifics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net security-related gains of $4.2 million, or 82 cents a share, in the latest quarter and $1.4 million, or 26 cents a share, in the year earlier quarter. The year-ago first quarter sales included the sale of Powertech Systems, which was sold in the second quarter of 1989.

title: Candidates in 4 States Brace for Primary Day
description: The primary season begins in earnest on Tuesday as voters head to the polls in four states, with North Carolina drawing special attention as Democrats look for a candidate to carry their banner against Senator Jesse Helms this fall.

title: Queens Lawmaker Guilty in Bank Plot
description: A State Senator from Queens was convicted yesterday of taking $150,000 from a man he thought was a wheeler-dealer financier and promising to launder the money through a bank in Zaire that he said he owned.

title: Letting the Thing Speak for Itself
description: SPEECH THING, mentioned here last week, gives your PC a voice. A fair amount of commercial software already works with it, and a reasonably proficient Basic programmer can write other applications that speak for themselves.

title: Flooding Persists After Record Rain
description: The worst floods in decades, caused by storms nearly a week ago, are still plaguing large areas of Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas.

title: Protest Continues at College Over Decision to Admit Men
description: Mills College students kept control of the campus today in their protest against the trustees' decision to admit male undergraduates for the first time in the school's 138-year history.

title: Johnson, Dent Stall Specter Of Syndrome
description: This time a week ago the Knicks were wondering if they could make a layup, Davey Johnson and the Mets were wondering how David Cone could argue with an umpire while two baserunners scored, and the Yankees were wondering how much longer Bucky Dent would be their manager. But what a difference a weekend makes.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: 'Bonfire' Protest Recalls 'Fort Apache' Solution;   Hispanic Parents Care
description: To the Editor:

title: Voting to Pay Workers
description: The State Senate gave final passage today to a bill to allow state workers to be paid despite the impasse over the state's budget.

title: Keystone Consolidated IndusFtries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $1,592,000, or 43 cents a share for the latest quarter and $845,000, or 23 cents a share for the year-earlier period.

title: Housing Off in Canada
description: In a fresh sign that seven years of economic growth may be easing in Canada, the Government reported today that new-home construction had fallen 12 percent in April to its lowest level in two and a half years. April starts fell to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 199,000 units, compared with 226,000 in March. In addition, the composite leading indicator, a barometer of future economic activity, was unchanged in February after increases of one-tenth of 1 percent in January and three-tenths of a percent in each of the last three months of 1989, Statistics Canada said.

title: Europeans Envision A 'Son of Concorde'
description: The British and French aircraft manufacturers that built the Concorde - the sleek, swift supersonic transport plane - envision a ''son of Concorde'' that would carry twice as many passengers and fly almost twice as far.

title: Foote, Cone Earnings Drop by 41.5% in Period
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications reported a 41.5 percent drop in net income for the quarter ended March 31 to $1.34 million, or 13 cents a share, from $2.29 million, or 23 cents a share, in the 1989 first quarter. Revenues were down 6.7 percent, to $72.19 million from $77.34 million.

title: One Last Round for 2 Old Dominican Rivals
description: For more than five decades they have been rivals, and now the two men they call the Grand Elephants of Dominican politics are squaring off for what seems to be their final battle in national elections on May 16.

title: Thomas Ravasz, Psychoanalyst, 45
description: Thomas Ravasz, a New York psychoanalyst, died on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 45 years old and also lived in North Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Books of The Times;   Portrait or a Potboiler? 2 Novels in One.
description: Secret Anniversaries

title: Cuomo Urges Internal Police for Mohawks
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo called today for the creation of an indigenous police force to patrol the St. Regis Indian Reservation, but he said the state police would remain there ''for as long as it seems to me to be essential.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: An electrical problem forced a plane carrying the Princess of Wales to make an emergency landing at Gatwick Airport near London yesterday.

title: A Fervent Advocate Of the Proxy Battle
description: Robert A. G. Monks has a resume that might endear him to any corporate board: a Harvard-educated lawyer who made his fortune as an industrialist; former chairman of a leading Boston investment firm; two-time Republican candidate for the United States Senate in Maine. And, he held top positions in the Reagan Administration.

title: Prices on Treasury Issues Slip
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers prepared for today's start of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions.

title: Fairfield Communities reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,008,000. The company said improved results included $1,590,000 pre-tax first quarter profit recorded by its wholly- owned subsidiary, First Federal Savings & Loan Association of Charlotte, N.C.

title: Molecule That Protects Embryo Is Tracked
description: RESEARCHERS have tracked the activity of an unusual molecule in embryo cells, a finding that could help elucidate one of the most compelling problems in immunology: Why does a mother's body not reject a growing fetus as foreign tissue?

title: Knicks Must Adjust To Pistons' Defense
description: As an assistant coach last year, Stu Jackson sat alongide Rick Pitino and watched him shout ''white,'' when he wanted the Knicks in a full-court press and ''black,'' in a 2-2-1 three-quarter press.

title: Pioneer Financial Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PATTERNS
description: Pucci Redux

title: Columbia S&L reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Latest shares outstanding with a net loss, assumed conversion of common stock equivalents and other potentially dilutive securities are excluded as the effect would be antidilutive.

title: On Horse Racing;   Lasix: Opposing Sides Consult the Evidence
description: The news that Lasix makes horses run faster is no news to horseplayers. Now, however, that longstanding assumption has been certified in a prestigious medical journal and the continued use of the drug has become the sport's hottest issue.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Renovated Communist Stirs Some Romanians
description: By the time Ion Iliescu arrived two hours late for an election rally in this town on the banks of the Danube, the crowd was seething with excitement. About 40,000 people had packed the main square, some scrambling over rooftops and up trees for a better view, while women and children in the front rows waved roses and peonies, yelling out a new favorite on the Romanian campaign trail: ''When Iliescu appears, the sun comes out.''

title: CM Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Supertex Inc. reports earnings for Year to March 31
Viola Improves To 6-0 Mark
description: This is getting monotonous. Frank Viola pitches against the Astros. Viola mesmerizes the Astros. Viola leaves the game with an injury, and the Mets ease to a victory.

title: Robert W. Drummond, Investment Banker, 82
description: Robert Watchorn Drummond, a Philadelphia investment banker, died of cancer on Friday at his vacation home in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: Sutcliffe Has Surgery
description: The Chicago Cubs' right-handed pitcher Rick Sutcliffe underwent arthroscopic surgery on his pitching shoulder yesterday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital, and he is expected to be out for several weeks, the club announced.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: New Zealand Sale by NBC
description: The National Broadcasting Company said last week that it had sold shares in New Zealand's only private television channel, TV3, which has gone into receivership.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Latvia Selects a Premier After Soviet Tanks Roll By
description: Latvia's Parliament chose a new Prime Minister today to take it to independence after what appeared to be a Soviet show of strength there this morning.

title: 'Bonfire' Protest Recalls 'Fort Apache' Solution;   Belated Outrage
description: To the Editor:

title: Addict in Blue; One Officer's Battle - A special report:   He Wore a Badge, Then He Sold It for Crack
description: On the day Robert Biangazzo graduated from the New York City Police Academy, his family and his fiancee attended the ceremony at Madison Square Garden, then took him out for a fancy dinner and drinks at the Waterfront Crab House in Long Island City.

title: A Turbulent Ride Through N.H.L. Playoffs
description: After beating the Edmonton Oilers in the third game of the Campbell Conference final Sunday night, the Chicago Blackhawks had little time to hang around the locker room and savor their two-games-to-one lead in the four-of-seven-game series.

title: Carroll Behrhorst, 67; Doctor to Guatemalans
description: Dr. Carroll Behrhorst, a physician who left Kansas 28 years ago to practice among the poverty-stricken Cakchiquel Indians of rural Guatemala, died yesterday in Chimaltenango, Guatemala, apparently of a heart attack. He was 67 years old.

title: Market Place;   Profit Forecasts: How Accurate?
description: WALL STREET, having scaled back its hopes dramatically, now seems to have reduced its expectations for corporate profits to achievable levels. And that seems to be starting to help share prices.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about new lines of authority for the Police and Fire Departments at life-or-death emergencies misstated, through information supplied by the Police Department, who is to be in charge when a passenger is trapped in a vehicular accident. The ranking police officer is to be in charge.

title: Suitor Given Deal By Apple Bancorp
description: Apple Bancorp Inc., which has been trying to elude a hostile $38-a-share takeover bid by the New York investor Stanley Stahl, offered to give Mr. Stahl non-public information in exchange for an agreement not to bid for Apple for two years. The offer was disclosed in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: First-Quarter Productivity Declined 1%
description: The productivity of business in the United States fell an unexpectedly sharp 1 percent in the first quarter of 1990, despite the biggest gains in the manufacturing sector in nearly three years, the Labor Department said today.

title: 3-D Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $155,200. c-Net loss

title: Bush Will Veto Bill Requiring Job Leave for Care of Family
description: President Bush will veto any legislation requiring employers to give parents time off to care for their newborn babies or ill family members, the White House chief of staff, John H, Sununu, said today. It is the second time this spring that Congress and the White House have clashed over a measure aimed at helping families torn between the demands of work and home.

title: Washington Talk;   A.B.A. Walking Fine Line On Bench
description: For nearly 40 years, the American Bar Association has played a critical role in who becomes a Federal judge.

title: Troubled Oil, or Troubled Waters?
description: America has no rational strategy for exploring its coastal waters for oil and gas. The Interior Department and the oil companies want to drill; the environmentalists and their allies in the coastal states and Congress do not. Any middle ground in this paralyzing dispute disappeared with the wreck of the Exxon Valdez.

title: Careers;   Personnel Executives On the Rise
description: THE job of vice president or top manager in charge of human resources, or personnel departments, has become much more important in the last few years. Two recent surveys by leading management recruiters confirm the trend.

title: Sage Laboratories Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'Bonfire' Protest Recalls 'Fort Apache' Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution in Europe;   BONN OFFICIAL SEES RAPID UNIFICATION
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher said today that the ''two plus four'' talks had brought a ''historic turnaround'' that cleared the way for rapid German unity, and politicians in Bonn renewed calls to hold all-German elections as soon as possible.

title: U.S. Says New Data Show Repeated Drug Use by Barry
description: Federal prosecutors said today that new evidence showed that Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. repeatedly used cocaine over several years and in the six weeks before he was arrested last January on drug charges.

title: Deal for Newsletter Concern
description: K-III Holdings Inc. said today that it had agreed to acquire Ward's Communications, including a newsletter regarded as the statistical bible of the automotive industry, from the Thomson Corporation. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Synagogue Official Facing Charges Is Found Dead
description: Around Congregation Anshe Sholom in New Rochelle, William Hirsch was known as a generous man. For two decades he served as the temple's treasurer, and three years ago, at the Lake Isle Country Club in Eastchester, the synagogue honored him for his charity.

title: Remains of Apollo Spacecraft Will Be Buried
description: The Apollo capsule in which three astronauts died 23 years ago will be buried later this month in the abandoned missile silo that contains the debris of the space shuttle Challenger, the space agency said.

title: Icahn Seen As Loser in USX Vote
description: Carl C. Icahn all but conceded today that he had failed to win support for his plan to split the USX Corporation. The votes cast at the annual meeting here will not be tabulated for at least a week, but the indications are that the New York financier has come up short in his costly campaign.

title: Canseco's Power Puts Yanks Back on Earth
description: The Yankees fell back to earth tonight.

title: Polk Audio reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
Accounts
description: * W.K. Buckley Ltd., Toronto, a manufacturer of cold remedies, to the Mingo Group.

title: Q&A
description: Sap and Syrup

title: Dr. Hugh Jewett, 86, Professor of Urology
description: Dr. Hugh Judge Jewett, an international authority on bladder and prostate cancer and a former professor of urology at the Johns Hopkins Medical Institutions, died of prostate cancer on Sunday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 86 years old and lived in Baltimore.

title: Learning to Talk Like an Egghead
description: A FEW zillion nanoseconds ago I was in a wait state at a computer confab and overheard some chipheads skreeding the verbosity of the silicon biz. (While loitering at a recent computer show, I overheard some computer engineers complaining about the use of jargon in the computer industry.) Now, even a narrow-bandwidth wirebrain with a stack overflow can pick up the lingo with a little vocab tweaking. (However, virtually anyone can learn to speak computerese with a bit of study.) Download this (Here is a glossary of some of the terms one is likely to encounter at the computer store):

title: Brooklyn Bishop Will Pray In Protests at Abortion Clinics
description: The newly installed Bishop of Brooklyn, Thomas V. Daily, said yesterday that he hoped to curb abortions in his diocese by praying with others outside abortion clinics in peaceful and nonconfrontational protests that did not violate the law.

title: RMS International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Review/Dance;   In Boston, a 'Swan Lake' Without the Gimmicks
description: A huge risk and the most imaginative project to come down the ballet pike in a decade, the Boston Ballet's new ''Swan Lake,'' staged by a team famous in Soviet dance history, is a fabulous production and a major success.

title: Scurry-Rainbow Oil reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: U.S. Foreclosures for Farm Debts Reported on Rise
description: The Farmers Home Administration has written off nearly one-third of the $8.8 billion owed by delinquent borrowers and says there is an increase in foreclosures to collect the rest.

title: Helen of Troy reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The company said results for the latest fourth quarter and full year 1990 included earnings of $1,187,000 related to the resolution of certain U.S. and foreign tax issues.

title: Perini Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Geico Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Greyhound Views Strike As Over
description: The chief executive of Greyhound Lines Inc. said today that ''from all practical points of view,'' a drivers' strike now in its 10th week ''is over'' and that the nation's largest intercity bus system was operating on routes that contributed 98 percent of its revenues a year ago.

title: U.S. Details $1 Million Offer For Missiles by 2 Colombians
description: Two Colombian drug traffickers arrested last weekend had agreed to hand over $1 million in cocaine profits as a down payment for a ''substantial number'' of Stinger anti-aircraft missiles, F.B.I. officials said today.

title: Random Access Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Rise Found In Gonorrhea Resistant To Penicillin
description: Penicillin-resistant gonorrhea more than doubled from 1988 to 1989 and its treatment will require more expensive drugs, Federal researchers say.

title: Anthony G. Barbieri, Security Officer, 74
description: Anthony G. Barbieri, a former security officer and attache for the State Department, died on Thursday at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. He was 74 years old and lived in Pelham Manor, N.Y.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about life in the Jamaican neighborhoods where reggae music was born misstated the date of the death of Emperor Haile Selassie of Ethiopia. He died in 1975, a year after he was overthrown in a military coup.

title: Atlantic Richfield reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $323 million, or $1.94 a share, from an accounting adjustment. c-Included $634 million gain from initial public offering of Lyondell Petrochemical Co. stock. The gain was partially offset by $345 million in charges for future environmental and other expenses. The company said in the latest quarter the $323 million gain from accounting change for income taxes was partially offset by net charges totaling about $233 million. The charges included provisions for taxes and other related issues, future environmental cleanup costs, and high-coupon debt redemption. These charges in turn were partially offset by a gain from a natural gas settlement.

title: Scientific Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $89,000, or 2 cents a share, from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards.

title: Polls Bring Mitterrand Down to Earth
description: Long skilled at playing the role of elder statesman who stands above the fray of daily politics, President Francois Mitterrand has seen his popularity tumble sharply as he prepares to begin his 10th year in office on Thursday.

title: Dr. Campbell Heads Panel On Museum For Blacks
description: The board of the Smithsonian Institution today named Dr. Mary Schmidt Campbell, New York City Commissioner of Cultural Affairs, as chairwoman of a 22-member advisory board to study ways to exhibit on the Mall the heritage of black Americans.

title: Pine Barrens Lawsuit Halts L.I. Builders
description: A lawsuit seeking to limit development in the pine barrens of Suffolk County has halted construction in much of eastern Long Island since November.

title: 'Grand Hotel' and 'City of Angels' Lead the Nominations for Tonys
description: ''Grand Hotel'' received 12 nominations yesterday to lead the field for the 1990 Tony Awards. ''City of Angels'' took 11, ''The Grapes of Wrath'' got 8, ''Aspects of Love'' won 6, and ''Gypsy'' and ''The Piano Lesson'' came in with 5 each.

title: Soviet Scientists Flock to U.S., Acting as Tonic for Colleges
description: Reflecting the wavering of confidence in the future of the Soviet Union, scores of Soviet mathematicians and theoretical physicists are flocking to the United States as visiting scholars at universities. These eminent scientists are stimulating research in this country, providing an influx of new ideas and flashes of insight.

title: MCI Plans to Pay Dividend on Stock
description: The MCI Communications Corporation announced it would pay dividends on its common stock for the first time in its 27-year history. The nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company told shareholders at its annual meeting in Washington that it would begin paying a regular semiannual dividend of 5 cents a share on its common stock on June 11. MCI's stock rose 37.5 cents yesterday, to $38.25, in heavy over-the-counter trading of almost 2.1 million shares.

title: 12 Killed in Lebanon as Christian Forces Clash
description: Rival Christian forces fought each other with artillery and tank fire in east Beirut and the surrounding countryside today, killing at least 12 people and wounding at least 27, the police said.

title: 'Realizing a Dream'
description: The negotiating teams held three days of preliminary talks and then issued a statement beginning:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING

title: Bruins Push Capitals to the Brink of Elimination
description: Dale Hunter spent the night doing everything humanly possible, and more than a couple of things that are strictly prohibited, in pursuit of a triumph for the Capitals.

title: Trinity College Blacks Protest Window-Breaking at Center
description: A broken window at the black cultural center at Trinity College sparked a student protest today as well as an investigation by campus authorities into the weekend incident.

title: Stock Plan Announced By Playboy
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc. announced a recapitalization plan today aimed at helping the company finance acquisitions and other activities without diluting the controlling stake of its founder, Hugh Hefner.

title: Jefferson-Pilot Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gains on sales of investments of $3,679,000, or 10 cents a share and $8,006,000, or 21 cents a share, for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Review/Music;   Foss Ends Final Season With the Brooklyn
description: When the final chord of the Verdi Requiem faded away at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Sunday afternoon, Lukas Foss's 20th and final season as music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic came to an end. He will continue as conductor laureate - a post he also holds with the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra - and will work with the Brooklyn ensemble at least through 1992, a year after Dennis Russell Davies succeeds him as director. Mr. Foss, who is 67 years old, has said he wants to devote more time to composition.

title: Chess
description: The Dortmund Chess Festival was organized in timely fashion. For one thing, it was about time that West Germany (or either Germany, for that matter) held a first-class competition. Not since Nuremberg 1896, or maybe Barmen 1905, has a tournament as strong as the Dortmund International ''A'' taken place on German soil. In recent years, chess enthusiasm in West Germany has all gone into its elite league play for club teams.

title: Bonds Leads the Pirates To 4-1 Victory Over Padres
description: Barry Bonds had a home run as Pittsburgh scored four runs in the first inning tonight and went on to beat the Padres, 4-1, for their ninth victory in 11 games.

title: The Bacteria at the Table
description: ''Food is safer than it ever was,'' says the Secretary of Agriculture, Clayton Yeutter. Maybe that's true in some sense. But the number of people who get food poisoning has almost doubled in 15 years, proving food is not nearly safe enough.

title: Brain Damage Link
description: Scientists have discovered that a common substance found in plants, animals and the human brain can destroy critical brain areas that control movement, memory and higher mental functions.

title: Now, a Way to Conceal Identification of Caller
description: First there was caller identification, which allows people to see the number of the phone from which the call was made before they answer. Now a California company has set up a pair of 900 telephone numbers to foil these services - at a price.

title: Webster Clothes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
Bridge
description: In the last year, the people of Poland have been unhappy about many things, but not the performance of their bridge team. They won the European Championship in Turku, Finland, in July, and although they lost to Brazil, the eventual champions, in the NEC Bermuda Bowl contest in Perth, Australia, in September, they took the bronze medal.

title: Wicat Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Banc One Texas
description: Bank One Texas, a subsidiary of the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, assumed the deposits and certain other liabilities of the former First State Federal Savings Association in San Antonio. Terms of the transaction were not disclosed. Bank One assumed $287 million in deposits of First State Federal, which was closed on Friday by the Office of Thrift Supervision.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Former President JIMMY CARTER was named the 1990 recipient of the Philadelphia Liberty Medal yesterday for his involvement in ''issues of liberty around the globe,'' said MARTIN MEYERSON, who is president emeritus of the University of Pennsylvania and chairman of the 12-member selection commission.

title: Banister Continental reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: William Schiller, 81; Headed Hershey Foods
description: William E. Schiller, retired chairman of Hershey Foods Corporation in Hershey, Pa., died of heart disease last Wednesday at Hershey Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived in Hershey.

title: Volkswagen Deal With China Near
description: Volkswagen A.G. of West Germany is poised to sign an agreement for what will be the largest automobile joint venture in China, a company spokesman said. The car maker and China's First Automotive Works are expected to agree to a 150,000-car venture by the second half of the year, said Burkhard Welkener, deputy general manager of Shanghai Volkswagen.

title: Nat Sherman, 86, Cigar Merchant Who Began as a Peddler, Is Dead
description: Nat Sherman, the cigar merchant who started as a peddler on the streets of the Lower East Side, died of heart failure on Monday at Miami Heart Hospital in Miami Beach after a long bout with colon cancer. He was 86 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Miami Beach.

title: New England Business ServFice Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment of $525,000 from a cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,366,000 and $1,846,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which included losses of $915,000 in the quarter and 9 months on sale of discontinued operations.

title: United Gaming Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
By Design By Not Just Any T-Shirt
description: What a difference a designer makes. Even a T-shirt takes on a new life when a designer puts a hand to it. (It also takes on a new price, though it will be cheaper than the rest of a collection.) The most spectacular has to be Christian Lacroix's black cotton-knit long-sleeved T, with a huge, painted gold Maltese cross on the front, studded with fake gems. It's at Bloomingdale's for $245, still a lot less than the couture version.

title: Read Weber, 83, Dies; Manhattan Architect
description: Read Weber, a founding member of the architectural firm of Katz Waisman Blumenkranz Stein & Weber in Manhattan, died of complications from a stroke and a lung infection on Saturday at a nursing home in Santa Fe, N.M. She was 83 years old and lived in Cerillos, N.M.

title: Dynamics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $220,000 to increase a reserve for unrealized losses on the company's current marketable securities portfolio. c-Net income First-quarter results also included $254,000 of income of CTS Corp. as compared to CTS income of $698,000 included in the same period in 1989. This represents the company's proportionate share of CTS' first quarter earnings in accordance with the equity method of accounting required for that investment.

title: U.S. AND IRAN MOVE ON SMALLER CLAIMS
description: The United States and Iran have made substantial progress toward a settlement of more than 2,000 small claims against Iran by Americans who contend that their property was improperly seized by Teheran, Administration officials said today.

title: Topics of The Times;   Left High and Dry
description: It turned out to be a lovely weekend in New York, much to the astonishment of the weathermen. There was barely a trace of the three inches of rain that some thought would deluge the metropolitan area. For all the ostensible science (''barometric pressure,'' ''relative humidity''), forecasting the weather seems approximately as accurate as forecasting the economy.

title: The Feds' Odd Count
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Offers Fare Refunds
description: In an attempt to win back the business traveler, Eastern Airlines announced yesterday that it would refund the fare of any first-class customer who finds the service unsatisfactory.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a news conference to protest remarks made by the Newsday columnist Jimmy Breslin misstated the title of Helen Zia, one of the speakers. Ms. Zia is president of the New York Chapter of the Asian-American Journalists Association.

title: Democrat to Oppose Congressman Scheuer
description: State Senator Leonard P. Stavisky announced yesterday that he would challenge a fellow Democrat, Representative James H. Scheuer, for his Congressional seat.

title: Eller Quits As Head Of Circle K
description: Karl Eller, who less than a year ago was trying to put together a leveraged buyout of the Circle K Corporation, resigned yesterday as chairman and chief executive of the troubled convenience-store chain.

title: G.M.A.C. Offering $250 Million Notes
description: The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, is offering $250 million in notes due 2000 through underwriters led by Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: At the State Dept., Historygate
description: LEAD: The State Department is playing games with history. The result is that thousands of scholars, journalists and diplomats who depend on the renowned series of documents on foreign policy known as ''Foreign Relations of the United States'' can no longer trust its reliability.

title: United Healthcare reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Tire Maker Outdistances Rivals
description: At a time when most tire companies are merging in the face of global competition and shuttering many factories, the Cooper Tire and Rubber Company is thriving as an independent and expanding its capacity.

title: Adultery Count Might Be Dropped By Agreement in Wisconsin Case
description: A woman charged with violating Wisconsin's rarely enforced adultery law has entered an agreement with prosecutors that is expected to result in the dismissal of the charge.

title: Philadelphia Suburban Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said earnings at its largest unit, Philadelphia Suburban Water Co., improved for the quarter due to a rate increase received in December 1989.

title: Pro Bono
description: * The Ad Council has chosen Wells, Rich, Greene to create a campaign to counter drunken driving.

title: Plains Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bovar Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,785,000 and $3,518,000 for the latest quarter and year-ago period, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ma and Ax Perform Bolcom
description: With so many styles, epochs and musical philosophies to reconcile, William Bolcom must lead a crowded inner life. The American composer is a splendid popular-music pianist, a fixture in musical academia and the fashioner of sonatas, oratorios, operas and more, all drawing on the variety of his own experience.

title: The Weight of Mexico
description: One local paper said 10 million people had come to the capital to see the Pope, who arrived Sunday. It's conceivable. Some Mexicans say the country's population is now 90 million. Nobody can be sure.

title: Greenwich Pharmaceuticals reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Henley Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $2,000,000, or 10 cents a share. The company noted that 1989 results have been restated to reflect Henley Properties Inc. as discontinued operations. The first quarter of 1990 reflects the consolidation of Pneumo Abex effective June 1, 1989. The company said the loss in the latest quarter was primarily attributable to increased interest expense associated with the acquisition of the remaining 50 percent stake in Pneumo Abex which Henley did not own, in June 1989.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have to deal with racism the rest of my life. Why should I deal with that in college?''

title: Article 012790 -- No Title
description: The City and County of Denver are tentatively offering $600 million in airport system revenue bonds to help finance a portion of the costs of the new Denver International Airport and some related costs.

title: 'Live Bodies' to Test Ex-Olympians
description: In the summer of 1988, they were amateurs shooting for a chance to compete at the Olympics in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Shrinking the Old-Tire Mountain: Progress Slow
description: A variety of companies are making progress toward ways to put to good use the hundreds of millions of tires Americans throw out each year. But environmentalists say the new technology still falls short of conquering on its own a problem that has become one of the nation's most notorious.

title: El Paso Electric reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after income of $1,513,000, or 4 cents a share. There is no share earnings for the latest quarter because preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income. Year-ago loss from continuing operations of $7,233,000 included after- tax regulatory disallowance of $15,044,000.

title: For American Caviar
description: PADDLEFISH caviar, most often sold under the title American sturgeon caviar, is similar in color and size to Russian sevruga, but costs about half as much. A caviar pound is typically 14 ounces. Quality can vary considerably. Caviar can usually be kept in the refrigerator for several weeks. Here are some places where the roe can be obtained: MACY'S CELLAR, 151 West 34th Street, Manhattan, 212-695-4400, extension 2002. American sturgeon caviar is $12.20 a 2 ounce tin, $42.50 a 7-ounce tin and $84.95 a 14-ounce tin.

title: Auto Wiper Claim Limited
description: The Ford Motor Company did not intentionally infringe on an inventor's patent rights to his intermittent windshield wiper, a Federal jury decided today.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Did Bush Err on Lithuania? 12 Say He Didn't
description: Should President Bush have responded more critically or more aggressively to the Soviet crackdown in Lithuania?

title: Corrections
description: An article in some copies on May 1 about a raid by the South Korean police on the Government-run Korean Broadcasting System described the clash incorrectly. The police did not use clubs to beat striking workers.

title: Americans Fail Test
description: A spate of American track and field athletes have tested positive recently for banned substances found in common cold medications that drug experts say work as stimulants.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about Sharpe James's first term as Mayor of Newark misstated the infant mortality rates for Newark and New Jersey. In 1988, the last year for which figures are available, the city's rate was 19.3 per 1,000 births, and the state's was 9.8 per 1,000.

title: Romanian Anti-Communists Keep Up Anti-Iliescu Protest
description: Anti-Communist protesters stormed out of a meeting today with the Provisional President, Ion Iliescu, dashing Government hopes of a quick end to a 17-day demonstration demanding Mr. Iliescu's resignation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Taj International Hotels, to Lipman, Richmond, Greene Advertising.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Creativity Takes Twist At Berenter
description: THE advertising of Berenter, Greenhouse & Webster is inventive. Take its forthcoming work for Baileys Original Irish Cream Liqueur. It was invented in the agency's test kitchen.

title: Americans Could Use Trap Door
description: rrTired of the same old faces cluttering up last place, year after year? There is a solution for complacency in American professional sports, and it is called relegation.

title: Review/Music;   A Modern Sound for Flute
description: Admirably, the Argentine flutist Jorge de la Vega offered a lot of contemporary music in his New York debut recital on Wednesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. Unfortunately, it was mostly evanescent and featureless stuff. You could have walked away humming the melody, if only you could remember it.

title: Congress Provides Open Forum on Soviet Data
description: To the Editor:

title: Salvador Vows New Push in Jesuit Case
description: The Salvadoran Government vowed today to cooperate with a judge's investigation into the killing of six Jesuit priests and two women in November and to take action if any obstacles are put in the judge's way.

title: Greenery Rehabilitation Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Orion Capital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results reflect after-tax realized investment gain of $1,220,000, or 19 cents a shre, in first quarter 1989, and a loss of $966,000, or 15 cents a share, in first quarter 1990. The company said it had net operating loss carryforwards of $1.598 million in first quarter 1990 and $2.633 million in the year-ago quarter.

title: Toyota Is Buying More Delco Parts
description: The General Motors Corporation's Delco Products division will export suspension struts later this year to the Toyota Motor Corporation in Japan. G.M. said it expected to supply about 500,000 struts a year from its factory in Kettering, Ohio, for use in Toyota Corollas.

title: Angry Dinkins Defends Role In Race Cases
description: With uncharacteristic public anger, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday defended his attempt to mediate a black-led boycott of Korean-American grocery stores in Brooklyn and his response to other racially charged incidents.

title: Aon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Class Mission Is Teaching, Not Labeling
description: Randee Sacher's second graders were smart enough to know where they stood, even though no one had told them.

title: Setbacks for Italian Media Executive
description: The inexorable rise of Silvio Berlusconi, who has become the most powerful figure in the Italian media, has been abruptly halted by a series of legal and political blows that threaten his private television empire and his hold over Italy's largest publishing group.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Crack Leap in Washington
description: With drug violence continuing in Washington D.C. and the city's Mayor facing crack charges, a sobered William Bennett expresses ''bitter disappointment'' that Federal antidrug programs in the capital haven't done more. At the same time, the drug czar sees a glimmer of hope: a Drug Use Forecasting survey recently developed by the National Institute of Justice suggests that cocaine use in the District has decreased.

title: Corona Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $581,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: British Jet Down Off Sardinia
description: A British military jet taking part in a NATO exercise crashed 20 miles southwest of Sardinia shortly before dawn today. Searchers found the wreckage of the plane, an AV-8 Harrier, but the pilot was missing and presumed dead, a British Defense Ministry official said. The cause of the crash was not known.

title: Yes, Cut the Deficit. Then What?
description: Will the budget deadlock finally be broken this time? President Bush's willingness to hold wide-open talks with the leaders of Congress is encouraging. But ultimate success depends on an agreement that goes beyond honest deficit reduction and addresses urgent national needs.

title: A Printer Translates Into Braille
description: A new computer printer can translate letters and numbers into Braille characters and reproduce graphic images in relief, using standard office paper. The first graphics printer for the blind was introduced recently by Howtek Inc., a Hudson, N.H., company that developed the machine in cooperation with the National Federation of the Blind.

title: Taxpayer Money for Arts Comes With Strings
description: To the Editor:

title: Thermedics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Portland Journal;   A Lonely Law Enforcer Pursues New Violator
description: Lee Barrett walked into a nightclub looking for evidence. Earlier, someone had filed a report -anonymously, of course - that the club, Starry Night, was breaking the law. Mr. Barrett's job was to investigate and, if needed, take swift action.

title: Panel Urges Maddox's Suspension For Refusing To Testify in Inquiry
description: A disciplinary committee in Brooklyn recommended yesterday that Alton H. Maddox Jr. be suspended from practicing law for not cooperating with an investigation into charges of misconduct against him in the Tawana Brawley case, a committee official said.

title: U.S. Tunes Up Vs. Poland
description: While the United States soccer team was struggling to score in a 1-0 victory over Malta last Saturday in Piscataway, N.J., two other teams bound for the World Cup were struggling with Poland over the weekend in Chicago.

title: Valley West Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: b-After a loss of $170,000 for the quarter and income of $1,064,000, or 3 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively, both from discontinued operations. c-Net income d-Included income from discontinued operations of $430,000, or 1 cent a share and $9,760,000, or 26 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: About Education;   Instead of being a crucible for scientists, introductory courses tend to distill them out.
description: Every year, almost 2,500 students at the University of Arizona take introductory chemistry. But only about 20 graduate as chemistry majors. This sends a message: introductory science courses, instead of attracting students to science, may scare them away.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING

title: Economic Scene;   Small Business, Large Mirage
description: THESE are disillusioning times. Evangelists steal, athletes cheat and even old Bossy the cow has been caught wreaking death and destruction. But at least one culture hero remains untarnished: the small business, America's engine of employment and prosperity.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Vinegar by the Drop

title: Cubic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included pretax gain of $5.3 million, or 43 cents a share, from the sale of the G.S. Parsons Co. unit.

title: Atari Founder Joining In Commodore Venture
description: Nolan Bushnell, the video game and personal computer pioneer who founded the Atari Corporation, is joining forces with an old rival, Commodore International Ltd.

title: In Looks, a Sense of Racial Unity
description: YOUNG Americans seem to be looking more alike these days. And that's not all. Young people of different ethnic backgrounds are acting and sounding a lot alike, too.

title: Shortfall In Pension Funds Cited
description: The pension funds of 50 large companies are each $40 million or more short of the funds they would need to meet all their obligations, should they close, and together those corporations are potentially short $14 billion, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporporation, a Government agency, said yesterday.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Integrity Corp., Philadelphia, an insurance company, said it had retained Kidder, Peabody & Co. to explore alternatives to increase its capital base.

title: Elevator Tragedies Reflect Decline in Play Areas
description: To the Editor:

title: Washington Bank Plans Revamping
description: The Washington Bancorporation agreed to tighten management practices and procedures after defaulting on about $26 million in short-term debt. The agreement with Federal regulators includes a special review of the company's real estate loans, the bank said on Monday. The company's stock plunged $5.50, or 61.1 percent, on Monday in over-the-counter trading, but it recovered $1.25 a share, or 35.7 percent, to $4.75 today.

title: Chronicle
description: Declaring his mental fitness, BRIAN WILSON of the Beach Boys took over the microphone Monday at a Los Angeles news conference called by his cousin STANLEY LOVE, who was about to announce his intention to become legal overseer of the musician's estate and life.

title: Without Them, Shad Is Nothing
description: IT'S a dirty job, but somebody's got to bone it.

title: F.D.A. Quashes Claims for a Cookie
description: It was a treat that was just too good to be true. The Phoenix Fiber Cookie, said to have just 124 calories, 2.2 grams of fat and 10 grams of fiber, promised to help dieters lose 14 pounds in 14 days. It was also supposed to be useful in treating cardiovascular disease, colon cancer, diabetes and diverticulitis, according to promotional literature.

title: North's Notes Show He Met Bush Soon After Lying to Congress in '86
description: Only hours after Oliver L. North met with Congressmen in 1986 and lied to them about his involvement with the Nicaraguan rebels, he met with Vice President George Bush, Mr. North's private notebooks show.

title: Jury Rules for Borg
description: A nine-member jury in Stockholm found the weekly magazine Z guilty of defamation yesterday after it published allegations that the five-time Wimbledon champion Bjorn Borg used cocaine.

title: Mets Win 4th in A Row
description: The Mets were not having much success hitting against Rick Reuschel of the Giants last night at Shea Stadium. As it turned out, they did not have to hit much in order to defeat Reuschel.

title: Donald J. Bedford; Investigator, 54
description: Donald J. Bedford, chief of investigators for the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, died of cancer on Monday at Long Island College Hospital. He was 54 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: MEASLES CAMPAIGN STALLS ON MONEY
description: The Federal Government has run out of money to provide emergency vaccinations for an expanding epidemic of measles, Federal officials say.

title: Rates Decline At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates fell moderately at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper yesterday. It was the first decline in rates at the auction in more than a month.

title: 'Gasohol' May Cut Monoxide but Raise Smog, Study Asserts
description: A study prepared for the oil industry and released yesterday has cast doubt on a much-discussed method of fighting air pollution, concluding that requiring grain alcohol in gasoline will produce a minor reduction in carbon monoxide, but a large increase in smog. An amendment to the Clean Air Act approved by the Senate would mandate such a change.

title: Pirates Rout Padres as Terrell Records His First Victory
description: Mike LaValliere and Andy Van Slyke belted home runs and Walt Terrell earned his first victory for Pittsburgh tonight as the Pirates beat San Diego, 10-2, for their 10th victory in 12 games.

title: Reviews/Music;   Mozart to Cage at Chamber Society
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center concluded its 21st season last night at Alice Tully Hall with a program that, in its stark juxtaposition of traditional and modern fare and its heavy concentration of guest performers, epitomized a year of transition. Fred Sherry, in his first season as artistic director, profoundly shook up an organization that many felt had grown complacent over the two decades since its founding by Charles Wadsworth. Mr. Sherry realigned personnel and refocused programming to include many works the society had not previously performed, including a heavier representation of contemporary music.

title: Mota to Run in L'eggs
description: Rosa Mota of Portugal, one of the best female marathon runners, will make her first appearance in the 19th annual L'eggs Mini Marathon (10 kilometers) on May 26, in Central Park. Mota, 31 years old, has won 11 of 16 career marathons, including a gold medal in the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, South Korea.

title: Berry Petroleum Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jessica James; Actress, 60
description: Jessica James, an actress, died of breast cancer on Monday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 60 years old.

title: Moynihan Rebuffed on Captives
description: Israel has rejected calls by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan for the unconditional release of hundreds of Shiite Muslim prisoners in southern Lebanon as a good-will gesture to Iran for the recent release of two American hostages.

title: Zemex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ISS International Service SysFtem reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Invacare Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WINE TALK
description: GLOOM and doom. If anyone on the wine industry's mailing lists were asked to sum up the current mood among professionals, it would be hard to come up with three more descriptive words.

title: More in China Willingly Rear Just One Child
description: Gong Daifang, a 36-year-old peasant, has made a decision that her ancestors probably would never have understood: her 10-year-old son is enough, and she will not have another child.

title: Chronicle
description: At age 79, MARY G. ROEBLING decided it was time to step down as the chairman of the National State Bank, one of New Jersey's largest independent banks. That was six years ago. Since then, ''I've never been so busy,'' she said. At 30, she was the first woman to head a major bank, the Trenton Trust. She was a founder of the Women's Bank N.A. of Denver, the first nationally chartered bank started by women, and the first woman to serve as a member of the Board of Governors of the American Stock Exchange.

title: China to Sell Companies
description: China plans to sell four small state-owned companies in the Shenzhen special economic zone near Hong Kong to foreign or domestic interests, The People's Daily said today. The newspaper said all of the concerns were poorly managed and losing money.

title: Lawyer for Thrift Office
description: The new director of the Office of Thrift Supervision has appointed a lawyer with little direct experience in the savings and loan industry as the agency's top attorney. In his first appointment since taking office a month ago, the thrift supervision director, T. Timothy Ryan Jr., on Monday named Harris Weinstein as chief counsel. The 54-year-old Mr. Weinstein will be in charge of nearly 200 lawyers and supporting staff members. Since 1971, he has been a partner in the Washington law firm of Covington & Burling, which he joined in 1962.

title: Swiss Consider Joining I.M.F.
description: Switzerland, whose aversion to joining world organizations is legendary, is considering becoming a member of the International Monetary Fund. The Swiss Finance Minister, Otto Stich, said today that the Bern Government would decide this month whether to join the 152-nation world lending agency.

title: Knicks Go From Boston High to Detroit Low
description: The Knicks will be remembered in these playoffs for the three straight victories over the Boston Celtics that made them only the third team to come back from an 0-2 deficit and win a three-of-five game series. They might just as well be remembered for the embarrassing losses that flanked the victory streak.

title: Maybe Just Rageous
description: When 150 Wellesley women announced themselves ''outraged'' about having Barbara Bush do the commencement speech, I suspected something funny was going on.

title: Lotte Jacobi, 93; Photographer Made Portraits of Artists
description: Lotte Jacobi, a fourth-generation photographer who fled Nazi Germany in 1935 and won fame with her sensitive portraits of scientists, statesmen and luminaries in the arts, died of pneumonia on Sunday in the Havenwood Nursing Home in Concord, N.H. She was 93 years old and lived in Deering, N.H.

title: Food Prices Cause Concern
description: A survey of consumers has uncovered what may be a growing unease over the health of the American economy, an industry group said today.

title: IRAQ SAYS IT MADE AN ATOM 'TRIGGER'
description: President Saddam Hussein asserted today that Iraq had acquired a secret American electronic device that could be used to detonate a nuclear bomb and that it was now able to make the detonators itself.

title: Washington at Work;   Mr. Goodwrench Goes to Washington: A House Success Story
description: The New Republic's cover story on Congress last week was entitled ''Capitol Hell.'' An issue of Business Week on the newsstands not long ago declared, ''Congress: It Doesn't Work. Let's Fix It.''

title: A Saving Count
description: To the Editor:

description: Year-ago results are restated and included only the month of March when the company began commercial production. Results are in Canadian dollars.

New Rules for Hazardous Waste Are Completed by Federal Agency
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced the last of its standards for treating hazardous waste that is disposed of in landfills or underground wells.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a sexual assault case in Glen Ridge, N.J., last year involving a retarded teen-ager misstated the use of I.Q. levels in placing children in special education classes in New Jersey. I.Q. is a factor only for students who are classified as mentally retarded.

title: Remembering Food, as Mother Cooked It
description: WHEN it comes to eating, there is perhaps nothing more evocative than memory: the recollection of taste magnified through the prism of time.

title: At Wesleyan, a Day to Reflect on Racial Tension
description: Hundreds of Wesleyan University students gathered this afternoon on the broad campus green to sit and tell stories of hate and fear.

title: 150 Jews Visit a House Where Genocide Was Born
description: Proclaiming that ''memory is stronger than its enemies,'' about 150 representatives of Jews from around the world gathered today at Wannsee Villa, the lakeside mansion where officials of the Third Reich met 48 years ago to outline the policy of Nazi genocide.

title: Coca Mines Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1990 first quarter included a gain on sale of stock in Equity Silver Mines Ltd. of $585,100, compared to a similar gain of $28,300 in the first quarter of 1989.

title: Savings Bailout Agency to Allow Large Cuts in Prices of Real Estate
description: Seeking to speed up the nation's savings and loan bailout, the Government today agreed to permit big markdowns on the $16.4 billion worth of real estate and other properties it has for sale.

title: Angeles Corp.
description: The Angeles Corporation said it expected to report a loss for the third quarter of about $3.9 million after taking a substantial charge related to the withdrawal of a public offering of a real estate limited partnership. The real estate and investment management company said it had cut back on employees who work on direct offerings of real estate to concentrate on raising money from institutional and investment banking sources.

title: Pathe Extends MGM/UA Bid
description: Pathe Communications Inc. extended its tender offer again yesterday for the shares of the MGM/UA Communications Company. Pathe's tender offer was set to expire tomorrow.

title: REPUBLICANS SENSE CHANCE IN HAWAII
description: A race that would test the new political chemistry in the newest state could also offer Republicans their best chance in years to send one of their own to the United States Senate from this Democratic stronghold. This prospect has raised hopes among Republicans nationally for recapturing control of the Senate this year.

title: Restaurant Slump Claims a Victim
description: The luxury American restaurant Metro closed Saturday night, underscoring what many in the New York City restaurant industry say is a continuing, and perhaps, worsening slump.

title: BUSH BUDGET CHIEF SOUNDS THE ALARM ON A RISING DEFICIT
description: Raising the pressure on Congress to negotiate a budget settlement, the White House warned today that without agreement on major reductions in the deficit, the Government would face mandatory cuts of up to $100 billion this fall.

title: 2 Straw Votes for Fama
description: Two of three alternate jurors on the panel hearing the case against Joseph Fama said yesterday that they would have acquitted Mr. Fama of murder.

title: Stephen J. Borell, 66, Piano Tuner, Is Dead
description: Stephen J. Borell, a piano tuner and technician for some of the world's best-known musicians, died of colon cancer on Monday at his daughter's home in Cumberland, R.I. He was 66 years old and lived in Astoria, Queens.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: AN extraordinary number of Americans live in what the Census Bureau rather oddly calls single-person families. Additionally, many people eat alone because they eat at different times than the rest of their families.

title: Survey Cites Problems At Black Companies
description: The nation's largest black-owned companies, hurt by weakness in the economy last year, had virtually flat sales and a sharp decline in employment, according to a survey by Black Enterprise magazine.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: Results reflected 16 weeks ended April 25, 1990 and April 19, 1989.

description: The son of a Washington real estate magnate was accused today of passing confidential information about one of his father's deals to a friend who allegedly traded illegally on the inside information.

description: To the Editor:

title: Flanagan Released
description: Mike Flanagan, who has a 165-136 career record, was released by the Toronto Blue Jays yesterday.

U.S. WILL OPPOSE AID IN OZONE PLAN
description: The Bush Administration has decided to oppose an international plan that would grant $100 million to developing nations to drastically reduce the use of chemicals that are depleting the earth's protective ozone layer, officials said today.

title: Christopher Chodoff, Antiques Dealer, 81
description: Christopher Chodoff, a New York antiques dealer and furniture designer, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Stocks Extend Gains as Dow Rises 11.94
description: Stock prices extended their gains yesterday for the seventh day, with the Dow Jones industrial average spurting 11.94 points, to 2,733.56.

title: Interstate General Co. LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest increased revenues are due to the February 1990 acquisition of American Family Homes and first full quarter of rental income from real estate assets acquired from San Juan Racing Association in December 1989.

description: b-Net loss Latest quarter results included income from discontinued operations of $5,521,000 and an extraordinary credit of $4,876,000 from a tax credit and from the repurchase of subordinated debentures. Latest year results included income from discontinued operations of $37,540,000 and an extraordinary credit of $32,217,000 from gains on the sale of the aluminum business, a tax credit and from the repurchase of subordinated debentures. Year-ago quarter results included income from discontinued operations of $15,248,000 and an extraordinary credit of $1,300,000. Prior year results included income from discontinued operations of $52,754,000 and an extraordinary credit of $11,015,000.

title: American Integrity reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $3,400,000, or 50 cents a share.

title: Rembert Reaches the Jets After an Indirect Route
description: There was nobody at La Guardia Airport to pick up Reggie Rembert and bring him to the Jets' minicamp on Monday, so he took a taxi and wound up becoming a part of the kind of broken pattern he almost never ran as a wide receiver at West Virginia.

title: A Party Platter for Those Who Really, Really Like Garlic
description: I CAN'T think of another dish that lends itself better to a party than grand aioli. It is easy to make, colorful and there are countless variations with vegetables, fish and meat.

title: Navy Ship Fire Kills One and Injures 12
description: A fire broke out in the boiler room of a Navy destroyer today, killing one sailor and injuring 12 others in the worst accident at sea since the Navy briefly halted operations for a fleetwide safety review last November.

title: Rating Cuts For 2 Banks
description: Moody's Investors Service reduced the long-term debt ratings yesterday of the Chemical Banking Corporation of New York, the nation's sixth-largest banking company, and Fleet Norstar Financial Group of Providence, R.I., the 16th-largest banking company.

title: Navy Drops Efforts To Seek Repayment From 2 Gay Students
description: The Department of the Navy has reversed itself and decided not to seek reimbursement of scholarship money from two students who were dismissed from the Reserve Officers Training Corps after informing their commanding officers that they were gay. But the two students will not be allowed to enroll in R.O.T.C. again.

title: Study Finds Little Effect in Limited Use of Drugs
description: Teen-agers who experiment with drugs to a limited degree tend to be better adjusted than those who abstain or use drugs frequently, researchers say.

title: Town & Country Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Central Newspaper Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Nissan Prospers Despite Errors
description: Making mistakes in the United States is nothing new to the Nissan Motor Company. The third-largest Japanese auto maker in the market tried three times unsuccessfully to introduce a mini-van, failed to anticipate changes in American taste and underwent a name change that alienated some dealers and confused consumers.

title: Laser Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $115,421.

title: School Chief in Selma Settles Suit on Ouster
description: Selma's first black School Superintendent, whose ouster led to student boycotts and other community protests, has accepted a settlement of $150,000 to drop his $10 million lawsuit against the school board.

title: Failure Found in Generic Drug for Cystic Fibrosis
description: A generic drug prescribed for cystic fibrosis patients was found to be ineffective and not equivalent to a brand-name compound in a small study. The researchers said the findings showed that the type of drugs involved should be regulated by the Government.

title: XL-Datacomp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a one-time net gain of $4.8 million, or 40 cents a share.

title: Lockheed Expected To Move Aircraft Unit
description: The Lockheed Corporation would move the headquarters of its aeronautics division from Burbank, Calif., to Marietta, Ga., under a plan considered today by its board.
