description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Adtec Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income c-Included accounting change gain of $97,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Thermo Cardiosystems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and share earnings hae been adjusted to reflect a 50-percent stock dividend paid Jan. 15, 1990, and a 25-percent stock dividend paid May 7, 1990.

title: Breslin Is Given 2-Week Suspension
description: The columnist Jimmy Breslin was suspended from New York Newsday last night for two weeks without pay for a ''lack of sensitivity'' in connection with sexual and racial slurs he made about a Korean-American colleague.

title: Top Officer Retiring From Amstar Sugar
description: The Amstar Sugar Corporation, makers of the Domino brand, said yesterday that William C. Shanley is retiring as president and chief executive effective on Oct. 1 and will be succeeded by Jack F. Lay, who is now senior vice president.

title: About New York;   Clara Hale Uses Babies to Scare Drug Abusers
description: American history prompts varied interpretations. For those whose ancestors were worked as slaves for over two centuries only to be relegated to life under less obvious masters, the view can be as unsentimental as Mother Hale's.

title: Dallas Times Herald Loses Its Suit Over Features Deal
description: A jury said today that The Dallas Times Herald was not harmed by the loss last fall of 26 comics and features to its larger rival, The Dallas Morning News, and voted, 10 to 2, to decline a damage award.

title: Berlitz International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said latest share earnings are after preferred dividend requirement of $2.9 million.

title: Visa and Mastercard Cancel Card Venture
description: The two largest credit card companies, Visa and Mastercard, agreed yesterday to stop joint development of a nationwide debit card. The agreement was part of the settlement of a lawsuit filed last year by law enforcement officials in 14 states.

title: Experts on Hill Sift Taxes to See Which to Raise
description: As the White House and Congress lay plans for formal budget negotiations, fiscal experts on Capitol Hill are beginning to examine a long list of possible tax increases, ''user fees'' and tax-loophole closings that could yield $25 billion or more for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, and even larger amounts in future years.

title: Real Estate;   Hotels Given Face Lifts In Manhattan
description: MANHATTAN hotels, from the expensive small boutique lodgings to the larger chain properties and the more down-market inns, are in the midst of a restoration and renovation binge that is reshaping at least 25 properties.

title: Education Vouchers: A 'Win-Win' Plan
description: LEAD: For decades, school vouchers have been touted by conservatives from Milton Friedman to George Bush as the cure for our ailing public schools. They claim that if parents are allowed to choose where to spend their school dollars, vouchers will stimulate the creation of superior alternatives to public schools, too long ossified by their monopoly power.

title: A Galaxy of Fallen Women Conjured Up by a Rising Star
description: Jennifer Jason Leigh was seated in the rotunda of the Pierre Hotel in Manhattan the other day, sipping tea and toying with the smoked salmon on her plate. Elegantly turned out in a maroon silk chiffon dress, her honey-blond hair upswept in a 40's-style wave, the actress was the utter antithesis of the prostitutes, schizophrenics, anorexics and brutalized women she has searingly portrayed in a dozen feature films, plays and television dramas.

title: Yields Are Flat to Higher
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts were generally flat to slightly higher for the week that ended yesterday.

title: BRT Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included provisions for possible losses of $2,500,000 and $3,000,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included a provision for possible losses of $300,000 for the quarter and a gain of $609,000 on the sale of marketable securities for the 6 months.

title: El Al Net Up by 28.7%
description: The state-owned El Al Israel Airlines today reported a net income of $24.2 million for 1989, its fourth consecutive profitable year. The profit marked a 28.7 percent jump from El Al's 1988 net income of $18.8 million. Revenues rose by 7.2 percent, to $713.6 million, from $665.3 million in 1988. El Al said it carried more than 1.7 million passengers last year.

title: Penn Engineering & Mfg.  Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Metromedia-Lin Agreement
description: After weeks of intense negotiations, the Lin Broadcasting Corporation and Metromedia Inc. reached an agreement yesterday on details of Lin's previously announced purchase of Metromedia's stake in the New York City cellular franchise for $1.9 billion.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Grove's Owner Decides Not to Sell Company
description: More than two months after putting the troubled New York publisher Grove Weidenfeld up for auction, its owner, Ann Getty, said yesterday that she would not sell the company.

title: WORKER LEAVE BILL SENT TO THE HOUSE
description: Ignoring the threat of a veto, the House Rules Committee approved legislation today that would require employers to grant workers up to three months of unpaid leave to care for newborn infants or sick relatives without jeopardizing their jobs.

title: Allied, Federated Report '89 Losses
description: The Allied Stores Corporation, a unit of the Campeau Corporation, which is protected from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, had a $925.2 million loss in 1989, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing. Allied sales rose 5.2 percent in 1989, to $2.71 billion, up from $2.57 billion in 1988. Allied said that as of April 25, it had $185 million in cash on hand.

title: JRM Holdings Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,005 and $266,985 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $361,809 for the quarter and $850,319 for the 9 months. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Bush Seems Concerned That Economy May Slip
description: Just when it seemed clear that the economy had once again avoided sliding into recession, thereby further confounding those who still profess belief in business cycles, President Bush appears to have decided that the seven-and-a-half-year expansion is, in fact, at risk.

title: ISRAELIS DEFEND ARMS-SALE ROLE
description: Responding to disclosures that Israeli weapons shipped to a Caribbean island ended up with a Colombian drug trafficker, the Israeli authorities said today that they had followed all procedures meant to prevent such diversions.

title: Trimas Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pinkerton reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
description: The company noted that results for the first quarter of 1990 and 1989 are for Pinkerton as a private company. The company became a public entity on April 4.

title: Mayor to Face Runoff in Atlantic City Vote
description: Mayor James L. Usry, who has been indicted, and City Councilman Jim Whelan were the two top vote-getters in today's nonpartisan mayoral election, setting up a June 12 runoff in this casino city.

title: ATOMIC-UNIT LEAKS CITED IN TENNESSEE
description: Tons of toxic mercury and substantial amounts of the radioactive element cesium have spread from a Government nuclear installation in Oak Ridge, Tenn., and contaminated the sediment of a 39,000-acre reservoir system, a new Government report says.

title: Book Notes
description: Steinbeck Novella

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: A. Plunket Greene, 57, A Fashion Executive
description: Alexander Plunket Greene, a fashion executive who with his wife, Mary Quant, helped revolutionize the British fashion scene in the 1960's, has died, his family said.

title: Legislators Plan Bottle Tax To Help Reduce Budget Gap
description: Legislative leaders have tentatively agreed to place a 2-cent tax on nonrefillable bottles, a move that could raise at least $90 million a year and help close New York State's $4 billion budget gap, legislative officials said today.

title: Colonial Commercial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New 3-Year U.S. Notes Sell Well
description: Driven by a record bid from small investors, the Treasury sold $10.5 billion in three-year notes yesterday, with the yield rising to 8.74 percent, the highest level in a year.

title: Satan Made Me Steal Your Money
description: LEAD: I didn't set out to steal your money. The devil made me do it.

title: U.S.-Kenyan Dispute Grows a Little Testier
description: A Kenyan Cabinet member accused the United States today of supporting the opposition, another step in the dispute between the United States and Kenya over the future of democracy in this nation. The American Ambassador denied the accusation.

title: Beware the Little Girl in Red
description: When it comes to morality there's little to choose between the wolf and Little Red Riding Hood. While the one was guilty of eating up grandma, the other was guilty of bringing the old lady booze. What did you think was in that basket anyway? Diet soda?

title: KEY RATES
Cheney Backs New Nuclear Arms for NATO
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said today that it was essential for NATO to deploy a new generation of tactical nuclear missiles, to be installed on American warplanes in Europe, even though President Bush abandoned plans last week to upgrade short-range nuclear weapons based on West German soil.

title: International Paper Returns Directors
description: The International Paper Company's shareholders re-elected six directors despite calls from a union representative to bring ''new blood'' into the company.

title: Floods Force 325 Arkansas Families to Flee
description: The rain-swollen Arkansas River reached a record level today, forcing about 325 families from their homes.

title: Central Holding Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Home Resale Drop Is 1.6%
description: Ex-isting house sales declined 1.6 percent in the first quarter, a real estate trade group said today, as mortgage rates anchored themselves in double digits and prices in many areas continued to rise.

title: Brooklyn IND Train Kills 2 Signal Workers
description: An IND subway train bound for Coney Island struck and killed two transit workers on an elevated stetch of track in Brooklyn during the evening rush yesterday.

title: A Big Loss For Lomas
description: The Lomas Financial Corporation, a conglomerate operating under bankruptcy protection, said on Monday that it had a loss of $500 million in its fiscal third quarter ended March 31 on revenues of $67.8 million. The huge loss reflected an increase to the company's reserves.

title: Florida East Coast Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Falcon Oil & Gas reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Kollmorgen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $17,079,000, or $1.59 a share, which included a net gain of $18,800,000, or $1.75 a share on sale of Kollmorgen Corp.'s 50 percent interest in the Additive Products Co. joint venture and the graphics part of its PCK Technology division. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $824,000, or 8 cents a share.

title: Chronicle
description: Archbishop EUGENE A. MARINO, the highest ranking black in the nation's Roman Catholic hierarchy, has temporarily relinquished his duties as the head of the archdiocese of Atlanta after physicians found him at risk of a heart attack, a spokesman said yesterday.

title: De Klerk Begins Major Tour of West Europe
description: Following up on the success of his talks with the African National Congress last week, President F. W. de Klerk left today on a nine-nation tour of Western Europe that the Government hopes will win new sympathy, and patience, for his vision of evolutionary change in South Africa from apartheid.

title: Yanks Are No Match When They Play A's
description: They tried, but in the end the Yankees could not fully explain how things happened. Bucky Dent shook his head and lamented lost opportunities. Greg Cadaret blamed himself for continually falling behind in the count. Roberto Kelly said he simply forgot to take his sunglasses with him to the outfield.

title: Time Warner's Chief Resigns
description: Time Warner Inc. said yesterday that J. Richard Munro, the company's co-chairman and chief executive, will step down from his posts today.

title: In a Switch, Bush Offers to Stop Producing Chemical Weapons
description: In a policy switch, President Bush has offered to end the production of chemical weapons if the Soviet Union agrees to American proposals, including one to bring about deep cuts in the two nations' poison gas supplies, Administration officials say.

title: Caviar: Black Gold In America
description: IT was at the exclusive Broadmoor Hotel in Colorado Springs that Frank Hale had his first taste of caviar. The year was 1964 and he was working as a busboy. He was standing in the kitchen when the chef came over with a cracker. ''I spit it out,'' recalled Mr. Hale, the 50-year-old son of a Baptist minister, unashamed to say in his Southern twang that he could not understand why anyone would pay through the nose for fish eggs.

title: Adirondacks Report Upsets Residents
description: After holding hearings from Long Island to Buffalo, the Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century released a final report today in Albany, where the fate of its proposals for preserving the area's wilderness will largely be determined.

title: Senators to Seek Vote On Bush Futures Plan
description: The two senior members of the Senate Agriculture Committee said today that they would push for a floor vote on the Bush Administration's plan to transfer jurisdiction over stock-index futures to the Securities and Exchange Commission from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

title: Ex-Stock Exchange Head to Run for House
description: James J. Needham, a former chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that he will challenge Representative George Hochbrueckner in Suffolk County.

title: Andal Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the decline in revenues in the latest quarter and 6 months resulted from the divestiture in July 1989 of 75 percent of Andal's ownership in its business of trading and distributing flat rolled steel and tin mill products.

title: Century Telephone Enterp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $354,000, or 1 cent a share, on the sale of a portion of an investment.

title: Pirates Enhance Power With the Unpredictable
description: Baseball, especially winning baseball, like politics, makes strange bedfellows. Sid Bream and Wally Backman provide a vivid example.

title: Texas Oil's Sales
description: The USX Corporation said its Texas Oil and Gas Corporation unit had agreed to sell oil and gas properties and related assets for $193 million to ARCO Oil and Gas Company, a unit of the Atlantic Richfield Company, and the Sonat Exploration Company. USX said talks were continuing with bidders on other oil and gas assets.

title: A Warm Thatcher but a Cool Press for Quayle
description: Vice President Dan Quayle, in the middle of a European tour celebrating an American President (Dwight D. Eisenhower, not George Bush), got a warm reception today from Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, but a roasting from some of the British press.

title: Artistic Head At Kennedy Center Quits
description: Marta Casals Istomin, the artistic director of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts for 10 years, resigned today, citing philosophical differences with the institution's nes chairman, James D. Wolfensohn.

title: Garan Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Voyages to Knowledge in Space Age
description: With knitted brows, 12-year-old Mario Bernardi wrestled a robotic arm. After minutes of playing with its control buttons, he manipulated the machine to lift a saltshaker-shaped container, move it to a scale and weigh it.

title: Summer Squall Out Of Belmont
description: Summer Squall, who finished second in the Kentucky Derby last Saturday and will run in the Preakness Stakes on May 19, will not be entered in the Belmont Stakes on June 9, his owners announced yesterday.

title: Dekalb Energy Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $12,045,000, or $1.15 a share for the latest quarter and $6,911,000, or 66 cents a share for the year-earlier period. The company said the improved results were due to higher energy prices, and included a one-time $8.1 million benefit from the settlement of a natural gas take-or-pay dispute, and an after-tax, primarily non-cash gain of $11.3 million from the divestiture of its remaining agricultural leasing portfolio and $800,000 of leasing net income from operations.

title: Pope, in Mexico, Preaches Harmony
description: Pope John Paul II ventured into the conservative heartland of Mexican Roman Catholicism today, bringing a message of reconciliation to a region that still harbors deep resentments over a religious war fought here 60 years ago.

title: State Senate Expels Jenkins After Conviction in Bank Plot ALBANY, May 8 (AP) -
description: Jenkins, Democrat of Queens, who was convicted on Federal felony charges in a money-laundering plot, has been expelled from the State Senate, officials said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acclaim Entertainment Inc., Oyster Bay, L.I., a home entertainment products company, promoted Anthony R. Williams to vice president of finance and chief financial officer.

title: New York's Top Court Allows Random Drug Tests of Guards
description: New York State's highest court today for the first time upheld random drug testing for a broad group of public employees, ruling that jail guards in New York City could be subject to chance testing.

title: Market Developed For Farmer Mac
description: Four financial service companies agreed in principle to develop a primary and secondary market for guaranteed securities backed by eligible rural housing and electrical loans issued by the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation, or Farmer Mac.

title: INSIDE
description: The Diaries of Oliver North

title: Suns and Their Coach Stun Lakers on Road
description: The Phoenix Suns and Coach Cotton Fitzsimmons exorcised some personal demons with a startling 104-102 comeback victory over the Los Angeles Lakers tonight at the Forum.

title: Nabors Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: This year's first quarter results included a partial contribution from Loffland Brothers, which was acquired in late February.

title: Engines for U.P.S. From Rolls-Royce
description: Rolls-Royce P.L.C. said it would supply Tay 650 aircraft engines for the entire United Parcel Service Inc. fleet of Boeing 727-100 planes in a deal that could be worth more than $600 million. Including options, the deal covers as many as 80 aircraft and up to 280 engines, Rolls-Royce said.

title: Aubagne Journal;   Are Glory Days at an End for the Foreign Legion?
description: Marching to the slow rhythm of their regimental song, their white kepis glistening almost boastfully in the sun, the legionnaires lined up before a monument proclaiming Honor and Loyalty to commemorate a moment of heroism and sacrifice more than a century ago.

title: Thermo Process Sytems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Covington Development reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Y&A Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: An article on the Business Technology page on May 2 about color facsimile machines misidentified an industry analyst at Dataquest. She is Ruth A. Gardner.

title: Conservatives Win in Croatia
description: A conservative nationalist party has as expected taken a large parliamentary majority in the final round of the first free multiparty elections in the Yugoslav republic of Croatia in more than 50 years.

title: Edmonton Wins to Tie Series, 2-2
description: Mark Messier, the captain of the Edmonton Oilers, took stick slashes to the legs and elbow smashes to the face from the Chicago Blackhawks tonight in the fourth game of the Campbell Conference finals.

title: German Coalition Leaders Split on Soviet Proposal for Unification
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today rejected the notion suggested by Moscow that the Germans could accept unification before all the implications for other countries are worked out.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13

title: Chronicle
description: NORA DUNN of ''Saturday Night Live'' is refusing to perform on this weekend's show because the guest host will be ANDREW DICE CLAY and she considers his comedy act degrading and repulsive.

title: American Consumer Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bridge
description: After an opening day full of problems, the Omar Sharif World Individual, with a record-breaking prize fund of $200,000, seemed to be on an even keel this afternoon at the Showboat Hotel Casino.

title: S.E. Nichols Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 3
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from gain on early extinguishment of debt of $1,545,000, or 33 cents a share, and $2,351,000, or 50 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively; and also included a loss from discontinued operations of $496,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $4,675,000, or 99 cents a share, for the year. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $501,000, or 10 cents a share, and $1,949,000, or 41 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Latest year results included $27 million charge in the fourth quarter and $30,800,000 reserve in the year for store closure costs and restructuring costs. Periods for 1989 were reclassified to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Arch Moore Pleads Guilty
description: Former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. today fulfilled an agreement with Federal prosecutors by pleading guilty to an indictment charging extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and obstruction of justice. Mr. Moore, a 67-year-old Republican, struck the plea bargain with the Government last month. He faces imprisonment of up to 36 years and fines of as much as $1.2 million when he is sentenced July 10.

title: Seizing 2 Buildings, Students Protest a CUNY Budget Plan
description: City University of New York students took over administration buildings, marched through Queens and Manhattan and held rallies at four campuses yesterday to protest a proposal before the State Legislature to cut the university's budget.

title: Sales Below Estimate at a 2d Auction
description: Willem de Kooning's ''Palisade,'' an abstract parkway landscape from 1957 in bold, colorful strokes, was sold for $7.2 million at Sotheby's in New York last night. The price was the highest paid in an auction at which the selectivity of the market became clear. Although 10 records for the works of artists were rewritten, several major paintings did not sell, and others brought prices at or below their estimates.

title: Medco Containment reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said results for the latest nine months included a loss of $42,882,000, or 82 cents a share, from the writedown of securities.

title: Review/Piano;   A Recitalist to Undermine a Critic
description: About halfway through Mordecai Shehori's piano recital on Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall, it occurred to me that I was enjoying myself much too much. Part of a reviewer's duty is to pay unwavering attention to the mechanical details that form the base of any proficient performance. That, however, proved difficult to do because the techniques of playing the instrument were continually being upstaged by the music itself. The musician, whose medium just happened to be the piano, consistently got under the skin of the score and cut toward the expressive bone. Result: pure, guilty pleasure. At piano recitals especially, that happens infrequently enough to deserve mention.

title: Mead Data Trying to Stay No. 1
description: In the last decade, the Mead Corporation moved swiftly and surely into the top rank of the multibillion-dollar electronic information business. But it is finding that staying there is getting tougher all the time.

title: New Support For Arpino In Dispute At Joffrey
description: Statements in support of Gerald Arpino, the former artistic director and resident choreographer of the embattled Joffrey Ballet, were issued yesterday by board members of the Los Angeles and San Francisco Friends of the Joffrey Ballet.

title: Racial Harassment Altering Blacks' Choices on Colleges
description: Recent cases of racial harassment on the nation's campuses and a general atmosphere of racial tension have become increasingly important factors in the decisions made by many black families about where to send their children to college, according to high school counselors and black students and their families.

title: Dynascan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company attributed the loss in the latest quarter to soft retail demand and increased competition, especially in the telecommunication productes segment.

title: Capitals Can't Find Much Reason to Hope
description: Dino Ciccarelli stood inside the locker room speaking into a bunch of microphones and Coach Terry Murray stood outside it talking into another set of tape recorders, together creating what sounded a lot like a resignation in stereo.

title: The Pop Life
description: For Michael Jackson

title: FIGHT AGAINST AIDS LAGS IN ROMANIA
description: Hampered by a shortage of equipment and a sluggish bureaucracy, the Romanian Government has been able to make only halting strides in its fight against AIDS, which has hit hardest here among infants.

title: Workers Disrupt Pan Am Meeting
description: More than 150 union employees, angry over continuing losses at the Pan Am Corporation and the lack of a contract, jeered at the airline company's annual meeting and threatened to strike. Pan Am's 6,500 union reservation agents, cargo agents and clerical workers have worked without a contract for two years.

title: Lin Broadcasting reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included non-recurring charges of $292.9 million which are principally attributable to Lin's obligations arising from the completion of McCaw Cellular Communication Inc.'s tender offer for 21.9 million shares of Lin's stock. c-Net income

title: Video Jukebox Network reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pryor Gets License
description: Aaron Pryor, twice denied boxing licenses because of cataracts in his left eye, has been granted permission to fight in Wisconsin.

title: HMO America Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect accounting change.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: I HAVE always been fond of pork tenderloin, an exceptionally versatile cut. Tenderloin is the tenderest cut of any meat because it comes from muscle that gets very little exercise, in contrast to, say, the leg or shoulder.

title: Cardinal O Fiaich; Irish Primate, 66, Dies on Pilgrimage
description: Tomas Cardinal O Fiaich, the Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland, died today in France while on a pilgrimage, news organizations quoted his nephew as reporting. He was was 66 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   NBC Planning Nostalgia Show
description: NBC News Productions is scheduled to announce today that it will produce a weekly series based on Memories, a nostalgia magazine published by Diamandis Communications.

title: I.N.S. Agent Accused of Selling Green Cards to Drug Dealers
description: An Immigration and Naturalization Service employee was charged yesterday with taking more than $100,000 in bribes in return for helping to provide Colombian drug smugglers with cards identifying them as permanent residents, the authorities said.

title: Albania Says It Now Wants A Role in European Security
description: Albania announced today that it wanted to join the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, a further move away from its policy of isolation.

title: Carl Channell, 44, Fund-Raiser For Conservatives, Dies of Injuries
description: Carl R. (Spitz) Channell, a fund-raiser for conservative political causes who pleaded guilty to criminal charges stemming from the Iran-contra affair, died Monday of complications from injuries he suffered in a traffic accident two months ago. He was 44 years old.

title: Pistons Don't Want Any Knick to Score
description: There was nothing magical about the way the Detroit Pistons made the Knicks' offense disappear tonight.

title: Handy & Harman reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Power Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $3,474,000 and $4,153,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively, which reflects the company's share of charges for Great-West Life Assurance Co. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/Dance;   Ballet Theater Celebrates Its Anniversary (Again)
description: In case the word isn't out, American Ballet Theater is celebrating its 50th anniversary this year, and on Monday night it officially opened an eight-week golden-jubilee season at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Bush's Second Chance on China
description: June 3 marks the first anniversary of the massacre of innocents in the streets of Beijing.

title: I.M.F. PANEL VOTES TO ADD $60 BILLION TO POOL FOR LOANS
description: After three years of contentious negotiations, rich and poor countries agreed today on a 50 percent increase in the resources of the International Monetary Fund, giving it the money to speed market-oriented economic policies in Eastern Europe and help third world countries cut their debt burden.

title: Toshiba Shows Faster Laptop
description: The Toshiba Corporation today introduced the first laptop computer built with Sun Microsystems Inc.'s Sparc microprocessor. The Toshiba Sparc LT, AS1000/L10 weighs 17.7 pounds and is priced in Japan at the equivalent of about $13,200. The company plans to start shipping the computer in Japan in mid-July. United States marketing plans have not been announced.

title: Snarl in Processing Pap Tests Angers Caucus
description: Angered by the failure of the Department of Health to process 2,000 Pap smear tests, the women's caucus of the City Council demanded a promise from the Dinkins administration yesterday that programs for women would not face budget cuts.

title: And Now, From Israel, Comes Fool's Gold
description: CAVIAR, an extravagance that can cost more than $60 an ounce, could soon be nearly as cheap as a cheeseburger. And it could be kosher, as well.

title: High Salaries At Columbia
description: Columbia Savings and Loan Association's top executives received $4 million in bonuses in 1989, even as the association's holdings of high-yield ''junk bonds'' led to a $591.1 million loss for the year.

title: Expeditors International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Market Place;   'Junk Bond' Hopes Amid the Dangers
description: WITH representatives of the state regulatory agencies meeting in Washington tomorrow to recommend restrictions on ''junk bond'' investments by insurance companies, many investors in this battered market are worried about another selloff.

title: Robert Brookhart, 53; Assistant to Archivist
description: Robert Brookhart, assistant to the Archivist of the United States, died of an embolism Monday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington, where he was under treatment for lung cancer. He was 53 years old and lived in Washington.

title: In Lexington, Ky., the Bands Play On
description: LEAD: Fortunes have been lost. Reputations sullied. But in this, the capital of thoroughbred horse country, there has yet to be a scandal black enough to deflate the partying that surrounds the Kentucky Derby.

title: Savings Bond Sales Up
description: Sales of United States savings bonds rose 11 percent in April over the month last year, increasing the total value of bonds held by Americans to a record $120.49 billion, the Treasury Department reported today. The Treasury said sales last month totaled $703 million, up from $634 million sold in April 1989. Savings bonds currently earn interest at a rate of 7.01 percent when held five years or longer.

title: Review/Theater;   Kevin Kline Plays His 2d Hamlet In 4 Years, This Time Directing
description: When Kevin Kline is at center stage in a Shakespeare production, New York audiences can for once relax, secure in the knowledge that they will be seeing a classical actor of exceptional gifts and the highest integrity. Mr. Kline does not cruise through the classics to pump up his vanity and earn public-relations brownie points. Is there another star in this country - one whose services are in high demand in New York and Hollywood - who would undertake ''Hamlet'' twice in four years, as he has now done at the Public Theater?

title: Grandiose Central Terminal
description: ''Grand Central Prepares for the 21st Century,'' reads the headline on a Metro-North news release about its plan to renovate the great landmark. The commuter railroad proposes to restore the terminal esthetically and structurally, and add an array of retail stores. But delve past the exciting prospectus and it's clear that Metro-North knows more about what it wants to do than how to do it.

title: Books of The Times;   The Knowing Stories of Ward Just
description: Twenty-One

title: Miami's Seikaly Voted Most Improved Player
description: The National Basketball Association's Most Improved Player says he'll continue to get better.

title: 2d Jury Gets Case in Bensonhurst Killing
description: Keith Mondello, who was dressed in black and white, heard himself described as two very different people yesterday, the day the murder case against him went to the jury.

title: Good Health Habits Can Reduce Risks Of Hazards in Food
description: WASHING fresh food before it is cooked or eaten was ingrained in the over-40 generations by parents who never picked up a baby bottle from the floor and stuck it back in the baby's mouth; who washed the outside of milk and cream bottles when they came from the milk truck, and who always transferred leftover food from a can before storing it.

title: After 3-Year Losing Battle, Weltman Quits Nets
description: Harry Weltman resigned yesterday as the senior vice president and general manager of the New Jersey Nets after a three-season battle to rebuild the team into a respectable National Basketball Association franchise.

title: EUROPEANS WEIGH FUND TO AID EAST
description: The 12 European Community nations are discussing a plan to help Eastern Europe break away from barter-based trading and start trading in convertible currencies as Western countries do, European officials say.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Teen-Agers to Put Out Sassy's December Issue
description: If the December issue of Sassy looks a bit ragged in spots, do not blame the editors. They will have had very little to do with it. Sassy, continuing its reputation for trailblazing, plans to publish what it calls the ''first-ever reader-produced issue of a consumer magazine.''

title: Racketeering Charge Against Judge Dropped
description: The Justice Department has decided not to try a Federal district judge for the second time on a charge of racketeering brought under an act intended to fight organized crime. But it will bring the judge, Robert P. Aguilar, to trial again on five other charges.

title: Celtics Drop Rodgers as Coach After 2 Years
description: Jimmy Rodgers, who coached the once-mighty Boston Celtics through two lackluster seasons and two first-round eliminations in post-season play, including Sunday's upset victory by the Knicks in Boston Garden, was dismissed as the team's head coach yesterday.

title: 92d St. Y, Running a Deficit, Delays Year of Schubertiade
description: After a decade of growth, the 92d Street Y - the adventurous educational and cultural center on Lexington Avenue - is trimming its programs in an effort to reduce a projected 1991 deficit of $1.5 million.

title: Onex Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings were before the effect of a stock dividend. The company said the decline in earnings was due to non-operating charges this year compared to gains in 1989, and lower earnings from its Norex leasing and Sky Chefs subsidiaries. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: For This Project, Subway Cars Are the Stuff of Dreams
description: For George Applebaum, the most frustrating part of riding the subways is not being able to get on a train during rush hour because the doorway is blocked by passengers.

title: Futures Case Jury Selection
description: Jury selection began today in United States District Court for the trial of three traders of Swiss franc futures on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange who are accused of swindling customers. The traders - Robert D. Mosky, Danny L. Scheck and David Zatz - represent one of four groups of 47 Chicago futures traders who were indicted last year.

title: Appalachian Play Tops Hayes Awards
description: Round House Theater won four awards for its production of ''Heathen Valley,'' an Appalachian drama by Romulus Linney, at the sixth annual Helen Hayes Awards ceremony honoring outstanding achievement in the Washington theater.

title: Concern Sold by Warsaw
description: Dozens of people gathered today outside the headquarters of a leading Polish foreign trade company to buy shares of the biggest state-owned concern being sold by the Government.

title: Senate Ethics Panel Votes To Investigate Durenberger
description: The Senate Ethics Committee voted today to conduct a full investigation of Senator Dave Durenberger's handling of a Minneapolis condominium apartment, asserting there was strong evidence that the Senator ''may have abused his United States Senate Office and misused United States Senate funds.''

title: To Save Fish, Judge Curbs Lowering of Lake
description: In a dispute centering on the longtime drought afflicting the upper Great Plains, a Federal district judge today ordered the Army Corps of Engineers to bow to the wishes of three states and limit releases of water from a major Missouri River reservoir until June 1 in order to protect fishing.

title: Argentina to Get Aid and Begin Debt Talks
description: Setting the stage for the next major step in the Bush Administration's push to reduce third world debt, Argentina will get approval of renewed assistance from the International Monetary Fund and begin negotations on debt reduction with its commercial banks by the end of the month, Argentine and I.M.F. officials said here today.

title: WALESA SETS OUT ON 'POLITICAL WAR'
description: Lech Walesa, the leader of the Solidarity trade union, declared today that Poland's revolution has stagnated and pledged to foment ''permanent political war'' that would shake the Government he helped create last year.

title: Brazil Job Cuts Planned
description: Irritated by the slow pace of his austerity program, President Fernando Collor de Mello of Brazil called today for the number of Government employees to be cut by up to 400,000.

title: Alphonse and Gaston
description: George Bush could use the charming manner and glib tongue of Ronald Reagan, now that the President is trying to get out of the tax corner he painted himself into in 1988.

title: See Rickey Run. See Rickey Walk. See Yanks Lose.
description: The place was nearly empty when Rickey Henderson walked across the outfield grass and disappeared into the fading afternoon. He was showered and changed and heading for his car, but he looked back just long enough to wave toward someone and perhaps take one more look at home plate.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about a news conference protesting remarks by the columnist Jimmy Breslin misstated the circumstances under which an editor left New York Newsday in 1987. The editor, John Cotter, left after he was reported to have made racial remarks about a black Newsday editor; Mr. Cotter has denied making the remarks.

title: Events: Tours of Homes, Gardens and Brooklyn
description: Uptown Six, United Cerebral Palsy of New York City, 105 Madison Avenue; 212-683-6700.

description: The company said net income is computed after special payments on preferred stock conversions totaling $306,000.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * EMC Corp., Hopkinton, Mass., a manufacturer of computer products, named Harold P. Ano senior vice president for marketing. He replaces David L. Guy, who was named senior vice president in charge of contracts with distributors and marketers.

description: Year-ago share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split payable on May 31, 1990. The company said that specialty store revenues increased 16 percent in the first quarter and general merchandise revenues rose 5.4 percent. Domestic revenues rose 9.7 percent and foreign revenues, expressed in U.S. dollars, increased 10 percent.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,142,214 which consisted of a writedown of $1,174,000 and a gain of $31,786. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $1,785,607 which consisted of a writedown and charge of $1,968,607 and a gain of $183,000. title: It's Brutal. It's Ruthless. It's Flea-Market Season.
description: THEY were ''at home'' with the flu, colds and let-us-not-forget migraines. But there they were at the crack of dawn on a sunny Thursday in Manhattan, 40 adults who never felt better, loaded on a bus headed for Pennsylvania on a pilgrimage aptly named Antiques Mania.

title: A Guide To Markets
description: HERE is a sampling of some of the better antiques and flea markets around the United States.

title: BORDER SCREENING AGAINST CRIMINALS IS SEEN AS FLAWED
description: The computerized information system used by customs agents to screen visitors to the United States is so flawed that major drug traffickers and other criminals may be able to enter the country without detection, Federal investigators have concluded.

title: National-Standard Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $45,000. The company did not provide figures for earnings before extraordinary item and the amount of the extraordinary item in the 6-month results.

title: Toro to Close Plant
description: The Toro Company said this week that it planned to close its Lawn-Boy plant in Plymouth, Wis., and shift Lawn-Boy riding products and space heater manufacturing operations to an existing Lawn-Boy plant in Sardis, Miss. Toro said it also planned to stop producing snow throwers and tillers as part of the move. These products are made in Plymouth.

title: M/I Schottenstein Homes reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
At Rally, Jackson Assails Harvard Law School
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said today that the ''moral character'' of Harvard Law School was on trial in the current dispute over the school's failure to appoint a black woman to its tenured faculty.

title: Atmos Energy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bobrik Still Leads In Tour
description: Raul Alcala of Mexico, who had become the co-favorite in the Tour de Trump bicycle race, made a big move this morning toward the overall lead. But he missed an opportunity in the afternoon, and Vyacheslav Bobrik, a 19-year-old Soviet amateur, was the overall leader for the fifth consecutive day in America's most important cycling event.

title: Don Appell, 73, Actor And Playwright, Dies
description: Don Appell, a playwright, director and actor, died of heart failure and pneumonia on Friday at the Allen Pavilion at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 73 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Endre Bohem, Producer, 89
description: Endre Bohem, a film and television producer, died on Saturday at his home here. He was 89 years old.

The average cash cost of production was $247 an ounce, down from $332.

These are primarily related to the company's Swiss Franc denominated bonds. The loss for the quarter is also attributable to lower copper prices and lower copper production at the EL Indio Mine in Chile.

title: 80 Homes Are Destroyed by Wildfires in Michigan
description: A number of fires in Michigan's parched Lower Peninsula destroyed at least 80 homes and blackened more than 16 square miles before being brought under control late Tuesday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Politicians Seek Sign from California In Vote on Doubling of Gasoline Tax
description: Californians will decide next month whether to double the gasoline tax and lift the lid on state spending to finance transportation improvements, a vote being awaited in Washington as a bellwether of national sentiment about tax increases.

title: The Pearl's Back-Door Induction
description: In sports, a Hall of Fame is more than a gallery of bronze busts or plaques. Of all the subjects in sports, a Hall of Fame is the most subjective. Whether an elector or a fan, everybody has different standards as to who should be in, who should not, and why. Since it is so subjective, one person's standards are as valid as anyone else's. That's why so many people take a Hall of Fame so seriously. If not personally. Would you vote for Pete Rose in 1992? Does John Mackey deserve to be in Canton? Why did it take Earl Monroe so long? But with the approach of the Basketball Hall of Fame induction ceremonies on Tuesday, the subject is not the standards by which Earl (the Pearl) Monroe, Dave Bing and Elvin Hayes should be judged for membership. It's the standards by which they were shamefully selected on an odious back-door play in order to assure Springfield, Mass., of celebrants for its three-day enshrinement festival.

title: VSB Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings for the year-ago 6 months are not applicable; VSB was not a public company for the entire period.

title: Time Unit and 7 Days in Deal
description: Entertainment Weekly, the magazine begun in February by the Time Inc. Magazine Company, has purchased the name and subscription list of 7 Days, which ceased publication on April 16.

title: Moore Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tension, and Attention, Outside Brooklyn Court
description: There was the big square labyrinth of blue police barricades, with dozens of uniformed officers watching and waiting. There were hundreds of demonstrators beneath a banner renaming a shady park ''Yusuf Square.''

title: The Tax-Rise Question;   Bush Rationale for Cutting Deficit Queried, But Economists See Need for Budget Deal
description: Congress may be prepared to buy the White House's rationale for putting a tax increase on the negotiating table now. But few independent analysts accept the Administration's peculiar argument that rising unemployment makes the case for a quick budget fix more compelling than it was a few months or a few years ago.

title: West's 'Monster Game' Pulls Suns Ahead
description: It was not as though Mark West had dropped unannounced out of the sky and into the Great Western Forum on Tuesday night.

title: Waiting in Texas: Will Floods Take Everything?
description: Benny DeWitt rounded up his cows on Tuesday and moved them to higher ground. Already there were six inches of water covering what used to be the road outside his house, and he knew that soon the muddy waves would probably cover his land and come through his front door.

title: U.S. Scores 3 Goals to Beat Poland
description: Not more than a few hundred yards from where Wilt Chamberlain once scored 100 points in a basketball game, the United States national soccer team exploded in similar manner tonight, defeating Poland, 3-1.

title: Enno Poersch, 45, AIDS Group Co-Founder
description: Enno Poersch, a co-founder of the Gay Men's Health Crisis, died of AIDS on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 45 years old. Mr. Poersch, a graduate of Yale, was a set designer for the stage and films and had also worked as a graphic designer.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Soldiers Honored at a Time of Few Heroes
description: The traditional parade of missiles and troops through Red Square today honoring the Allied victory in World War II had a hollow ring, particularly for those it was meant to honor.

title: On Judging a Nation by Its Playgrounds;   Aggressive Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Opera;   Even With Magic, Unlucky in Love
description: Writing opera on a large scale is a labor-intensive, thankless task these days, not least because the outlets for such endeavors are few. One way for a composer to circumvent that hurdle is to strike up an alliance with a conservatory that has an opera-performance department.

title: Darling and Ojeda Squirming in Limbo
description: Ron Darling sat in the dugout last night even though he probably should have been in the bullpen. Davey Johnson had told him to be ready as a reliever. Bob Ojeda started even though he became a resident of the bullpen before the season began. Johnson told him six starters was too many and one had to go. Then Johnson started him last night.

title: Mid-South Insurance Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Change in Social Security for Women Is Urged
description: The Older Women's League called on Congress yesterday to give some form of Social Security credit to women who stay home to care for children or disabled family members.

title: Recording Industry Shows Its New Warning Label
description: The recording industry today showed its new uniform, voluntary warning label to go on recordings that have explicit lyrics.

title: Connecticut Assembly Approves 14-Day Delay for Gun Purchases
description: The General Assembly today narrowly approved a bill that would require a 14-day ''cooling off'' period between the initiation of most gun transactions and the final delivery of the weapon.

title: IRT Property reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the first quarter 1989 figures included a gain of $924,573, or 7 cents a share, from the sale of properties.

title: Bill to Relax Political Ban Withstands Test
description: The Senate has voted to allow agents of the I.R.S., the C.I.A. and the F.B.I. to participate in political campaigns, rejecting a Republican attempt to maintain a ban established by the 51-year-old Hatch Act.

title: Fokker Sees Big Profits This Year
description: The Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V., which was saved from bankruptcy less than three years ago, said its profits could double this year after trebling in 1989. Last month, the company said its 1989 net profits rose threefold, to 42.4 million guilders, or about $23 million.

title: Test-Tube Tigers Born in Zoo
description: Zoo officials today announced the birth of tigers conceived by in-vitro fertilization and said the process could help preserve the endangered tiger population as well as other species.

title: Profit Up 42.1% At SmithKline
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the merged health, household products and pharmaceuticals company, said today that its first-quarter profit jumped 42.1 percent because of the sale of some businesses.

title: Bonilla Sparks a Rally As Pirates Beat Reds
description: Bobby Bonilla's run-scoring double touched off a four-run sixth inning for Pittsburgh tonight as the Pirates beat the Cincinnati Reds, 6-2, in a meeting of division leaders.

title: Hartco Enterprises reports earnings for Year to Jan 27
description: Share earnings reflect a 4-for-3 stock split in July 1989. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: British Inquiry On Car Prices
description: Britain today ordered an investigation into why Britons pay more for their cars than motorists in most other European countries.

description: International A3-13

title: U.S. to Press Japan Goals
description: The United States will continue to press Japan to open its semiconductor markets to American and foreign competition, the assistant United States trade representative, Donald Phillips, said today.

description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $15.5 million on sale of a German reinsurance subsidiary. Pre-tax capital gains were $26.6 million versus $6.6 million.

title: Guilty Plea On Kickback
description: An electronics distributor pleaded guilty on Tuesday to paying $113,000 in kickbacks to a senior buyer at Norden Systems Inc.

title: New York City Council Takes Hesitant Steps to New Powers
description: Four months after inheriting greatly expanded powers, the New York City Council is struggling to use them. But its new muscle-flexing has often been stymied by its own members, many of whom are mired in the sloppy, sleepy style of the past.

title: Concern About Inventories Causes Energy Price Surge
description: Energy futures prices surged yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange amid concerns that gasoline and crude oil inventories would be tight in the near term.

title: Kodak Tells Holders To Expect Better Year
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest maker of photographic products, said today that it expected an improved financial picture for the year after posting a 62 percent drop in profits last year.

title: U.S. Is Assailed at Geneva Talks For Backing Out of Ozone Plan
description: A White House decision to oppose financial aid for developing countries to phase out chemicals that are destroying the Earth's ozone layer was sharply criticized today at an international meeting in Geneva.

description: Executives at the nation's hospitals are struggling to overturn new Federal regulations that make it easier for unions to try to organize the three million nonunion workers at community hospitals.

description: b-Net income The company said it has sold its 25- percent interest in Bos Stockbroking Ltd. in Australia and will soon complete the sale of 28.5 percent of Disnat Investment. Figures are in Canadian funds.

description: The Treasury sold $10.5 billion worth of new 10-year notes yesterday, but interest rates had to move higher to accomplish the task.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I allowed myself to be taken in by the intellectuals. I believed too much in the Polish intellectuals and followed their advice. They misled me. That's why I know now I will have to stand up against it and propose this concept fo permanent political war.''

title: BBDO Gets A President In New York
description: AFTER nearly two years without a top executive to supervise account management, BBDO New York yesterday named Thomas H. Carey, a 23-year veteran of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, as its new president and chief operating officer.

description: LADY BIRD JOHNSON traveled from the LBJ Ranch in Stonewall, Tex., to Austin on Friday to attend a 25th anniversary celebration of President Johnson's inauguration. Amid the speeches, Austin Mayor LEE COOKE announced his intention to have Town Lake renamed Lady Bird Lake.

title: Metro Matters;   Malcolm X Plan: Picking a Shrine Or Self-Reliance
description: Past a padlocked stairway and beneath the rubble, it is said that blood still stains floorboards on the wooden stage of a decrepit building in upper Manhattan, and that bullet holes in the black plaster walls bear further witness to a murder.

title: New York Needs More Officers, But Lacks Money, Brown Says
description: New York City Police Commissioner Lee P. Brown said yesterday that it would take ''a lot more'' police officers to provide the kind of street patrols needed to make New Yorkers feel safe. But he did not hold out much hope of getting them in the face of the city's budget crisis.

title: Winnie Mandela Named in Beatings
description: Winnie Mandela, the apartheid foe and wife of the African National Congress leader, Nelson Mandela, has been accused by witnesses at the murder trial here of a former bodyguard of initiating the beating and torture of three youths at her home in Soweto.

title: Study Finds Untallied TV Viewers
description: A study conducted by the A. C. Nielsen Company on television viewing outside the home has revealed hundreds of thousands of previously unrecorded viewers who could be worth hundreds of millions of dollars to the networks, an ABC executive said yesterday.

title: Review/Theater;   Dragons and Other Intruders of the Mind
description: If only all of ''Dragon's Nest'' had been like its best bits and pieces. There were real touches of imagination in the multi-media work that Lee Nagrin presented last Thursday night at La Mama. But between the bits and pieces came long dull stretches.

title: More Immigration Can Cut the Deficit
description: LEAD: Congressional leaders and President Bush continue to agonize over ways to trim the Federal deficit. But its most important underlying social causes - demographic changes - would show them a promising direction.

title: Pope Challenges Rich Nations to Start Sharing
description: Pope John Paul II warned today that Communism's collapse did not mean capitalism had triumphed, and he challenged industrialized countries and big business to stop ''hoarding'' and start distributing wealth fairly.

title: Health Chief Is Criticized On AIDS Shift
description: After barely a month in office, New York City's new Health Commissioner has upset some of his prime supporters as well as critics by abolishing an AIDS-prevention program for drug abusers, who are now the main source of AIDS cases.

title: Shuttle Launching Delayed by Faulty Valve
description: A breakdown in Columbia's cooling system has forced NASA to delay next week's scheduled launching of the shuttle by two to three weeks, the space agency said today.

title: Lou Rawls to Perform In a Benefit at the Apollo
description: Lou Rawls, Joe Williams and the Mount Zion Baptist Church Gospel Choir are to be among those taking part in a benefit concert in honor of Sarah Vaughan at 7:30 tonight at the Apollo Theater, 253 West 125th Street. Miss Vaughan died of lung cancer on April 3 at the age of 66.

description: The United States and Iran announced today that they had reached a tentative agreement to settle some 2,500 small financial disputes growing out of their break in relations after the Iranian revolution in 1979.

title: Currents;   Decorative Arts: The A B C's
description: THE second edition of ''The Penguin Dictionary of Decorative Arts'' weighs more than four pounds, has nearly 5,000 entries (600 of them new) and more than 1,000 illustrations, and is a delight to read.

title: Author Updates Ovid Impertinently

Despite the fact that the chapter is an account of an imaginary speech by the Roman poet Ovid to the Emperor Augustus, its meaning was all too clear to Romanian officials.

Revenues for the most recent quarter were $104.3 million, up from $94 million in the period in 1989.

title: Corrections

Calling on Israel to release hostages, the Senator said they were being held in violation of international law, but he did not ask for the move as a good-will gesture to Iran.

description: Frank Bernarducci Sr., a retired advertising executive, died of cancer on Monday at the Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 65 years old and lived in Rego Park, Queens.

title: Using Satellites To Navigate Cars
description: A new car navigation system that uses satellites to plot a vehicle's location and displays it to the driver on a computer map will go on sale next month in Japan, the Pioneer Electronic Corporation said. The device is the first such system available on the retail market, said Toru Yokomizo, a Pioneer spokesman.

title: Next's Machine With Fast Chip
description: Next Inc. said today that it would offer a version of its computer based on Motorola Inc.'s 68040 microprocessor later this year.

title: Central Reserve Life reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Venezuela Loan Fight
description: Conditions attached to loans from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are depriving third world nations of the ''freedom of action to order our economic policy priorities,'' Venezuelan Foreign Affairs Minister Reinaldo Figueredo said today at a meeting of the United Nations' Economic Commission for Latin America and the Carribean. Venezuela, which received an extended credit facility from the I.M.F. last year to help it adjust its economy, is currently negotiating a series of loans with the World Bank.

title: Mexico Plan on Oil Exports
description: Mexico is considering a reduction in oil exports to take care of domestic industrial needs, the Government said in a five-year energy plan that was released last week.

title: Involuntary Bankruptcy For Drexel Trading Division
description: The commodities trading subsidiary of Drexel Burnham Lambert Group Inc. was placed into involuntary bankruptcy yesterday, signaling a growing animosity between Drexel and its creditors.

description: Private developers and real estate experts yesterday praised the Government's decision to cut the price of billions of dollars' worth of real estate being sold through the Resolution Trust Corporation, but they cautioned that the discounts might not increase the number of potential buyers.

title: F.C.C. Backs Bill for 7 Bells
description: The Federal Communications Commission endorsed a bill today that would ease restrictions preventing the seven regional Bell telephone companies from manufacturing communications equipment.

title: Experimental AIDS Drug Has Mixed Results
description: Two small-scale studies have found that an experimental AIDS drug, DDI, showed preliminary signs of effectiveness but caused serious side effects.

title: Apple Computer Software Delay
description: Apple Computer Inc. said it had delayed until the end of the year shipment of its new system 7.0 software for its Macintosh computers, which had been expected to be shipped this summer. The company disclosed the delay in materials that featured highlights of its annual conference for Macintosh developers being held this week. An Apple spokeswoman said the company was conducting more tests on the new software to insure its high quality.

description: b-Included net of $2,900,000 related to certain commitment fees and interest received less a related settlement paid by the company. Share earnings are in units.

description: IF elegant dining on Western food calls for sterling silver knives and forks, an elaborate Chinese banquet may require sterling chopsticks.

description: Bay Meadows is a race track near San Francisco with a long and glorious history, a less exalted present and great hopes for future real estate profits. It is also the scene of one of the nastiest proxy fights of this or any other season.
