title: Jessica James, Actress, 60
description: Jessica James, an actress, died of breast cancer on Monday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 60 years old.

title: A Singer Wins Frito-Lay Suit
description: Frito-Lay Inc. must pay the singer Tom Waits almost $2.5 million for imitating his gravelly style in a radio commercial for corn chips, a Federal court jury decided on Tuesday.

title: Accounts
description: * Nestle to the J. Walter Thompson Co. for confectionery sales in Europe, with a budget of $15 million.

title: Xtra Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $3,500,000. c-Net income and included a gain from discontinued operations of $180,000, or 3 cents a share, and $318,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Latest quarter results included an aftertax writedown of certain revenue equipment of $4,780,000 and a charge of $5,686,000 related to a proxy contest earlier this year. In connection with the $4,780,000 revenue equipment writedown recorded in the second quarter, it intends to remove about 3,000 excess piggyback trailers from its intermodal fleet and said other cost containment programs are being formulated and will be implemented shortly.

title: Money-Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for tax-exempts and unchanged for taxables for the week ended yesterday.

title: New Data on Sugar and Child Behavior
description: Yale University medical researchers have found hormonal evidence to support the popular but controversial belief that sugar can provoke abnormal behavior in some children.

title: Columbia Gas System reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
David E. Shoch, Ophthalmologist, 71
description: Dr. David E. Shoch, an ophthalmologist and educator, died of cancer on Tuesday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago. He was 71 years old and lived in Glencoe, Ill.

title: Stahl Spurns Offer By Apple Bancorp
description: Stanley Stahl, the New York developer who is seeking to acquire Apple Bancorp Inc. for $140 million, refused an offer to be allowed to review the savings bank's confidential financial information if he agreed not to bid for the institution for two years. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Stahl said that the conditions were unacceptable.

title: Henry Willets Underhill, Engineer, 77
description: Henry Willets Underhill, a civil engineer and a landowner on Long Island, died of cancer Tuesday at Winthrop-University Hospital in Mineola, L.I. He was 77 years old and lived in Jericho, L.I.

title: Ernst & Young Selects Health-Care Consultant
description: Joseph W. Duva, who gained attention for his work to cut the corporate cost of health care at the Allied-Signal Corporation, is widening his arena, as a benefits consultant for Ernst & Young.

title: Arden Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from early extinguishment of debt of $16,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: New York City Bond Rating Dropped Over State Impasse
description: Moody's Investors Service, one of the nation's two major credit-rating services, yesterday lowered its rating on $1.25 billion of notes issued by New York City and on $900 million of notes the city plans to sell today.

title: Canadian Occidental PetroFleum Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Brands Inc., Old Greenwich, Conn., said its shareholders defeated a proposal that would require the company to stop producing and marketing tobacco products by the year 2000.

title: WIDE PERIL IS SEEN IN PASSIVE SMOKING
description: After the first major Government study of the risks of secondhand cigarette smoke, the Environmental Protection Agency has tentatively concluded that it causes 3,000 or more lung-cancer deaths annually and a substantial number of respiratory illnesses and deaths among the children of smokers, Federal officials said today.

title: Cuomo Plan: Protect Jobs, Raise Taxes
description: New York's state government, which is struggling to close a $4 billion budget gap, employs more workers in relation to its population than any of the other nine largest states. But this year, as in most years, the budget will almost certainly not be balanced by laying off employees.

title: I.B.M.-Prentiss Venture
description: The NCNB Corporation has lent more than $100 million to the International Business Machines Corporation and Prentiss Properties to build offices in Austin. The agreement provides financing for a 1.1-million-square-foot office complex to be occupied by I.B.M. Prentiss Properties is the developer and Austin Industries is expected to be named the contractor.

title: Philip M. Neufeld, 84, A Financial Executive
description: Philip M. Neufeld, second vice president and financial consultant with Shearson Lehman Hutton, died of congestive heart failure on Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Growth Seen in British Debt
description: The British are sinking deeper into debt to pay for affluent life styles, the National Consumer Council said today.

title: Home Improvement
description: METAL porch railings need proper care to preserve their appearance and sturdiness. Many newer railings are made of aluminum, which needs little maintenance. But steel and wrought-iron railings are prone to rust and require close attention.

title: Chance for a Woman
description: Rick Pitino, the Kentucky coach, says he is seriously considering having a woman as a graduate assistant or volunteer coach for the 1990-91 basketball season.

title: Emons Holdings Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Hamilton Oil Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
WMS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Included an accounting adjustment loss of $2,611,000, an expense incurred on early extinguishment of debt. Results for 1990 periods included unrealized loss of $7,023,000 relating to the writeoff of the company's investment in the common stock of Divi Hotels N.V.

title: Frustration Is Growing For Angels and Royals
description: John Schuerholz suspects that it began in spring training, and he blames himself for it. ''I threw away a chain letter,'' the Kansas City Royals' general manager confessed. ''It said something about bad luck.'' Mike Port, the California Angels' general manager, offered no simple explanation or simple way out of his team's plight. ''Nobody has extended to us the opportunity to start over,'' he said, ''so we have to deal with it.''

title: Christian Bay, 69, A Political Scientist Who Studied Peace
description: Christian Bay, a retired professor of political science at the University of Toronto, died Sunday of pneumonia at Toronto Western Hospital, a colleague said yesterday. Professor Bay was 69 years old and lived in Toronto.

title: On Taxes: Rereading Their Lips
description: June 24, 1988 ''There is a difference as plain as day between us. Tax cuts versus tax hikes. And I am not going to raise taxes, period.'' - George Bush, discussing differences between him and Gov. Michael S. Dukakis. Later in the news conference Mr. Bush was asked it was ruling out all types of new or additional taxes, including excise taxes. ''Yes,'' he said. ''Yes, I ruled them all out.'' He added that the only exception would be user fees, items like the admission price to national parks or a surcharge on boat licenses.

title: Power Corp. of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $2,404,000 for the latest quarter and an extraordinary credit of $330,764,000, or $2.61 a share, for the year-ago quarter, mainly from a gain on the sale of the interest in Consolidted-Bathurst Inc. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Artopex International Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Israel Is Bolstered and Its Foes Are Weakened by Change Sweeping Europe
description: In a region where one side's gain is taken gleefully as the other's pain, Israel has emerged as the beneficiary of changing times in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, while the Arab world confronts the losses.

title: CHRONICLE
description: MAYA YING LIN, who designed the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington when she was a student at Yale, has been commissioned to design a sculpture to celebrate new generations of women on that campus, culminating a yearlong observance of the 20th anniversary of the admission of women to Yale.

title: New York's Granddaddy Of Open-Air Selling
description: IT was 8:20 last Sunday morning in Manhattan, and 23,000-odd marathon cyclists were whizzing past 25th Street and the Avenue of the Americas. Only a few people noticed. At that time of day and in that particular place, most of the others out and about were bent over 250 tables laden with tchotchkes, or sifting through boxes at the Annex Antiques Fair and Flea Market.

title: Computers and Other Targets;   How Japan Learns, and Wins, Even by Losing
description: Japan's Fifth Generation Computer project, now in its ninth year, has met so few of its vaunted goals that Japanese officials are now plotting another course toward achieving superiority in advanced computers. Observers who scoff at industrial policy can cite this as another failure of government attempts to pick winning technologies. Yet the opposite lesson is correct.

title: Technology Official Quits At Pentagon
description: The director of the Defense Department program that monitors the advanced technologies of America's foremost economic competitors has resigned, saying he has become frustrated by the Bush Administration's refusal to support plans to assist the nation's high-technology industries.

title: Special Goal For Nicklaus
description: The Memorial Tournament this week may not be one of golf's four major championships, but among golf's top players, it is at the very least a significant.

title: Review/Music;   'The Beggar's Opera,' An 18th-Century Satire
description: The Ten Ten Players, a flexible company that has been resident at the Park Avenue Christian Church (1010 Park Avenue, at 85th Street) since 1955, presents everything from classic theater to contemporary satire, with occasional forays into musicals and light opera. Its current production, ''The Beggar's Opera,'' mixes several of those genres.

title: The Window Washers
description: At a party in Prague, the new dean of the journalism school at Charles University presents his calling card and leans forward to translate the two words under his name.

title: Revenue Properties reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Vote by Boy, 12, Kills Bill in Florida House
description: The 12-year-old son of a state legislator unintentionally cast a vote last week that killed a House bill.

title: Pamrapo Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings for year-ago quarter are not available. The company began trading Nov. 14, 1989. Previously, the company had been a mutual savings and loan.

title: Baldwin Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'Change in the Heir' to Close
description: ''A Change in the Heir,'' a musical comedy by George H. Gorham and Dan Sticco, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Edison Theater, 240 West 47th Street. Directed by David H. Bell, the play will have run for 23 previews and 17 regular performances.

title: Navy Investigation of Iowa Explosion Was Thorough and Sound
description: To the Editor:

title: Staining Spool Furniture: the Right Turn
description: LEAD: Successful staining means uniform overall color. This is easier said than done, especially on old furniture that has been stripped, leaving he wood dried out and, perhaps, a little lifeless.

title: Aquanautics Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Campeau Units Get Extension
description: Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation today obtained a four-month extension in which to file their reorganization plan to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: U.S. Talks to Banks About Easing Poland's Debt
description: The Bush Administration told Congress today that it opposed writing off American Government debt in Eastern Europe, but raised the possibility that commercial banks could forgive a portion of their debts and provide Poland with additional loans through special provisions of the Brady debt reduction plan.

title: Careercom Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: G.O.P.'s New Hope to Unseat Bradley
description: One of the least desired pursuits in the Garden State is running against Senator Bill Bradley, the Democrat who many voters hope will be the first New Jerseyan in the White House since Woodrow Wilson. Enter Christine Todd Whitman.

title: Porta Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SPORTS PEOPLE: COLLEGE BASKETBALL
description: LEAD: Terrell Jackson, a former player on athletic scholarship at Drake, has filed a lawsuit against the college charging that Drake did not provide him with an adequate education because it failed to give him sufficient academic counseling and tutoring to earn a degree.

title: 10 John Jay Students Arrested During Protest
description: Ten students at the John Jay College of Criminal Justice in Manhattan were arrested yesterday during a protest over proposed budget cuts.

title: 95 Abortion Protesters Are Freed
description: After being held for 11 weeks in a Vermont jail for failing to identify themselves after being arrested, 95 protesters against abortion did so and were released today.

title: Behind Thai Boom: The Japanese
description: Asia is replete with economic miracle stories, so it is little surprise that Thailand has joined the list as having one of the world's fastest-growing economies. As evidence, the number of cars have tripled, choking traffic, and cement is in short supply as prosperous-looking houses and industrial parks rise almost at once.

title: Finevest Foods reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it did not recognize any federal tax benefits in the latest quarter. It said these will be available to offset future taxable income.

title: Another Student Faces Indictment In St. John's Case
description: At least one more St. John's University student was indicted yesterday in a case in which three students have been charged with sexually assaulting another student in an off-campus house, law-enforcement officials said.

title: Talking Deals;   The Slowdown In Bank Mergers
description: WHEN the Bank of New York acquired the Irving Bank Corporation in 1988, the combination was hailed as an example of the wave of bank mergers that would create a new generation of larger, more profitable banks.

title: CPT Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $4,684,000 for both the quarter and 9 months. c-Included an extraordinary charge of $8,141,000 for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: Westinghouse Contract
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said on Tuesday that it had signed a $10.8 million contract to equip the Warsaw airport with an air traffic control system featuring the most advanced technology. The contract, to be completed in 15 months, is the biggest by a United States company in Poland since the Solidarity-led Government took over last September, the company said. The contract includes an approach-control radar called ASR-9 that is being installed at many of the busiest airports in the United States.

title: Fight at Seton Hall
description: A fight among members of Seton Hall University's basketball team last week, in a dormitory that houses many of the players, resulted in a broken jaw for Joe Remimbas, a senior guard, and an investigation that may take several weeks.

title: Park Electrochemical reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Included one-time gain of $792,000, or 15 cents a share, from accounting change.

title: Mistrial Ruled in Windshield Wiper Case
description: A Federal judge declared a mistrial today when a jury was unable to agree on damages that the Ford Motor Company should pay an inventor for infringing his patents for a widely used windshield wiper system.

title: Reed and Hawks Talk; No Offer Reported
description: Willis Reed, the Net vice president, spent four hours yesterday being interviewed in Atlanta by Hawks officials regarding Atlanta's vacant head-coaching job.

title: Judge Asks Cuomo to Act in Westchester Case
description: A judge asked Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today to appoint a special prosecutor to investigate ''numerous significant irregularities'' by the Westchester County District Attorney in presenting allegations of conflict of interest about a County Legislator to a grand jury.

title: A Phone in Your Pocket? Tryout Set for New Service
description: The Federal Communications Commission has granted a cellular telephone company experimental licenses for a new type of telephone network that will greatly expand the number of callers who can use cellular service simultaneously.

title: Worthy Fulbrights Deserve More Funding
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution in Europe;   Thatcher Urges Lithuanian To Compromise With Soviets
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today urged moderation and compromise on the visiting Prime Minister of Lithuania, the Baltic republic that proclaimed independence from the Soviet Union two months ago.

title: Volkswagen Profit Up 5.5%
description: Volkswagen A.G., West Germany's largest auto maker, reported today that its first-quarter profit rose 5.5 percent from the results in the period last year.

title: Keating Assails His Critics In Lincoln Savings Failure
description: His lawyers have told him to stop talking, since he is the target of a host of lawsuits stemming from the failure of his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association. But Charles H. Keating Jr. has decided to keep talking, even in front of some of his harshest critics.

title: Neely Scores 2 Goals To Give Bruins Sweep
description: The goal that ended the game amounted to a slam dunk - a technically perfect, kind of breathtakingly bang-bang play - and it amounted to a wonderfully apt image for the conclusion of the Wales Conference final.

title: Tseng Labs reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Self-Effacing William Acquavella, Who Struck Art's Biggest Deal
description: The record $143 million deal made by Sotheby's and the Acquavella Gallery to buy the contents of the Pierre Matisse Gallery puts an unaccustomed spotlight on William Acquavella, a power in the art world who until now has skillfully managed to escape the clutches of celebrity.

title: National Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Strategies and Alibis;   For the Republicans and Democrats Alike, The Issue Is Not so Much Taxes as Blame
description: The game of ploy and counterploy has begun, and for the Democrats and the Republicans alike the goal is to dodge the onus of increasing taxes.

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Roz H. James, Restaurateur, 60
description: Roz H. James, former co-owner of La Famille, a Harlem restaurant founded in 1958 by her husband, Benjamin R. James, and Willette Crane Murray, died of leukemia on May 3 at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan and San Francisco.

title: California Opens Up New Offensive on Fruit Flies
description: The discovery of more Mediterranean fruit flies in the Los Angeles area has led agriculture officials to step up aerial spraying of pesticide and has renewed public debate over the state's strategy for fighting the flies.

title: Mattel Declares 3/-a-Share Payout
description: Mattel Inc. said its board had declared a quarterly dividend of 3 cents a share. It will be the company's first dividend since June 1983. The toy maker, based in Hawthorne, Calif., faced several years of large losses and operating difficulties but has returned to profitability.

title: Hal M. Adams Jr., 42, Interior Designer, Dies
description: Hal M. Adams Jr., head of Hal Adams Inc., a Manhattan interior design business, died on Sunday at Doctor's Hospital. He was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Nasturtiums, An Old Friend
description: IT IS impossible to visit the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here now without thinking about what is missing since the night of March 19, when thieves disguised as policemen removed three Rembrandts, a Vermeer and several other works of art that were of incalculable value to the museum's collection. But on my first visit to the Gardner not long ago, thoughts of the art theft, as sickening as the topic is, were quickly banished by the garden in the central courtyard of the building, which Mrs. Gardner built between 1899 and 1903 and occupied until her death in 1924.

title: Breslin Suspension Called a Victory for Minority Journalists
description: Jimmy Breslin's two-week suspension from Newsday and New York Newsday is being viewed as an important, high-profile victory over newsroom racism and sexism by leaders of minority journalist organizations.

title: Chairs That Sit Well With Active People
description: LEAD: CAN'T find a comfortable seat at the beach, park or Little League game? Bring your own. A variety of lightweight, portable chairs fold, roll and fit into beach bags, backpacks or their own storage bags. And a few are handy enough to use when waiting in long lines.

title: Why Girls Are Prone to Depression
description: Girls as young as 12 are more prone to depression than boys, new studies show, and a prime factor is their preoccupation with their appearance.

title: Salvador Rebels Make New Peace Offer
description: In what could emerge as a framework for an end to the fighting here, the Salvadoran rebels have offered to end resupply operations and accept international verification of compliance in return for an end to United States military aid to the Government.

title: Forest Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included non-recurring merger- related costs from Forest's acquisition of UAD Laboratories.

description: Revenues represent gross billlings.

description: To The Home Section:

title: Dean Is Indicted On Sex Charges In Abuse of Girl
description: The dean of students at a junior high school in Washington Heights has been indicted on charges of sexually abusing a 13-year-old seventh grader, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday.

title: Family Feud Jolts Caviar Company
description: A family dispute over some very high-class roe is rocking the world's largest distributor of Russian caviar.

title: On Judging a Nation by Its Playgrounds;   Not Genetic
description: To the Editor:

description: The company said that its 16 acquisitions over the last 12 months accounted for about a third of the quarterly revenue gain.

title: Knicks Are Tough Film Critics After Seeing Themselves
description: The Knicks watched an X-rated basketball movie this morning at their hotel. It starred them at their offensive worst and might well have been entitled, ''What They Did in Boston Was Banned in Detroit.''

title: Pull Up a Chair and Pass the Handcuffs
description: THE northwest corner of the Fashion Institute of Technology has never been so busy. From morning to night, people stop and stare through the windows at ''Flat Tops,'' four table-top designs by five designers.

St. Joe Paper reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are adjusted to give effect to a 350-for-1 stock split effected March 22, 1990.

description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $315,000, or 5 cents a share. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $316,000, or 4 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Furniture as Fine Sculpture
description: THE work of three well-known artists whose medium is furniture is on view through May 26 at the Franklin Parrasch gallery, 584 Broadway, at Prince Street. The exhibit, ''American Furniture: Circa 1990,'' focuses on recent work by Garry Knox Bennett, John Cederquist and Thomas Hucker.

title: Molson Cos.  reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $11,215,000, or 34 cents a share. The company said the brewing segment increased its profit to $129.1 million from $96.4 million. It said both Diversey Corp. and Beaver Lumber had higher operating profit in the latest quarter. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Albany, Concerned for Businesses, Re-examines Plans for Sales Taxes
description: Under pressure from service industries, lawmakers are looking for alternatives to the sales taxes on services that they had agreed to earlier.

title: Perception Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $450,000 charge for a potentialliability and writedown related to a leasing contract. c-Net income and included a tax credit of $100,000 and $35,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: U.S. Opens Case Against 3 Futures Traders
description: In its opening argument today before a packed Federal courtroom here, the Government laid out details of its case against three futures traders charged with routinely defrauding customers. The trial is the first stemming from the extensive undercover inquiry of trading fraud in Chicago's futures markets.

title: NORTH'S NOTEBOOK IS PLAYED DOWN
description: Bush Administration officials said today that the Aug. 6, 1986, meeting between Col. Oliver L. North and Vice President Bush that was disclosed on Tuesday centered on the arms sales to Iran and efforts to secure the release of American hostages in Lebanon.

title: Joffrey Board Tries to Decide the Fate of Its Troupe
description: The board of the troubled Joffrey Ballet spoke by telephone hookup yesterday in New York and Los Angeles to try to decide on the direction of the company. The meeting came after four days of lengthy negotiations between representatives of the Joffrey and Gerald Arpino, the former artistic director and resident choreographer of the company.

title: Evolution in Europe;   NATO Splits on Removing Nuclear Artillery From West Germany
description: West German and Dutch officials said today that NATO should move quickly to withdraw nuclear-tipped artillery shells from German soil. But the United States resisted any immediate decision, saying the question must be studied thoroughly.

title: Primark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain on disposal of $493,000, or 3 cents a share, and a loss from discontinued operations of $1,654,000. Year-ago quarter results included a one-time pension gain of $934,000.

title: Unisys Official Quits o Join Hypres as Chief
description: Hollis L. Caswell, president of the Unisys Computer Systems Group, has resigned and was named chairman and chief executive of a small company called Hypres Inc., which is seeking to develop commercial products using superconducting technology.

title: Walter J. Muller, 96, School Football Coach
description: Walter J. (Wally) Muller, who coached football at Boys High School in Brooklyn from 1923 to 1958, died of congestive heart failure on Monday at Imperial Point Medical Center in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Mr. Muller made his home in Pompano Beach, Fla., for the last 27 years. He was 96 years old.

title: Air Midwest reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $104,000, or 3 cents a share. c-Net loss The company said latest year's first quarter net included net gain on sales of assets, primarily four aircraft of $2,074,000. Excluding these gains, the first quarter loss would have been comparable to last year's first quarter loss.

title: Books of The Times;   Finding China's Future in Its Past
description: The Search for Modern China

title: Stocks Recover From Selloff; Dow Off 0.68
description: Stocks rebounded late yesterday after a strong selloff, but still failed to manage a gain for the day. The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.68 point at the close, to 2,732.88, thus breaking a string of seven gains in a row.

title: Bats in the House
description: To The Home Section:

title: John W. Hanson, 73, Industrial-Oil Importer
description: John W. Hanson, a businessman who imported industrial oils, died of lymphoma on Tuesday at his home in Huntington, L.I. He was 73 years old.

IGI Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Board Proposes Rent Increases At Lower Level
description: New York City's Rent Guidelines Board last night proposed increases of 3 percent and 5 percent on one- and two-year lease renewals for rent-stabilized apartments.

title: Bridge
description: The final of the Omar Sharif World Individual began here this afternoon, with 44 players from nine countries in the hunt for the first prize of $40,000. Among the 84 players who failed to make the cut was the movie star hostLeading qualifying section A was Eliakim Shoufel of Israel, with 95 imps. Maurice Friedman of Little Neck, Queens, led section B with 96 imps.

title: New Commission Plan From DDB Needham
description: In a bold, if expected, bid to change the conventional way advertising agencies do business, DDB Needham Worldwide disclosed a plan yesterday to tie its compensation to the performance of its clients' products.

title: Review/Dance;   Whimsical Works by an Optimistic Troupe
description: ''I'm so optimistic.'' That's the significance of the mysterious acronym in the name of the ISO Dance Theater, which bounded through a gala performance Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater. It is easy to be optimistic about ISO; its shows are goofy fun. But the apparently casual silliness derives from great theatrical shrewdness.

title: Western Corporate reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the widened loss was primarily attributable to the glass container business, which experienced increased operational costs.

title: Nu-West Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Study Set on Future of the Concorde
description: The British and French aircraft makers that built the Concorde formally announced today a two-to-three-year study on the feasibility of building a successor to the supersonic airliner. The plane that is envisioned would fly much farther, carry at least twice as many passengers and offer ''normal fares,'' including economy prices.

title: Review/Music;   A Harp Commands The Spotlight
description: Last Thursday evening, at the same time the Van Cliburn Piano Competition was showing off last year's winner in Carnegie Hall, the International Harp Contest in Israel presented its most recent winner, Isabelle Moretti of France, in Alice Tully Hall. While the former event more effectively captured the public's imagination, the latter may have been at least as rewarding musically, and this despite the harp's more limited repertory.

title: On Judging a Nation by Its Playgrounds;   Bad Science
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Review/Theater;   Musical From a Virginia Woolf Novel
description: Virginia Woolf wrote the last pages of ''The Waves'' with ''such intensity and intoxication'' as to remind her of the times she was overcome by madness. With its torrential language and metaphorical interludes, the novel completely reflects the author's obsessive self-concern. Chronicling the interlocked relationships of six friends in Edwardian England, it is, to borrow the words of one of the characters, ''a mysterious illumination'' of life unto death.

title: N.C.A.A. Panel Urges Looser Rules on Eligibility and Pro Drafts
description: A National Collegiate Athletic Association committee has recommended that underclassmen who make themselves eligible for professional drafts be allowed to resume their college careers if they change their minds about becoming professionals, whether or not they have been drafted.

title: Florida Paper's Demise
description: The Clearwater Sun ended publication last Friday after 76 years in business. ''We were unable to make an effective business,'' Bruce E. Coury, publisher of Clearwater Newspapers Inc., said in a statement. Last summer, the newspaper, which was owned by the Hearst Corporation, switched from daily publication to a tabloid-size weekly focusing exclusively on news in Clearwater. The city, on the central Gulf Coast, is also covered by two large dailies nearby: The St. Petersburg Times and The Tampa Tribune.

title: Cambodia: Don't Look Away
description: With each passing day of political stalemate, the human toll in Cambodia escalates. After surviving mass murder and slave labor under Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge, Cambodians both within the country and in encampments along the Thai border continue to suffer in silence.

title: I.B.M. to Transfer Some Operations
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would consolidate its typewriter business by moving certain operations to Kentucky, in a streamlining step that would not involve layoffs. The company, based in Armonk, N.Y., said it would consolidate the business by transferring sales and marketing operations to Lexington, Ky., where the typewriters are manufactured.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Three balloonists say they will attempt to be the first to circumnavigate the earth in a balloon.

title: For Serious Couples, Serious Stores
description: HERMAN ROTENBERG'S business card says his company carries ''1,873 Unusual Wedding Bands,'' but in fact he hasn't done an accurate count lately. The slogan is also the name of his company, which is at Booth 86 at the National Jewelers Exchange on West 47th Street.

title: Parental Leave: Leave It at That
description: In the face of a threatened veto by President Bush, the House is expected to vote today on legislation that would require employers to grant workers up to three months of unpaid leave to care for newborn or adopted babies or seriously ill members of the nuclear family.

title: Insituform Gulf South reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company cited the increase in competition in the underground pipe reconstruction industry, especially with the company's primary customers, as the principal reason for the decrease in earnings. Instituform Gulf said that revenues resulting from projects utilizing the Instituform process decreased to $998,000 in the current year's third quarter from $2,526,000 for the last year's third quarter.

title: Old Error Stalls Focusing of Space Telescope
description: An error made years ago in planning has set back efforts to focus the Hubble Space Telescope and delayed by at least another week an attempt to take the first picture of the heavens with the $1.5 billion instrument.

title: Legg Mason Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Burmese Party Is Prevented From Election Campaigning
description: Burmese military leaders have disrupted opposition campaigning for this month's multiparty elections by arresting officials of the major party, diplomats there said today.

title: Enterra Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Personal Health
description: If you are a woman near or beyond menopause, you may have heard a lot about the risk of osteoporosis and heart disease, and about the possible link between estrogen replacement therapy and cancer.

title: Liposome Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Men Arrested in Kidnap And Rape of an L.I. Woman
description: Two men were arrested yesterday and charged with kidnapping an 18-year-old Long Island woman from a shopping mall on Monday night and repeatedly raping her, the Nassau County police said.

title: California Judge Offers Plan On Profit Rates of Insurers
description: An administrative law judge here has recommended that insurance companies be allowed rates of profit that some Californians believe could overturn the insurance revolution that the state's voters started in 1988.

title: Close to Home
description: WHAT I did was this: Left the house in the early morning, took a bus up Eighth Avenue to 40th Street, debarked, entered Port Authority, hung a left past the orange juice stand and pulled $23 for a ticket on New Jersey Transit off my roll. This big spender was going to Atlantic City.

title: Grant Cooper, Lawyer Who Led Defense of Sirhan, Is Dead at 87
description: Grant B. Cooper, a criminal lawyer whose clients included Sirhan B. Sirhan, the assassin of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, died of an aortic aneurysm last Thursday at the Hospital of the Good Samaritan in Los Angeles. He was 87 years old.

title: A Retrospective Of 'Telephone Hour'
description: A retrospective of radio and television programs presented on ''The Telephone Hour'' from 1940 to 1968 is under way at the Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street.

title: Thomas Nervous but Well
description: Before every playoff game, Isiah Thomas is nervous. His stomach is jittery. His heart is pounding. Thomas compares it with the feeling a college student gets before a final exam. But through the years, Thomas has learned to make that nervousness work for him.

title: INSIDE
description: Wider Inquiry on Senator

title: Drive to Save Dolphins Jolts American Tuna Fleet
description: The tuna boat Venturous was a few hundred miles off Acapulco with a million-dollar load of 900 tons of fish in her hold when a radio message arrived to cut short the voyage and return to port.

title: Currents;   Curtains Dull and Gray? Slap On a Little Paint
description: PAINTINGS by famous artists like Willem de Kooning are often reproduced on posters and postcards. Seldom are they found on curtains in private homes. But in Hattie Thrasher's apartment in Manhattan, a painting by Mr. de Kooning inspired a design on her curtains.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Texas Man Is Found Guilty In Poisoning of Historic Tree
description: A jury today found a man guilty in the poisoning of the Treaty Oak, a centuries-old tree that was severely damaged by a powerful herbicide.

title: Man Held in Death of Son, 2
description: A Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with killing his 2-year-old son, the police said. The police said the father, Daniel Singleton, 24, of 180 Brook Avenue in the Mott Haven section, beat his son, Daniel Jr., to death on Tuesday morning. The boy's mother, Josephine St. John, 26, took him to Lincoln Hospital, where she claimed that he had injured himself the day before in a fall, the police said. But a medical examiner's report said the boy died of a fractured skull and arm, fractured ribs and a lacerated liver. Ms. St. John has not been charged.

title: East Europe Trade Pacts
description: The European Community signed accords on Tuesday with East Germany and Bulgaria, virtually completing the first stage of an effort to improve trade and economic links across a once-divided continent.

title: VWR Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $269,000 for the latest period, and the year-ago period included a gain from discontinued operations of $459,000, or 8 cents a share. All results have been restated. The company changed to a cvalendar year in 1989 from a fiscal year ending Feb. 28. Effective March 1, VWR Spun-off its non-laboratory distribution business into a new public company, Momentum Distribution Inc. Results of the new company for January and February are presented as companies distributed in the first quarter statements.

title: Unican Security Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: No Verdict On Bensonhurst
description: Both juries in the Bensonhurst murder case completed full days of deliberations yesterday without reaching verdicts.

title: Luxembourg NATO Envoy Quits
description: Luxembourg's envoy to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has resigned after he committed a minor security infraction, Foreign Minister Jacques Poos told Parliament today.

title: Cenvill Investors reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Swift Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Parent & Child
description: PERHAPS more than any other sign of adulthood, the marriage of a child redefines the relationship between the generations. Psychologists and others who study families say these changes are often predictable and usually start when the couple announces its engagement.

title: Stake Is Raised In Ultimate Corp.
description: Norman Elowitz, the chief executive of Honey Fashions Ltd., raised his stake in the Ultimate Corporation to 7.2 percent, from 6.27 percent, and said he was contemplating whether to make another bid for the computer system concern, based in East Hanover, N.J. Last year, Mr. Elowitz offered to acquire Ultimate for $10 a share, or $94.9 million. But Ultimate's board decided in February not to sell.

title: S.I.'s Relief Called Brooklyn's Headache
description: In 1986, Staten Island got a break when the eastbound toll of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge was removed to speed traffic to Brooklyn and reduce air pollution. To the delight of Staten Islanders, the change has worked as intended.

title: Tootsie Rolls Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Patrick Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Arch Moore Pleads Guilty
description: Former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr. fulfilled an agreement with Federal prosecutors on Tuesday by pleading guilty to an indictment charging extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and obstruction of justice. Mr. Moore, a 67-year-old Republican, struck the plea bargain with the Government last month. He faces imprisonment of up to 36 years and fines of as much as $1.2 million when he is sentenced July 10.

title: South Pacific Trade Pact
description: New Zealand and Australia said this week that they would achieve free trade starting July 1 -five years ahead of schedule.

title:
DESIGN NOTEBOOK;

Tour the Future: Talk to a Student
description: LEAD: EVERY spring at semester's end, a rite takes place in architecture schools across the nation. After spending three months agonizing over models and drawings of architectural projects, students present them to a jury of architects and academics. The jury's comments, questions and criticisms are often rough.

title: Currents;   Get Milk; Sharpen Pencils
description: LORRAINE SHIRKUS, a product designer and painter, imagined what a napkin might look like if an architect began doodling after being stood up at lunch. ''Faux Lunch,'' a cotton place mat and complementary napkin, is the result.

title: Economic-Political Unrest Erupts In Violent Protests in South Korea
description: In the largest anti-Government demonstrations in nearly three years, thousands of students marched through the streets of Seoul and other major cities to protest the apparent consolidation of power by a new political party controlled by President Roh Tae Woo.

title: Yukon Energy reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: A 50 Percent Solution for El Salvador
description: Senior House Democrats are proposing an ingenious and sensible plan for ending El Salvador's bitter civil war. They would condition U.S. military aid on the actions of the Salvadoran Government and its guerrilla opponents.

title: Alba-Waldensian Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHRONICLE
description: One Washington landmark that former President RICHARD M. NIXON never visits is the Watergate, the residential-office complex that gave its name to the scandal that brought down his Administration.

title: Kabul Journal;   In Power Still, Afghan Can Thank His 4-Star Aide
description: As Afghanistan's rulers have been assassinated or driven into exile. Mohammed Aslam Watanjar has been one of the country's pre-eminent survivors.

title: United Cities Gas Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dinkins Steps Up Criticism of Brooklyn Protesters
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, stepping up his criticism of a black-led boycott of Korean-American grocery stores in Brooklyn, said yesterday that ''a large mountain has been made out of a very small molehill'' by the protesters, who, he said, ''have expanded this beyond reasonableness.''

title: Review/Ballet;   Tharp Bends the Rules Again In Scottish-Inspired 'Brief Fling'
description: American Ballet Theater offered a full plate on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House: ''Brief Fling,'' a premiere by Twyla Tharp; ''Birthday Offering,'' a jewel by Sir Frederick Ashton from 1956 that is new to Ballet Theater; a guest appearance in Antony Tudor's ''Jardin aux Lilas'' by Carla Fracci, the Italian ballerina who was one of the company's stars until the 1980's, and Fernando Bujones's official return to the regular repertory after five years.

title: Amtech Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lufthansa in Talks On DHL Holding
description: The West German state-controlled airline, Lufthansa A.G., said it and other parties were discussing the possibility of taking a minority stake in DHL Worldwide Express Inc., the courier service. A Lufthansa spokesman declined to provide any further details. He also would not identify the other parties involved in the talks.

title: Bulls in Charge of Series With 76ers
description: The Philadelphia 76ers, basketball's current version of the Broad Street Bullies, must soon return to their style of muscle-and-tussle and thump-and-bump - if only the officials will let them.

title: Valley Federal Savings Bank (Inc) (O( reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $51,000, or 5 cents a share, and $82,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included a tax credit of $96,960, or 9 cents a share, and $143,376, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, which included $559,404 one-time gain on sale of the bank stock in the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. Valley Federal Savings Bank is based in Terre Haute, Ind.

title: KEY RATES
Evolution in Europe;   ALBANIA DROPPING CURBS ON WORSHIP AND BAN ON TRAVEL
description: Albania today announced a series of laws that may bring about far-reaching liberalization in this most restrictive of European Communist countries. They include a measure providing for freedom to travel abroad and, apparently, restoration of the right to practice religion.

title: Democrats Prepared for 'Good Faith' Talks on Budget
description: Democratic Congressional leaders told President Bush today that they would accept his invitation to begin ''good faith'' budget negotiations, but hours later fierce skirmishing erupted in Congress over who would take the blame if the bargaining led to tax increases.

title: Cerebral Tax Folly
description: To the Editor:

title: National Western Life reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Sea Blockade Spurs New Carnage Between the Lebanese Christians
description: Twelve people were killed today as warring Christian forces fought savage artillery duels today, bringing most of Lebanon's Christian enclave under shellfire in a new flare-up of the four-month Christian conflict, hospital officials said.

title: Law School Standards: the Old and the New;   'A Superb Scholar'
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film;   The Teacher Is Angry; Watch Your Back
description: ''Any student caught on school property with an automatic weapon will be detained by security personnel.'' This is the situation at the start of Mark L. Lester's ''Class of 1999,'' a spinoff from his ''Class of 1984,'' which came out in 1982.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Caribbean Festivals

title: The Law and Marion Barry Jr.
description: 1974: Marion S. Barry Jr. is elected to the District of Columia City Council and re-elected in 1976.

title: South Asian Solution Is Real Autonomy
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Homeless Men Die in Collapse in Bronx
description: A 24-foot concrete floor slab, the skeletal remains of a tenement demolished years ago, collapsed in a pounding rain on a bleak hillside lot in the Bronx yesterday and killed three homeless men huddled underneath in a makeshift shelter, the police said.

title: Market Place;   Innovation Hurts Cellular Stocks
description: THE planned testing of a new type of cellular telephone service raises the prospect of fresh competition for current providers of such service, further depressing their stock prices.

title: CHINA ANNOUNCES RELEASE FROM JAIL OF 211 DISSIDENTS
description: China today announced the release of 211 people jailed for taking part in the democracy movement last year, including several of the most prominent supporters of greater democracy. Diplomats described the action as an attempt to improve Beijing's relations with the West.

title: EQK Green Acres L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Albania's Secret Police Is Cautiously Criticized
description: Western residents in Albania say that if the new policy of ''democratization'' is to become a reality, a reduction in the pervasive powers of the secret police is a prerequisite.

title: 27 Killed as a Plane Carrying Pilgrims Crashes in Mexico
description: A plane carrying people to see Pope John Paul II crashed today, killing at least 27 of the 38 people on board, including a bishop, the authorities said.

title: Let Cities, Not Feds, Handle Census Count
description: To the Editor:

title: Canadian Occidental PetroFleum Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said lower sales in the latest quarter were due to a decline of natural gas sales in the U.S. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: K. C. Jones Bows Out
description: K. C. Jones, former head coach of the Boston Celtics and now an assistant with the Seattle SuperSonics, has withdrawn from the list of candidates under consideration for the Atlanta Hawks' coaching job. Mike Fratello resigned as the Hawks' head coach last month.

title: Computers and Other Targets: II;   A Lesson From Japan: Experiment
description: Japan may have stumbled in its highly publicized effort to produce a Fifth Generation computer that can talk to people, but its Government-fostered computer industry puts U.S. companies under ever-greater pressure. Japan is now mounting a challenge to U.S. supremacy in a promising technology, massive parallel processing.

title: Dow Jones Fills Post at Telerate
description: Dow Jones & Company said yesterday that Carl M. Valenti had been named president of Telerate Inc., its electronic financial data subsidiary.

title: Suit Is Filed In MGM Deal
description: The producer of ''The Good, the Bad and the Ugly'' filed suit on Wednesday in Federal court to block the proposed $1.22 billion acquisition of the MGM/UA Communications Company by the Pathe Communications Corporation.

title: I.B.M. Introduces New Model 25 PC
description: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had introduced a new Model 25 personal computer that offers more functions, faster processing, 50 percent more fixed disk drive capacity and higher resolution color graphics than existing machines.

title: F.B.I. Agent Under Attack at Trial
description: Defense lawyers for three futures traders on trial on fraud charges here attacked the credibility of a critical Government witness in opening statements today.

title: Fernandez Pushes an End To Patronage
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, urged a state legislative panel yesterday to strip community school boards of almost all their hiring powers and to limit their authority to setting broad policy.

title: Danaher Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dinkins Re-examines AIDS Pact
description: New York City officials re-examined their cancellation of parts of an AIDS-prevention program yesterday as pressure to restore them arose from AIDS and drug-treatment organizations.

title: Educational Development reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
2 Juries Rehear Testimony
description: The two juries in the Bensonhurst murder trial heard testimony reread during deliberations yesterday.

title: Cyprus Journal;   What Next for the U.N. on This 'Fairy Tale' Isle?
description: From a blue wooden hut overlooking the Pyla plateau in southern Cyprus, Maj. Franz Walch of the Austrian Army surveys the rippling wheat fields with satisfaction.

title: Free Electronic Concert
description: A free concert of electronic works by nine student composers will be presented in Paul Hall at the Juilliard School, 144 West 66th Street, tonight at 8. The composers, who are all graduate students, are Nico Abondolo, Keith Albright, Gilles Bernard, Emily George, Viviana Guzman, Mari Kimura, Joel McGee, Andrew Moore and Liuh-Wen Ting. Information: 799-5000.

title: Luigi Nono, 66, Italian Composer With a Marxist Avant-Garde Tilt
description: Luigi Nono, the most prominent of Italy's postwar avant-garde composers, died at his home in Venice on Tuesday. He was 66 years old.

title: Woman Says She Received Letter From 7 Missing Chinese Farmers
description: When last seen two weeks ago, the seven Chinese farmers destined for an agricultural exchange program in Massachusetts had just arrived at Kennedy International Airport. Then they vanished mysteriously. Speculation followed that they had been kidnapped, perhaps to be pressed into some sort of indentured servitude.

title: Artists Exhibit Views Of the Subway System
description: Artists' renderings of the subway system are on display at the New York Transit Museum, Boerum Place and Schermerhorn Street, in Brooklyn Heights.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * J. C. Penney Television Shopping Channel to Bozell.

title: Excerpts From Ruling On Begging in Subway
description: Following are excerpts from a ruling by a three-judge panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit permitting the New York City Transit Authority to ban begging in the subways.

title: Israel to Hold Bank Inquiry
description: Israel's Supreme Court today ordered the Attorney General to reopen an investigation into whether criminal charges should be lodged against the nation's leading banks and former directors for a stock market crash in 1983.

title: S.C.I. Is Selling Insurance Unit
description: The Service Corporation International, the world's largest funeral services company whose earnings have been hurt by a slowing mortality rate, said it would sell its insurance subsidiary to the Torchmark Corporation for $165 million.

title: NATO Plans More Cuts in Short-Range A-Arms
description: The NATO Defense Ministers agreed today that the alliance could safely make further cuts in short-range nuclear weapons in response to the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe in the last year.

title: Diner's Journal
description: East Side Italian

title: Police Colonel Slain in Chile
description: Two gunmen today shot to death a former Chilean police intelligence chief, Col. Luis Fontaine, the police and witnesses said. Colonel Fontaine was shot seven times in the head.

title: Bliss Quits Joffrey Board And Says Others Will Go
description: Anthony A. Bliss, co-chairman of the troubled Joffrey Ballet, said yesterday that he had resigned from the Joffrey board. He said he understood that David H. Murdock, the other co-chairman, had also resigned, and that Frank W. Lynch, vice chairman of the board, had either resigned or was about to.

title: Economic Scene;   Pressures Mount For a Budget Deal
description: POWERFUL forces have been pushing the President and the Democratic leadership of Congress toward a deal to cut the widening budget deficit, even if that involves an increase in taxes. The deficit could soar to well over $200 billion in the fiscal year 1991 as a result of lower revenues, higher interest payments and a bigger bill for bailing out savings and loan institutions than the Administration expected.

title: Boonton Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Island Telephone reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Nordstrom reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Hearing Planned in Research Dispute
description: A Congressional subcommittee investigating a disputed scientific paper said today that it would hold a hearing to present new evidence, obtained by the Secret Service, of irregularities in the data reported by a researcher involved in the study.

title: Financial Benefit reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included realized investment losses of $568,000.

title: Goldfield Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Durham Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $733,000. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: McDonnell Plans Additional Layoffs
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, plagued by operational trouble at its Douglas Aircraft subsidiary, raised the number of layoffs planned this summer to 4,000, from 3,000, the company said. The layoffs will be centered at the Douglas Aircraft plant in Long Beach, Calif.

title: Restaurants
description: Poiret

title: Centocor reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings for both periods were less than one cent a share.

title: 3 More Indicted In Sex Assault Near St. John's
description: Three more St. John's University students were charged yesterday with sexually assaulting another student, bringing to six the number of male students indicted in what a prosecutor called an evening of ''depravity'' and ''viciousness'' in an off-campus house.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Investor Says Ultimate Can Use His Expertise
description: LEAD: The management of the Ultimate Corporation was mistaken if it thought that Norman Elowitz would simply disappear after his offer to buy the company was rejected in February.

title: College Aid Form Is a Model of Confoundedness
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Seasons Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Death as a Ripple in Deep Racial Current
description: Loyal Garner Jr. had been dead for only an hour when officials began the fight over his body and over who would rule on how he had died.

title: Beijing Aims Jail Releases at Influencing U.S.
description: A secret document prepared after a high-level meeting in Beijing this spring says the Chinese Communists intend to use the release of political prisoners as one of their few available ''cards'' to influence American policy toward China.

title: Circle Fine Art Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said its latest quarterly and 6 months losses reflect about $1 million in startup costs, increased overhead and decreased margins relating to launching the art collectors circle, an art-marketing program introduced recently.

title: Hills Defends White House Move on Japan Trade
description: The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, told Congress today that despite recent moves by the Japanese to open their markets, the animosity toward Japan in this country had become ''a tidal wave and you have to run very fast to be in front of it.''

title: In Tax Debate, Clearer Signs Of Broader Role for Sununu
description: John H. Sununu, President Bush's chief of staff, has taken an expanded role in White House political operations to fill a gap created by the prolonged illness of Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, Administration officials and party strategists say.

title: Review/Art;   Anselm Kiefer Explores And Confronts the Past
description: On the eve of German reunification - and with all the anxiety and apprehension that the event stirs in the minds of many people - the works of Anselm Kiefer increasingly compel our attention.

title: On Stage
description: U.S.-African Parallel

title: U.S. Recalls Romanian Envoy
description: The United States is recalling its Ambassador to Romania as a signal of displeasure over intimidation and harassment of opposition parties, the State Department said today. The State Department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said Ambassador Alan Green would return to Bucharest in time for the May 20 elections, when Romanians will vote for a President and a bicameral Parliament.

title: Cecil Wallace-Whitfield, Bahamas Politician, 60
description: Sir Cecil Wallace-Whitfield, leader of the opposition party in the Bahamas, died on Wednesday in a Miami hospital, where he had gone for cancer treatment. He was 60 years old.

title: Books of The Times;   The Decisive Moments In Characters' Lives
description: Family Sins & Other Stories

title: Bruins' Sweep Suiting Sinden Like a T-Shirt
description: Harry Sinden, the charming rasp still in his voice and his craggy face even more deeply creased by a perpetual smile, looked fairly comic Wednesday night in the newest fashion rage that had just swept through a quietly jubilant corner of the Capital Centre basement.

title: Agnico-Eagle reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Canadian Roxy Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Salute to Israel Parade, Fifth Avenue from 57th to 86th Streets will be closed on Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Kohl Pressing East for an Accord on Monetary Treaty
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that the East German Government must agree to major economic changes contained in the proposed state treaty on monetary, economic and social union before the Deutsche mark can become the sole legal tender in both nations. The treaty is viewed as the single most important step toward political unification of the two nations.

title: City Landmark Tours Celebrate Preservation
description: Twenty-five years ago, New York City made a formal commitment to protect its architectural heritage. Since Mayor Robert F. Wagner signed the Landmarks Preservation Law on April 19, 1965, 53 historic districts have been created, and more than 900 buildings or interiors have been given landmark status. To celebrate this anniversary, a number of tours and exhibitions are scheduled this spring.

title: Sale by Hershey
description: The Hershey Foods Corporation signed an agreement to sell its shares in A.B. Marabou, a Swedish confectionery and snack food concern, to Orkla Borregaard A.S. of Oslo for cash in excess of $75 million. Hershey said the deal was expected to result in a one-time after-tax gain in excess of $35 million. The transaction will be completed as soon as Swedish and Norwegian Government approvals are received, it said. Hershey's shares rose 37.5 cents today, to $34.125, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Sales Tax on Services Is Scrapped by Albany
description: Bowing to heavy pressure from businesses, New York's legislative leaders said today that they had agreed to scrap a plan that would have imposed sales taxes on services like management consulting, public relations and custom computer programming. The leaders also eliminated a planned sales tax on magazines.

title: Review/Dance;   Ballet Theater Restores Old Favorite
description: The good news at American Ballet Theater on Wednesday night was the return of ''Rodeo,'' Agnes de Mille's quintessential bit of Americana, to the company for the first time since 1982. Now the equally good news: Ballet Theater's dancers have started off the season at an astonishingly high level - symbolized by the stupendous performance that Julio Bocca gave in the afternoon in ''La Bayadere.''

title: Gendex Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Comdata Holdings Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Devjo Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Korea Boils as Economy Cools
description: The tensions that fueled the big anti-Government demonstrations in South Korea Wednesday have been building for months. And the main causes of the rising discontent have been the troubles of this nation's economy and what is seen to be the Government's inept, heavy-handed response.

title: Foreign Landowners
description: Foreigners continue to own just under 1 percent of the nation's agricultural land, a level that has varied little over the years, the Agriculture Department said today. The department's Economic Research Service made its 1989 end of the year review of reports under a 1978 law requiring foreigners to register American agricultural land holdings. As of Dec. 31, 1989, about 12.9 million acres of agricultural land were owned by foreigners, an increase of 263,273 acres from a year earlier. Of the land owned by foreign interests, 46 percent was forest land, 18 percent cropland, 31 percent pasture and other agricultural land, and 5 percent agricultural land not under cultivation.

title: Flowmole Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Senate Report Warns Of Surging Cocaine Use
description: Nearly 2.2 million Americans use cocaine each week, more than double the number in previous Federal estimates, according to a Senate report today that offered a bleak portrait of cocaine use in the United States.

title: Celtic Conference
description: Celtic music, poetry and traditions will be featured at an all-day conference tomorrow at the Alexander Robertson School, 3 West 95th Street. Celtic mythology and Welsh culture will be covered during the conference, which will also feature fiddle and bagpipe music and poetry readings. It is sponsored by the Celtic League. Admission is $10. Information: 295-0820.

title: Edwards Fires Away and Keeps Ewing Tied Up
description: Through the first two games of the Knicks-Pistons playoff series, James Edwards has been a more dominant inside force than Patrick Ewing. And that is just one of the reasons the Pistons hold a 2-0 lead.

title: Unbridled's Closing Run Supports One Adage
description: The old adage that any horse can win the Kentucky Derby if he can run its final quarter-mile in 24 seconds proved true this year. Unbridled was the only one of the 15 horses in the race to crack the 25-second barrier for his final quarter, and he won by 3 1/2 lengths.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Riney's First Spot For Carvel Ice Cream
description: Hal Riney has a gravelly voice that is occasionally heard narrating commercials. Tom Carvel, the ice cream man, had a mumbly voice that often narrated his company's spots. In February, when Hal Riney & Partners won the Carvel Corporation account, many wondered whether the ad man would replace the marble-mouthed entrepreneur.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption in Weekend last Friday, with an article about avant-garde music, misidentified the musician and instrument shown. Adam Weisman was playing the surrogate kithara.

title: Senate, 67-30, Votes to Amend The Hatch Act
description: The Senate today approved a measure that would allow Federal workers to participate in many partisan political activities from which they have been excluded for 50 years.

title: John Paul, in Mexico, Denounces Birth Control
description: Pope John Paul II preached a hard sermon against birth control today in this Roman Catholic country that is struggling to stop its population's explosive growth rate.

title: Overboard on Ozone
description: Every President needs a Darth Vader in the White House to thwart special pleaders and scrutinize even apple-pie issues. President Bush's chief of staff, John Sununu, and Budget Director, Richard Darman, have played this role zestfully in curbing what they see as excessive solicitude for the environment. But in their latest foray, an assault on the international effort to protect the ozone layer, they have simply abandoned all sense of proportion and judgment.

title: Rotation Juggled; Mets Are Dizzy
description: Being a starting pitcher for the Mets these days is like playing musical chairs. Listen closely, Ron Darling and Bob Ojeda, there is an available chair in San Francisco on Tuesday. Manager Davey Johnson will let you know when the music begins.

title: Altered Campaign Bill Aids Senators
description: Several Senate Democrats who face re-election in 1992 have engineered new provisions in their party's campaign financing bill that would allow their campaign organizations to spend hundreds of thousands of dollars beyond the legislation's spending limits.

title: Cara reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Theater;   Marooned in Moscow After the Revolution
description: It may well be possible for a Soviet director, even one who doesn't speak English, to parachute into the United States and successfully re-create a celebrated Moscow production with American actors unschooled in Russian theatrical styles. But the more likely result of such a hands-across-the-water cultural experiment is typified by Boris A. Morozov's production of Mikhail Bulgakov's ''Zoya's Apartment'' at the Circle in the Square. Mr. Morozov is resident director of the Maly Theater in Moscow. His New York cast is headed by such actors as Bronson Pinchot, of television's ''Perfect Strangers,'' and Robert LuPone, of ''A Chorus Line.'' In ''Zoya's Apartment,'' East and West do not so much meet as smash their heads against a wall as formidable as Berlin's once was.

title: U.S. Chip Index Is Unchanged
description: Sales of computer chips to the United States market declined in April, but the semiconductor industry's leading indicator remained constant, an industry group said today.

title: Canadian Energy Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said increased revenues were attributable to the consolidation of results of CES Thermal Services Ltd. in the previous year CES Thermal was accounted for as an affiliate. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Marxist Coalition Gaining Strength in Nepal
description: As a hastily assembled interim Government struggles to assert its power in Nepal, the left is positioning itself to set the pace of political change.

title: Court Affirms Utilities Must Pay for Charity
description: New York State's top court ruled today that it was unconstitutional for utilities to bill customers for corporate gifts to charity.

title: Outlays in Quarter $1.6 Billion at Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company said its first-quarter capital spending amounted to $1.6 billion, but the company would not project total spending for 1990. The auto giant's 1989 capital outlays were $6.8 billion, according to its chairman and chief executive, Harold Poling, who spoke at a news conference after the company's annual meeting.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ''How proud my brother would be of these two books,'' Senator EDWARD M. KENNEDY told guests at the 10th annual ROBERT F. KENNEDY Book Awards ceremony at Hickory Hill, the McLean, Va., home of ETHEL KENNEDY. ''They both light a candle in the darkness and they certainly serve the memory of Robert Kennedy.''

title: A Terry Riley Premiere
description: The Kronos Quartet (David Harrington and John Sherba, violinists; Hank Dutt, violist, and Joan Jeanrenaud, cellist) will give the New York premiere of Terry Riley's ''Salome Dances for Peace'' at Alice Tully Hall tomorrow evening at 8 o'clock. The full-evening work draws on both the biblical story of Salome and legends from American Indian cultures. Tickets are $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: Review/Music;   Ashkenazy With the Berlin Radio Symphony
description: Virtuoso pianists who take up conducting, as Vladimir Ashkenazy did a decade ago, begin with a theoretical advantage over most other fledgling maestros. Their instrument's range is similar to that of the orchestra and its literature is unmatched anywhere in Western music for quantity and quality. The pianist's outlook on music tends to be wider, if not necessarily deeper, than a violinist's, say, or a percussionist's. Progress in the new profession, understandably, is often quicker.

title: Strong Gate Receipts Raising Some Salaries
description: For all their struggles this year on the field, members of the United States national soccer team will discover today or tomorrow that they have been more successful than they realized.

title: U.N. Agency Rejects P.L.O. Role
description: The World Health Organization voted today to defer indefinitely the Palestine Liberation Organization's application for full membership.

title: Equity Oil Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Florida Joins Paper Case
description: The State of Florida moved on Wednesday to join The St. Petersburg Times in a legal battle over stock dividends with a group led by the Texas billionaire Robert M. Bass.

title: Maybe Bush Said, 'No New Taxis'
description: LEAD: Did George Bush ever really say, ''No new taxes''?

title: New President Named In Shuffle at Honda
description: Two executives with experience in Honda's United States operations were also named to top positions: Shoichiro Irimajiri, 50, and Yoshide Munekuni, 52, were named executive vice presidents.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Pro Bono
description: * Messner Vetere Berger Carey Schmetterer has become the agency for the singer Paul Simon's Children's Health Fund.

title: Thousands March in Algeria To Back Democratic Change
description: Tens of thousands of Algerians marched through the capital today in a peaceful demonstration in support of democratic change and against Muslim fundamentalism.

title: Series of 3 Readings From Irish Literature
description: Contemporary Irish literature is the theme of a three-part series of readings to begin on Monday at 8 P.M. at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. The first reading will feature the poets Seamus Heaney, John Montague and Nuala Ni Dhomhnaill, who will read from their own writing.

title: Grace F. Salvatori, 80, Philanthropist, Is Dead
description: Grace Ford Salvatori, a philanthropist who was a leading fund-raiser for the Los Angeles Music Center, died on Saturday at her home in Los Angeles. She was 80 years old.

title: Thomas's 3-Pointers Bad News To Knicks
description: Magic Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers has a nickname for his best friend when a game is on the line. He calls Isiah Thomas of the Detroit Pistons Money Time.

title: Crownx reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 89th Career Playoff Goal By Kurri Ties Record
description: Jari Kurri's record-tying playoff goal late in the second period carried Edmonton to a 4-3 victory over the Chicago Blackhawks tonight and put the Oilers one victory away from the Stanley Cup finals.

title: Pop/Jazz;   Rockabilly Music: Far From Dead And Not for Misfits
description: THE cult of rockabilly lives on, more than 30 years after its heyday and long after many of its original purveyors have faded into obscurity. The Cramps and Flat Duo Jets, two rockabilly-influenced bands intent on carrying that music's raunchy energy and grisly passion into the 90's, will perform tomorrow night at the Ritz.

title: Rutgers Students' Sit-In Turns Mellow
description: Downstairs in occupied Milledoler Hall at Rutgers University, Amiri Baraka, the poet, was reading from his works and stoking the spirits of student protesters seeking, among other demands, a freeze on tuition and tenure for him.

title: Six New Narcotics Charges Filed Against Mayor Barry
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., already in serious legal and political trouble because of eight drug-related charges lodged against him, was indicted today on six new counts by a Federal grand jury.

title: American Travellers Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Eastern Air Goes to Ogilvy
description: Eastern Airlines announced yesterday that it had switched its $45 million advertising account from Lintas New York to Ogilvy & Mather. The move stunned Lintas, which had held the account since 1982 and just two months ago was a finalist for the account of Continental Airlines, which like Eastern is a subsidiary of the Texas Air Corporation.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Once Again Cannes, the Magical and the Mad
description: When the carry-on baggage for the New York-to-Nice flight includes film cans, it's a sure sign of the season. Two days ago the Croisette, the sweeping oceanfront promenade that is this city's most majestic sight, was dotted with peaceable tourists, but that changed literally overnight. Like the glorious banks of snapdragons that line the boulevard, different in variety but crammed together in the tightest imaginable fashion, thousands of journalists, wheeler-dealers, celebrities, fans and wishful thinkers have now descended upon this formerly quiet scene.

title: Amvestors Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NWNL Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said it had realized investment losses aftertax in first quarter 1990 of $4.217 million, compared with losses of $3.037 million in the year-ago quarter.

title: Westinghouse Dip
description: The stock of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation fell $2 today, to $72, on the New York Stock Exchange in the wake of what analysts described as a lackluster presentation by the company at a meeting on Tuesday. Traders said that a relative lack of enthusiasm by Paul Lego, Westinghouse's president and chief operating officer, at a session with securities analysts had had a negative effect on the stock.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addenda
description: * D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles has acquired a ''substantial minority equity interest'' in Synergie Communications Ltd., Thailand, which will merge with D.M.B.& B.'s Thai agency and be named Synergie/ D.M.B.& B. Ltd.

title: McCaw Cellular reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $157.8 million. c-Net loss

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Review/Film;   Manhattan's Privileged and the Plague of AIDS
description: Possibly because it is the first mainstream American film about AIDS, ''Longtime Companion'' is a lot gentler and even more upbeat than it need be. It is instructional, mannerly and, with the exception of a couple of scenes and performances, insipid. It's as if it didn't want to offend people who don't want to think about the plague (but who probably won't go to see the movie anyway).

title: Arabs Agree to Hold Talks in Baghdad
description: Arab countries, increasingly alarmed over the influx of Soviet Jews to Israel, agreed today to hold a summit meeting in Baghdad.

title: Sceptre Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Preferred-share dividends were not immediately available. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Wizard of The Mailbox Is Honored
description: YESTERDAY was gray and rainy in New York. It was a day for people to stay home and read their mail and pay their bills. It was, in short, the kind of day that direct marketers love.

title: Calgene Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
