description: b-Included a pretax gain of $1,294,000 on sale of assets for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss The company said latest 6-month results included product sale of $6.3 million from Plant Genetics Inc., acquired July 1, 1989, and from Noblebear Inc., acquired Feb. 1, 1990. The company also said the gain on sale of assets in the current year resulted from gain of the sale of a 30 percent equity interest in Calgene's seed potato business to Kirin Brewery Co., Ltd.

title: Law School Standards: the Old and the New;   The Wrong Criteria
description: To the Editor:

title: Connecticut Budget Is Left Unfinished
description: A dispute over how Connecticut can best avoid future budget crises flared into a battle of wills that paralyzed the General Assembly in the final hours of its annual session Wednesday, leaving the state without a completed budget for the fiscal year that begins July 1.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Criticism of Israel

title: Washington Talk;   First Lady as a Symbol On Buses and Ballots
description: Barbara Bush achieved Warhol-pop stature this week when she showed up on the side of a bus.

title: How Representatives Voted On Bill to Give Workers Leave
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 237 to 187 by which the House of Representatives today approved the family and medical leave bill. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the bill. Voting''yes'' were 198 Democrats and 39 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 54 Democrats and 133 Republicans. Y is a ''yes'' vote. N is a ''no'' vote. X denotes those not voting. There is one vacancy in the 435-member House.

title: 2 MEN ARE INDICTED IN MEXICO DUMPING
description: Federal prosecutors in Los Angeles today announced indictments of two men on charges of dumping toxic waste in Mexico in the first instance in which the United States has pursued prosecution of an environmental crime across its southern border.

title: Wal-Mart Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the costing of inventories under the LIFO (last in first out) method of accounting reduced net income $12,600,000, or 2 cents a share, for the current quarter, compared with $12,600,000, or 2 cents a share, for the same quarter last year.

title: Dow Is Up Only 5.63 Despite Rate Outlook
description: Stocks barely advanced yesterday, even after results of the Treasury's $10 billion bond sale showed that interest rates could be on the way down.

title: Panel on Bombing Seeks Revamping of F.A.A.
description: The Presidential commission that investigated the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 has concluded that the Federal Aviation Administration is not properly organized to prevent or respond to such attacks and that it should revamp its anti-terrorist activities, Federal officials say.

title: Paris Receives Pretoria Leader at Start of Tour
description: At the start of a nine-country European tour that would have been unthinkable only months ago, President F. W. de Klerk won recognition today for his efforts to end apartheid by becoming the first South African leader to be received by a French President since 1947.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   McDonald's Changes Its Campaign Slogan
description: After extolling the ''good time, great taste of McDonald's'' for six years, the fast-food icon is changing its advertising slogan. Effective tonight, the theme will be ''You know the one, McDonald's, for food, folks and fun.'' In a statement, Paul D. Schrage, McDonald's senior executive vice president and chief marketing officer, called the new theme ''a message that reflects the basic values that set McDonald's apart.''

title: Viacom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said that in February 1989, it sold its Cleveland and Long Island Cable systems for about $546.7 million, which has used to repay $512.7 million of its bank debt after reduction of related expenses and taxes, causing a first quarter 1989 pre-tax gain of $304.8 million.

title: People
description: * Marianne Coleman has been promoted to senior vice president and finance director at Campbell-Mithun-Esty Advertising, a unit of Saatchi & Saatchi.

title: Law School Standards: the Old and the New
description: To the Editor:

title: Great Falls Gas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reviews/Film;   A Heroes-and-Villains Tale From the Myths of Lapland
description: Set in desolate, snow-covered stretches of the Arctic, ''Pathfinder'' is based on a 1,000-year-old legend passed from one generation of Laplanders to the next: a 16-year-old hero named Aigin saves a village from a roving band of thugs. If Aigin were as familiar as Davy Crockett, American viewers would be able to enliven this bare-bones adventure with their own memories of a well-known story. But ''Pathfinder'' is on its own, a translatable myth that remains too slow-moving and flat for foreign viewers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Free after three years and three months of captivity in Lebanon, ROBERT POLHILL must now contend with the minutiae of freedom, like lapsed memberships.

title: Pogorelich Recital
description: The pianist Ivo Pogorelich is to play Haydn's Sonata in D (Hob. XVI:19), Brahms's Three Intermezzi (Op. 117), Scriabin's Sonata No. 4 (Op. 30) and Balakirev's ''Islamey'' at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday at 8:30 P.M. The program also includes six Scarlatti sonatas, three Chopin mazurkas and three of Liszt's ''Transcendental Etudes.'' The performance was postponed from Feb. 25 because Mr. Pogorelich was ill. Tickets (those from Feb. 25 will be honored on Sunday) are $15 to $30. Information: 874-6770.

title: Capital Southwest reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Assets represent net assets.

title: Cray Computer Expected Monday
description: Cray Research Inc., trying to capture the low-end of the supercomputer market, will introduce a less expensive version of its high-powered Cray Y-MP supercomputer on Monday, an industry analyst said. Rick Martin at Prudential-Bache Securities said in a report that Minneapolis-based Cray had confirmed it would introduce the system.

title: Grain and Soybeans Are Up In Advance of Crop Report
description: Grain and soybean futures closed mostly higher in quiet trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Liberian Bloodshed, U.S. Diplomacy
description: A war is being fought in Liberia, which has close ties with the U.S., and very few in Washington have taken notice.

title: New Arena for Japanese Business: Space
description: After years of sitting on the sidelines of the space business, some of Japan's largest industrial and electronics companies are joining forces in the country's first commercial venture to launch private satellites into orbit, Government and industry executives say.

title: 76ers' Nash Resigns
description: John Nash, general manager of the Philadelphia 76ers the last four seasons, has resigned to pursue other opportunities, the club announced yesterday.

title: Accomplice in AIDS Deaths? Clues Are Sifted
description: New research by the French co-discoverer of the AIDS virus has added fuel to a dispute over a thesis that a microbe may be an accomplice in the disease's killing of human cells.

title: India Rejects U.S. Talks
description: India today rejected talks with the United States over removing India from the American list of countries singled out for unfair trading practices.

title: Officer Died Saving Other Sailors
description: The sailor killed in the blaze aboard the guided-missile destroyer Conyngham had roused sleeping crewmates from their quarters before being overcome by smoke, a crew member says.

title: Albania Reforms, Sort Of
description: A crack is opening in the fastness of Albania, Europe's last bastion of Communist absolutism. New laws will permit Albanians to travel abroad and to worship deities other than Marx, Stalin and Enver Hoxha, Albania's tyrant from 1944 until his death five years ago. The laws were adopted unanimously, as is always the case in the People's Assembly, and just in time to provide copy for visiting Soviet and American journalists.

title: House Passes Measure on Family Leave
description: Defying a veto threat, the House of Representatives today passed a measure that would require companies to grant workers up to three months of unpaid leave for the birth or adoption of children or to tend to ill family members.

title: The Winding Road From 'Bess' to Tully Hall
description: When Clamma Dale steamed up the Broadway stage 13 years ago as the female lead in the Houston Grand Opera production of ''Porgy and Bess,'' it seemed that the classical music world had found its own version of Diana Ross. After rave reviews for her lush voice and sinuous performance, the soprano was expected to be much in view as her career headed upward.

title: Washington's Budget Charade
description: LEAD: There are two dirty secrets in the budget ''debate'' that is now monopolizing Washington's attention: first, everyone knows what has to be done; second, few have any intention of doing it.

title: Newspaper Deal Studied
description: Central Newspapers Inc., the publishing company partly owned by the family of Vice President Dan Quayle, said on Wednesday that it was considering the acquisition of two West Coast newspapers. The announcement, made at the company's annual meeting, did not identify the newspapers. The company, which publishes The Phoenix Gazette, The Arizona Republic, The Indianapolis News, The Indianapolis Star and other dailies in Indiana, told stockholders it had a good year in 1989 despite reduced advertising linage.

title: Gary Keeper; TV Executive, 39
description: Gary Keeper, a senior programming executive at the Showtime cable television network, died of AIDS on Sunday at the North Hollywood Medical Center. He was 39 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Fremont General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $239,000, or 3 cents a share and $462,000, or 6 cents a share for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively.

title: Fairs and Festivals
description: Today

title: Auctions
description: How good will the results be from next week's sales in New York of artworks and prints produced over the last century? This question was on the minds of many of the thousands of collectors, dealers and auctioneers who attended this week's sales of contemporary art - the results of which were disappointing - or who plan to be at the auctions next Tuesday through Saturday of Impressionist and modern art. These major sales have been organized by Christie's, Sotheby's and Habsburg, Feldman, a Geneva-based house.

title: BRIEFS
description: * ARCO,Los Angeles, and Texaco Inc., White Plains, plan to drill exploratory wells in the Beaufort and Chukchi seas. Texaco plans to drill 51 sites on 13 geological prospects, with exploration to start next year, said a spokesman for the Interior Department. ARCO plans to drill two wells in an area known as the Fireweed prospect. Both plans are subject to Government review.

title: Budd Canada reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an amount equal to 60 cents a share as a result of receipt of price adjustments retroactive to the prior year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Taking a Defensive Stand
description: Seven summers ago, in the dawn of his bright career, the idea would have been unthinkable. Steve Sax, then a 23-year-old second baseman for the Los Angeles Dodgers, was in the midst of the most horrifying season of his life. For all the talent he demonstrated, none of it seemed to come in the field.

title: Cost of Budget Delay Is Placed at $18 Million
description: New York State's delay in adopting a budget will cost New York City taxpayers about $18 million, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said yesterday.

title: $47 Million Issue By Pennsylvania
description: The Pennsylvania Housing Finance Agency is offering $47 million in single-family mortgage revenue bonds through underwriters led by Bear, Stearns & Company.

title: Trump Is Reportedly Selling Yacht
description: Donald J. Trump has arranged to sell his 282-foot yacht in Japan for about $110 million, Wall Street executives and a lawyer close to the deal said yesterday.

title: U.S. Joins U.N. Move to Assail Israel
description: The Bush Administration is negotiating with Arab countries on the wording of a new United Nations Security Council resolution that would criticize Israeli settlements in occupied Arab territories as a breach of international law, diplomats involved in the talks say.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Upholds Ban On Begging in New York Subways
description: A Federal appeals court in Manhattan declared yesterday that begging is not a constitutionally protected right and upheld the New York City subway system's power to bar panhandlers.

title: Man Gets 9 Years in Poisoning of Historic Tree
description: The man convicted of poisoning Austin's 500-year-old Treaty Oak was sentenced today to serve nine years in prison and pay a $1,000 fine.

title:
Family-Style Apartments;

Large Condo Units Rise at East 93d St.
description: LEAD: The family-oriented building offering only large apartments was the rule rather than the exception when apartment houses were first developed on Manhattan's Upper East Side. Now that kind of building is having a comeback in the Royal Carnegie, a 15-story condominium under construction at 134 East 93d Street, at Lexington Avenue.

title: Central Jersey Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said that fourth quarter results reflected real estate reserves and a provision for loan losses totaling $5.5 million. This increase was made in conjunction with examiners from the office of Thrift Supervision and the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. About $4 million of the increase is attributable to valuation reserves for investments in three real estate projects with substantially all of the balance provided for general loan loss purposes.

title: Crown Life Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $3.3 million charge from asset writedowns, primarily in the mortgage and real estate portfolios in the Southern U.S. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. Welcomes Move
description: The Bush Administration today welcomed China's release of 211 prisoners arrested for involvement in the pro-democracy demonstrations, but urged Beijing to disclose the number and names of all the others who remain in detention.

title: AIRPORT OVERHAUL AT KENNEDY IS CUT
description: Under pressure from financially pressed airlines, the Port Authority has put off construction of a $1 billion central terminal and monorail system at Kennedy International Airport.

title: 'Comic Relief': Being Funny for a Serious Cause
description: In an earlier time, film makers as different as Charlie Chaplin and Preston Sturges demonstrated that comedy and misfortune make unnatural but sometimes compelling bedfellows. When three of this generation's brightest comedic talents -Billy Crystal, Whoopi Goldberg and Robin Williams - collaborated four years ago on a television program to raise money for the homeless, they had not seen the documentary segments that were interspersed among the monologues and set pieces. Along with the audience, they saw videotaped interviews with homeless families, many of them average people caught in hard times. Unlike colleagues in the entertainment industry who had taken up other causes, the trio could not underscore their effort with heartfelt songs or melancholy monologues. They were comics; their job was to be funny.

title: Steinberg Pleased With Jets, but Is Wary
description: The Jets' minicamp does not break until Friday, but the team's new general manager, Dick Steinberg, had seen enough by today to issue a qualified state-of-the-Jets address.

title: Reviews/Film;   Life, Sex, Death and Chaos
description: At the start of ''The Big Bang,'' the film's director, James Toback, sits in an elegant restaurant with his eventual producer, Joseph H. Kanter. As Mr. Toback argues that he has a good if unlikely idea - a movie in which ordinary and quasi-famous people talk about life, sex, death and chaos - the scene nods at ''My Dinner With Andre,'' the classic model of a raconteur's film. But in its quick-take approach to cosmic issues, ''The Big Bang'' has more in common with Diane Keaton's lightweight ''Heaven,'' minus the artsy film clips.

title: John Liu, 59, Is Dead; Engineer and Inventor
description: John Kung-Fu Liu, an inventor and business executive, died of heart failure Monday at the Medical College of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia. He was 59 years old and lived in Valley Forge, Pa.

title: New Look at an 'Obscure' Ruling, 20 Years Later
description: Few people would recognize a 20-year-old Supreme Court decision called Goldberg v. Kelly, let alone accord it a place in the pantheon of the Court's major rulings.

title: Liberty and Mustaf To Enter N.B.A. Draft
description: Their schools face sanctions from the National Collegiate Athletic Association and they themselves face a Sunday deadline to become eligible for the draft, so Marcus Liberty and Jerrod Mustaf have faced up to the situation and decided to curtail their pursuit of a degree in order to pursue pro careers instead.

title: Tax Returns By Block Up 7.1%
description: H & R Block Inc. said it had prepared 14 million tax returns in the fiscal year that ended on April 30, a 7.1 percent rise over the previous year. Block, which will not report its 1990 corporate earnings until June, said the number of returns prepared by its company-owned and franchised offices worldwide was up from 13.1 million returns in the 1989 fiscal year.

title: Thomas L. Boardman; Newspaper Editor, 70
description: Thomas L. Boardman, a former editor for two Scripps Howard newspapers, died of leukemia on May 4 at his home in Cleveland. He was 70 years old.

title: Cummins Thwarts Latest Threat
description: For the second time in a year, Henry B. Schacht, the chairman of the Cummins Engine Company, has eliminated a threat from a big dissident shareholder who could have upset his longstanding plan to turn around the company.

title: Copley Properties Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pauline Frederick Is Dead at 84; Was News Analyst for 3 Networks
description: Pauline Frederick, a longtime radio and television news analyst of world affairs, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Lake Forest (Ill.) Hospital while visiting relatives. She was 84 years old and lived in Sarasota, Fla.

title: Grandparent Visitation Rights at a New Level
description: When parents divorce, laws in all 50 states allow the grandparents to petition the courts to keep seeing their grandchildren. But Illinois has gone one step further: It allows that same right to grandparents when the child's parents are still married.

title: Peter T. Schneck; Architect, 53
description: Peter T. Schneck, an American architect based in Italy for the last quarter-century and a principal designer of the Costa Smeralda resort on Sardinia, died of AIDS on Monday at his home in Rome. He was 53 years old.

title: Disease Detection InternaFtional reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
CHRONICLE
description: Four of the men who carried out Britain's ''Great Train Robbery'' in 1963 met in a London cemetery yesterday to bid farewell to one of their accomplices, who was murdered at his Spanish villa last month.

title: Loopholes for Incumbents
description: Several Senate Democrats have achieved changes in their party's campaign financing bill that would allow each to spend much more than the limits that the bill sets. Page A20.

title: Bond Sale's Yields Defy Predictions
description: The Treasury wrapped up its quarterly refunding auctions yesterday by selling $10 billion worth of 30-year bonds at yield levels well below what most credit market analysts had thought possible little more than a week ago.

title: Walker Percy, Is Dead at 74; A Novelist of the New South
description: Walker Percy, a Southern author who wrote about modern man's search for faith and love in a chaotic world in ''The Moviegoer'' and other novels, died yesterday at his home across Lake Pontchartrain from New Orleans. He would have been 75 years old on Monday.

title: Bell Atlantic, U.S. Settle Bid Dispute
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Treasury Department said yesterday that they had settled a dispute over whether the company, the nation's largest provider of local telephone service, had misled the Federal Government.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Sheffield in Commotion
description: A police spokesman in Tampa, Fla., has confirmed a report in The St. Petersburg Times yesterday of a commotion in Tampa almost two months ago involving Gary Sheffield of the Milwaukee Brewers and almost involving his more famous uncle, Dwight Gooden of the Mets. The spokesman, Willie Howell, said the confrontation was based on a case of mistaken identity and no one was arrested.

title: Koreans Agree to Sell Land
description: South Korea's top 10 conglomerates said today that they would sell their nonproductive land and buildings in the next six months to support a Government drive to end rampant real estate speculation.

title: Compudyne Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $148,000. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $51,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Wetterau Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Art;   So Big and So Dressed Up, New Galleries Bloom in SoHo
description: NEW galleries in SoHo are a sign of business as usual, to put it mildly. They come along nearly every week, it sometimes seems. Still, a dozen recent arrivals to the downtown gallery scene stand out, as much for the scale and poshness of their layouts as for the art on view.

title: The Big-Gov Right
description: Hear that rumbling, grinding, groaning sound? It's the noise of the tectonic plates of the political right, building up ineluctable pressure along the San Darman Fault.

title: McCaw's Net Up in Quarter
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. reported yesterday that its earnings for the first quarter rose to $851.9 million, or $4.97 a share, compared with a loss of $97.7 million for the first quarter of 1989.

title: Judge Critical Of Dinkins Over Boycott
description: A Brooklyn judge issued an order yesterday barring demonstrators from picketing within 50 feet of two Korean-American food stores. In doing so, he criticized Mayor David N. Dinkins, expressing regret that the Mayor had not intervened personally to help end the four-month-old boycott that began over a dispute with a black customer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: Worthy in Command As Lakers Rout Suns
description: James Worthy, who seems to save his most spectacular games for the National Basketball Association playoffs, lived up to his reputation tonight.

title: At the Movies
description: ''If you took away the ninja aspect,'' said Steve Barron, ''it would be like taking away the swords from the Three Musketeers.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Begging in the subway often amounts to nothing less than assault.''

title: Reds Rally to End Pirates' Streak at Five
description: Joe Oliver hit a three-run homer and Paul O'Neill drove in three runs in a tie-breaking eight-run eighth inning tonight as the Cincinnati Reds beat Pittsburgh, 10-4, to end the Pirates' streak of five consecutive victories.

title: KEY RATES
Our Towns;   Learning of Life, Perchance to Act In a Tale of Woe
description: For months, elementary schools in the region had been preparing for the Children's Shakespeare Festival here this week. Terry Hofler decided his sixth graders at Alexander Burger school in the South Bronx would do ''Romeo & Juliet.'' Many girls wanted to be Juliet. (Of course. Juliet is the sun.) Few boys were willing to be Romeo. (Of course. Romeo wears tights and likes girls.) Mr. Hofler chose Reinaldo Santiago as Romeo, which gave Reinaldo an uneasy feeling at first. ''I thought, you know it would be . . .'' said Reinaldo. ''At first I thought . . . You know. You know . . . I thought it would be . . .'' Reinaldo whispered: ''Not so mannish. After a while as I was doing the play it looks like it wouldn't be embarrassing.''

title: Aerospace Contractor Indicted in Fraud Case
description: An aerospace company and two of its managers have been charged with fraud in the Government's industry-wide investigation into falsified test reports on essential aircraft components.

title: Genscher Yields to Kohl on Unification Pace
description: Apparently reversing an earlier position, Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher declared today that all aspects of German unity had to be resolved before actual unification.

title: Lithuania Takes Over Media In New Defiance of Moscow
description: Lithuania took formal control of its radio and television today in the latest move defying Kremlin insistence that the breakaway republic abandon its declaration of independence.

title: Review/Art;   'Marsden Hartley in Bavaria' Traces A Painter's Retreat and Renewal
description: ''Marsden Hartley in Bavaria'' is an intelligent, highly focused exhibition that zeroes in on a pivotal but little-known period in the career of a major American artist. The more than 80 works at the Baruch College Gallery do not show Hartley at his best, but they are consistently engaging, and they illuminate his personality, his thinking and the great art he subsequently made.

title: Panel Backs Move to Limit 'Junk Bond' Use by Insurers
description: Representatives of state insurance regulatory agencies approved recommendations yesterday that are aimed at limiting insurance company ownership of high-yield, high-risk ''junk bonds.'' The restrictions are expected to be approved by all 50 regulators next month and would be binding on insurers.

title: High-Resolution Images That Capture The Tension Of Court Life In A Turbulent Period
description: The exhibition poster hanging in the window of Cardozo Law School in New York shows A. Richard Golub standing in a packed courtroom, gesturing broadly in the manner of Ed Norton preparing to shoot some pool. His adversary, Martin Shelton, looks on, appearing bemused. At the same time, Justices A. Leo Milonas, Ernst Rosenberger and Joseph Sullivan of the Appellate Division in Manhattan are behind the bench, warily eyeing the often outrageous Mr. Golub.

title: From Goldberg v. Kelly
description: For qualified recipients, welfare provides the means to obtain essential food, clothing, housing, and medical care. . . . Termination of aid pending resolution of a controversy over eligibility may deprive an eligible recipient of the very means by which to live while he waits. Since he lacks independent resources, his situation becomes immediately desperate. His need to concentrate upon finding the means for daily subsistence, in turn, adversely affects his ability to seek redress from the welfare bureaucracy.

title: DEALS
description: BASKETBALL

title: Conquest Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said results for the 1990 quarter included the effect of the results of operations of Canadian Conquest Exploration Inc., which was acquired in April 1989. Revenues for the 1990 quarter included $2,160,000 attributable to Canadian operations. Revenues for the 1989 quarter included $2,160,000 related to the settlement of certain take-or-pay disputes.

title: Review/Film;   Antiwar Message From Bob Hoskins
description: Starring, directed by and co-written by Bob Hoskins, ''The Raggedy Rawney'' is a sincere, picturesque antiwar film about gypsy life. Those parts fit together just as awkwardly as you'd guess.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Wellcome Dropping Its T.P.A. Heart Drug
description: The Wellcome Foundation Ltd. has dropped its plans to develop and sell a drug for heart attack victims in the wake of a jury decision that the drug infringes patents held by Genentech Inc.

title: Graham-Field Health Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gains on purchase of senior subordinated notes of $286,000, or 4 cents a share for the latest quarter and $532,000, or 7 cents a share for the year-earlier period.

title: CBI Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $6,580,000, or 34 cents a common share, from sale of the company's 20 percent interest in Australian Submarine Corp.

title: Yield Settles at About 6.40% On New York City Notes
description: A $900 million sale by New York City of revenue-anticipation notes due June 29 of this year was priced yesterday through competitive bidding. Securities traders said the sale went well and the bidding was aggressive.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The son of the first man to climb Mount Everest reached the peak of the world's highest mountain yesterday. PETER HILLARY, the 36-year-old son of Sir EDMUND HILLARY, reached the top of the 29,029-foot peak 37 years after his father did.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   A Times Ad Director
description: Charles T. Coyle has been named advertising director of The New York Times Magazine. Mr. Coyle will be responsible for advertising at The New York Times Magazine and the Magazine Part 2's.

title: A Woman In Coaching Fraternity?
description: ''Hey, I don't hire idiots,'' Hubie Brown has been known to say when complimented on the assistant coaches who have worked for him.

title: Equipment Co. of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary tax credit of $26,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Consumer Credit Rises
description: Americans took out $2.6 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in March, as borrowing to buy automobiles rebounded from February, the Government said today.

title: Russian Nobles Gather To Don the Old Mantles
description: The nobles of Russia gathered tonight in a small converted church off Red Square to collectively come out of the shadows of long-enforced oblivion.

title: South Asian Solution Is Real Autonomy;   Weak Pakistani Claims
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Savoy Memories

title: Comic Is Protested as 'Saturday Night' Host
description: As ''Saturday Night Live'' nears the end of its 15th season, it is again provoking angry debate and protest over issues of comic license and what is appropriate for a network television broadcast - arguments that have dogged the show periodically since its premiere.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * FPL Group Inc., Sarasota, Fla., a utility holding company, named James L. Broadhead, its president and chief executive, to the additional post of chairman. He succeeds Marshall McDonald, who retired.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Imperial Tobacco Is Revamping
description: Imperial Tobacco Ltd., maker of John Player cigarettes, announced it would invest $67 million in new technology, close two factories and slash 1,125 jobs. Imperial, a subsidiary of the conglomerate Hanson P.L.C., said it would make the cuts to its 4,500-member work force in the next two years.

title: David Yohalem; International Consultant, 46
description: David Yohalem, a specialist in the developing nations of Africa, died of lymphoma yesterday at his home in Northampton, Mass. He was 46 years old.

title: Convest Energy Partners reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Prior quarter results included a non-recurring gain of $660,000 from a gas contract settlement.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS URGE BANKERS TO AVOID TIGHTENING CREDIT
description: In an extraordinary meeting, the nation's top banking regulators urged banking industry executives today to continue lending to creditworthy customers.

title: Foote, Cone & Belding Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Record-Setter Is Pace Favorite
description: After setting track records last month at Freehold and Buffalo Raceways while stretching his unbeaten streak in 1990 to eight races, Dorunrun Bluegrass looms as the dominant choice in the George Morton Levy Memorial final tomorrow night at Yonkers Raceway.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 508 money market mutual funds declined by $2.22 billion, to $383.5 billion, in the week that ended last Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 160 institutional funds decreased by $831.2 million, to $91.48 billion. The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were down by $531.6 million, to $132.17 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds decreased by $854.3 million, to $159.84 billion, the institute said.

title: Jaclyn Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Shares earnings for 1989 have been restated to reflect 48 percent stock dividend paid in June 1989.

title: Court Is Urged To Rehear Case On Ritual Drugs
description: An unusually diverse coalition of religious groups and constitutional scholars asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider a recent decision permitting states to take legal action against people who use illegal drugs as part of religious rituals.

title: Wind Sends Scores Into Stratosphere
description: It was a day of awful opposites at Muirfield Village Golf Club during the opening round of the Memorial Tournament, and only Fred Couples was able to negotiate them sufficiently to break par.

title: Rolland Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gain of $259,000 on the sale of a warehouse. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Test Drug Blocks Rejection of New Hearts in Mice
description: Scientists at a biotechnology company report that a synthesized substance that blocks a master switch of the immune system can inhibit the rejection of transplanted hearts in animals.

title: A 'Classic Attacker' Leads the Dutch
description: Like those of Ted Williams's at the plate and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's at the low post, Marco Van Basten's movements in and around the penalty area are a sublime ballet, a choreography of perfect arcs and angles.

title: Time Warner Said to Plan Venture
description: Time Warner Inc., the media, entertainment and publishing giant, is preparing to start a chain of some 100 entertainment stores in regional shopping centers on the order of the successful Disney Stores, retail and financial executives in New York said yesterday.

title: Dry-Fly Fishing Superb Along Catskill Streams
description: Fly fishermen in Catskill streams are enjoying splendid spring fishing conditions, said Ed Van Put of Livingston Manor, N.Y., one of the region's acknowledged masters of the sport.

title: Roll-Call in Senate On U.S. Employees
description: Following is the 67-30 roll-call by which the Senate voted today to loosen restrictions on political activities by Federal and postal workers under the Hatch Act.

title: Why Not Watergate?
description: The publication of Oliver North's notebooks should make us think about an awkward question. Why have the institutions that worked so well in Watergate, correcting the wrongs of Richard Nixon, failed to deal with the constitutional dangers of the Iran-contra affair?

title: Gitano Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included one-time charge of 10 cents a share in connection with the recent Charter 11 filing by Ames Department Stores Inc.

title: Review/Dance;   Spanish Traditions Updated
description: In addition to preserving traditional Spanish forms, the Carlota Santana Spanish Dance Arts Company seeks to create new works in the Spanish idiom. The New York-based group offered fine examples of both types of dances last Friday night at St. Peter's Lutheran Church.

title: Reader's Digest reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $267,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $224,000. c-Included an extraordinary credit of $140,000 and $446,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. The company said the decrease in third quarter net resulted primarily from a $13.1 million nonrecurring pretax expense for appreciation in the value of the company's equivalent stock units.

title: David S. Parker, 71; General Was a Chief For the Canal Zone
description: David S. Parker, a retired Army major general who was a former Governor of the Panama Canal Zone, died of congestive heart failure on Wednesday at Marin General Hospital at Greenbrae, Calif. He was 71 years old and lived in Belvedere, Calif.

title: Salvadoran Military Challenges Congress
description: To the Editor:

title: Air Canada reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The Notary Public: New Regulations
description: There are about four million notaries public in the United States, and every state sets its own rules for appointing them and overseeing their work. Since just about everyone who buys a home or signs a will or power of attorney needs to have signatures notarized, notaries' services are vital.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Rust and Wood Rot
description: Outdoor furniture, playground equipment and wood decks need care just once or twice a year to prolong their lives, and now is the time to spruce them up for use all summer.

title: Candy Plant Plea Denied
description: A United States Government panel today turned down a request by the Swiss candy maker Jacobs Suchard Ltd. to establish a special foreign trade zone for its Chicago plant so that the plant could save money by importing sugar at world prices.

title: Ultimate's Founder May Seek Control
description: Theodore M. Sabarese, the founder and former chairman of the Ultimate Corporation, said he was considering seeking control of the East Hanover, N.J., computer services concern through a tender offer or a proxy fight. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Sabarese said he now controlled 6.6 percent of Ultimate's shares outstanding, but he would soon be left with less than 1 percent.

title: The Sinking Of Mark Jackson
description: When Maurice Cheeks joined the Knicks on Feb. 22 in the trade for Rod Strickland, his role, it was said by management and believed by many, including Mark Jackson, was as a backup point guard for Mark Jackson.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Aztar Corp., Phoenix, a casino gaming company, said it would make discretionary purchases of up to two million shares of its common stock, or about 5 percent of the shares outstanding.

title: The Chancellor Demolishes the Gates
description: New York's Schools Chancellor, Joseph Fernandez, wants to scrap the rigid, 10-year-old ''gates'' policy of holding back students who don't perform and to substitute enriched instruction for slow learners. The gates program has failed; the new approach makes eminent sense.

title: Mid-South Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: To Keep New York Bridges From Falling Down
description: To the Editor:

title: Professional Care reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that revenue figures include $150,000 for the latest quarter, and $450,000 for the 6-month period, collected from visiting nurses service of New York for accounts receivable which had been previously.

title: Vanguard Cellular reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Worst Cyclone in the Decade Batters India and Kills 210
description: Medical teams and troops began a large relief operation today to repair the damage from the decade's worst cyclone, which battered India's southern coast for two days and killed at least 210 people.

title: Misha Raitzin, a Tenor With Met, Is Dead at 59
description: Misha Raitzin, a tenor who sang with the Metropolitan Opera, died of a lung aneurysm at his Manhattan home on Wednesday. He was 59 years old.

title: Mae Sien Hong, Press Agent, 75
description: Mae Sien Hong, a former press agent for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus and the Harlem Globe Trotters, died of cancer on May 4 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. She was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Reports Spur Treasury Price Rise
description: Interest rates plunged yesterday as prices of Treasury securities soared, largely on new evidence that the economy was softening and inflation fears subsiding.

title: Questions on AIDS Figures Arise in Dallas Survey
description: A random survey sponsored by the Federal Centers for Disease Control has found far fewer people infected with the AIDS virus in Dallas County than expected, agency officials said here today.

title: Dinkins Asks for Racial Unity And Offers to Mediate Boycott
description: In a rare live television speech from a packed City Council chamber last night, Mayor David N. Dinkins appealed to New Yorkers for racial unity and said he would do ''whatever is necessary'' to maintain public order and safety.

title: Pittsburgh & W.Va. Railroad reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush, Trying to Quell Tax Debate, Insists Budget Talks Will Be Open
description: Trying to quell the storm caused by the remarks of his chief of staff, President Bush insisted today that he was willing to discuss everything, including taxes, in the upcoming budget negotiations.

title: Patents;   Are Disputes Too Complex For Juries?
description: The failure of a jury to agree this week on damages for Robert W. Kearns, the inventor of the intermittent windshield wiper, has lent new vigor to the debate about the role of juries in deciding complex patent disputes.

title: About New York;   Meet at the River To Wash, Wax And Schmooze
description: New York is a city where entire cultures seem to materialize out of thin air, with the help, sometimes, of a little water.

title: CHRONICLE
description: One of the most famous of all picture-postcard vistas, the Parc du Champ de Mars with the Eiffel Tower, is in for some alterations. It will be the site of the latest, and some hope the last, of President FRANCOIS MITTERRAND's grand architectural works, the International Conference Center of Paris.

title: Procter & Gamble Pulls Some TV Ads Over Slur to Coffee
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, the nation's largest television advertiser of packaged goods, has pulled its advertising from a Boston television station because it broadcast commercials saying that buying the company's Folgers coffee helps bring ''misery, destruction and death'' in El Salvador.

title: Attacks on Jewish Graves Jolt France
description: More than 50 graves in two Jewish cemeteries in France have been found desecrated in the last two days, bringing ominous warnings from French political and religious leaders today that a racist mood is spreading across the country.

title: Duncan Out for a Game For Bumping Umpire
description: Baseball invoked the don't-bump-the-ump rule again yesterday, and the game's top batter was bumped from a game last night as a result.

title: Man Sentenced to Die for Murder of Ex-Wife
description: A man who used the hours of a brief prison furlough to murder his former wife was sentenced today to die in the electric chair after he told a judge that his ex-wife was to blame for her death.

title: BUSH SETS TARGET FOR MARS LANDING
description: President Bush declared yesterday that the United States should send astronauts to Mars in the next 30 years as the long-term goal of a ''new age of exploration.''

title: 'New York Overture'
description: Gerard Schwarz will conduct the New York Chamber Symphony in the world premiere of William Thomas McKinley's ''New York Overture'' at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, at 8 o'clock tonight and at 3 P.M. tomorrow. The program also includes Stravinsky's ''Dumbarton Oaks'' Concerto, the Brahms Variations on a Theme by Haydn, and the Mendelssohn Piano Concerto No. 2, with Joseph Kalichstein as the soloist. Tickets: $20 to $25. Information: 996-1100.

title: Daniel Behrman, 66, An Author and Editor
description: Daniel S. Behrman, an author of books on science and a former editor for Unesco, died of cancer on Wednesday at his home in Rangeley, Me. He was 66 years old.

title: Presidio Oil reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for 1990 included properties acquired from Home Petroleum in December 1989. Shares outstanding include 3,339,716 Class B shares in both years.

title: KEY RATES
Brascan Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: INSIDE
description: Anti-Semitism in France

title: Brenda Mines reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Restated Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Another Turnaround Is Needed by Knicks
description: Only three teams have come back from 0-2 deficits to win an opening-round three-of-five-game playoff series in the National Basketball Association. Sound a bit familiar? The Knicks were in that situation last week after losing the first two games to the Boston Celtics. The Knicks won the next three, and now they are one of the three teams to have rallied after being down by 0-2.

title: Review/Music;   On One Bill, Two Firsts By Brahms
description: Zubin Mehta's current program with the New York Philharmonic, presented first on Thursday evening in Avery Fisher Hall, is elegantly simple and, though it breaks no new ground, makes uncommonly good sense: Brahms's Piano Concerto No. 1 in D minor (Op. 15) and Symphony No. 1 in C minor (Op. 68).

title: Bridge
description: Two unusual events ended Thursday on the East Coast. In Atlantic City, the first Omar Sharif World Individual was won by Zia Mahmood, the globe-trotting Pakistani star, winning the record-setting first prize of $40,000. And in Washington, a team representing Corporate America pinned a second defeat on a Congressional team, winning by 77 imps.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the release of 211 Chinese political prisoners carried an incorrect byline in some editions. The article was by Nicholas D. Kristof, not Sheryl WuDunn.

title: Exide Electronics Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
A Tug-of-War Over Treating Divers
description: Drivers taking the lazy curve on York Street in this borough on the Delaware River must wonder what to make of the 19-foot-long cylinder that recently appeared at the headquarters of the Garden State Underwater Recovery Unit.

title: RB&W Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a tax credit of $290,000, or 6 cents a share.

title: Review/Music;   Yearning and Self-Reliance by Cher
description: Stardom, sentiment and skin are the makings of ''The Cher Extravaganza,'' as Cher called her concert here tonight at the Nassau Coliseum. In a song-and-dance show that lasts slightly more than an hour, Cher doesn't hype herself directly; that's done by video clips that recap her triumphs as television star, hit maker and award-winning actress. In between, Cher strolls the stage with a new costume for nearly every song, chats with the audience, wanders through the gyrations of an eight-member dance troupe and sings, in a tremulous alto made for melodrama, about yearning and self-reliance.

title: LDDS Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for 1990 included operations of Advantage Cos. Year-ago share earnings reflected the acquisition of Advantage Cos. Year-ago first quarter share net was 9 cents.

title: Chairman Quits Great Northern
description: The chairman of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, William R. Laidig, who led the paper company's unsuccessful effort to fend off the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, left the company today with a lucrative severance package.

title: Galtaco Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $930,000 for the quarter and $1,565,000 for the 6 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: American Stores May Sell Buttrey
description: The American Stores Company said it was considering the sale of its Buttrey Food and Drug unit, which operates 44 supermarkets and combination food and drug stores in the West. The company said its litigation with the California Attorney General prohibiting its merger with Lucky Stores and Alpha Beta supermarket chains had forced it to review all its ''marginal performing assets'' for possible sale.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the House of Representatives' passage of a bill on parental leave misidentified the woman shown with Representative Patricia Schroeder.

title: Review/Film;   Hippie Daye Here Again
description: Unless fate and Hollywood take some very peculiar turns, a Judd Nelson cameo should never be the highlight of any movie. But Mr. Nelson, who plays himself and is ecstatically greeted as Nicholas Cage and Charlie Sheen, provides the only half-funny moment in ''Far Out Man.'' Tommy Chong - the taller, more zonked-out half of Cheech and Chong - is the writer, director and star of this pathetic story about a leftover hippie. His idea of parodying the psychedelic past is to say, ''Look, a roach,'' and pick up a marijuana joint about a foot long.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Dubcek in Washington: Slovak With a Message
description: Alexander Dubcek, the father of the Prague Spring, came to Washington today, not as the leader of a free Czechoslovakia, as he had thought likely for a fleeting moment last fall, but to remind Americans that Slovaks as well as Czechs carried out the revolution of 1989.

title: Inquiry Clouds Bid To Lead Connecticut
description: For the last five months, Joel Schiavone, a wealthy New Haven developer best known for his banjo playing and off-beat publicity stunts, has waged a relentless long-shot campaign for the Republican nomination for governor.

title: News Analysis;   Jawboning the Bankers
description: Despite a clear signal to the banking community that regulators did not want the industry to close its lending spigot, bankers are likely to remain cautious and require proof of a more accommodating regulatory environment before they make large amounts of extra credit available.

title: Stephens Has Surgery
description: Woody Stephens, who has trained winners of two Kentucky Derbies and is the only trainer to win five consecutive Belmont Stakes, was in critical condition last night after open-heart surgery.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the tension surrounding the Bensonhurst murder trial misstated a defendant's name in some copies. It is Keith Mondello.

title: Quest Supply reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kodak Raising Prices
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it had increased prices for rental, service and supplies for most of its copier and electronic publishing system lines. List prices for the equipment itself will remain the same, the company said. Kodak said it would increase copier equipment rental and service rates by 5 percent.

title: Lithuania's Leaders Know What They're Doing;   Debt to the Red Army
description: To the Editor:

title: Danaher Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Corrected from Friday, May 11, editions.

title: Fibronics International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $290,000, or 4 cents a share for the latest quarter and $212,000, or 3 cents a share for the year-earlier period.

title: St. John's Suspends 3 In Sexual-Assault Case
description: Three St. John's University students indicted on Wednesday on charges of sexually assaulting another student were suspended yesterday pending the outcome of their cases. Three other students previously indicted in the case were suspended earlier.

title: Panel Is Told of Backlog of Savings-Fraud Cases
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has a backlog of 234 referrals and complaints of large-scale fraud involving the nation's financial institutions, according to data released today at a Congressional hearing.

title: Quixote Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sico Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Charles Farrell, Actor, Dies at 88; Made Debut in 'Seventh Heaven'
description: Charles Farrell, the gentle-mannered actor whose career spanned four decades, ranging from silent films to talkies to the 1950's television series ''My Little Margie,'' died on Sunday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif. He was 88 years old.

title: Interior Secretary Questions Law on Endangered Species
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. says Congress should consider modifying the Endangered Species Act so that protection of animals and plants is balanced against benefits to society from certain kinds of development.

title: Stroh Is Interested In Acquiring Heileman
description: The Stroh Brewery Company said today that it was interested in acquiring the G. Heileman Brewing Company, a unit of Bond Corporation Holdings, the beleaguered company of the Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond.

title: An Anti-Insect Sunscreen
description: A new sunscreen that promises to take the bite out of enjoying the outdoors is now on the market. Called Treo, it was introduced last month by Primavera Products Inc., of Northvale, N.J., and is a combination moisturizer, sunscreen and insect repellent.

title: PHLCorp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kerr Addison Mines reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Defense Says Noriega's Lawyers Met Castro
description: Lawyers for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega met in March with President Fidel Castro of Cuba, who provided them with documents that will help defend the former Panamanian leader against drug-smuggling charges, a defense lawyer said today.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS ;

title: United Pilots' Unit Ratifies Accord
description: The United Airlines pilots' union said its executive council had ratified a tentative collective bargaining agreement, completing organized labor's formal commitment to create the nation's largest employee-owned company. United Airlines, the nation's second-largest airline, is a subsidiary of the Chicago-based UAL Corporation. A $6.8 billion management and pilots' bid for UAL fell through last year and was replaced by a planned $4.4 billion employee buyout of the airline.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 12, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Opera on Rock
description: ''Rimshot,'' an opera about the rise and fall of a rock-and-roll musician, will be presented at 8 o'clock tonight at the Pace Downtown Theater, Schimmel Center for the Arts, Pace Plaza, 3 Spruce Street, at Gold Street. The opera features music by Russell Currie and a libretto by Ron Singer. The cast consists of members of the Orra Chamber Ensemble; the director is Jennifer Johanos. Tickets are $15 ($8 for students and the elderly). Information: 346-1715 or 620-4294.

title: Piedmont Management reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MILITARY SERVICES PROPOSING SLASHES IN EXISTING FORCES
description: Responding to instructions from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, the military services have prepared new long-term spending plans that call for a major contraction of the armed forces by the end of the decade.

title: Till Death (or Maybe Trade) Do Us Part
description: By The Associated Press

title: Sixers Hold Off Late Rally
description: Charles Barkley scored 34 points and Philadelphia withstood a furious fourth-quarter rally to beat Chicago, 118-112, tonight and cut the Bulls' lead to 2-1 in their Eastern Conference semifinal series.

title: Joffrey Series Is Canceled At Berkeley
description: The Joffrey Ballet, in turmoil since the May 1 resignation of Gerald Arpino, its artistic director and resident choreographer, will not perform as scheduled at Zellerbach Hall at the University of California at Berkeley. Its season, which would have run from July 17 to 29, was canceled yesterday by Cal Performances, the sponsoring organization, when the Joffrey was unable to provide assurances that Mr. Arpino's ballets, which he withdrew from the repertory, would be performed as scheduled. According to Friday's San Francisco Examiner, a Cal Performances representative said that the information was needed for advertising purposes.

title: U.S. to Push for Death Penalty in a Drug Slaying
description: Federal prosecutors say they will seek the death penalty for two men charged with murder in the first use of a 1988 Federal law allowing the death penalty for murders committed to further drug conspiracies.

title: Sevenson Environmental reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Velarde To Left, Yankees To Victory
description: By the time the game started, Dave Winfield had already taken off his Yankee uniform, changed back into his street clothes and left the Kingdome, his career with the team apparently at an end. But life with the Yankees goes on. While Winfield returned to his hotel room to ponder his next move, the Yankees recovered from their dreadful stay in Oakland, bringing their three-game losing streak to its own conclusion.

title: Bank Shareholder
description: A Washington businessman, John J. Mason, who controls a 6.4 percent stake in the Washington Bancorporation, said he might make a proposal that could result ''in changes in the present board of directors or management'' of the bank holding company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Mason also said he might acquire additional Washington Bancorporation shares. Mr. Mason is the former chairman of the Washington-based National Savings and Trust Company, which is now the Crestar Financial Corporation.

title: Forte Pleads Not Guilty
description: Chet Forte, the former Columbia basketball star who won nine Emmy Awards as a television director and producer with ABC Sports before leaving in 1987 to become an independent producer, pleaded not guilty yesterday in United States District Court in Camden, N.J., to charges of mail fraud, transporting stolen property across state lines, and failure to file a Federal tax return in 1987.

title: Keating Home In Foreclosure
description: A California bank has begun to foreclose on the home of Charles H. Keating Jr., the financier whose scandal-ridden Lincoln Savings and Loan Association was taken over by the Government.

title: P&F Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After payment of preferred dividends.

title: College to Reconsider Decision to Admit Men
description: The trustees of Mills College will reconsider their decision to admit male undergraduates, the school's president said Thursday, but will reverse their vote only if another way to improve the school's finances can be devised.

title: Big Strike by State Workers in Nicaragua
description: About 60,000 Government workers staged sit-in strikes today, demanding 200 percent pay increases and paralyzing the new administration as it struggles to rebuild the economy.

title: Winfield an Angel? Yes. No. Maybe.
description: The feud that has raged for years between Dave Winfield and his boss, George Steinbrenner, rose to a new and even more bizarre level today when the Yankees announced they had traded the 38-year-old outfielder to the California Angels. Winfield, citing the basic labor agreement between major league baseball's players and owners, refused to accept the trade, leaving the status of the deal unclear.

title: Computer Factory reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest quarter included a $5,394,000 pretax charge against net income, which included an adjustment on inventory and a reserve for the potential expenses associated with the closing of underperforming stores.

title: Nobel Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Dollar Posts Sharp Drop Against Yen
description: The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen yesterday, reflecting some improved confidence in Japan and the follow-through of the dollar's steep decline against the West German mark and other European currencies earlier in the week.

title: Your Money;   The 'Kiddie Tax' And Summer Jobs
description: With summer approaching, many students would like to find summer jobs. Some parents, on the other hand, being vaguely aware of the ''kiddie tax,'' are concerned about the effect that might have on the family's finances.

title: Federal Realty Investment Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: New Producer for NBC 'Nightly News'
description: NBC announced the appointment of a new executive producer of the ''Nightly News'' yesterday, a move that a network executive said signaled that Jane Pauley would soon become co-anchor with Tom Brokaw of the evening newscast.

title: Books of The Times;   A First Novel of Conflict Over a Ban on Abortion
description: The Amendment

title: Businesses Offering Variant on H.M.O.'s
description: Already beset by a confusing system of health care, consumers are now being offered yet another medical plan - a re-invented health maintenance organization.

title: Pope, in Mexico, Faces Rising Protestant Tide
description: All week long, the Government and the Roman Catholic faithful of southeastern Mexico prepared for the arrival of Pope John Paul II today. But at the Complete Evangelical Church of God here, the visit was greeted with an indifference bordering on hostility.

title: Nairobi Journal;   An Envoy Who Starts Fires to Get Things Started
description: Smith Hempstone, the American Ambassador to this East African nation, was not bashful about coveting the job. He recounts approaching George Bush before he won the Presidential election and saying quite bluntly, ''When you are President I would like to be your Ambassador to Kenya.''

title: MICC Investments Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $26.8 million on the sale of the gas and propane businesses of Inter-city Gas Corp. Revenue figures were not available. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Sale of PTL Network May Be Near
description: A court-appointed trustee says he will sell Jim Bakker's PTL satellite network to Oral Roberts University for $6 million at the end of the month unless he finds a buyer for the television ministry's entire complex.

title: Justice Aide Quits Amid Tensions Over Thornburgh's Stewardship
description: The second highest official at the Justice Department, Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer, abruptly announced his resignation today, two weeks after he was forced to withdraw a letter of support for stringent sentencing guidelines for corporations convicted of crimes.

title: Blackstone in Lodging-Chain Deal
description: LEAD: Trying to strengthen its financial position, the owner of the Howard Johnson and Ramada franchise system said today that it had signed an agreement in principle to sell 65 percent of the two lodging chains to Blackstone Capital Partners in a transaction worth about $200 million.

title: Walshire Assurance Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
69,000 Toys Are Recalled
description: Two manufacturers are recalling more than 69,000 toys because they contain parts that present choking hazards to small children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today. Goldwell International, Inc., is recalling 13,583 Public Telephone toys that have been sold nationally since March 1989, the agency said, and Target Stores has recalled 27,000 My First Buddy Wrecker trucks, 27,000 My First Buddy Pumper fire trucks and 1,497 Potpourri Baby Dolls. Consumers are urged to return the toys to the stores where they were bought, for a refund.

title: Sterling Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Supradur Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Net income Included in this year's quarterly results is a foreign currency exchange loss of $33,000 compared to a loss of $3,000 for the same quarter in 1989. Also included are research and development expenses of $163,000 compared to $18,000 in the first quarter of 1989.

title: A.T.& T. Network
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it was introducing a learning network combining classroom curriculum with electronic mail messaging for the education market. The A.T.& T. Learning Network matches geographically diverse classrooms by curriculum interest and grade level to form a learning circle in which students share ideas and information via A.T.&T. Mail, the company said. A complete educational package including curriculum, software and network use costs about $350 a semester.

title: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $3,900,000, or 8 cents a share. c-Net loss Share earnings are after accretion of preferred stock dividends of $11.6 million for 1990 and $11.4 million for 1989. The company said latest quarter operating profit remained stable, reflecting a $3 million charge related to an additional anticipated loss on the 1990 goodwill games. It also said first quarter 1989 operating profit included a $3 million credit for the Atlanta Hawks' share of entry fees for expansion of NBA teams.

title: Daily News and Gannett Win Writing Prize
description: Reporters for The Daily News and Gannett Westchester-Rockland Newspapers have won the 1990 Meyer Berger Award for their writings about New York City, Columbia University announced yesterday.

title: Michigan Retirement Fund Opposes G.M. Pension Rise
description: The Michigan State Retirement System, which holds 8.8 million shares of stock in the General Motors Corporation, will vote against a proposal to increase the pensions of the company's retiring chairman, Roger B. Smith, and 3,350 executives by $41.6 million, state officials said yesterday.

title: Adrian Brodey, Dermatologist, 78
description: Dr. Adrian Brodey, a dermatologist for more than 40 years, died of prostate cancer yesterday at his house in Lawrence, L.I. He was 78 years old.

title: Osborn Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included non- recurring gain of $5.6 million from sale of radio properties.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Walker Percy, the Southern novelist, misstated his age and, in some copies, gave inconsistent birthdates for him. He was 73 years old and was born on May 28, 1916.

title: Oshawa Group reports earnings for Qtr to April 21
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Lithuania's Leaders Know What They're Doing;   Not a Secession
description: To the Editor:

title: Pro-Met Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dibrell Brothers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that on April 9 it finalized the previously reported purchase of R.J. Reynolds Tabacos Do Brasil for $50 million, subject to adjustments based on audit, and the simultaneous sale of Reynolds- Brazil's cigarette business to Philip Morris.

title: Soviets Buy More Wheat
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 250,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery next month, the Agriculture Department said today. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the wheat had been sold by two companies, which would receive subsidies under the Export Enhancement Program.

title: 2d Lithuanian Sets Himself Ablaze, Near Soviet Border
description: A Lithuanian doused his body with alcohol and set himself on fire at a border crossing between the Soviet Union and Hungary, suffering serious injuries, the police said today.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Ex-Communists Stirring Up Unrest In the East, Bonn Official Asserts
description: East Germany's former Communists are inciting unrest among workers who fear that they will lose their jobs as the nation unites with West Germany, a West German official charged today.

title: Corrections
description: The Auctions column in Weekend yesterday misstated the total receipts at a contemporary art sale at Christie's on Monday and Tuesday. The total for 352 lots was $53.8 million, not $71.1 million.

title: A Troubled Winery Where Debt Is Aging
description: When Paul M. Schlem created the Vintners International Company three years ago by acquiring Paul Masson, Taylor California Cellars and the Taylor Wine Company of New York, he planned to sell assets to reduce debt, cut overhead and move these once- strong brands into the higher end of the market.

title: A President Strong on Civil Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Guide to Low Light Bills And Bright Lights, Too
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Cellular reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Laimbeer Questionable
description: While the Detroit Pistons were practicing yesterday morning in Auburn Hills, Mich., Bill Laimbeer, the starting center, was at a local hospital having his sore left knee examined and treated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will never allow any group or any person to turn to violence or the threat of violence to intimidate others, no matter how legitimate their anger or frustration may be.'' - Mayor David N. Dinkins. [1:1]

title: Murderer Executed in Missouri After Supreme Court Lifts a Stay
description: Dale Riley, a spokesman at the Potosi Correctional Center, said that when Mr. Stokes learned that his appeals had been denied, he asked for a sedative but took the news calmly. ''His only comment was that he did not want any personal witnesses,'' the spokesman said.

title: SEOUL'S TWO SIDES SEEM FRUSTRATED
description: As life returned to normal on Seoul's scarred downtown streets, several dissident leaders conceded today that the Korean public seemed to distrust the demonstrators as much as they distrusted the Government.

title: Critics Say 'Star Wars' Test May Be a Treaty Violation
description: The Pentagon yesterday began a ''Star Wars'' test that critics say comes the closest to violating the 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty out of all the experiments conducted so far in the seven-year $20 billion program of research on the anti-missile system.

title: N.Y.'s Backward High Court
description: LEAD: Throughout the 1980's, the New York Court of Appeals, the state's highest court, rendered decisions in housing, education and employment that have set back the increasingly difficult struggle of minorities to achieve equality.

title: Smithfield Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a charge of $115,000 from the discontinuance of the company's plans to franchise its retail stores in North Carolina. c-Net income

title: Dow Gains Points; Volume Up
description: Falling interest rates and growing signs that inflationary pressures are on the way down helped lift stock prices sharply yesterday in the heaviest trading in five months.

title: Bernard Lias, Dancer, 44
description: Bernard Lias, a dancer and choreographer who toured with the Alvin Ailey company in the 1970's, died on Wednesday in Manhattan. The cause of death was not disclosed. He was 44 years old.

title: Arbitrator Is Likely To Decide
description: The Yankees said yesterday they had traded Dave Winfield to the California Angels, but George Nicolau will most likely be the judge of that.

title: Too Late Now! Budget Will Be the Tardiest.
description: They did it.

title: Review/Music;   From Folky Purity to Imprecation
description: Sinead O'Connor's songs probe emotions that most pop tidies up. Instead of romance, she sings about obsessive desire; after a breakup, she snarls her anger or bewails unbearable loneliness. When a lover has died, she keens over his tomb (and she has more songs about dead lovers than any other woman in rock). She is victim and avenger, mourner and accuser, with a voice that veers from folky purity to rasps and shrieks, sometimes within one sustained syllable. Yet she's hardly an out-of-control banshee. In recordings and in concert, she combines fervor and detachment. Her voice tears through songs with a somber sense of purpose and concentration.

title: Evolution in Europe;   PEREZ DE CUELLAR VISITS ALBANIANS
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations flew here today for talks with Albania's Communist leaders. The Albanians see the visit as an opportunity to advance the opening of their isolated and restricted country.

title: Students Persist In Occupation Of Campus Hall
description: Dozens of students at John Jay College of Criminal Justice continued to occupy an administration building last night after a violent confrontation with the police on Thursday that left at least five students injured, student leaders said.

title: Irving Kobrin, Executive, 87
description: Irving Kobrin, a retired business executive, died of pneumonia yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Barr Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Kids' TV: A Near-Blank Screen
description: LEAD: In the 1970's, while giving her class a history test, a fifth-grade teacher in New Canaan, Conn., was startled to hear musical murmurs. Under their breaths, most of her students were singing the ''ABC Schoolhouse Rock'' song about the preamble to the Constitution. Almost the entire class answered the question correctly.

title: Hershey Oil Deal
description: The American Exploration Company said it had agreed to acquire the Hershey Oil Corporation in a deal valued at $40 million. American Exploration said it would pay $7 a share for up to 20 percent of Hershey's common stock and exchange 1.6 American Exploration common shares for each remaining Hershey share. Hershey's stock rose 25 cents today, to $5.625, on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Ellen M. Ross Marries Christopher S. Sarafian
description: Ellen Margaret Ross, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald E. Ross of Boca Raton, Fla., was married there yesterday at St. Joan of Arc Roman Catholic Church to Christopher Scott Sarafian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Peter Sarafian of Bronxville, N.Y. The Rev. Martin Devereaux performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. John R. McMahon and the Revs. Kenneth McKenna, William E. Warren and Alfred Isacsson.

title: Perpetual Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The New York City Council's Committee on Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs was swamped yesterday by laudatory speeches for the man who help changed American ballet, the Russian immigrant who founded the School of American Ballet and the New York City Ballet. And at the end, the committee responded with a chorus of ayes to a motion to rename West 63d Street from Broadway to Columbus Avenue GEORGE BALANCHINE Way.

title: Minnesota Widens Rights Act To Counter High Court Move
description: In a direct countermove to the United States Supreme Court, Minnesota has expanded its human rights law to broaden the rights of employees and subcontractors who want to take job discrimination complaints to the state's courts.

title: Retail Sales Show Plunge of 0.6% for April
description: Retail sales, held back by another big drop in auto demand, fell by six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest setback in six months, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Jews Urge Washington To Oppose U.N. Move
description: Leading American Jewish organizations urged the Bush Administration today to oppose any United Nations Security Council resolution criticizing Israel for settling Soviet Jews in the territories it occupied after the 1967 war.

title: Olympic Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Students End Sit-In at Rutgers After 11 Days
description: An 11-day student sit-in at an administration building at Rutgers University ended peacefully this morning without arrests.

title: Pennsylvania Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Paper Says Pretoria Put Germs in Namibian Water
description: As part of an international sabotage campaign that stretched as far as Europe, a secret unit of the South African Defense Ministry put cholera germs in drinking water in Namibia, a newspaper said today. But a health official said extensive tests turned up no traces of the germ.

title: Robert I. Herzog, Stockbroker, 89
description: Robert I. Herzog, a retired stockbroker, died of pneumonia on April 27 at the Joseph Morse Geriatric Center in West Palm Beach, Fla. He was 89 years old and lived in West Palm Beach.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Salute to Israel Parade, Fifth Avenue from 57th to 86th Streets will be closed tomorrow from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Gooden Strikes Out 15 in 7 Innings and Drives In 4 to Lead Mets
description: With his bat, with his arm and with his old-time flair, Dwight Gooden struck out 15 batters in seven innings, knocked in 4 runs and led the Mets to a 9-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers last night in his most compelling performance of an anxious season.

title: Gustav H. Koven, 80; Led a Tank Company
description: Gustav H. Koven, chairman of L. O. Koven and Brothers Inc., manufacturer of steel tanks in Dover, N.J., died on Thursday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Green Village, N.J., and Bequia, St. Vincent.

title: Albany: Better, but Still Ducking
description: Budget-making this season in Albany continues to give New Yorkers a most discomfiting insight into the failings of their political leaders. With the budget already more than a month late, the state's top elected officials are still ducking the chance to do things right.

title: Taiwan Bank Offerings Fail
description: Failure of a public offer to sell 46 million Government shares in three state-run commercial banks will delay Taiwan's efforts to privatize state companies, bank officials and stock analysts said today.

title: Court Imposes Limit on Indian Rights to Resources
description: In a decision with far-reaching consequences, a Federal judge has ruled that northern Wisconsin's ''harvestable natural resources'' should be split 50-50 between the state's Chippewa Indians and non-Indians.

title: Atari Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Oak Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $142,000. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $591,000.

title: U.S. Soccer Team Seeks 3d in Row
description: It has been nearly a year since the United States national soccer team won three consecutive games. This year, two in a row has been a rarity.

title: No Dice for Saturday Night
description: LEAD: There's something wonderfully perverse in the fact that it took a comedian from one of America's more off-color television shows to try to finally place a limit on the level of ugliness that can be passed off as humor.

title: PRODUCER PRICES FALL 0.3% IN SIGN INFLATION IS EASING
