description: The wintertime jump in the nation's inflation rate appears to be wearing off, and inflation seems to be settling back to the moderate level that has prevailed over the last two years, a Government report indicated yesterday.

title: 2 Salvadoran Army Cadets Testify on Slaying of Jesuits
description: Two military cadets who had been receiving instruction abroad testified today before the judge investigating the slaying of six Jesuit priests and two women last November. The cadets' testimony was not released.

title: 'This City Is Sick of Violence': Dinkins's Address
description: Following are excerpts from a transcript of Mayor David N. Dinkins's address, ''An Affirmation of Tolerance and Respect,'' at City Hall last night, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: FFP Partners reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $326,000, or 9 cents a share. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $32,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Cru of Dreams
description: I used to read Spicy Detective when I wanted to kick my fantasy gear into overdrive; now I read wine columns in the newspapers.

title: Printronix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net loss Year earlier periods are after a pretax provision of $2,816,000 for the restructuring of manufacturing operations.

title: Lithuania's Leaders Know What They're Doing
description: To the Editor:

title: Inflation Spurt in Britain
description: Britain's annualized inflation rate leaped sharply to an eight-year high of 9.4 percent in April from 8.1 percent in March. Inflation last reached 9.4 percent in April 1982 and has climbed to its current level from a low of 3.3 percent in January 1988. The main components in the latest rise were the introduction of a poll tax to finance local government and the increase in duties on alcohol, tobacco and gasoline.

title: New Goddess of Democracy To Haunt Beijing's Leaders
description: Over the next month or so, China is expected to have to deal with a new irritant: the Goddess of Democracy, a 225-foot ship that is preparing to broadcast a stream of pro-democracy news and commentaries to the Chinese people.

title: Lawmakers Assail Albany on Welfare Bill Delay
description: Ten members of New York's Congressional delegation, including Senators Daniel Patrick Moynihan and Alfonse M. D'Amato, have written Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders to complain about the state's delay in passing welfare reform legislation.

title: China Listens
description: By releasing 211 political prisoners in jail since the post-Tiananmen crackdown, Beijing eases some of the suffering wrought by its repressive ways. It also refutes the facile myth that Chinese leaders can't be influenced by outside pressure to respect minimal human rights.

title: Older Officers Moving Back To Foot Duty
description: For 29 years, Joseph Diliberti has been a police officer on the Lower East Side. After more than two decades on patrol, he was rewarded with a desk job, giving lectures to people on how to prevent crime.

title: Mexico's Drug Poison
description: The message President Carlos Salinas de Gortari wants to send the U.S., he says, is that: ''Mexico is changing. We want to be in the international arena. It's the only way to stay Mexican.''

title: Burlington Coat Factory Warehouse Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said that operating results for the third quarter were directly affected by the shift in the Easter selling season from March, of a year-ago, to April of this year. This resulted in the shifting of about $12 million in net sales to the fourth quarter of the current fiscal year.

title: Beliefs
description: Do people like Marion Pritchard hold a vital clue to the moral education of future generations?

title: Nepal King Orders Rewriting of Constitution
description: In a move that caught the newly installed Government by surprise, the King of Nepal named a panel today to rewrite the country's Constitution without consulting his Prime Minister.

title: Mexico Opens Bank Debate
description: The Mexican Congress opened debate today on a bill that would end the Government's full control of the nation's banking industry.

title: Review/Television;   Drama of Wife Beating, Without Sensationalism
description: An intelligently thought-out script acted with powerful but restrained emotion makes ''Shattered Dreams,'' a new made-for-television film about wife abuse to be seen tomorrow at 9 P.M. on CBS, a moving and believable drama.

title: The Funny Side of Social Issues
description: LEAD: ''Two feet off the ground,'' said John Mortimer, the English novelist, barrister, dramatist, translator, television writer, memoirist and all-purpose funnyman. ''That's where my characters are. I write a kind of heightened realism to achieve a comic and slightly theatrical effect. People have compared my writing to G.

title: FLYING SPRING VISITORS
description: About the only place bees ads wasps are not found is Antarctica. In this country the honeybee is so venerated that a joint resolution has been introduced in the House of Representatives to make it the national insect. Here are the most frequent insect vistors at this time of year and what, if anything, should be done about them. Be cautious when bees are about; if you are allergic and get stung, get medical help at once.

title: Hoechst Unit's Net Off 33.8%
description: The Hoechst Celanese Corporation said on Thursday that its earnings fell 33.8 percent in the first quarter because of weakness in several markets for its chemical and textile products.

title: University Chief Is Charged With Making Indecent Calls
description: The president of American University was charged today with two misdemeanor counts of making indecent telephone calls, the Fairfax County police said.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Sex Magazines and Massage Parlors Test Hungary's New Limits
description: Pornography, long banned by the Communists as the worst spawn of Western decadence, has broken into the open in Hungary, taking its place on the newsstands as another example of a newly emboldened press.

title: Rickey Lee Jones to Open Riverstage Concerts
description: Reebok Riverstage, an outdoor series of rock and pop concerts, is to begin on June 13 with a show by the singers Rickey Lee Jones and Lyle Lovett. The series, which runs through Sept 9, is to include appearances by B.B. King, Ziggy Marley and the Melody Makers, Tears for Fears, Barry White and others.

title: Arts Endowment Plans Its Strategy
description: One year after attacks on the National Endowment for the Arts began, the members of the National Council on the Arts - Presidentially appointed advisers to the agency -gathered here this weekend to determine how to respond to their opponents.

title: Catholic Diocese Drops Speech by a Kennedy
description: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence ordered a church high school to cancel a speech last Sunday by State Representative Patrick Kennedy, son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, because he supports a woman's right to abortion.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday about the stocks of cellular telephone companies misstated the value of the plant, property and equipment included in a recent acquisition by the GTE Corporation.

title: Manager Out at G.M. Plant
description: Patricia Carrigan, who at one time was the only woman running a General Motors Corporation assembly plant, abruptly retired two weeks ago from a G.M. parts plant in Bay City, Mich., and news reports have swirled in recent days about misadministration of a benefit plan for workers at the plant.

title: Cubs Hit 3 Homers in First But Stumble to Reds by 7-5
description: Chris Sabo's three-run double off Mitch Williams with two out in the eighth inning tonight rallied the Cincinnati Reds past the Chicago Cubs, 7-5.

title: Some Police Skeptical of Any Plans to Roust Beggars
description: New York transit officials yesterday promised an aggressive effort to enforce a ban on subway panhandling, but some transit officers suggested that it won't be that easy.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-7

title: Amax Bid To Acquire Peabody
description: The Peabody Coal Company received a $1.25 billion bid yesterday from Amax Inc., the large New York metals and mining company.

title: Quadra Logic Tech reports earnings for Year to Jan. 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Local Boy Makes Third
description: For months, the only thing on Mike McCarthy's mind was winning the Central Park portion of the Tour de Trump bicycle race yesterday.

title: Country Lake Foods reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Goods Linked to Drugs Are Seized by Agents
description: Federal agents today seized houses, cars, and boats bought with millions of dollars unearthed from drums buried on a farm owned by a reputed drug kingpin, the authorities said.

title: Oregon's Brave Medical Experiment
description: Last week the state of Oregon announced that it would curtail many medical services for the poor -but the move does not demonstrate hardheartedness so much as hardheaded compassion. In a brave experiment, the state hopes to make basic medical services more widely available with intelligent rationing of health care.

title: Maker of Aerospace Fasteners Pleads Guilty
description: The largest maker of aerospace fasteners pleaded guilty today to conspiracy and agreed to pay $18 million in fines and costs to settle Federal charges that it had schemed for 15 years to falsify test reports on parts.

title: Jerusalem Dispute Irks O'Connor
description: John Cardinal O'Connor of New York has strongly condemned the presence of armed Israeli settlers in the traditional Christian quarter of Jerusalem's Old City.

title: CHRONICLE
description: SAMMY DAVIS JR.'s health has deteriorated steadily since the cancer-stricken entertainer left a hospital eight weeks ago to recuperate at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif., friends said yesterday. His weight was reported to have dropped to about 60 pounds. His publicity agent, Susan Reynolds, would not comment except to say that Mr. Davis was resting and ''there has been no change.''

title: In the Region: Long Island
description: Recent Sales

title: Some Computer Conversation Is Changing Human Contact
description: Patricia Gemmell met Brian Dear by replying to a friendly note that appeared on her computer screen one day, a message sent on a computer network linking her machine with many others. She responded with a computer quip of her own and the two, who were programmers at different campuses of the University of Maryland, struck up a friendship that went on electronically for weeks before they finally met. Two years later, they were married.

title: Sometimes All of New York Seems a Vast, Endless Movie
description: WHEN the Brooklyn pizza joint went up in flames ignited by racial friction in ''Do the Right Thing,'' did this mean movies are telling the world the wrong thing about New York? When Popeye Doyle, pursuing a French connection, just missed the 42d Street shuttle in pursuit of a bad guy, did this mean that crime in New York waits on no man? When King Kong pulverized an elevated train, then scaled the Empire State Building, grabbing a girl and an airplane, was this bad for New York's image?

title: Ewing Steps Up And Delivers a Lot
description: From the Detroit Pistons' perspective, Patrick Ewing scored too many points and took too many free throws yesterday.

title: Rewards of Public Service Are Growing
description: TO some, it seemed like business as usual: the nation's largest owner and operator of private prisons purchased 40 acres from a group of local officials, including a State Senator who was instrumental in persuading the Legislature to approve a contract with the company to build and operate a women's prison on the site.

title: 'A DEATH I MAY HAVE CAUSED'
description: LEAD:

title: Fresh-Air Guest Arrives When Sons Go to Camp
description: SOME parents, when their children go away to camp, sit back and relax, thankful for the temporary respite.

title: 4 Questioned in Desecrations
description: The police detained four neo-Nazi sympathizers today in the desecration of a Jewish cemetery and the mutilation of a corpse, acts that have stirred new fears of anti-Semitism in France. But a police officer who declined to be identified said it was unlikely that neo-Nazis from Avignon were responsible for the desecration of the graves, in nearby Carpentras. He speculated that the vandals had come from elsewhere. Under French law, the suspects must be freed within 48 hours unless they are arrested and charged.

title: Abortion Law: Vital Compromise
description: POLITICS creates unusual alliances, as the passage of Connecticut's recently enacted abortion law shows.

title: Bridgeport Confronting Growing Homicide Rate
description: LEAD: BRIDGEPORT police officials have recorded more than twice as many homicides so far this year as for the same period last year. Acting Police Chief Guy Izzo said that as of Wednesday, the city, Connecticut's largest, had 26 reported homicides. In the same period in 1989, there were 10 to 12, he said.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: PARSONS' MILL, by Timothy Lewontin. (Plume, $8.95.) Seeking the ennobling virtues of hard work, an overeducated New Englander takes a job at a Vermont sawmill. ''A delightful, surprisingly absorbing account'' of his year as an apprentice sawyer, this book ''approaches the gung-ho participatory journalism that George Plimpton performed in his athletic days,'' Bill Kent said here last year.

title: In Pelham, Bovine Heraldry and a Wild, Wonderful Frontier
description: The Pelham Art Center's ''American Cowboy: The Myth and the Reality'' opened a few weeks ago but began months earlier with a publicity campaign. In addition to a blizzard of announcements, this included a search in the New York City area for a live cowboy to star at the opening in return for, among other prizes, lifetime membership in the center.

title: Wheeling Out Iacocca For a Long-Shot Attack
description: A DECADE after lurching to the brink of bankruptcy, the Chrysler Corporation is in trouble again, and again Chrysler has resorted to extreme measures. But the company is not asking for a bailout. It is simply bringing out Lee Iacocca.

title: Perspectives: Astoria's Waterfront;   The New Addition to the Queens Skyline
description: AN unfamiliar sight on the Queens shore in Astoria has been capturing the attention of viewers from Manhattan and the Triborough Bridge lately. At a bend in the waterfront called Pot Cove stands a broad new building with a pyramid-like roof, recently topped out at its full 23 stories.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

The Cheerful, Trusty, Affordable Bloom
description: LEAD: AMONG the gifts May offers are garden centers in bloom. A profusion of splendid color greets the browsing gardener: dazzling pink petunias, snow-white alyssum and lavender ageratum destined to border flaming red geraniums. Tray after tray of seedlings wait to be transferred from the confines of four-inch-square plastic pots to the rich earth of newly spaded gardens.

title: Groups as Targets
description: To the Editor:

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Palisades
description: THERE is a magical quality about Palisades, a three-square-mile heavily wooded hamlet just 12 miles north of the George Washington Bridge. Many of the houses have no numbers, just storybook names like Pirate's Lair, Captain John, Chateau Hash, Laundry, Ding Dong. The telltale signs of modern development - condominiums, supermarkets, shopping centers and fast-food outlets - are conspicuous by their absence.

title: Suffolk Wrestling With Fate of Estates
description: LEAD: PERCHED atop a long, rambling hill and overlooking Huntington Harbor sits a fairy tale-like castle named Coindre Hall. The 52-room, French chateau-style mansion represents the largest of six Suffolk County-owned estates and remains the most problematic.

title: INSIDE
description: Tensions in Singapore

title: Eleanor Cornell Married to Mark Hays Gottwald
description: Eleanor Van Rensselaer Cornell, a daughter of Mrs. Mortimer Ryon of Solebury, Pa., and M. Keen Cornell of Bear Creek, Pa., was married in Solebury yesterday at the home of her mother and stepfather to Mark Hays Gottwald, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce C. Gottwald of Richmond. The Rev. Charles L. Orr, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: The New German Era Begins
description: The new era of German ascendance is already beginning.

title: Their Art Is an Extended Family Affair
description: LEAD: GROWING up in the household of Sidney and Joan Lewisohn Simon had its advantages, four Simon siblings agree, especially if, as it turned out, four of the five children in the family eventually became artists.

title: Miss Shea Weds George Wheatley 3d
description: Mary Ann Shea, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Shea of Brookville, L.I., was married yesterday to George Milholland Wheatley 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wheatley Jr. of Old Brookville and Bridgehampton, L.I. The Rev. Charles A. Ribaudo officiated at St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I.

title: THE SHEER NECESSITY FOR POETRY
description: THE COMPLETE POEMS OF ANNA AKHMATOVA

title: A BOTANICAL FEAST FOR ROYAL TABLES
description: The profusion of imaginative porcelain designs throughout Europe in the 18th century came at a time when botanists were documenting the flora of the continent. This spurred the production of one of the most remarkable dinner services ever devised: Flora Danica, a set of 1,802 pieces, each decorated with a different wild plant of Denmark.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

To Keep Hispanic Students, Colleges Must Think Anew
description: LEAD: WE are losing many of our minority students at alarming rates. In the area of higher education, Hispanic students have traditionally faced a formidable range of barriers that have impeded their success. Although access is a particularly perplexing problem for this group, a more pressing concern is how to keep those who have entered institutions of higher learning from dropping out.

title: Lodging a Complaint
description: It appears that a Senate ethics committee investigation may hit Senator Dave Durenberger where he lives. The panel, which was already looking into the Minnesota Republican's involvement in a book deal and his use of a limousine for personal travel, voted unanimously last week to consider whether he misused Senate funds that he got as reimbursement for staying at his own Minneapolis condominium apartment. The committee said it found ''substantial credible evidence'' that Mr. Durenberger had violated Senate rules by seeking payment for stays in his own residence. The panel also said it would look into possible impropriety in the backdating of documents relating to the ownership of the one-bedroom apartment. Mr. Durenberger, who repaid the Senate $11,005 in January after another panel found he was not entitled to certain reimbursements for using the apartment, denied any wrongdoing. He said he used the Minneapolis apartment as he would use a hotel, and that his principal residence back in Minnesota was 70 miles away, at his parents' home in the town of Avon.

title: Bible Tax Exemption Voided
description: A Federal appeals court has unanimously struck down a 1939 North Carolina law that exempted Bibles from the state sales tax. The United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, ruled Thursday that exempting the Bible, but not other literature, ''forces the state to discriminate on the basis of the contents of a book, text, or other published work, which is intolerable under the First Amendment.''

title: Norwegian Fare and Fitness at One Spot
description: OSLO, in a fitness club at the southern edge of Stamford, is a happy development, as Scandinavians have been all but invisible in the ethnic restaurant revival that has overtaken Connecticut in the past 10 years.

title: A Tie For Ajax And The U.S.
description: For the second consecutive game, the United States national soccer team gave up an easy goal, but this time it cost the team a victory.

title: Alison Denne Marries Brooks Foehl
description: Alison Joan Denne, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Denne of Riverside, Conn., and Brooks Lewis Foehl, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Foehl of Needham, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers officiated at the First Congregational Church in Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: A Fresh Start for Head Start?
description: LEAD: President Bush's proposal to add a half billion dollars to the national Head Start budget could be a brilliant investment. It could be the cornerstone of a national early-childhood development policy and the down payment on his promise to be the ''education President.'' And it could be the best response to the Gallup poll finding that 58 percent of Americans are willing to pay more taxes to care for young children of working parents and 69 percent would pay more taxes to finance Head

title: BEST SELLERS: May 20, 1990
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978. 2 1 4 SEPTEMBER, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $22.95.) Guests from many parts of the world encounter their often unexpected destinies during a get-together in a small Scottish town. 3 3 12 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 4 2 9 THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $21.95.) Jason Bourne plans to infiltrate the ruthless Medusa Brigade. 5 4 4 SKINNY LEGS AND ALL, by Tom Robbins. (Bantam, $19.95.) The horror and humor of the upcoming apocalypse are played out at a restaurant near the United Nations. 6 6 5 THE EVENING NEWS, by Arthur Hailey. (Doubleday, $21.95.) Life as lived by two competitive television correspondents. 7 5 6 MASQUERADE, by Janet Dailey. (Little, Brown, $19.95.) The political pundit and baseball buff describes the craft of the game. 2 2 16 MEGATRENDS 2000, by John Naisbitt and Patricia Aburdene. (Morrow, $21.95.) Prognostications for the next decade. 3 43 16 BARBARIANS AT THE GATE, by Bryan Burrough and John Helyar. (Harper & Row, $22.95.) The 1988 battle for control of RJR Nabisco. 4 5 8 MEANS OF ASCENT, by Robert A. Caro. (Knopf, $24.95.) Lyndon Johnson's seven-year pursuit of a seat in the Senate, won in 1948 by 87 votes. 5* 3 14 HEAD FIRST, by Norman Cousins. (Dutton, $19.95.) How the brain affects the body's endocrine and immune systems. 6 8 3 IN THE ARENA, by Richard Nixon. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The 37th President reflects on his public career and private life. 7 6 34 IT WAS ON FIRE WHEN I LAY DOWN ON IT, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) Wall Street's tumultuous 1980's, as witnessed by a young bond trader. 9 11J 108 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 10 9 9 PARTING WITH ILLUSIONS, By Vladimir Pozner. (Atlantic Monthly, $19.95.) The autobiography of a man, raised in New York, who became a commenator on Radio Moscow. 11 * 10 2 LEGACIES, by Bette Bao Lord. (Knopf, $19.95.) Reflections on the Chinese experience during the past quarter-century by a writer who was born in China, raised in America. 12 12 15 THE CUCKOO'S EGG, by Clifford Stoll. (Doubleday, $19.95.) An astrophysicist tells how he stalked a computer hacker. 13 13 12 WHAT I SAW AT THE REVOLUTION, by Peggy Noonan. (Random House, $19.95.) The memoirs of a former Presidential speechwriter. 13 79 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $17.95.) Inspirational essays. 9 15 3 FLASHBACKS, by Morley Safer. (Random House, $18.95.) The observations of a journalist on revisiting Vietnam 25 years later. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 65 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's financial advice. 2 2 22 THE GREAT WALDO SEARCH, by Martin Handford. (Little, Brown, $10.95.) A book of illustrations in which the game is to find a ubiquitous chap named Waldo. 3 3 11 SECRETS ABOUT MEN EVERY WOMAN SHOULD KNOW, by Barbara De Angelis. (Delacorte, $17.95.) Ways by which women can improve their relationships with men. 4 4 12 BEWARE THE NAKED MAN WHO OFFERS YOU HIS SHIRT, by Harvey Mackay. (Morrow, $19.95.) Advice on how to get ahead in business. 5 5 3 THE BETTER HOMES AND GARDENS NEW COOKBOOK. (Meredith, $19.95.) A ring-bound version of the 10th edition.

title: Utility Is Criticized For Its Tree Trimming
description: LEAD: WHEN Hurricane Gloria struck Connecticut in 1985, falling trees interrupted electrical service for many customers. After the storm, the State Department of Public Utility Control criticized Northeast Utilities for having failed to trim the trees along its power lines, and the utility began an aggressive tree-trimming program.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Campus Life pages on April 29 incorrectly described a tenure revision proposal defeated by the faculty senate of the University of Connecticut at Storrs. It would have given graduate students, once hired, two years to finish their Ph.D. work before the faculty began to evaluate them for tenure, a process that can last up to seven years. Currently, the evaluation starts while students are still working on their Ph.D. programs.

title: Dr. Natali Franzblau Weds
description: Dr. Natali R. Franzblau, a daughter of Judith B. Haveson of New York and S. M. Chris Franzblau of Cedar Grove, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Robert A. Singer, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Herbert Singer of Roslyn, L.I. Rabbi Lawrence Kotok officiated at the Greenbrook Country Club in North Caldwell, N.J. The bride, a graduate of Tufts University, is a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at Thomas Jefferson University Hospital in Philadelphia. She received her M.D. from Albert Einstein College of Medicine, where her husband, a graduate of the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill and the State University Health Science Center in Brooklyn, is a resident in internal medicine.

title: Adirondacks Protest Clogs I-87 Near Albany
description: Hundreds of people angry over a state report on the future of the Adirondacks clogged Interstate 87 north of Albany on Friday by driving at speeds as low as 5 miles an hour, the state police said.

title: Style Makers;   Doug Fraser, Illustrator
description: In Doug Fraser's illustrations for Business Week magazine or for advertising campaigns for Lowenbrau Light, the men are muscular, their shoulders and arms outlined in black. Dark shadows cross their faces. These powerful men are often depicted standing or brooding against vast expanses of space.

title: Rating Safaris
description: To the Editor: The item about the report called Safari Rating Service (Travel Advisory, Feb. 25) piqued my interest, since I am a principal in a nature tour company that operates in Africa.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Those whose memories of the 1970's have not faded may remember Henry Wilhelm of Grinnell, Iowa. An early advocate of archival processing, Mr. Wilhelm forsook a thriving business in black-and-white print washers to investigate the fading characteristics of color films. He promised to gather independent data on all available color films and papers and to report on his results in a book.

title: Free Park Concerts to Start on July 30
description: The 26th season of free park concerts by the New York Philharmonic will begin on July 30 on the Great Lawn of Central Park, with Yoel Levi, the music director of the Atlanta Symphony, leading the orchestra in Mendelssohn's ''Italian'' Symphony and the Berlioz ''Symphonie Fantastique.''

title: Not for Publication
description: Jimmy Breslin could have used an editor. Ten days ago, in the heat of outrage at the temerity of a young Korean-American colleague who criticized one of his Newsday columns as sexist - he joked about how his homelife had deteriorated since his wife was elected to the City Council - the 61-year-old journalist stormed about the newsroom loudly loosing racial and sexual epithets about the reporter, 25-year-old Ji-Yeon Mary Yuh. Mr. Breslin, a Pulitzer Prize winner with a reputation for railing against bigotry, subsequently apologized for his comments. And, despite calls by Asian American and other journalists for Mr. Breslin's suspension, Newsday executives pronounced him sufficiently chastened. That might have been the end of it, but Mr. Breslin apparently could not resist joshing about the matter on a call-in radio talk show. His comments, said his boss, Donald Forst, ''indicated a lack of sensitivity to what continues to be a painful episode.'' Mr. Breslin was suspended for two weeks without pay. Reached at home for a comment, Mr. Breslin said, ''Leave me alone.''

title: APARTHEID FROM THE INSIDE
description: THE MIND OF SOUTH AFRICA

title: Question Of the Week;   Will Dent and Johnson Last The Season?
description: If the Mets are not above .500 by June 1, Johnson will be gone. The knowledgeable Mets fan realizes that it's not the manager's fault. The Mets are simply not that good and pitching alone isn't enough. The team batting average has been low and the Mets are very weak defensively.

title: Harlem Boy Finds 'Big Hugs' In Jersey
description: DAVID RIVERA, who is 6 years old, knows what he likes best about visiting the Anderson family in Brick Township.

title: Insurance Payments For Cancer Care
description: In response to Matilda Cuomo's article on breast cancer (Opinion, April 8, ''Taking Aim at a Preventable Tragedy''), I am the perfect example of what she advocates.

title:
DINING OUT;

A Place to Try Unusual Chinese Dishes
description: LEAD: CHINESE restaurants that have opened in the last few years are frequently elegant and modern, a far cry from the plain shopping center type or the fancier but sometimes garish establishments with Chinese artifacts.

title: Bikers and Hikers On the Greenbelt Trail
description: ''About Long Island: Over the River and Through the Woods'' (April 15) presents an extremely inaccurate and damaging introduction to our Nassau-Suffolk Greenbelt Trail. The article constantly refers to difficult and muddy train conditions, waving a macho flag describing the triumph of man and machine over nature's obstacles. In reality, the Nassau-Suffolk Greenbelt Trail is exceedingly sensitive to erosion in mist areas, especially when the ground is moist.

title: New York Prosecutor Will Lead U.S. Inquiry Into Mail Bombings
description: The Justice Department has named a senior Federal prosecutor from New York to manage the investigation of mail bombings late last year that killed a Federal judge in Alabama and a civil rights lawyer in Georgia.

title: Christine MilesWed in Albany
description: Christine Marie Miles, the director of the Albany Institute of History and Art, and John Joseph Kelliher, the secretary of the New York State Public Service Commission, were married yesterday. The Rev. Jennings Matheson, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Anthony Chiaramonte, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Kenwood Chapel of the Doane Stuart School in Albany.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: Report on business inventories for March. The securities fraud trial of John Mulheren, a former abritrager, begins in New York.

title: New Phone Line Advises Travelers About Vaccines
description: When Dr. Mary Nettleman of the University of Iowa began to get requests for unneeded vaccinations, against cholera, for example, from patients at the Travel and Tropical Medicine Clinic she directs in Iowa City, she began to ask why the potential travelers wanted them. Her patients said they got the information from calls to the embassies and consulates of the countries they planned to visit.

title: The Senate's Honor
description: ''The system by which American campaigns are financed is out of control and getting worse.'' So says Senator George Mitchell, the Democratic majority leader. Senator Robert Dole, the Republican leader, agrees, and the two men promise their best efforts toward serious reform.

title: Joan C. Bierbower Becomes a Bride
description: Joan Cavett Bierbower, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Joseph Bierbower of Bethesda, Md., was married yesterday to Woodward Livingston Kaye, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Kaye of Middleburg, Va. Msgr. W. Louis Quinn and Msgr. John Murphy performed the ceremony at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We were told recently that the insulation covering the pipes in our basement contains asbestos. Should anything be done to remove this insulation, or is there something we can do ourselves to make sure the asbestos fibers do not contaminate the basement?

title: THOREAU WITH BOTTLED GAS
description: LEAD:

title: Are Japan's U.S. Auto Plants Unfair?
description: Last February, the Chrysler Corporation announced it would close an assembly plant in St. Louis. This was the 18th major American assembly and stamping operation closed (or slated to be closed) by Chrysler and the General Motors Corporation since 1986.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: IF you think that New Jersey suffers from a poor image in the national press today, you should have been around 85 years ago when McClure's Magazine hit the stands with an article entitled ''New Jersey: A Traitor State'' by Lincoln Steffens.

title: Witt Appears Headed For Yanks and Bullpen
description: Two months ago, George Steinbrenner sat with a group of reporters and insisted that Mike Witt would never pitch for the Yankees. Not as long as Steinbrenner was owner of the team, he said.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Men vs. Women, Again

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

DESIGNING MAN
description: LEAD: From illustrations of vamps with cigarettes and long-stemmed beauties with Bugattis to costumes for Marlene Dietrich and the never-never land of Frank Capra's 1937 film ''Lost Horizon,'' the designer Ernst Dryden (1887-1938) proved a nimble recorder of the dreams of his age. By turns a poster artist (under his original name, Ernst Deutsch), clothing designer, fashion illustrator and Hollywood costumier, Dryden was influenced by movements from Gustav Klimt's Vienna Secession to the Bauhaus and consistently celebrated a luscious, attenuated elegance.

title: Marie Elizabeth Sekreta Marries Eric E. Jensen
description: Marie Elizabeth Sekreta, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin S. Sekreta of Malverne, L.I., was married there yesterday at the Our Lady of Lourdes Roman Catholic Church to Eric Edmond Jensen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Whitmore Jensen of New York. The Rev. Thomas V. Arnao officiated.

title: Is Flunking a Grade Ever For a Pupil's Own Good?
description: FEW events are more humiliating and disheartening for a child than being held back in school.

title: Soviet Economy: A Shattered Dream
description: During last Saturday's soccer match between Spartak and Dynamo Kiev, television viewers were presented with a uniquely Soviet half-time entertainment: an interview with a presidential economic adviser, Stanislav S. Shatalin.

title: A Day for 40-Something Mothers to Plot Their Own Futures
description: Change is the law of life. And those who look only to the past or the present are certain to miss the future. - John F. Kennedy

title: Winfield Heads Home, Future Unclear
description: There were still two games to play before the team returned home, but in the late morning, as a cool wind blew outside and clouds covered the sky, Dave Winfield packed his bags, rode to the airport with his wife, Tonya, and flew home to the New York area.

title: WHEN LEGAL TITANS CLASH
description: As a 1973 graduate of the Harvard Law School who began her studies there 20 years ago - when the 7 percent admission for women was considered a radical new policy - I was both interested and dismayed by what Ken Emerson reports to be the state of legal education there (''When Legal Titans Clash,'' April 22). Except for Dean Robert Clark, the teachers quoted are exactly the same voices of the law school I knew in 1970. And the extreme positions cited sound increasingly irrelevant to the world of the 1990's.

title: CHINA: THE HARD ROAD TO NOW
description: LEAD:

title: Chinese Couple Qualify for Status as Refugees
description: The State Department has ruled that a Chinese couple who fled their homeland's family-planning policy qualify for refugee status, clearing the way for them to receive political asylum, their lawyer said on Friday.

title: Market Sees That Junk Bonds Are, Well, Junk;   Marx on Profits
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. and Mexico Take Aim at Drug Chemicals
description: Spurred by a new American law aimed at crippling the ability of drug cartels to manufacture narcotics, the United States and Mexico are stepping up efforts to prevent thousands of tons of American-made chemicals needed to produce cocaine, heroin and other illegal drugs from flowing into Mexico.

title: Retiring at 22
description: One year after his doctor told him he had the knees of a 60-year-old, Kent Carlsson, the rest of whom is just 22, has decided to give up tennis. The Swedish clay-court specialist, who ranked as high as sixth in the world in 1988, cited his chronic knee problems in explaining why he would abandon plans for a comeback after being sidelined since last July. . . . Dave Smith, the deputy managing editor and exectuive sports editor of The Dallas Morning News, has won the 1990 Red Smith Award. Smith is the first person other than a writer to win the award for outstanding contributuions to sports journalism. It is given annually by The Associated Press Sports Editors in honor of the New York Times columnist who died in 1982. Dave is not related to Red. . . . Ian White, a 7-foot-1-inch center who averaged 16 points and 13 rebounds a game for Henry Hudson Regional High School in Highlands, N.J., last season, has signed to play for Iona. An exchange student from England, White will be the tallest player ever at Iona. . . . Jeff Harding, the Australian boxer who holds the World Boxing Council light-heavyweight title, suffered a training injury that has forced him to postpone a defense against Dennis Andries of England, scheduled for June 2 in Melbourne. The fight is expected to be rescheduled for June 30. Harding reopened an old cut on his left eyebrow when he bumped heads with a sparring partner.

title: I WAS A WHITE SHAKETTE
description: GOODBYE WITHOUT LEAVING

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column on April 29 misstated United Airlines' policy on exchanging a ticket when a lower fare for the same destination is advertised, based on information provided by the airline. A ticket may be exchanged if the difference between fares is more than $25, the airline says, but all conditions for the new fare, including advance-purchase restrictions, must be met, and space must be available in the new booking class on the same flight. Rather than being liberal, as described in the column, United's policy is similar to that of other major airlines.

title: Spain: Spires in the Sky
description: SCAFFOLDING HAS BECOME an integral part of Spain's urban landscape. So have construction crews, churning up clouds of dust and dirt. On almost every major street in cities like Madrid and Barcelona, buildings shrouded in green plastic resemble giant packages waiting to be unwrapped.

title: New Political Realities Create Conservative Identity Crisis
description: After a decade of Republican Presidents, years that saw many of the most cherished conservative precepts enshrined in policy, the conservative movement itself is in the midst of an identity crisis, trying to redefine its causes and goals for the 1990's.

title: Evening Hours;   For Friends And Patrons Of the Arts
description: On Thursday evening, friends and benefactors of black artists and the Studio Museum in Harlem celebrated the museum's 22d anniversary with a dinner-dance at the Waldorf-Astoria. Leaders of major corporations, politicians and the museum's trustees and board honored Mayor David N. Dinkins as the 1990 patron of the arts. The evening was a benefit for the museum.

title: Dogwood Trees Are in Trouble
description: THE dogwood trees are in full bloom. What more glorious sight could spring have? These native trees, which carry their displays in layers, appear as clouds in the woods or as spectacular specimens on home lawns. Travelers drive for miles to see favorite spots where dogwoods grow.

title: In the Region: Westchester
description: Recent Sales

title: High-Tech Pen Pals Make Classes Global
description: LEAD: Early on a recent Monday morning at Ossining High School, a ninth-grade global-studies class learned about Argentina the next best way to being there. With the help of a conference telephone, a camera, a small viewing screen and a computer, the Ossining students spoke with and saw live pictures of their counterparts in a school on

title: SoHo Hotels
description: To the Editor:

title: Smothering Adelgids to Save the Hemlocks
description: THE woolly adelgids are here - and they are eating Westchester's hemlocks. To combat the creatures, the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation is spraying dormant oil - considered to be safe for the environment, animals and humans - in seven county parks and properties.

title: Rouse's New Strategy: Mixed Use and 'Remerchandising'
description: Most of the time, Mathias J. DeVito is an even-tempered man. But lately, there is a surefire formula for getting a rise out of him: Repeat some of the things analysts are saying about the Rouse Company, the real estate development firm he has headed since 1979.

title: News Analysis;   Dinkins, the Volume Up In a Speech on Race, the Mayor Responds To Complaint That He Hadn't Said Enough
description: New Yorkers long used to a vocal white mayor some had blamed for racial tensions were suddenly grappling last week with a quiet new black mayor some blamed for not doing more to ease the turmoil.

title: One Bensonhurst Jury Says It Has Reached a Deadlock
description: After four days of deliberations, the jurors considering the charges against Keith Mondello, one of the defendants in the Bensonhurst murder case, said yesterday that they were unable to reach a unanimous verdict on some of the charges.

title: WHEN LEGAL TITANS CLASH
description: Your article suggests to me that the Harvard Law School may take itself a bit too seriously. The chief architect of the law in the last decade is a man who never attended Harvard or any other law school, i.e. Ronald Reagan. It is temperament, not intellect, that largely determines legal decisions - a fact well illustrated by the schisms at Harvard itself. The life of the law, it has been observed, is not logic but experience, and as personalities and experience vary, so will the conclusions at which jurists arrive.

title: Market Sees That Junk Bonds Are, Well, Junk;   Venture Capital
description: To the Editor:

title: VOLUNTEER CORPS FOR EAST EUROPE
description: President Bush said today that he would create a volunteer corps to try to strengthen the emerging democracies in Central and Eastern Europe.

title:
IN SHORT;

REFERENCE
description: LEAD:

title: Elyse A. Knapp To Wed in June
description: June wedding plans for Elyse Anne Knapp and Jeffrey Dan Sollender, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel D. Sollender of Rye, N.Y., have been announced by Ms. Knapp's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jules F. Knapp of Highland Park, Ill.

title: Fashion;   Half a Yard or So of Nylon and Spandex, and Voila!
description: A swimsuit takes maybe half a yard of fabric, yet designers come up with a staggering array of new styles every year. They cut them high or low, drape them and wrap them, try new fabrics and colors. They want to appeal to different tastes, yes, but they must also take into account the variations in women's bodies.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Nyack, Where Charm, Antiques and Art Galleries Overlook the Hudson
description: Small historical villages with character and charm dot the Hudson River shoreline north of New York City, standing in contrast to the clogged and chaotic metropolis at the river's south end.

title: NAZI HUNTING: TRIALS THAN NEVER GROW COLD
description: JUSTICE NOT VENGEANCE

title: WHY WE DON'T KNOW WHAT WE DON'T KNOW JUST ASK E.D. HIRSCH
description: CHARLOTTESVILLE, VA., IS AN IDEAL SITE FORJU the study of American rhythms and continuities. On the famous lawn of the University of Virginia is the cloister where Edgar Allan Poe had his quarters - commemorated today by a plaque reading domus parva magni poetae. On a hill 10 miles away is Monticello, the exquisite home that Thomas Jefferson built for himself, with its slave quarters still visible (even more limited in space and comfort than Poe's), and another touching memorial, a stone obelisk at Jefferson's grave recalling his role as author of the Declaration of Independence and the Virginia Statute on Religious Liberty, and as founder of the university. It modestly and perhaps ironically omits his Presidency from the list of accomplishments.

title: Minor Differences Mean a Lot
description: CONTINENTAL DIVIDE

title: Alcala Takes Lead in Tour de Trump
description: For seven days, a 19-year-old Soviet amateur, Vladislav Bobrik, had been leading the Tour de Trump bicycle race. For seven days, the professional riders had been saying Bobrik would be caught and would not win.

title: Boston Ballet Opens a Door, Illuminating a Bygone Russia
description: The Boston Ballet's new ''Swan Lake,'' staged by Konstantin Sergeyev and Natalya Dudinskaya of the Kirov Ballet and led for three weeks this month by mixed casts that pair Soviet stars with dancers from the Boston company, has inevitably attracted much attention.

title:
Outdoors;

The Appetizing Herbal Wilderness
description: LEAD: As a modern hunter-gatherer, I like to believe that at least one of my motives for regularly participating in the rituals of fishing, hunting or otherwise harvesting from the land is to create a brief link with our hunting and gathering past and give myself a glimpse of what it was like for our historic or prehistoric predecessors to spear, hook, shoot or uproot for a living.

title: Correction
description: A table listing some sources of methane, published last Sunday with an article about cattle, omitted data on methane emissions related to coal mining. These emissions are estimated at 38.6 million tons a year worldwide, according to the studies on which the table was based.

title: NONFICTION
description: MOTHER, MAY YOU NEVER SEE THE SIGHTS I HAVE SEEN: The Fifty-Seventh Massachusetts Veteran Volunteers in the Army of the Potomac 1864-1865. By Warren Wilkinson. (Harper & Row, $30.) ''Give me twenty days and I could make a splendid regiment of this,'' wrote Col. William F. Bartlett, ''but man proposes and Grant disposes.'' Hurriedly raised around Worcester, Mass., in 1864, when the need for Civil War cannon fodder was still acute - though the war had lost all its luster - the 57th had more than its share of reluctant recruits, bounty jumpers and deserters, but the unit soon distinguished itself by its ability to absorb punishment in battle. Suffering under the command of the Union's worst general, the ambitious drunkard James H. Ledlie, the regiment's baptism came in one of the most terrible battles of the war, the Wilderness campaign in May 1864, in which 262 men were killed or wounded in the marshy Virginia thickets. Subsequently, the battles of Spotsylvania Court House, Cold Harbor and Petersburg whittled the regiment down further - to the point where it could be argued that no other Union regiment in the war lost more men, killed and mortally wounded, than the 57th Massachusetts. Warren Wilkinson, an independent scholar, has done a splendid, prodigious job of research in ''Mother, May You Never See the Sights I Have Seen,'' tracking down scattered diaries and letters, combining them with official records and previously published material to produce a remarkable day-to-day account of the hell that was this Massachusetts regiment's Civil War. Sensitively evoking the moments of fear, bravado, heroism, cowardice and numb stoicism, the author has re-created for the reader the mud, the dust, the smell of gunpowder and the stench of the unburied dead. Seldom does one encounter a history of a military unit that so compellingly reproduces its experiences.

title: THE FELIX BLOCH AFFAIR: Did the K.G.B. Man Collect Stamps?
description: UNTIL HE DISAPPEARED LAST JUNE, Reino Gikman, the K.G.B. man who met with Felix Bloch, lived with Helga Hobart in Vienna in a gingerbread cottage surrounded by a metal fence topped with barbed wire. Frau Hobart lives there still, protected by a fierce dog and a sign that reads ''Pflichtgetreuer Hund'' (Dutiful Dog). When I approached her house, he bared his teeth, tried furiously to leap the fence, and when that failed, to dig beneath it, all the while barking loudly. Frau Hobart was not at home, had given no interviews, and had turned away a hundred reporters, her neighbor said.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

Testing a New Site for Newark Offices
description: LEAD: MORE than two decades after racial riots left Newark a symbol of poverty, frustration and decay, the city of 300,000 people has been gaining welcome attention as a growing commercial hub in northern New Jersey.

title: Sure, He Can Dress, But Can He Coach?
description: A 20th wedding anniversary is an appropriate occasion for reflection and self-evaluation, even if husband and wife are happily living the life styles of the semirich and somewhat famous.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Now that the season has settled in and plants are growing, nourishment should be supplied to boost growth and bloom; a general fertilizer such as 5-10-5 can be used for most plants; follow label application rates. Finish pruning early-flowering shrubs that have outgrown their spaces. Keep after weeds. Finish major planting of perennials and woody plants. Sow another half-row of salad crops, especially leaf lettuces, to keep harvest coming through the summer months.

title: Question Of the Week;   Will Dent and Johnson Last The Season?
description: While I am certainly no Davey Johnson fan, it was not he who stripped a spirited 1986 team of its heart and soul, leaving us with a bland collection of robots, with four third basemen, six starting pitchers, no legitimate center fielder or catcher, no backup shortstop and half the players out of position. Fire McIlvaine and Cashen.

title: Researching the Research
description: The 1986 study was about immunology, but there has been no immunity from questioning the research that went into it. A Congressional subcomittee, which has been looking into the integrity of federally financed research, has scheduled a hearing tomorrow to present what is said to be new evidence, obtained by the Secret Service, of irregularities in the data reported by a researcher involved in the study. The scientist, Dr. Thereza Imanishi-Kari of Tufts University, and her lawyer deny any wrongdoing and say they will not attend. Researchers involved with the paper, including Dr. David Baltimore, one of the nation's leading biologists, say the paper's conclusions are sound, although there were some ''minor'' problems with some of the supporting data from Dr. Imanishi-Kari's laboratory. The subcommittee, headed by Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat, says the Secret Service found that 25 pages had been altered or written out of chronological order. Said Dr. Imanishi-Kari, ''They want me to respond, but I haven't been given anything to respond to.''

title: YANKEES END SLIDE WITH RALLY
description: While Dave Winfield returned to his hotel room on Friday night to ponder his next move, the Yankees recovered from their dreadful stay in Oakland and brought their three-game losing streak to a conclusion.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: Commercial Property: West Midtown;   Zeckendorf Is Ready for Another Burst of Building
description: HAVING already played a large role in reshaping the corridor between Times Square and Columbus Circle, with four projects finished or close to completion, the Zeckendorf Company has set its sights even higher, involving itself in three more developments that are now germinating.

title: Review/Theater;   Two Characters in Search of an Offstage Chekhov
description: Ten years ago, John Ford Noonan wrote ''A Coupla White Chicks Sitting Around Talking.'' In his new show, he is once again up to his conversational tricks. This time he is also onstage. In the two-character comedy ''Talking Things Over With Chekhov,'' he plays a playwright drawn to his own dimensions - always amiable and seemingly undisturbed by questions of theatrical form.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Reinvest The Peace Dividend
description: LEAD: THE Berlin Wall has fallen. The Warsaw Pact has collapsed and the Soviet threat has disappeared. Yet the 1991 Federal Budget reflects the same cold war assumptions that have determined public policies for the last 40 years.

description: The new Government of Chile agreed in principle today to pay compensation for the killing of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader assassinated in Washington 14 years ago.

LONG ISLAND OPINION;

The Gregarious, Closed World of Canada Geese
description: LEAD: THEY filled the early morning sky, a long arcing skein, their honking a musical conversation competing with the whistle of the high west wind of earliest day.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We were told recently that the insulation covering the pipes in our basement contains asbestos. Should anything be done to remove this insulation, or is there something we can do ourselves to make sure the asbestos fibers do not contaminate the basement?

title: Review/Dance;   Ferri and Colleagues Add Nuance to 'Giselle'
description: Alessandra Ferri, Julio Bocca, Victor Barbee and Susan Jaffe made the first ''Giselle'' of the American Ballet Theater season Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House unusually dramatic, even idiosyncratic.

description: It used to be said that in baseball a pitcher's second year was the hardest. The hitters had gotten on to his style by then and were all set to take advantage of its weaknesses.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday on a speech given by Mayor David N. Dinkins inaccurately described a comment he made about the killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins in Brooklyn. The Mayor said he hoped ''those individuals responsible for the death of Yusuf Hawkins will feel the strong arm of the law.''

description: OVER the years, some of Wanda Mitchell's friends in Brooklyn doubted her summertime experiences with the Katz family of Northport, her host as a Fresh Air Fund child.

title: Rock From New Zealand Inhabits Its Own Hemisphere
description: While punk-era bands like the Sex Pistols, the Ramones and Talking Heads were re-energizing rock-and-roll in the United Kingdom and the United States, a group called the Clean, active in New Zealand from 1978 until 1982, was responsible for reshaping the sound of rock music in that country. A guitar-pop band with the rebellious attitude of punk, the Clean developed a rough, garagey style and do-it-yourself approach that continues to have an impact in New Zealand today.

title: Anita B. Elkind Is Married
description: Anita B. Elkind, a daughter of Marilyn B. Elkind of Somers, N.Y., and Victor Elkind of La Jolla, Calif., was married last evening at Temple Emanu-El in Yonkers to Dr. Richard M. Pomerantz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Pomerantz of Scarsdale, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham Klausner officiated. Mrs. Pomerantz, 23 years old and a cum laude graduate of Wellesley College, is the general manager of the Argus Computerized Exchange, an information service in Burlington, Mass. Dr. Pomerantz, 29, is a cardiology fellow at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He received his undergraduate and medical degrees from Johns Hopkins University and is a member of Phi Beta Kappa.

description: The Parliament demonstrated strong support today for a law setting criminal penalties, including prison terms of up to six years, for public remarks insulting the Soviet President.

This year, the forum was fancier than usual, presented at Alice Tully Hall by the Composers' Showcase organization, which in turn is presented by Lincoln Center's Great Performers series.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article in the Business Forum last Sunday about merger regulations in the European Community misstated the Community's rules about when notification of a merger and certain joint ventures must occur. Notification is required when the aggregate worldwide turnover of the companies involved is greater than $6 billion - and two or more of the parties involved have aggregate Community-wide turnover of more than $300 million each. (This rule does not apply if each party achieves more than two-thirds of its Community-wide turnover within a single country.)

description: The East German authorities have decided not to prosecute Erich Honecker, the ousted Communist leader, citing his failing health, the Interior Minister, Peter-Michael Diestel, said in an interview published today.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Simon Jones, a British actor who lives in New York, has very definite views about the situation. His summation is ''they pass through the door and become someone else.'' The door he's talking about is that of any number of (but certainly not all) upscale shops, boutiques and galleries, and 'they' are the sales personnel (but certainly not all) at these establishments.

title: Sarah Spurdle Marries David Stack
description: Sarah Stuart Spurdle and David Rorick Stack were married yesterday at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson, N.J. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. officiated. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John W. Spurdle Jr. of New York. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. J. William Stack Jr. of New Canaan, Conn. Margaret Warren Spurdle was her sister's maid of honor; Peter Snyder Stack, the bridegroom's brother, was the best man.

title: Stone Symbols Of Shaker Permanence
description: As I approached the Shaker village in Canterbury, N.H., from the south, I became aware of its stone walls at the same moment I spotted the white clapboard buildings. They vie for your attention: the simple buildings surrounded by shade trees and perched on top of a high hill, and the lichen-encrusted, gray-green walls built with stones the size of which I had never seen before in a wall. Some of the stones extend well over a yard in every dimension; they weigh more than 4,000 pounds each. The walls, I discovered, have been impressing visitors for almost 200 years.

title:
Four Inns at twohundredsomething;

Middleburg, Va.: Old-time hospitality at the Red Fox Inn
description: LEAD: Nothing in this world is immutable, but the Red Fox Inn of Middleburg, Va., comes close. In business since at least 1751, this stolid fieldstone house stands as a comforting reminder that the hospitality and quiet pleasures of an earlier day endure.

title: At Avianca Crash, A Series of Errors
description: In the March 4 Long Island Weekly, two articles discussed the Avianca air crash rescue operation [''Volunteer Forces Are Bolstered After Crash'' and ''The Night the Plane Fell,'' Opinion Page] . Both are peppered with quotes such as ''despite any difficulties (poor communications, coordination, security and traffic control) the fire services performed well,'' ''they did the best job possible'' and ''nothing could have prepared them for that night.''

title: A Mother Superior, In So Many Ways
description: LEAD: This is my first Mother's Day without my mother. I can hear her voice so clearly, most notably last Thanksgiving a few days before she died. ''Please don't wear black to my funeral,'' she told me. ''Black has never been your best color. You really look much better in jewel tones; royal blue, red, a vibrant yellow.

description: To the Sports Editor:

description: A MIXED-USE waterfront project that has been plagued with problems for a decade is moving ahead with its final phase, scheduled for completion in 1992.

title: Loryn R. Cohen Is a Bride
description: Loryn R. Cohen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold S. Cohen of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married last evening at Congregation Emanuel of Westchester in Rye, N.Y., to Michael L. Kass, a son of Harriet Marcus and Dr. Alfred Kass, both of Columbus, Ohio. Rabbi Daniel Wolk officiated. Mrs. Kass, 24 years old and a graduate of Tulane University, is an associate at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. The bridegroom, 24 and a summa cum laude graduate of Tulane, is an associate at Lazard Freres & Company in New York.

title: Nancy Gilbert Weds Kimball Holland
description: Nancy P. Gilbert, the daughter of Mrs. Frederick A. Gilbert of Osterville, Mass., and the late Mr. Gilbert, and K. Kimball Holland, a son of Mrs. G. Kenneth Holland of Bronxville, N.Y., and the late Dr. Holland, were married yesterday. The Rev. Avery Manchester performed the nondenominational ceremony at the First Church of Round Hill in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Salute to Israel Parade, Fifth Avenue from 57th to 86th Streets will be closed today from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.

title: Of Yuppies, A Marriage And Bagels
description: When Rose and Jack Rothenberg first meet Milton and Bunny Gross on a mountaintop in Israel, the vacationing couples quickly discover that they have more in common than just being from New York City. Their children - 27-year-old Richard Rothenberg and 26-year-old Ellen Gross - are unmarried lawyers who live a block apart on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. Once snapshots have been passed around and resumes exchanged, all agree that the two were meant for each other.

title:
MUSIC;

In the Chung Family, Togetherness Is Part Of the Art of Music
description: LEAD: When the conductor Myung Whun Chung made a 10-day concert tour of Korea last fall, he did not go alone. He packed up his entire family - wife and three sons and their French tutor - and enrolled the children in a Korean school for the duration of their stay. His sister, the violinist Kyung Wha Chung, who will be heard in a solo recital Wednesday at Avery Fisher Hall, sympathizes.

title: Preparations Before House Painting
description: FOR exterior house paint to last as long as its manufacturer says it will, the surface to which the paint is applied must be carefully prepared. This can be the most arduous and time-consuming part of painting.

title: Celia M. Kent and Dr. John Abernethy Married
description: Celia Marin Kent was married yesterday at the Central Presbyterian Church in Summit, N.J., to Dr. John Duncan Abernethy. The Rev. Leland Gartrell officiated.

title: Photo: Twenty-five years after independence from Malaysia, relations between Singapore's dominant Chinese and minority Malays have turned a bit sour. The largely Malay district of Geylang Serai in Singapore was busier than usual as Muslims shopped for the feast marking the end of Ramadan. (Associated Press for The New York Times);   Chinese-Malay Relations Turn Sour in Singapore
description: ''I don't think they heard me come in,'' said Maizurah, a university graduate with a good entry-level job in Singapore's meritocratic civil service. Four of her Singaporean-Chinese colleagues, two of them her friends, were talking. ''They were only joking, you know, it was about something in the news, but it was the usual thing about 'the lazy Malays.' I just walked out again, very quietly.'' Was she upset? ''Yes,'' she said. ''I'm still upset a little.''

title: Wedding Plans For Traci Reed And W. B. Dippy
description: Mr. and Mrs. John S. Reed of Greenwich, Conn., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Traci Reed and William Bradner Dippy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George B. Dippy 3d of Old Greenwich, Conn.

title: NATURE WRITERS: A SPECIES UNTO THEMSELVES
description: If extraterrestrials have ever visited our planet and decide to return, one of the best gifts they could bring is a home movie showing us in our infancy, as well as now-extinct animals and pristine landscapes. Until that day, the best we can do is turn to nature writers to provide us with visions of bygone creatures, civilizations lost to history and unsullied landscapes.

title: Bipartisan Resolve On O'Rourke Plan
description: THE bipartisan coalition that took control of the County Board of Legislators earlier this year presented its 1990 agenda last week, speaking with a single political voice that was intended to emphasize the group's increasing strength and purpose.

title: June Wedding Is Planned By Ellen M. Harrington
description: Dr. and Mrs. Henry J. Philie of East Sandwich, Mass., have announced June wedding plans for Mrs. Philie's daughter Ellen M. Harrington and Robert K. Watson, a son of Robert C. Watson Jr. of Hanover, N.H., and the late Ann K. Watson. Ms. Harrington, 26 years old, is also the daughter of Dr. Joseph A. Harrington 3d of Andover, Mass.

title: Hollywood Pays Court to the Young Adult
description: When ''Driving Miss Daisy'' topped $100 million at the box office this weekend, that feat underscored something that has become increasingly obvious to movie makers: teen-agers no longer are the prime audience.

title: PORTABLE PLAYERS REWARD THEIR FANS
description: For 10 years, since Sony's first Walkman, it has been possible to put music in your pocket. The artistic consequences of this magician's trick are uncertain for the long run, and one wonders what Beethoven would have thought of traipsing about with the ''Eroica.'' As an inveterate hiker, he might even have liked the idea. At any rate, he would have been delighted with the earphones.

title: Juliet B. Karelsen To Wed in June
description: June wedding plans for Juliet B. Karelsen and William F. Roorbach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Roorbach of New Canaan, Conn., have been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Frank E. Karelsen 3d of New York.

title: Salvadoran Justice Wears Out Patience
description: SALVADORAN soldiers may have hoped to rid themselves of meddlesome priests when they gunned down six Jesuits last November, along with their cook and her young daughter. But the slain churchmen are proving to be more potent adversaries in death than they were in life.

title: One-Night Stands, Year After Year
description: BERNARD SLADE'S romantic play ''Same Time Next Year,'' currently at the Broadhollow Theater in Farmingdale, opens the morning after an adulterous one-night stand.

title: Jennifer Ehrlich Becomes a Bride
description: Jennifer A. Ehrlich, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Ehrlich of New York, and David J. Rimmer, the son of Phyllis Rimmer of Bay Terrace, Queens, and the late Murray Rimmer, were married yesterday at the Water Club in New York by Rabbi James Prosnit.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article by The Associated Press in some editions last Sunday about anti-Semitic graffiti at Bertolt Brecht's grave in Berlin misstated the playwright's religion. He was reared as a Lutheran; he was not Jewish. The article also misidentified a country where Brecht lived in exile before settling in East Germany. It was Denmark, not the Netherlands.

title: Evolution in Europe: Old Scores to Settle;   Punish Ousted Leaders, 100,000 in Prague Ask
description: About 100,000 people rallied in the center of Prague today to demand that ousted Communist leaders be punished for crimes committed during four decades of totalitarian rule.

title:
MUSIC;

For Papa, Art Was Important. So Was Money
description: LEAD: This article is adapted from ''Enrico Caruso: My Father and My Family,'' a memoir about the legendary Italian tenor, to be published next month by Amadeus Press. Enrico Caruso Jr., one of two sons born to the singer and his common-law wife, Ada Giacchetti, was brought from Italy to America in 1919 by Caruso and his legal wife, Dorothy.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Christie, Manson and Woods Ltd. of London will auction a portion of a hoard of coins from the reigns of Henry I, Stephen and Henry II. The 482 coins were discovered in a ditch in Wicklewood, a town near Norwich, Britain in 1989. The hoard consists mainly of pennies, but a third of them are cut farthings and half-pennies.

title: In 'Gypsy,' a Rose Is a Role Is a Killer
description: ''It's like a prizefight,'' said Tyne Daly of her role in the current Broadway revival of ''Gypsy,'' which last week received five Tony Award nominations, including one for Ms. Daly. ''It's like being in training for a prizefight. The way the part is written, it allows no letdown. Especially on two-performance days - we call them double-headers - that tends to feel more like an athletic event than an artistic experience.''

title: Evolution in Europe: In Unity, Perhaps Strength;   3 Baltic Chiefs Agree to Coordinate Their Policies
description: The presidents of the three Baltic republics met today and agreed to coordinate foreign and domestic policies in a united effort to gain their independence from Moscow.

title:
The Executive Life;

Out With Wire Hangers, And Death to Tired Togs
description: LEAD: Seven years ago, Beverly Rothenberg had her first wardrobe panic attack. On the brink of starting a new career as an advertising sales executive in New York, Ms. Rothenberg, a former teacher, realized that her collection of school-marmish suits was too dowdy for her stylish new post in a cutting-edge industry.

title: A FATHER'S PAWN
description: I FIRST MET GATA KAMSKY TWO SUMMERS AGO, IN Timisoara, Romania, where he was competing in the under-14 division of the youth world chess championship. ''He is the most gifted chess prodigy of all time - the next world champion,'' said a Romanian journalist who was shaking with excitement as he led me to a solemn boy with bangs and owl eyes, who moved the chess pieces against another great prodigy, Sofia Polgar from Hungary. The lithe, arrestingly pretty Sofia had been fighting off Gata's attacking pieces for hours, and with a wounded expression that might melt any adolescent boy's heart, she whispered her offer of a draw. Gata refused with only the slightest trace of a smile as he pushed his pawns ahead and snuffed out Sofia's championship dreams with end-game technique so punishing and precise that it gave me goose bumps.

title: Barbara Bush and the American Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: In the Region: New Jersey
description: Recent Sales

title: China's Shadow Falls Across Hong Kong's Films
description: A few months after public protests here over the violent repression of democracy in Tiananmen Square, it's business as usual in Hong Kong. After years in New York, a young Chinese remarked that his native city ''had become a gigantic shopping mall.'' The so-called Hong Kong dream, a vision of the good life parallel to the American Dream, however, shouldn't be reduced to pure mercantilism. For the film scholar Esther Yau, Hong Kong's precarious existence represents a utopia, the right not to choose between the Communist Party and the Kuomintang. Nowhere is this utopia better expressed than in the film industry - where audiences may enjoy a taste of paradise lost long ago in Hollywood. In Hong Kong, film making is an unpretentious industry, designed for profit, popular entertainment and export to Japan, Taiwan and Korea.

title: MISSING IN DUBLIN
description: MOTHERLAND

title: The Mortal Sphinx
description: THE RIDDLE OF THE SPHINX, UPDATED: is it falling down or not? During the replacement of masonry on the paws and flanks in the last decade, speculation has been ongoing about the ultimate fate of the monumental man-lion hybrid at Giza, Egypt. Dating from approximately 2550 B.C., the 66-foot-high Sphinx was fashioned from low-grade limestone that historians believe was the inferior remains of the area quarried for the first pyramid. Weather-beaten in the subsequent millennia and long mottled by fissures and flaking, the Sphinx has suffered in modernity from the additional ravages of pollution, a rising water table and the rumbling of traffic in nearby Cairo.

title: WHAT WOMEN WANT FROM FEMINISM
description: Vivian Gornick compares feminism to psychoanalysis, and is saddened that women seem stuck at the level at which insight does not seem to produce real change (''Who Says We Haven't Made A Revolution?'' April 15). I think feminism has achieved more successes, is more popular and has changed women's outlooks more than Gornick recognizes, but in any case her metaphor is misleading. Feminism is not a form of introspection. It is a social movement, aimed at changing the structures of society for both men and women, from the home and the workplace to the doctor's office and the courts. Those structures have proved to be resistant to fundamental change, but whose fault is that?

title: Diploma for Hank Gathers
description: Nearly 10 weeks after Hank Gathers, the college basketball star, collapsed during a game and later died, the athlete's family returned today to receive his posthumous bachelor's degree from the college against which the family has filed a $32.5 million negligence suit.

title: WHEN WILL THE BOOK BE DONE?
description: The difficulties Susan Sheehan spoke of were not related to the actual craft of making a book. She spoke only of externals in the author's life - a car accident and a lawsuit, in particular, that kept him from his writing table and delayed the process of completion.

title: Blending Sophisticated With Homey
description: RESTAURANT name-droppers pepper their conversations with big-deal places sporting foreign names that begin with La, Le and Chez. Although Barney's, with its home-grown moniker, may not make their list, it should be on yours.

title: 'NOTHING IN MODERATION'

title: REFERENCE
description: ATLAS OF HUMAN ANATOMY. By Frank H. Netter. (Ciba-Geigy, 14 Henderson Drive, West Caldwell, N.J. 07006, Cloth, $120; Paper, $49.95.) Commercial art wasn't the career Frank H. Netter's parents wanted for him. Despite his early success as an illustrator in the 1920's, they persuaded him to go to medical school. But they never could make him reject his drawing entirely. During classes, he would fill his notebooks with pictures, and these eventually won the admiration of his teachers. Soon they were asking him to illustrate their lectures and textbooks, and the freelancing eased the costs of a medical education. In 1938, now trained as a surgeon, Dr. Netter illustrated a pamphlet on the heart as an advertisement for a medication produced by the Ciba Pharmaceutical Company. The drawings were so exquisitely detailed that physicians everywhere admired them, and this response was not lost on Ciba, which signed Dr. Netter up to do additional illustrations. Ultimately, he created more than 4,000 drawings for the company and for its magazine Clinical Symposia, moving from one human organ system to another and filling several volumes. Now, in ''Atlas of Human Anatomy,'' the 83-year-old Dr. Netter has produced a comprehensive single-volume color atlas of 514 plates of human anatomy. Many are new, and scores more are revisions from earlier volumes to reflect medical advances. Modern techniques like CAT scans and magnetic resonance imaging - technology that can see the body as it has never been seen before - have not been lost on Dr. Netter, and his illustrations have grown ever more revealing. Dr. Netter has always sought a balance between complexity and simplification, an objective that makes his work broadly appealing. This atlas should be useful for premedical students, health workers and anyone curious about what lies beneath the skin.

In fact, they combine the best of all three: you can shop sitting down, play the commodities market with real commodities that you carry home in the trunk of your car, catch a comedy act without paying a cover charge and eat for under $5.

title: Nantucket on My Mind
description: The house my family has rented and lived in on Nantucket every summer since I was 3 years old was at one time, before the advent of the Coast Guard, a lifesaving station. Weather-beaten, gray-shingled, it sits on a slight rise in the land at the eastern end of the island, the beach and the Atlantic everywhere behind it. Looking straight out from the back porch, there is nothing to see but water, an expanse of blue tinged with slate that stretches beyond any identifiable distance. The nearest land mass in this direction, I've always been told, is Portugal. Like almost everything else about the house, this information has the air of myth about it. And yet I've never questioned this piece of geographic trivia; it is fact to me, my favorite fact, and it seems as much a part of this place as anything else.

title: REFERENCE
description: HUNTING HUMANS: An Encyclopedia of Modern Serial Killers. By Michael Newton. (Loompanics Unlimited, $34.95.) Why an encyclopedia of serial killers? There is probably no satisfactory answer, and perhaps a publisher whose previous efforts include a manual of bodyguarding and a catalogue of poisons (''sold for informational purposes only'') doesn't need one. Still, for anybody with a taste for this sort of thing, Michael Newton's ''Hunting Humans'' appears to be relatively complete. The entries number 544, covering approximately 750 individuals who committed every imaginable variety of mayhem: mutilation, necrophilia, cannibalism, dismemberment, vampirism, human sacrifice. Only 20th-century serial killers are dealt with; absent are such earlier monsters as Gilles de Rais and Jack the Ripper - though the book does have two Jack the Rippers of its own, as well as a Jack the Stripper. Many of the murderers fit the stereotype of the rootless male drifter, but by no means all. At least two had been Eagle Scouts; one was a Sunday school teacher. About 8 percent are women, and they tended to stay close to home, doing away with husbands, children, boarders - almost invariably by poison. Without the contexts true-crime books provide, the entries often consist of little more than lists of killings, and a reader who proceeds from cover to cover is likely to start skipping around, searching out oddities in this already odd crowd: the man who fed the corpses to his pet alligators, the fellow who ''developed a bizarre, abiding hatred'' for the Domino's Pizza chain. Nonetheless, reading through the entries from A to Z is the best approach, since the volume's main impact is cumulative. There are so many! Serial killing is not an uncommon phenomenon that occasionally erupts into headlines with the apprehension of a Charles Manson or a Theodore Bundy. As this book makes abundantly and depressingly clear, it is something going on all the time and, apparently, with increasing frequency.
