title: REFERENCE
description: THE ALMANAC OF SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY: What's New and What's Known. Edited by Richard Golob and Eric Brus. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, Cloth, $59.95; Paper, $29.95.) It takes a lot of guts to try to squeeze everything the thinking person needs to know about science and technology into a 530-page book. The sheer scope of this enterprise is captured in the dizzying mix of topics advertised on the cover: AIDS, Hubble Space Telescope, Punctuated Equilibrium, Brain Grafts, Mount St. Helens, Quarks, Acid Rain, Coronary Bypass Surgery, Black Holes - and on and on. It is hard to imagine a scientific subject that has been in the news in the last decade that is not touched upon somewhere in ''The Almanac of Science and Technology.'' Yet for a book with such a high fact-per-sentence ratio, the writing is very clear. Naturally, trade-offs between breadth and depth were necessary. There is far more technology here than science, much more medicine than basic biological research. The section called Brain and Behavior, for example, concentrates on the great new gadgets and techniques - PET scanners, computerized electroencephalography, and so forth - that allow scientists to monitor the brain; it includes, as well, pages on sleep disorders, stress-caused illnesses and fetal-cell therapy. But nowhere to be found is the most basic concept of neuroscience: how a neuron works. When it comes to chemistry, the entries on quasicrystals, antirubber, caged atoms and other recently synthesized curiosities are right on the technological cutting edge. But why, in a chapter that devotes half a page to automotive catalytic converters and a page to radar-absorbing paint, is there nothing about the periodic table of the elements? The book is much broader on physics, describing not only the nuts and bolts of giant accelerators but also the intellectual milestones in the quest for a grand unification theory. Ideally, this balance between the theoretical and the technological would have been struck in every chapter. Even so, this is a very useful book. In the few weeks it has been on my desk I've referred to it several times, usually finding just what I was looking for.

title: Winning a Place To Show Racing Silks
description: The article on April 22 [''Elmont Seamstress Is the Betsy Ross of Horse Racing''] tells us that Antoinette Brocklebank sews 25 percent of the silks at Belmont, so it's 4 to 1 that the winning jockey will wear her outfit. You can tell that the writer hasn't spent much time at the track. A probability of 25 percent corresponds to 3 to 1 odds against. Four to one would be 20 percent.

title: A Rough-Hewn Maine Seaport
description: Portlanders have a homing instinct. Stay at a bed-and-breakfast and your host regales you with the tale of the descendant who came back to see how time had transformed the old family place into the Pomegranate Inn. Stand at the top of the plunging staircase at the Morse-Libby House, known today as Victoria Mansion, and its director recalls the Libby granddaughter's return to tell how ''Grandpa Libby'' struck fear in the hearts of youngsters who might venture down its historic slide. Tall tales and small: they underscore the intimacy of this urban landscape where history is biography.

title: READ MY SUPERTITLES? WHY NOT, IF IT'S APPROPRIATE?
description: Opera attracts people with strong opinions. No argument so far? We might also agree that for some reason the art form fosters among its followers a kind of Maginot Line mentality that encourages smug rigidity. An either/or dualism, I find, dominates a frustrating debate about projected titles in the May issue of Opera News, the monthly voice of the Metropolitan Opera Guild. The possibility that titles may be esthetically valid in certain circumstances is argued eloquently by that formidable intellect Sir Isaiah Berlin, but barely entertained by other experts rallied to discuss one of the most remarkable developments in modern opera history.

title: In Today's TV Families, Who Knows Best?
description: Recently, on ABC's ''Growing Pains,'' Mike (Kirk Cameron) got what he thought was his big break - a walk-on part in a TV series as a nameless cop dying of gunshot wounds. Mike's sister, Carol (Tracey Gold), recognized the part for the inconsequential bit of body spasm it was and offered only the most measured of congratulations. But Dad (Alan Thicke), a psychologist who's supposed to know better, was mostly interested in having Mike get the autograph of the buxom series star. Who was the center of moral authority in this TV family moment? Certainy not Dad. Almost as recently on ''Roseanne,'' also on ABC, the eponymous heroine's adolescent daughter, Darlene, wrote a poem good enough for her to read aloud before a nighttime parent assembly. But Darlene balked, saying she wasn't going to go because she didn't want to look like a nerd. Conflict ensued between her and Roseanne (Roseanne Barr), who herself had written a notebook full of poetry as an adolescent. Roseanne prevailed. Darlene read. Both these instances illustrate where the center of authority lies in two different families; though opposite, each is becoming predictable on nighttime TV series. When the TV family in question is working class, or minority, the heavy-duty moral considerations, when they need to be made, are typically made by the parents. Not infallibly, but reflectively, with hands on.

title: Ginger in Western Cooking
description: THE Chinese use fresh ginger in their cooking the way Westerners use salt and pepper. But in recent years it has been showing up more and more in dishes that are not in the least Chinese. Ginger adds a refreshing tartness to fish and chicken, perks up marinades, and is also good with vegetables such as mustard greens or broccoli rabe, adding a slightly sharp spicy taste that counteracts their bitterness.

title: WHEN WOMAN WANT FROM FEMINISM
description: Looking at the feminists on your cover reminded me of an early 20th-century gathering of old bolsheviks, not because their philosophies are the same, but because I think one day these powerhouses, too, will be regarded with loathing. Similarities? Hearts in the right place and recognition of a need for change. Same mistakes: assuming that only they have the right answers.

title: NONFICTION
description: REPORTS OF MY DEATH. By Karl Shapiro. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $22.95.) In this second volume of his autobiography, Karl Shapiro describes his years as a ''career poet'' - poetry consultant at the Library of Congress, editor of Poetry, professor of English and creative writing - while ruefully lamenting the idea that poetry should ever have become a career at all. Some of the most engaging parts of ''Reports of My Death,'' in fact, are those that take an ironic look at the professionalism that has afflicted poets since World War II, a phenomenon Mr. Shapiro attributes to the proliferation of grants and creative writing programs and the competition for worldly success. He also has some comments about the deleterious effect of the freedom-mad 1960's on the practice of poetry: ''Poetry plunged out of the classics, out of the modern masters, out of all standards, and plopped into the playpen.'' Unfortunately, Mr. Shapiro's account of his life, related in the third person, is disappointingly flat: his descriptions of people and events are oddly flavorless, and his labored analyses of his own states of mind fail to illuminate much. Mr. Shapiro also makes far too many disclaimers of interest in fame, money, prizes (''He was constantly turning down invitations which others would kill for'') or the adoration of various beautiful and brilliant women (''He was too innocent to know that his going to bed with them was part of their program''). Only when he is considering the present state of poetry or describing his loving pilgrimage to the grave of Auden does Mr. Shapiro's tone take on the urgency and elegiac quality that make his book truly sound like the autobiography of a poet.

title: Review/Recital;   Violin-Piano Duo in a Variety of Rarities
description: Michael Appleman, a violinist, and Diane Huling, a pianist, who perform together as the Appleman-Huling Duo, offered a refreshing debut program at Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening. The usual components were there - a Beethoven Sonata, a late-Romantic work, a piece of early modernism, a premiere and a showpiece. But most of the works were rarities, and the duo made strong cases for them.

Mother's Many Roles (And Prices)
description: LEAD: WHAT would I earn if I were paid individually for all the jobs I do as full-time wife and mother? I figured it out the other day.

title: POSTINGS: On Lake Pontoosuc;   150 Berkshire Condos
description: The shores of Lake Pontoosuc in Pittsfield, Mass., once resounded to the joyful shouts of New York City children who spent their summers at Camp Waconah for girls and Camp Potomac for boys.

title: Abortion-Rights Advocate Views a Victory
description: PATRICIA BAKER, the executive director of Planned Parenthood of Connecticut in New Haven, says that the broad support for the state's new abortion-rights law was built, in part, through a strong grass-roots effort by some 60 organizations in the state. The law is seen by legal experts around the country as a milestone for of privacy rights, she said.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: UNIVERSE 1 (Foundation/Doubleday, Cloth, $19.95; Paper, $8.95), an anthology of new fiction, has an honorable pedigree. Terry Carr was one of science fiction's most respected editors; each year from 1970 until his untimely death at the age of 50 in 1987 he brought out a collection of previously unpublished short stories under the umbrella title ''Universe.'' Robert Silverberg, whose own stories often graced the Carr anthologies, assures us in a brief introduction that he and his co-editor, Karen Haber, are looking for the same kind of science fiction that attracted Carr: ''intellectually challenging, strongly plotted, and gracefully written.'' These are estimable criteria; I only wish that more of the 20 stories in the new anthology lived up to them.

title: The Modern Charts Its Course Step by Step
description: For quite some time now, a nine-word-question - ''What will become of the Museum of Modern Art?'' - has been rumbling around the art world like a freight train overheard in the dark. Ever since the great first generation of the museum's founders, supporters, curators and miscellaneous adherents began to thin out, that question has been asked.

title: Protecting Microbes and Mathematics
description: Quiet and largely unnoticed in its red-brick building two blocks from the White House, the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit is having a revolutionary effect on the ground rules under which technology is developed and controlled in the United States.

title: Race Hatred Isn't Cool
description: To the Editor:

title: Strong Adjectives

title:
DINING OUT;

Freshness Heads the Menu in Tuckahoe
description: LEAD: Diners frequent restaurants for a number of reasons and skillfully prepared fresh ingredients are not always the reason for customer loyalty. Service or atmosphere or price often dictate which restaurants become favorites. All this is by way of saying that although dining at Salerno's can still be a treat, our recent visits have been somewhat disappointing, perhaps because we have difficulty reconciling the pricey dishes with the informality of the place.

title: The Man Who Invented Synchronism
description: THE Montclair Art Museum's magnum opus of the season is a Morgan Russell retrospective, the first ever. Abstract Expressionism was the movement that put this country on the art world map, but it was not the first to attract international attention. That honor goes to Synchromism, which was invented by Russell and unveiled by him and Stanton MacDonald-Wright in the Munich of 1913.

title: Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?
description: It was a moment of triumph for John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of the General Electric Company.

title: Style Makers;   Toshio Goma, Kimono Designer
description: ''Not too many people wear kimonos anymore,'' said Toshio Goma, a textile and kimono designer in Japan who has been trying to introduce the radiant colors of the traditional aristocratic kimono fabrics to American designers. Mr. Goma, who is 45 years old and a descendant of 14 generations of kimono artists, seems to be succeeding.

description: Ann Marie Journey, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Drexel Dahlke Journey of Washington, and Ray Wilbert Wuolo, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Wilbert Leander Wuolo of Rochester, Minn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Vivian Jones performed the ceremony at the Plymouth Congregational Church in Minneapolis.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

The Beauty of a Prom Dress Is In the Eye of the Wearer
description: LEAD: JUST when you need them the most, Dr. Spock and Piaget let you down. Even though they may have offered reliable advice on potty training and early education, they leave you dangling when your child reaches the tricky teen-age years.

title: Moncrief's Memory
description: Glad-Handing alumni are familiar to most big-time college athletes, but according to the former Arkansas basketball star Sidney Moncrief, some alumni hands are more gladdening than others. Or, as Moncrief puts it in his new book: ''I can't say that occasionally an alumnus or overzealous fan didn't walk up to me after a game and put a hundred-dollar bill in my hand when he shook it.''

description: More than at any time since President Bush took office, a deep sense of uncertainty has settled over the Administration about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's prospects for success and his ability to conclude the broad range of Soviet-American arms-control agreements sought by Washington.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. We were told recently that the insulation covering the pipes in our basement contains asbestos. Should anything be done to remove this insulation, or is there something we can do ourselves to make sure the asbestos fibers do not contaminate the basement?

description: THE hard times in residential building oserare bringing a welcome remodeling to the remodeling industry - long plagued by a reputation for shoddy practices.

title: Lifestyle;   For the Bachelorette, A Wilder Last Fling
description: They were nine women in their early 20's out on the town. They wore dangling earrings, spike heels and cocktail clothes. They were drinking champagne because Loryn Cohen, an associate at Bear, Stearns & Company, was getting married over the weekend to Michael Kass, an associate at Lazard Freres & Company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: Spain: Hot to Be the New Spot
description: Show time is 10 minutes away and workmen are still swarming the stage of the Palacio de Congresos, Madrid's official fashion theater. The name of Manuel Pina, one of the city's premier designers, appears on a wall at the rear. There, to the staccato of hammering, Pina's logo is being wreathed in a tangle of roses and barbed wire. A kinky touch, the wreath is an apt metaphor for the rigor and the romance of Spanish design. But its last-minute placement is also indicative of the sketchy, sometimes improvisational nature of Spain's attempt to become the latest hot spot on the international fashion circuit.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: An ordinary stamp with an ordinary portrait issued by Liechtenstein in 1968 is a sort of modernist, self- referential item: The stamp honors a stamp collector.

description: To the Editor:

Pastimes: Gardening;

Rugged Vine
description: LEAD: It was my lucky day one Sunday morning last June when I stopped at the flower stand at a flea market. The passion flower was in bloom. It had burst open from a small, one-inch bud into a spectacular bloom, four inches in diameters.

title: Severe Disability Fails To Deter Artist's Efforts
description: LEAD: EXPRESSION is important to Catherine Hines, who, because of cerebral palsy has never been able to carry on a conversation or pick up a pen and write a letter to a friend.

The author's failure to include even one reinforces the inferior status afforded female scholars and female lawyers in our society.

title: Salem's Seafaring Legacy
description: As the early-morning mist comes in from the harbor in Salem, Mass., the most pleasant place to be is on the Common. This wide expanse of green is both a cultural and physical hub of the coastal town north of Boston, and the odd geometry of its criss-crossing paths is a product of habit and time. Today, morning joggers may have replaced the pasturing cows and military parades of former times, but still there is a feeling in this setting, surrounded by fine Federal houses, of the orderliness and peace that gave this Essex County town its name (from the Hebrew word shalom, meaning peace).

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;

On the Boards: New and Bigger Theaters
description: LEAD: ONE of Westchester's legitimate theaters is expanding into a new building, another is moving into a renovated school and others are contemplating improvements to their existing spaces.

description: FOUR CENTURIES

title: Speak Out on Social Issues, Pope Tells Mexico Bishops

title: Merchants to Help State Build Furnishings 'Bank'
description: LEAD: WHEN his store hit the grand old age of 60, Wallace Rubin wanted to give something back to the people of Fairfield and New Haven Counties who had kept Wayside Furniture in business all those years. Something beyond a cake and coffee reception, but what? ''We decided that homelessness was a major issue and here we were in our business trying to help people have a beautiful home,'' Mr.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL

title: The 'Historic' Era Is Coming Closer to Us
description: During the stereo LP era, the term ''historical'' was traditionally used for recordings originally issued at 78 rpm, and the field was naturally dominated by the descendants of the companies that were dominant in the years before LP - above all the Victor Talking Machine Company (later RCA, now BMG) and the Gramophone Company (EMI/Angel). The current Polygram companies (Deutsche Grammophon, Philips and Decca/London) have a comparatively meager and parochial inheritance in that area. But now the period during which those companies came into their own, the 1950's, has receded far enough into the past to earn the adjective ''historic'' in London's new midprice, CD-only series bearing that name. (Philips uses ''legendary.'') Bargain-priced reissues of distinguished early-LP recordings are nothing new, of course. But it is a little startling to realize that the performances in this generally rewarding batch of nine single disks and one three-disk set (featuring Josef Krips, Julius Katchen, Lisa Della Casa, Clifford Curzon and others) are mostly older today than those classic Galli-Curci, Bauer, Kreisler and Bori records were when they began appearing as historical reissues in the 1950's. So, historic indeed.

title: Unlikely Duo Develops a Winning Scent
description: LEAD: IT was an unlikely scenario, but, as it turned out, the chemistry was right. Leonard Paul Cuozzo was an automobile salesman who tinkered with fragrances in his spare time and dreamed of one day gaining a toehold in the glitzy, fiercely competitive fragrance industry.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: KENSICO DAM PLAZA;

Arborists Tend to the Needs of Old Friends in a Rite of Spring
description: LEAD: WHEN he was growing up, John Triano loved the trees at the Kensico Dam Plaza here. He climbed their branches in spring, rested in their shade in summer, crunched through their leaves in the fall.

title: Images of History Show How a Green Helped Define a City
description: LEAD: SINCE New Haven was established in the 1600's by settlers from Stamford, the two cities' histories have been intertwined. Now, the Stamford Historical Society has mounted an exhibition, ''New Haven's Green: Town Center Since 1638.''

title: Chemical-Free Farm Produces Livestock And Plenty of Pride
description: LEAD: AT Breezy Hill Farm in Warren, the feed lot is full this time of year with more than two dozen ewes nursing about 50 lambs. In a nearby barn, pens hold newborn lambs, still bonding with their mothers, and a quartet of piglets. The coop across a meadow resounds with the peeps of 150 baby chicks; 25 young turkeys will arrive next month.

title: About Men;   California Dreaming
description: I GREW UP IN THE Kentucky knobs, a westward-flung, northwest-curling finger of the Appalachians: steep, Catholic-ridden ridges that form a ragged barrier between the ruling-class Presbyterians and gentlemen-farmer Episcopalians of the rolling Bluegrass (to the north and east) and the foot-washing Baptists and dirt-poor Pentacostals of the lumpy Pennyrile (to the south and west). Across nearly two centuries, we Catholics of the knobs made our livings from servicing vice, our own and our neighbors'. In spring and summer, when creeks ran full and clear in their limestone beds, distilleries ran round the clock. Men farmed tobacco during the day, worked the night shift making bourbon: Heaven Hill, Jim Beam, Antique, Maker's Mark. Women raised kids in daylight, worked the bottling plants at night. In fall, the creeks ran low, the distilleries shut down, and we turned to the tobacco harvest.

title: All About/Toothpaste;   Growth Is Glacial, but the Market Is Big, and So Is the Gross
description: There are few things in life more humdrum than the toothbrush. One of them is toothpaste. Yet the unprepossessing goo has for decades occupied the attention of some of the world's largest and savviest manufacturers of consumer products.

title: Suzette M. Brooks Becomes a Bride
description: Suzette M. Brooks, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Brooks of New York, was married last evening at Temple Rodeph Sholom in New York to Seth J. Masters, a son of Judith Bush of Sharon, Vt., and Dr. Roger D. Masters of South Woodstock, Vt. Rabbi Harold I. Saperstein and Cantor Ephraim Biran officiated.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

The Tug of a Beloved Dog's Memory Doesn't Ease With Time
description: LEAD: I WAS riding down Stratton Road listening to Mozart. My heart skipped two beats as I spotted them. High, majestic-looking, sporting the warm burnt hues of autumn on their furry coats. ''Airedales, the giant terriers . . .,'' I whispered under my breath. I almost hit a tree on the side of the road.

title: Carol S. Weissman Is Wed to Lawrence B. Wolfe
description: Carol Sue Weissman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Saul A. Weissman of Roslyn Heights, L.I., was married there last evening to Lawrence Brian Wolfe, a son of Milton A. Wolfe of Plymouth, Mass., and Betty L. Wolfe of Needham, Mass. Rabbi Aaron Petuchowsky performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai.

title: Review/Theater;   'The Tower of Evil,' Dumas Revenge Tale
description: Though Alexandre Dumas pere is best known for his romantic novels ''The Three Musketeers'' and ''The Count of Monte Cristo,'' he also left a legacy of plays, including ''La Tour de Nesle,'' a bloodthirsty historical melodrama written in 1832. Despite that play's continuing popularity in France, it turns out to be creaky and contrived, not the well-oiled mechanism one would have expected. The fact is attributable to the play itself (entitled ''The Tower of Evil'' in Michael Feingold's new translation) and also to Carey Perloff's production at the CSC Repertory.

title: REFERENCE
description: ''E'' IS FOR ELVIS: An A-to-Z Illustrated Guide to the King of Rock and Roll. By Caroline Latham and Jeannie Sakol. (NAL, $19.95.) ''E'' is also for enormous: Elvis Presley, a man of enormous talent and enormous excess, has inspired books of enormous ambition (Greil Marcus's ''Mystery Train''), enormous contempt (Albert Goldman's ''Elvis'') and enormous triviality (too many to single out just one). '' 'E' Is For Elvis'' is among the most trivial of all, yet it's not without a certain goony charm. The book is organized as an alphabetical listing of notable people, events and items in Presley's life. Caroline Latham and Jeannie Sakol's concept of notable, however, may differ from yours or mine: ''Crazy,'' for example, is one entry under ''C.'' What's that? Why, it's ''one of the nicknames frequently used for Elvis Presley by members of his entourage.'' Oh. But wait, on the same page there's an entry for George Cukor. What's the great film director's Elvis connection? He apparently spent one day on the set of a Presley movie and is quoted as saying of the rock idol: ''He can do anything! He would be a dream to direct. His comedy timing is faultless.'' Dropping the guise of objective historians for just one minute, Ms. Latham and Ms. Sakol cannot resist adding, ''What a pity Cukor never worked with Elvis on a film.'' How true: in the Spencer Tracy role opposite Katharine Hepburn in ''Pat and Mike,'' perhaps? So it goes, from A to Z, including ''sooties'' (''the baby-talk word Elvis used for feet''). Almost inadvertently, there is a serious subtext beneath this book's stream of silliness: Presley's talent and image exerted such an influence on millions of people that, 12 years after his death, no fact or detail of his pop myth remains too unimportant to be pondered by his fans. (There's a first-rate scholarly book about this phenomenon, by the way: Neal and Janice Gregory's ''When Elvis Died.'') Presley is in many respects the culmination of this century's popular culture, and cannot be summarized, contained or even dismissed by a book as foolish and harmless as '' 'E' Is For Elvis.''

title: Write Off Castro? The Odds Change
description: AS Communist dictatorships tottered and fell in Eastern Europe last year, a natural question was whether the 31-year-old Cuban regime of Fidel Castro would soon be next.

title: Violence? In the Beholder's Eye
description: Bizarre. Poetic. Weird. Gross. Disgusting. Comic. Brilliant. Obnoxious. Stylish. Sadistic. Sorrowful. Puerile. Triumphant. The list goes on.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: NEW PRESTON;

Upscale Shops Are Taking Root in an Out-of-the-Way Village
description: LEAD: SIX years ago, Barbara Corey Tippin of Westport was looking for a building to renovate as a bookstore. Her quest led her to Litchfield County, to New Preston, a part of the town of Washington. The community's quaint 19th-century Main Street had fallen on hard times. The grocery store had gone out of business several years earlier, and the post office had been moved to Marble Dale, another section of Washington.

title: From Troubled Times To Host of Talk Shows
description: LEAD: SALLY JESSY RAPHAEL - host of national television and radio talk shows, a Westchester resident and the author of a new autobiography - has interviewed thousands of people in her career.

title: Debate Over Gun-Control Bill Intensifies
description: LAW-ENFORCEMENT officials say New Jersey's gun-control laws, which are among the strictest in the nation, are not tough enough to protect police officers and innocent bystanders from the lethal crossfire of drug-related shootings.

description: Tennis

title: China Waits Anxiously for Ruling On Its Trade Status With the U.S.
description: A highly charged issue is looming in relations between the United States and China, and it has Chinese officials and intellectuals concerned over their future, their standard of living and their contacts with the West.

title: Currency;   A Bad Week for the Dollar
description: It was a bad week for the dollar. First, on Wednesday, it dropped sharply against the West German mark, the Swiss franc and other European currencies. Then on Friday, the other shoe fell, as the dollar plummeted against the Japanese yen. The dollar has been weak against the mark and most Europen currencies all year but strong against the yen. The move last week was triggered by a change in sentiment about interest rates in the United States. Until last week, the odds favored an increase in rates. Now the betting is for no change or maybe even a decrease. Friday's inflation report, showing a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, just reinforced the belief that interest rates might actually decline. $ Last Previous Year Week Week Ago Japanese Yen 152.70 158.25 135.85 per Dollar W.German Mark 1.6380 1.6662 1.8917 per Dollar Canadian Dollar 1.1763 1.1630 1.1878 per U.S. Dollar British Pound 1.6778 1.6630 1.6630 U.S. Dollar per British Pound Gold $368.50 $371.30 $376.25 Republic National Bank

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Yankee Doodle Sorter
description: LEAD: I AM changing my ways. The state is telling me that by 1991 my newspapers must be separated, my bottles recycled and my toxic cleaning fluids properly discarded. This new legislation is forcing me to become a more conscious consumer and I feel good about it.

title: Review/Music;   King's Singers From Britain
description: The King's Singers, like their instrumental counterparts the Canadian Brass, ply the murky waters that lie between the high-minded in music and music that will sell. It is not an easy job. One noticed as much at Alice Tully Hall last Sunday night as these six British vocalists rowed arduously back and forth between Renaissance classics, obscure Romanticism and 20th-century trivia.

title:
RIDGEWOOD JOURNAL;

After Dispute, Return of Race to Memorial Day Pleases Runners
description: LEAD: THE annual Ridgewood Run, which has been held here every Memorial Day for 14 years, went badly off course last year when organizers angered many residents and runners by changing the date.

title: Catching Up With Change In Eastern Europe: First Steps and Second Thoughts
description: THE transformation of Eastern Europe is moving off the streets and into the political chambers, but the speed of change is still dizzying. As the emerging democracies seek their own identities, they are also trying to determine their places in a Europe whose Western powers are already faced with the challenges of creating a new community by 1992. Here, compiled from reports by New York Times correspondents, is a country-by-country update on the evolution.

title: Yes, Screen Blood by Risk, Not Country of Origin
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page caption and a headline with an article on April 8 about Italian gardens misstated the location of Bagnaia. It is in central, not northern, Italy.

title: WHEN WILL THE BOOK BE DONE?
description: As a writer, I am familiar with the stops and starts of bringing a project into the world: the expectations, the disappointments, the longing for the normalcy of a predictable job and the awareness, not always pleasant, that there is truly nothing else one can, or must, do (''When Will the Book Be Done?'' April 15). Thus, I was touched by Susan Sheehan's depiction of such a writer's life, both her own and her husband, Neil's. I was moved by Neil's dedication and thrilled at his deserved triumph. And I have tremendous respect for the marriage/partnership sustained by the Sheehans, through their mutual belief in each other. Thank you for an inspiring portrait.

title: Orioles Defeat Athletics on 2 Homers by Ripken
description: Cal Ripken's second home run of the game led off the ninth inning today as Baltimore beat Oakland by 3-2 in the Orioles' first victory over the Athletics in nine games.

title: WHAT WOMEN WANT FROM FEMINISM
description: The author theorizes proficiently with many philosophical models. But where are strong political models such as Golda Meir and Margaret Thatcher mentioned? For a serious student of feminism, Gornick might serve us better with a discussion of women who use power well, or even those who have abused it, such as Indira Ghandi.

title: Nelda Christiansen, a Writer, Marries Clifton Swiggett, a Software Manager
description: Nelda Christiansen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Christiansen of Bainbridge Island, Wash., was married there yesterday to Clifton Swiggett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Swiggett of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Donald Mayer officiated at the Eagle Harbor Congregational Church.

title: Norman Splashes To Memorial Lead
description: Wind, rain and fast greens have made an already difficult golf course miserably demanding, but not coincidently, two of the game's elite were at the top of the leader board today after three rounds of the Memorial Tournament.

title: Rating Safaris
description: To the Editor: I have traveled to Africa and have been researching the African travel market for six months. One of my research inquiries took me to D. H. Doelker in December after seeing her advertisement in the Travel section.

title: Tuckahoe Bridge Awaits State
description: LIKE many of the county's older villages, Tuckahoe had been showing signs of age. When village officials discovered that the rumbling of car and truck traffic over the Main Street bridge had doubled in a decade, they called in state engineers to evaluate the health of the 75-year-old structure - the only western access to the business district.

title: Miriam E. Kearney Married to Kevin A. Tedesco
description: Miriam E. Kearney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Kearney 3d of Essex Fells, N.J., was married yesterday to Kevin A. Tedesco, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Tedesco of Armonk, N.Y. The Rev. George Cotter, the bride's uncle, officiated at Our Lady of the Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Roseland, N.J. The bride, 29 years old and a Post College graduate, is a sales representative with Reuters Information Services in New York. Mr. Tedesco, 31 and a Northeastern University graduate, is a communications manager at the Young & Rubicam advertising agency in New York.

title: Amy de l'Orme Petersen Wed to Gardner Walling
description: At the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., Amy de l'Orme Petersen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Petersen of Haverford, Pa., was married yesterday to Gardner Ritner Skene Walling, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Walling of Gladwyne, Pa. The Very Rev. Dean Arnold E. Mintz and the Rev. James R. Squire officiated. Mrs. Walling, a graduate of Denison University, as is her husband, is a special events director at the Cystic Fibrosis Foundation in Philadelphia. Her father is a principal in Experience-on-Tap, employment consultants to retired people in Strafford, Pa. The bridegroom is a vice president of the Exact Fuel coal company in Pennsauken, N.J.

title: Grandson's Cycling Gift
description: Coba Zanoli is 78 years old. Last year, when she became sick, her grandson, Michael, tried to cheer her. He said he would bring her from the Netherlands to the United States this year to watch him race.

title: Senate Campaign Reform vs. a Senate Campaign
description: THE most skilled group of political fund raisers anywhere, members of the United States Senate, came forward last week with what they pronounced as their best efforts at improving the way Senate campaigns raise and spend money.

title: America's Cup: What the Impasse Meant
description: It's over. At long last, the America's Cup has found a home. Some would have us believe that for the three long years we sailors patiently waited for court decisions to come down, yacht racing had completely stalled out on the water. On the contrary, there was a lot going on. It may be that the America's Cup crowd will find they have to work harder for our attention next time around.

title: The Silent Drama In Vuillard's Rooms
description: EdouarD Vuillard has been called an intimist, and the term has made it possible for him to be thought of as minor: a painter of interiors, of life that is merely private, a thoughtful, wistful chronicler of a vanished world, a boy who lived at home. Major shows devoted to Vuillard are rare. ''The Intimate Interiors of Edouard Vuillard,'' the exhibition of his paintings and prints that will open on Friday at the Brooklyn Museum (it has already been seen in Washington and Houston), is the first major show in nearly two decades.

title: Amy J. Leissner Becomes a Bride
description: Amy J. Leissner, the finance associate at the New York City Ballet, was married yesterday to Stuart Wittenstein, the coordinator of the vision resource center at the New York City Board of Education, at the home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. B. E. Leissner, near Victoria, Tex. Judge Frank Crane, a retired judge of the 135th Judicial District Court of Texas in Victoria, officiated.

title: Elizabeth Winans Planning To Wed James Rossman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter Winans of Bedford, N.Y., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Winans and James Rossman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rossman of Cleveland.

NEW JERSEY Q & A: LILLIAN C. LIBURDI;

Port Chief's Aim: Beating the Competition
description: LEAD: AMONG pictures, plaques and mementos in Lillian C. Liburdi's office is a life preserver with these words on it: ''S.S. Liburdi, Port Authority Port Director, Revival Ltd.'' The rescue and revival implication is the challenge to Ms. Liburdi to lead the effort to make the local ports - Newark and Elizabeth on the New

title: The Executive Computer;   Where the Libraries Are Leading the Way
description: Companies that are trying to figure out how they will manage the flow of information in the 1990's and beyond might begin their research with a trip to the library - not to take out a book but to study the ways in which libraries are preparing for the 21st century. In the vanguard of information technology, today's librarians are as likely to be experts in work stations, networking, communications protocols, electronic imaging and fiber optics as they are in books and manuscripts. The information technologies and techniques now being explored by libraries are likely to serve as models for businesses in the years to come.

title:
DANCE;

Troupe to Show Up-to-Date Profile
description: LEAD: THE push and pull of couples, as choreographed by Nicholas Rodriguez for DanceCompass, receives a sharply humorful interpretation in ''Inasides Out,'' which the Montclair-based modern troupe will perform next Sunday at Montclair State College. This dance-theater piece and the four other works on the program provide an up-to-date profile of the company Mr.

title: State Using Electronic Device To Monitor Prisoners at Home
description: LEAD: AN experimental electronic monitor that lets prisoners and parolees serve supervised time at home has impressed state corrections officials with its ability to cut costs and reduce prison overcrowding.

title: Wendy Dietze Marries Jay M. Courage
description: Katherine E. Dietze, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Dietze of Mountain Lakes, N.J., was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York to Jay M. Courage, a son of Elsa J. Courage of Birmingham, Mich., and Jay W. Courage of Greenville, S.C. The Rev. Jane Henderson officiated. The bride, known as Wendy, is a vice president at Salomon Brothers, where the bridegroom is a director of energy investment banking. Mrs. Courage graduated from Brown University and received an M.B.A. from Columbia University. The bridegroom received an undergraduate degree and an M.B.A. from the University of Michigan. His first marriage ended in divorce.

title: Janet Bobit Marries Richard Greenberg
description: Janet J. Bobit and Richard B. Greenberg were married yesterday at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston by Associate Justice Rudolph Kass of the Massachusetts Court of Appeals. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley R. Bobit of Midland, Mich. Her husband is a son of Bernice C. Greenberg of Miami Beach and the late Mortimer J. Greenberg.

title: POSTINGS: $25.5 Million Minimum;   Hotel Auction
description: The 16-story Parkview Hilton overlooking the Connecticut State Capitol in Hartford, which had been been closed earlier this year for lack of businesss, will be auctioned off next month. The 401-room hotel, one of the largest in the state, its adjoining 320-space garage and the two acres of land they sit on carry a minimum price of $25.5 million.

title: A Negative Vote On Affirmative Action
description: IN A FEW SHORT YEARS, WHEN MY TWO children will be applying to college, the affirmative-action policies by which most universities offer black students some form of preferential treatment will present me with a dilemma. I am a middle-class black, a college professor, far from wealthy, but also well removed from the kind of deprivation that would qualify my children for the label ''disadvantaged.'' Both of them have endured racial insensitivity from whites. They have been called names, have suffered slights and have experienced first hand the peculiar malevolence that racism brings out of people. Yet they have never experienced racial discrimination, have never been stopped by their race on any path they have chosen to follow. Still, their society now tells them that if they will only designate themselves as black on their college applications, they will probably do better in the college lottery than if they conceal this fact. I think there is something of a Faustian bargain in this.

title: Christina Burnet Weds David Peng
description: Christina Margaret Burnet, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank N. Burnet of Silver Spring, Md., was married yesterday in Washington to David Hoantee Peng, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lee Dah Peng of Ozone Park, Queens. The Rev. Francis J. Bober officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Stephen Martyr.

title: At 77, Finding Work for the Handicapped
description: EVALD GASSTROM, an industrial engineer and the former owner and president of the Eagle Rule Manufacturing Company, a large tool manufacturer, is an unlikely social worker. Yet some years ago, after Mr. Gasstrom sold his company to the Durall Tool Company in Yonkers, he became the director of a vocational-rehabilitation workshop in East Harlem.

title: CORPORTE DESIGN THAT STAYS ONTHE SAFE SIDE
description: It may be easy to knock I.B.M. if you're in the computer business, but it's tougher if you're in the architecture business. For nearly 40 years the I.B.M. Corporation has been the business world's most consistently serious architectural patron, producing an array of buildings by the likes of Eero Saarinen, Marcel Breuer, Mies van der Rohe, Edward Larrabee Barnes and Mitchell/Giurgola that seem intended not only to serve the company's needs, but to prove beyond any doubt that a mega-corporation can engage in high-quality building on an international scale.

title: Car Bombs Kill at Least 19 In 2 Bogota Shopping Malls
description: Car bombs today ripped through two malls packed with last-minute Mother's Day shoppers here, killing at least 19 people and injuring 143, the Health Ministry said.

title: From Comic Artist And Caricaturist, A Painter Evolves
description: If there were a list of the top 10 artists on college dormitory walls, Lyonel Feininger would surely be on it. His quietly dynamic paintings of new skyscrapers and old churches, old boats and new streets, composed of cubistic planes no thicker than glass or more solid than light but as hard as diamonds and fixed as keystones, have made him a dormitory star. The popular Feininger encourages the belief that a commitment to change and a yearning for refuge is a viable mix.

The player was far from the best student ever to play for Mr. Albies, but a year after his eligibility ran out he was there to tell his team how much he had learned from playing baseball for Mr. Albies and how much he could apply to his life after he graduated that spring.

title: WHEN LEGAL TITANS CLASH
description: Ken Emerson committed a journalistic impropriety by asking me to comment on a purported statement by Dean Robert Clark, one that was different from the one by Clark that he published. He told me that Clark had said that ordinary people didn't really need lawyers, except for wills and divorces. Clark's actual statement was: ''It might be a sign of ill health in the country if people needed lawyers more. An ordinary person, I guess, uses a lawyer for a will, a divorce, buying a house and so on, and even those things ought to be more routinized.'' I leave it to your readers to judge whether those ideas are the same statements.

title: Tech Notes;   Zapping Safety Into Toxic Waste
description: Researchers at Battelle Memorial Institute's Pacific Northwest Laboratories have come up with what they call a ''promising'' approach to dealing with radioactive and toxic materials contaminating ground at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington state: they electrocute it. Last month, they drove four 30-foot-long graphite and molybdenum electrodes into the ground at the edges of a site, 40 feet in diameter, contaminated with cesium and strontium and hazardous chemicals. They ran power through the electrodes for 288 hours, heating the soil and contaminants to 3,500 degrees Fahrenheit. The electricity melted 900 tons of material. In a year, when the material cools, scientists hope to find that the long-lived radioisotopes have been trapped harmlessly in the obsidian-like mass.

title:
THEATER;

Theatrical Pilgrims Find a Road Less Traveled
description: LEAD: A new breed of director is advancing toward fame, if not fortune, in today's theater. Often armed with a graduate degree in the craft or solid regional credits instead of years of experience behind the scenes in New York, these directors have something else in common: they are women in a field not noted for extending them a warm welcome.

title: Released Harmed
description: However bad the living conditions for most foreign hostages in Lebanon, Frank Herbert Reed said they were worse for him. Mr. Reed, one of two recently released American hostages, said at news conference last week that he was singled out for harsh treatment by his Shiite fundamentalist abductors and that his 43 months in captivity were punctuated by beatings that at various times left his feet, ribs and nose broken. The 57-year-old Mr. Reed, who at the time of his capture was a director of the Lebanese International School in Beirut, said the beatings were punishment for his two attempts to escape. Most of the time, he said, he was blindfolded and manacled. ''I have been lying on my back for literally three and half years chained either to a wall or a radiator,'' he said. Robert Polhill, a 55-year-old accounting professor who on April 30 became the first to be released among eight American captives held in Lebanon, said he was ''shocked to hear what Frank was saying,'' about his treatment by his abductors. Said Mr. Reed, ''Thank God they didn't kill me.''

description: Get ready to rap and roll. The show stars Young MC, who won this year's Grammy Award for rap music, and Kid 'n Play, a hip-hop rap duo that recently gained attention in the critically praised black teen-age crossover movie ''House Party.''

title: REFERENCE
description: THE BFI COMPANION TO THE WESTERN. Edited by Edward Buscombe. (Atheneum, $50.) Remember the western? Edward Buscombe of the British Film Institute does, and he and a legion of contributors have produced a magnificent, lavishly packaged compendium of facts, figures, maps, thumbnail biographies and capsule reviews for the enjoyment and edification of fans of this fast disappearing cultural product. It is ironic, but perhaps fitting, that a book like ''The BFI Companion to the Western'' becomes possible only when its subject is dying or dead, and thus a fit specimen for cultural archeologists. It is paradoxical as well that it has been left to Britain to produce a book on what is, after all, often regarded as the essentially American genre of the essential American art form. If the western is indeed dead, it is enjoying a brisk afterlife on videotape, and Mr. Buscombe's book should become an essential companion for the armchair aficionados of classics like ''My Darling Clementine'' or ''Red River,'' as well as for enthusiasts of such genre benders as ''One-Eyed Jacks'' and ''The Missouri Breaks.'' The first third or so of this volume is devoted to a ''Culture and History'' dictionary, wherein we find entries ranging from ''Abilene'' to ''Zapata'' and learn things like ''three dentists have made a notable contribution to the Western''; that wooden Indians in films were often the ''occasion of a joke''; that the Sharps rifle was the favorite gun of buffalo hunters; and that John (Liver-Eating) Johnson was ''reputed to have killed over two hundred Crow'' Indians, although it is not known whether he ate their livers. Many of these entries are disappointing, low on facts and high on all-too-obvious academic observations about metaphors, themes and the like. The rest of the book is divided among a selective (as opposed to exhaustive) collection of film summaries, a section of biographical sketches of actors and directors and an annotated list of television westerns. Although the entries in these sections, too, are uneven, most of the significant films and film makers are cited. And Mr. Buscombe has included an additional treat: 22 color plates reproducing the work of celebrated painters of western scenes like Thomas Cole and Frederic Zimmerman.

title: REFERENCE
description: WICKED WORDS: A Treasury of Curses, Insults, Put-Downs, and Other Formerly Unprintable Terms From Anglo-Saxon Times to the Present. By Hugh Rawson. (Crown, $24.95.) This compendium of epithets, pejoratives, blasphemies and obscenities manages to be informal in its style without succumbing to idiosyncrasy or leering. It also manages to be scholarly without being didactic or dry - always a hazard for those who want to achieve respectability and objectivity about any vulgar subject. The tone here is urbane, amused; and the result is that one ends up reading ''Wicked Words'' as much for enjoyment as for information. The nine or 10 major expletives receive essay-length treatment, including combinative forms and phrases, etymological facts and speculations. For example, we learn that the commonest obscenity meaning ''vulva'' - ''the most heavily tabooed of all English words,'' according to Mr. Rawson - may well be derived from the same root that appears in ''gynecologist,'' and that many Anglo-Saxon words became taboo only after the Norman conquest. Mr. Rawson, in his introduction and in the entries themselves, writes with a nice, funny, Latinate turn of phrase - ''Shakespeare also seems to have been using lay down with more than pure recumbency in mind.'' And under the word ''hot:'' ''That passion elevates the temperature has long been known.'' It may be a little confusing to list minor geographical insults - like ''Bedlam,'' ''Buncombe County, North Carolina,'' and ''Shanghai'' - under ''Peoria,'' but generally the book is clear and well organized, and many entries end with enlightening cross-references and excellent bibliographical material. As it should be in any such collection, the implicit feeling here is wonder at and delight in that most complex, expressive and spontaneous work of art, language.

title: Much to Be Said For Neighborliness In the New Europe
description: AFTER the fall of the Berlin wall, France and West Germany suddenly looked at each other anew and wondered. They had succeeded in burying centuries of mutual distrust after World War II, but as change stirred up history, there were ominous signs that old rivalries had not been forgotten.

title: THE FELIX BLOCH AFFAIR
description: PARIS IN THE SPRING. IT IS EARLY EVENING ON MAY 14, 1989 , and Felix Bloch is strolling down the Rue Faubourg St.-Honore, one of the world's most expensive shopping streets, carrying a black airline-type bag with a shoulder strap. He pauses to look in the shop windows. He is being watched, and the watchers think he is studying the reflections in the glass to see if he is being followed.

Plucky actors appeared in new plays in the basement of a brownstone here. The Renegade had an instant identity, capped by professional credentials. That was five years ago.

title: Westbury Plans Not the Perfect Solution
description: A group, Arise of Westbury, has wonderful ideas for an empty property in Freeport (''Proposal for Jobs and Homes Fought,'' April 15). Their plans sound like the perfect answer to a serious social problem. They were certainly widely quoted and much attention was given to their description of a recent meeting.

title: Market Sees That Junk Bonds Are, Well, Junk;   Remember Banks?
description: To the Editor:

title: Four Inns at twohundredsomething;   The Eastern Shore: At the Robert Morris Inn, a taste of the colonies
description: If you are contemplating a sojourn at the Robert Morris Inn on the Eastern Shore of Maryland, it might be wise to take along a good book or a good friend. For there are few distractions at the charming inn that dates back to 1701.

title: As AIDS Spreads, So Do Warnings for Partners
description: After years of reluctance, a growing number of states have begun recording the names of people who are shown by tests to be infected with the AIDS virus and warning their sex and drug partners.

title: Mutual Funds
description: A Spotlight on 'Forgotten Funds'

title: Talking Like a Leader
description: In a rare and dramatic televised speech from City Hall Friday night, Mayor David Dinkins turned from quiet diplomacy to leadership. His ringing personal appeal for racial tolerance and healing deserves the attention and respect of all fair-minded New Yorkers.

title: NONFICTION
description: JANUARY SUN: One Day, Three Lives, A South African Town. By Richard Stengel. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) ''One is political here just by being human,'' an Indian businessman says in Richard Stengel's portrayal of a midsummer's day in the life of an Afrikaner, an Indian and a black South African who live in the small Transvaal town of Brits. Unfortunately, both the human and the political elements are curiously muted in a book that seems to have borrowed its style from documentary television: everything that falls within the camera's focus is minutely examined to the accompaniment of a dispassionate and disembodied voice-over narration. Mr. Stengel, in his first book, has selected his facts with little regard to what might interest or inform his audience. The number of taxis owned by a particular taxi company, the names of each factory in the town, routes taken to and from work, every gesture made by a shoe salesman or customer are carefully and solemnly noted to stultifying effect. We come to know exactly what these characters do, but remarkably little about who they are. Yet the book has its rewards, particularly when the principal figures are allowed to speak. Referring to the homelands, the black man says, ''In South Africa . . . the white man has names for places where there are no places.'' The Afrikaner veterinarian, whose specialty is artificial insemination, waxes eloquent on the type of cow known as the Africander: ''Our cattle are less calm, less docile than European cattle. The Africander likes freedom.'' The effect is chilling when he speaks of the human population in similar eugenic terms. These are a few of the book's occasional patches of light, but for the most part, ''January Sun'' fails to illuminate.

title: ARCHIVES FROM TWO WHO GOT ROCK ROLLING
description: It's mildly amazing how little commercial success Carl Perkins and Jerry Lee Lewis have had, given their positions as two of the great architects of rock-and roll. Both started recording in the mid-1950's; by 1960, each had worn out his respective hits (and Mr. Lewis had married his 13-year-old cousin, which further helped sink his carreer). After that, each spent most of his time either reworking a handful of his best material or looking to country music for salvation.

title: Elizabeth O'Neill To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Ann O'Neill to James Anthony Mercadante, the son of Dr. and Mrs. James L. Mercadante of Garden City, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. O'Neill of Garden City. A June wedding is planned.

title: Focus: The I-5 Corridor;   A Lively New Washington Growth Area
description: ONLY three years ago, the suburban community of Everett, Wash., 30 miles north of Seattle, was hobbled by a recession that enveloped the Pacific Northwest. Now commercial activity there is among the strongest in the country, and growth, accompanied by residential and retail construction, is expected to continue until well into the mid-90's.

title: Leave the Stock Index Futures Alone
description: In New York and Washington these days, there is a lot of grumbling about stock index futures. These are contracts to buy or sell the value of a stock index, like the Standard & Poor's 500, on a future date at a price established when the contract is entered into.

title: The Woman Joyce's Women Came From
description: Julie Harris stands in a rehearsal hall dangling a book distastefully, as if it were an insect with 3 heads and 14 legs. Affecting a confident Irish lilt, she charges into her lines: '' 'Ulysses.' A book so dirty that in America it drove them into the streets to fornicate. Aah, but that's literature.'' At the word ''literature,'' she opens her hand, and the accursed book crashes down into a trunk.

title: Good Cards, Good Crowds
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Session Ended, Capitol Glories Are Campaign Grist
description: Just before midnight on Wednesday, House Speaker Richard J. Balducci banged his gavel, at once signaling the end of the General Assembly's 1990 session and the start of the campaign season for the statewide elections in November.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: It is not uncommon for a club to arrange a Pro-Am event in which invited experts play with members. But that requires the cooperation of many stars who may not be willing to spare the time. Few clubs appreciate that a special evening can be built around one or two experts who play each board with a different partner.

title: Communities Are Recycling Tires in Clean-Energy Program
description: SEVERAL times a month, trucks laden with waste tires leave the Yonkers compacting station on Saw Mill River Road bound for Port Newark, N.J. There, at Integrated Tire, a recycler licensed by the New Jersey Environmental Protection Department, the tires are shredded into two-inch strips and shipped to be used as a supplemental fuel in making cement.

title: THE GUIDE
description: COUNTY FUTURE

title: Games Congressmen Play
description: LEAD: DEMOCRATIC CONGRESSMAN CHARLIE WILSON of Texas is tall, lean and as ramrod straight as any movie cowboy. He is also conservative, flamboyant and unpredictable. Through the 1980's, his consuming interest was the Afghan guerrillas: several times he visited them (once trying to take along his friend, a former Miss World; when the Air Force balked, he set out to cut Defense Department appropriations), and his colleagues half-jokingly traded rumors about his firing weapons at Soviet troops.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Mother and Friend

title: POSTINGS: Nuns Selling Land;   L.I. Synagogue
description: A new congregation of 150 Jewish families in Woodbury, L.I., has contracted to buy six acres from Roman Catholic nuns as the site for what may be the first Conservative synagogue to be built in Nassau County in many years. The Woodbury Jewish Center will be built on South Woods Road across the street from Our Lady of Mercy Academy, operated by the Order of the Sisters of Mercy.

title: The 1800's Live On In a New York Village
description: The Seneca Indians called it Gen-nis-he-y, or ''beautiful valley.'' The broad, fertile region spreading westward from New York State's Finger Lakes to the Niagara Frontier also shares its name with America's longest north-flowing river and with a form of malaria (''Genessee fever''), which plagued early pioneers.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

A Daughter's Welcome Duty
description: LEAD: HER normally high yet stable blood pressure soared a bit, and the symptoms were not good. Her head hurt, she had no appetite, the mouth felt dry, the body weak. The skin was pale hide, and the eyes looked sickly; glassy, pink and puffy.

description: Katherine Rae Stallings, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Stallings of Rumson, N.J., was married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York to Jonathan Peter Bren, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter M. Bren of New York. The Rev. Charles S. Temple performed the ceremony.

title: Bensonhurst Jury Stuck
description: The jury in the trial of Keith Mondello said it had decided some counts but was unable to reach agreement on other charges. The judge told the jurors to keep trying. Page 24.

description: No matter what the situation, never underestimate George Steinbrenner's motives to manipulate it.

title: Question Of the Week;   Will Dent and Johnson Last The Season?
description: Whether Davey or Bucky goes, or should go, is unimportant. Whether it will ever again be a consistent joy to be a baseball fan in New York is at stake.

description: Elizabeth Hollister Adam, the daughter of Donald G. Adam of Pittsburgh and Nancy T. Adam of Nantucket, Mass., was married yesterday to Charles Francis Smithers 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Smithers Jr. of New Canaan and Old Black Point, Conn., at the Unitarian Universalist Church in Nantucket. The Rev. Edward Anderson officiated.

description: I was a vice president at Merrill Lynch & Company in charge of developing and implementing large-scale financial computer systems. By March 1, 1988, we had achieved our major program goals and I became a cost-cutting statistic and was fired.

description: I was stuck in traffic, pointed vaguely at New York City. Fuming had turned to pondering, and I was guessing I was incorrigible.

description: Brazil is the newest high-risk gamble in Latin America's emerging stock markets.

description: Maintaining their risky ritual despite stern warnings against it, the Blackhawks' fans again filled old Chicago Stadium with smoke and light from hundreds of sparklers tonight as a man sang the national anthem before the game against Edmonton.

title: Sharon Kern and Daniel Taub Are Married
description: The marriage of Sharon Kern to Daniel Taub took place last evening at the St. Moritz in New York. Rabbi Stephen Franklin officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Kern of Yonkers. Her husband is the son of Mr. and Mrs. William Taub of Dobbs Ferry, N.Y.

title: A Matter of Choices
description: I have long nursed a secret fantasy of kidnapping Barbara Bush, taking her to a Connecticut hideaway with a perennial border and lots of chintz, and force-feeding her Gatorade until she breaks down and admits that she is pro-choice. This fantasy has nothing to do with Mrs. Bush; it has to do with the role we have been led to believe she plays in the life of her husband.

description: Only in America, or only in Madison Square Garden, can Patrick Ewing share a high-five with Spike Lee, smack in the middle of a genuine, certified, official David Stern National Basketball Association playoff game.

title: THE MIDI MENACE: MACHINE PERFECTION IS FAR FORM PERFECT
description: It's everywhere - or getting there. Canned music has escaped the home stereo to blare from concert stages. Blame it on musicians' love of convenience, fear of mistakes or urge to modernize; blame it on the fact that audiences hear recorded music far more often than live music, and educate our ears accordingly. But without even a taped fanfare, automation now infests the performance of popular music; no one apologizes any more.

title: Solid Choices
description: In a vote of the National Basketball Association's 27 head coaches, David Robinson of San Antonio, the unanimous choice as N.B.A. Rookie of the Year, and Tim Hardaway of Golden State were unanimously voted to the league's all-rookie team named yesterday.

title: Laura House Weds
description: Laura Lynne House, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Junius House of Tarboro, N.C., was married last evening to Jonathan Avram Kramer, a son of Mrs. M. Eli Kramer of New York and the late Mr. Kramer. Rabbi Dennis Ross officiated at the Washington Hebrew Congregation. Mrs. Kramer, 25 years old, graduated from Vassar College, as did her husband. She is a candidate for an M.B.A. degree at George Washington University. Mr. Kramer, 26, is a real-estate broker at Barrueta & Associates in Washington.

title: Four Inns at twohundredsomething;   New Hampshire: John Hancock never slept at this inn
description: The town of Hancock, nestled in the Monadnock region of southwestern New Hampshire - a part of the state that tourism boosters like to call the Currier & Ives corner - boasts 47 buildings on the National Register of Historic Places. One of them, the 10-room John Hancock Inn, is said to be the oldest continuously operating inn in the state.

title: For Census Taker, Lonely Roads Lead to More Lonely Roads
description: FREDERICK FELTON'S job seems awfully lonely as he drives along the winding country roads of Roxbury, seeking out houses hidden deep in the woods. In two hours on one recent afternoon, he encountered just one person. But at least somebody was home.

title: Decoding Bush's Signal On Taxes
description: IN his first 15 months in the White House, amassing his 70 percent popularity rating, President Bush never once suggested that prospects for the economy were anything but rosy, never mentioned that the budget deficit was a problem that would prove painful to solve and never even hinted that his campaign pledge of ''no new taxes'' was other than the guiding beacon of his Administration.

title: Beaufort, a Town That Rose Again
description: In March 1936 the photographer Walker Evans, who was documenting poverty in the South, found himself in Beaufort, S.C., facing an undeniably beautiful 18th-century frame house. The delicate carving around the door frame, the detailed corner moldings and elaborate cornices recalled an era of high style and craftsmanship.

''People would say, 'Just what the world needs, another modern-dance company,' '' acknowledges the brawny, boyish Mr.

description: Warring Christian factions blasted each other's positions with heavy artillery and rockets today, killing 8 people and wounding 30, the police said.

MUSIC;

Opera Institute Fights for Its Life
description: LEAD: LIKE many arts organizations in New Jersey, Opera Music Theater International, directed by Jerome Hines, may have to face the effects of substantial cuts in funds from the state. Mr. Hines, who will present his company in performance next Sunday, is hopeful that the final production of this season will not be the institute's final performance.

title:
Four Inns at twohundredsomethingFour Inns at twohundredsomething;

The Connecticut River: The Griswold Inn: a lively tradition
description: LEAD: The Griswold Inn in Essex, Conn., welcomed its first guest on June 7, 1776. Two hundred and fourteen years later its walls whisper of Indian skirmishes, of patriot and Redcoat plots, of underground railway operations. The cannonball poster bed in Room 2 - its original rope lacing replaced by innerspring and mattress - sighs and groans as only a bed devoted for centuries to the accommodation of weary travelers can.

title: How Brokers Do Their Co-op Surveys
description: THE surveys of the cooperative market produced by a few major borkerages are theo only statistical data available on apartment sales. They light up a few corners of an otherwise dark picture, but they cover only Manhattan, only the upper end of the market and only a small fraction of the thousands of sales that are believed to be made in New York City each year. Some Characters in the Human Comedy

The man kissing Millicent Johnson's hand at a dinner for the American Academy in Rome was Vieri Traxler, the Italian representative at the United Nations, not Peter F. description: DRASTIC price reductions on condominiums in a converted mill are flushing out buyers for the CDM Development Corporation of Boston, a subsidiary of Camp Dresser & McKee of Boston, an international engineering concern.

Slattery 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Slattery Jr. of Garden City, L.I. The Rev. John Coppinger officiated. Mrs. Slattery, a graduate of Rutgers College, received an M.B.A. degree from Pennsylvania State University and is an associate at the Bankers Trust Company in New York. The bridegroom, a graduate of the University of Notre Dame and its law school, is a vice president of LBS Communications, a television syndication company in New York.

description: Mexico's Chamber of Deputies has approved a constitutional amendment to allow private ownership of banks, eight years after they were nationalized.

description: LEAD: The Democrats may be setting themselves up for a double knockout on the budget.

description: Fieldy, a tough 7-year-old mare who has raced all over the country, circled a small field and scored a 1 1/4-length victory yesterday in the $87,900 Beaugay Handicap at Belmont Park.

title: British Deal For Kaolin
description: The ECC Group P.L.C., formerly known as English China Clays, said last week that it had agreed to buy Georgia Kaolin from Combustion Engineering Inc., a unit of ABB Asea Brown Boveri, for $520 million.

title: American Bankers Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its first quarter earnings were adversely affected by a series of storms in the southeastern United States, which caused about $1.5 million in insurance claims, as well as two large farm-owner losses, aggregating about $400,000, net of reinsurance.

title: Chairman of Philips Is Said To Be Stepping Down Early
description: Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics giant, is expected to announce on Monday that its chairman, Cornelis J. van der Klugt, is stepping down more than a year earlier than planned because of pressures resulting from the company's surprisingly poor earnings for the first quarter.

title: Winner: Coney Island
description: A MAJOR new study by an award-winning Brooklyn research group has concluded that a domed sports stadium should be built in Coney Island and financed by a novel combination of bank loans and public donations.

title: Review/Music;   Delicacy Wins Out Over Exuberance
description: The music offered at the Bang on a Can Festival is often as exuberantly raucous as the festival's name suggests. But although there was plenty of exuberance and occasional touches of raucousness in the Kazue Sawai Koto Ensemble's concert, the Thursday night installment of the festival at the RAPP Arts Center, delicacy and detail were more salient features.

title: Ouster at Uganda Bank
description: Uganda's central bank governor, his deputy and the managing director of the country's biggest state commercial bank have been dismissed in a surprise shake-up of the banking industry here. A statement issued on Thursday by President Yoweri Museveni's office gave no reason for the dismissal of the governor of the Bank of Uganda, Suleiman Kiggundu, and the deputy governor, Perez Bukumunhe. But it said a team of financial experts, directly answerable to Mr. Museveni, would be hired to analyze how to improve the bank's perfomance. The statement named Nyonitonyo Kikonyogo, a former deputy governor, as the new governor, and Ezra Suruma, formerly research director at the bank, as the new deputy governor.

title: Knicks Tumble To Pistons
description: The Knicks were forced to try to win with a foul-plagued Patrick Ewing yesterday, but they weren't successful. The Detroit Pistons, the National Basketball Association's defending champions and best defensive team, didn't allow it to happen.

title: Review/Ballet;   A Tcherkassky Milestone
description: Marianna Tcherkassky celebrated her 20th anniversary as a member of American Ballet Theater by dancing the title role of ''Giselle'' on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: S&M Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said sales dropped due to the closing of a Mr. Tire retail center that contributed to revenue in first quarter 1989 but no 1990.

title: Two Picassos Stolen From Bank in Miami
description: Two paintings by Picasso valued at nearly $600,000 were stolen from the headquarters of Republic National Bank of Miami, the police have said. Bank employees noticed that the paintings - ''Musical Instrument Cello'' and ''Bull Skull on a Draped Table'' - were missing early on Thursday, the police said.

title: Miltope Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its U.S. Army tactical command and control system program contributed about $8.5 million in sales, up from $2.2 million a year earlier.

description: b-Net loss The company said anticipated earnings from backlog have incresed from the year-end level of $110 million to $11 million at the end of the latest quarter; however, Turner's totalvolume of construction backlog has declinedslightly from $4.70 billion at year-end 1989 to $4.62 billion at March 31.

title: Review/Art;   After a Much-Debated Cleaning, A Richly Hued Sistine Emerges
description: The project by a team of Vatican restorers to clean Michelangelo's frescoes on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, and in the lunettes just below, has finally concluded, triumphantly, after a decade of sometimes angry debate and widespread concern over the fate of this great work. The newly revealed ceiling looks overwhelmingly beautiful.

title: Perez Unlikely to Make Cut
description: Bob Gansler, the coach of the soccer team that will represent the United States in the World Cup finals next month in Italy, is expected to name his 22-man squad this week, some two weeks before the deadline.

description: Alicia Jennifer Stein, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Stein of New York, was married yesterday to James Roman Rieger, the son of June Rieger of London and the late George Rieger. Judge Michael R. Juviler of the State Court of Claims performed the ceremony at the Faculty House of Columbia University.

title: Evolution in Europe;   For West's Christian Democrats, the East Offers a Chance and a Challenge
description: With many former East bloc countries uncertain where the path away from Communism will lead them, Western Europe's Christian Democratic parties are trying to woo them toward a form of capitalism that emphasizes Christian social values.

title: How Gorbachev Rejected Plan To 'Shock Treat' the Economy
description: In the middle of March, about 60 economists and lawyers began convening each day at a Government country house in the pine woods outside Moscow. Their assignment was to draft laws and decrees that would transform the lethargic, state-planned Soviet economy into a free market, and do it quickly.

title: Barnwell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Uncaring Women's Health Care
description: LEAD: A woman visits her doctor for a yearly checkup.

title: Denver Journal;   Zoo, Sadly: Elephants Are Not For Riding
description: When Simon and Garfunkel said, ''It's all happening at the zoo,'' this is not what they had in mind.

title: Pioneer Systems reports earnings for Year to Dec 2
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $251,000 and $370,000 for the latest and prior years, respectively. Year-ago loss from discontinued operations included write-off of negative goodwill of $948,000, or 30 cents a share, and gain on disposal of operations of $500,000, or 16 cents a share. Year-ago results included write-off of excess of cost over fair value of assets acquired of $2,129,000, or 67 cents a share.

title: Electrochemical Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Electrochemical Industries (Frutarom) Ltd. said comparable results are not available since the company was not required to report first quarter 1989 results. The company's stock was not traded in the U.S. at that time.

title: Ohio Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cuomo Calls for Rise in Gas Tax to Go to Roads
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, saying New York needs to do so before the Federal Government does, has called for a higher state gasoline tax with guaranteed regional distribution of the proceeds.

title: Review/Television;   'Saturday Night Live,' With Andrew Dice Clay
description: ''I want to say Happy Mother's Day to my mother and every other mother out there,'' said Andrew Dice Clay at the end of his appearance as host of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live.'' Making mothers and other women happy has never been one of his priorities before, of course. It was the unrelenting misogyny of the comedian's enormously popular stand-up routine that led Nora Dunn, a regular cast member, and Sinead O'Connor, the scheduled musical guest, to boycott Saturday's show. But even misogynists have moms, and he sounded like he meant it. Can it be he can really act?

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;

Like Father, Like Son
description: LEAD: Is advertising talent inherited or learned? An argument for the former comes from Dick Buckley of the Buckley/Swartz agency in Swampscott, Mass., whose son Bryan is co-chairman of the daring young agency Buckley/DeCerchio Inc. Dick Buckley's latest work is a pro bono ad and logo for the Democracy for China Fund.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Carrier Corp., Syracuse, a subsidiary of the United Technologies Corp. that makes air-conditioning, heating and refrigeration equipment, appointed Richard M. Whiston vice president and general counsel, replacing Richard F. Taylor Jr., who retired.

title: Other Korean Grocers Give To Those in Brooklyn Boycott
description: Korean merchants in New York City are so determined that two Brooklyn greengrocers must survive the heated boycott by black groups trying to close them that they are contributing money to keep the stores open.

title: Review/Music;   Baritone in a Schubert Song Cycle
description: The baritone Sanford Sylvan has won a fine reputation for his intelligent singing and acting in Peter Sellars's productions and elsewhere, with music ranging from Mozart to Weill to Philip Glass to John Adams. Thus his appearance for Schubert's song cycle ''Die Schone Mullerin'' on Thursday night at Merkin Concert Hall, as the last item on this season's popular On Original Instruments series, was widely anticipated.

title: The Militant Women
description: Like many schools across the country, Mills College of Oakland, Calif., is faced with an enrollment shortage. Desperate for tuition income, the trustees of the college that has for 138 years taught only women undergraduates announced that it would admit young men.
