description: Results for the quarter are net of a provision representing management's estimate of the potential impact of premium refund liability under the rate rollback mandated by the 1988 California insurance initiative, proposition 103. The amount of the provision was not immediately available. The estimate is consistent with the method femployed by management for determining potential refund liability at Dec. 31, 1989. No refund liability was recorded in the first quarter of 1989.

title: High Price of Truth
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazilian Stock Speculator Is Freed
description: A Brazilian judge has freed the stock speculator Naji Robert Nahas, who was placed under house arrest after causing a crisis in Brazil's stock exchanges last year, officials said today.

title: Myra Seftel Weds Steven Reisman
description: Myra Lynne Seftel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Seftel of Manhasset, L.I., was married last evening at the Great Neck (L.I.) Synagogue to Dr. Steven Allen Reisman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Reisman of Long Beach, L.I. Rabbi Dale Polakoff officiated.

title: The Dance Is Made and Danced: Now, Whose Property Is It?
description: The dispute between the Joffrey Ballet and Gerald Arpino illustrates all kinds of difficulties in the intersection of ballet and business, but one issue that has especially confounded those on the performing side is whether a choreographer owns his own work.

title: DBA Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Mr. Darman and Green Vegetables
description: Richard Darman, director of the Office of Management and Budget, is a delightful scold. Sometimes he needles business leaders, sometimes Congress or environmentalists or opinion makers, but the stiletto is always wrapped in a colorful phrase. In a metaphor-strewn speech at Harvard recently, he accused the usual suspects of having lost confidence in America.

title: Blacks Attack 3 Vietnamese; One Hurt Badly
description: Shouting anti-Korean slurs, a mob of up to 15 black youths armed with a baseball bat, knives and bottles attacked three Vietnamese men on a Brooklyn street early yesterday and fractured the skull of one victim before fleeing into the night, the police said.

title: Minven Gold reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: the company said it had a larger first-quarter loss than expected mainly due to a significant decrease in the grade of ore mined at its Blackdome mine in British Columbia. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Census Knocks, but Few Want to Answer
description: It took Eddie Quiles exactly half an hour on a recent Saturday to knock on nine apartment doors in the South Bronx and compile one of the sorriest records in the annals of door-to-door canvassing - three households did not answer, four asked him to come back later and two told him to get lost.

title: In South Korea, Another Spring Is Torn by Anger
description: A rally to express solidarity among anti-government workers and students was disrupted this weekend when scuffling broke out on stage. ''We demand to be heard!'' a group of students shouted, trying to seize the microphone. After heated words, the protesters were allowed to denounce the shutting down of their militant campus newspaper, and the rally ended peacefully.

title: Motts Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $503,036 and $309,521 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Dr. Sylvia Kodsi Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Sylvia R. Kodsi, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Baroukh E. Kodsi of Brooklyn, and Dr. Michael Evan Rettig, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Bernard Rettig of Woodmere, L.I., were married yesterday evening. Rabbi Leonard J. Goldstein officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Fittipaldi Breaks Time-Trial Mark
description: Emerson Fittipaldi outdid his teammate Rick Mears with a record-shattering qualifying run today, but the defending Indianapolis 500 champion will have to wait six days to find out if he will start from the pole in the 74th Indy classic, on May 27.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;

A Transition At Swatch USA
description: LEAD: Unwilling to sit still while Swatch International shops around for a new international advertising agency to take care of its estimated $35 million account, Swatch Watch USA. has enlisted a tiny creative boutique agency to see it through the transition.

title: Panama Needs Help, Now
description: Nearly five months have gone by since we invaded Panama, toppled the regime, brought Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to the U.S. to stand trial and arranged for the swearing in of Guillermo Endara as President. The Panamanians applauded our intervention on their behalf and anticipated economic assistance.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This victim of hate and ignorance has a Vietnamese name.

title: Will America Make World Safe for Global Warming?
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMENCEMENTS
description: American University

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Royal Gold Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included receipt of $3.7 million for termination of the Camp Bird venture. c-Net loss

title: Amplicon Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Metallurgical Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Argentina's Painful Path to Efficiency
description: Argentina is suffering through one of its worst recessions since the 1930's. Thousands of people employed by private companies have lost their jobs, and for the first time in 40 years, the hard times might even result in layoffs among the millions of workers on the public payroll.

title: Chengdu Journal;   China's 50 Million Migrants Slip the Short Leash
description: The streets of this provincial capital are paved not with gold but with a layer of asphalt topped with dust, mud and decaying cabbage leaves, but still the peasants troop here in search of jobs and a new life.

title: INSIDE
description: Anger Rising in Romania

title: Syracuse Is Seeded No. 1
description: Syracuse, the defending national champion and unbeaten in its last 24 games, and Yale, which fell one goal short of its first undefeated season, were seeded first and second yesterday in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I lacrosse tournament.

title: Overmyer Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Excitement At Casinos: Is Trump Dealing?
description: Speculating about a possible deal involving Donald J. Trump's three casinos has almost replaced slot machines as the most popular game in Atlantic City.

title: TV Program for Doctors' Offices
description: Whittle Communications is to announce today that it will provide an hourlong television program for doctors offices, starting in October. The program will enable advertisers to reach a select group of consumers, especially mothers.

title: Purcell's 'King Arthur' To Be Given in Concert
description: A concert performance of Purcell's opera ''King Arthur'' is to be presented by the Central City Chorus and an orchestra playing authentic Baroque instruments on Sunday at 7 P.M. at the Central Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue at 64th Street.

title: Louis M. Weber, Lawyer, 85
description: Louis M. Weber, a former counsel for the Skouras Theaters Corporation, died Saturday while visiting relatives in Vienna, Va. He was 85 years old.

title: Accusations On Exxon
description: A former Exxon Corporation manager says company officials received gifts and trips in exchange for awarding lucrative charter-boat contracts last year as part of the cleanup of the huge oil spill off Alaska.

title: Bel Fuse Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company attributed the improved results to revenue growth, cost controls and more efficient overseas operations.

title: Angels Could End Winfield Conflict
description: The conflict between Dave Winfield and the Yankees is apparently headed for arbitration this week, but the California Angels, the team that may or may not be Winfield's employer, are apparently willing to consider discussing a new contract, which could head off a hearing.

title: UNION CALLS STRIKE AT CINCINNATI BELL
description: About 3,000 union workers for Cincinnati Bell struck over health benefits early today, leaving management personnel to run operations.

title: First Regional Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that latest quarter results reflect a reise in expenses, due in part to outlays associated with a substantial new account with Transcorp Pension Services Inc. of Laguna, Calif.

title: Market Place;   The Dubious View of the Rally
description: The Dow Jones industrial average is within a few points of setting a high, but many money managers remain dubious that the rally will continue. They note, for instance, that many stocks have not risen nearly as much as the Dow.

title: The Murders Over the Sneakers
description: ON the cover of the current issue of Sports Illustrated, there is a provocative drawing and headline.

title: Espey Manufacturing & ElecFtronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dodgers Trade Randolph for A's Javier
description: The Los Angeles Dodgers finally found a way to get Juan Samuel and his high-risk glove out of center field yesterday. They traded Willie Randolph to the Oakland Athletics for Stan Javier, and cleared the way for Samuel to relocate to the less adventurous vicinity of second base.

title: Bridge
description: A Swedish player, winner of the prestigious Cavendish Charity Invitational Pairs two years ago, made a strong bid Saturday to repeat the victory.

title: Tax Specter Shadows a G.O.P. Leader
description: If President Bush decides that forging a budget compromise with Congress means endorsing tax increases, one Republican he will be asking to help carry the political burden is Representative Jerry Lewis, the six-term Congressman whose district sprawls here on the eastern edge of the Los Angeles Basin.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;

Accounts
description: LEAD: * McCall's magazine to Holland Advertising.

title: 36 Years Later, an Integrated Georgia Prom
description: For 20 years, blacks and whites at the high school in this rural Georgia town sat side by side in classes and Key Club meetings, marched in the band together and wore the same black-and-gold uniforms on the football team.

title: Big Role Model, Barren Stage
description: GOLF may be sport's ultimate test of self-reliance, and perhaps no golfer has ever relied on himself as doggedly as Calvin Peete. A product of the streets of Detroit and the citrus groves of Florida who was one of 19 siblings, Peete never hit a golf ball until the age of 23. He has never had a formal lesson. He has a permanently deformed left arm that impairs his ability to generate club-head speed.

title: Princeton Women First
description: The Princeton women's varsity crew held off a sustained challenge by Cornell today to win the Governor's Cup in the final race of the 18th annual Eastern Association of Women's Rowing Colleges Sprint Championships.

title: Closing of Sepulcher Wasn't Israel's Doing
description: To the Editor:

title: North American Biologicals reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $49,000 and $12,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Reviews/Music;   A Recitalist's Nostalgic Bent
description: Both the pleasures and the problems of Pedro Firpo's piano playing were evident in the first work on his Saturday afternoon program at Weill Recital Hall. The piece was Scarlatti's compact, outgoing Sonata in E (K. 380), and Mr. Firpo gave it a bright, crisp harpsichordlike sound that kept its rhythms dancing. Yet there was a lurking skittishness that yielded smudged trills, wrong notes and other forms of imprecision. Later in the recital, a penchant for humming, loudly and out of tune, joined the list of deficits.

title: New Game Plan for Sports Daily
description: The creators of The National thought they had a formula that could not fail: a daily sports newspaper packed with local and national news.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Sarah Jane Nelson Weds Lee Breslow
description: Sarah Jane Nelson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norbert Nelson of New York and Bellport, L.I., and Lee David Breslow, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David Breslow of Wilmington, Del., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Rabbi Jonathan Gerard at the Upper Village Hall in East Derry, N.H.

title: The House of Commons As 'Best Show in Town'
description: Like the star of a cult film, Bernard Weatherill is better known by his role than by his real name. ''Mr. Speaker'' has been getting fan mail from all over the world since television went into the British House of Commons last November.

title: 7 Vie for S.I. Council Seat Under Strange Party Labels
description: When Staten Island voters go to the polls tomorrow to elect a new City Council member, they will not see the familiar Democratic and Republican Party lines on the voting machines.

title: Medex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
North American Ventures reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,400,000.

title: Will America Make World Safe for Global Warming?;   'Tote It Home'
description: To the Editor: We are all accustomed to having even the smallest purchase bagged, and this is adding tons to our mounting waste. Tote bags have become imaginative and popular, and we should take them shopping (except for obviously heavy burdens), as Europeans use their string bags.

title: Fama Jury Asks Judge to Explain a Charge
description: The jury considering the charges against Joseph Fama in the Bensonhurst murder case asked yesterday for a legal explanation of the most serious charge against the 19-year old defendant.

title: Reviews/Music;   On Banjo, Tunes of the Past
description: Cynthia Sayer has played banjo and sung with a variety of unusual groups, including Stanley's Washboard Kings in which her colleagues included virtuosos of the washboard and the blue blower (tissue paper and comb) and a brilliant group organized by Eddy Davis that revived the musical mayhem once perpetrated by Spike Jones and his City Slickers.

title: No Winnebago Payout
description: The struggling Winnebago Industries has chosen not to declare a semiannual cash dividend on its stock, the first time it has omitted a dividend in five years. The company's chairman, John K. Hanson, said the decision had been based on the current slump in the sales of motor homes, the company's main product. The move follows losses in the last two quarters and comes four weeks after Winnebago dismissed its president and chief executive, Richard Conner, who had held the post four months.

title: Seaport Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pentech International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Accel International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $76,000, or 1 cent a share. The company said the latest quarter's share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect the 5 percent common stock dividend payable on June 4 to shareholders of record on May 4.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Ladies Step Forward On Tee-Marker Rage
description: LEAD: THE debate over women's tee markers on golf courses has raged for almost a century, but a consensus is finally emerging that should benefit golfers of all ages, male and female.

title: Pro-Israel General Proposes To Trade Muslim Hostages
description: The commander of the Israeli-backed Southern Lebanon Army, Gen. Antoine Lahd, said today that he was ready to trade a ''large number'' of the 300 Muslims held by his militia for 16 Western hostages held by pro-Iranian Shiites.

title: Telephone Game Shows
description: Players International Inc., a marketer of gaming products, announced last week that it had signed a licensing agreement with a division of Merv Griffin Enterprises to produce ''Jeopardy!'' and ''Wheel of Fortune'' telephone games in the United States, Canada and Puerto Rico.

title: Pickens Charge Against Toyota
description: The Texas oilman and investor T. Boone Pickens has accused the Toyota Motor Corporation of blocking him from placing advertisements in Japanese newspapers in his bid to assert ownership rights in a Japanese company.

title: J.E. Davis Dies at 77; North Dakota Leader
description: John Edward Davis, former Federal director of Civil Defense, national commander of the American Legion and a two-term Governor of North Dakota, died Saturday at his winter home in Rancho Mirage, Calif. He was 77 years old.

title: CS Resources Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1989 results aren't comparable, since it went public and completed a corporate reorganization in September. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Microsemi Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $570,000, or 7 cents a share, due to the repurchase of debentures at less than face value.

title: Thousands in France Rally Against Anti-Semitism
description: Addressing thousands who came on a pilgrimage of protest and penitence to the Jewish cemetery where 34 graves were desecrated last week, the Chief Rabbi of France appealed to his compatriots today to stand against anti-Semitism before it spreads through the country.

title: Cabdriver Is Shot in Harlem
description: A livery-cab driver was shot in the face last night in Harlem by one of two men who attempted to rob him, the police said. The taxi driver, Gideon Umgsiaofegha, 23 years old, of 2334 Tiebout Avenue in the Fordham section of the Bronx, was listed in serious condition after surgery at Harlem Hospital, said Sgt. Mary Wrensen, a police spokeswoman. She said the shooting, which occurred at 8:30 P.M. at West 145th Street and Edgecombe Avenue, did not appear to be related to the recent series of cabdriver shootings and robberies in the Bronx. Sergeant Wrensen said the two suspects fled on foot.

title: Wendy Roth Wed To Peter Wright
description: Wendy Joan Roth, a daughter of Paul M. Roth of Malibu, Calif., and Marjorie L. Roth of Hallandale, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter Allen Wright, a son of Edmund Wright of White Plains and the late Marion R. Wright. Rabbi Paul R. Seigel officiated at the Tappan Hill Restaurant in Tarrytown.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;

Ingalls Gets Colombo
description: LEAD: Colombo Inc., the yogurt manufacturer, appointed Ingalls, Quinn & Johnson the agency for its $4 million account, which will also include advertising for some unspecified new products. The previous agency was Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor. Separately, Ingalls was also awarded a $1.5 million account for Showbox, a new storage and display system for photographs manufactured by the H-B Group.

title: Study Offers Remedies For Impoverished Delta
description: A new Federal study of the Mississippi Delta says the region, stricken by poverty, needs a broad range of remedies to help it catch up with the rest of the country.

title: Piedmont Mining reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $160,000, or 1 cent a share. c-Net loss

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Critic's Notebook;   Cannes, Where Clint Eastwood Takes a Chance
description: If the Cannes International Film Festival gave an award for valor, it would certainly go to Clint Eastwood this year. Mr. Eastwood has made a film about the wholly inimitable John Huston, has chosen to play this larger-than-life character himself, and has elected to show his ''White Hunter, Black Heart'' in competition, though films by Andrzej Wajda, Federico Fellini, Paul Schrader and others will not be taking that chance. He has even, in a film that deals with Huston's extracurricular activities as he prepared to direct ''The African Queen,'' cast Marisa Berenson in the role of Katharine Hepburn. That particular gamble happens to pay off. Ms. Berenson doesn't say much; she just looks game and confident, and that's enough.

title: Fisher Business Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Old Republic International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mantle's '61 Memories
description: HE is grayer now, and the legs, never much to speak of, aren't what they used to be. But after only a moment's hesitation (''Which one is me?'') Mickey Mantle stepped right up to the painting last week and proved himself a master switch-pointer, equally adept from either side of the easel as photographers directed him to pick out his image on a group portrait of the 1961 Yankee team.

title: Community National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed lower first quarter earnings primarily to a loan loss provision of approximately $1,300,000, compared with $200,000 for the first quarter 1989.

title: Business and the Law;   Revising the Code Of Legal Ethics
description: THE American Law Institute, the nation's most prominent legal organization, holds its annual meeting this week. Its agenda includes debate over a project intended to clarify the ethics of the profession.

title: Books of The Times;   Oh, How Malicious That Man Could Be!
description: Walter Winchell: A Novel

title: Washington REIT reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Outdoors: Curtain Goes Up on Bluefish
description: ''THIS is the start of a beautiful year,'' Don Mohr said a few days ago when he hauled a six-pound bluefish from the surf at Wasque Point. Wasque Point, which juts into the Atlantic from the southern end of Chappaquiddick on Martha's Vineyard Island, Mass., is traditionally the species' first port of call along the island's beaches each spring.

title: Chemical Weapons: 2 Percent Shy
description: President Bush proposes that the United States and the Soviet Union end production of chemical weapons and begin destroying their existing stocks. That raises hopes for a multinational treaty to rid the globe of chemical weapons. But those hopes may be premature because Mr. Bush insists the U.S. must hold onto 2 percent of its weapons even after it signs a treaty.

title: Review/Concert;   Chilly Traces in a Spring Celebration
description: Advertised as a spring serenade, the Sylvan Winds' concert at Weill Recital Hall on Thursday night brought along a little November bleakness as well. Most of this music was for double wind quintet: Florent Schmitt's Lied and Scherzo, an Andante by Sergei Taneyev, and an arrangement (without the usual trumpets in the finale) of Dvorak's ''Czech'' Suite.

title: Equitec Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,073,000.

title: Bell in a Small Town Stirs Sound and Fury
description: The ringing of the town bell from a white-steepled church on Main Street has been a venerated sound for nearly a century in this 320-year-old community of about 3,000 people.

title: 3 Killed in Madagascar in Attempted Coup
description: Rebels saying they wanted to end 15 years of dictatorship seized the Madagascar radio early today, but the Government quickly regained control after the coup attempt failed to obtain public support.

title: Elizabeth Solovay Becomes a Bride
description: The wedding of Elizabeth Cotton Solovay, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Solovay of New York and Westport, Conn., and David Jonathan Goldburg, the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Jay Goldburg of St. Louis, took place yesterday in Westport. The bridegroom's father and Rabbi Robert Orkand performed the ceremony at Temple Israel.

title: Row or Cycle, All in One
description: Multisports Inc. of Houston has designed the Re-Quest, a machine that combines two popular fitness workouts: rowing and bicycling.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;

Assessing Nissan's Zen Effort
description: LEAD: AFTER more than a year of invoking Zen-like precepts of luxury and showing little more than rocks, trees and misty fields in its advertising, the ''Nature'' campaign of Infiniti, the luxury-car division of Nissan, has concluded its run as planned.

title: Chronicle
description: The theater world will be rallying on two fronts tomorrow to support the National Endowment for the Arts in a battle with Congress over the renewal appropriations bill for the endowment, a major dispenser of grants to the arts. The artists oppose provisions that would require grant recipients to sign a pledge that the funds will not be used to produce obscene works of art.

title: Chronicle
description: WALLACE LOH was born in Chongquing, China, 45 years ago, went with his parents to Peru when he was 2 years old and came to the United States by himself when he was 15. During the political activism of the 1960's, Mr. Loh said, he was determined to become a lawyer. But unable to gain acceptance into law school, he chose psychology and received a Ph.D. from the University of Michigan in 1970. The law still beckoned, and in 1974, he received a law degree from Yale.

title: Question Box
description: Talented First Basemen

title: Alcala Winner In Tour
description: Greg LeMond came alive today, Michael Zanoli won the day's battle and Vladislav Bobrik faded into the dust. Through it all, Raul Alcala of Mexico, as expected, won the 11-day, 1,107-mile Tour de Trump, America's premier bicycle race.

title: Paragon Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said oil and gas sales amounted to $1,043,194 in the latest quarter compared with $729,669 a year ago. It said cash flow is estimated to be $3 million, or 82 cents a shre, this year compared to the $1,927,274, or 53 cents a share, last year. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: West Offers New Way to East
description: Western Europe's Christian Democratic parties are trying to woo East bloc countries toward a form of capitalism that emphasizes Christian social values. Page A11.

title: Mandela Says South Africa Persecuted His Wife
description: Nelson Mandela, the South African black nationalist leader, today defended his wife, Winnie, saying she had been the victim of the ''most scandalous persecution'' by the Government.

title: Lebanese Christian Fighting Goes On in Beirut; 3 Killed
description: Rival Lebanese Christians fought with artillery and rocket fire today, killing 3 people and wounding at least 16, security informants said.

title: Kidney Failure Is Suspected In the Death of an Elephant
description: Kidney failure was suspected in the death of an elephant whose calf was stillborn in a Caesarean section last month, Burnet Park Zoo officials said today.

title: Oilers Aren't Sore Underdogs
description: For the sixth time in eight seasons, the Edmonton Oilers are in the Stanley Cup finals, opening the four-of-seven-game series Tuesday night at Boston against the Bruins.

title: Correction
description: Two photographs were transposed yesterday in the Headliners column in The Week in Review. A picture of Frank Herbert Reed, the recently released hostage, was at the top of the column. Senator Dave Durenberger of Minnesota was pictured at the bottom.

title: Jeremy Rifkin Weds Carol Grunewald
description: Carol Grunewald, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Grunewald, of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday in Chevy Chase, Md., to Jeremy Rifkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Rifkin of Chicago. Rabbi Martin Siegel and the Rev. Mr. John Lynn, a Roman Catholic deacon, officiated at Woodend, the Audubon Naturalist Society and Wildlife Refuge.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Romanian Protesters Assert Revolution Has Been Stolen
description: With the first elections after four decades of Communist domination approaching, people here in the cradle of Romania's revolution, like many other Romanians elsewhere, are expressing not hope, but anger somewhat reminiscent of the outrage that swept President Nicolae Ceausescu from power last December.

title: Dominion Bankshares Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said that had its first quarter 1990 loan loss provision remained at the $13 million level, as it recorded in fourth quarter 1989, it would have had net income of about $23.4 million, or 61 cents a share.

title: Who Elected Sununu?
description: John Sununu may be expanding the previous limits of an office that is neither elective nor subject to Congressional confirmation. He seems clearly to be the most openly powerful White House chief of staff of the several who in recent years have been closely at a President's side.

title: Reviews/Music;   Clamma Dale, a Soprano
description: Since Clamma Dale first offered the singing stage a bright prospect more than a decade ago, the American soprano has remained before the public but without ever really recapturing its attention. Her recital on Friday night at Alice Tully Hall raised some troubling questions about her progress.

title: Navratilova Upset In a 50-Minute Final
description: When the one-sided 50-minute match was over, Martina Navratilova said she felt as if she had been run over by a truck.

title: Qualified and Obligated to Speak Out on Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: Israel Charging Officer In Antigua Camp Case
description: A senior Defense Ministry official said today that a police complaint would be filed charging a reserve colonel with holding unauthorized talks on the establishment of a military training camp in Antigua, the Caribbean island.

title: The Joffrey's Dancers Get Their Paychecks
description: The Joffrey Ballet, in financial and aministrative turmoil since the resignation on May 1 of Gerald Arpino, its artistic director and resident choreographer, distributed dancers' salaries on Saturday afternoon at the Music Center of Los Angeles County, where the company performs through May 27.

title: Rocky Mountain Chocolate reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Primary share earnings for year- ago period include accretion of preferred stock dividends; fully diluted earnings for the previous fiscal year were anti-dilutive.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Albanian Leader Says the Country Will Be Democratized but Will Retain Socialism
description: In his first encounter with foreign journalists, President Ramiz Alia said on Saturday that his policy of democratizing this isolated Communist country could not be stopped.

title: N.A.S.D. Fines Stuart-James
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers has fined the Stuart-James Company more than $2 million for overcharging companies. It is one of the largest fines ever levied against a brokerage firm by the N.A.S.D., which polices over-the-counter stock trading.

title: Death in Teaneck; The Gun Question - A Special Report:   Police Version Still Contested A Month After Youth's Killing
description: A month after a black youth, Phillip C. Pannell, was shot to death by a white police officer, significant differences remain between the police account of the shooting and accounts given by other witnesses.

description: GOLF

title: Wallach Knocks In 8 Runs for Expos
description: Tim Wallach drove in eight runs, including six on two three-run homers, and Oil Can Boyd pitched his first shutout in five years as Montreal routed San Diego, 15-0, today.

description: b-Net income

title: Bankruptcy Lawyers Move to Bigger Firm
description: Joel B. Zweibel, one of the nation's top bankruptcy lawyers, and several associates are leaving the mid-sized New York law firm of Kramer, Levin, Nessen, Kamin & Frankel for the larger New York offices of O'Melveny & Myers.

description: To the Editor:

title: Morrison Petroleums reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Abortion Molds Pennsylvania
description: Abortion is such a galvanizing issue in the Pennsylvania primary that it is affecting the campaign of nearly every candidate in Tuesday's elections.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

At South Bronx High, 'Fitness Fever'
description: LEAD: WHEN Lou Schlanger was appointed to teach physical education at South Bronx High School in 1984, he was determined to give the job his all. He'd been waiting two years for such a job in the public schools. (Thanks to a shortage of openings, physical education is the toughest appointment in the system).

title: American Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gain on sale of properties of $1,669,000 in 1989 and $251,000 in 1988. The company attributed the fourth quarter losses to investments in related entities in which it must record its share of losses. These losses amounted to 59 cents a share in the fourth quarter.

title: Ford to Idle Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company said it would idle its Chicago assembly plant this week because of a shortage of orders from dealers. The factory, which produces about 5,000 Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable models weekly, employs about 2,500 hourly workers on two shifts.

title: Executives See a Chance Of Deficit Cut
description: Despite repeated disappointments, many of the nation's top corporate executives say they think there is at least an even-money chance for a breakthrough in budget negotiations that begin on Tuesday in Washington, with a sizable number supporting such an agreement even if it includes an increase in personal income taxes.

title: Southwest Gas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that the gas segment's contribution to consolidated net income was $20,006,000 during the current quarter, down slightly from the $20,663,000 recorded in the first quarter of 1989.

title: Panel Calls for More Spending on Advanced TV <
description: At a time when the Defense Department appears intent on cutting back support for research on high-definition television technology, a Pentagon advisory panel is urging that support for such research be increased tenfold to at least $100 million a year for the next five years.

title: Will America Make World Safe for Global Warming?;   Let's Generate Less
description: To the Editor:

title: Hold Present Line on Strategic Oil Reserve
description: To the Editor:

title: Pistons' Defense Braces
description: Whether it was John Salley blocking shots, Dennis Rodman with a hand in someone's face or Isiah Thomas harassing one of the Knicks' guards, the Detroit Pistons' defense never rested yesterday afternoon.

title: Clark Oil's Chief Named Texaco Chemical Officer
description: Texaco Inc. has named a president for the Texaco Chemical Company, one of its largest subsidiaries.

title: 2 U.S. Airmen Slain in the Philippines
description: Two American servicemen were killed today near an air base on the eve of talks between the United States and the Philippines on extending the lease on United States military bases.

title: Evolution in Europe;   GERMANYS TAKE UP APPROVAL OF PACT ON ECONOMIC UNION
description: East and West German economic experts set the stage over the weekend for their political leaders to negotiate a treaty that would merge the two countries' monetary, economic and social policies by midsummer.

title: Cae Industries reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The company attributed the earnings decline to restatement of income tax provisions. The company said fiscal 1989 final net income of $42,755,000 included a charge of $399,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;

People
description: LEAD: * Mary Dexter has been promoted to senior vice president and director of integrated operations and systems at FCB/Leber Katz Partners.

title: Main Builder In Stamford Is Faltering
description: This is the town that the F. D. Rich Company built. It was F. D. Rich that bulldozed virtually all of Stamford's decrepit downtown 25 years ago. And it was F. D. Rich that erected many of the high-rise office buildings that came to symbolize Stamford's rebirth as a corporate capital.

title: Suns Halt Laker Rally to Win
description: Kevin Johnson scored 11 of his 30 points in the final 10 minutes 14 seconds and the Phoenix Suns survived a late Los Angeles rally to beat the Lakers, 114-101, today, for a 3-1 lead in their National Basketball Association playoff series.

title: Film Deal By Columbia And Producer
description: Columbia Pictures Entertainment said yesterday that it had signed a production, financing and distribution agreement for movies and television programs made by James L. Brooks, whose films include ''Broadcast News,'' ''Starting Over'' and ''Terms of Endearment.''

title: Consumers' Gas reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the results of these two periods aren't directly comparable as revenues were billed under different rate designs. In addition, the 1990 earnings figures reflect revenues billed primarily under interim rates, which if amended, ''could have a material effect on the earnings figures reported thus far.'' Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. May Give Up One of Its Bases In the Philippines, Officials Say
description: American and Philippine officials say the United States may have to relinquish at least one of its two huge military bases in the Philippines over the next 10 years because of rising opposition to the installations in the former American colony.

title: Low-Power TV Gains Strength
description: Though it rarely registers more than an asterisk in the Nielsen and Arbitron ratings, low-power television has finally begun to live up to the enthusiasm that greeted its inception a decade ago.

title: NDE Environmental reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures for 1990 includes operations of Pan Am Environmental Systems Inc., from date of acquisition, March 7, 1990.

title: Bulls Lead 76ers in Series, 3-1
description: The Chicago Bulls broke Philadephia on the 76ers' own court today, winning, 111-101, to take a 3-1 lead in the four-of-seven-game playoff series.

title: Sununu's Role in Debates on Environmental Issues Reflects Old Patterns
description: Name an environmental issue in Washington these days, and the chances are that John M. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, is in the thick of it, setting President Bush's policy.

title: Subway Overkill
description: In refusing to recognize a constitutional ''right to beg'' in New York subways, the U.S. Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reached the right result in the wrong way. The court recognized interests of riders but intemperately denied any validity in the beggars' free-speech claims.

title: Biotech Research LaboratoFries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Pope Is Awed By the cheers Of Mexicans
description: After 47 of them, papal voyages outside Italy would seem to hold few surprises. Yet no one who travels with Pope John Paul II fails to be amazed by his sense of mission, not to mention his stamina as he approaches his 70th birthday next Friday.

title: General Magnaplate reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Annette Perlman Marries in Brooklyn
description: Annette Perlman and Yehuda Fishman were married yesterday at the Kingsway Jewish Center in Brooklyn. Rabbi Emanuel Gettinger and Cantor Akiva Besser officiated.

title: Tecogen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $9,000 and $24,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: With New Attitude, Brewers Discover Zeal for Winning
description: When the Milwaukee Brewers took a hard look at their 1989 season, they were none too pleased with the harsh portrait they came to recognize as themselves.

title: Teaneck Shirt Slogan Sides With the Police
description: A Teaneck, N.J., police officer has begun selling T-shirts siding with the officer who shot a black teen-ager there last month, the president of the Teaneck Policemen's Benevolent Association said yesterday.

title: Dr. Ann Kelley Becomes a Bride
description: Dr. Ann Elizabeth Kelley, an associate professor of psychology at Harvard University, was married yesterday to Dr. Leonard Abraham Levin, an ophthalmology resident at the Massachusetts Eye and Ear Infirmary in Boston. Rabbi Albert Ginsburgh officiated at the Habitat Institute for the Environment in Belmont, Mass.

title: Shellfish Is Tiny, but Problems It Could Cause Are Huge
description: The zebra mussel, an aquatic invader from Europe, is rapidly advancing into New York State, threatening to become a major pest in the Hudson, Delaware and Susquehanna Rivers, marine biologists say.

title: Orioles Gain Sweep Of A's
description: Jay Tibbs and four relievers combined on a five-hitter as the Baltimore Orioles beat Oakland, 4-1, today and swept their first series against the Athletics since May 1987.

title: Karyn L. Rotker Weds In Roslyn Harbor, L.I.
description: Karyn Lori Rotker, the daughter of Acting Justice Seymour Rotker of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Elena Rotker, was married yesterday to Leon Paul Lynn, a son of Simon Lynn of Lawrence, L.I., and the late Jeanne Lynn. Rabbi Joseph Weiss performed the ceremony at the Swan Club in Roslyn Harbor, L.I.

title: Scor U.S.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Net income for both periods include fresh start tax benefits of less than 1 cent per share.

title: Mutual Federal Savings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gains of $204,000 in the latest quarter and $148,000 in prior quarter, for tax loss carryforwards. c-Net income

title: Yankees' Big Effort Spoiled by Pitchers
description: They have heard the rumors since the first days of April, when the season was just beginning and the Yankees were moving forward. But now, more than one month and 17 losses later, it is likely that the rumors will become real.

title: York Research reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations amounting to 1 cent a share in the second quarter and 2 cents a share in the 6-month period.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;   Too Many Books Are Coming Back Unsold
description: ''GONE today, here tomorrow.'' That was how Alfred A. Knopf summed up a publisher's difficulty in selling books. Six years after the great publisher's death, the problem is growing.

title: Tunisian Leader Begins Visit to Washington
description: The President of Tunisia will begin a three-day visit to Washington on Monday with two pivotal issues on his agenda: the immigration of Soviet Jews to Israel, and the Western outcry about Iraq's manufacture and deployment of long-range missiles, chemical weapons and other advanced military technology.

title: Naval Injustice
description: Judgments rain down on the Navy's shabby investigation of the U.S.S. Iowa explosion that killed 47 sailors last year. First Kendall Truitt, a gunner's mate 3d class, who was libeled by leaks from Navy investigators, had the temerity to tell Congress that blaming his buddy Clayton Hartwig for the tragedy was ''a big cover-up.'' Then a House Armed Services subcommittee weighed in with a detailed denunciation of the Navy's probe.

title: Service Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $147,000, or 5 cents a share, and $84,000, or 3 cents a share, for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. The year-ago quarter also included income from discontinued operations of $1,711,000, or 61 cents a share, and a loss of $118,000 from accretion and divs. on 5-percent pref. stock.

title: Making a Song More Than Just A Pretty Melody
description: ''Let's suppose,'' E. Y. (Yip) Harburg once said, ''that God had had only the tune for 'Let there be light' and stood on the brink of eternity and sang, 'Da-da-da-da!'

title: 39-State Male Prostitution Ring Is Reported
description: Investigators say they have uncovered a 39-state male prostitution ring run by a Navy computer expert. They say it advertised through an electronic network and in magazines for homosexuals.

title: A Bookstore With Many Tongues
description: The two dozen bookstores that adorn Harvard Square specialize in everything from religion to revolution, science to science fiction. But only one store here stocks a Russian-language edition of the Constitution of the United States, a shelf of Esperanto titles imported from the Netherlands and the Latin version of ''Winnie the Pooh,'' translated by a Hungarian medical doctor who lived in Brazil.

title: International Aluminum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $565,000.

title: Bush's 2 Top Budget Aides Avoid Discussion of Taxes
description: With budget negotiations with Congress set to begin Tuesday, two of the Bush Administration's top economic policy makers carefully avoided any statements today that might rile Congress or disclose President Bush's position on raising taxes.

title: Florio Shifts Policy From School Testing To More Aid to Poor
description: Gov. Jim Florio this spring is reversing many of the nationally praised education policies of his predecessor, Thomas H. Kean, moving away from reforms that were part of the ''back to basics'' movement of the 1980's and redirecting New Jersey's resources toward overcoming the effects of poverty on children.

title: Atlas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $808,000, or 14 cents a share for the quarter and $1,539,000, or 26 cents for the 9 months, and the 9 months also included income from discontinued operations of $30,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $69,000, or 1 cent a share and $546,000, or 9 cents a share for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and an extraordinary tax credit of $262,000, or 5 cents a share for both the quarter and 9 months. Year-ago results restated for discontinued operations.

title: A Jet Set in Motion
description: IT has been years since he competed on his high school track team and much of his recent running has been done going backward or side-to-side covering receivers for the Jets. But now Erik McMillan, the acclaimed third-year safety, is getting a chance to test his forward motion.

title: CF Income Partners L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
description: Treasury financings this week are confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: East German Fuel Sales
description: East Germany's state-owned Minol oil company almost tripled gasoline sales in the first four months of 1990, reflecting a rise in car ownership in East Germany. The head of Minol's retail division, Leonhard Kneler, told the state news agency last week that at least 100 new gasoline stations a year would be needed to meet demand from East German drivers and the greatly increased number of West German cars visiting the East. Many East Germans have bought second-hand West German cars since travel restrictions were relaxed.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;

Esquire's New Approach Adopts Art as Theme
description: LEAD: Esquire magazine is trying a new way to demonstrate the sophistication of its audience. A year ago, a trade advertising campaign by Kirshenbaum & Bond featured hairy-chested men laden with gold chains to illustrate the slogan, ''Some men will never be ready for Esquire.'' The magazine has a new advertising agency - Welch & Nehlen in Garden City, L.

title: Mylex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Radio Ship Docks in Taiwan Before Broadcasts to China
description: Taiwanese set off firecrackers today to welcome the radio ship, the Goddess of Democracy, to northern Keelung, where she will refuel before heading for the high seas to broadcast pro-democracy messages to China.

title: Chronicle
description: Forbes is going Chinese, says MALCOLM S. FORBES JR. Starting in November, the American business magazine will be published in Chinese in Hong Kong in what Mr. Forbes said would be ''the first worldwide Chinese-language business magazine.'' The Chinese Forbes, to be published in conjunction with the Capital Communication Corporation Ltd. of Hong Kong, is the first major publishing project undertaken by Mr. Forbes since succeeding his late father as president and chief executive of Forbes Inc.

title: Rates Expected to Drop Further
description: Many participants in the credit markets say they expect a further decline in interest rates this week, as more investors in fixed-income securities become convinced that the Bush Administration and Congress are moving to confront the nation's budget deficit.

Teleconcepts Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: b-Included a gain of $2,900,000 related to certain commitment fees and interest received and a related settlement paid by the company. Figures for 1989 are pro forma; the company was formed in October 1989.

title: Racers to Celebrate Recovery in Bay Area
description: LEAD: The Bay to Breakers, the world's largest foot race with about 100,000 entrants, held each spring in San Francisco, has new significance this year.

description: b-Net loss

title: Jack Woliston, Journalist, 74
description: Jack Woliston, a reporter and editor for United Press International for 39 years, died on Saturday at his home in Palm Harbor, Fla. He was 74 years old and had suffered from lung cancer.

title: Minnova Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said earnings are higher due to the opening of two new mines which began production July 1, 1989. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Pacer Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reviews/Music;   On Dancing vs. Watching
description: The show at the Palladium on Thursday night underscored the sort of cultural ricocheting that can take place in the Caribbean. Azuquita, a Panamanian singer who has lived in New York and Paris, played a set of salsa, a Cuban and Puerto Rican music; Azuquita learned the music by listening to shows beamed on the radio from Cuba. Chantelle, a group from Puerto Rico, played merengue, a music usually from the Dominican Republic.

title: Coach Is Arrested
description: Gary Williams, basketball coach at the University of Maryland, was arrested and charged with drunken driving early Saturday. Edwin Lashley, a spokesman for the Maryland state police, said Williams was stopped at about 1:50 A.M. after a Maryland state trooper said he noticed the coach's car weaving at a speed of about 65 miles an hour, 10 over the speed limit, on the Capital Beltway.

title: Economic Watch;   Debate on Puerto Rico's Future Has a Bottom Line
description: If President Bush and Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon have their way, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico will get the chance next year to vote on joining the Union or casting it off forever.

title: Southland Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $52,040,000, or 26 cents a share, related to the company's sale of its 50-percent interest in Citgo Petroleum Corp., which was completed Jan. 31. c-Included a charge from debt exchange of $56,047,000 and also included income from discontinued operations of $17,336,000, or 8 cents a share. The company said it reduced its senior bank term loan to $900.4 million from about $2.5 billion since it went private in late 1987. It has repaid $399.5 million of that loan this year, and is obligated to repay $12.9 million on June 30, $18.8 million on Sept. 30 and $18.8 million on Dec. 31.

title: Parisians Join in Protest Against Hate
description: Tens of thousands of people, including President Francois Mitterrand, numerous other politicians and many leading religious figures, joined in a silent march tonight through the streets of Paris to protest anti-Semitism and the desecration of 34 graves last week at a cemetery in southern France.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bell Helicopter Textron Inc., Fort Worth, a maker of helicopters, said it would lay off about 115 employees, or less than 2 percent of its work force of 7,000.

title: Salinas Journal;   Mixing Two Cultures In a Diamond Test Tube
description: In the dugout of a minor league baseball park here, the manager, Heidi Koga, and his hybrid team are discovering that ''Attaboy! Attaboy!'' means the same in Japanese and in English.

title: Rothman's Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Abortion Issue Taking Odd Turn in California
description: All of the gubernatorial candidates here have campaigned on the promise that they will guard the right of women to choose abortions. But on Sunday night Dianne Feinstein, the only woman in the race, said she opposed abortions for purposes of sex selection and would consider outlawing them.

title: Roberto Ornelas; Federal Official, 58
description: Roberto Ornelas, a former national president of the League of United Latin American Citizens, died of cancer on Friday in a Dallas hospital. He was 58 years old.

title: When Rules and Order Marked City Schools
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place;   Behind the Rally In Bank Stocks
description: BANKING company stocks, after being shunned by Wall Street for the last seven months, increased sharply during the stock market rally of the last two sessions, and may be treated more graciously in coming months.

title: Q&A
description: Insect Migration

title: Hal F. Davis, 73, Ad Executive And Head of a Jazz Organization
description: Hal F. Davis, a retired advertising executive and an expert on jazz, died on Sunday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 73 years old. Mr. Davis retired in 1978 as president of Grey & Davis Inc., an advertising agency in Manhattan. Before that he was vice president for radio and television at Grey Advertising and was later assistant to the president and assistant to the chairman there. He was named president of Grey Advertising's subsidiary, Grey Public Relations, in 1969 and a year later formed his own affiliated advertising agency, Grey & Davis Inc.

title: Manila Bases Talks Open Amid Protests
description: Talks on the future of United States military bases began here today as the police clashed with hundreds of anti-American demonstrators.

title: Plan to Save U.S. Agencies
description: The Bush Administration outlined a plan today aimed at avoiding another savings-and-loan-style crisis involving the Government-sponsored agencies that finance housing, farming and education.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Frank Gehry Project to Build A Vision From the U.S. in Paris
description: The American Center in Paris, which since 1934 has operated cultural and social programs from an old building on the Left Bank, plans to announce today in Manhattan that in 1992 it will move to a building on the outskirts of Paris to be designed by Frank Gehry, one of America's most celebrated architects.

title: Dow Hits New Peak, At 2,821.53
description: The Dow Jones industrial average scaled a new high yesterday in a move that brokers said was driven by high hopes that the President and Congress can soon come to grips with the deficit, as well as Wall Street euphoria over Friday's spectacular 63.07-point rise in the key market indicator and a big decline in interest rates.

title: Jordan Halts March to West Bank
description: Jordanian police officers and troops backed by tanks threw tear gas and fired into the air today to disperse thousands of demonstrators who tried to enter the Israeli-occupied West Bank during a pro-Palestinian march.

title: Pamour Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company said its share of losses of subsidiary and associated companies was $637,000 in the latest quarter compared with $1,334,000 a year ago. It said that, as the investment in subsidiary ERG Resources Inc. has been written off, its losses are not reflected in Pamour's 1990 results.

title: The Pistons' Ninth Man: Obsession
description: Maybe it's because the Detroit Pistons want to show that they didn't win the National Basketball Association championship last year just because Magic Johnson and Byron Scott of the Los Angeles Lakers were hobbling on ailing hamstring muscles. Maybe it's because the Pistons want to show that they can do it without Rick Mahorn, who was lost in the expansion draft while he and his teammates were enjoying their civic celebration. Maybe it's simply because the Pistons want to show that they are a basketball team in the purest sense.

title: Patterns
description: The Long and Short of It The city never sleeps, and fashion never rests. Just when you became comfortable with short skirts, guess what?

title: As Hard Times Hit Industry, Woman's Day Is Being Sold
description: Diamandis Communications Inc. said yesterday that it was putting Woman's Day, its flagship publication, up for sale.

title: McGrath Rentcorp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   2d Account Back at Waring
description: ''Who says you can't go home again?'' a pleased Saul Waring, president of Waring & LaRosa, asked yesterday.

title: Motorola Chip
description: Motorola Inc. introduced a specialized processing chip that the company said was optimized for a new class of multimedia computing applications that combine graphics and sound. The 96002 is a floating-point mathematical co-processor that approaches supercomputer speeds on certain operations and will permit the development of desktop work stations that have full-motion video and stereo digital sound capabilities. The company refers to the chip as a ''media engine'' and said that in addition to video and sound applications the chip could be used in color printing and facsimile applications as well as telecommunications uses.

title: Death By Delay?
description: A man who is in prison for a serious crime is found to have a recurrence of cancer. It is a cancer that can be treated if action is taken promptly; otherwise it is almost invariably fatal. The prison authorities delay, for weeks, his getting the necessary treatment.

title: GAF Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are on a pro forma basis. Results for the first quarter 1989 were prepared as if the transfer of the GAF surfactants business are excluded for each period. The company completed its first year as a private company since a management buyout in March 1989.

title: 4 Die in Navy Copter Crash
description: A Navy helicopter crashed into the Atlantic Ocean off this resort a few miles south of Jacksonville today and all four people aboard were killed, the Navy said. Divers found the bodies in the fuselage of the SH-2 Sea Sprite helicopter, said a spokesman at the Jacksonville Naval Air Station. It was on its way from the Atlantic Underwater Test and Evaluation Center in the Bahamas to its home base at Willow Grove, Pa.

title: Mandela to Come to U.S. in June, Meeting Bush and Visiting 5 Cities
description: Nelson Mandela, the leader of South Africa's black majority, will visit the United States next month for talks with President Bush, organizers of his trip said today. New York City officials said they were hoping to honor Mr. Mandela with a ticker-tape parade.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Saving the Planet From Us Isn't Always Easy
description: BALANCE OF THE PLANET is a rich and complex computer simulation that challenges you to try to save the earth and its living things, not from Martians or mutant turtles, but from us.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Soviet Circus, Deeply in Debt, Is Stuck in U.S.
description: A troupe of the Soviet Union's leading acrobats, clowns, jugglers and animal trainers entered the United States six weeks ago with visions of sellout crowds and warm applause, only to end up in a frustrating odyssey that has left them stranded in a Marietta motel.

title: Dinkins Presses For Stiffer Law In Gang Attacks
description: Keeping his focus on racial tensions, Mayor David N. Dinkins joined two legislators yesterday to press for a new state law to stiffen the penalties for assaults committed by groups of three or more. The Mayor's aides meanwhile kept trying without success to resolve a black boycott of two Korean-American grocery stores.

title: William Bufalino Sr., 72, Lawyer For Hoffa and Teamsters' Union
description: William E. Bufalino Sr., a lawyer and associate of the former teamster leader James R. Hoffa, died of leukemia on Saturday at Holy Cross Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 72 years old.

title: Riley Is Finding Pleasure In Team's Underdog Role
description: The Phoenix Suns are a victory away from eliminating the traditionally dominant Los Angeles Lakers from the National Basketball Association playoffs.

description: b-Included an equity loss of $203,178 from a 50-percent owned venture.

description: Revenue figures were not immediately available. The company said Laurentian Bank's contribution to its first-quarter earnings was $4.6 million, or 82 percent more than first-quarter 1989. Figures are in Canadian funds.

description: b-Net loss

title: Once More Admired Than Bought, A Writer Finally Basks in Success
description: For many years, John Banville, the Irish author of eight novels and the literary editor of The Irish Times, dwelled in that ambiguous zone where critical success mingles unsatisfactorily with indifferent commercial performance. Known for four highly original historical novels, centering on figures like Copernicus and Kepler, he had won a good deal of respect from literary colleagues and critics but not much money or fame.

description: b-Net loss

Methane and Climate
description: French and Soviet scientists studying the Vostok ice core in East Antarctica have fine-tuned the link between methane levels and climate shifts over the past 160,000 years. They argue that fluctuations in carbon dioxide and methane concentrations were probably responsible for 50 percent of the cases of dramatic warming and cooling of the earth during the last two ice ages.

title: Unitog Co. reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: The company said that in the 1989 first quarter, it prepaid a major portion of subordinated debt, incurring prepayment charges, without which net earnings would have been $556,000, or 14 cents a share. The company also announced the acquisition of Eagle Uniform and Linen Service Inc., its first uniform rental plant in Indiana, which willtake effect in the second quarter.

title: Easy Goer to Race Tomorrow
description: Easy Goer, who won a record six Grade I stakes races in New York last year, but lost three of four duels with Sunday Silence, will make his first start as a 4-year-old in the Gold Stage Stakes tomorrow at Belmont Park.

title: TLC Beatrice International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included an extraordinary credit of $672,000, or 7 cents a share, and also included income from discontinued operations of $760,000, or 8 cents a share. Latest quarter loss per share is after preferred dividend payments of $2,329,000, compared with $1,925,000 in the year-ago period.

title: Sponsor for Big Apple
description: William A. Blue, commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association, announced yesterday that Japan Airlines would assume title sponsorship for the Big Apple Classic, a new event presented by Golf magazine on Aug. 16-19 at the Wykagyl Country Club in New Rochelle, N.Y.

title: GORBACHEV BARS INDEPENDENCE BIDS OF 2 BALTIC LANDS
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today officially rejected moves toward independence taken by Latvia and Estonia, saying the two Baltic republics lacked any legal basis for their attempts to leave the Soviet Union.

title: Apple Says Xerox Claim Is Dismissed
description: Apple Computer Inc. said the Xerox Corporation's one remaining claim in a copyright suit filed in December had been dismissed. In March, a Federal judge dismissed five of six claims in the suit, which contended that the screen display of Apple's Macintosh had unlawfully used copyrighted technology developed by Xerox for its Star computer. The Xerox product was introduced in 1981, three years before Macintosh.

title: WORLD POPULATION WILL TOP 6 BILLION
description: Efforts are faltering to limit population growth in developing countries, and the 1990's will see the greatest increase in human numbers of any decade, the United Nations Fund for Population Activities says in its latest annual survey on the world's population.

title: Chess
description: The Dortmund International ''A'' Tournament in West Germany, which ended April 16, featured a fight for first place right down to the wire between two Soviet grandmasters, Alexandr Chernin and Boris Gelfand. The 30-year-old Chernin had started with four straight victories and was entitled to think that the tourney triumph would be an easy one for him. But 21-year-old Gelfand, regarded as the Soviet Union's coming man, put on a spurt that brought him to a half point off the lead. But then Chernin matched Gelfand's last two victories with two of his own to fend him off and seize first prize.

title: 3 Win $4,000 Lincoln Center Awards
description: Joan Barnhill, an actress and cabaret singer; Daire Fitzgerald, a cellist, and Scott St. John, a violinist, were named winners of Martin E. Segal Awards yesterday.

Southeastern Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: b-Included a pretax gain of $48,118,000 on sale of a partnership interest. c-Net loss and included a pretax charge of $33,000 related to a writeoff of deferred cellular license costs.

title: Allen H. Morgan, 64, Environmentalist, Dies
description: Allen H. Morgan, an environmentalist, died of cancer on Sunday at the Lahey Clinic in Burlington, Mass. He was 64 years old and lived in Wayland, Mass.

title: Haiti Turmoil Seen as Threat to Vote
description: Hopes for democratic change and stability that rose when Ertha Pascal-Trouillot was named President of a provisional Government two months ago have faded. A breakdown of authority and a growing sense of international isolation have left Haitians deeply apprehensive about the future.

title: Charter Medical Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said during the quarter it discovered and corrected inaccurate recording of previously reported contractual allowances, bad debts and expense accruals. As a result of the corrections and revised estimates of the net realizable value of accounts receivable, the company reduced operating income by about $35 million. In addition, Charter Medical abandoned certain development projects and lost a lawsuit, resulting in an unusual charge to operating income of $11.2 million. Operating income for the quarter ended March 31, before the adjustment was $52.9 million. This is less than anticipated primarily because of reduced patient days in established hospitals, increased contractual allowances and bad debts, and increased operating costs , including marketing expenses.

When Patricia Espinoza was caught chewing gum on Friday, she wore it on her nose.

S.p.A. formed a joint venture with the Yugoslav Energoprojekt Holding Corporation, an engineering and data processing company, to sell Olivetti systems and products in Yugoslavia. Olivetti said its Olivetti System and Networks subsidiary would hold 50 percent of the new venture, to be called Olivetti Energodata, while Energoprojekt would hold a 46 percent stake. The remaining 4 percent would be held by Dinara, Olivetti's trading arm in Yugoslavia.

title: Chronicle

The justice said he objected to ''portrayal of minority citizens in rioting and threatening behavior.'' That decision angered NICHOLAS R. AMATO, the Essex County Executive, who said it meant losing the $250,000 that Warner Brothers agreed to pay for five days of filming on location. The movie stars TOM HANKS.

Delta said it would also offer a special $199 one-way fare for travel between Los Angeles and New York, with double frequent-flier bonus miles from June 1 to July 31. Tickets must be purchased by May 31 for the Los Angeles-New York flights and by June 15 for the Los Angeles-San Francisco flights. All special fare travel must be completed by June 30, it said.

title: Calvin Black; Development Advocate, 61

He was 61 years old. Mr. Black, former chairman of the League for the Advancement of States Equal Rights, was a Commissioner of San Juan County, Utah, since 1967, except for two years when he was a member of the Utah Legislature. He was a Republican.

title: In Even This Elegant Garden

The plans of autumn and the hopes of winter are coming into bloom, and dreams have to be stacked up now against reality. Did the artfully planted white tulips look at all like a drift of snow, as the garden catalogue promised? Does the pattern of varicolored tulips remind anyone of a Persian carpet? Will the rose on the bush be anywhere near as lovely as the one in the imagining?
