The executive, David B. Payne, who is 54 years old, was named to the top financial post last year. ''I'm going home,''

title: Southland Loss Is Cut
description: The Southland Corporation, the parent of the 7-Eleven chain of convenience stores, said today that tax benefits from past red ink helped reduce its first-quarter loss by nearly 60 percent.

title: Scholars Say First Atelier Was in a Cave
description: MORE than bones or hand-wrought stone tools, paintings on cave walls awaken the recognition of kinship between modern humans and their prehistoric ancestors, and new discoveries in France seem to resurrect these artists at work, sketching their visions in charcoal, mixing the paints and creating distinctive palettes.

title: Let Private Lawyers Prosecute S & L Fraud
description: To the Editor:

title: Montana Naturals InternaFtional reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Community Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Eased Bank Rules Urged
description: Closing the United States to competition from foreign banks would be ineffective and prompt retaliation against American banks, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told a Congressional panel today.

title: U.S.-Albanian Talks
description: American and Albanian officials met recently to discuss establishing normal relations, the first official contact between the two countries in more than 50 years, a State Department official said today.

title: International Telecharge reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
KEY RATES
Varian Begins A Revamping
description: Varian Associates Inc., which manufactures electron devices and analytical instruments, said today that it would sell some non-core operations and product lines to improve performance.

title: Circadian Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $2,500,000 charge related to writedown of certain assets.

title: 5 Wounded in London By Bomb at Army Site
description: A bomb exploded outside a British Army building in southeast London today, wounding five people.

title: Corrections
description: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday misstated the performance of United Technologies stock from Jan. 2 through May 11.

title: Dumars Is at His Best As Pistons Seek Title
description: Whenever Joe Dumars 3d takes the floor with the Detroit Pistons, his father, Joe Dumars 2d, watches the game intently on television from his home in Louisiana.

title: Vari-Care Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Stewart Takes First Loss On Twins' 15-Hit Attack
description: Allan Anderson pitched a four-hitter and Kirby Puckett had 5 of Minnesota's 15 hits as the Twins beat Oakland, 6-2, tonight, handing Dave Stewart his first loss of the season and saddling the Athletics with their first three-game losing streak this year.

title: New Jersey's Chief Film Critic
description: Robert Wilentz, New Jersey's Chief Justice, is thought to be the enlightened leader of one of the more enlightened state supreme courts. But in recent days he has subjected his glowing reputation to the smoke of a cinematic bonfire.

title: Rhode Island Housing Bonds
description: The Rhode Island Housing and Mortgage Corporation is tentatively offering $70 million in bonds that will be used to make low-cost home mortgages available with a maximum yield of 7.85 percent for an issue due 2022 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Metro Datelines;   New York Is Given Four Land Parcels
description: A habitat for endangered rattlesnakes and a trout stream are among four parcels that have been given to the state of New York, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo announced yesterday.

title: Rio Journal;   A Most Unlovely Slum (Even if the View Is Nice)
description: Santa Marta hill affords an exhilarating postcard view of Rio's tourist attractions - Sugar Loaf Mountain, South Atlantic beaches and the Christ statue high on a neighboring mountain peak.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Metro Datelines;   Cable Franchise Vote Is Allowed to Proceed
description: A move to delay tonight's vote by the Board of Estimate on renewing two cable television franchises in Manhattan was rejected by a state appeals court judge yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Daisy Exposito has been named president of the Bravo Group, the Hispanic-market agency of Young & Rubicam, New York.

title: Scott to Enter Pro Draft
description: Dennis Scott, the high-scoring swingman who helped Georgia Tech reach the Final Four this year, is giving up his final year of college eligibility to enter the N.B.A. draft next month.

title: John P. E. Brown, Executive, 78
description: John P. E. Brown, a retired vice president of the American Arbitration Association, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 78 years old.

title: Canada Southern Pete reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company is listed on the Pacific Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: American Medical Building reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
An Incentive for Bigger Families
description: In the pristine subways that move Singapore's workers with near-silent efficiency, there are posters showing a young Singaporean father in a playful pillow fight with his children. The advertisements are part of a campaign to encourage families to have more children, the reverse of what is being sought by most of Singapore's Southeast Asian neighbors.

title: Safeguard Health Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Philips Ouster Tied to Loose Management
description: The forced resignation of Cornelis J. van der Klugt, the chairman of Philips N.V., announced today as expected, represents a dramatic fall from grace for a man regarded as one of the statesmen of European business and a highly visible supporter of the economic integration of Europe.

title: Bionaire Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
description: The company changed its fiscal year to Feb. 28 from May 31.

title: Public Strikes Illegal, Chamorro Aide Says
description: The Government today decreed strikes by public workers illegal, urged thousands of striking state employees to return to work and threatened to fire anyone who did not comply.

title: American Health Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Forum Retirement Partners L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lasix Emerges as a Front-Runner
description: rrThis should be racing's happiest season, a time for talk of the Triple Crown and the rich spring handicaps. This year, though, the controversy about Lasix is not only overshadowing the racing, but also increasingly becoming a part of it.

title: Lab Notes Are False, Secret Service Says
description: The Secret Service said today that printed tapes of readings from laboratory equipment used in research related to a disputed scientific paper were not produced at the times a scientist testified they were.

title: A Common Ground in the Abortion Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: North American Biologicals Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $49,000 and $12,000 for the latest and year-ago quarters, respectively, which reflect the utilization of carryforward general business credits in 1990 and net operating loss carryforwards in 1989 of less than 1 cent a share.

title: Valspar Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
description: Results for 1990 includes sales from the McCloskey business, acquired July 7, 1989. The latest second quarter and six months results for Valspar Corp. included a previously reported aftertax charge of $2,243,000, or 10 cents a share, stemming from the Chapter 11 filing of Amdura Corp. Two Amdura subsidiaries are customers of Valspar's consumer coatings group.

title: Ned L. Pines, 84, Dies; A New York Publisher
description: Ned L. Pines, a New York publisher, died yesterday at the American Hospital in Paris after a brief illness. He was 84 years old and lived in Paris, Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.

title: Fama Jury Questioning Whether He Fired Gun
description: Jurors in the Bensonhurst case asked the judge yesterday whether they could convict Joseph Fama of murder even if they found that he did not fire the fatal shots at Yusuf K. Hawkins.

title: Bridge
description: Foreign invaders carried off most of the prize money on Sunday in Manhattan in the Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs. The winners, who collected more than $30,000, were Eliakim Shoufel of Israel and Piotr Gawrys of Poland. Second place went to Jon Baldursson and Adalsteinn Jorgensen of Iceland.

title: Winfield Case Heads to Arbitrator
description: The saga of Dave Winfield and which team he belongs to, either the Yankees or the California Angels, may finally be decided tomorrow when an arbitrator will hear both sides of the argument.

title: Holnam Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter's results doesn't reflect acquisition of Northwestern states on Jan. 19, nor the March 8 acquisition of a minority interest in Ideal Basic Industries Inc.

title: Small Investors Cautious; Some See a Chance to Sell
description: Though small investors have not completely sat out the recent stock market rally, they have been unenthusiastic participants. Record prices have been propelled by the institutional investor, brokers say, and in some cases individuals are seeing a good opportunity to sell their stocks.

title: Bankatlantic reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included extraordinary gain of $804,000, or 26 cents a share, from sale of Federal Home Loan bank advances. Bankatlantic is a subsidiary of Bankatlantic Financial Corp.

title: OMI Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter results included a gain of $1,028,000 from the sale of a vessel.

title: Melcor Developments reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: ALL-GERMAN VOTE COULD COME IN '90
description: With uneasiness growing in both Germanys over the possible costs of reunification, Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany indicated today for the first time that all-German elections could be held as early as Dec. 2.

title: Accord Near On Preserving Westway Site
description: Top officials here said today that they were near an accord that would ban real-estate development along most of the waterfront on the lower West Side of Manhattan.

title: Of German Pride and German Conscience
description: To the Editor:

title: Schizophrenia Drug Hailed, Except for Cost
description: A DRUG put on the market three months ago was hailed here yesterday as the biggest breakthrough in 20 years in the treatment of schizophrenia, but critics charged that the high cost of tests associated with it has put it out of reach of most patients.

title: Census And Sensibility
description: LEAD:

title: Review/Country;   True Sweetness, No Grit
description: Ricky Skaggs helped start country's new-traditionalism movement a decade ago when he stripped away orchestral arrangements and restored bluegrass picking to country songs. While the core country audience supports him nicely, with regular No. 1 singles, he has been unable to reach beyond that core. A rare New York appearance on Friday night at the Ritz suggested why: the gulf between honky-tonk, which has carried Dwight Yoakam and Randy Travis to the wider audience, and bluegrass.

title: Gateway Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said that as result of the weakened Australian economy and dollar, its Australian subsidiary, Micro Networks, had a loss partially caused by a U.S. dollar reduction in average selling prices. The company also said it has provided for a loss of $152,000 as a result of the Micro Networks transaction.

title: Maxx Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Feb. 28
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Congressman Defending Scientist Who Is Suspected in War Crimes
description: A Congressman from Ohio says he is urging Arthur Rudolph, a retired NASA rocket scientist who is accused of brutalizing Nazi prisoners in World War II, to return to the United States from West Germany in defiance of a Justice Department order.

title: Runner From London Is a Prospect for the Jets
description: Until Victor Ebubedike showed up last week, the most promising Jets player anyone could remember coming out of England was Bobby Howfield, a place-kicker who preceded Pat Leahy.

title: A Less Expensive Supercomputer
description: Cray Research Inc. introduced a supercomputer priced at $2.2 million and up, less than half the price of its existing Cray Y-MP products, which start at $5 million. The new machine, the Cray Y-MP2E, can be air-cooled, which is less costly than the liquid refrigerants used by the Y-MP family. ''Until now the cost of ownership has put supercomputing out of reach for many organizations,'' John A. Rollwagen, Cray's chairman and chief executive, said in a statement. The new machine will also cost less to install, operate and maintain, he said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Black-and-White Ads With a Splash of Color
description: Torn between the vibrancy of color and classic style of black-and-white? The latest in interactive advertising lets you have it both ways.

title: Sonesta International HotelFs Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Dance;   Adding Complexity To Familiar Beethoven
description: ''Pastorale,'' James Kudelka's new work for the National Ballet of Canada, is nothing short of amazing, a ballet unlike any other, full of risks and substance in its theme and choreographic complexities.

title: Support in Larger Cities Is Vital for Tour's Success
description: Now that the second Tour de Trump has ended, the people who run America's major bicycle race are starting to make plans for next year. They feel sure there will be a next year, but it may be different.

title: Metro Mobile Cts Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
TV News Crews Guarded
description: Many New York television stations, fearing violence against their employees and the loss of equipment, are sending guards with crews covering news in areas where racial tensions are high.

title: Asset Investors Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reduced by $2,800,000 due to the carrying amount adjustment of three of the company's collateralized mortgage obligation excess cash flows (more commonly referred to as CMO residuals or residual cash flows).

title: Comarco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 22
Electronic Arts reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflected tax-loss carryforward of $5,000 and $485,000 for thequarter and year, respectively. c-Reflected tax-loss carryforward of $193,000.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in SportsMonday on the Baltimore Orioles' victory over the Oakland A's misstated the results of the weekend series between the teams. The Orioles won two of the three games in the series, not all three. The headline repeated the error.

title: Review/Ballet;   Proof That the Dancers Make All the Difference
description: Four of American Ballet Theater's best performers took the lead roles in ''Giselle'' on Saturday afternoon and evening at the Metropolitan Opera House, and proved once more how individual interpretations can be. In the afternoon, Amanda McKerrow and Guillaume Graffin offered a first act that was unforgettable in its telling, complex dramatic nuances. The second act shone brightest in the evening, in an unforgettably exciting performance by Cynthia Harvey and Julio Bocca.

title: Aid Officials in Zambia
description: Experts from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank have arrived here to review Zambia's economic recovery plans. Sources close to the Ministry of Finance said today that the two teams would help Zambia use an aid package of $450 million worked out by donors at a Paris meeting in April. Faced with a $7.2 billion debt and a declining standard of living, Zambia was promised fresh aid at the Paris meeting after the approval of its 1990-94 economic recovery plan by the I.M.F. and World Bank.

title: Seibels Bruce Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,271,963, or 17 cents a share, and $391,283, or 5 cents a share, for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. Results for 1989 have been restated to reflect Gay & Taylor as discontinued operation.

title: Penn West Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Velcro Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Frontier Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Masstor Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Sunshine Mining Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings results are after preferred dividend requirements of $3,235,000 in both periods.

title: Little Anger At Sex Case At St. John's
description: It is spring and the school year is almost over, but pounding rock music does not seep out of dormitory windows onto the quadrangle, and golden retrievers do not race after frisbees on the lawn. St. John's University in Queens does not have dormitories or campus pets, and the only place music blares is the parking lot, from the cars of students going home or to their jobs.

title: Glut of Potatoes in Poland Is Showing The Price of Change to Free Market
description: In the hot afternoon sun in the woods behind Mieczyslaw Piecak's farm, they were picking over a pile of rotting potatoes the other day, prospecting for a few firm tubers that could be saved for seed or cattle fodder.

title: Ingersoll Cutting Costs At Chain
description: Almost three weeks after Ralph Ingersoll 2d shut down The St. Louis Sun, stringent cost-cutting measures - including a hiring freeze and a 12 percent reduction in news space - have been imposed at his Suburban Newspapers of Greater St. Louis.

title: Dartmouth Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Stop Playing Games: Finish Start
description: As Secretary of State Baker departs for Moscow to try to wrap up a strategic arms accord, State Department officials raise doubts about Mikhail Gorbachev's ability to deliver. They may believe what they say, but the last-minute doubt-sowing has a self-serving quality.

title: The Letter of the Law
description: ST. PETER, so the story goes, looked up from his post at the Pearly Gates and saw the Devil sneakily moving the fence, trying to claim more territory. As the Devil moved the boundary markers ever closer, Peter warned him, ''Stop that or I'll sue you.''

title: Goldriver L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The partnership said that as a result of the continued adverse impact to revenue and net income during construction of the Gold River Hotel & Casino's expansion project, it anticipates that it will be out of compliance with the covenant in its bond indenture governing its minimum partners' equity as of June 30, unless the deficiency is cured. The company also said Goldriver Finance Corp. is a wholly owned unit of Goldriver L.P.

title: Thornburgh Shuffles 2 Top Aides, Giving Loyalists Less Visible Jobs
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today reassigned two of his closest aides in response to criticism that he had isolated himself from top deputies.

title: $1 Billion Mortgage Swap Arranged by Freddie Mac
description: The Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, known as Freddie Mac, which maintains a flow of funds to mortgage lenders by purchasing their mortgages, announced yesterday that it would swap more than $1 billion in adjustable-rate mortgages tied to the cost-of-funds index.

title: Eating Well
description: FOR food fanatics, spring's warmer weather, longer days, cherry blossoms and azaleas are much less important than tender young spinach leaves, slender stalks of rhubarb, strawberries that are red from top to bottom and asparagus at reasonable prices.

title: Judge Questions A New Charge In Racial Case
description: The judge in the Howard Beach racial-attack case expressed strong doubt yesterday about a prosecution attempt to expand the charges against three defendants who face a retrial.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Perkin Unit To Remain U.S. Owned
description: In a long-awaited agreement that will keep a vital semiconductor technology under United States ownership, a California company said yesterday that it would acquire a division of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation that makes the sophisticated machines needed to develop the world's most-advanced computer chips.

title: A Correction: Hudson Building Ban
description: A map accompanying an article yesterday about plans for the Hudson River waterfront incorrectly located the areas where real estate development would be banned.

title: Henry P. Hayes, Executive, 83
description: Henry P. Hayes, a retired executive of the National Broadcasting Company, died of complications from a series of strokes Monday at Meadow Lakes, a retirement community in Hightstown, N.J., where he lived. He was 83 years old and had been a longtime resident of Manhattan.

title: From Citibank, Millions for Schools
description: Citibank announced yesterday that it would spend $20 million over the next 10 years to improve urban schools in a variety of ways, including the development of new approaches to teaching and the promotion of technology in the classroom.

title: 'Today' Staff Is Shuffled To Restore 'Family'
description: NBC News yesterday moved to restore what its president called ''a sense of family'' to the ''Today'' show by adding three new personalities to the program. The additions follow months of declining ratings for the morning news program since the departure of the co-host, Jane Pauley, in December and her replacement by Deborah Norville.

title: 2 Students Are Killed In Montana Dormitory
description: A Montana State University student killed two other students with a shotgun early this morning and was then captured almost 100 miles away, the authorities said.

title: China Cancels Grumman Deal
description: China has pulled out of a $502 million deal under which the United States had agreed to help modernize 55 Chinese F-8 fighter jets, the Pentagon said today.

title: 5 Arrested Protesting Abortion
description: Five men were arrested today inside an Atlanta abortion clinic, a day after the United States Supreme Court upheld an injunction that has kept protesters away from the clinics. The five protesters entered the Atlanta Surgicenter early today and locked themselves together with chain-like bicycle locks, officials said.

title: W. E. Scarbrough, 43, Queens Judge Since '83
description: Judge Wayne E. Scarbrough of Criminal Court in Queens, died of a brain aneurysm on Monday at the Golden Hill Health Care Center in Milford, Conn. He was 43 years old and lived in Rosedale, Queens.

title: Hanover Bank Forms Into 4 Groups
description: The Manufacturers Hanover Corporation announced a reorganization of its business into four major groups yesterday.

title: Citicorp Paper Is Down Again
description: Interest rates declined yesterday for the second consecutive week at Citicorp's regular auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: Manila Gets Tough on U.S. Bases
description: The Philippine Government formally told the United States today that the 1947 agreement allowing American military bases here would not be extended when it expires in September 1991. The step was largely symbolic, and both Philippine and American officials said a new treaty could still be negotiated.

title: Fed Nominee Endorsed
description: The nomination of Assistant Treasury Secretary David W. Mullins Jr. to a vacant seat on the seven-member Federal Reserve Board was endorsed today by the Senate Banking Committee. The committee voted, 18 to 0, to forward the nomination to the full Senate, which is expected to approve it. Mr. Mullins, who is 44 years old, is an architect of President Bush's savings and loan industry bailout. He was a Harvard business professor before moving to the Treasury Department in October 1988. He was nominated to fill the six years remaining in the term of H. Robert Heller, who resigned.

title: Plea for Peace at Irish Prelate's Burial
description: Tomas Cardinal O Fiaich, Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland, was buried today after a Requiem Mass at St. Patrick's Cathedral in Armagh, Northern Ireland, with a call by the senior Bishop of that province for an end to violence between its Protestants and Catholics.

title: Bankruptcy Petition Filed By Circle K
description: The Circle K Corporation, the troubled convenience-store chain, filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy code last night.

title: CAUTION PREVAILS IN OPENING SESSION OF BUDGET TALKS
description: President Bush opened budget negotiations with Congress today by refusing a request from the Democratic Congressional leadership that he make a televised address outlining the nation's economic problems and putting forward his own remedy.

title: Faster Deportation for Crimes to Be Proposed
description: The Bush Administration will offer legislation on Wednesday to expand the power of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to deport people convicted of crimes, Administration officials said today.

title: KEY RATES
Monroe Inducted
description: Earl Monroe, overlooked three times by the voters, savored his long-awaited induction into the Basketball's Hall of Fame yesterday in Springfield, Mass. Also enshrined were Elvin Hayes, Dave Bing and the late Neil Johnston, the Philadelphia Warriors' hook-shot specialist who won three consecutive scoring titles in the 1950's.

title: Electric Vehicles Would Reduce Pollution
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: The REV. BERNICE ALBERTINE KING spent an exhilarating day Monday. More than 20 years after her father, the REV. DR. MARTIN LUTHER KING JR., delivered his last sermon at the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta, she gave her first.

title: U.S. Suspends Hughes Unit
description: The Air Force said today that it had suspended a missile research and development unit of the Hughes Aircraft Company from receiving new contracts and might bar it for three years for its role in a scandal involving stolen budget documents.

title: George Bush 101: Vintage Days for Sizing Him Up
description: If you seek to discover what manner of man is running the United States, these are vintage days for watching George Bush.

title: Egyptian President Meets With Gorbachev
description: In a visit formally ending 18 years of strained relations, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt met in the Kremlin today, signing a declaration condemning the settlement of Soviet Jews in Israel's occupied territories.

title: White House Rules Out Plan To Weaken a Law on Wildlife
description: Rejecting complaints by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., the White House says President Bush does not want to weaken the nation's primary law protecting endangered animals and plants.

title: Airport Bonds Priced by Hawaii
description: Hawaii tentatively priced $100 million in airport systems revenue bonds yesterday with a maximum yield of 7.50 percent for an issue due in 2020 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Why Didn't Winfield Just Leave?
description: We cannot pin this one on George. We have his word on that. This Winfield business was the idea of his Baseball People.

title: Capitalist Ferment at Czech Brewer
description: With its ancient copper mash vats, ponderous oak barrels and age-old beer-making techniques, this city's famed Pilsner Urquell brewery long took a back seat to other enterprises as Communist central planners invested massively in favored industries like machinery and steel.

title: Nintendo Research
description: Nintendo of America Inc. said its parent company in Japan would establish a $3 million fund at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Laboratory for research into how children learn while they play. The world's leading maker of video games said the Nintendo Fund would support the work of Seymour Papert, who maintains that traditional teaching methods have become increasingly out of touch with children. He develops high-technology learning tools for his research.

title: AIDS Care Deterred
description: To the Editor:

title: Fair Play for College Athletes
description: In the recent National Football League draft of college players, 18 were juniors taking advantage of the pros' new openness to underclassmen. But 20 other juniors went unchosen. They ended up without contracts and, thanks to an antiquated notion of amateurism, without the option to resume their collegiate playing careers.

title: Hubble Telescope Able to Focus
description: After three troubled weeks trying to steady a wiggling spacecraft and fix its sights on the heavens, ground controllers said yesterday that the Hubble Space Telescope was responding reliably to commands and was for the first time focusing on guide stars. This apparently clears the way for the telescope to take its first picture on Sunday.

title: Corrections
description: The Outdoors column in Sports Pages on Friday, about fly fishing in the Catskills, misidentified a family of fly tiers who own a fly shop in Roscoe, N.Y. They are Walt, Winnie and Mary Dette.

title: Economic Scene;   Penny-Wise On Ozone?
description: IT was time to ante up last week on the latest global deal to save the ozone layer, and the Bush Administration decided not to play: The White House announced it would not share the cost of weaning poor countries from the use of ozone-depleting chemicals before they became truly addicted. Subsidies to encourage the substitution of nonpolluting gases in air-conditioners, refrigerators and plastic insulation, the Administration suggested, would have to come from the existing resources of the World Bank.

title: Dent Is Silent but Players Rush to Winfield's Defense
description: On a night when Don Mattingly hit his 100th home run at Yankee Stadium and the Yankees swept to a decisive 7-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins, the main questions for Manager Bucky Dent after the game had to do with the man who was not there, Dave Winfield, and the one whose own days might be numbered, himself.

title: Fighting Hate With Decency
description: New Yorkers, their racial sensitivities already heightened, were quick to see the violent clash between black youths and Vietnamese men in Brooklyn early Sunday as an alarming example of bigotry run amok. Too quick, it appears. The police, retreating from earlier accounts, conclude that the melee, though brutal, did not begin as a racially motivated assault.

title: Arpino Allows Joffrey To Perform His Ballets
description: Gerald Arpino has agreed that the Joffrey Ballet may perform ballets he choreographed during its Los Angeles season at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion of the Music Center, the Joffrey's board of directors announced yesterday.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: CHOESTOE, which means ''Land of the Dancing Rabbit'' in Cherokee, is nestled in the Georgia mountains about 100 miles north of Atlanta, near the Appalachian Trail. There is no post office at this crossroads where U.S. 129 and Georgia 180 meet, just a little country store,a couple of trout farms and over on the banks of the Nottely River, George and Cecilia Holland's Logan Turnpike Farm.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Anti-Independence Crowds Storm Parliaments in Estonia and Latvia
description: Crowds of anti-independence protesters stormed the Parliament buildings in Latvia and neighboring Estonia today in the largest display of physical force since the Baltic republics began their formal withdrawal from the Soviet Union.

title: INSURANCE SNAG IN PENNSYLVANIA
description: Gov. Robert P. Casey's plan to reduce automobile insurance premiums has suffered several legal setbacks, raising a question as to whether consumers will get their promised reductions on July 1.

title: About New York;   Two Who Look For the Elderly Few Others See
description: There are unlikely jobs in New York City. This column is about one of them. It is about two mental-health workers who troll high-rise apartments, cheap hotels and park benches to find sick old people and get them to a doctor at the Bellevue Hospital Center.

title: Federal Home Loan Banks Offer $875 Million in Bonds
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank System, a network of 12 regional banks that lend money to savings and loan associations, tapped the securities market yesterday with an $875 million offering at par of one-year and two-year bonds through various securities dealers.

title: Time Unit Closing Magazine
description: Southpoint, a regional general interest magazine, will cease publication with its June issue.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Equivalency Degrees Down
description: The number of dropouts who receive high school equivalency degrees has significantly declined, the American Council on Education said today.

title: Grace Nute, 94, Dies; Historian and Teacher
description: Grace Lee Nute, a historian and educator who was a retired research associate at the Minnesota Historical Society, died May 4 at a nursing home in Menlo Park, Calif. She was 94 years old and lived in Walnut Creek, Calif.

title: Peter C. Stocker, 47, California Developer
description: Peter C. Stocker, a Northern California real estate developer, was killed Saturday in a helicopter crash in Monterey County, Calif. He was 47 years old and lived in Sausalito, Calif.

title: Free Speech Lives in a Brooklyn Plaza
description: If you had any questions about the relationship of the Communist Manifesto, the Bible, the Central Intelligence Agency, a burning American flag and Big Band music to the Bensonhurst murder trial, you could have found someone very glad to enlighten you yesterday outside State Supreme Court in Brooklyn.

title: Fremont Journal;   Tradition Is Outgrown In Baby Food's Capital
description: For nearly 60 years, visitors have made the journey to this remote town in western Michigan, drawn to the big yellow-brick factory suffused with the warm aromas of mashed peas and steamed squash.

title: Fighter Wins 3 Times
description: It's not every fighter who can win a single boxing match three times, but then not every boxer calls himself the Magician. Dennis Milton does, however, and yesterday, he achieved his third victory in a middleweight bout against Michael (the Silk) Olajide in Albany last Dec. 1.

title: Mattingly and Cary Keep Twins in Check
description: Chuck Cary says he just wants to pitch. Cary is not worried about the elbow injury that put him on the disabled list, he is not worried about a place in the starting rotation, and he is not worried about being traded. Traded? With Dave Winfield lurking in the clubhouse this afternoon and his situation growing stranger by the hour, it is difficult for players on the Yankees to avoid thinking about things like trades, roster changes and arbitration.

title: Reviews/Theater;   3 Widows With Unseemly Behavior
description: If you believe that one good reason for going to the theater is to escape television sitcoms, you may not be tickled to end up at ''The Cemetery Club,'' the new attraction at the Brooks Atkinson. From its peppy canned theme music to its final-scene sermonizing, this comedy about three Jewish widows in Forest Hills, Queens, is ''Golden Girls'' at four times the length but with at most one-fourth the star wattage. Moving at the leisurely pace of a contentious canasta hand, ''The Cemetery Club'' could be one of the best arguments yet advanced for cremation.

title: As the World Turns
description: May 11: The Yankees, in Seattle for a series against the Mariners, announce that Dave Winfield, their 38-year-old outfielder, has been traded to the California Angels for a pitcher, Mike Witt. Winfield, citing a clause in baseball's basic labor agreement that says he can veto the trade, says he won't go. The Yankees, citing what they contend is a superceding clause in Winfield's personal contract, say he has no choice. Winfield decides he is in limbo. ''Get me a cab to limbo,'' he says as he heads back to New York to await an arbitration decision.

title: Review/Music;   Amsterdam's Calm Reflection On the Baroque
description: Perhaps the most authentic thing about Sunday afternoon's concert by the Amsterdam Baroque Orchestra was its pervasive calmness. Conducted by Ton Koopman and offering a program largely familiar to friends of early-18th-century style, these 16 period-instrument players were able to couch both high energy and reflection in terms of quiet confidence.

title: Reviews/Theater;   Retribution and Revenge in Short
description: The five plays in Marathon 1990, the 13th annual one-act festival at the Ensemble Studio Theater, deal varyingly with retribution and revenge. This concern is amusingly exemplified by comedies from Bill Bozzone and Frank D. Gilroy. Both are skilled practitioners of the short play form. They know that a one-act should never overstay the audience's interest.

title: Article 933290 -- No Title
description: By an overwhelming vote, the Senate today brushed aside efforts to delay action on a groundbreaking bill to provide emergency relief funds to deal with the AIDS epidemic.

title: INSIDE
description: Itineraries for 3 V.I.P.'s

title: A Fact of Life: Sex-Video Rentals
description: It was a routine week night at Videoplus. Youngsters scanned the racks for ''Teen-Age Mutant Ninja Turtles.'' High-school girls giggled at a Patrick Swayze poster. And John Schnaubelt, one of a half-dozen adults in the store, strode to the counter with two tapes that will never be reviewed by Siskel and Ebert: ''Ginger's Boy-Girl Hits'' and ''Splash Shots.''

title: CHRONICLE
description: Minutes before he was to argue that burning the flag is protected by the First Amendment, WILLIAM M. KUNSTLER went before the Supreme Court Justices Monday in a gentler cause. The civil liberties lawyer vouched for KARIN KUNSTLER GOLDMAN, his daughter, as worthy to be admitted to the Supreme Court bar. In thanks, she gave him a Mark Cross pen.

title: Pistons' Defense Leaves Knicks Out in Cold
description: The much-heralded Detroit Pistons' defense was just too much for the Knicks tonight.

title: Carter's Pinch-Hit Double Lifts Giants
description: It was just like old times, except for one small detail. When Gary Carter sliced a double down the right-field line to drive in the deciding run tonight, then thrust his fist into the air, he did not do it for the Mets.

title: Mary Oppen, Author, 81
description: Mary Oppen, an author and artist, died of ovarian cancer on Monday at Alta Bates-Herrick Hospital in Berkeley, Calif. She was 81 years old and lived in Albany, Calif.

title: Accounts
description: * Guinness Import Company, to Mathieu, Goluskin, Donovan & Clarke, for its Moosehead brand beer, for a summer promotional campaign with a budget of $3 million.

title: Winfield Comes and Then Goes, but Turmoil Remains
description: Four days after they traded him to the California Angels, Dave Winfield arrived at Yankee Stadium yesterday afternoon prepared to play for the Yankees.

title: Books of The Times;   Decade of Changing American Values
description: The Worst Years of Our Lives

title: Capital Mayor in Court to Deny New Charges
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. pleaded not guilty in Federal District Court today to six new drug-related charges, saying afterward that he felt ''fantastic'' despite his many legal and political difficulties and was confident of his defense.

title: Industrial Production Down 0.4%
description: Industrial production fell in April for the first time since January, with a sharp drop in the output of motor vehicles and parts, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Is Botswana a Model for Democracies in Africa?
description: In the African context, an unusual event occurred in Botswana last October: national elections were held among eight competing political parties. When some of the results were disputed, the judiciary, not the politicians, interceded.

title: A Portable 'Book' Player From Sony
description: The Sony Corporation introduced a palm-sized electronic ''book'' player that stores 100,000 pages of text on a compact disk. The ''Data Discman'' uses a read-only compact disk, or CD-ROM, to store information. The data on the three-inch disk can be shown on a small liquid crystal display mounted on the 1.2-pound machine.

title: U.S. Will Tie Aid to Exports In Bid to Curb the Practice
description: Moving to promote United States exports more aggressively, the Bush Administration today announced an initiative aimed at inducing other developed countries, principally Japan and France, to curb their export-aid programs.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: CHRONICLE
description: His birthday was April 20, but the party was last night. Former Mayor ROBERT F. WAGNER was 80 years old and hundreds of friends gathered at the Winter Garden to celebrate.

title: Knicks Run Out of Energy
description: By the end of tonight's game, the Knicks looked like a tired team that needed a vacation.

title: Low-Priced Work Station From Sun
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. introduced and began shipping a low-priced computer work station today that will compete directly with personal computers. It is in the price range of powerful personal computers and works twice as fast.

title: Outcry Over Visits From South Africa
description: Administration officials said today that they were considering ways to revise the schedule for the White House visits of President F. W. de Klerk of South Africa and Nelson Mandela because of protests that Mr. de Klerk's visit comes first.

title: K. C. Jones Is Named Coach of SuperSonics
description: K. C. Jones, who played on eight Boston Celtics teams that won National Basketball Association championships and coached two others that captured titles, yesterday was named head coach of the Seattle SuperSonics. Jones, 58 years old, succeeds Bernie Bickerstaff, who will become the team's vice president in charge of operations.

title: Racist Theories Compromise Teaching Ability;   Freedom to Poison
description: To the Editor:

title: Philip Clark, Educator And Psychologist, 73
description: Dr. Philip Clark, a psychologist and an educational administrator, died of heart failure on Monday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: Trusthouse-Bass
description: Trusthouse Forte P.L.C. said it had bought the Crest hotel chain in Britain from Bass P.L.C. for $:300 million, or more than $501 million, in cash. Trusthouse said the deal involved 43 hotels in Britain. Profits of the assets being acquired were $:29.9 million in the year that ended on Sept. 30, 1989. Bass said total proceeds from its Crest disposal program, which includes hotels outside Britain, are expected to exceed $:400 million.

title: Suns Rally to Beat Lakers, Earning Trip to West Final
description: The Phoenix Suns set aside years of franchise-deep frustration tonight, beating the Los Angeles Lakers, 106-103, at the Forum and advancing to the National Basketball Association's Western Conference final.

title: Dawson Belts 2 as Cubs Rout Braves
description: Andre Dawson hit two two-run homers and Jeff Pico, just up from the minors, allowed one hit in six shutout innings tonight as the Chicago Cubs routed the Atlanta Braves, 12-2.

title: Don't Give In to the Drug Forces by Putting Kids in Orphanages
description: To the Editor:

title: From Texas Rodeo to Winner's Circle
description: After Unbridled worked five furlongs in a nifty 1:00 2/5 seconds yesterday morning at Churchill Downs, Carl Nafzger, the colt's trainer, had some discouraging words for the other horses that will be running in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday.

title: 5 Airlines, 16 meals, a Handful of Hits
description: ONE of my longtime guidelines as a restaurant critic is this: ''The quality of food is in inverse proportion to the altitude of the dining room, with airplanes the extreme example.''

title: Walter Thornton, Agent for Models, Dies of Stroke at 88
description: Walter Thornton, retired head of the Walter Thornton Agency in Manhattan, once one of the nation's largest modeling agencies, died of a stroke on Monday at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Long Beach, Calif. He was 88 years old and lived in Jalisco, Mexico.

title: W. B. Mullins, 52, A Founding Official Of the Peace Corps
description: William B. Mullins, a former Peace Corps official who became a foundation executive, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 52 years old.

title: Harland C. Forbes Is Dead at 92; Ex-Chief Executive of Con Edison
description: Harland Clement Forbes, a retired chief executive of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died of pneumonia yesterday at Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla. He was 92 years old and had lived in Sarasota since moving there from Manhasset, L.I., in 1965.

title: Can Good Food Fly At 35,000 Feet?
description: KEVIN GREENE hates jokes about airline food. And as director of catering services for Pan American World Airways at Kennedy International Airport, he's heard them all.

title: Bridge
description: Many of the players who competed in the Cavendish Charity Invitational Pairs over the weekend stayed to compete in the Cavendish Teams, a three-session event that began Monday night. Exactly half of the 12 competing squads consisted largely or wholly of players from other continents.

title: 'Robbins's Broadway' to Close Sept. 1
description: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' the most expensive show in Broadway history, is to close Sept. 1 at the Imperial Theater after a run of less than two years and after making back only a little more than half its investment, its producers announced yesterday.

title: Klima's Goal in 3d Overtime Wins Cup Opener for Oilers
description: The red goal light, unlike the others in Boston Garden, worked when it had to, even though it was beginning to appear as if it might never get turned on.

title: Time Warner Loses a Vote On Cable TV
description: In a surprise vote five minutes before a midnight deadline, the New York City Board of Estimate unanimously agreed last night to issue a preliminary denial of Time Warner's applications to renew the two cable television franchises it controls in Manhattan.

title: D'Arcy Buys Agency
description: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles said it had acquired Donald E. Whiting Inc., a telephone directory advertising agency based in Deerfield, Ill. Whiting will become a division of D.M.B.& B./Yellow Pages in Chicago. D.M.B.& B./Yellow Pages also promoted Mary MacDonald to the newly created position of chief executive and managing director.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THERE are few meat staples more versatile and inexpensive than chicken legs. What's more, they happen to be the most flavorful part of the bird.

title: Smith Decision on Student Aid: 'Tip of the Iceberg'
description: With Federal aid for student grants and loans down dramatically from levels of a decade ago, college administrators predict that fewer and fewer colleges will be able to guarantee financial aid to all the students they admit.

title: Steroid Test Positive
description: A Soviet athlete who finished second in the women's division of the Los Angeles Marathon on March 4, has tested positive for steroid use and will be suspended from competition in the United States for two years, The Athletics Congress announced yesterday.

title: The Sweetest Peas: Smaller Is Better
description: IN ''Food,'' his highly personal one-volume encyclopedia, the late Waverley Root began the three-page entry on peas with this anecdote:

title: HIGH CANCER RISKS FOR SOME AT MILLS
description: Flour mill employees who have worked with grain pesticides for many years face a risk of cancer that can be nine times the risk faced by other workers in the grain industry, a new study has found.

title: Fleet/Norstar
description: The Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc. is offering $150 million in notes due in 1993 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The 9.95 percent three-year notes are priced at 100, to yield 135 basis points more than Treasuries with a similar maturity. Noncallable by the company, the notes are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by Standart & Poor's.

title: Bellamy and Rival Fight To Run Against Regan
description: The stage was set yesterday for what is likely to be the only statewide primary this September and the most hotly contested statewide general election in November - both for state comptroller.

title: Bush Sending 3 Aides To Assist on Kashmir
description: President Bush is sending three senior officials to India and Pakistan in an effort to ease tensions between the two countries over the disputed territory of Kashmir, the White House said today.

title: Violent Toys: An Alternative
description: Fed up with the proliferation of violent toys for children? So is the San Francisco advertising agency Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley and its client Dakin Inc., a maker of heart-melting stuffed animals. Hence the agency's first campaign for Dakin, which contrasts the company's cuddly toys with the competition's war toys and violent video games. ''Gifts you can feel good about'' is the theme line, ''Is it any wonder the prisons are full?'' asks a headline above a sampling of toys: a bloody knife, a tank, a rocket, a warplane, a water pistol, a hand grenade and a space warrior. Another ad, with the headline ''We help children develop more than their trigger finger,'' shows a little girl with curly blond hair squeezing a big white teddy bear.

title: Chrysler to Announce Plans for a Sports Car
description: Faced with slack sales and competition against its most successful vehicles, the Chrysler Corporation will announce this week that it plans to offer a powerful two-seat sports car late next year. The plans for the car, to be called the Dodge Viper, were confirmed by Chrysler managers today in response to a press report.

title: Partnership in Firm Awarded to Victim of Sex Bias
description: A Federal district judge in Washington has ordered Price Waterhouse, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, to give a partnership to a woman who said she was denied the promotion in 1983 because of negative sexual stereotypes.

title: Castle & Cook Split Delayed by Taxes
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. said today that it would delay separating its food and real estate businesses because of tax questions and a tightening of credit available to companies in the real estate industry.

title: Wine Talk
description: AN Englishman named Andrew Barr has written one of the most interesting books on wine to come along in some time. It's called ''Wine Snobbery,'' and two years after it was published in England, he is still in a peck of trouble.

title: Albany Legislators Reach Accord On $1.4 Billion in Taxes and Fees
description: New York State's legislative leaders today reached a final accord on a $1.4 billion package of taxes and fees that would raise the price of dozens of goods and services, including liquor, soda, car rentals and parking.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Graduation at Sarah Lawrence College promises to be a Newman family affair. JOANNE WOODWARD and CLEA NEWMAN will both receive bachelor of arts degrees. And PAUL NEWMAN, the husband and father, is delivering the commencement address.

title: Florida Center Holding Aliens Is Under Inquiry
description: Amid a growing Justice Department investigation into complaints of mistreatment of aliens at the Krome Detention Center here, additional former detainees at the center are making complaints of sexual harassment and physical abuse.

title: Beersheba Journal;   Many Emigres, Much Hope (Will the Jobs Come?)
description: A desert wind soothes this grove of academe far from Palestinian revolt, and the calm, said Mikhail Zusman, lately of Kharkov in the Ukraine, is to his liking.

title: S.E.C. Division Head Leaving
description: Kathryn B. McGrath, the director of the Securities and Exchange Commission's investment management division, announced today that she will resign next month to become a partner in the Washington office of Morgan Lewis & Bockius, a New York-based law firm.

title: Fund Family Planning For the Third World
description: To the Editor:

title: At the Nation's Table
description: WHEN Tom DeBaggio hung a handpainted sign outside his blue-frame house 16 years ago to advertise his basil, bay leaf and tomato plants, he had few takers.

title: Smaller Loss At Resorts
description: Resorts International Inc., the casino and hotel company that has been struggling to emerge from bankruptcy, reported a quarterly loss of $3.1 million today, down from $18.7 million in the period last year.

title: Tracey Ullman to Leave Her TV Show on Fox
description: Tracey Ullman said yesterday that she would not return for a fifth season of ''The Tracey Ullman Show'' in the fall. The weekly show, in which the English-born comedian performs in comedy sketches with a resident company and guest stars, was one of the first programs to bring critical acclaim to the fledgling Fox Television network, winning four Emmy Awards last year.

title: Peter R. Knauss, 52, A Political Scientist
description: Peter R. Knauss, an expert on Africa who was an associate professor of political science at the University of Illinois at Chicago, died of AIDS on Sunday at St. Francis Hospital in Evanston, Ill. He was 52 years old and lived in Evanston. Dr. Knauss's area of expertise was African politics. He joined the faculty in 1968; in 1988 he was promoted to associate professor.

title: Trial Starts in Agent's Slaying
description: Opening arguments were held today in a Federal trial resulting from the slaying of the American anti-drug agent Enrique Camarena and three other men in Mexico.

title: Commission to Push for Liberal Allowances for Recruits
description: The co-chairmen of the Knight Foundation Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics said today that the 22-member panel would likely press for more liberal allowances for recruits, the abolition of athletic dormitories and an end to off-season tournaments for prep basketball players.

title: Oboist and Quintet Win Prizes in Competition
description: Washington Barella, a Brazilian oboist, and the Meridian Arts Ensemble, a New York City-based brass quintet, have been named first-prize winners in Concert Artists Guild's 1990 New York competition. The award includes $2,500 in cash, a three-year recording contract on Channel Classics' Winning Artists series, recitals in New York and other cities, and management by Concert Artists Guild.

title: Racist Theories Compromise Teaching Ability
description: To the Editor:

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;

We Didn't Criticize Mrs. Bush
description: LEAD: All right, I've had enough! As a Wellesley College student and co-author of the petition that started this whole Barbara Bush mess, I'd like to set the record straight.

title: Market Place;   The Bitter Fight For Kollmorgen
description: THE struggle for control of the Kollmorgen Corporation, which has been going on for more than a year, may come to a conclusion next week as shareholders decide whether to keep current management or vote in directors from the Vernitron Corporation, a rival maker of electric motors. It is a fight that all sides may wish had never begun.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: DEAR Diary:

title: Arts Endowment Faces Challenge From the States' Arts Agencies
description: The National Endowment for the Arts faces a fresh challenge from elements of the arts community itself that are apparently allied with leading House Republicans. This comes just as the endowment is facing its worst buffeting ever.

title: Food Notes
description: An Asian Winner

title: New York Police Report Soaring Crime in January
description: Murders, rapes and robberies in New York City rose in January far above the number for the same month last year, according to police statistics released yesterday.

title: Manhattan Driver Badly Hurt By Falling Bag of Tile Mortar
description: A driver was critically injured in Manhattan yesterday when a 70-pound bag of tile mortar was apparently dropped from a construction site, crushing the roof of his car, the police said.

title: NEW STEPS URGED FOR AIR SECURITY
description: The Presidential commission that investigated the bombing of Pan American Flight 103 called today for far-reaching new measures internationally and at domestic airports to counter such attacks. But it also sharply criticized a costly bomb-detection initiative already undertaken by the Bush Administration.

title: C.D. Yields Show a Decline
description: On a national scale, yields on certificates of deposit were down and money market accounts were up for the week ended yesterday.

title: He's Not Laughing (Well, Not Always)
description: Backstage at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on a recent Saturday night, Garrison Keillor, the humorist, looked somber. It was hard to see why.

title: Debt and Stock Agreement Advances Bid for Penrod
description: An investor group that includes Richard E. Rainwater, the Fort Worth financier, today took what appeared to be a final step toward completing its bid for control of the Penrod Drilling Company by agreeing to acquire 31.3 percent of Penrod's debt and equity held by four banks.

title: John Jay's Chief to Accede To Some Student Demands
description: Under pressure from students occupying a campus building, the president of John Jay College of Criminal Justice said yesterday that he would accede to some of their demands, including granting tenure to a popular Hispanic professor.

title: Lebanese Offers to Quit if Church Asks Him
description: Gen. Michel Aoun, who says he is the leader of Lebanon's only legitimate government, has reportedly offered to step aside if asked to do so by the head of his Maronite Catholic Church, newspapers here have reported.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Air and Water Technologies Corp., Branchburg, N.J., an environmental treatment and services company, said Compagnie Generale des Eaux, France, would purchase $100 million of Air and Water Class A common stock in a private placement.

title: Article 978090 -- No Title
description: A company has agreed to pay $3.5 million in back pay to female employees ''who were steered into traditionally female jobs when they were hired,'' the Labor Department announced today.

title: Vehicle Sales Off 8.7% In First 10 Days of May
description: A seasonal sales increase expected by automobile makers and dealers has still not materialized, with sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks falling by 8.7 percent in early May.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-12

title: Mr. Bush, the Wagon's Leaving
description: During the march from Selma to Montgomery, the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. quoted an old Georgia preacher as saying, ''Them that's going, git on the wagon. Them that ain't, git out of the way.'' Those words from 1965 send a powerful message to President Bush today.

title: U.S. Seeking an Emergency Loan To Help Nicaragua's New Leader
description: The Bush Administration said today that it was seeking to arrange an emergency loan for Nicaragua to help the democratically elected Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro stave off bankruptcy and prevent the country's possible relapse into civil war.

title:
EDUCATION;

Preschool Program in New York City Is Reported to Surpass Head Start
description: LEAD: To Rodney Williams, 4 years old, the Project Giant Step preschool class at P.S. 154 in Harlem is a much-anticipated part of his weekday routine. While concocting a make-believe birthday cake in the sandbox, Rodney said that school is ''excellent'' and that he is looking forward to kindergarten in the fall.

title: S.I. Picks Republican To Fill a Council Seat
description: Staten Island voters elected Alfred C. Cerullo 3d to the City Council yesterday from a field of seven candidates in a special election.

title: The Pop Life
description: Jazzman From Moscow

title: Warnaco Unit Gets Buyout Deal
description: Warnaco Inc., one of the largest brand name apparel companies, announced yesterday that its management would buy out the company's Activewear division for $85 million.

title: Asbestos Trust Fund Of Manville Queried
description: Two judges supervising hundreds of asbestos-damage cases said yesterday that they might seek to reopen the bankruptcy proceeding of the Manville Corporation and suggested that the multibillion-dollar trust set up by the company to compensate victims of asbestos-related diseases had been mismanaged.

title: History Bleached at State
description: It's hardly a secret that the Central Intelligence Agency helped arrange the 1953 coup in Iran that restored the Shah to his Peacock Throne. When the deed was done, His Imperial Majesty offered this toast to Kermit Roosevelt, then head of the C.I.A.'s Middle East operations: ''I owe my throne to God, my people, my army - and to you!'' The tale is told in Mr. Roosevelt's memoir, ''Countercoup,'' published in 1979 and widely available.

title: Dolls That Carried the News of Fashion
description: It was March 1945, the war against Germany dragged on and everything was in short supply. But with France already liberated, Paris found an ingenious way of proclaiming that it was still the world capital of fashion.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Travel Related Services Co., New York, a subsidiary of American Express Co., named James M. Li executive vice president and chief quality and credit officer. American Express named Stephen Friedman president of Travel Related Services for Japan and East Asia, and Alberto Modolo president of Travel Related Services for Australia, the South Pacific and South Asia.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've got a Department of Environmental Conservation that gives out a lot of advice on the outer atmosphere and the Brazilian rain forest - why can't they get the PCB's off the river in Glens Falls?''

title: Judge Limits U.S. Drug Tests
description: A Federal judge today declared mandatory drug tests for lawyers applying to work in the Justice Department's antitrust division to be unconstitutional.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Visual Beauty Is Transcendent In Two Films at Cannes Festival
description: This year's Cannes International Film Festival has entered its pretty phase, with two outstandingly lovely-looking major selections. Both ''Night Sun,'' which brings the visual style of the brothers Paolo and Vittorio Taviani to bear upon a story by Tolstoy, and ''Daddy Nostalgie,'' Bertrand Tavernier's loving look at the last days spent together by a daughter and her dying father, are elegant and supremely romantic visual achievements. Both these films are also certain to find their way to American audiences, very possibly as part of the New York Film Festival this fall.

title: Racist Theories Compromise Teaching Ability;   A Social Purpose
description: To the Editor:

title: Lane Requires 3 to a Car (And Getting Used to It)
description: First Arthur Field pleaded ignorance. Then he told the state trooper who had pulled him over that he had taken a wrong turn. ''I'm not sure where I am,'' he said.

title: Article 985390 -- No Title
description: Vincent van Gogh's haunting ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' completed six weeks before the artist's suicide in 1890, was bought last night for $82.5 million by Hideto Kobayashi of the Gallery Kobayashi of Tokyo in a sale at Christie's in New York. The price was the highest ever paid for an artwork purchased at an auction house.

title: Review/Dance;   Ballet Theater Welcomes Back A Pair of Longtime Bolshoi Stars
description: Yekaterina Maksimova and Vladimir Vasiliev burst upon New York City in 1959, the greatest of the passionate young dancers who, with Moscow's more established stars, made the Bolshoi Ballet's American debut a total triumph.

title: Sikhs Slay 6 in North India
description: Sikh militants impersonating Government security troops shot and killed seven Hindus after luring them out of their homes in the northern state of Punjab, the police said today. The killings occurred late Monday in Darrowali, 42 miles north of the Sikh holy city of Amritsar.

title: Real Estate;   Japanese Help Fill Trade Center
description: ''THANK heavens for the Japanese!'' George Rossi exclaimed. They are making the office leasing numbers look respectable at the World Trade Center.

title: DIALOGUE: How to Shrink the Deficit;   The Budget Summit: Don't Raise Taxes
description: The brazen cry to raise taxes in 1990 has to be the most shameless assault on Americans' pocketbooks in this century.

title: Women Lauded at Barnard
description: Gov. Madeleine M. Kunin of Vermont told Barnard College's graduating class yesterday that women are, as never before, poised to play a greater role in world politics, the environment and the economy.

title: Review/Music;   Minimalist River's Source Appears With New Group
description: Both physically and spiritually, Terry Riley epitomizes a protected Northern California innocence that seems to have long fled the rest of the country. But last week he was much in evidence in the heart of tough, urban sophistication, New York City.

title: Chrysler Executive Joins Black & Decker
description: Michael N. Hammes is moving from the Chrysler Corporation to the Black & Decker Corporation, where he will be executive vice president and president of its power tools group, the No. 2 post in the organization.

title: The Return Of Perrier Is Noted, Sort of
description: PERRIER, long the king of bubbly water, is back on the market. But customers are not flocking to the green pear-shaped bottles like so many subjects to a returning monarch.

title: Corrections
description: A map accompanying an article yesterday about plans for the Hudson River waterfront incorrectly located the areas where real estate development would be banned. A corrective map appears on page B4.

title: Foreign Passports Tell of a Desperate Hong Kong
description: The term ''pregnancy leave'' is taking on a new meaning here, as shown by a successful Hong Kong Chinese banker who is negotiating an unusual sweetener before he takes a new job. He wants his employer to pay to send his pregnant wife to Canada to give birth, insuring that their child will be born a Canadian citizen.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an obituary and a headline yesterday about Andrei P. Kirilenko, a former member of the Soviet Politburo, misstated his age. He was 83.

title: New York State Pollution Bonds
description: A $166.5 million bond offering by the New York State Environmental Facilities Corporation was tentatively priced yesterday to yield a maximum of about 7.719 percent for bonds due in 2012.

title: Ciba-Geigy Unit
description: Ciba-Geigy Ltd. of Switzerland said it had agreed to sell its Spectra-Physics subsidiary to Pharos A.B. of Sweden for an undisclosed amount. Spectra-Physics, which makes lasers and laser systems, had sales of $324 million in 1989. Ciba-Geigy said it expects to continue cooperative business arrangements with Spectra-Physics in the chemistry field.

title: Lionel to Ketchum
description: Lionel Leisure Inc., the toy retailer, has awarded Ketchum Advertising in Philadelphia the creative portion of the accounts for its Lionel Kiddie City and Lionel Playworld. Ketchum replaces LevLane Advertising, Bala-Cynwyd, Pa. Lee Media will continue to do the media buying for the accounts, which have a broadcast budget of $6 million to $8 million.

title: ITT Officer, Moving Up, Seen as Next President
description: The ITT Corporation yesterday named Dale R. Comey, an executive at its insurance unit, as an executive vice president of the corporation, and a company official said that he had been identified as ITT's next president.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Excerpts From Rehnquist Speech Urging Curb on Death Penalty Appeals
description: Following are excerpts from Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist's speech to the American Law Institute today on death penalty appeals:

title: Evolution in Europe;   Kohl in a Hurry
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's new interest in moving up German unification seems based largely on the perception that his election chances could be hurt if he waits too long.

title: People
description: * W. Dillaway Ayres Jr. has joined the investment banking firm of Veronis, Suhler & Associates Inc. as senior vice president concentrating on the broadcasting field.

title: Littler Elected to Hall
description: Gene Littler, the 1961 United States Open champion and seven-time Ryder Cup team member, and three others have been elected to the PGA World Golf Hall of Fame in Pinehurst, N.C., and will be inducted on Nov. 3.

title: DIALOGUE: How to Shrink the Deficit;   The Budget Summit: Cut Spending, Raise Taxes
description: The President and leaders of Congress have a splendid opportunity this week to enhance their political popularity. If they can agree on a credible plan for eliminating the Federal deficit over the next several years, they can strengthen the economy, restore faith in the democratic process and prove cynics wrong.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Evolution in Europe;   Gorbachev's Surprise: An Extra Day for Tours, and Breakfast With Reagan
description: The White House disclosed a public schedule today for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to the United States that made it clear that the Soviet leader has seized control of his itinerary in a manner befitting the master showman of international politics.

title: Corrections
description: The Washington Talk column on Friday about the emergence of Barbara Bush as a political symbol mistated the positions of two top Bush Administration officials on gun control. Vice President Quayle and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, both oppose gun control.

title: Book Notes
description: Mandela's Memoirs

title: After 15 Years, Hudson Still Has PCB's
description: Nearly 15 years after New York State determined that PCB sludge in the Hudson River represented a health hazard, it has made almost no progress in cleaning up the toxic mess.

title: 2,000 Attend Rally
description: About 2,000 people gathered in Union Square Park in Manhattan yesterday afternoon to hear writers, actors, politicians and others call for legislation to extend the life of the National Endowment for the Arts without any restrictions on its grant-giving policies.

title: A Creative Partnership Survives
description: OF the thousands of creative partnerships in advertising agencies large and small, perhaps none is stronger than the one that bonds Charlie Moss and Stan Dragoti. It has survived Mr. Moss's ascension to agency leadership; he is now the vice chairman and corporate creative director of Wells, Rich, Greene Inc. It has triumphed over Mr. Dragoti's Hollywood success as the director of ''Mr. Mom,'' ''Love at First Bite'' and other films.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: JUST as thin-crusted pizzas were a hot snack of the '80s, satays - the grilled meat, fish or vegetables so common in Asia - may be a snack of the '90s. At least Rick and Ann Yoder, owners of the Wild Ginger, an Asian restaurant that opened here last July, hope so.

title: J. Francis Canny, 77, An Executive Recruiter
description: J. Francis Canny, an executive recruiter, died of lung cancer on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: Waite Said to Recover in Lebanese Captivity
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury's special envoy, Terry Waite, is alive and well after 40 months as a hostage in Lebanon and has recovered from a recent illness, people with connections to militants in Lebanon said today.

title: Dow Rises Slightly, to a High of 2,822.45
description: The Dow Jones industrial average seesawed throughout the session yesterday, ending with a small gain and breaking through to another high at 2,822.45.

title: Dropout Plans Not Working, Study Finds
description: New York City schools spent more than $120 million in the last four years to prevent students from dropping out, but most of the participants did not improve their attendance or their academic work, a major new study says.

title: Insiders of the Outer
description: Plans are afoot for building another beltway around Washington. It would lie outside the present beltway, so, naturally, it is already being called ''the outer beltway.''

title: Mondello Jury Cites Stalemate On Some Counts
description: For the second time in a week of deliberations in the Bensonhurst case, the jury considering the charges against Keith Mondello told the judge that it was deadlocked on some of the charges.

title: GUERRILLAS RESIST AFGHAN VOTE PLAN
description: Having failed to oust the Soviet-backed Government in Kabul more than a year after Moscow withdrew its troops, Afghan guerrilla groups are resisting proposals that the war be settled in internationally supervised elections.

title: STRIKES TESTING CHAMORRO'S RULE
description: Striking civil servants loyal to the opposition Sandinista Front ignored a Government ultimatum ordering them to return to work by 9 A.M. today, confronting the new and impoverished Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro with its first serious political crisis.

title: U.S. Issues Dip in Quiet Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in quiet trading yesterday, as dealers took profits after the recent strong rally.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Links to the Vatican Restored by Romania
description: The Vatican and Romania today re-established diplomatic relations that were broken by the former hard-line Communist Government 40 years ago.

title: News Corp. Profit Plunges
description: The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's media empire, reported today that net profit dropped 74 percent, to $93 million for the first nine months of the current fiscal year from $384.8 million in the period a year earlier.

title: REHNQUIST URGES CURB ON APPEALS OF DEATH PENALTY
description: Declaring that the system for handling death penalty appeals in the Federal courts ''verges on the chaotic,'' Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist today issued his most direct call for passage of a bill to place strict new limits on appeals by death row prisoners.

title: Novel Program for the Jobless Aims to Create Entrepreneurs
description: What if the Government gave people who lost their jobs their half-year of unemployment benefits all at once, in one check, to start a business?

title: For Bush, Christmas All Year
description: In his first year in office, President Bush received 83 caps, 66 golf balls, 51 neckties, 36 shirts, 25 books about the Constitution, 13 pairs of cowboy boots, 9 Mickey and Minnie Mouse dolls, 6 fishing rods, 3 tins of caviar and 2 ''We the People'' cufflinks. The Gorbachevs gave him a box of Christmas tree ornaments.

title: The Race to Develop the Pocket Telephone
description: Several obstacles remain before wireless telephone systems now in development can replace cellular and wired services. Among them is finding a place on the increasingly busy end of the radio-wave spectrum that these systems plan to exploit.

title: California Amplifier reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss Prior 12 month results included a gain of $221,000, or 6 cents a share, from the settlement of certain debt.

Quebecor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $62,622,000 on the issuance of capital stock by Quebecor Printing Inc. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,272,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.
