Commonwealth Mortgage of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Great Oaks Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Expanding Services in Marketing
description: BACKER SPIELVOGEL BATES WORLDWIDE is likely to become the next large advertising agency to create a comprehensive program to coordinate various forms of marketing communications for its clients, says a vice chairman of the agency.

title: Evora Journal;   On Portuguese Farms, a Leftist Dream Withers
description: The surviving farming cooperatives still carry combative names like Popular Resistance and Victory for the People. And out of loyalty to the only party that ever supported their movement, to this day their members vote solidly Communist.

title: Salvador Opens Peace Talks With Guerrillas
description: Peace talks between the Government of President Alfredo Cristiani and leftist rebels began in Venezuela today amid a sharp increase in tensions and growing political uncertainty here.

title: Tribune/Swab-Fox Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Biotechnica International Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: TV Project Is Set Up In Europe
description: Thomson S.A., the French electronics group, and Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics company, have agreed to work together in a $3.6 billion effort to develop a European system of high-definition television.

title: An Invitation to Tea Sets
description: TEAPOTS that resemble trumpets, Gothic spires or guards at Buckingham Palace are in ''Spirit of Europe,'' an exhibition of tea sets designed by students at Parsons School of Design. The exhibition, the result of a design competition sponsored by Villeroy & Boch, a German manufacturer of ceramics, is at the company's store at 974 Madison Avenue (76th Street).

title: Global Natural Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jordan and Bulls Have a Date With Pistons
description: When Michael Jordan plays the way he did tonight, he needs only a little assistance. Scottie Pippen provided more than enough. Jordan (37 points) and Pippen (29 points) led the Chicago Bulls to a series-clinching, 117-99 victory over the Philadelphia 76ers at Chicago Stadium. By winning the four-of-seven-game series by four games to one, Chicago advanced to the Eastern Conference final for the second consecutive season. In that four-of-seven-game series, the Bulls will meet the Pistons, beginning Sunday afternoon in Auburn Hills, Mich.

title: A Video Made Just for the Diaper Set
description: LEAD: As Dr. Marshall Haith sees it, the market for his videotape for children is the under 12 set - under 12 months, that is. The half-hour ''Early Images'' video has been likened to a picture book for television or a dynamic mobile. It combines pictures and sounds attractive to infants in 27 vignettes that are designed to stimulate their sensory abilities.

title: 2 Charged in Export Case
description: Two American computer industry executives have been arrested on charges that they intended to export to Bulgaria an advanced supercomputer, Customs officials said today. The suspects, identified as Robert Wheeler, 44, president of American Technology Group Ltd. of San Francisco, and Nick Spiliotis, 44, president of C.I.D. Corp. of Long Beach, Calif., will be charged with violating the Export Administration Act.

title: Two Jews Are Said to Admit Desecrating Graves in Israel
description: Two Jewish followers of a Messianic cult have admitted desecrating 250 Jewish graves in Haifa, Israeli radio said today.

title: Associates Buying A Unit of Mellon
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation has agreed to sell its consumer finance subsidiary to the Associates Corporation of North America, the companies said. Mellon said the sale of the Mellon Financial Services Corporation, based in Oakbrook Terrace, Ill., would result in a one-time, after-tax gain of about $75 million. Mellon said it would retain about $90 million in commercial finance loans. The transaction, subject to regulatory approval, is expected to close by June 30.

title: Arts Endowment Backers Are Split on Strategy
description: Congressional supporters of the National Endowment for the Arts are divided over whether to seek a one-year or a five-year reauthorization for the agency.

title: McGwire's Clutch Hit Wins for A's
description: Mark McGwire hit a two-out, two-run home run in the ninth, the first homer by a right-handed hitter against Doug Jones since 1987, as the Oakland Athletics beat the Cleveland Indians, 7-6, and ended a four-game losing streak.

title: A Connecticut G.O.P. Leader Backs Weicker
description: A Republican candidate for governor, State Senator Reginald J. Smith, said today that he would drop his candidacy and turn his back on his party as well by throwing his support to Lowell P. Weicker Jr., a former Republican and a former United States Senator who is running as an independent.

title: Addington Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $17.9 million from the sale of a gold mining subsidiary.

title: Leeco Diagnostics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: The Blooms That Don't Stoop to Boast
description: THE middle of May is the time of the greatest profusion of bloom in my garden. Spring is at its peak. The dominant color, besides the fresh new tide of greens of the lawn and the shrubbery border, is white.

title: PSYCHIATRISTS UNDER PRESSURE: A SPECIAL REPORT:   HEALTH;   New Paths to Mental Health Put Strains on Some Healers
description: Many psychiatrists say they are seeing fewer patients and drawing less satisfaction from their work than ever before. Some are leaving the profession or moving to areas where the competition for patients is less fierce. And the number of newcomers to the profession is dwindling.

title: Review/Music;   Isley Without Brothers
description: Ernie Isley's show at the Bottom Line on Friday night found a man unsure of his strengths. Mr. Isley, the longtime guitarist for the Isley Brothers and a stage veteran, has recently released his first album, and the responsibilities of leading a band, singing and playing all at the same time seemed to rattle him a touch. At times, he looked scared of the microphone. And though he is known as a guitarist, he is a better singer and songwriter, writing decently literate songs that compartmentalize beautiful melody after melody. But instead of concentrating on the song forms, he often let his tunes become vehicles for long solos that quickly became indistinguishable in their flood of notes.

title: Dow Off 2.77, to 2,819.68, on Profit Taking
description: Stocks fell yesterday in continued profit taking although they hit another new high during the session after two days of record closing prices.

title: New Brunswick Scientific reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Baltimore Bancorp, Baltimore, a bank holding company, said it had rejected the takeover offer of $217 million by Allied Irish Bank and its First Maryland Bancorp subsidiary.

title: With Condos on Their Hands, Builders Turn to Auctioneers
description: The bidding had reached $247,000, and Steven Good - natty as a banker, with a red rosebud boutonniere -raised his gavel and put a little more pitch into his patter.

title: Savannah Foods & Indus reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Some Classes Resume at John Jay College
description: The John Jay College of Criminal Justice resumed some of its classes without incident yesterday despite the continued occupation of a building by protesters.

description: * Cray Research Inc., Minneapolis, the computer company, named Franklin J. Parisi vice president of corporate communications.

title: Resorts International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its loss from operations for the 1990 quarter was $21,000, compared to earnings from operations of $6,582,000 in the year- ago period. Resorts and its subsidiaries did not accrue interest on their public debt during the latest quarter. Resorts' subsidiary, Griffin Resorts Inc., earned $2,099,000 in the 1990 quarter, compared to $5,153,000 in 1989, on operating revenues of $50,050,000 and $50,475,000 for 1990 and 1989, respectively. Resorts said 1990 operating earnings were $5,818,000 compared to $9,075,000 in the year-ago quarter.

title: Harvey Oxenhorn, 38, Kennedy School Aide
description: Harvey Oxenhorn, director of the public policy communications program at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University, died in an automobile accident Saturday in Hillsdale, N.Y. He was 38 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: Counsel Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Personal Health
description: An attempt the other day to plug in a new portable telephone gave me quite a shock, figuratively and almost literally. Having chosen my sons' bedside table as the most convenient location, I looked behind it to find a tangled mass of wires resembling the spaghetti I had just eaten for lunch.

title: Events: Walks Through Time
description: A Walk Through Time, Flatbush Dutch Reformed Church, Flatbush and Church Avenues, Brooklyn; 718-856-3700.

title: Magazine Circulation Rules Altered
description: At the urging of advertisers who want more precise knowledge of who is reading what, the Audit Bureau of Circulations said yesterday that it would audit the circulation of many magazines that do not charge for subscriptions.

title: Nasdaq System Drops a Stock
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers said yesterday that it had decided to drop the stock of Southland Communications Inc. from the Nasdaq system, effective today.

title: Review/Pop;   Frank Sinatra Opens and Then Cancels
description: Frank Sinatra has never been a performer one could describe as mellow, but on Tuesday evening at the opening night of his sold-out shows at Radio City Music Hall he seemed to be in an unusually good mood. Though he said nothing during the concert about the failing health of his friend Sammy Davis Jr., the remaining four nights of the engagement were canceled after Mr. Davis died yesterday.

title: Reviews/Theater;   A 'Pinhead' in the Hollywood Hills
description: There probably are not that many playwrights who have both written television shows for Norman Lear and participated in a screenwriting workshop with Gabriel Garcia Marquez, but such is the resume of Jose Rivera, whose new play, ''Each Day Dies With Sleep,'' is now at the Circle Repertory Company. The influence of both mentors is apparent in this work, in which glib ethnic comedy battles to a standoff with the metaphorical paraphernalia of magic realism. ''Each Day Dies With Sleep'' is the kind of evening in which the set is decorated with images from Rene Magritte while the characters make wisecracks about Sean Penn.

title: Manufacturer Ordered to Pay for Cleanup
description: New Jersey officials ordered PPG Industries yesterday to pay $31.5 million to clean up 32 residential lots in Jersey City that are contaminated with chromium.

title: New Fears on Chemicals and Nervous System
description: Attempts to safeguard the public against toxic chemicals that attack the nervous system have been ineffective, raising concern about the health of millions of Americans, Congressional researchers said today.

title: Teva Pharmaceutical reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are reported in new Israeli shekels adjusted to the rate of exchange at March 31, 1990: $1.00 equals 1.9940 nis. In U.S. dollars, the company reported first quarter net income of $4,925,000, or 22 cents an ADR, on sales of $70,476,000.

title: Acmat Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Star, a Survivor
description: A middle-aged man, on hearing recently that Sammy Davis Jr. was near death, remarked, ''I can't imagine a world without Sammy Davis in it.'' Many other Americans, even if they were no particular fans of the entertainer, probably feel the same way, and for humane as well as theatrical reasons.

description: Under conventional circumstances Cotton Fitzsimmons would duck the question; the coaching mentality would not allow him to deliver a straight answer.

These revenues have been offset against operating expenses and the resulting operating income of $987,000 for the three months and $3,887,000 for the 6 months, has been credited to the reserve for any closing costs which may be incurred.

description: Dave Winfield spent what he called ''nine good years'' with the Yankees, but he now belongs to the California Angels.

description: It's been 20 years since the May 4 incident, as it is called today by a student tour guide at Kent State University. To many, May 4, 1970, is still vivid.

description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev will be emulating two of his predecessors, Nikita S. Khrushchev and Leonid I. Brezhnev, when he heads west after his summit meeting with President Bush on May 31 and June 1-2.

description: Pre-share earnings for 1989 are not shown. The company was spun off from the former Zayre Corp. last May.

Investment Banks' Ties To Pretoria Draw Fire
description: Some of America's biggest investment banks, vying for lucrative contracts to handle New York City's bond issues, now find themselves embroiled in disputes about ties to South Africa. The bankers' predicament is the result of a curious blend of Wall Street rivalries and racial politics that is increasingly a feature of public finance in American cities.

title: Vaccine for Plants May Reduce Need for Pesticides
description: A kind of vaccine that protects plants against pests can reduce reliance on hazardous pesticides, the developer of the vaccine says.

title: Maxwell Buys 3 Tabloids
description: Robert Maxwell, the chairman and chief executive of the Mirror Group P.L.C., said yesterday that his British publishing company would acquire three tabloid newspapers from Globe International Publishing for an undisclosed sum.

title: Cable TV Vote Clouds Outlook For Franchisees
description: The outlook for the cable television franchises in Manhattan remains unclear after the Board of Estimate voted on Tuesday night to deny renewals preliminarily.

title: Jean Childress Lee; Statistician, 50
description: Jean Childress Lee, the director of biostatistics for the New York City Department of Health, died of cancer on Monday at Beth Israel Hospice in Manhattan. She was 50 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Growth Seen in Ireland
description: Ireland's economy seems ready to grow much more quickly in the next 10 years, helped by lower inflation and a decline in emigration, a leading independent study group said today. The country's 3.5 million people could look forward to an annual economic growth rate of 4 percent throughout the 1990's compared with an average 1.5 percent in the 1980's, the Economic and Social Research Institute said in its latest report. It forecast a decline in inflation from 4 percent to 2.5 percent. Ireland has one of the highest unemployment rates in the European Community, with almost one in five out of work.

title: To Gorbachev Anxieties, Add Yeltsin Candidacy
description: With several republics tugging loose around the periphery of the Soviet Union, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev faced a strong challenge today in the heartland of his domain - the vast, rich, and angry republic of Russia.

description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $98,000, or 2 cents a share and $113,000, or 2 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Hewlett-Packard reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Latest figures included the results of Apollo Computer, acquired in May 1989.

title: BUSH PRESSES CASE FOR MANAGUA AID
description: Trying to force Congress's hand on aid to Panama and Nicaragua, President Bush said today that delayed action on a relief package compelled him to reject an emergency loan to Nicaragua. He demanded that lawmakers approve the aid before taking a Memorial Day holiday next week.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: U.S. and Soviets Begin Task Of Shaping Arms Accords
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union today began trying to overcome obstacles blocking arms control agreements, but the increasingly unstable situation in the Baltic republics threatened to derail their efforts.

title: Consumer Prices Up By 0.2%
description: In a report that largely dispelled fears of accelerating inflation, the Labor Department said today that consumer prices climbed a modest two-tenths of 1 percent last month, the smallest increase since September.

title: Panel Says Democratizing of East Spells End to Radio Free Europe
description: The United States should begin planning now to end broadcasts by Radio Free Europe because the goal of democratic change in Eastern Europe is being achieved, a bipartisan advisory panel said today.

title: A Prize in a Literary Garden
description: IN the rosy light of a spring morning, sheep graze in the new fallen snow in a deserted mountainous region of old mines. Below in the Elan Valley along the banks of a river, one garden is covered with drifts of daffodils, and the yew topiary is beginning to sprout new shoots of pale green.

title: Black Customers, Korean Grocers: Need and Mistrust;   Shoppers Complain Of Hostile Treatment, But Choices Are Few
description: Three times last year, Jacqueline Lewis says, she was accused of stealing by different Korean market owners, who also leveled insults.

title: Playboy to Clothe Nude
description: Playboy Enterprises Inc., whose stock certificates have been graced with the nude image of the February 1971 Playmate since the company went public in 1971, said this week that it would replace the nude figure with a clothed one in a recapitalization plan announced last week. A spokeswoman, Terri Tomcisin, said Playboy has 14,000 single-share stockholders, many of whom bought the one share just to get the racy certificate. It costs the company $100,000 annually to service the accounts of those shareholders. Playboy hopes to reduce that expense by issuing a certificate that is less likely to encourage novelty purchases.

title: Mayor, Media, Mongers
description: Day after day, this great city, this treasury of talent and art, commerce and creativity, this particular civilization built by every race and religion on God's earth, this triumph of American freedom and opportunity, this New York, is being vilified, crucified and humiliated before the entire world, and by its own people.

title: 2 Charged in a Smuggling Scheme
description: Two California men have been arrested and charged with trying to smuggle a powerful supercomputer to Bulgaria, the Customs Service said today.

title: April Housing Construction Off 5.8%
description: Construction of new homes unexpectedly dropped for a third straight month in April to the lowest levels since the 1982 recession, the Commerce Department said today.

According to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, between April 9 and May 11, Mr. Posner bought 141,700 additional Tally shares on the open market for $8.625 to $10.25 each.

title: Pryor Bout Allowed After State Cancels It
description: Aaron Pryor's return to boxing, which sparked outrage because Pryor is legally blind in one eye, was called off by the state of Wisconsin yesterday and then reinstated within hours by a county judge. Judge John Ahlgrimm of Dane County Reserve Circuit Court said the state had abused its discretion by canceling the fight, against Daryl Jones, on the day it was scheduled.

title: Review/Recital;   A Full Program for Piano
description: Walid Howrani, a pianist born in New York, raised in Beirut and trained in Moscow, showed no lack of ambition in his program at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday evening. He offered three substantial sonatas in the first half, a set of Chopin and a sizable work by Liszt in the second.

The company said net results do not take into account about $106 million in unrealized gains in its investment portfolio.

description: As legislators in recent weeks have contemplated passing the toughest assault-rifle law in the nation, they have seen the sidewalks around the state Capitol flooded by legions of enraged gun-rights advocates, some in combat fatigues.

Yet rather than settle for a 5 percent cut here or a $700 million adjustment there, they need to take a new look at foreign aid, which is still addressing cold war concerns.

title: Review/Music;   The Bottom Line in Tune
description: Observers of William Schuman's career look at his history as a publishing executive, school administrator, teacher, consultant and public speaker and wonder how he ever found time to compose. He did and in many forms. Mr. Schuman's choral music, for example, easily filled a program at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday night. The New York Virtuoso Singers under Harold Rosenbaum were celebrating the American composer's 80th birthday with settings of Walt Whitman, everyday homilies and the 1897 Sears, Roebuck & Company catalogue.

Memorial for Mumford
description: A memorial for Lewis Mumford, the philosopher and critic, will be held at 11 A.M. on Sunday at the chapel of the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Conn. The speakers at the service, sponsored by the E. F. Schumacher Society Library of Great Barrington, Mass., will include Ian McHarg, retired head of the department of regional planning at the University of Pennsylvania; Alison Mumford Morss, Mr. Mumford's daughter, and the writers Brendan Gill, Russell Lynes and Kirkpatrick Sale. Mr. Mumford died on Jan. 26 at the age of 94.

title: Large Soviet Crop Seen
description: Weather conditions are favorable for a bumper grain crop in the Soviet Union this year, the Agriculture Department said last week. It put the 1990 Soviet crop at 215 million metric tons, up from 211.1 million last year. It would be the largest Soviet harvest since a record 237.4 million tons in 1978. Officials said the forecast consisted of 95 million tons of wheat, 106.5 million tons of coarse grains like barley and sorghum, and 13.5 million tons of miscellaneous grains.

description: A senior Justice Department lawyer has found that no one in the department should be disciplined for disclosure of information last year that resulted in a damaging report about a powerful Congressman.

title: Children's Commission Looks at Middle Years
description: LEAD: When the National Commission on Children visits the Helene Grant Elementary School in New Haven on Monday, the commissioners will hear from experts, some only 9 years old, on issues that are important to children ages 6 to 12.

title: An Aggressive Infection, Abrupt and Overwhelming
description: The bacterial infection that killed Jim Henson was an especially aggressive type of pneumonia known as streptococcus pneumonia group A. Dr. David Gelmont, director of the medical intensive care unit at New York Hospital, who treated Mr. Henson, described the infection as ''abrupt and potentially overwhelming.'' He said that death from the bacteria is neither common nor rare, and that the outcome might have been different if Mr. Henson had been hospitallized only eight hours earlier.

title: Burger King Investors Master L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: For entrepreneurs in Poland, Robert G. Faris is a man who may help to make dreams come true. The venture capitalist has been named president and chief executive of the Polish American Enterprise Fund, and will be in charge of handing out American dollars to promote free enterprise in Poland.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Food Notes column yesterday about the International Association of Cooking Professionals' awards for food and beverage books misidentified last year's grand prize winner. It was ''The Cake Bible,'' by Rose Levy Beranbaum (Morrow, 1988).

title: Review/Dance;   A Golden Boy's Energetic New Troupe
description: David Parsons may not walk on water. But he does walk on air - or so it seems in ''Caught,'' a now-celebrated dance solo in which a strobe light catches him in suspension before blinking off and going on to the next three-dimensional still.

description: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: A Smorgasbord for Furniture Shoppers
description: EVEN for IKEA, the giant Swedish supermarket of home furnishings, these are pretty big doings. Next Wednesday at 9 A.M., the company will finally open its doors to customers in the New York metropolitan area with a new 270,000-square-foot store - that's 6.2 acres - on the flatlands of Elizabeth, N.J., just off exit 13A of the New Jersey Turnpike. It has also planned a press preview tonight, and a blitz of television and print advertising.

title: Corning Increases Its Stake in Unilab
description: A unit of Corning Inc. has raised its stake in the Unilab Corporation to the equivalent of 26.3 percent, from 20.9 percent, and said it might seek control of the New York-based clinical laboratory group. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Corning, the specialty glass manufacturer based in Corning, N.Y., said the shares were bought by Metpath Inc., a subsidiary that also owns and operates clinical testing labs.

description: The combined production of red meat and poultry is expected to increase about 2 percent this year, because of a 7 percent increase in the output of broilers and turkeys, the Agriculture Department said on Tuesday. But red meat production is expected to decline 1 percent from last year.

title: Sammy Davis Jr. Dies at 64; Top Showman Broke Barriers
description: Sammy Davis Jr., a versatile and dynamic singer, dancer and actor who overcame extraordinary obstacles to become a leading American entertainer, died of throat cancer yesterday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 64 years old and had been in deteriorating health since his release from Cedar-Sinai Medical Center on March 13.

title: Soldier Dies in London Blast Outside a Recruiting Office
description: A British soldier was killed and another was seriously wounded today when an explosion destroyed their vehicle outside an army recruiting office in northwest London, the police said.

description: Thousands of Christians fleeing the factional fighting have caused an economic boom and a housing shortage in Muslim West Beirut, moving into seaside hotels, relocating their businesses, and adding to the already runaway inflation rate.

It was only the minor Gold Stage Stakes and the race yesterday had no appeal at all to bettors, but it was an occasion: the return of Easy Goer.

description: Five months after the only violent revolution in Eastern Europe, Romania heads into its first free elections on May 20 with only a tenuous hold on its newly won freedoms, facing a future that looks almost menacing.

description: The latest revenues included underwriting premium revenues of $3,186,000 in revenues from FEIC. Year-ago revenues does not include any underwriting premium revenues or underwriting earnings due to the open year deposit method in use in 1989 at FEIC.

title: Vermont City Loses Bid to Tax Use of Its Airspace
description: A city's novel attempt to tax the use of its airspace by jets taking off and landing at a nearby airport has failed in the Vermont Supreme Court, although the justices did call the effort imaginative.

title: Another Dodger Rhubarb in Brooklyn
description: On Sept. 24, 1957, as the loudspeaker blared a song rhyming ''Dem Bums'' with ''hits and runs,'' the Brooklyn Dodgers' fans filed out of Ebbets Field for the last time. Two weeks later Walter F. O'Malley announced that he was moving his team to Los Angeles and became the most hated man in Brooklyn.

title: Cautious Bush Says Urgency of Deficit Impelled Him to Seek Talks
description: In his first public explanation of why he initiated budget negotiations with Congress, President Bush said today that the deficit problem had become ''urgent enough'' that it needed to be addressed now, while the economy was reasonably strong.

title: A SKULL MAY LINK REPTILES TO MAN
description: Scrutiny of a 260-million-year-old skull has convinced scientists at the University of Toronto that a reptile about the size of a modern cat was probably a great-granduncle of the human race.

title: New York City Is Seeking to Use M.A.C. Surplus
description: New York City and New York State are negotiating with the Municipal Assistance Corporation to free $1.5 billion in surplus corporation funds to help balance the city's operating budget over the next seven years.

title: Bill Pace; Football Coach
description: Bill Pace, the head football coach at Vanderbilt University from 1966 until 1973, died of a heart attack Monday in Nashville. He was 58 years old.

title: Nazi Data on Hypothermia Termed Unscientific
description: A continuing debate over using Nazi data on hypothermia is moot, a new analysis suggests, because the concentration camp experiments in which the data were obtained were scientifically unsound.

title: Dinkins Expands Housing Plan to Assist the Poor
description: Moving to put his own stamp on New York City's $5.1 billion 12-year housing plan, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that the program would be revised and expanded to provide more housing for lower-income tenants and the homeless.

title: Sea Containers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Sale of ferry assets and containerships generated profit of $233 million. The company has written off against this profit all costs of defending the takeover bid by Temple Holdings Ltd. and has further established a $20 million reserve provision against possible additional expenses arising from the asset sales. c-Net loss Latest quarter share earnings are after preferred dividend payments of $2,810,000 in 1990 and $4,444,000 in 1989. The company said the sale of certain marine container assets to Tiphook PLC will be recorded in this year's second quarter.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: American Stores' Merger Settlement
description: The American Stores Company, California's largest supermarket chain, said it had agreed to sell most of its Alpha Beta stores to settle a state lawsuit challenging its $2.5 billion takeover of Lucky Stores on antitrust grounds. The decision follows a United States Supreme Court ruling last month that allowed California to sue the company to overturn the 1988 merger. American Stores admitted no wrongdoing and portrayed the deal as an effort to avoid any more costly legal battles.

title: National Health Labs reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bid to Keep An Eakins Is Rejected
description: The Modern Art Museum of Fort Worth has rejected an offer of a major painting by Stuart Davis intended as a bargaining chip to keep the museum from selling a masterpiece by Thomas Eakins outside Fort Worth.

title: Do Re Mi Fa Sol La Ti Boom
description: THE $500 Yamaha piano keyboard I have been playing can produce 5,050 different types of sounds with its 61 keys. It can imitate a harpsichord, a guitar, a trumpet, a violin - even a mandolin or a sitar. It can also mimic a racing car, bird calls, ambulance sirens, waves breaking on the sand and glass breaking on land; and it can shout ''Yeah!'' ''Ha!'' and ''Ow!'' on demand. All this, and ''Fur Elise'' too.

title: HOUSE TO DEBATE BILL ON DISABLED
description: The House of Representatives is expected to start debate Thursday on legislation to bar discrimination against the disabled in the workplace and in transportation, public accommodations and telephone services.

description: MICHAEL BONDI has been interviewed by everyone from The London Economist to Australian radio. The reason is the 18-inch forged steel troll he designed last November for the San Francisco Bay Bridge as an amulet to ward off earthquakes.

description: To the Editor:

title: Judge Sued for Barring Filming in Courthouse
description: The Essex County Executive, Nicholas R. Amato, filed suit today in Federal District Court contending that Robert N. Wilentz, New Jersey's Chief Justice, restricted free speech by denying a movie company permission to shoot in the Essex County Courthouse.

title: NEWS SUMMARY

title: Labor Secretary Seeks to Require Workers to Save
description: Labor Secretary Elizabeth Dole moved today to require Americans who change jobs to transfer their pension benefits to a new retirement account rather than spending the cash.

title: Chronicle
description: HERBERT VON KARAJAN cultivated an aloof, autocratic facade on the podium and a jet-set image off, zooming down Alpine slopes and flying his own plane. But in 1955 he wrote love letters, never published, that reveal a more romantic soul.

title: 3,000 Job Cuts At Northrop
description: The Northrop Corporation said today that it would eliminate about 3,000 jobs this year, or about 7 percent of its 41,000-member work force. Included in the cuts are about 500 jobs on the B-2 Stealth bomber program.

title: Rain or Shine, More Texas Flooding Is on the Way
description: It was a tense several minutes here when the truck full of Red Cross workers stalled up to its fenders in water on what used to be a bridge but had become part of the flood-swollen Trinity River.

title: Report Charges Violence Against Arab Children
description: A new and detailed report on the fate of young Palestinians in the revolt in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip challenges official accounts of the uprising and accuses Israeli soldiers of using ''severe, indiscriminate and recurrent'' violence against children.

title: Baker, as Promised in '89, Sold Chemical Bank Stock
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d kept a promise made early last year to sell his holdings in a New York bank and all his other publicly traded stock, a financial disclosure form shows.

title: NASA Might Rescue Satellite
description: The space agency says it will send up a shuttle to rescue a communication satellite left stranded in a uselessly low orbit, provided the satellite's owner pays the mission's cost of at least $130 million.

title: Bridge
description: Four strong squads battled down to the wire in the Cavendish Team Championship Tuesday night, and victory went to Paul Marston, Steve Burgess, both of Australia, Ed Manfield of Hyattsville, Md., and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif. They scored 174 victory points out of a possible 270, and the other placings were: second, Jill Blanchard of Manhattan and team 172; third, John Roberts of Manhattan and team 167; fourth, Kitty Bethe of Manhattan and team 166.

title: Peerless Carpet reports earnings for Year to Feb. 28
description: The company said the earnings decline was expected and was largely due to the consolidation since last June of the results of Galaxy Carpet Mills Inc.

title: Knicks Aim To Give Ewing Help On Offense
description: One-man teams have never won championships in the National Basketball Association. A tired Patrick Ewing had one of his infrequent poor shooting outings Tuesday night against the Pistons, making only one basket in the second half of a closely contested game. As a result, Detroit won, 95-84, and eliminated the Knicks from the playoffs.

title: Facing Stiff New Test, Truckers' Anxiety Rises
description: For more than 30 years Gary Lee Harris drove trucks without a serious accident. This year, at the age of 52, he found himself a student again, studying for a written test that he must pass to keep his job.

description: Kil Jin Kim figures it will take him 10 more years to come up with the money to buy his dream: a citrus farm for himself and his fiancee, the high school sweetheart who has waited back home in South Korea since he moved to New York a decade ago.

They are also paperback books about five wholesome young singers from the Boston area, and three of the books are on the paperback nonfiction best-seller list Three of the 16 titles on the paperback nonfiction best-seller list of The New York Times on Sunday and this coming Sunday are about the group. An earlier book had been a best seller until recently.

title: Chronicle
description: And nearby, at Teachers College Columbia University, medals were awarded for distinguished service to education to SIDNEY ALTMAN and FRED M. HECHINGER. Professor Altman is Nobel laureate in chemistry and the Sterling Professor of Biology at Yale University. He is a former dean of Yale College. Mr. Hechinger, president of The New York Times Company Foundation since 1977, has written about education since 1946. He writes a column on education.

title: Rebozo Is Selling Bank
description: A prominent Panamanian family has bought the Key Biscayne Bank from Charles (Bebe) Rebozo, the confidant of former President Richard M. Nixon, for an unspecified amount. A bank spokesman said on Tuesday that negotiations had not yet been completed between Mr. Rebozo and three trusts held by the Kardonski family of Panama and Miami.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Budget Hurry-Up-and-Wait Helps Forehands, Harms Civility
description: When a Republican Assemblyman shouted ''Heil Hitler!'' at the Democratic Assembly Speaker during an unusual filibuster Tuesday night, the anger and frustration underlying this year's prolonged budget debate erupted into public view.

title: Corrections

title: Chronicle
description: Kudos fluttered onto some of the nation's leading writers, artists and eggheads yesterday when the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters gave out its annual awards. C. VANN WOODWARD and KEVIN ROCHE won gold medals for history and architecture, respectively. PAUL ENGLE, co-founder of the University of Iowa writing program, received an award for distinguished service.

title: Unisys to Market Solbourne Product

The agreement is valued at $150 million over four years. Solbourne, based in Longmont, Colo., manufactures work stations using Sparc technology licensed from Sun Microsystems Inc.

Karen Walden will replace Ms. Bryant as editor in chief of New Woman magazine. In another move, Murdoch's parent, News America Publishing, said it would sell Sportswear International, a fashion industry trade maga-zine to Michael Belluomo, the maga-zine's former editor and publisher.

description: Fallon McElligott took top honors at the Art Directors Club annual Gold and Silver Awards show Tuesday. The agency won 13 awards for clients like Hush Puppies, Jim Beam, Porsche and Rolling Stone magazine, which also won big on the editorial side. Its art director, Fred Woodward, won 17 awards. BBDO led the television category with six awards.

description: The Juan Samuel Syndrome has claimed three teams in less than two seasons. The Philadelphia Phillies and the Mets took the cure by trading Samuel. The Los Angeles Dodgers also used a trade as the attempted antidote, but they didn't trade Samuel; they traded Willie Randolph.

description: Worldwide chip sales will remain flat in 1990 but will then experience annual growth of at least 10 percent until 1993, a trade group reported today.

description: Rosaria McNeil, wife of the Jets running back Freeman McNeil, gave birth to a 7-pound-5-ounce boy at the couple's home on Long Island yesterday. The baby, delivered with the help of a midwife, was named Freeman 4th.

title: Metro Matters;   Moving Beyond The Melting Pot, 25 Years Later
description: The 25th anniversary of the publication of ''Beyond the Melting Pot'' was officially marked this week, 30 years after the seminal study of race and ethnicity in New York City was completed, 27 years after it was published and 20 years since it was revised. The timing could not have been better. For whichever the anniversary, the book's underlying theme seems even more evident today: That, particularly where race is concerned, the melting pot metaphor didn't hold water.

description: Both juries in the Bensonhurst murder case showed signs of the stress from more than a week of deliberations as they recessed last night without reaching verdicts.

Cloud Depth Hides Knicks In New Dawn
description: rrFor more than a decade, the National Basketball Association's sun rose in the Atlantic outside Boston and set in the Pacific outside Los Angeles, without shining much anywhere else. But with the early departures of Larry Bird and now Magic Johnson from the playoffs, a new dawn is breaking. The trouble is, too many clouds hide where the sun will shine.

description: Large numbers of voters turned out today in an election that pitted two octogenarian rivals who have long dominated this country's politics against each other for what many expect will be the last time.

Market Place;   A Japanese Rally Made in the U.S.A.
description: WHEN the Japanese stock market was tumbling in January, February and March, there was concern that the malady would spread to the United States and other world markets. But Japan's problems, for the most part, stayed at home, despite an anemic yen and rising interest rates.

title: C.F.T.C. Is Backed by Dole
description: Bob Dole, the Senate Republican leader, has publicly stated that he does not support the Bush Administration's plan to transfer regulation of stock-index futures from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Strike Ended in Nicaragua; Chamorro Gives Big Raises
description: Government negotiators and striking union leaders announced agreement late tonight on a package of salary increases, job guarantees and other measures to end a weeklong strike by Sandinista-led civil servants that had brought the country's newly elected Government to a virtual standstill.

title: America's Art, Smeared
description: To listen to all the angry commotion surrounding the reauthorization of the National Endowment for the Arts, you'd think the Endowment was in the business of funding smut. That's exactly what some far-right activists would like the American public to think.

title: Franklin Savings Assn.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the increased loss in the third quarter was attributable to accounting adjustments as well as to the continued losses from operations.
