description: The company said net income in the year-ago period was reduced by $20 million, or 16 cents per share, for the discontinuance of an interactive television shopping service.

title: Missile Case Sentencing
description: A former Northrop Corporation factory manager was sentenced today to three years in prison for his role in a conspiracy to supply untested guidance system parts for cruise missiles.

title: The Law
description: Because of news and production requirements, the Law page appears today on page A32 instead of its usual position in the B section.

title: Bush Backing for Kohl
description: President Bush said he and Chancellor Helmut Kohl agreed that once Germany is reunified, it should remain in NATO and the rights of the Allies should be ended. Page A6.

title: Promenade Art Show
description: The 43d semiannual Promenade Art Show, which was rained out last weekend, will be held on Sunday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. on the Brooklyn Heights Promenade. About 100 artists will display and sell paintings, photographs and other artworks and crafts. Prices range from $5 to $5,000. Information: (718) 783-3077.

title: Philip Morris Unit In German Deal
description: Philip Morris G.m.b.H., the West German subsidiary of the Philip Morris Companies, has agreed to acquire the East German cigarette manufacturer VEB Kombinat Tabak. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Ferranti Case Accusations
description: A former executive of a leading British military contractor used a bogus company based in a New York post office box to send shipments of embargoed military arms to South Africa, an F.B.I. agent said on Wednesday.

title: Three Master Piano Men And a Panorama of Styles
description: Every time a rock-and-roll musician puts his fingers to an instrument, history speaks, revealing the complex workings of American culture. This weekend, three pianists who have had a direct influence on the shaping of American music - Allen Toussaint, Harry Van Walls and Dr. John - are making appearances in New York City. And if one listens closely, two things will appear in their playing: the present, in the form of the guidelines for any rock-and-roll pianist, and the past, with all its musical, social and historical connotations.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about Republican candidates for governor in Connecticut misstated former Senator Lowell P. Weicker's party affiliation. Mr. Weicker is running for governor as an independent candidate, but says he is still a member of the Republican Party.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Borden Inc., said it plans to spend $70 million to build two new food processing plants.

title: Review/Dance;   Ballet Theater Performs Tharp Set to Sinatra
description: The Metropolitan Opera House became a dance hall on Tuesday night. A glittering suspended globe - a decoration found in many ballrooms - hung above the stage, casting sparkles of light throughout the auditorium. Beneath it were romantic young couples who looked ready to dance all night.

title: What's in a Name Change On New Thruway Signs?
description: In selecting a governor, New York voters never had to choose between Mario M. Cuomo, a Democrat, and Thomas E. Dewey, a Republican. But the Thruway Authority did, and Mr. Cuomo has won.

title: Chronicle
description: Chief Justice WILLIAM H. REHNQUIST, a longtime history buff, listed a $22,500 advance from William Morrow & Company in his annual financial disclosure statement. When asked about it, the Supreme Court press office said the payment was for a new book Mr. Rehnquist is writing, a history of Chief Justice Salmon P. Chase and the impeachment trial of President Andrew Johnson.

title: Alton Journal;   Volunteers' Pride Turns To Ashes Over Lawsuit
description: The school bus wreck that killed 21 students near this tiny crossroads last September should have cemented a tragic bond between the Alton Volunteer Fire Department and its community.

title: Beijing Journal;   Marxism Died and Left a Big Hole in Their Lives
description: A secular age of faith appears to have collapsed in China, turning into a time of despair and doubt in which many people have no heroes and nothing to believe in.

title: Character Actors Are Taking a Star Turn
description: IN his book ''On Acting,'' Laurence Olivier expressed his admiration for John Gielgud, with direct reference not to his Shakespearean performances but to his stage roles in plays by Harold Pinter and David Storey. ''Today, for me, John has somehow completed the acting circle,'' he wrote. ''He has found his center, he is a brilliant character actor.''

title: Our Towns;   A Plan for Land Vs. 8 Generations Of a Family Farm
description: Since before the American Revolution, Concklins have farmed here. ''Eight generations,'' Richard Concklin said. ''We hope many more.'' The ninth is in the pipeline: Scott, a junior at Cornell agricultural school.

title: NEGOTIATORS SEE A $60 BILLION LIMIT ON CUTS IN DEFICIT
description: White House and Congressional negotiators ended their second day of budget talks today in general consensus that the Federal deficit for the fiscal year that begins next Oct. 1 could not be cut more than $60 billion without tipping the economy into a recession.

title: Cannes and the Sudden Limelight
description: The signs of overnight success at Cannes are unmistakable. Bleary eyes, a hoarse voice and a dazed but happy expression: all these are clear indications that a heretofore undiscovered talent has just been thrust into the international limelight.

title: 12.03 Rise Puts Dow Back on Record Track
description: Stocks resumed their steady advance yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average climbing in heavy trading to its third new high in four days.

title: New Jersey Votes the Strictest Law In the Nation on Assault Weapons
description: Over the protests of gun owners, the New Jersey Legislature today passed the nation's toughest law on assault weapons, banning the sale and restricting ownership of a wide range of semiautomatic guns.

title: TV Weekend;   China's Leader Calls Massacre 'Nothing'
description: It takes a lot to stop Barbara Walters in her tracks. But when Jiang Zemin, China's party leader, declares in an interview to be shown on the ABC News program ''20/20'' tonight that the massacre of hundreds of Chinese in Beijing last June was ''much ado about nothing,'' even she is taken aback.

title: The Top Defenders
description: All that talk about how well the Detroit Pistons play defense was borne out yesterday when two members of the Pistons - Dennis Rodman and Joe Dumars - became 40 percent of the National Basketball Association's all-defensive team for the second straight year.

title: Construction Unit Head Gets No. 2 Job at Turner
description: The Turner Corporation, the nation's largest general builder, said yesterday that it had named Harold J. Parmelee president.

title: Fed Nominee Confirmed
description: The Senate has confirmed President Bush's nomination of David W. Mullins Jr., an Assistant Treasury Secretary, to a seat on the seven-member Federal Reserve Board. Approval came on a voice vote without debate. Mr. Mullins, a 43-year-old former Harvard Business School professor and one of the designers of President Bush's savings and loan industry bailout plan last year, will fill the remaining six years of H. Robert Heller's term on the board.

title: Advertising;   Sara Lee Gives Lintas A $100 Million-Plus Job
description: A week after it was stunned by the loss of the $45 million Eastern Airlines account to Ogilvy & Mather, Lintas USA received cheering news from the Sara Lee Corporation, which consolidated most of its domestic food advertising accounts with Lintas yesterday.

title: Economic Pulse; The Farm Belt;   New Decade Finds New Hope on Farm
description: This is a springtime of renewed hope in the nation's Grain Belt.

title: Evolution in Europe;   East Germany's 'Utopian Socialist' Theology
description: Humboldt University here got a new rector recently, and in the eyes of many East Germans it seems fitting that he is the first theologian to head the institution since 1931.

title: Arts Groups Invited to Capitol Hill
description: The head of the House panel that oversees the National Endowment for the Arts announced today the formation of an advisory group, made up of representatives from major arts organizations, to help resolve the endowment's mandate, structure and future.

title: On Stage
description: One Idea Equals 2 Plays

title: A Promotion At Burger King
description: Robert J. Stetson, the Burger King Corporation's chief financial officer since February 1989, was named the fast food company's chief operating officer today.

title: A.T.&T. Plans to Cut Rates
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it planned to lower its interstate and international rates by about $160 million annually on July 1.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Review/Theater;   The Ties Binding a Man to His Money
description: For Harpagon, the title character in ''The Miser,'' greed is not only good but it is also essential for his well-being. In Mark Lamos's production of the play at Hartford Stage, Gerry Bamman makes it self-evident that the miser is as obsessive as he is egomaniacal, and, in so doing, the actor carries comedy to diabolical lengths.

title: Weapons Plants To Make Public Data on Health
description: Seeking to close a troubling chapter in the 48-year history of the atomic weapons industry, the Energy Department said today that next month it would make public the secret health and occupational records of 200,000 people who have worked in nuclear weapons plants.

title: In Central Brooklyn, a Branch of 3d World
description: Just down the block from the shouting boycotters, the police barricade and the embattled Korean grocery store that have become fixtures on Church Avenue in Flatbush, a man in the everyday garb of Pakistan and Afghanistan - long, baggy, pajama-like shalwar kamiz and sandals - looked over the merchandise in the Home Boy's Discount Store the other day.

title: A Rage To Kill
description: ''One of the most striking differences between the United States and other industrial countries is America's enthusiasm for execution.'' The Economist of London thus summed up a phenomenon that puzzles many foreign friends of the United States.

title: 'Ashley' To Miss Preakness With Injury
description: The middle dropped out of the Preakness Stakes today when Champagneforashley and Pleasant Tap suffered leg injuries that will keep them both out of the race Saturday.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: Books of The Times;   In Search of the Memory of Evil
description: One, by One, by One

title: A Free Society Doesn't Dictate to Artists
description: The National Endowment for the Arts comes before Congress for reauthorization this year in the midst of a political firestorm generated by a few works - especially some nude photographs by the late Robert Mapplethorpe. Many are clamoring for restrictions on what publicly-funded artists may express through their art. But they are forgetting about the First Amendment. In a free society, such ''content'' restrictions have no place.

title: A Smile, and Eyes That Go Cold
description: LEAD: The top man in China has a lovely smile and eyes that go cold. His name is Jiang Zemin.

title: STUDY FINDS LEAKS OF DATA ON I.R.A.
description: An independent police report published today says that British security forces passed information about Irish terrorism suspects to outlawed Protestant paramilitary groups in Northern Ireland.

title: Mrs. Gorbachev to Go to Wellesley
description: Raisa Gorbachev has accepted Barbara Bush's invitation to join her for a speech at commencement exercises at Wellesley College on June 1, Mrs. Bush's office announced today. Mrs. Gorbachev will be in the United States with her husband, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, from May 30 to June 4. A group of students at Wellesley have protested the selection of Mrs. Bush as a commencement speaker, saying her only accomplishment was marrying George Bush. Mrs. Gorbachev will also deliver remarks at the commencement ceremony.

title: Panama Party Offices Raided
description: Unidentified attackers threw a hand grenade at President Guillermo Endara's party headquarters early today, causing minor damage to buildings in the area but no injuries, witnesses said. The police said they had no immediate clues to the identity of the attackers. No group claimed responsibility.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Slovaks Pressing Czechs For an Equal Partnership
description: When Slovaks took to the streets in April to demand equal billing in their country's name, many Czechs found the idea of a change ridiculous.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Mr. Bush's Backdoor Bombshells
description: Most times when a President and his aides send public diplomatic signals, they want headlines and buttonhole the press to get them. But sometimes they'll make important points publicly and hope the press barely notices.

title: A Mixed-Use Development;   New Housing for Downtown Princeton
description: The development of Palmer Square, the hub of downtown Princeton anchored by the venerable Nassau Inn and facing Princeton University, began more than five decades ago. But only now is it moving toward completion.

title: Aiming to Carry the Torch
description: Once considered a long shot, Atlanta will submit itself to close scrutiny this week as a possible host city for the 1996 Summer Olympic Games.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the plans for President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to the United States referred imprecisely to his meeting with President Bush in Malta last December. That was the first time since Mr. Bush became President that he had met with Mr. Gorbachev.

title: A.T.&T. Credit Card Is Attacked
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company's complex arrangements to sponsor a bank credit card are drawing criticism from rivals in the business.

title: Janney Is Still Stunned After Matchup With the Stifler
description: For Craig Janney, the symptoms were acute and unrelenting. There were, for instance, the sense of claustrophobia, the pain in different parts of his body, the burning in his ears.

title: Corrections
description: A recipe for strawberry-rhubarb cream in the Living Section on Wednesday was printed in some copies with the steps for preparing the dish incorrectly numbered. There are three steps, not four.

title: Henson Death Clouds Disney's Muppet Deal
description: Jim Henson was involved in nearly every creative decision made in his multimillion-dollar Muppet empire. The chief executive of Henson Associates Inc. was a master puppeteer, storyteller and performer who was literally part of his product. As such, his death on Wednesday raises many questions about the future of his organization, which the Walt Disney Company agreed to buy last August.

title: Money Fund Assets Off
description: The assets of the nation's 507 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.78 billion, to $381.71 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 160 institutional funds increased by $270.10 million, to $91.75 billion. The assets of the 245 general-purpose funds were down $640.30 million, to $131.53 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds decreased $1.41 billion, to $158.43 billion, the institute said.

title: Problem Real Estate Loans Rise Sharply at First Fidelity
description: The First Fidelity Bancorporation in Lawrenceville, N.J., the 20th-largest banking company in the country, announced a sharp rise in problem real estate loans yesterday. Analysts expect the problems to result in a large loss for the second quarter.

title: Cafe Scene by Renoir Is Sold for $78.1 Million
description: Pierre Auguste Renoir's sun-dappled cafe scene ''At the Moulin de la Galette,'' from 1876, was sold last night for $78.1 million at Sotheby's, setting a record at auction for Impressionist art. The price was the second highest for any artwork sold at auction.

title: Chronicle
description: Its worth may be more as a conversation piece than as art, but now anyone with $4,000 can own a lithograph signed by PRINCE CHARLES. The Prince, who has been an amateur painter for some years, has agreed to sign an edition of 295 lithographs made from his watercolor titled ''Wensleydale From Moorcock.'' The painting is in an exhibition of the Prince's works in Urbino, Italy. If this edition sells, there will be more to come.

title: Paulette Goddard Left N.Y.U. $20 Million
description: The actress Paulette Goddard has left more than $20 million to New York University to establish scholarships, endowed professorships and a development fund for junior faculty members, the school's president announced yesterday.

title: Kay Jewelers' Credit Squeeze
description: Kay Jewelers Inc., the nation's second-largest specialty retailer of jewelry, said three banks providing $32 million in credit had indicated that they no longer wanted to be its lenders.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Romanians Seek Return of Farms Seized by State
description: Across Romania, mechanics, factory workers, pensioners and others have joined hundreds of farm workers in seeking the return of land taken from them in a collectivization drive 30 years ago by this country's former Communist Government.

title: Mandatory Pro Bono Violates Lawyers' Rights;   Exacting a Tribute
description: To the Editor:

title: Master Midfielder of Milan
description: It is late in the Italian first-division season. Internazionale of Milan, the defending champion, has just beaten the shellshocked goalie for Atalanta for the seventh time in the match. With the outcome long decided, Milan's coach, Giovanni Trapattoni, sends a rookie out to play and yells to Lothar Matthaus to move from his habitual spot at midfield to the right wing.

title: Harris Agrees to Pact
description: Major Harris, the quarterback who is the career offensive leader at West Virginia, has reached agreement on a one-year contract with the British Columbia Lions of the Canadian Football League, his agent, Ed Abram, said yesterday.

title: Restaurants
description: Chances are you won't share a banquette with Sean Penn or Mikhail Baryshnikov at Barocco, a minimally camouflaged industrial space in TriBeCa. But you will eat well, and at prices that will allow cab fare home and maybe an Off Broadway show.

title: Amatex Corp.
description: The Amatex Corporation, a privately held manufacturer of fire-resistant textiles, said it had emerged from bankruptcy and that independent trust funds had been established to handle all asbestos claims against the company. Amatex, based in Norristown, Pa., at one time used asbestos in its products. It faced 9,000 asbestos claims and anticipated receiving many more when it filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code in November 1982.

title: Parading for Causes
description: New York City's datebook this weekend, already crowded with festivals and fairs, also is filled with parades and walk- or bike-a-thons for various causes.

title: LAW: At the Bar;   When a law firm hires a psychiatrist for treatment of its institutional psyche.
description: What do you have when you have 50 lawyers together on a couch? It sounds like yet another lawyer joke. In fact, what you have is a partnership retreat of Morrison, Cohen, Singer & Weinstein in New York, and there is nothing funny about it.

title: Turcotte's Finish Is Late but Rewarding
description: Ron Turcotte, who won the Triple Crown aboard Secretariat 17 years ago and won purses totaling nearly $30 million before being paralyzed in a fall, earned another prize yesterday: his high school diploma.

title: Evolution in Europe;   RUSSIAN COUNTRY TOURED BY BAKER
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union took time out from their talks today for a drive in the countryside north of Moscow.

title: Bob Ojeda And His Day Off
description: rrBob Ojeda never knew much about American Indians until two winters ago, when he pointed his car along a back road near his hometown of Visalia, Calif.

title: Advertising;   People
description: * Hank Antosz, Camille Johnson, Richard O'Neill and Bob Zach have been named senior vice presidents at Chiat/Day/Mojo. Mr. Antosz is a media director in the agency's Venice, Calif., office; Ms. Johnson, a media director in San Francisco; Mr. O'Neill, an executive producer in Venice, and Mr. Zach, a media director in New York.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-11

title: Review/Art;   Lenore Tawney's Work In Fiber and Beyond
description: The extensive retrospective of the work of Lenore Tawney at the American Craft Museum is a mixed and problematic affair, one that informs without quite convincing.

title: Review/Theater;   Still in New Orleans And Singing the Blues
description: ''Further Mo,' '' Vernel Bagneris's rollicking sequel to his successful 1979 blues and jazz revue, ''One Mo' Time,'' returns to the original show's seedy stomping grounds, the Lyric Theater of New Orleans, to catch up with its four vaudevillian troupers. It is a year later (1927), and bawdy blues songs are still the specialty of the house.

title: Review/Film;   Four Eyes of Blue and an Old Love Rediscovered
description: Think of ''Bird on a Wire'' as ''The Mel and Goldie Movie'' and you'll be much less disappointed than if you walk in expecting the romance-action-comedy it claims to be. Just a glance at the print ads and subway posters reveals all you need to know about this Mel Gibson-Goldie Hawn film. Four of the widest, bluest eyes in Hollywood (apparent even in black-and-white photos) stare straight into the camera. They do this on screen, too, more than they look at each other. Their hands are joined over a gun, but it's a harmless-looking gun, because what matters here is not story but star casting.

title: Stop Subsidizing The Arts
description: Quick - what was Richard Nixon's greatest policy mistake?

title: Fear of Deadly Bacteria Type Grows
description: The bacteria that killed the puppeteer Jim Henson on Wednesday may be more virulent and more widespread than at any other time in the past 50 years, the Federal Centers for Disease Control said today.

title: Herman Cohen, 95; Headed Pimlico Track
description: Herman Cohen, the president of Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore from 1952 to 1986, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Baltimore. He was 95 years old.

title: Washington at Work;   Cranston, a Picture of Calm In the Eye of a Political Storm
description: Before his luck changed, Alan Cranston seemed the political equivalent of a master of the universe. So expert a player of the system was the four-term Senator from California that he was lionized by liberals for calling for a nuclear freeze while satisfying military contractors as a champion of the B-1 bomber, and a hero to good government groups for pushing campaign reform while boasting of his reputation as Congress's most hardball fund-raiser. Then the master lost his magic. Because of his association with Charles H. Keating Jr., the savings and loan executive and big campaign contributor, Mr. Cranston is collecting more allegations than honorary degrees. Not only do opinion polls show that his standing with the voters plummeting, but the uncertainty of his future has shaken the entire Democratic leadership. Just when the new majority leader, Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, is trying to solidify his hold, he may lose his experienced whip in the leadership elections late this year; the 75-year-old Californian has been second in command since 1977.

title: Businessman Identified As Buyer of van Gogh
description: A Japanese businessman, Ryoei Saito, was identified yesterday as the buyer of Vincent van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' which was sold Tuesday night at Christie's for $82.5 million, a record for an artwork at auction.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Baker Has New Arms Deal For Moscow, Officials Say
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d has taken new ideas for reducing conventional forces in Europe to Moscow, in an attempt to accommodate the Soviet position on a number of issues that have slowed completion of a treaty, American and Western diplomats said today.

title: Bob Kowalski, Dancer, 37
description: Bob Kowalski, a dancer and choreographer who helped found Works Contemporary Dance, a Hartford dance company, died of AIDS on Tuesday. He was 37 years old.

title: Gemini-Healthco
description: Healthco's shares rose $1 today, to $15.75, in over-the-counter trading, giving the company a value of $121.7 million. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Gemini said it would nominate candidates to replace Healthco's board at the company's annual meeting. Gemini controls 9.96 percent of Healthco's shares.

title: Panel Picks 3 Finalists For CUNY
description: A search committee has recommended that the next City University chancellor be chosen from three finalists, two Californians and a CUNY administrator, university officials said yesterday.

title: Sinatra Reschedules
description: The four Frank Sinatra concerts at Radio City Music Hall that were postponed because of Sammy Davis Jr.'s death have been rescheduled. Tickets from May 16 will be honored on June 17, tickets from May 17 will be honored June 14, tickets from May 18 will be honored June 15, and those from May 19 will be honored June 16. Anyone wishing to obtain a refund may do so through May 31 at the original place of purchase.

title: Elated Sandinistas, Ending Strike, Declare Victory Over Chamorro
description: Jubilant leaders of the opposition Sandinista Front declared victory today in a weeklong Civil Service strike that ended late Wednesday with broad Government concessions to Sandinista-led unions.

title: Now, 2 Millionaires on High Court
description: Justice John Paul Stevens has joined Justice Sandra Day O'Connor as the only millionaires on the Supreme Court, financial statements show.

title: Frolics in the Streets; A Party in the Park
description: IF you expect to spend a couple of quiet days in New York City this weekend, forget it.

title: War of Quick but Brutal Clashes Unfolds in Liberia
description: A week later, the evidence is still here. Lying in two shallow ditches behind the village are 15 bodies, swollen and decaying in the sweltering heat of the West African sun.

title: WIC's Golden Carrot
description: WIC (Women, Infants and Children) is something of a miracle among Federal nutrition programs: it's never been accused of that infamous Reagan trio of offenses, Waste, Fraud and Abuse. And there's considerable proof that it, like the other nutrition programs, has saved lives and dollars.

title: Chronicle
description: During World War II, ANTHONY DREXEL DUKE SR. commanded an LST, a landing ship. She survived the invasion of Normandy, several aerial and submarine attacks and the invasion of Okinawa.

title: Health Dept. Softens Stance on Cigarette Exports
description: After months of vigorous campaigning against the dangers of smoking, the Government's health agency today backed away from its past criticism of efforts to open new markets for American cigarettes around the world.

title: Spending Cap Seen as Last Hurdle to Adopting a Budget in Albany
description: With virtually all of their differences over this year's spending resolved, lawmakers today continued to wrangle over the state budget because of Republican demands for a spending cap that would not take effect until next year.

title: Pacificorp Raises Bid To Buy Pinnacle West
description: Pacificorp, the utility giant based in Portland, Ore., today increased to $1.82 billion its offer for Arizona's largest utility, the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation.

title: Timothy H. Fine, 52, A Franchising Lawyer
description: Timothy H. Fine, a leader in franchise law, died of cancer last Friday at his home in Berkeley, Calif. He was 52 years old.

title: Derwent Awards
description: Mary-Louise Parker of ''Prelude to a Kiss'' and Michael Jeter of ''Grand Hotel'' were chosen yesterday as winners of the 46th annual Clarence Derwent Awards. A $1,000 prize and an engraved crystal trophy go to ''the most promising female and male actors on the metropolitan scene.'' The awards were established in 1944 by Clarence Derwent, a former president of Actors' Equity Association, and are overseen by the Actors' Equity Foundation.

title: Chronicle
description: An official in the Environmental Protection Agency and an outspoken critic of Federal environmental policy, HUGH B. KAUFMAN, has been elected, as a write-in candidate, to the Town Council of Nora, Neb. (pop. 28) He has been working with grass-roots groups in Nebraska that are fighting a proposed low-level nuclear waste plant. Nora's citizens agreed that he needed a political base, so they wrote him in on Tuesday's ballot.

title: Deals
description: Football

title: Stewart Learns to Put Talent to Use
description: Payne Stewart's swing screams talent, but blaring knickers have gotten him more attention than his golf game.

title: Bruce W. Nichols, 60, Partner in Davis Polk
description: Bruce W. Nichols, a senior partner in the law firm of Davis Polk & Wardwell, died of prostate cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old.

title: Steinbrenner Softens After Winfield Leaves
description: Maybe it was fitting that the sorry affair involving Dave Winfield, the Yankees and the California Angels played itself out in the month of May. It is the month that became associated with Winfield in a way that may have capsulized his nine-year relationship with George Steinbrenner.

title: Work Stations From Unisys
description: The Unisys Corporation yesterday introduced a series of computer work stations based on Intel microprocessors intended to offer customers industry standard software options in computer networks.

title: Germans Press For Unified Team
description: A commission of sports experts from East Germany and West Germany called today for a united German team to compete at the 1992 Winter and Summer Olympic Games, the East German news agency A.D.N. said.

title: Notes Are Priced For Asian Bank
description: Underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. yesterday priced $300 million in notes issued by the Asian Development Bank.

title: Ashland in Deal With Occidental
description: Ashland Oil Inc. said it had agreed to buy the Occidental Petroleum Company's Appalachian natural gas properties for about $107 million. Ashland said it would acquire about 550,000 acres, primarily in West Virginia and eastern Kentucky. Production from the properties averages about 16 million cubic feet a day.

title: Behind Bush's Turnaround on Taxes
description: Why, after whistling a happy tune about the economy for 15 months and singing ''no new taxes'' as the anthem of his Administration, did President Bush suddenly change his tune, demand full-scale budget negotiations with Congress and imply that he was prepared to support higher taxes?

title: The Bensonhurst Case;   A Few Cry 'It's Not Fair' But Most React Quietly
description: A few cries of ''It's not fair,'' rang out in Bensonhurst last night, but the streets were no more crowded or noisy than they are on any warm evening. People milled about discussing Joseph Fama's murder conviction in somber - and decidedly bitter - tones.

title: Judge Drops 180 Counts In Helmsley Tax Case
description: Nearly all 188 counts in a state tax-fraud and tax-evasion indictment against Leona Helmsley were dismissed yesterday by a State Supreme Court judge in Manhattan, but he retained enough of them to leave what he called a strong case against her.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: The Bensonhurst Case;   Bensonhurst Defendant Is Found Guilty
description: Joseph Fama, a 19-year-old white man from the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, was convicted last night of the racial killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins, the 16-year-old black youth who went to the mostly white neighborhood to help a teen-age friend shop for a used car.

title: INSIDE
description: Shift on Cigarette Exports

title: Diner's Journal
description: Eating Your Vegetables

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Guilty.''

title: European Plan on Smoking
description: The European Community agreed today to cut the tar content of cigarettes and moved toward banning some forms of tobacco advertising in all its member countries.

title: 'Truly Blessed' Closing
description: ''Truly Blessed: A Musical Celebration of Mahalia Jackson,'' starring Queen Esther Marrow, is to close after the matinee on Sunday at the Longacre Theater, 220 West 48th Street. The play, directed by Robert Kalfin, will have run for 33 regular performances and 12 previews.

title: Mandatory Pro Bono Violates Lawyers' Rights;   Consider Inequities
description: To the Editor:

title: Seattle's Giles Drives In 7 As Mariners Pound Jays
description: Brian Giles, the No. 9 batter in the Seattle lineup, drove in seven runs with two home runs today as the Mariners pounded the Toronto Blue Jays, 14-6.

title: Economic Scene;   German Worries On Unification
description: The stunning defeat of Chancellor Helmut Kohl's Christian Democratic Union by the Social Democratic Party in two key West German states reflected voters' anxieties that unification with East Germany will cost them heavily. Mr. Kohl is now moving to head off a buildup of political pressures that could disrupt unification.

title: Awaiting Gorbachev Are Cookies, Song and Friendly Advice From Ex-Foes: Stanford;   Red Carpet Readied by Conservatives
description: The archivist at the Hoover Institution here is readying a display of Soviet historical documents that will include the final draft of the abdication letter of Czar Nicholas II, a rare first edition of the Communist Manifesto and the only surviving copy of Pravda's first issue.

title: Review/Film;   Robin Williams as Cad In 'Cadillac Man'
description: Roger Donaldson's ''Cadillac Man'' begins with terrific promise: a leisurely, uninterrupted helicopter tracking shot over New York City's borough of Queens. The air is heavy with smog, as it often is on a hot, still summer day. The colors of the landscape are the muted grays of the tombstones in the vast cemetery below.

title: Awaiting Gorbachev Are Cookies, Song and Friendly Advice From Ex-Foes: Minnesota;   Companies Hoping for New Market
description: A man who lives on the St. Croix River called to offer Mikhail S. Gorbachev use of his cabin, in case he wanted to rest up before his flight.

title: Mandatory Pro Bono Violates Lawyers' Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Late Coltrane

title: Review/Pop;   Taylor Dayne At the Beacon
description: What a trouper Taylor Dayne is! It was impossible to watch her concert on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater without thinking about the woman-hours behind the show, from grooming and fashion to music rehearsals to the practiced dances and hand gestures for every instant onstage. The result is 1990's pop as lab experiment, calculated to a fare-thee-well, strenuous and almost completely uninvolving.

title: U.S. IS PROTESTING POLLUTION PENALTY
description: The Justice Department will go to court on Friday to stop environmental agencies in California from collecting a $4.2 million pollution penalty from an oil company and spending the money to clean up San Francisco Bay.

title: Tide Rises on Suits for Bilingual Work Bonuses
description: As government agencies and private companies have struggled to serve more and more people who do not speak English, they have leaned hard on their bilingual employees for help. Now the employees are leaning back.

title: Damages Are Awarded To 2 Sisters for Abuse
description: Two women were awarded $1.2 million each from a jury that found that their father, a former Federal agent and child abuse expert, had sexually abused and beaten them when they were growing up.

title: Ex-Unionist Shot to Death In 'Mob Hit'
description: A former union leader who loomed as an important witness in a major labor-racketeering investigation was slain yesterday by a gunman who fired eight shots at him through a car window in Queens.

title: Ralph A. DeJur, Executive, 93
description: Ralph A. DeJur, retired president and chairman of the DeJur-Amsco Corporation, which made photographic equipment and office copiers, died on Wednesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 93 years old. Mr. DeJur, who was born in Manhattan, founded the company in the late 1920's with his brother, Harry. The company, in Long Island City, Queens, originally made photographic equipment and later expanded to include office copiers.

title: Broadcasts for China Delayed
description: An organizer of the Goddess of Democracy radio ship indicated today that the project to beam pro-democracy messages to China would be postponed indefinitely. The organizer, Christophe Nick, said the project had not received customs approval to bring aboard the ship a radio transmitter sent from France. The 1,200-ton vessel, which left France on March 17, arrived Sunday to take on provisions before sailing into international waters to broadcast toward Communist China.

title: Judge's Prayer Out of Order?
description: Five lawyers are arguing in a Federal lawsuit that a county judge's practice of opening sessions with a prayer forces his religious beliefs on a captive audience.

title: U.S. AND ARABS END SETTLEMENT TALKS
description: The United States and Arab nations have suspended talks in which they were trying to agree on the text of a United Nations Security Council resolution criticizing Israeli settlements in the occupied territories, American officials and Arab diplomats said today.

title: Shamir Coalition Effort Gets A New Three-Week Mandate
description: Yitzhak Shamir, the caretaker Prime Minister, was given three more weeks today to form a narrow coalition government with small religious and right-wing parties. He said he would announce its composition soon.

title: Shearson Is Said to Weigh Regrouping Into 2 Divisions
description: In a move that could lead to the restoration of one of Wall Street's most famous names, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is examining a plan to reorganize its four operational units into two divisions, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: The Bensonhurst Case;   Bensonhurst: Key Events
description: Aug. 23, 1989: A crowd of some 40 whites attacks four black youths in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn. Yusuf K. Hawkins, 16 years old, is slain by shots from a semi-automatic pistol.

title: Winfield Dons Uniform Of Angels
description: Over the years, Dave Winfield witnessed many a ceremony honoring the great and near great at Yankee Stadium.

title: Jewish Paper Makes Debut Next Week
description: A new national Jewish newspaper will begin publication next Friday, its publisher announced yesterday. The New York-based weekly, The Forward, will be published in English but is an outgrowth of the 94-year-old Yiddish-language newspaper Forverts. The new paper, published by the Forward Publishing Company, is partly owned by the publisher of Forverts, the Forward Association.

title: Review/Art;   'Poussin to Matisse': France to Russia to Met
description: The first half of ''From Poussin to Matisse: The Russian Taste for French Painting'' - opening on Sunday at the Metropolitan Museum of Art - begins with Poussin, moves through a discreet yet cheeky little Watteau, includes some forgettable period pieces by Claude Joseph Vernet and Louis Leopold Boilly, as well as a big 1809 Jacques Louis David demonstrating that even great artists can be insipid. The half ends with Ingres's 1841 ''Virgin With Chalice''; the relationship between the Virgin's hands, face and halo and the upright wafer at her left elbow is stunning.

title: Dominican Rivals in Tight Race
description: President Joaquin Balaguer and his longtime rival, Juan Bosch, remained locked in a close race today, a day after national elections, as some politicians said the vote count was extremely slow.

title: Louisiana Man Is Put to Death In 1977 Killing of a State Trooper
description: A two-time killer who shot a Louisiana state trooper to death was executed early this morning despite international outcries that he was almost mentally retarded.

title: Lichti in Car Accident
description: Todd Lichti, a rookie guard for the Denver Nuggets last season, underwent surgery for a broken bone in his right foot yesterday after he was injured in a one-car accident outside Lovelock, Nev., that killed the driver, team officials said. Lichti, a first-round pick out of Stanford, was headed for his parents' home in Concord, Calif. The driver, Kristin Gravrock of Bellevue, Wash., was pronounced dead at the scene. She was 23 years old.(AP)

title: Shift at Exxon
description: The Exxon Corporation said it would consolidate its Western and Eastern exploration divisions. The Western division has offices in Midland, Tex., and Denver, and the Eastern division is in Houston, where the merged unit will be based. The company's shares closed unchanged today, at $47.875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Tapani Finds Groove As Twins Top Yanks
description: It is the kind of batting situation Don Mattingly relishes and usually thrives on. Two out, two runners on base and the Yankees trailing by one run. With a rookie pitcher on the mound, it seemed very likely that a hit would fly off Mattingly's bat.

title: A Five-Year Plan to Cut The Deficit
description: If President Bush and Congressional leaders are serious about reaching a sound budget agreement, they should start by repealing Gramm-Rudman-Hollings. Like so much else, the budget-balancing law has been rendered obsolete by the end of the cold war.

title: Morgan Stanley Chairman to Retire
description: S. Parker Gilbert, who led Morgan Stanley & Company through the greatest period of growth in the firm's history, said yesterday that he would retire as chairman by the end of the year.

title: Brando's Son Held in Killing
description: A 26-year-old man was shot to death Wednesday night on the estate of the actor Marlon Brando, and the police said today that Mr. Brando's son Christian had admitted the slaying.

title: Kennedy Center Seeks $30.5 Million for Repairs
description: The 18-year-old John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts needs $30.5 million to repair a leaky marble roof, a crumbling garage and other fixtures, the leader of the center said today.

title: Viola, as a Starter, Has Been the Saver
description: Think of it. There have been seven games and seven victories, nearly all of them dominant. The pitcher who has won them all is employed by his hometown team, is financially secure, has found instant popularity in the city where he plays and dresses daily next to his former college teammate.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY, 18, 1990
description: International

title: Jenrette Named Equitable Chief
description: The Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States said yesterday that Richard H. Jenrette, its chairman, had been named to the additional posts of president and chief executive.

title: Bank Revamping
description: The Corestates Financial Corporation said it would consolidate its First Pennsylvania Bank and Philadelphia National Bank into a single network of 116 branches under the name First Pennsylvania Bank. The move will be completed by the end of the year.

title: Nielsen to Study Changes in Ratings
description: The A. C. Nielsen Company, responding to a request from the television networks, said yesterday that it would study the feasibility of combining its existing ''people meter'' system with other methods of measuring television audiences.

title: S. Arthur Dembner, Publisher, 69, Dies; Ex-News Executive
description: S. Arthur Dembner, a book publisher and former executive with Newsweek, died on Monday in the City Hospital Center in Elmhurst, Queens, after suffering a heart attack that day while on his way to play tennis. Mr. Dembner, who was 69 years old, lived in Manhattan.

title: Japan Trade Surplus Falls
description: The narrowing of Japan's trade surplus, interrupted in March after an 11-month decline, resumed in April, the Finance Ministry announced today.

title: N.F.L. Drug Chief
description: Dr. Lawrence Brown Jr., an internist who specializes in treating drug and alcohol abuse, was named by Commissioner Paul Tagliabue yesterday as the National Football League's drug abuse adviser.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Madison Avenue will be closed tomorrow from 47th Street to 65th Street from 1 P.M. to 4 P.M. for the Turkish Parade.

title: 27,000 Phone Lines Cut Off in Stamford By a Broken Switch
description: The failure of a large central office telephone switch in Stamford, Conn., cut off all but emergency service to a quarter of Stamford's telephone lines for nearly 20 hours yesterday.

title: Little Italy Party Hails Big Italy-Bound Squad
description: They were filming a movie in Little Italy yesterday, ''Godfather III.'' But that's not why the midafternoon traffic on Mulberry was blocked clear down to Canal.

title: Kroger Says President Will Be Its Next Chief
description: The Kroger Company, the nation's second-largest supermarket chain, yesterday named as its next chief executive Joseph A. Pichler, a former business school dean who joined the company in 1986 and helped it through a successful recapitalization.

title: Evolution in Europe;   GORBACHEV MEETS WITH LITHUANIAN; 'BIG STEP' IS CITED
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with the Prime Minister of Lithuania in the Kremlin tonight and agreed to begin talks with the breakaway republic if the Lithuanian Parliament suspends its declaration of independence.

title: No-Growth Capital Plan by Dinkins
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins presented a $22.2 billion no-growth capital-spending plan yesterday that would cover four years and delay building a new Police Academy from 1992 to 1995, restrain spending on other projects and seek to reduce borrowing costs.

title: Teacher Who Broke Boycott Seeks a Transfer
description: The Brooklyn teacher who led his high school class into a Korean-owned grocery store to protest a boycott there requested a transfer from his school yesterday, saying his life and the lives of his family have been threatened.

title: LAWMAKERS SEEK A RIGHTS BILL DEAL
description: In a new effort to break the deadlock over a major civil rights measure, a bipartisan group of senators today announced a compromise that they said would remove the major roadblock to gaining White House support for the legislation.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Mantegna's Big Offer

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Their Show of Shows

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Andersen Consulting, Chicago, a unit of Arthur Andersen Worldwide Organization, named William E. Storts managing partner for banking practice for the Americas.

title: Alcan Offering
description: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. is offering $150 million in 9.40 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of par through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. At pricing, the yield was about 80 basis points more than the Treasury's five-year note on a when-issued basis. It was on the high end of what most dealers had expected the range to be, about 75 to 80 basis points over Treasuries. The notes are noncallable by the company and rated A-2 by Moody's Investors Service and A by Standard & Poor's.

title: Military Makes Prejudice a Policy on Gays
description: To the Editor:

title: Spurs Beat Trail Blazers To Force a Seventh Game
description: The San Antonio Spurs forced a seventh game in their intense Western Conference semfinal against Portland with a 112-97 victory last night. Willie Anderson, averaging only 15 points against the Trail Blazers, scored 30, a playoff career high.

title: Fairs and Festivals This Weekend
description: TODAY

title: Treasuries Drop After Fed Signal
description: Prices of Treasury securities sagged yesterday after the Federal Reserve Board sent a strong signal that it has not eased monetary policy.

title: KEY RATES
Memorial for Jim Henson
description: A memorial service for the puppeteer Jim Henson, who created Kermit the Frog and many other Muppet creatures, is to be held at noon on Monday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street. Written instructions left by Mr. Henson, who died of a bacterial infection at 53 years of age on Wednesday, requested that no one attending wear black.

title: In a Brooklyn Store, Behind the Cash Register, Looking Out;   To Get Respect . . .
description: To the Editor:

title: Trade Gap Widened In March
description: The United States trade deficit widened substantially in March, to $8.4 billion, as exports and imports both surged, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Mandatory Pro Bono Violates Lawyers' Rights;   Unexpected Rewards
description: To the Editor:

title: Study on '89 By C.F.T.C.
description: A study by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission has found no evidence of manipulation of stock index futures or intramarket trading activity that would have hastened the stock market plunge last October.

title: James M. Wallace, Advertising Executive, 86
description: James M. Wallace, retired executive vice president of N. W. Ayer Inc., the advertising agency, died in his sleep Tuesday at his home in Pennswood Village, Newton, Pa. He was 86 years old.

title: Profits Up 25% at Campbell; Analysts Are Unimpressed
description: The Campbell Soup Company, one of the world's largest food companies, reported yesterday that its third-quarter earnings rose more than 25 percent, to $54.6 million, or 42 cents a share, compared with $43.5 million, or 34 cents a share, in the period last year.

title: Canada Trade Surplus
description: Canada's trade surplus soared in March, powered largely by a strong United States economy that consumed more Canadian goods than in February, the Government said today. The surplus swelled to $471 million (Canadian), or $402 million (United States), from a revised February surplus of $53 million (Canadian), or $45 million (United States). Exports rose 1.9 percent in March, to $11.86 billion, or $10.12 billion (United States), the highest level since last May, while imports fell 1.7 percent, to $11.39 billion, or $9.72 billion (United States).

title: Casper J. Schoener, Reporter, 74
description: Casper J. Schoener, a reporter for the Associated Press for more than 40 years who was better known by his nickname, Joe Schroeder, when he covered City Hall from 1966 to 1981, died of complications from anemia on Wednesday at the Medical Center of Ocean County in Point Pleasant, N.J. He was 74 years old and lived in Lakewood, N.J.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Bush and Kohl Agree That Reunited Germany Should Remain in NATO
description: President Bush, in his most emphatic statement of support for German unity to date, said today that he and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany agreed that once Germany was unified, it should remain in NATO and the rights of the World War II victors should be ended.

title: G.M. Will Close Factory in Atlanta
description: The General Motors Corporation will shut its Lakewood assembly plant in Atlanta on Aug. 6 and lay off 2,200 workers. A G.M. spokeswoman, Sharon Hines, said the auto maker would stop making 1990 versions of the Chevrolet Caprice at Lakewood. Production of the 1991 Caprice began in March in Willow Run, Mich.

title: Wild Swings in the Budget Ball Park
description: Even rookie pitchers in spring training have better control than the people who are tossing around President Bush's budget numbers this year. In February, they estimated that next year's Federal deficit would be $101.5 billion. In March they said it might reach $115 billion, in April $120 billion and this week, $140 billion. Can't anyone here at least keep score?

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Market Place;   Few Bargains In Environment
description: The long crescendo of publicity about environmental problems that preceded the celebration of Earth Day last month helped a number of stocks reach lofty prices. Waste disposal, pollution control and recycling companies and producers of energy-saving equipment all benefited from the wave of investor interest.

title: Corrections
description: An article on of Perrier mineral water to stores in New York City incorrectly described a test done on the water.

title: Conscience at the Summit
description: So great has been the progress on human rights in the Soviet Union that it is tempting for the West to relax its vigilance and pressure. That would betray the prisoners of conscience still wasting away in remote labor camps and psychiatric wards. The context, however, has changed. Talks with Soviet officials on human rights are now routine. There is a shared sense that remaining cases have become unfinished business. Attending to it should figure high in preparations for Mikhail Gorbachev's summit visit at month's end.

title: Price Jumps On American Stores Stock
description: The share price of the American Stores Company rose sharply today, a day after California's largest supermarket chain agreed to sell most of its Alpha Beta stores to settle a state lawsuit challenging its $2.5 billion takeover of Lucky Stores on antitrust grounds.

title: Advertising;   Rosenfeld, Sirowitz Gets President
description: Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss, one of the many ad agencies that trace their lineage to Doyle Dane Bernbach and the creative revolution, began its transition to a second generation of management yesterday by naming a president without Doyle Dane or creative credentials.

title: In a Brooklyn Store, Behind the Cash Register, Looking Out
description: To the Editor:

title: The Bensonhurst Case;   Weary Jury Wasn't Convinced That Fama Was the Gunman
description: Nine of the jurors who convicted Joseph Fama of murder declared last night that they were convinced he was part of the white mob that killed Yusuf K. Hawkins on a steamy night in Bensonhurst last August. But they said there was not enough evidence to show that the defendant fired the fatal shots.

title: Correction
description: An editorial on Wednesday about college football incorrectly described a proposed change in eligibility rules. The change, if adopted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, would in the future allow juniors who are not selected in the pro football draft to return to college as players. But it would not apply to the 20 juniors not selected this year.

title: Elbit Computers Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter figures included for the first time results of subsidiary ELescint Ltd. on a 62 percent basis. The company said the latest quarter's revenues included $36 million in sales from Elscint.

title: Graphic Scanning reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included loss from payment of legal settlement of $23,050,000. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,547,000 and $3,751,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Strober Org.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a cumulative effect of an accounting change of $100,000.

title: Chinese Aide May Seek U.S. Refuge
description: A senior Chinese official who disagreed with the military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last spring has quietly arrived in the United States, apparently seeking refuge, American officials said yesterday.

title: Patents: A New Toy And Sailboat At Exhibition;   A New Toy And Sailboat At Exhibition
description: Eager to show off their latest bursts of creativity, inventors flocked last week to the Patent and Trademark Office's annual Inventors Expo in Crystal City, Va.

title: B&H Ocean Carriers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Evolution in Europe;   Walesa Ends Gdansk Strike, Cautioning Against Anarchy
description: The Solidarity leader Lech Walesa today ended a strike by Gdansk shipyard workers, telling them that anarchy would damage Poland's image abroad.

title: Democracy Could Take Hold in Africa . . .
description: LEAD: In their dealings with Africa, the U.S. and the Western donor community for the most part have addressed economic and humanitarian problems and the causes and effects of civil and military strife. Until recently, the issue of democracy remained on a back burner.

title: Apple Bancorp Gets Annual Meeting Delay
description: The Apple Bancorp won a few months to explore its options when a Delaware court ruled late Thursday that it did not have to hold its annual meeting by mid-June, as its largest shareholder had insisted.

title: 2d Brooklyn Jury Rejects Murder Counts
description: A 19-year-old white man was acquitted yesterday of killing a 16-year-old black youth who crossed one of the invisible barriers that separate white from black New York when he went to the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn last Aug. 23.

title: IRAN-CONTRA PANEL OPENS NEW INQUIRY ON REAGAN'S AIDES
description: A new Federal grand jury today began a criminal inquiry into the Iran-contra affair that is expected to center on the activities of mid-level Reagan Administration officials, Government officials said.

title: Milk Hormone Poses Health and Welfare Risks
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A chart with an article yesterday on the nation's farm economy used an incorrect scale for the number of farms in the United States. The number of farms shown was in millions.

title: A Writer Moves Up, This Time in Hungary
description: He is a playwright. He became the symbol of his nation's resistance to Soviet domination. He spent years in jail. The head of his country's writers' union, he was recently voted President of a newly non-Communist nation in Eastern Europe.

title: Citing Unrest, Contras Cancel Plan to Disarm
description: Contra rebel commanders declared today that they had indefinitely suspended the demobilization of their guerrilla army because of continuing political unrest in the country.

title: A Surprise Spacewalk: Repairs for Soviet Ship
description: Soviet astronauts aboard the Mir space station are planning an unscheduled spacewalk to repair their damaged transport ship and insure a safe return to Earth, published reports and American experts say.

title: TIE/communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
About New York;   Luck and Pluck: From Poverty To Mega-Dealing
description: ''The man happens to be lucky,'' said the big man's dapper driver.

title: Japonica Step At Allegheny
description: A New York-based investor group seeking control of Allegheny International Inc. said on Thursday that it had acquired 59 percent of the troubled appliance maker's junior debt through a public tender offer.

title: Navistar International reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: With Tiny Margin Between Them, Dominican Foes Agree to Recount
description: With a margin of only about 11,000 votes separating the two leading candidates in Wednesday's presidential elections, the major political parties agreed today to a ballot-by-ballot recount that is expected to take up to 10 days.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   T-Bills, Notes and Bonds
description: People looking for a fixed-income investment, perhaps to park a tax refund, can find safety and certain tax advantages in Treasury securities. There is no risk of default, which is why they pay less interest than other debt securities, and if they are held to maturity there is no need to worry about price fluctuations. Interest earned is exempt from state and local taxes. Because they can be bought at auction directly from the Treasury without fees or commissions, their returns are higher than those of money market funds. Treasuries can also be bought through commercial banks and certain securities dealers, which do charge a commission. Auction dates are announced in newspapers and through recorded telephone messages at Federal Reserve Banks and branches. Here are the securities available at treasury auction.

title: Pacesetter Homes reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: A Product Dead-Ended By Liability Fears
description: It seemed like a dream come true: a virtual miracle fiber touted as being as tough as asbestos but completely safe and versatile enough to be used in products ranging from roofing materials to spackling compounds to brake shoes.

title: Evolution in Europe;   3 Admit to Vandalism At a French Cemetery
description: The authorities said today that three neo-Nazi skinheads had admitted to desecrating a Roman Catholic cemetery near Rennes in western France last Wednesday night.

title: One Man, Two Masterpieces And Many Questions in Japan
description: A Japanese industrialist identified himself today as the buyer of the two most expensive paintings ever sold at auction. The purchases are considered likely to deepen already serious concern over the manner in which Japanese businessmen are amassing and displaying collections of Western art.

title: F.A. Computer Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Hurt by pretax costs of $507,000 related to consolidation of operations, and $142,000 from the writeoff of deferred registration costs for the quarter, and the 9 months included a gain of $195,000 from centralization of operating loss carryforwards. c-Net income d-Net loss F.A. Computer does business as Gates-FA Distributing.

title: Rohr Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Car Stereos
description: Installing stereo gear in an automobile can seem simple, particularly if all you want to do is put in a radio-cassette unit and a pair of speakers. But it is not, especially if the car has no spaces for the units.

title: Felonies Increase in Subways
description: The New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that the number of felonies committed in the subway system in March had increased by 8.8 percent over last year's level, to 1,454 crimes compared with 1,336 crimes in 1989. The rise in felonies is mainly due to an 11.5 percent increase in robberies, officials said. The number of felonies reported in February rose over last year's level by 18 percent. Transit officials have linked a recent decline in ridership to the rising levels of subway crime and fear.

title: Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings of the Royal Dutch Petroleum Co. are $1.59 for the latest quarter compared with $2.64 for the year-ago period. The Shell Transport and Trading Co.'s share earnings are $0.91 and $1.50 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. Sales represent sales proceeds. Royal Dutch and Shell Transport are listed separately on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Germanys Sign Pact Binding Economies
description: East and West Germany's Finance Ministers signed a state treaty today to merge their economies and make the West German mark the sole legal tender in both nations by July 2, in what Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany called ''a first decisive step on the path to unity.''

title: Auctions' Big Spenders: The Japanese
description: Japanese art buyers dominated the bidding for Impressionist and modern paintings this week at Christie's and Sotheby's auction houses in New York. The sales were high points of the spring auctions in New York.

title: Ethiopia Cancels Talks In U.S. on Food Accord
description: A senior Ethiopian official scheduled and then abruptly canceled a meeting with an American official today on an agreement guaranteeing safe passage for tons of emergency food supplies for starving people in northern Ethiopia.

title: Patents: A New Toy And Sailboat At Exhibition;   A Lotion to Ease Pain
description: A Las Vegas chemist, David Roberts, was promoting Stopp, a lotion that he said relieved soreness caused by everything from bumps and bruises to lower back pain and arthritis. ''I go way beyond soothing,'' said Mr. Roberts, who sells a four-ounce container for $5 through the mail. He first patented the compound as a hair thickener in 1972 and later discovered that it relieved pain as well. ''I don't know why it works,'' he said, and acknowledged that the Food and Drug Administration had not approved his claims.

title: Topics of The Times;   The Midnight TV Drama
description: In a midnight decision, the Board of Estimate voted tentatively this week not to renew the franchises of Manhattan Cable TV and Paragon Cable. But this won't inconvenience viewers if the parties move quickly to find a formula both can live with.

title: McGraw-Hill Drops Baldwin Suit
description: McGraw-Hill Inc. yesterday abruptly dropped a suit against the family of the late James Baldwin that sought to recover a $200,000 advance paid to the writer before his death in 1987 for a book he never completed.

title: Black College Women Need More Than Money
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Love Letters' Benefit
description: The actors Jane Curtin and Stephen Collins will be featured in a benefit performance of A. R. Gurney's ''Love Letters'' on Monday at 8 P.M. at the Lucille Lortel Theater, 121 Christopher Street. The show will benefit programs at the St. Luke-in-the-Fields School on Hudson Street. Tickets are $125. Reservations: 924-5960.

title: Dr. Stephen Yohalem, An Endocrinologist, 74
description: Dr. Stephen Bennett Yohalem, an endocrinologist and a researcher in nuclear medicine, died of a heart attack on Sunday in Genoa, Italy, where he was traveling with his wife. He was 74 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Review/Music;   Exploring Brahms's Dual Nature
description: Brahms seemed to house within one soul the severe parent and the daydreaming child. The disciplinarian inveighs against the wandering imagination in his music - or is it the other way around?

title: Crestbrook Forest reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The company said the decline in sales reflected reduced demand for pulp, and the fall in net earnings was more directly attributable to increase operaiting costs and expenses. Sales for the first quarter included $34.1 million from pulp operations, and $27.7 million from lumber and plywood, compared to $39.6 million and $23.7 million, respectively, in the year-ago period.

title: Viola's Streak Halted
description: In their season of perpetual struggle, the Mets have grown to rely on Frank Viola as their solitary beam. But tonight, when they needed him to stop their ungainly slide, Viola became fallible.

title: No Yankee Tampering, Players Union Says
description: The California Angels have no grounds for accusing the Yankees of tampering with Dave Winfield, the players' labor leader said yesterday, because Winfield's trade to the Angels had not been completed at the time tampering was alleged to have taken place.

title: Woman Sues Boycotted Grocery in Flatbush
description: A $6 million lawsuit was filed yesterday by the Haitian woman whose claim that she was assaulted in a Korean grocery in Brooklyn in January touched off protests and a boycott that continue.

title: DNA Analysis Fails To Provide a Match In Park Rape Case
description: A DNA analysis that sought to match new evidence with the defendants in the Central Park rape case was inconclusive, a spokesman for Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said yesterday.

title: Patents: A New Toy And Sailboat At Exhibition;   Eye-Catching Neon
description: Kennan C. Herrick of Oakland, Calif., an electrical engineer and an artist specializing in neon light sculptures, said he was searching for ways to expand his art when he stumbled on ''neon bubbles.'' Mr. Herrick invented an electrical transformer that causes the formation of what looked like bubbles in a standard neon tube. By slightly modifying the shape of the electrical sine wave, the transformer causes the bubbles to move at varying speeds and in either direction. Mr. Herrick said the device would make neon advertising more eye-catching.

title: Donald Larsen, 65; Led a Refugee Service
description: The Rev. Donald Larsen, director of the Lutheran Immigration and Refugee Service in Manhattan, died of liver and kidney failure on Thursday at the Hackensack (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in River Edge, N.J.

title: Bridge
description: France and the United States have frequently battled in world championships, and there have also been some semiofficial encounters. Sixty years ago in Paris a Culbertson foursome played a French team using plafond scoring, a method that preceded contract. The match was agreed a draw almost at the end, when the scores were almost even and a dispute could not be resolved.

title: Campbell Soup Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Proffitt's Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
Man Is Killed on a Subway Train While Trying to Thwart a Robbery
description: A 53-year-old Harlem factory worker saw a fellow passenger being robbed at gunpoint on the J train yesterday morning and came to his aid, saying ''leave that man alone.'' The gunman shot the worker dead.

title: Different Verdicts: Why?
description: In two days, two separate juries in the same case presented New York with two very different verdicts.

title: Envirosource Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $3,000,000. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $4,648,000 and an extraordinary tax benefit of $1,210,000. Preferred stock dividends exceeded net income in the year-ago quarter.

title: Nu Horizon Electronics reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
Corrections
description: The Diner's Journal in Weekend yesterday mistated the dates that Huberts on Shelter Island, L.I., will be open. The restaurant will be open from Memorial Day to Labor Day, and will not close during August.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-6

title: HOUSE FOR THE HOMELESS PROVOKES DISPUTE
description: Donna Russell says God led her to open her lakefront house to homeless families, but her neighbors say she is breaking the law.

title: Unicorp Canada reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $2,100,000, or 10 cents a share. Figures are in Canadian funds. b-Net income

title: Kurri Sets Record as Oilers Take 2-0 Lead
description: The horns pierced the otherwise silent air in Boston Garden late in the third period, one sad blare, one broken note following another. It was clearly too late, the game too lost for the horns to have been sounded in encouragement. And so it was not farfetched to surmise that they were instead offered as a goodbye.

title: Recognition Equipment reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said the primary factor in these results is the impact of the expected termination of a major contract with the United States Federal Reserve Banks. Of the losses for the quarter, about $7 million represents charges resulting from the termination of manufacturing and development activities associated with the contract to supply currency systems to the Federal Reserve Banks.

title: Choir Turns 40
description: Kenneth Dake and James Simms are to conduct St. George's Choral Society in a concert celebrating the choir's 40th anniversary at St. George's Church, 209 East 16th Street, at 4 P.M. tomorrow. The program includes works by George Kemmer, Wayne Cohn and Calvin Hampton, as well as a group of spirituals arranged by Harry T. Burleigh. Harry Huff is to be the organist, and Douglas Perry is to be the tenor soloist. Suggested donation is $5. Information: 475-0830.

title: Reading Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $2,475,000.

title: Mortgage Rates Drop
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.37 percent this week, down from 10.54 percent the previous week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.56 percent this week, down from 8.63 percent.

title: Samuel L. Taylor, Minister, 52
description: The Rev. Dr. Samuel L. Taylor, a Brooklyn minister who served Presbyterian and Reformed Church congregations for more than two decades, died of cancer on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 52 years old.

title: Slimmer Peabody Attracts Suitors
description: A few years ago, the Peabody Holding Company was among the nation's least efficient producers of coal. But the St. Louis company, the nation's largest coal producer, has since reduced its production costs.

title: Collins Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $242,000, or 7 cents a share for the quarter and $318,000, or 10 cents a share for the 6 months. c-Included extraordinary tax credits of $201,000, or 6 cents a share and $278,000, or 8 cents a share for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: May Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,000,000.

title: Centuri Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Capital Cities Chief Elected
description: Daniel B. Burke, the longtime assistant to the retiring chief executive, Thomas S. Murphy, was formally elected on Thursday to replace Mr. Murphy as head of Capital Cities/ABC Inc., the media giant based in New York.

title: Auction of 2 Documents Sets Beethoven Record
description: A music manuscript and a letter by Ludwig van Beethoven broke world auction records for the composer, Sotheby's auction announced this week.

title: >Flexible Benefits: A Boon To Couples
description: Couples who work are being confronted with a new puzzle: how to coordinate the different flexible benefit plans offered by their employers. The goal is to get the right benefits for the family at the lowest total cost without duplicating coverage.

title: News Analysis;   Pound's Link to Europe
description: With the first phase of European economic and monetary union set to begin on July 1, the anticipation is rising in the British financial markets that Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher will soon let the pound join the European exchange rate mechanism.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: Fleet Aerospace reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Acton Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $5,786,000. Year-ago income from continuing operations of $8,899,000 included pre- tax gains of about $11,910,266 on sale of company's Cable Television System and $3,320,000 on sale of option fee.

title: Cardinal Urges Jews to Respect Loyalty to Pope
description: In an intensely emotional personal address, John Cardinal O'Connor pleaded with a Jewish audience on Thursday evening to recognize the danger of constant criticism of the Pope or harsh attacks on other objects of Roman Catholic loyalty.

title: Gap Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
Some Curb On Credit Is Reported
description: A Federal Reserve Board study confirmed today what many financial experts have been saying for weeks: the nation's commercial banks are restricting loans and other types of credit to small and medium-sized companies.

title: Corrections
description: A music review on Thursday about a program honoring the composer William Schuman at Merkin Concert Hall last Saturday misidentified the pianist who played his ''Variations on Chester.'' She was Lisa Moore, who substituted for Ilana Vered, the artist listed in the program.

title: Budget-Deficit Law Is Facing Change
description: One point on which the budget negotiators from the White House and Congress seem headed for agreement is that the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law will have to be changed. The $64 billion deficit limit set by the law for the next fiscal year simply cannot be reached, and the across-the-board spending cuts that it requires if that target is missed would be politically, economically and socially devastating.

title: Nucorp Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reading & Bates Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Cause of Forest Fire Found
description: A local prosecutor said today that a forest fire that left scores of people homeless here last week had been traced to the burning of rubbish by a homeowner, but that the authorities would not press charges against the man. The Crawford County Prosecutor, John Huss, said he believed that a fire set by the homeowner on March 16 smoldered underground for two months before rekindling. The cause of the forest fire involved an ''incredibly bizarre set of circumstances and leads me to conclude that there was no criminal violation,'' the prosecutor said.

description: A draft of a bill that would reregulate the cable television industry was disclosed yesterday to cable industry leaders by the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which is headed by John D. Dingell, the influential Michigan Democrat.

It also prompted soul searching by New York City's major news organizations.

title: Crenshaw Overcomes Penalty To Share Lead at the Colonial
description: Ben Crenshaw overcame a two-stroke penalty, shot a blistering five-under-par 65 and tied Russ Cochran at 134 today for the second-round lead of the Southwestern Bell Colonial tournament.

title: Corrections

Manure Taints Village's Water
description: Residents have been told to boil their water after a farm tractor accidentally dumped a load of liquid manure into a spring that supplies water to the village, officials said. The contamination, which was reported Thursday, affected about 350 homes in the Chautauqua County village. Mayor Homer Bowker said the town was considering legal action against the tractor driver, whose name was not released. He said the order to boil all water would be in effect for a few more days, until the system could be purged.

description: Companies

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was just a routine day yesterday for POPE JOHN PAUL II, who held his usual audiences with visitors to the Vatican and made his usual speeches. But world leaders stopped to salute him on his 70th birthday, hailing the Polish-born Pope as an inspiration behind the changes in Eastern Europe in the last year.

title: B&H Maritime Carriers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Black College Women Need More Than Money;   New York Can't Count On Getting Bottle Money
