title: Patents: A New Toy And Sailboat At Exhibition;   A Better Catamaran
description: John Rosenberger, an art dealer in Centerport, L.I., displayed a 25-foot prototype of an improved catamaran. Featuring three pontoons - two in the rear and a central one up front -the 92-pound sailboat skims over the water without having a rudder drag below. In the absence of a rudder, the boat's four-sided frame turns by using cables to pull the pontoons into a banana-like curve. To veer left, for example, the rear pontoons tilt to the right and the front pontoon turns to the left. Mr. Rosenberger said his boat was faster and lighter than conventional catamarans and could be collapsed into a package small enough to fit on top of a car.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BETSY GOTBAUM and DAVID N. DINKINS met 20 years ago playing tennis. Today New York's Parks Commissioner and New York's Mayor team up in a doubles match against two former city officials, SID DAVIDOFF and ANTHONY B. GLIEDMAN.

title: School Pact to Allow Drug Tests on Demand
description: Under an agreement reached with five of its unions, the Board of Education will allow principals and other supervisors to demand drug tests of school workers suspected of using drugs or alcohol.

title: U.S. TO EXPAND USE OF AIDS MEDICINES
description: In a move that has been eagerly awaited by advocates for people with AIDS, the Department of Health and Human Services said yesterday that it would formally outline a proposal to make experimental drugs available to people with AIDS who have exhausted conventional treatments.

title: Fed Voted in March for Tight Rein
description: Federal Reserve policy makers concluded at their March meeting that excessive inflation would continue and decided to maintain high interest rate policies in the face of a moderately growing economy, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

title: Sports People: BASEBALL;   Ryan Out for a While
description: Nolan Ryan of the Rangers returned to Texas from Baltimore yesterday to have his sore back examined. He was expected to miss his next scheduled start, Tuesday night in Boston.

Evolution in Europe;   New Soviet Envoy to U.S.
description: Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, a First Deputy Foreign Minister, has been confirmed as Soviet Ambassador to the United States, the official press agency Tass said today. He replaces Yuri V. Dubinin, who will be ''transferred to other duties,'' Tass reported. Mr. Bessmertnykh's appointment was proposed as part of a shuffle of Soviet diplomatic posts in Europe and North America, announced last month.

description: Philippine and American negotiators today ended preliminary talks on the future of United States military installations by agreeing only to hold more discussions on ''new, restructured relations'' between their two nations.

description: Fuller Potter, an abstract painter, died of emphysema on Thursday at Westerly Hospital in Westerly, R.I. He was 80 years old and lived in Old Mystic, Conn.

description: The New England Patriots released Stanley Morgan yesterday, a move that will allow the 13-year wide receiver to sign with another N.F.L. team without compensation to the Patriots.

description: Vietnam War veterans with soft-tissue sarcoma, a rare form of cancer linked to exposure to Agent Orange, will become eligible for disability payments, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, Edward J. Derwinski, said today.

Shlaudeman, is a former Ambassador to Brazil, Peru, Argentina and Venezuela and also served as special negotiator for Central America under President Reagan.

description: Benjamin Halpern, professor emeritus of Near Eastern and Judaic studies at Brandeis University, died May 5 at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston. He was 78 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

description: Just two months ago, Clayton Williams charged out of political obscurity to become the Republican candidate for governor of Texas by winning a landslide primary victory, but these days he is not riding quite so tall in the saddle.

title: Bleeding Recurs, but 'Squall' Still In Preakness
description: Summer Squall began bleeding from the nose as he grazed after a gallop this morning, calling into question his fitness for the $686,000 Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday.

title: Patents: A New Toy And Sailboat At Exhibition;   Belt Aids Swimmers
description: To protect swimmers who become exhausted far from shore, a triathlon racer in Warren, Mich., displayed an inflatable belt that can keep a person afloat. Called Hydrobelt, it features a balloon-like tube that straps across the body and can be inflated instantly by a carbon dioxide canister. According to the inventor, Mark Supal, the device does not interfere with normal swimming but provides double the buoyancy the average person needs to stay afloat.

title: Adopting Drug Babies    A Special Report;   Child-Rearing Is Stormy When Drugs Cloud Birth
description: Couples who become adoptive and foster parents of drug-exposed babies often find that rearing them is vastly more difficult than experts had predicted.

description: Dalton Prejean was executed in the Louisiana electric chair early today despite protests that he was dying for a crime he committed as a brain-damaged teen-ager.

title: Posner Discloses Move by Guilford
description: Victor Posner, the Miami financier, said he had been approached by the senior management of Guilford Mills Inc. about ''a possible business combination'' with the Graniteville Company, a private South Carolina textile manufacturer that Mr. Posner acquired in 1982. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Posner also said he had raised his stake in Guilford to 10.5 percent. He added that there was no assurance that any transaction would be consummated.

Although the agreement is short on specifics, Pratt officials said it opened the door to cooperative ventures on small to medium-sized commercial aviation engines.

description: Jill Ireland, the British-born movie actress who chronicled her long battle against breast cancer in a best-selling book, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Malibu, Calif. She was 54 years old.

title: Phase Out the Philippine Bases
description: If the Philippines truly doesn't want the United States to keep its bases there, the thing to do is simple: Leave. Maintaining a good relationship and avoiding rancor is more important to American security than holding on to the bases. But there's a better answer: Leave gradually.

title: Agents Find Drug Tunnel to U.S.

title: Lawrence M. Graziano, Missionary, 69
description: Bishop Lawrence M. Graziano, a Franciscan missionary in Central America and South America for most of his adult life, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the Bronx-Lebanon Hospital Center. He was 69 years old and was stricken while traveling from confirmation services on Staten Island to his residence at the Mount Carmel Friary in Mount Vernon, N.Y.

title: Protecting Young Eyes
description: Your eyes are protected by sunglasses. Should your children be wearing them too? Ophthalmologists say children's eyes need as much or more protection from the sun as adults. The lenses of children's eyes are clearer and so can absorb more ultraviolet light. Early exposure to sunlight may lead to retinal damage as well as the development of cataracts later in life.

title: Xerox to Offer New Copier Line
description: The Xerox Corporation will introduce a line of electronic copiers later this year that will set the pace for the company in the next decade, officials said at the annual shareholders meeting. But Xerox officials divulged little at the meeting on Thursday about the new ''multi-function'' products, other than that they will use digital scanners rather than the light lenses used by most copiers.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Columbia Gas System Inc., Wilmington, Del., a natural gas holding company, said it was offering for sale its Columbia Gas of New York Inc. distribution unit, which has annual sales of $65 million and distributes about 15 billion cubic feet of natural gas a year.

title: Stamford Phones Work Again
description: A balky central office telephone switch in Stamford, Conn., began working again on Thursday night, 19 hours after it abruptly shut down and cut off all but emergency service to 27,000 telephone lines in the Fairfield County city. The Southern New England Telephone Company said yesterday that it did not know why the computerized switch failed during a programming change or why it later started working again. ''We have tons of printouts to go through,'' said a spokeswoman for the company, Beverly E. Levy.

title: Marlene Hess, a Banking Executive, Is Married to James Zirin, a Lawyer
description: Marlene Hess, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Hess of New York, was married yesterday at her parents' home to James David Zirin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morris G. Zirin of Palm Beach, Fla. Rabbi Richard S. Chapin performed the ceremony.

title:
Voices of the New Generation;

As a Korean, I'm No Longer 'Neutral'
description: LEAD: My job renovating housing for the homeless often takes me into the most devastated and dangerous neighborhoods of our city. I have sometimes feared for my safety, but I've always felt that my ''neutral'' skin color afforded me more protection than that of my white co-workers.

description: Many business and professional people pursue their work so single-mindedly that they have no time to deal with personal finances. Soon they have the financial equivalent of a neglected garden in fertile soil; weeds - or debts - threaten to take over. Two-income couples are particularly vulnerable.

description: Mayor David N. Dinkins cut his political teeth in Harlem clubhouses and was a Democratic district leader for many years. But since he took office on Jan. 1, the Mayor has given party organizations and clubs, even those that supported him, little of the classic currency of politics - jobs.

title: Evolution in Europe;   For Russians in Latvia, Hostility Feeds Anxiety
description: Soviet lieutenant stood apart from his fellow officers in the angry crowd that gathered last Tuesday outside the Latvian Parliament. He was not demonstrating against Latvian independence. He did not shout or push. He had come during his lunch hour to see what was going on, and stayed on to get doused in Latvian hostility.

title: Women's College Rescinds Its Decision to Admit Men
description: Bowing to pressure from a student strike supported by faculty and alumnae, the trustees of Mills College voted today to rescind their decision to admit men to the 138-year-old women's college.

title: Oriole Singles Tie a Record
description: The Baltimore Orioles tied an American League record in the first inning tonight when they hit eight consecutive singles against Bobby Witt of the Texas Rangers. The Orioles won the game, 13-1. Baltimore scored seven runs in the inning despite not hitting the ball hard against Witt, who pitched the entire inning, throwing 44 pitches.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in some copies of Sports Pages yesterday misstated the day on which runners wishing to compete in the New York City Marathon in November can line up for application forms at Tavern on the Green near West 67th Street in Central Park. It is tomorrow at 10 A.M.

title: Blockbuster Sees 10% Market Share
description: The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation, owner of the nation's largest videocassette rental chain, expects to increase its share of the video rental market to 10 percent this year from its current 6 percent to 7 percent share. The company said at its annual meeting on Wednesday that it planned promotions to sustain its growth, including an eight-week $10 million contest.

title: Menem Confounds
description: Some people here are convinced that President Carlos Saul Menem is the one who can at last lever this country out of deep doldrums. Some don't trust him at all. But practically all of the dozens of Argentines I've spoken with find him strange, a man they can't pin down.

title: Winpak Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: No Headline
description: After 582 Chances, Error for Sandberg

title: Packs of 4 Tokens Will Be Sold in Queens
description: To encourage more riders to buy tokens in bulk and to shorten the long lines at token booths, the New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that it plans to sell packs of four tokens as an experiment.

title: THE CHARGES AGAINST KEITH MONDELLO
description: 1) Second-degree murder Not guilty (intentional)

title: Jordan Can Ill Afford to Criticize Israel's Record on Jerusalem
description: To the Editor:

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: ROBERT SEAN LEONARD;

Young Actor's Life Has Makings of Movie
description: LEAD: IT would make a good movie. A 15-year-old sophomore at Ridgewood High School is playing the Artful Dodger in the musical ''Oliver'' with the school's theater group, New Players, when he is discovered by a casting agency secretary and whisked off to Broadway and the movies.

title: Whitaker Wins on Decision
description: Pernell Whitaker showed his quickness and ring cunning. Azumah Nelson showed his age. As a result, after 12 rounds at Caesars Palace here tonight, the 26-year-old Whitaker scored a unanimous decision over the 31-year-old Nelson to retain his International Boxing Federation and World Boxing Council lightweight titles.

title: Engineering Fields Fertile For the Rest of the Century
description: Bolstered by mounting demands from industry and a national shortage of technical students, career opportunities for science and engineering graduates are making a strong comeback after recently experiencing a slump.

title: FICTION
description: CLOVER. By Dori Sanders. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $13.95.) In Dori Sanders' striking first novel, Clover, a 10-year-old black girl from a small town in South Carolina, chronicles her bewildering but gradually deepening relationship with her white stepmother following her father's tragic death only hours after the marriage. Clover's tumbling, unpredictable first-person narrative mixes standard grammar with black dialect, precocious insights with meandering prattle and memories of the past with a present in which her father still has a ghostlike presence. The story is sprinkled with a hilarious, highly specific commentary on food, which is both Clover's favorite way of describing her world and Ms. Sanders' shrewd means of illuminating the subtleties of racial conflict. Sara Kate, Clover's stepmother, is a ''real smart'' textile designer, but she doesn't have any more sense than to boil turnip greens ''flat-out in water, without a speck of grease'' and then dot them with cubes of Jell-O. Her new neighbors find her habits peculiar, but their customs are equally strange to Sara Kate. In one striking scene, she even sneaks into the cemetery to snatch away the mayonnaise jars full of plastic flowers from K-Mart with which her new family and friends have decorated her husband's grave. The author, a banquet manager who still spends the growing season on a farm in South Carolina, has staked out an impressive new territory here, replete with peach farmers, textile workers, drunks and crazy people, with the newly middle class as well as the terminally poor. As a specimen of the new realism in regional fiction, ''Clover'' is very much the genuine item.

title: PENGUINS WHERE IT NEVER SNOWS
description: In Brazil, where it never snows, the equivalent of a flamingo on the lawn was once a penguin on a refrigerator.

title: Debts Spur Land Auction
description: THE Hamakua Sugar Company, one of Hawaii's biggest sugar companies, is hoping to sell 8,000 acres - almost all of it zoned for agriculture - to help pay off its debts. It will begin by offering 5,000 acres at two auctions here, on June 28 and Aug. 16, at which it expects to raise $65 million.

title: Review/Film;   Womanhood and Politics In David Hare's 'Strapless'
description: ''Strapless,'' which was shown as part of the 1989 New York Film Festival, opens today at the Plaza and at the Chelsea and Worldwide Cinemas. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 23, 1989.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. A few months ago, the temperature in my cellar fell well below freezing, and some latex paint that I had there froze. Is there some solvent or liquid I can add now that will liquefy the paint and make it useable again?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think our discussions have resulted in some real accomplishments, and the progress we have made here makes me optimistic that we will have a productive summit in Washington.''

title: THE ECONOMY
description: Dealing With the Deficit - Sort Of

title: Commercial Property: Rebuilding 14th Street;   Merchants Ambivalent About Their Prospects
description: FOURTEENTH STREET is in for a rough ride beginning next month, when a long-anticipated reconstruction of roadway, sidewalks, curbs, water mains and sewer lines is to start. The result is promising, but not all of the businesses that now line the street may live to see the day.

title: THE IRAN-CONTRA COMMITTEES
description: Seymour Hersh told me he was writing a ''revisionist'' history of the Iran-contra investigation. His article ''The Iran-Contra Committees - Did They Protect Reagan?'' (April 29) is more revision than history.

title: The Auto Age May Be Exhausted, but What Comes Next?
description: A CRITIC wrote of Philip II of Spain, who raised political ambition to high art, ''no experience of the failure of his policy could shake his belief in its essential excellence.''

title: Egypt Says Israel Vows No First Strikes
description: The Egyptian Government said today that in an effort to ease regional tension centering on Iraq, Egypt has secured an assurance from Israel that it will not launch a first strike against any Arab country.

title: Fashion: On the Street;   For Spring, More and More, White Is Right
description: It may still be spring, but the official color of summer is already in midseason. That would be white, which on the milder days of the past few weeks burst forth in a profusion of outfits, most of them anchored by cotton, linen or tweed jackets.

title: WOULD SOME HELP BE SO BAD?
description: People fall in love with music for different reasons and at different speeds. Most gifted musicians find themselves ensnared willy-nilly, for better or worse, virtually from birth. For some modestly talented listeners, the experience of being thrilled by a particular sequence of pitches and rhythms comes with telegraphic suddenness, often in adolescence. I have a reader who testifies that while in his late teens he was felled by hearing the ''Poet and Peasant'' Overture. For many other people, enthrallment with music is a slow process, a series of friendly letters that somehow develops into a romance. In any and all cases, there is an element of mystery involved.

title: Style Makers;   Judith Niedermaier, Display Designer
description: Whether the props, fixtures and furniture at one of the nation's most influential retail-display concerns are inspired by Madonna or ancient Greece, the goal is the same: to sell clothes.

title: Managing;   Using Money to Change Executive Behavior
description: Reuben Mark, the Colgate-Palmolive Company's chief executive, has just made part of each executive's bonus contingent on hiring or promoting at least one additional woman or minority member. ''Putting money on the line puts teeth into management's value statements,'' he said.

title: 'Lear' Girds for a Remarkable Episode
description: The P. T. Barnum of the avant-garde, Robert Wilson began his career in theater in the late 60's with a war on language. In silent epics like ''Deathman Glance'' he ignored it. In masterpieces like ''Einstein on the Beach'' he deconstructed it. Now this sworn enemy of speech is rehearsing Shakespeare's ''King Lear,'' one of the greatest arrays of words we have. The production opens Saturday at the Schauspiel, where it plays until June 17, after which it might travel to Berlin and, eventually, to New York.

title: Technology;   Hunting the Elusive Teraflop
description: W. Daniel Hillis is searching for the elusive teraflop. He is competing with scientists at Intel Scientific Computers in Beaverton, Ore., and to a lesser extent, Cray Research Inc. of Minneapolis. Mr. Hillis is the 34-year-old creator of the Connection Machine, a futuristic supercomputer that he believes will be the basis for the first teraflop computer. A teraflop is a currently unattainably high rate of computing speed - 1,000 times faster than today's supercomputers. It is a goal for the next generation of high-performance machines.

title: For Some Authors, Book Publishers Pay Millions Without a Word
description: NOT so long ago, an author wrote a novel and a publisher paid for it. Today, in the quest for big-name authors and bigger profits, the order has reversed. Publishers are now increasingly using multimillion-dollar advances to woo best-selling novelists into signing contracts, sometimes without even a glimmer of what they will be writing about.

title: Wendy A. Wiener Is a Bride on L.I.
description: Wendy Ann Wiener, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin B. Wiener of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married Thursday evening to Dr. Fred Bruce Kastenbaum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Kastenbaum of Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Gilbert Rosenthal officiated at the Inwood (L.I.) Country Club. Mrs. Kastenbaum, 30 years old, attended Emerson College and the University of Southern California. Until recently she was a saleswoman at Bellmarc Realty in New York. Her father retired as the secretary and treasurer of the U.S.W. Meat Corporation in New Hyde Park, L.I.

title: Emotional Support and Cancer Recovery
description: BECAUSE people who have undergone chemotherapy for cancer often feel isolated, one of the best ways friends or family members can show support is to encourage them to get back into the mainstream of life. Despite the seriousness of their disease, people with cancer long to resume various interests and activities. This advice comes from someone who has had first-hand experience.

description: GALIMOTO

title: Biotechnology Benefits From Glasnost
description: AFTER communicating by satellite for 18 months, two high school students - one on Long Island and the other in Moscow - are about to realize their dream of establishing a center for biotechnology education in Moscow.

title: 'Tenured Radicals'
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa Michaelis and Billy Schlosser, Musicians, Wed
description: Lisa Cecile Michaelis was married yesterday to William Coxe Schlosser at the Mark Hotel in New York by the Rev. Lisa Ward, a Unitarian minister. The bride is the daughter of Marianne Zelnicker of Mobile, Ala., and Arnold Michaelis of New York. Mr. Schlosser is a son of Leonard B. Schlosser and Mary Coxe Schlosser, both of New York.

title: Review/Music;   Anniversary for Jubal Trio
description: With the proliferation of chamber music in the United States in recent decades, all manner of oddly configured groups have arisen, often ephemerally. A trio consisting of a soprano, a flutist and a harpist might seem at best a casual alignment, born for a single occasion and then evaporating like dew. But there was the Jubal Trio on Monday night at Merkin Concert Hall, proudly celebrating its 15th anniversary.

title: EAST BERLIN OPENS NAZI FILES TO U.S.
description: The Justice Department has reached agreement with East Germany for access to that country's World War II archives, a move that investigators say could result in important new prosecutions of Nazi war criminals living in the United States.

title: Circus Buffs and Scholars
description: To the Editor:

title: STARTING FORM GREAT FAITH, MISS.
description: THE ROAD TO MEMPHIS

title:
Focus: California;

Replacing S & L's as Financing Sources
description: LEAD: IRA C. NORRIS, a builder of affordable housing in Southern California, has been in business since 1977 and has never dealt with a savings and loan institution. Instead, his company, Inco Homes, based here, has taken the untraditional route of getting construction loans solely from banks.

title: Question Of the Week;   Do the Yankees Need Dave Winfield?
description: The Yankees definitely need Dave Winfield. He has had an extremely consistent career in the field and with the bat. His value has somewhat declined because of his injury, but consistency is something the Yankees need especially since their front office contributes to the team's unsettledness. Winfield had the ability to help the Yankees in turbulent times if he had been given the chance to play out of his current slump. Winfield was and is a very talented and popular ballplayer, but he was never the straw that stirred the drink, as was No. 44.

title: THE ATHENS STRUT, FROM RINGSIDE
description: Greeks on the whole do not drink to drink but to see and be seen, and Kolonaki Square in downtown Athens is where it happens: any one of an array of sidewalk bars and cafes provides a suitably public setting for the macho strut and eye contact over the ouzo.

title: Susan Safenowitz Becomes a Bride
description: Susan M. Safenowitz, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Safenowitz of Old Westbury, L.I., was married last evening to Alan D. Levine, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Levine of Searingtown, L.I. Rabbi Myron Fenster performed the ceremony at the Shelter Rock Jewish Center in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Michelle Gitlitz to Wed Jonathan Lupkin in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton J. Dimenstein of Milford, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for Mrs. Dimenstein's daughter Michelle Ilene Gitlitz and Jonathan Daniel Lupkin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stanley N. Lupkin of Bayside, Queens.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: The Executive Computer;   Put on Your Data Glove and Goggles and Step
description: The concept of cyberspace, which first gained popular appeal in a 1984 science-fiction novel, is so radical that even today few people agree on its definition. Some describe cyberspace as an infinite, computer-generated artificial world where humans experience an approximation of reality. There, geographic distance is irrelevant and participants can see, hear and even touch objects that exist only as computer data - pure information. The more romantic see cyberspace as a fantastic world that exists behind a computer screen, which one may enter in much the same fashion as Alice went through the looking glass.

title: Lynn Ann Pantano Plans Marriage to Charles Dale
description: October wedding plans for Lynn Anne Pantano and Stuart Charles Dale have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Lester L. Coleman and Carl A. Pantano, both of New York.

title: Melanie S. Kelton Is Married to David H. Landau
description: Melanie S. Kelton, a medical student, and David H. Landau, an associate at the New York law firm of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson, were married last evening at the Hotel Inter-Continental in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner and Cantor Howard Nevison officiated.

title: New York Fans Beat Montreal's
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;

Spanish Fare in 2 Comfortable Settings
description: LEAD: FOR those interested in a little gastronomic exploration, Bergenline Avenue in West New York is the main artery of a bustling Hispanic enclave. Travel agencies, bridal shops and markets stocked with plantains, cassava and tamales dot the Hudson County neighborhood, which has been settled by hundreds of Cubans and, more recently, by Central and South

title: Hockey Award
description: He has won more games than any other American college hockey coach and now Len Ceglarski, who has a record of 632-309-35 in his 32 years at Clarkson College and Boston College, is getting some recognition. He will receive the 1990 Lester Patrick Award for service to United States hockey. . . . Joe Theismann, the former Notre Dame and Washington Redskins quarterback, has been inducted into the GTE Academic All-America Hall of Fame along with Jamaal Wilkes, the former U.C.L.A. and National Basketball Association star; Howard Twilley, a former University of Tulsa and Miami Dolphin receiver, and Steve Taylor, a former University of Delaware and minor league pitcher. Lester Jordan, the 86-year-old former sports information director for Southern Methodist and a founder of the Collegiate Sports Information Directors Association, whose members select the inductees, was also honored at ceremonies in Los Angeles last week.

title: Albert A. Grobe, 81, WQXR Announcer And Journalist, Dies
description: Albert A. Grobe, who retired in 1973 as chief announcer of WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, after more than three decades with the station, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Slathering on Liposomes at Night
description: To the Editor:

title: Quebec and Canada: Loveless Match
description: ''Scotch and water,'' said Claude Beland, uttering the words with a shudder usually reserved for cod liver oil. ''Here, we drink wine.''

title: Out of The Kitchen
description: One person's idea of drudgery is another's inspiration. Considert his: Many people think that kitchen chores - like cooking and cleaning up - are menial, even demeaning duties, and that aprons are what you wwear to do them in. But then there are those for whom cooking cloths and clothes kindle deliciously romantic visions of picnics on the grass, barbecues int he backyard or creative repasts stirred up in a kitchen fit for a gourmet. The designers Marc Jacobs, Michael Kors and Michael Leva are among the latter. For summer, all have dished up some delightfully whimsical fashions based on such things as aprons, tablecloths and tea towels. Now, of course, because these are designers' togs, trhey are not made of just plain old ordinary fabrics. Jacobs went to Scotland to get his tea-towel linens woven, while Kors traveled to Italy to find his gingham-checked cotton gabardine. You could even cook up your own version of a casual summer costume by cleverly wrapping a couple of aprons arond your body, or tying a napkin around your coif or bosom. You could even call this kitchen couture!

title: Pagliarulo Slowly Adjusts to Padres By MICHAEL MARTINEZ
description: The good days are gone now. When they vanished last season, Mike Pagliarulo hoped he could forget them quickly, but now, some 10 months after the Yankees casually traded him away, he still has the memories.

title: Many Jobs Clean Up on the Environment
description: Item: The Jefferson Group, a Washington, D.C.-based government affairs firm, is hiring for a new office that will focus on environmental and workplace safety. Why? ''Many companies will need help n understanding and meeting the new requirements,'' said Mark D. Cowan, Jefferson's chief executive.

title: For the Politicians, The Prize in 1990 Is Really 1992
description: THE rap on politicians is that they can't seem to think about anything but the next election. Not fair. This year they are focusing on the election after the next one.

title: Miss Mummert Becomes Bride Of M. A. Lewis
description: Christine MacRae Mummert and Michael Anthony Lewis were married yesterday at the home of the bride's grandmother Mrs. Reuben T. Carlson in Princeton, N.J. The Rev. Mary Speers, a Presbyterian minister, officiated.

title: Kuwait Arrests Leading Advocates of Democracy
description: At least 12 prominent pro-democracy advocates have been arrested in Kuwait in the last few days. The moves have dealt a blow to a democracy movement that emerged with surprising force in the country at the start of the year.

title: Churches Feature Works of Connecticut Composers
description: ONE of these days, Connecticut will have an arts organization clearinghouse coordinate dates and avoid cultural logjams.

title: Fashion;   Spring Mufflers: Style, Not Warmth
description: On the West Coast, sporty lightweight woven mufflers are often worn year round. The trend has now threaded its way east.

title: Adding And Subtracting

title: CUISINE ART
description: LEAD: Claire Joyes and her husband, the great-grandson of Alice Monet, have successfully re-created the gardens at Giverny that Claude Monet and his second wife enjoyed for more than 40 years; however, her book MONET'S TABLE: The Cooking Journals of Claude Monet (Simon & Schuster, $29.95) is a less evocative restoration.

title: Laura Gant Weds Peter Lilienfield
description: Laura Ross Gant, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Gant of New Vernon, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Cahn Lilienfield, the son of Elizabeth C. Askow of Winnetka, Ill., and the late Edward W. Lilienfield. The Rev. J. Calvin K. Jackson performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church of Basking Ridge, N.J.

title: What We See When We Cut To the Videotape
description: The advent of the readily portable video camera and the extraordinary popularity of the new ABC television program, ''America's Funniest Home Videos,'' combine to raise the question: what is happening to the ways we perceive the world as we move in and through it?

title: HOLOCAUST MUSEUM: A TROUBLED START
description: As a former concentration-camp inmate, I agree with Lucy S. Dawidowicz that the memorial should be one of ''compelling austerity.'' I would urge those in charge to show their respect to those who perished by using as examples such memorials as Yad Vashem in Israel, the Memorial of the Unknown Jewish Martyr in Paris and the Vietnam Memorial in Washington.

title: O'Rourke's Task: To Sell a Sales Tax
description: LEAD: COUNTY EXECUTIVE Andrew P. O'Rourke has a lot of selling to do if he expects to win approval of a sales-tax plan that he said could generate $32 million for the county government, $48 million for local governments and $16 million for school districts.

title: Bridgette Gibson Wed in California
description: Bridgette Gibson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Gibson of Manhattan Beach, Calif., was married yesterday to William E. Goodman 5th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Goodman 4th of New York. The Rev. Judith Heffron officiated at St. Cross Episcopal Church in Hermosa Beach, Calif.

title: VOTES ON NEW JERSEY'S GUN BILL
description: On Thursday the New Jersey Legislature passed the nation's toughest law on assault weapons. Following are the roll calls:

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: Momentum is a mysterious factor, bringing with it an aura of invincibility while it lasts, but liable to plummet back to earth at any moment. After the 10th round of the Watson, Farley and Williams International Tournament in London, which ended May 3, Patrick Wolff of the United States had won 8 points and it looked as though his steamroller would never stop. Yet he was staggered by a loss to the British grandmaster Michael Adams in round 11, scraped out a draw in round 12 to another British grandmaster, Murray Chandler, and fell out of first place by losing to still another British grandmaster, Julian Hodgson, in the last round.

title: Elizabeth Glaeser, Executive, Is Wed
description: Elizabeth Glaeser, the manager of capital markets for Mobil in New York, and Dr. Edmund Chaitman, a psychoanalyst in Englewood, N.J., were married yesterday at the Georgian Suite in Manhattan. The Rev. Bruce Bayne, an Episcopal minister, and Cantor David Benedict performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Ford Weds E. B. Daeschler
description: The Bethel Chapel in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Emily Ewing Ford, a daughter of Enfield Berry Ford of Riverside, Conn., and Margaret Ford Cowan of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., to Edward Bassett Daeschler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert John Daeschler of Short Hills, N.J. The Rev. John W. Moody performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: The 'L' in the Program Makes Racing a Loser
description: Let's see if we've got this right. Ben Johnson was hauled into Olympic headquarters in the middle of the night, deprived of his gold medal for having performance-enhancing steroids in his system.

title: Robyn Loring Married To Dr. Leon Specthrie
description: Robyn A. Loring, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Loring of St. George, S.I., was married last evening to Dr. Leon K. Specthrie, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jared Specthrie of Riverdale, the Bronx. Rabbi Gerald I. Weider officiated at the Grand Summit Hotel in Summit, N.J.

title: AMERICAN GOSSIP
description: WALTER WINCHELLA Novel.

title: Educating the Palate: Wines On the Table for Each Course
description: LEAD: SEVERAL area restaurants have begun conducting special dinners that focus on wine both to inform consumers and to enhance midweek patronage. In general, a set meal, with a different wine paired to each course, is offered for prices of $45 to $100 a person.

title: Review/Theater;   Culture Shock in Hwang's 'F.O.B.'
description: At the end of the first act of David Henry Hwang's ''F.O.B.,'' there is a mirthful eating scene that summarizes the conflict between an American-born young man of Chinese descent and a newly landed immigrant, fresh off the boat (F.O.B.) from China. The newcomer, played by Dennis Dun, pours a jar of fiery hot sauce over his dinner and eats it as if it were the most savory of delights. The American (Stan Egi) feels forced to compete, but his tastebuds have become accustomed to the blandness of fast food and he is soon gasping for breath. He continues the competition while the F.O.B. smiles - dare one say it? - inscrutably.

title: Dr. Alison Baldock, Veterinarian, Weds
description: Dr. Alison Reams Baldock, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Lawrence Baldock of Springtown, Pa., was married yesterday at the Old Moravian Chapel in Bethlehem, Pa., to Dr. Richard Albert Rockar, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Andrew Rockar of Cabot, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Douglas W. Caldwell officiated, assisted by the Rev. Philip Rodgers, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Yugoslavia's Team Next Match for U.S.
description: The United States national soccer team, bound for the 1990 World Cup finals next month in Italy, ends a domestic schedule of games today when it plays one of Yugoslavia's best club teams, Partisan Belgrade, at the Yale Bowl in New Haven.

title: Irene Bruynes Marries Mario Ponce
description: Irene W. Bruynes, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Cees Bruynes of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday at the Second Congregational Church to Mario A. Ponce, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Mario P. Ponce of Glen Ridge, N.J. The Rev. T. Merton Rymph performed the ceremony.

title: G.O.P. Conservatives Take Grass-Roots Road
description: Representative Newt Gingrich's vision of the conservative future came to Sprayberry's Barbecue here today. Satellite trucks rolled up in the parking lot, Mr. Gingrich took his spot before the cameras, and a national teleconference began, grandly aimed at inaugurating a ''citizens opportunity movement.''

title: Strange Ties Crenshaw
description: Curtis Strange solved the swirling winds today to shoot a one-under-par 69 and tie Ben Crenshaw for the lead going into the final round of the Southwestern Bell Colonial tournament on Sunday.

title: Awake on the Job
description: Business has grown tremendously at the Sleep Disorders Center at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York, which may help explain why the center's director, Dr. Neil B. Kavey, is himself trying to get by on six or six and a half hours a night. Like other researchers in this growing field, Dr. Kavey said last week that too many Americans do not get enough sleep and that the situation isn't getting any better. For one thing, sleeping a lot does not improve one's image. ''In our society,'' Dr. Kavey said, ''it's considered dynamic, a feather in one's cap, to say you only need five and a half hours' sleep. If you say you've got to get eight and a half hours, people look at you askance, as though you lack drive and ambition.'' Dr. Kavey does not mean to joke around - he said at least 40 percent of the Columbia-Presbyterian center's patients suffer from ''some sort of extreme sleep deprivation'' - but in the case of ordinary harried people, he can see how it's hard to put things off just in order to go to bed earlier. ''I'm just too busy,'' he said.

title: Further Facts on Ducky the Swan
description: It is with keen interest and considerable relief that I read the letter written by Marilyn Forman of Locust Valley.

title: Denys Arcand Offers a 'Jesus' for the 1990's
description: Jesus hangs on the cross, nails driven through his feet and hands, his side pierced, his body limp and stained with blood.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WESTERLY, R.I.;

Motels Caught In a Legal Web
description: LEAD: A FAILED condominium conversion plan has entangled several motels in this shoreline community in suits and title claims. But banks that now control the properties have hired managers to operate the motels, and their 125 or so rooms may be open this summer.

title: Soul-Soothing Ride
description: I HAVE had occasion to ride along the Ocean Parkway from Meadowbrook to Captree almost every week in the last few months. This is a ride I always enjoy, both as a driver and as a passenger. It soothes and pacifies to see the sky meet the ocean and the bay. The variety of colors and shapes, the chance of seeing wildlife, the absence of commercialism and the absence of people are among the attractions.

title: Berlin
description: To the Editor: In addition to the people mentioned by Judith Shulevitz as habitues of the Cafe des Westens in pre-World War I Berlin (Travel, Feb. 25), there comes to mind the English poet Rupert Brooke, who was quite aware of such Post Impressionists as Franz Marc, Kokoschka and Kandinsky.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: As prices rise for examples of the rarest United States coins - an Augustus Humbert $20-gold piece sold for $1.35 million last year - a United States silver dollar with a strange story is among the stars of high-priced coins.

title: Victoriana Befits a Cottage Industrialist
description: AS a college student in Philadelphia, she spent hours at a splattered easel, painting canvases with bold strokes of abstract design or delicate lines of portraiture. As a married mother of three in Kentucky, she sketched patterns at the kitchen table in the evening and sold down comforters out of an old bakery during the day.

title: Pilgrims Seek Blessing At Lourdes in Litchfield
description: MARLENE POPP, a small gray-haired woman in a pink raincoat, stepped gingerly from the tour bus and gazed at the tall birches that lead to an arched stone gate. ''Isn't this beautiful!'' she said. Then, hurrying to catch up with her friends, she entered Lourdes in Litchfield, singing ''Ave Maria'' as she went.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-18

title: How to Cut the U.S. Divorce Rate by 75%
description: To the Editor:

title: A Popular Newcomer on the East End
description: SUMMER is still a month away, but Hampton trendsetters are making a beeline to Basilico Restaurant. Everyone who is anyone has already made the trek. Old Southamptonites, looking like they just stepped out of a Ralph Lauren advertisement, rub shoulders with the straight-from-SoHo set decked out in the latest gear.

title: On Language;   Bogie, Anyone?
description: THE DEVIL, LONG lingering in the details of language, now stalks the corridors of the Pentagon.

title: 'Tenured Radicals'
description: To the Editor:

title: Lifestyle;   Yes, There Are Dream Summer Jobs
description: Claudia Farb of Manhattan used to spend her days off imagining ways to escape New York's smothering summer heat. When Ms. Farb, an assistant research scientist at New York University, learned of a company that was seeking guides to lead bicycle tours on weekends and vacations, she oiled her 10-speed and applied.

title: No Bail for Brando's Son
description: Marlon Brando's son Christian was ordered held without bail Friday after he pleaded not guilty to a charge of first-degree murder in the shooting death of his sister's boyfriend on the actor's estate Wednesday night. Judge Rosemary Shumsky of Municipal Court denied a plea from the defendant's lawyers that a bail hearing be held immediately. When the prosecutor said he was not ready to argue bail, Judge Shumsky set a bail hearing for Tuesday.

title: Ashley Mercer Weds Glenn Schwitter
description: Ashley French Mercer and Glenn Paul Schwitter were married yesterday at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in East Hampton, L.I., by the Rev. Francis B. Creamer Jr. Mrs. Schwitter is a daughter of the Rev. Francis Overman Mercer of New York and Douglas Demarest Mercer of East Hampton. Her husband is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Schwitter of New York.

title: Gorbachev Issues Housing Law
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev called today for the legalization of private ownership of residential lots in an attempt to solve the nation's critical shortage of housing, the press agency Tass said.

title: News Analysis;   Budget in Albany: Cheers and Fears
description: When New York's long-overdue budget received final approval at 4:01 A.M. today, state lawmakers congratulated themselves for having found a solution to the worst financial problems that the state has seen in more than a decade. But critics both inside and outside government say they fear that, even though the budget includes the largest tax increase in the state's history, it will not guarantee balanced budgets in coming years.

title: FORDHAM'S GRADUATES HONOR THOSE KILLED IN EL SALVADOR
description: The six Jesuit priests of the University of Central America who were slain in El Salvador last November and those who continue their mission were especially honored yesterday at the 145th commencement of Fordham University.

Why Do Hospitals Waste Money on Fancy Brochures?

description: Dave Winfield, Devon White, Dante Bichette and Wally Joyner each hit a home run today, powering the California Angels past Toronto, 11-9, and sending the Blue Jays to their fifth consecutive loss.

title: Amy J. Lapkin Weds J. E. Frank In New York

title: A Walk Across England
description: THROUGH the misty morning we had rambled along the edge of the Ennerdale Water. On a clear day we should have seen a succession of nubby peaks - Bowness Knott, Starling Dodd, High Stile - but the clouds lay about them like an old feather bed. We ate our lunch leaning against a stone fence at the end of the water, just where the woods began. The only sounds in this valley without a road were the wind, an avian choir and the passing River Liza.

title: Kristin Ludington Becomes a Bride
description: Kristin Wishart Ludington, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William F. Ludington of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark Wayne Fritz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles D. Fritz of Birmingham, Mich. The Rev. Dr. John W. Bishop performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Campus Life: Wheaton;   Disciplinary Acts Raise Questions On Free Speech
description: The right to free speech clashed with Christianideals of ''responsible freedom'' at Wheaton College last week as nine students were disciplined for pieces printed in a student-run alternative newspaper.

title: New Lottery for N.B.A.
description: The draft lottery, the annual game the National Basketball Association plays to give the weaker teams a chance to get better, will be held today at the Equitable Center in Manhattan. At stake will be the order of draft selection for the 11 teams that failed to make the playoffs.

title: Taking a Mulligan or Two With the Rules of Golf
description: One day I was playing a round of golf with my friend Miles Jaffee, an excellent sailor, skier and tennis player who never bothered to master the art of batting balls through pastures. After one particularly bad shot, Miles picked up the ball and threw it toward the hole. His eyes lit up; the thrill of invention was about to replace the agony of defeat.

title: Blazers Defeat Spurs in Clincher
description: Clyde Drexler sank five free throws in the final 26 seconds of overtime today and the Portland Trail Blazers took advantage of a crucial breakaway foul call to beat San Antonio, 108-105, in the deciding seventh game of the Western Conference semifinals.

title: Fresh Air Fund Introduces Itself to Children
description: Most of Jane Rosenblum's second-grade class at Public School 111 on West 53d Street in Manhattan have never traveled out of New York City, so they were fascinated recently when a skit about the Fresh Air Fund was performed at their school.

The ceremony was performed by Judge Pierre N. Leval of Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title:
ART;

The Vocabulary of Expressionism

A recent recalculation of figures from the Standard Rate and Data Service, a magazine reference guide, indicated that there were 225 new magazines and 119 that ceased publication.

Vanderbilt 2d was undoubtedly a bona fide ''child of the gilded age,'' said Gay Wagner, executive director of the Vanderbilt Museum.

description: Francesca A. Morselli, a daughter of Dr. Mario A. Morselli and Dr. Mariafranca Morselli of South Burlington, Vt., was married in Woodstock, Vt., yesterday to David S. Sinnott, a son of Betty Lou Sinnott of Duxbury, Mass., and the late Peter Sinnott. Canon Donald Boyer and the Rev. Charles Davignon, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated jointly at St. James Episcopal Church on the Green.

IN THE NEW YORK REGION: WESTCHESTER;

Small Office Tenants Now Provide 'Bread and Butter' for Developers

Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, was kidnapped more than five years ago, the editors of the news agency have been faced with a quandary: how to cover the Middle East thoroughly and objectively while pressing news contacts in the region to help obtain the freedom of their correspondent, who is held hostage by Muslim extremists.

description: Clarence D. Rappleyea Jr., the State Assembly minority leader, announced today that he would not seek the Republican nomination for governor.
