description: LEAD:

title: DREAM BOATS
description: There's a world of luxury afloat ot there, on the balmy seas of the Caribbean, the Mediterranean and the Polynesian pacific. The water is calm, the sun is warm and islands beckon in the distance. The conveyances are beautiful boats, some with teak decks and spanking white sails, some with powerful motors and streamlined chassis. A captain and crew take care of you.

title: Question Of the Week;   Do the Yankees Need Dave Winfield?
description: The only thing the Yankees really need is the one thing they can never have: a new owner.

title: COSMIC COUNTRY
description: LEAD:

title: Miss Ingals, Lawyer, Wed To S. P. Valiunas, Banker
description: Candace Ingals, the daughter of Mary L. Ingals of Washington and E. Fletcher Ingals 3d of Glenbrook, Nev., was married in Washington yesterday to Saulius P. Valiunas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Valiunas of Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Dr. John C. Harper performed the Episcopal ceremony at St. John's Church in Lafayette Square.

title: NEWPORT'S GRAND TRADITION
description: Newport has flirted with sailors and the sea since it was settled in 1639, and its history charts the rise and fall of life under sail from Colonial days through the era of the America's Cup.

title: Everything for N.Y.U.
description: At the graduation ceremonies last week at New York University, it was the school that received the biggest present: $20 million from the estate of Paulette Goddard. Students cheered at President John Brademas's announcement of the bequest, the largest ever for N.Y.U. Ms. Goddard, who died April 23 at the age of 78, left everything to the university. She was wealthy in part from her films, which reached from Charlie Chaplin's ''Modern Times'' in 1936 to the Italian ''Time of Indifference'' in 1964, and she had more yet from her marriages to Mr. Chaplin, Burgess Meredith and Erich Maria Remarque. Ms. Goddard did not go to N.Y.U., and she lived mostly in Switzerland, but she gave to the school more than generously. After Mr. Remarque's death, she donated his library and his working papers for ''All Quiet on the Western Front,'' and from 1977 to 1979 she provided $3 million in scholarships for students at the Tisch School of the Arts. Ms. Goddard was also more of a New Yorker than people might think. She was born Marion Levy in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Byte-Sized, but Big
description: THE MONITOR (RIGHT) IS 14 feet high. The keyboard (above) is 25 feet long. The floppy disk is six feet on a side. In an era in which the desktop computer stands as a monument to miniaturization, the walk-through computer exhibit being installed at the Computer Museum in Boston is iconoclastic in its dimensions, if more conventionally educational in its purpose. ''We want to provide people with a compelling introduction to computers,'' says the director of the museum, Oliver B. Strimpel, who conceived the project three years ago. Designed by Richard Fowler, an Englishman who is head of design at Britain's National Museum of Photography, Film and Television, and fabricated by the F. W. Dixon Company in Woburn, Mass., the exhibit includes learning stations and a video show that explains how software works. It opens to the public June 23.

title: TAIWAN ANNOUNCES A DEMOCRACY STEP
description: President Lee Teng-hui said today that he would revoke his Government's declaration of a ''Communist rebellion'' on the Chinese mainland, clearing the way for constitutional rule here and moving a step closer to formal acknowledgment of the Communist Party's 40-year control over the mainland.

title: Deborah Devine Is Married
description: Deborah A. Devine, the daughter of Mrs. John P. Devine of Short Hills, N.J., and the late Mr. Devine, was married yesterday to Edward M. Caruso, the son of Mary Caruso of Wayne, Pa., and Edward R. Caruso of Phoenixville, Pa. Msgr. Harrold Murray and the Rev. Patrick McLaughlin officiated at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Short Hills. Mrs. Caruso, 24 years old, is an assistant to the Philadelphia regional director of Prudential Bache Securities. She and her husband are graduates of Mount St. Mary's College in Emmitsburg, Md. Mr. Caruso, 26, is an insurance agent in his father's company, Edward R. Caruso & Associates, in Philadelphia.

title: WINDY CITY DREAMING
description: THE COAST OF CHICAGO. By Stuart Dybek. (Knopf, $17.95.) Stuart Dybek could flip a coin and win a bet that it would land on its edge. In his second collection of stories, he gambles (usually successfully) that the paradoxical borders and margins of life are the most interesting places to locate his fiction. Some of these 14 stories are big and rich, long enough for a leisurely pace and pleasant reiterations of themes and motifs without running the least risk of seeming overstuffed or repetitious. The other stories, interleaved, are extremely short, ranging from a few paragraphs to a few pages. But these brief illuminations are no less effective, and they stand alone with a deft elegance that makes them far more than amusing little palate cleansers between courses. Crossing over to the lost territories of childhood is a recurring theme in ''The Coast of Chicago.'' Memories that are intensely dreamlike, as opposed to nostalgic, seem to drive many of Mr. Dybek's characters, whose thoughts circle and hover over old Chicago neighborhoods. One of the longest and most moving stories, ''Nighthawks,'' has clearly been inspired by the eponymous Edward Hopper painting of a cafe and its middle-of-the-night denizens. Mr. Dybek names the night counterman Ray and imagines him trying to sleep during the day: ''Perhaps it's something other than insomnia, to lie listening to children yelling as if they've re-created light; to try to dream, but succeed only in remembering.'' Laden but not burdened with significant imagery, this story exemplifies Mr. Dybek's persistence in examining the edge between wakefulness and dreaming, where memories lie coiled.

title: A FIVE-STAR VIEW FROM EVERY TABLE
description: Hong Kong, Britain's rich capitalist colony that sits at the tip of mainland China, is a sparkling monument to hard work and high living. And for a panoramic view of this restless, energetic entrepot, and a close-up look at the unabashed luxury for which it is famous, few places can rival the imposing Lobby Lounge in the five-star Regent Hotel. There, attended by waiters in white uniforms and seated in a large upholstered chair at a table decorated with fresh flowers, a visitor can look out, through a wall of 40-foot-high glass windows, at the spectacular harbor, with its endless stream of battered barges, pleasure junks and passenger ferries, and across to Hong Kong Island's glistening string of glass and mirrored skyscrapers.

title: Smiley Sidelined
description: John Smiley, a left-handed pitcher for the Pittsburgh Pirates, broke his throwing hand yesterday when he slammed it in a car door as he was going to Atlanta-Fulton County Stadium. The Pirates placed Smiley on the 21-day disabled list. Smiley has a record of 3-3 with a 3.37 earned run average in 45Z innings. (AP)

title: Recycling Property For the Future
description: The growing environmental awareness of the past few years has brought with it the realization that we can no longer continue to be a throwaway society.

title:
In the Region: New Jersey;

Meeting the Space Needs for Exhibitions
description: LEAD: A RISE in the number of trade shows, exhibitions and business meetings in New Jersey has brought on a spurt in the development of convention centers.

title: POLITICS AT THE CLUB TOMAJ
description: ON APRIL 8, I PUT IN A CALL TO BUDAPEST and got the news: the Alliance of Free Democrats had finished second in Hungary's parliamentary elections. My interest in the outcome was both personal and professional. For the last six months I had helped advise that lively, upstart party of former dissidents through Hungary's first free election campaign in 43 years. It had been a bruising battle, and Balint Magyar, de facto head of the campaign, sounded tired and frustrated as he recited the results to me over the telephone: the center-right Hungarian Democratic Forum, 40 percent; the Alliance of Free Democrats, 24 percent; the Independent Smallholders and Socialists, a combined 20 percent. The Free Democrats, who had invested so much of their lives for the last 15 years in reforming Hungary, would now be the loyal opposition.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: I'LL TAKE IT, by Paul Rudnick. (Ballantine, $4.95.) Supposedly in search of the glories of autumn, the Esker sisters go on a factory outlet shopping spree in New England, ending their adventure by robbing L. L. Bean. The novel ''may be morally iffy, but it is great fun,'' Susan Isaacs said here last year. Paul Rudnick has written ''an amusing, warmhearted book that will appeal to anyone who has an uncritical love of family and shiny objects.''

title: Lifestyle;   Greetings! Have You Ever Sent A Louie?
description: Congratulations on your award!

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE ROCKY HILL FERRY;

Floating Landmark Still Finds Passengers for a Quick Voyage
description: LEAD: FOR the 341st year, the Rocky Hill ferry is making its crossings of the Connecticut River, carrying cars, bicyclists and pedestrians between Rocky Hill and Glastonbury.

title: How the Politics Shifted on AIDS Funds
description: The politics of AIDS has fundamentally shifted in Congress, turning lawmakers who once cringed at voting for money to combat the epidemic or assist its victims into vocal supporters of more Federal aid.

title: East End Farmers Adjust to Pressures of Change
description: LEAD: IT is planting time on the East End, and the sound of the bulldozer is heard in the fields. With farm acreage already halved since 1970, even the slump in the Island's housing industry and an end to the growth in population have not stilled the work of developers laying curbs, digging sumps and cutting roadbeds through some of the richest farmland in the state.

title: New Germany; Old Fears
description: By formal agreement concluded Friday, the two Germanys will become one on July 1, barely eight months after the wall's fall. To most people, what was unthinkable then seems unremarkable now. Polls indicate that Americans are less concerned about German unification than are the Germans themselves.

title: 'Tenured Radicals'
description: To the Editor:

title: Unwelcome, Partner
description: Last week, Ann B. Hopkins was celebrating, smoking cigarettes, drinking beer, making jokes and otherwise acting thick-skinned, the way she has through seven years of litigation over her right to be a partner in a big accounting firm. It was just that unfeminine posture that had led the firm to reject her, a Federal judge had found, and because of that the firm would have to take her back.

title: Dr. John Fisher Wed To Dr. Nancy Carlson
description: Dr. Nancy A. Carlson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Carlson of Boston, and Dr. John M. Fisher, the son of Dr. and Mrs. John Fisher of St. Albans, Vt., were married yesterday in Edgartown, Mass. The Rev. William Eddy performed the ceremony in St. Andrew's Episcopal Church.

title: Utensil Essentials
description: BY THE TIME I MOVED OUT OF MY New York apartment last year, I had filled 12 large boxes with molds for steamed pudding, terrines for pate en croute, 300 tartlet pans, muffin tins in every shape and size, a set of wedding-cake pans, an arsenal of knives and 15 ice-cream scoops.

title: REAGAN'S DISRAELI
description: FIGHTING FOR PEACE

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

3 Errors Shadowed Literary Life
description: LEAD: ALL of us make mistakes, and at 93 years of age, I have made my share of them. But only three stand out and still bother me occasionally. One happened in the 1920's, when I spent most of my July days in Paris, as did many of the young writers of that period. I lingered at the busy Dome and the Select, the popular bistros, and chatted with the important literary figures, like Gertrude Stein, and her companion, Alice B.

title: Faded Glory of Syracuse
description: ONE can never be sure how people will react to Syracuse, a city that appears hesitant, uncertain of its magnitude and its identity, belonging neither with the big Sicilian ports of Palermo, Catania and Messina nor with the smaller and sleepier provincial capitals like Agrigento and Enna. Some visitors to Syracuse are fascinated by the evocative atmosphere of faded glory in what was once the greatest and perhaps most beautiful of the Greek cities in the western Mediterranean. Others are put off by the ugliness of the new city, and by the decay and neglect that deface the old.

title: Q and A
description: Afloat With Dolphins

title: How to Police Future Stock Futures
description: The staid Securities and Exchange Commission and the upstart Commodity Futures Trading Commission have gone to war. The issue is important, and heated: which agency should regulate the market in stock index futures.

title: County Works to Woo Tourists
description: FROM the Hudson to the Sound; from historic Sunnyside in Tarrytown to Playland amusement park in Rye, attracting tourists to take part in all that Westchester County has to offer has become a serious business.

title: Plenty Is New Under the Sun At Cannes?
description: No one could have predicted that a world-famous star of westerns and police action films would make his first screen appearance here dressed in pink coat, high boots and riding breeches, a country gentleman ready for the fox hunt. And no one could have guessed that a venerable film maker whose work is known for its rigorousness and ferocity would bring forth a gentle, even childlike collection of fairy tales. Nor would anyone have supposed that a film maker who has always favored incendiary tactics would choose his most controversial subject yet, then treat it decoratively and with kid gloves.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

An Old, but New Fruit to Grow
description: LEAD: The fruits resemble small apples, tinged yellow or red, with their calyx ends flared open. Inside the flesh is as soft as a baked apple and the flavor has a refreshing briskness with winy overtones. It makes me think of old-fashioned applesauce laced with cinnamon. Embedded in the pulp are five, large seeds.

title: Harassment of Woman Shakes Naval Academy
description: A photograph shows a fully dressed young woman crouching near a urinal, her left wrist handcuffed to a pipe, while a group of young men look on. There is a smile on her face. The woman, 19-year-old Gwen Marie Dreyer, was a second-year midshipman at the United States Naval Academy here until she resigned last month. The men who carried her into the bathroom and handcuffed her are still midshipmen.

title: HIS HEAD IN THE STARS
description: FOR ALL OUR EXPLORING, SPACE IS STILL A MYSTERY; one tiny, pockmarked moon, after all, is as far as we've set foot. Perhaps that is why we demand more than just dry data from those assigned to study the planets and peer beyond the Milky Way. A space scientist has to be a visionary, a poet in a white lab coat who can give voice to our collective craving for adventure, our fascination with a universe we have not been able to touch.

title: HOLOCAUST MUSEUM: A TROUBLED START
description: I am a first-generation American offspring of Holocaust survivors, and I don't want to see a Holocaust museum on the Mall in Washington (''Holocaust Museum: A Troubled Start,'' by Judith Miller, April 22).

title: WOODMAN, SPARE THAT TREE!
description: HEY! GET OFF OUR TRAIN

title: Campus Life: Tufts;   It Takes Time, As Well as Credits, To Graduate Here
description: Ari Socolow has completed the 34 courses needed to graduate from Tufts University, and he completed them in six semesters, not the usual eight, making the dean's list last fall and this spring.

title: crime
description: The Appalachian town of Hamelin, Tenn. (population 900), doesn't know whether it's coming or going, in Sharyn McCrumb's IF EVER I RETURN, PRETTY PEGGY-O (Scribners, $17.95), what with the murder of a local teen-ager and the high school reunion of the class of 1966 both happening in the same week. In truth, the identity confusion and general anxiety stirred by the reunion seem to have the more disorienting effect on the generation of Hamelin that lost its innocence during the Vietnam War years.

title: BENSONHURST AFTERMATH: Reporter's Notebook;   Hate Quickly Overflows A Courtroom Fishbowl
description: In the end, the hate was there in the courtroom, just as it was there on 69th Street in Bensonhurst on the August night when Yusuf K. Hawkins was shot to death.

title: U.S. AND SOVIETS CLOSE TO A PACT ON 30% CUT IN NUCLEAR MISSILES; AGREE ON CHEMICAL-ARMS CURBS
description: American and Soviet officials announced major progress today toward a treaty reducing long-range nuclear weapons. They also said they had concluded an agreement to end their chemical-weapons production and sharply reduce their chemical stocks.

title: A Moment for Dusting Off Faded Reputations;
description: Judging by the current spate of exhibitions devoted to the images of little known or long forgotten photographers, one might think that the world was running out of photographs. But since photography is by nature a prolific medium, and practically anyone can take a picture, some less obvious possibility than a paucity of pictures must be at play.

title: 11 Vie for Florio and Courter House Seats
description: NOTHING hates a vacuum as much as politics, and the Congressional vacancies created by last year's gubernatorial election are attracting much of the attention in this year's elections.

title: 'I CAN POP I CAN BREAK I CAN SLIDE AND JERK'
description: THE MOUSE RAP

title: Postings: 75 Yards for a Touchdown;   A Moving Experience
description: Randy Reveley, who owns Reveley Construction in Hoboken, N.J., planned to subdivide his two-acre property, off West Saddle River Road in the Rambling Brook Estates section of Ridgewood, N.J., into four lots when he bought it last year for $900,000. But he couldn't bring himself to raze a two-level center-hall colonial that stood in the path of a road he wanted to build into the cul-de-sac. His family temporarily lived in the house, built in 1940 in a peach orchard by the late local builder George W. Peterson.

title: Society Has the Cure For Girls' Depression
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;

Personal Glimpses of Alfred Stieglitz
description: LEAD: >ALFRED STIEGLITZ (1864-1946) was one of a handful of photographers who made his medium into an American art form. He was a propagandist who edited photography journals and he also maintained an art gallery where he exhibited avant-garde painting.

title: Text of Statement by Baker
description: Following is the text of the statement today by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d after talks with Soviet leaders:

title: RUNNING AWAY TO SEA, THE FREIGHTER WAY
description: When you announce to your loved ones that you are hopping a freighter to South America and will be gone for two months and they bid you fond farewell on the eve of your departure, why are you seen skulking around town a week later? Because just as time and tide wait for no man, freighters don't depart for a ready woman. They go when their cargo is loaded, and their passengers bide their time until it is.

title: Candidate Tries to Unblur His Image
description: In the campaign for the Democratic nomination for governor of the most populous state, Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp of California is a politician of paradoxes.

title: Shaw's 'Pygmalion' at Yale Repertory
description: BEFORE the performance of George Bernard Shaw's ''Pygmalion'' begins at the Yale Repertory Theater, one can read about the misanthropic sculptor whose statue came ''miraculously alive'' upon being kissed. The gist of the tale is spelled out right on the curtain.

title: A Troubadour for Troubled Folk
description: Two years ago, the singer and songwriter Michael Smith was working as a clerk for Time magazine in Chicago and playing occasional dates in folk clubs when Frank Galati of Chicago's Steppenwolf Theater Company dropped in one night to hear him perform.

title: Art Appreciator
description: Sagging art market? Not when Ryoei Saito is around. Shopping at Christie's and Sotheby's last week, the Japanese industrialist paid the highest and the second-highest prices ever paid for a work of art at auction. First was Vincent van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' $82.5 million, on Tuesday. Next was Pierre Auguste Renoir's cafe scene ''At the Moulin de la Galette,'' $78.1 million, on Thursday. (The previous record was $53.9 million for van Gogh's ''Irises.'') Through his representative at the New York auctions, he picked up other things, too. Extravagant as he is, Mr. Saito was not the only Japanese high bidder last week; in all, Japanese buyers accounted for more than half the sales at the two houses. Mr. Saito, 74 years old, once sold off many of his artworks to save his business, the Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Company. But when profits revived, so did Mr. Saito's collecting habits. When he was asked what he would do with a Rodin sculpture he bought last week, he replied: ''It was only $1.6 million. That's for my yard.''

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: The U.A.W. begins a three-day convention to set strategy for coming contract talks. Federal budget deficit report for April.

title: Corporations Demand Flexibility in New Offices
description: IN the six months since J. P. Morgan & Company began moving into its new 47-story headquarters building at 60 Wall Street, its staff has continued a game of musical chairs that became routine during the 80's in the tumultuous world of investment banking, where multimillion dollar deals are struck in hours and new lines of business are established in days.

title: Installing a Ceiling Fan
description: LARGE-BLADED ceiling fans are more economical to operate than air-conditioners and can add to comfort and energy savings the year round.

title: The Odd and the Usual At the Vassar Book Sale
description: LEAD: WANT to read ''The Westport Atlas of American Wars?'' How about browsing through the ''Parish-Watson Collection of Mohammedan Potteries''? Or ''The Democrat Book, 1936,'' a volume of photographs of prominent party members autographed by Franklin D. Roosevelt?

title: Names in England, Names in New Jersey
description: The interest in New Jersey place names (Letters to the New Jersey Editor, April 15) reminds me that several years ago I wrote to a gentleman in London asking if I could buy or exchange a book he had bought at auction that I wanted. He responded that he did not approve of allowing British treasures to fall into the hands of foreigners.

title: The Post Neo-Nixon (Annotated)
description: LEAD: About one thing we should be perfectly clear: he won't go away. And why should he? Oh, sure, his critics -whom he doesn't blame - would like to see him dipped and frozen in amber. But why deny the rest of us the periodic pleasures of watching him flicker back to life? For on those occasions, he inhabits us.

title: The Kingdom of California Date Palms
description: PROBABLY because our backyard in Arizona was overgrown with peaches, apricots, plums, pomegranates and grapes through most of my childhood, fresh fruit has never tasted like real food to me. Nourishment was what came from the store in a brown bag. Anything I could walk out the back door and pluck off a branch had no nutritional value.

title: ART, ALE AND ROCK-AND-ROLL
description: When the wind whistles across Puget Sound and up the hills that front Seattle's harborside, few places make a better refuge from westerly gales than the Virginia Inn Tavern, one block north of the Pike Place Market.

title: Evening Hours;   At a Round of Benefits, Aristocrats All
description: When the Russian Nobility Association in America held its annual Easter Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria on May 11, vestiges of imperial Russia were everywhere. There were a good many Romanovs, titles, rows of medals, colorful sashes and men wearing white gloves to dance. There were a ballet divertissement on Russian fairy tales, a dance orchestra and, late in the evening, a balalaika ensemble that inspired some high-spirited Cossack dancing. The evening was a benefit for the association, and the chairwoman was Countess Tatiana Bobrinskoy.

title: HOLOCAUST MUSEUM: A TROUBLED START
description: Have the supporters of the museum considered other alternatives to the project? Surely the victims and survivors of the Holocaust deserve nothing less than a legacy that combines remembrance, regeneration and reform. Why not establish memorial institutes dedicated to research into the physical, political and economic ills afflicting societies?

title: Hogan Stays a Presence at 77
description: Ben Hogan avoids reflecting on the particulars of his magnificent career, even though they happen to include four United States Open victories, five other major championships, and a reputation as the greatest shotmaker who ever lived.

title: Bali's Dyed Gringsing Cloth, a 7-Year Wonder
description: IN the pantheon of things black and white and red all over, the Balinese textile called gringsing must certainly be the most obscure. The double-ikat technique used to make it - that of tying and dyeing the threads of both length and width, warp and weft, before weaving - is done nowhere else in Indonesia. A single piece can take up to eight years to make, in a process so ancient some secrets and patterns have been lost or muddled irrevocably. Moreover, once a gringsing piece is finally finished, if it is of very high quality it is reserved by its makers for village rituals and ceremonies.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: AT 10:32 P.M. on Wednesday, March 22, Dennis Miranda, captain of the Minolta/Watershed Watch Team, pulled his vintage sedan beside a likely-looking spot along Clinton Road, not far from Greenwood Lake. Stoically, he left the warm interior of the car, walked a short distance to a chilly pond rich with the sound of spring peepers and proceeded to whistle.

title: Eastern Germans Paid Dearly, and Early, for Their Nazi Past
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Medical Center Offers Builders $1.3 Billion Rx
description: BECAUSE of the collapse of the energy industry, the 10-year commercial building boom that shaped this city's skyline has, since the mid-80's, come to a virtual standstill - except on the 600-acre campus of the Texas Medical Center next to Rice University.

title: Incumbency an Issue in Races for Congress
description: LONG ISLAND Congressional races are shaping up this year not only as confrontations between Republicans and Democrats but also between what is being called a new alignment in American politics - incumbents and nonincumbents.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

The Long and Winding Trip Down the Aisle
description: LEAD: IT'S May 20: Do you know where your daughter is? If she's not walking down an aisle or shopping for a bridal gown, there's a reason.

title: In Search of Capitalism With a Human Face
description: TWO decades ago Communist reformers in Eastern Europe wanted to build a new type of economic system, one that would be a bold mix of Marxism and the free market. Eager to shun Stalinist repression and stagnation as well as to avoid capitalist evils like unemployment, these idealists dreamed of constructing ''socialism with a human face.''

title: Korean Flavors Arrive in New Haven
description: THE latest Asian cuisine to find a welcome in downtown New Haven is Korean, and judging by the crowds flowing in and out of the large dining room of Seoul, this was overdue.

title: Mitterrand Adviser to Head Bank to Aid Eastern Europe
description: The 42 member nations of the new Bank for European Reconstruction and Development, established to provide financial aid to Eastern Europe, tonight elected a French official as its president and selected London as its headquarters.

title: Not So Far
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: States' Prisons Continue to Bulge, Overwhelming Efforts at Reform
description: Fueled by new laws and stiffer sentences endorsed by an impatient public, the states' prison population grew more than 10 percent last year and began to overwhelm even states like Washington, which had been among the few to avoid overcrowding.

title: Kitchen Comforts
description: On the walls of Merrill Stenbeck's Manhattan kitchen are whimsical Palissy-style plates with serpents crawling across the surface. ''They're supposed to scare you out of your wits when you sneak into the kitchen for a midnight snack,'' says Merrill Stenbeck, co-owner of Valley House Antiques, a shop in Locust Valley, L.I.

title: Exam for Barkley
description: With his team eliminated from the playoffs last week, the Philadelphia 76ers' All-Star forward, Charles Barkley, can now tend to what caused pain and numbness in his right shoulder in the team's final playoff games.

title: Jonna Godley Is the Bride Of Dr. Keith Elliot Scharf
description: Jonna L. Godley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William H. Godley Jr. of Frenchtown, N.J., and Dr. Keith Elliot Scharf, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank D. Scharf of Guilford, Conn., and New York, were married yesterday at the United Nations Chapel in New York. The Rev. Vernon Nichols, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony.

title: READ HIS LIPS: MORE TAXES
description: OUTSIDERS FIRST SUSPECTED THAT SOMETHING UNUSUAL WAS AFOOT in Trenton, the sleepy capital on the bank of the Delaware River, several hours before Jim Florio took the oath of office as the 49th Governor of New Jersey.

title: TALES OF AN ITALIAN ANCHORAGE
description: In the crowded months of July and August, sailing yachts at Porto Ercole's small public quay (no dock fee, but little fresh water) are tied up eight-in-line, rather the way souvenir Indian elephants are linked, an arrangement that encourages new friendships and a lazy reluctance to put out to sea.

title: Solace After Bereavement: Counseling Services Grow
description: Nearly every day, Gail Bishop travels through small towns in northern Colorado like a circuit rider, visiting families that have suffered a death in the last year. She works for a funeral home that not only buries the dead but also helps survivors deal with their grief.

title: THE IRAN-CONTRA COMMITTEES
description: I did not read Seymour Hersh's piece beyond the point where he referred to Arthur Liman's speculation that a Reagan impeachment would have destroyed a chance for arms control with Russia.

title: Pay for Play
description: If John Cullerton and a majority of his colleagues have their way, it won't be long before college athletes in Illinois begin drawing salaries and enjoying due-process civil rights protection in investigations by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.

title:
ART;

Long Line of Fabulists Adds Some New Names
description: LEAD: WITH predecessors ranging from Hieronymus Bosch and Francisco Goya to Walt Disney and Salvador Dali, the eight contemporary artists in ''Dreams and Illusions,'' the current exhibition at the Islip Art Museum, are among the latest in a long and distinguished line of fabulists.

title: Question Of the Week;   Do the Yankees Need Dave Winfield?
description: The Yankees needed Dave Winfield, but it's too late now. I hope by this time, he's back to stardom and helping the Angels strive for the pennant. Steinbrenner could never stand Winfield. The athlete earned every penny of his salary by his playing accomplishments, but the owner never forgave him for outdoing him on the business transaction of his 10-year contract. Steinbrenner is the kind who would pay $3 million for a Picasso, and if he thought the market value had gone down to $2 million, declare the artist a lousy painter.

title: Award to Local Director For Wetlands Advocacy
description: WHEN Laura Tessier returned to her desk at the County Soil and Conservation District office in White Plains last month after a vacation, she found a letter informing her that she was one of six winners of the first National Wetlands Awards. The honor was for her ''commitment to wetlands conservation,'' said Nicole Veilleux, who wrote the letter and is editor of The National Wetlands Newsletter in Washington.

title: Brace Krag Is Married To Kristen B. Peterson
description: Kristen Bouvier Peterson, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Peterson 3d of Bernardsville, N.J., was married there yesterday at St. Bernard's Episcopal Church to William Brace Krag Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Krag of Grosse Pointe Farms, Mich. The Rev. Frederick Stephen Baldwin officiated.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There are still some people around who truly believe that such words as ''dear'' and ''darling'' used in greetings and introductions indicate an intimate relationship, or at least a close friendship with the man or woman in question. Nothing could be further from the truth. What it actually indicates in most cases is that the greeter or introducer has totally forgotten your name.

title: May Our Postage Stamps Never Be Triangular
description: To the Editor:

title: In the End, It Was Dent Who Set Winfield Trade in Motion
description: When Bucky Dent played for the Yankees in the turbulent days that gave birth to baseball's Bronx Zoo, he studiously avoided involvement in the mad, mad world of George and Billy and Reggie. Ron Guidry, Willie Randolph and Dent were the best at remaining quiet and aloof from the daily turmoil.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Desert Bloom of Love

title: FEMINISM AND THERAPY
description: As a wife, mother, professional nurse and teacher, I say it's time the women's movement supported the importance of the work of women like me. Instead, many feminists of this revolution have tried to persuade me and my peers to abandon our ''women's work.'' As a result, the exhilaration I felt in my 1970's consciousness-raising groups has turned to ashes.

title: Corrections
description: Two photographs were transposed last week in the Headliners column. A picture of Frank Herbert Reed, the recently released hostage, was at the top of the column. Senator Dave Durenberger of Minnesota was pictured at the bottom.

title: L. Gordon Hill Dies; Retired General, 67
description: Maj. Gen. L. Gordon Hill, retired, a former chief of public information for the Army and its main press spokesman in Saigon in the late 1960's, died of cardiac arrest on Friday at Fairfax (Va.) Hospital. He was 67 years old and lived in Burke, Va.

title: Lifestyle;   A Big Hug (the Noisier the Better) for a Friend of Young Art Lovers
description: The men wore safety pins, instead of studs, on their formal shirts, as Thomas N. Armstrong 3d always does. The women wore bow ties because Mr. Armstrong has never been one for a four-in-hand. Another nod to the guest of honor was the windup toys at dinner, especially the dancing tomatoes.

title: Wheaton College
description: Former Senator Paul E. Tsongas of Massachusetts yesterday urged the 253 graduates at the 155th commencement of Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., to take responsibility for the future, emphasized the importance of preserving the environment and encouraged his audience to shape the future through public office. Queen Noor of Jordan, the former Lisa Najeeb Halaby, received an honorary degree for her efforts to enhance the quality of life in Jordan and, through the Noor Al Hussein Foundation, for overseeing many projects to promote education, environmental protection, child care, social welfare and women's development. Other recipients of honorary degrees were Kathryn S. Fuller, president of the World Wildlife Fund; the author Jonathan Kozol, and Professor Emeritus Holcombe M. Austin of Wheaton.

title:
Review/Recital;

A Pianist From Japan
description: LEAD: Mayumi Naruko Jensen, a Japanese pianist who studied in Tokyo, Vienna, New York, and Grenoble, France, made her New York debut with a suitably international program on Tuesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. Her program included French, Japanese, Danish and Norwegian works.

title: Employee Disgruntlement and Productivity
description: To the Editor:

title: Several Spring Programs Stand Out
description: THE spring concert season is just about over. But a few worthy programs remain on the agenda.

title: HARVARD LAW SCHOOL
description: It seems ironic that Dean Robert C. Clark, who ''deplored contemporary students' ignorance 'of how one goes about proving something,' '' should use obfuscating language himself in trying to justify corporate law as a career choice. ''Corporate law,'' he says, ''is intensely moral, you know.'' The challenge of it, he says, is ''to devise optimal controls on managerial discretion.''

title: In Praise of Older Women
description: To the Editor:

title: A View of Aging, From Under a Raft
description: LEAD: NOW is the time, really past the time, when plans for the summer vacation should be in place. Early plans are particularly needed by now if an extended family or other group gathering is projected.

title: Was This Exhibition Necessary?
description: What must be conceded about ''The Passionate Eye: Impressionist and Other Master Paintings From the E. G. Buhrle Collection,'' at the National Gallery of Art through July 15, is that it includes 85 works of quality and consistency.

title: THE TANGY FLAVORS OF MARSEILLES
description: When I visit Marseilles it is for a cure de poisson, for the city is a fish lover's paradise unequaled in France. At the tip of the Vieux Port, along the weather-beaten Quai des Belges, the city awakens to the familiar cries of the fishmonger. It's a rough and ancient symphony as fishermen, their wives and their children, begin to set out the daily catch.

title: Lawnside Journal;   Boroughwide Effort Saves a House Used by Runaway Slaves
description: THE stage was set for the start of construction of King's Court, a development of 20 town houses here in Camden County.

title: Condos Surging As Resort Choice
description: RENTALS of resort condominium are booming. What is propelling them is the need of families with two or three children to economize on food by having some meals in and to get enough space while spending a week skiing or visiting Disney World. Anyone who has crowded a family with two children into a motel room needs no hard sell to know why renting a place with two rooms for sleeping, two baths, two television sets and a kitchen is a step forward.

title: Israel's Kibbutz Guesthouses
description: AMONG Israel's best-kept secrets are the guesthouses of its kibbutzim. About 25 kibbutz-operated hotels and holiday villages set up by these collective settlements are scattered throughout the country, from the northern Galilee to the Negev, from the Mediterranean to the Jordan River. They offer visitors a chance to escape the crowded cities and relax in an informal and intimate atmosphere. Accommodations range from the sparse to the almost luxurious, the food is wholesome and plentiful, the prices affordable.

title: Loved Ahab. Hated the Whale.
description: ''Call me, Ishmael. We'll do lunch.''

title: Help Afghans Live With - Not Kill - Each Other
description: To the Editor:

title: RECIPE FOR RIDING OUT A STORM
description: THUNDER CAKE

title: Sharing Secrets of Enamel
description: THE seven members of the Enamel Guild of New Jersey decided to share the secrets of their ancient craft in the show window and display area of the First Mountain Crafters Gallery here. ''People just don't understand how it's done,'' said Katharine Wood of Princeton, a guild member.

title: ALL PAWS ON DECK
description: RIPTIDE

title: SPEAKERS FISH THE DEPTHS FOR BASS
description: In general, accountants and musicians have little in common. Yet they agree on the importance of the bottom line.

title: The Downfall of Drexel Weakens a Soft Market
description: IN just a few words - ''Here are the keys'' - the investment banking firm of Drexel Burnham Lambert let its landlord know that it would no longer be needing 108,000 square feet of space in the Fulton Landing development on the Brooklyn waterfront.

title: Owners Meet to Confront New and Old Issues
description: The National Football League owners will gather in Dallas on Wednesday and Thursday to address a bushel of items. The agenda includes awarding Super Bowl XXVIII in 1994 to either Atlanta, New Orleans, Tampa, Fla., or Miami; the introduction of the league's new drug advisers, Dr. John Lombardo (steroids) and Dr. Lawrence S. Brown (street drugs), and discussing the merits of allowing corporations to own franchises.

title: Lithuania Debates Gorbachev Demand
description: The Lithuanian Parliament began today to debate how far the republic was willing to retreat from its declaration of independence in an attempt to coax the Kremlin to discuss the issue.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: Many of the top-ranked stars on the international scene are used to playing against each other but have never played as partners. That situation was remedied for some earlier this month at the World Individual, hosted by Omar Sharif at the Showboat Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City.

title: To Recover U.S. Hostages, Declare the 'War' Over
description: LEAD: EUPHORIA arising from the release of two of the American hostages held in Lebanon must be tempered by the recognition of how difficult further progress is going to be.

title: SUNY Graduating First Deaf Student
description: LEAD: AMONG the seniors who will receive degrees from the State University of New York at Purchase today will be the first deaf student to graduate in the college's almost 20-year history.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: CARLA LENA MAXWELL;

How 'Flying Around' Became a Way of Life
description: LEAD: MANY a little girl dreams of being a dancer. Growing up in Larchmont in the 1950's, Carla Lena Maxwell didn't specifically have that dream, but her talent was discovered early and nurtured and the rest is dance history.

title: Review/Music;   2 Masters Of Blues Go North
description: Snooks Eaglin and Johnny Adams, two New Orleans blues singers who rarely travel to the North - and two of the greatest blues musicians alive - came to the Lone Star Roadhouse on Monday night to perform and be videotaped (on high-definition television equipment) for a performance collection of the Smithsonian Institution, a project of the Rhythm and Blues Foundation. They shared a bill with Charles Brown, a pianist and singer, and Ruth Brown (no relation), who has been a Lone Star regular during her stint in the cast of ''Black and Blue.'' But the New Orleans contingent made the night exceptional, one for the archives.

title: U.S. May Tell What It Paid for Noriega's Services
description: Under the pressure of subpoenas, the United States Government is likely to disclose for the first time the amount of money it paid Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama in the years he worked for American intelligence agencies, two Justice Department officials involved in the case say.

title:
IN THE NEW YORK REGION: LONG ISLAND;

Military Cuts Moving Grumman Into Development and Leasing
description: LEAD: HANGING in the lobby of the Grumman Corporation's headquarters building in Bethpage is a wall-size illustration of the lunar module's first moon landing, along with scale models of other Grumman craft starting with a pontoon float plane built in 1930.

title: Software Offers Solid Future
description: When William Gates, co-founder and chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, recruits young programmers he looks for the sharpest college graduates who excel in mathematics or physics. For example, scoring in the nation's top 100 in the prestigious Putnam exam, a puzzle-solving mathematics test for college students, will guarantee a career with the Redmond, Wash., software producer, the nation's second-largest.

title: Lynn J. Griffo Is Wed To Jay Mark Sackman
description: Lynn Jennifer Griffo, a daughter of Betty A. Griffo of New City, N.Y., and Henry P. Griffo of Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Jay Mark Sackman, a son of Michael Sackman of Boca Raton, Fla., and the late Lulu R. Sackman. The Rev. Richard D. Leonard officiated at the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York.

title: Miss Smilow, Legal Assistant, to Wed Jeffrey Varsa, Lawyer, in September
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joel E. Smilow of Westport, Conn., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter, Susan D. Smilow, and Jeffrey D. Varsa, the son of Dr. Evelyn E. Handler of West Newton, Mass., and George Varsa of New York.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: WHY CAN'T YOU BEHAVE? A GUIDE TO BOOKS ON MANNERS
description: I come from a funny family. We have a lot of family jokes. Most of them are purely silly, such as the name Treddy I. Biotical, which stemmed from a made-up disease, which in turn stemmed from something else too long and silly to explain. But one of our jokes, initially, did not even remotely resemble a joke. It was the simple question, ''Would you do that in a restaurant?''

title: Bus Crash Kills 1 and Hurts 44
description: A charter bus carrying European tourists lost its brakes on a winding mountain highway on Friday, slammed into an embankment and rolled over, killing one person and injuring 44 others, the authorities said. The the dead woman was identified as Marguerite Finat, 60 years old, of France. The bus, operated by Southwest Charter Co., had left Las Vegas for Mammoth Lakes.

title: WHY IT TOOK SO LONG
description: I was working as a newspaperman when I was drafted into the Army during the Korean War, and I decided to write a continuing column about it for my paper called This New Army, which was what everybody was calling that same old Army in those days. I wrote about how unbelievably stupid sergeants and corporals were, how unspeakably dreadful Army food was and how very peculiarly the general behaved when he noticed I was marching out of step.

title: HARVARD LAW SCHOOL
description: I was dismayed by the false impression Ken Emerson gave that I am among a supposed group of professors who ''politely but pointedly distance themselves from [Alan] Dershowitz.'' Not only is Alan a friend of mine, but I have enormous respect for the important work he does.

title: IS THE SOUTH POLE SAFE FOR PENGUINS?
description: ANTARCTICA

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Breast Cancer? Don't Kid Yourself
description: LEAD: EIGHTY percent of breast lumps are not cancerous. On the Long Island Weekly Opinion page recently, Matilda Cuomo urged all women to have more mammograms. Right on, Matilda! Breast examination fear killed my sister. Early breast examination saved my life. Twice.

title: >Furry Characters Teach Good Health to Children
description: HOW do you teach the importance of health to young children? By entertaining them, said Kaiser Permanente, the nation's oldest and largest health maintenance organization.

title: Jane West Plans to Marry Steven R. Welker in June
description: Mrs. Herbert B. West of Darien, Conn., has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Jane H. West and Steven R. Welker, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Welker of Somers, N.Y.

title: Man, Once Homeless, Is Now a Sculptor
description: LEAD: BRIAN HANLON believes in miracles. Five years ago, he was sleeping in a park on a cardboard box, destitute and drug addicted.

title: Black Attacks on Hispanics And Whites Linked to Verdict
description: Groups of black men attacked white and Hispanic people early yesterday in two incidents that the police said were motivated in part by anger over the Mondello verdict. Both assaults were classified as bias crimes, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Tina Mohrmann.

title: Israel Wakes Up to the Big New Wave of Soviet Jews
description: CONFRONTED with the prospect of a great new wave of Soviet Jewish immigration, Israelis are pondering how and whether they can manage an influx that could equal in magnitude those that built a different, less complex Israel four decades ago.

title: An Easy Mark To Pickpockets Of 3 Continents
description: MY husband has had his wallet stolen or rifled four times on three continents, making him a world expert of a sort. None of the incidents occurred in his home territory, New York City, which, considering that he spends most of his time there and the publicity New York gets on such topics, one might suppose they would.

title: Disabled Youngsters Are On the Ball
description: IT'S not just a hit. It's more like a home run.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester;   Moving Day for the 1834 Gillette House
description: IN 1834, when Francis Gillette built his country house at what is now 511 Bloomfield Avenue in Hartford, people came by carriage from miles around to admire it. The multicolored stone building in Greek Revival style was a rarity in those days of predominantly wooden construction.

title: Review/Dance;   'Combat' By Jersey Troupe
description: The New Jersey Ballet Company made a pleasant impression on Wednesday night at the Triplex Theater. A concern for technical accuracy and proper placement was evident throughout the evening. But the dancers were also aware that ballet is an art of the stage as well as the studio, and they performed with theatrical assurance.

title: Armstrong Wins No. 7 as Reds Shut Out Cards
description: Jack Armstrong pitched a four-hitter to become the major leagues' second seven-game winner and Rolando Roomes hit a three-run homer as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the St. Louis Cardinals, 4-0, tonight.

title: A Changing World
description: These are dark days for the boys of Bensonhurst. Their world is fading as fast as the summer sun over the city some of their fathers and grandfathers helped build. They are angry the way people are angry when they see a sure thing slipping through their fingers.

title: Miss Young Weds Gerard J. Murray
description: Caroline Young, a daughter of Alexandra K. Self of New York and Walter Lee Young of Bronxville, N.Y., was married yesterday to Gerard J. Murray, a son of Constance B. Murray of New York and the late Peter D. Murray. The Rev. Paul McCarren officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York.

title: Storrs Lamb Weds Edward Cote Jr.
description: Storrs Heathcote Lamb, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawton Storrs Lamb of Katonah, N.Y., was married yesterday at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church in Bedford, N.Y., to Edward Troutman Cote Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cote of Ligonier, Pa. The Venerable Robert A. Bryan, an uncle of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Beirut Faction Offers Deal on Israeli Bodies
description: A Shiite Muslim militia today offered to return to Israel the remains of at least two Israeli soldiers if Israel agreed to release several hundred Arab prisoners held in southern Lebanon.

title: Day-Care Center for Alzheimer's Patients
description: LEAD: IT looked like the sort of game a kindergarten class might play.

title: Rousing a Sleeping Industrial Giant
description: Not long after he became president of Mitsubishi Heavy Industries last year, Kentaro Aikawa took a tour of the company's sprawling aerospace works here. Mr. Aikawa spent most of his career as a shipbuilder and turbine engineer for the company in Nagasaki, so he was something of a stranger to the rows of F-15 fighters, Boeing 767 fuselages and Japanese rockets under construction. But he knew that while Mitsubishi's capabilities in aerospace are much feared in Washington, they are poor business in Japan.

title: Fittipaldi Keeps Pole Spot
description: Arie Luyendyk was jubilant, Al Unser Jr. was stunned and Emerson Fittipaldi remained on the pole for the Indianapolis 500 on May 27 after the first-round qualifications finally ended today.

title: ROMANIA IS BRACED ON EVE OF ELECTION
description: Five months after toppling their Communist dictator, the people of Romania will take another step on Sunday on the bumpy road toward democracy when they hold the nation's first free elections in more than a half-century.

title: Fairfax Leary, Lawyer And Law Professor, 80
description: Fairfax Leary, a retired lawyer, professor and author on American commercial law, died Thursday at his home in Villanova, Pa. He was 80 years old.

title: GLOBAL CHANGE AND BUDGET CUTS TEST PENTAGON
description: Beyond disputes over dollars and weapons, the battle of the military budget reflects a debate over the shape of the American military in a transformed world.

title: Dr. Conzen Weds Dr. T. W. James

James of Norwich, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro officiated at the Marble Collegiate Church in New York.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Old Tappan
description: LEAD: The scenes played out on a recent Sunday afternoon capture the homey spirit of Old Tappan: Children gather in a field behind the high school for a softball game, a golfer collects runaway balls, and householders mow and trim their lawns. Traffic is light and the streets belong to bikers and runners.

title: Towns Softening Apartment Bans
description: LEAD: WITH the number of households composed of just one or two people rising at the same time as the demand for affordable rental housing, housing advocates around Connecticut are calling on towns to relax their restrictions against apartments in single-family houses. And many communities are doing so or considering it.

description: LEAD: WHEN a three-and-a-half-acre parcel of state-owned land in Mount Sinai was bulldozed last summer, many neighborhood residents assumed it was the beginning of yet another shopping center.

title: Campus Life:;   A Different Kind Of Education: Going on Patrol
description: While other students are completing problem sets and studying for exams, some college students here are putting their fears aside, donning red berets and, as Guardian Angels, patrolling this city in an effort to combat crime.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: WORLD CUP SOCCER

title: Credit Where It's Due
description: To the Editor:

title: What's There to Do? Go to the Mall
description: THE day began with worthy intentions. Wanting to get away for a few hours, my wife suggested, ''Let's head over to Stroudsburg and look around.'' On this dreary day, gray and chilly enough to inhibit outside activity, yet not really nippy enough to make cold-weather options attractive, the prospect of spending our weekday off uncovering a neat little museum or bistro across the Delaware held some appeal. We ended up at the Bridgewater Mall in search of an electric wok. Exactly how and why this alteration in plans occurred opens up a complex of tangled issues, the most significant parroting a constant lament of our children: ''There's nothing to do around here.''

title: 1 Killed in Second Shooting on Montana Campuses
description: A man who appeared to be drunk walked into a college cafeteria and opened fire with a revolver on Friday, killing one college employee and wounding another, the authorities said.

title: FLIP-FLOPPING FISH
description: FISH EYES

title:
Washington;

Casting a Lure For Shoppers
description: LEAD: THE 1913 Homer Building, expanded, and renovated, is expected to test the District's ability to recapture the retail business it lost to suburban malls more than three decades ago.

title: 2 Killed in Strife in Pakistan
description: Militants set fire to a dozen shops and shot 2 people to death today, bringing to 21 the number of people killed in the last week in clashes between rival ethnic parties, the police said. They said members of the Mohajir Quami Movement, a militant Indian immigrant party, and Sindhi nationalists demanding independence or greater autonomy were responsible for the violence. The Mohajir movement wants to be recognized as a fifth nationality in Pakistan, along with the Pathans, Baluchi, Sindhis and Punjabis.

title: Being Prepared If the College Says No
description: We found James Wickenden's article on what parents should do ''When the College Says No'' (Opinion page, April 15) most interesting and potentially very useful for the parents of college-bound students -especially those students who have applied to the most competitive schools.

title: The Minority Community's Shopping-Mall Hard Sell
description: For some time now, business has been bleak at the Radiance Boutique. And it's starting to wear on owner Ruby Golden, who for 18 years made a good living in the competitive world of retailing. ''I'm not doing well at all. I hate you to print that. But it's the truth,'' Ms. Golden said. ''And I'm not doing well because there aren't enough stores here.''

title: Dorinda Scharff Weds
description: Dorinda Scharff, a daughter of Eleanor M. Scharff of Philadelphia and the late Robert K. Scharff, was married yesterday to Roland J. Hawkins, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Otho Hawkins. Gregory R. Manning, a former judge of Riverhead (L.I.) Justice Court, officiated in the bridegroom's home in Remsenburg, L.I. Mrs. Hawkins, a summa cum laude graduate of Pratt Institute, is a vice president of the Potter & Moore cosmetics company in New York. Mr. Hawkins, a graduate of the Ecole Superieure de Commerce in Paris, is the chairman of A.C.R.C. International, a consulting and marketing firm, and of Jet Vacations, an Air France subsidiary, both in New York. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Q and A
description: Tax on Selling Fixtures

title: After 15 Years, a Kiss for Christopher Lloyd
description: Christopher Lloyd, the wild-eyed character actor whose performances as the visionary time traveler Emmett Brown in the ''Back to the Future'' movies have won him the kind of attention usually reserved for leading men, has been making films for 15 years, since his first role as a member of the Asylum Ensemble in ''One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.''

description: Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Hatterer of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Julie Anne Hatterer and Dr. Michael Lawrence Gelb, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Gelb of New York.

George Chorba performed a combined Presbyterian and Episcopalian ceremony.

Mansson of Mount Kisco, N.Y., and the late Mr. Mansson. The Very Rev. Stephen H. Gushkee officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Woodbury, Conn.

Of the four items, only ''The Steadfast Tin Soldier'' was not set to a concerto. Fortunately, the ballets were so varied that the evening never grew musically or choreographically monotonous.

title: The Comeuppance of a Trial Lawyer
description: THE administration at Columbia Law School will either love or hate ''Guilty Conscience,'' depending on whether it is more interested in being seen as a school that produces clever lawyers or one that graduates ethical human beings.

title:
IN THE NATION: SANTA BARBARA, CALIF.;

After 22 Years, a Downtown Mall To Fit the City's Low-Key Image

title: HOW A U.S. MISSILE NEARLY UNDID DEAL
description: An obscure cruise missile with the odd name of Tacit Rainbow almost managed to unravel all the progress that American and Soviet negotiators achieved in their four days of arms control talks in Moscow, a senior Administration official said today.

description: THE TOWN THAT STARTED THE CIVIL WAR

title: Gun-Control Groups Adjust Their Aim
description: THE national gun-control lobby regards New Jersey's tough ban on assault weapons, which was approved last week, as another sign of the mounting momentum for a variety of firearms controls in legislatures across the country. ''We see a complete change in the political climate,'' said Gwen Fitzgerald, a spokeswoman for Handgun Control Inc., an advocacy group.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: A chart last Sunday on April 13 with the All About column misstated the 1989 market share of the Church & Dwight Company's Arm & Hammer Dental Care toothpaste. The product's market share was 3 percent, not 0.8 percent.

title: Good Grief, It's Glasgow!
description: GLASGOW, the 1990 European City of Culture, after such choices as Athens, Florence, Amsterdam, West Berlin and Paris? People who think of Glasgow as it was in the 1960's, a place of sooty slums and idle shipyards along the River Clyde, will shake their heads in disbelief.

title: Campus Life: Michigan State;   Bringing Back the 60's: A Retro Shanty Town
description: In the spring of 1970, students at Michigan State University built Tent City on an empty area on campus they called People's Park. Students who camped there protested everything from United States involvement in Cambodia to chain fences around grassy areas.

title: Curb on Shrimp Nets Urged to Protect Turtles
description: A study by the National Academy of Sciences has urged the mandatory use of trapdoors on nets used on shrimp boats in the Gulf of Mexico and South Atlantic to protect sea turtles that are swept up in the catches.

title: GOALIE SPARKS OILERS
description: Cam Neely in full windup at the face-off circle. Brian Propp unchecked and unobstructed from the blue line. Craig Janney in flight across the slot with the puck.

description: BASEBALL IN APRIL

title: Demand Growing for Young Maestro
description: LAURENCE GILGORE contemplated the intricate music score spread out before him on the conference table in the Stamford Chamber Orchestra's offices, calmly turning pages and drawing on a steady stream of cigarettes. In two days, he would conduct the premiere of the piece. Now it was time for rehearsal, and the composer, from Latvia, was downstairs awaiting Mr. Gilgore's arrival on the Palace Theater stage, along with the orchestra.

title: CHARTERING YOUR DREAM BOAT
description: For American yachting enthusiasts, the Caribbean is still the most popular destination, particularly the Virgin Islands, the Grenadines and, for those hearty sailors eager for lots of sea, the stretch between Anguilla and St. Lucia. The ideal way to travel these waters is in a chartered boat, since there is a large selection available year round. Caribbean charter holidays are usually active, built around such sports as diving and water-skiing. Snorkeling, windsurfing and fishing gear are standard equipment on most boats. Many first-time sailboat charterers also use their trip to learn to sail.

title: Miss Farber Wed To Peter Cheston
description: Allison B. Farber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul L. Farber of New York, and Peter C. Cheston, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore C. Cheston of Bethesda, Md., and London, were married last evening in New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel officiated at Union Theological Seminary.

title:
MUSIC;

Masterwork Chorus Marking 35th Anniversary
description: LEAD: THE Masterwork Chorus and Orchestra, celebrating its 35th anniversary tonight, will return to Morristown High School to perform in the auditorium where it all began. Masterwork will even perform a major work that it gave at its first public concert.

title: Style Makers;   Delah McKay; Jacket Designer
description: When Delah McKay found herself out of work last year, she went back to her first love: designing. She whipped up a black velvet jacket reversing to an ocelot print and showed it to boutiques in the New York area. Tallulah, in Woodbury, L.I., took six, and Asena in Manhattan took four. Both shops sold out in the first week and immediately reordered.

title: Care-Giving at Home Should Not Cost You Your Job
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: SURVIVING THE HOLOCAUST: The Kovno Ghetto Diary. By Avraham Tory. Edited by Martin Gilbert. (Harvard University, $34.95.) When the Germans swept through the Baltic states in the summer of 1941, they left behind scores of ghettos, each with its own ''Elders' Council'' answerable to Gestapo overlords. When they came to the Lithuanian city of Kovno, a young Jewish lawyer, Avraham Tory, began writing a diary about the transformation of his city into his prison. The Kovno council made Mr. Tory its secretary; he started adding documents to his collection - as many Nazi decrees and council reports as he could obtain - and buried them, along with installments of his diary, underneath a ghetto workshop. The resulting book, ''Surviving the Holocaust,'' benefits from Mr. Tory's mobility as a council official; he moved freely inside the ghetto and out, meeting as often with German commandants as with members of the council and with the Jewish underground. Particularly revealing are Mr. Tory's accounts of daily battles between the council and Jewish collaborationists over how far to go when enforcing Nazi orders, and of the bitter doubts inside the council as to whether its chosen policy - cooperation - would avert annihilation. The most vivid passages, however, describe direct encounters with Nazis, transactions that ranged from the psychotic to the oddly banal. The diary, which has already been used in the trials of four war criminals, has been edited by the historian Martin Gilbert, who gives much-needed background notes on Mr. Tory (who now lives in Tel Aviv), the ghetto and the harrowing dangers of preserving the manuscript during and after the war. The excellent translation from the Yiddish is by Jerzy Michalowicz.

title: A TEXAS PORT FAR FROM THE SEA
description: Think of certain cities and you see the flash and shapely flow of water. No one would have trouble identifying them solely by the configuration of buildings on the banks of their rivers - the Thames, the Seine, the Danube, the Charles, the Hudson and, recently made familiar to us, the Vltava (crossed magnificently by Prague's Charles Bridge, where until last year defiant young folk singers purveyed forbidden Beatles music, ill-sung but earnest).

title: Duty-Free Shops
description: To the Editor: To change from a 750 milliliter bottle to a one liter bottle, as you tried to do in the chart accompanying the article on duty-free shops, you must add one-third of the former, not the 25 percent or one-fourth that you reported. Properly scaling the price to one liter gives $38.40. To reach the $36 for a bottle of liqueur in midtown Manhattan by adding the 25 percent listed in the footnote to the table, the 750 milliliter would have cost $28.80.

title: Can Politics Get to the Roots of Racial Strife?
description: IF David N. Dinkins was judged more harshly than his white rivals in last year's New York City mayoral campaign, as he repeatedly complained, he also benefited from a double standard: Some voters hoped that the election of a black, particularly in a city of reverberating symbols, might ameliorate racial tensions.

title: World Markets;   Vibrant Britain, Dull Platinum
description: The London stock market has been buffeted in recent months by fears of recession, high interest rates, inflation, poll tax riots and the political troubles of the Thatcher Government. After hitting a record high of 2,463.7 on Jan. 3, the FTSE 100 fell 14.6 percent to a low of 2,103.4 at the end of April.

title: Gorbachev's Schedule? Anyone's Guess
description: No hotel rooms have been reserved. The Kremlin has not come up with a schedule. Press arrangements have not been made. No one even knows where they will get the fuel for Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Aeroflot plane.

title: AFTER OPULENCE, A NEW 'LITE' ARCHITECTURE
description: This is not an age with any consensus about style: for all that certain ideologues may claim otherwise, the 90's are starting out to be as eclectic as the 80's. There is still plenty of post-modernism, there is still plenty of late-modernism, and there is still every possible thing in between. But one thing is coming to stand out, and it is less a style than a sense that architecture is going to be asking less of us, whatever form it takes.

title: The Jab of the One-Act
description: The one-act play is a faithful suitor, if short on conversation. It is making its annual visit to the Ensemble Studio Theater for the group's 13th one-act marathon. Running through June 17, at 549 West 52d Street in Manhattan, the program consists of three evenings of four plays each: Series A (through today), B (Wednesday through June 3) and C (June 6 through 17). This year's dozen playwrights include the familiar - Frank D. Gilroy, Romulus Linney and Joyce Carol Oates - and the not quite - first-timers like Susan Kim. Is less really more? FRANK D. GILROY (''Match Point,'' Series A): ''One-acts have the same relevance that short stories have vis a vis novels, or sprint races vis a vis a long-distance run. They are deft jabs, not a knockout punch. In and out. The thought is home before you know it.''

title: FICTION
description: MIGRANT SOULS. By Arturo Islas. (Morrow, $16.95.) In this second novel by Arturo Islas, we meet three generations of a Chicano family as they sink roots in the fictitious Texas border town of Del Sapo. The Angel family - which also figured in Mr. Islas' first novel, ''The Rain God'' - wrestles with problems of identity and values: Are they Mexicans or are they Americans of Mexican heritage? Descendants of conquistadors or Indians? Modern free-thinking Roman Catholics or followers of the traditional church? Even the most self-assured members of the clan seem cast adrift; historically, they have been ''migrant, not immigrant, souls. They simply and naturally went from one bloody side of the river to the other.'' With such marked dichotomies and a cast of complex characters, Mr. Islas has all the raw materials for an affecting saga, but ''Migrant Souls'' fails to deliver. The characters choose to preach instead of interact, and they rarely break out of their typecasting. Ofelia, the eldest of three sisters, is always cloyingly obedient; her sister Serena is the eternal peacemaker; their cousin Miguel Chico, an alcoholic homosexual writer, is forever brooding. The third sister, Josie, is outwardly defiant; she bucks tradition and marries a half-Mexican soldier, Harold Newman, who takes her away to California. Ten years race by: Josie sleeps with Harold's best friend, who is probably the father of her second daughter; Harold unexpectedly deserts the family; and a divorced Josie returns to Texas. Unfortunately, we never learn how Josie feels about all this because the tragic turns in her life are related through expository passages or through artificially staged dialogue. And, since we don't feel sufficiently connected to the characters, their suffering fails to move us. When Mr. Islas simply steps back and lets his characters be - as in a scene in which Josie's father smuggles a Mexican turkey across the border - his writing can be fresh and humorous. Unfortunately, ''Migrant Souls'' contains too few passages like this one.

title: Easy Rambles in South Germany
description: THE hills and valleys of southwestern Germany offer rustic, gentle scenery to soothe a traveler weary from the sight of too many half-timbered houses with window boxes of geraniums. Here, away from the crowded streets of the area's medieval towns, footpaths slope through hills of pines and through orchards where horses crop the grass under gnarled fruit trees. Trails wind past houses whose pastel facades have chipped away in places to reveal ancient half-timbering underneath. Best of all, they provide an occasional glimpse of life behind lace-curtained windows, or of work being done in orderly gardens sprouting enormous cabbages.

title: An Exclusively Male Failing
description: To the Editor:

title: Campus Life: UCLA;   First a Newsletter, Soon a Newspaper On Muslim Issues

title: Marketing the Modern Town House
description: IN Woody Allen's ''Hannah and Her Sisters,'' David, a slick architect, squires Hannah's youngest sister, Holly, and her conniving best friend, April, around New York in his white Jaguar to look at buildings. When they come to one of David's works, a Post-Modern town house of red granite, dark windows and steel tubing, April coos, ''It has an organic quality, almost entirely wholly interdependent, if you know what I mean, but I can't put it into words.''

title: After 22 Years, Teacher Faces Layoff
description: IN a sunlit basement studio at Kings Highway Elementary School in Westport, Karen Ernst, an art teacher, asked a group of third graders to write about the ways art has touched their lives. Without hesitating, Josh Drimmer sequestered himself at an empty table, sat pensively for a moment, then opened his notebook and scribbled:

title: OUT OF THEIR DEPTHS

IN THE NATION: CORAL GABLES, FLA.;

A Return, With Project Incentives, To the Pastel Mediterranean Look

But now, prodded by a 1986 building ordinance offering incentives on height, setbacks and floor-area ratios for building in the Mediterranean style, the third major commercial project in three years has taken on the pastel hues and red tile roofs that dominate this

title: BOMBINGS SUSPECT IS PUT IN A LINEUP

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;

The Bonding Breakfast, or When Daddy's a Soft Touch
description: LEAD: THERE is a myth about the magic of bonding with an infant in his first few weeks of life. What I remember of those weeks is, in a sleep-deprived haze, carrying my son around the kitchen walking in oval and figure-eight patterns counting my own footsteps to block out his screaming. Many nights I was beyond 2,000 when I gave up keeping track.

title: 'Work Harder' One Clue To One-of-a-Kind Star
description: You won't find too many professional athletes like Dennis Rodman of the Detroit Pistons, in any size, of any color, in any place, at any time, in any sport.

title: European Opportunities Beckoning Developers
description: DURING the boom years of the 80's the United States was a land of opportunity for real estate developers and investors the world over. Now, with an ambitious plan to lift bureaucratic, legal and trade barriers among the 12 countries of the European Economic Community inching toward a 1992 start, and the political thaw in the Eastern Bloc raising hopes for an economic rejuvenation in those countries, many American real estate entreprenuers are looking to Europe for the next wave of opportunity.

description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current. Here are some Indian and Middle Eastern restaurants open for Sunday dining.

title: EASTERN EUROPE SEEKS THE SKILLED
description: As a young girl in Detroit, Carolyn A. Kley often listened to her grandmother's tales of what life was like in Poland before she immigrated to America. This summer, Caroline, now a student at the University of Michigan School of Business Administration, is going to Poland to help its Government manage the difficult transition from a planned to a capitalist economy.

Architect Seeks Old Details For a 'Proper' Restoration

Antarctica lies to the southwest, visible to the naked eye as a large gray filing cabinet - one among scores of metal file cases dwarfed in a space the size of a football field.

description: The Southampton Town supervisor has proposed spending $15 million to buy hundreds of undeveloped acres for water conservation, recreation and protection of endangered species.

title: Further Facts On Ducky the Swan
description: No doubt Marilyn Forman is a well-meaning friend of animals, but her letter to the editor (April 15), the ''missing facts'' she purports to supply to my story about Ducky, the one-winged swan, are not all facts, but rather an attempt to justify her own actions.

title: A Newly Acquired Collection, and More, at New Britain
description: A BEQUEST, a show by sisters who never made it but should have and a solo by Italo Scanga: all at the New Britain Museum of American Art, it is a mix to give viewers pause. It ought to give them paws, too, for the Scanga exhibit is but a pendant to a larger show that requires a half-hour scramble over to the Art Guild in Farmington.

title: YOUNG, GIFTED AND COOL
description: IT'S 3:30 IN THE MORNING AT BRADLEY'S, THE GREENWICH Village restaurant and jazz club. The dark, oak-paneled room is filled, mostly with young musicians who have dropped in after their jobs. The pianist John Hicks and the bassist Walter Booker, both well-known veterans of the New York club scene, are laying down a surging rhythm under the trumpet of Roy Hargrove, which is tearing its way through an up-tempo blues. The long, rich-toned trumpet lines crackle with energy, hugging the twisting harmonies like a bicycle racer leaning into a series of curves. Booker, a large, bearlike man, rocks back and forth with his bass, a beatific smile on his face, his shirt soaked with perspiration.

title: California Developers Find New Financing Sources
description: LEAD: Ira C. Norris, a builder of affordable housing in Southern California, has been in business since 1977 and has never dealt with a savings and loan institution. Instead, his company, Inco Homes, based here, has taken the untraditional route of getting construction loans solely from banks.

description: At the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York, Cynthia M. Tripp was married yesterday to David H. Swanson. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth B. Swanson, the bridegroom's brother, performed the ceremony.

Or Sinead O'Connor, with the top album. It's also Z. Z. Top and Midnight Oil and Johnny Gill and M. C. Hammer and Kid 'n' Play and Clint Black and Kitaro and the Gipsy Kings and Carman and the Mississippi Mass Choir and Ana Gabriel and the duo of Rod Stewart and Ronald Isley.

title: Amenities No Longer Just a Seductive Option

title: Northeast Notebook: Greenville, Me.;   North Woods Selling Well
description: LAND sales in Maine's North Woods have remained strong in recent months despite a general slowdown in the state's real estate market, according to brokers trying to sell and conservationists trying to protect the land.

title: Very Very Good to Him
description: With a new $9.1 million contract to salve bitterness and doubt, Dave Winfield is a California Angel now. For almost a week, starting when he was yanked away from practice and told he was being traded, Winfield refused to leave. Even George Steinbrenner, who had fought with Winfield for most of the outfielder's nine years as a Yankee, seemed embarrassed; he said the trade was not his idea and ''was not handled with dignity.'' Meanwhile, Dave Winfield did not exactly belong to anybody, at least until an arbitrator could decide how much permission was required for the trade and how much was given. But negotiations produced a deal: Winfield gets a three-year contract extension, although the Angels may cancel the second two years, at an annual rate higher than his 10-year contract with the Yankees had given him. (The Yankees get a pitcher, Mike Witt.) ''This is good for Dave Winfield,'' he said before joining his new team in Milwaukee. On Thursday, scratched from the starting lineup in his first game for lack of sleep, he pinch-hit in the eighth and grounded out.

title: All About/AM Radio;   Struggling Stations in Search of a Niche

Because Boca Raton is popular with wealthy retirees, Mr. Goldsmith immediately changed the station's format to all-business. This year, he said, the station will make a profit.

title: A Loner With a Strong Emotional Center
description: Eduard Tubin is one of music's loners. Estonian by birth, the composer spent the last half of his life in Sweden. He followed no fashions, belonged to no school. When he died in 1982, he left a legacy of 10 symphonies, two operas, two ballets and a variety of concertos, cantatas and works in smaller forms. Virtually none of this music is widely known in the United States.
