About two dozen people, many of them women, were reported injured; several reportedly received knife wounds.

description: I worry that Vivian Gornick's therapeutic metaphor may reflect some subtle despondency about the times, in contrast to her more stirring message of optimism (''Who Says We Haven't Made a Revolution?'' April 15). My heart sank at the image of the lonely analysand. I realize that analysis may have been an effective mode of change for Gornick as an individual, but it does not describe what she or any of the rest of us did or must now do to right wrongs. Where is the action? What has become of the arguing and the organizing and the hard work?

Ease and Confidence in Ossining

These days strings of glittery pinlights do more to mark the entrance than does the now muted purple clapboard, which, losing the brash intensity and uncertainty of its youth, echos the new-found ease and confidence of the establishment, quiet and low-keyed because it is secure.

They are all bridge fanatics. On a wet afternoon earlier this month in Washington, the motley group gathered at the Capitol Hill Club to play the second annual Corporate America versus United States Congress Bridge Match.

title: Style Makers;   Deborah Reich, Topiarist
description: For fun, she visits formal Italian gardens and scuba dives to view underwater floras. For work, she creates gardens and topiaries. Deborah Reich attributes her interest in gardens in large part to childhood visits to the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Hiking With History in the Pyrenees
description: IN 1700, Louis XIV of France observed his grandson's accession to the Spanish throne with satisfaction: ''the Pyrenees have ceased to exist,'' he boasted. Luckily for those who crave the satisfactions of great massifs, the Sun King's edict left undisturbed this soaring frontier dividing France from the Iberian peninsula. The Pyrenees, a chain running 270 miles from Atlantic to Mediterranean, from the Basque country to Catalonia, retains its air of regal isolation long after the heirs of the Bourbons were compelled to surrender theirs.

description: How would A.T.&.T. have traded had the company not been broken up?

title: MADONNA SAUNTERS DOWN TIN PAN ALLEY
description: Madonna throws both fans and skeptics a curve ball with ''I'm Breathless: Music From and Inspired by the Film 'Dick Tracy' '' (Sire/Warner Brothers 26209; all three formats). Taking a tangent from a career in which she has reshaped a decade's dance music and pop, Madonna has made an album in which 9 out of 12 songs are anachronistic, doo-wacka-doo numbers, mock period pieces intended to echo the quasi-1930's flavor of the forthcoming movie ''Dick Tracy.''

title: BETWEEN HERSELF AND HERSELF
description: PRACTICALITIES: Marguerite Duras Speaks to Jerome Beaujour. By Marguerite Duras. (Grove Weidenfeld, $15.95.) Marguerite Duras is probably best known in this country for her autobiographical novel ''The Lover'' and her script for Alain Resnais's film ''Hiroshima Mon Amour.'' Readers will recognize the fragmented, elliptical style of these works in ''Practicalities,'' a collection of transcribed conversations with her friend Jerome Beaujour. Pruned and polished after the fact by Ms. Duras, these 48 brief pieces contain little in the way of casual chat; the author calls them ''return journeys between you and me, and between myself and myself.'' Like her prose outings, they package considerable pain and self-revelation in a controlled, almost cool voice. Broadly speaking, the subject matter is autobiographical, following Ms. Duras's belief that ''you can talk about your life your whole life long.'' She describes an early sexual encounter on a train, her alcoholism, a love affair with a man 35 years her junior and her unchanging ''uniform'' of a ''black cardigan, straight skirt, polo-neck sweater and short boots in winter.'' These notations of her life's ''practicalities'' often rise to a bleak poetry. She is also amusingly tart on the subject of other writers: Sartre, for example, is ''the Solzhenitsyn of a country without a Gulag.'' When she starts ruminating, though, the book sometimes founders under its cargo of epigrammatic goods - phrase upon fluent phrase, all of them seemingly assembled from a kind of philosophical Lego set whose main elements are death, madness, memory and sex. Granted, these same elements form the backbone of Ms. Duras's best fiction. But there, under the pressure of narrative, they combine in a mysterious and powerful fusion. In conversation, they remain diffuse abstractions - a brilliant writer's table talk, forgotten halfway through dessert.

Behind the manager, more than two dozen Mets had begun to jog a lap around the field. And as Johnson spoke, Darryl Strawberry, hatless in the sun, was moving slowly in the middle of the pack along the third-base line toward home plate.

description: Herbert Friedman of New York has announced June wedding plans for Andrea L. Echikson, the daughter of the late Lee Friedman, and Tom A. Bernstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Bernstein of Bedford, N.Y.

title: Journeys With Johann
description: On Friday at 9 P.M., PBS will broadcast ''The Stations of Bach,'' a 90-minute biography structured around a tour of the places Bach (at right) lived in or visited throughout Germany. The cameras visit Bach's birthplace in Eisenach and various later stops, including Weimar, Dresden, Celle and Hamburg, offering views of sumptuous churches, palaces and countryside. In commentary by the violinist James Buswell and interviews with scholars, the composer is presented in a warmly human light, which ultimately makes the scope of his achievement, represented in performances by Mr. Buswell and prominent East German Baroque specialists, seem only more remarkable. -2> A presentation of South Carolina ETV, the program was conceived by its executive producer, Mordecai Bauman (at left). Mr. Bauman, who is 78 and lives in Manhattan's Greenwich Village, has plied a varied career in the arts and education. After heading the opera department of the Cleveland Institute of Music, he founded Indian Hill, a summer arts program in Stockbridge, Mass., in 1952 and ran it for 25 years. But this is his first television production.

title: On Screen They're a Brotherhood
description: Michelle Pfeiffer slithered and sang on a piano and walked away with THE FABULOUS BAKER BOYS (1989, I.V.E., $89.98), Steve Kloves's stylish first film, to be released this week. But the movie owes a good share of its sophisticated charm to strong, generous performances by its male stars, updating a theme as old as Cain and Abel - only here it's nonviolent and has music. As a down-and-out lounge act, the real-life siblings Jeff Bridges, the heartthrob brother, and Beau Bridges, the sturdy brother, make the tensions, jealousies and loyalties of brotherhood subterranean and believable.

title: With 'Woman in Mind,' McCarter Bids a Farewell
description: ALTHOUGH Alan Ayckbourn was called ''England's prolific present-day Bard'' upon the production of his 37th play last year - Shakespeare wrote 36 - it is as ''the English Neil Simon'' that his limited reputation in the commercial theater is still defined. As catch phrases go, ''the comic laureate of Britain's middle class'' might be the handiest one for theatergoers who know more of Mr. Ayckbourn than Broadway has presented, but less than has appeared countrywide and in England, where the laughter provoked by his plays is clouded by agitation and forboding.

title: Children Learn To Put Things Off By Watching
description: PROCRASTINATION is so common a trait that it seems a natural human tendency - a minor personality flaw and sometimes humorous. We are entertained by news coverage of dual national events highlighting the ultimate in mass procrastination; each spring hordes of taxpayers wait in lines at the post office to file last-minute returns. And toward year's end the masses rush to complete their purchases on Christmas Eve. Because adult procrastination appears harmless, we tend to believe that it is equally so for children. It is not!

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Doylestown's Tools on Mercer Mile
description: Three stone buildings within a mile of one another house one of the largest and most comprehensive collections of tools and machinery from the 18th, 19th and early 20th centuries - a tribute to America's industrial revolution.

title: Currency;   Ending the Week on an Up Note
description: It was an up week, but just a little, for the dollar. After falling against the Japanese yen in the beginning of the week, the dollar inched back Thursday and Friday. It also rose those two days against other major currencies, except for the British pound. It is not clear if the rally is just a correction after the sharp drop of the week before or rather the start of a new trend. But the overall outlook for the dollar is still bearish because of the expectation that interest rates in the United States will remain stable or even decline. Meanwhile, the British pound got its lift from new signals that the Conservative Government of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher would move into the European Monetary System soon. Such a move would add some stability to the pound.

title:
TELEVISION;

A Step That Even a Daring Director Took Warily
description: LEAD: It took some convincing before the director Lamont Johnson, who cut his teeth on live television in the 50's and is now arguably one of the industry's elder statesman, finally agreed to take on ''Voices Within: The Lives of Truddi Chase,'' a four-hour mini-series starring Shelley Long as Truddi, which will be broadcast tonight and tomorrow on ABC at 9 P.M.

title: Questions From the Paymasters In Afghanistan's No-Win War
description: THE senior Pakistani official looked warily about the room at a diplomatic gathering here last week. ''In a practical sense, it's all over,'' he said, referring to the issue he has been wrestling with as a member of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's inner circle.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: LIBRARY-RAISING

title: Mutual Funds;   Bracing for Tougher Times
description: Once upon a time - more than 120 years ago - a small East Texas river town called Jefferson was thriving as steamships carried cotton and timber down the Red River to the Mississippi and thence to New Orleans. Then one day, the railroad magnate Jay Gould (no relation to this writer) came to Jefferson. He wanted to bring his railroad through town, but local leaders scoffed and Jay Gould took his railroad plans somewhere else. Not long afterward, the Red River around Jefferson became unnavigable and the once-booming town boomed no more.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: An important focus of do-it-yourself stamp collecting is the maximum card, which straddles the intersection of philately and deltiology - the study of postcards.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;

Car Washing And Courtship
description: LEAD: THE neighborhood I live in, one of the oldest areas of Berkeley Heights, is predominantly Italian. Just about everyone in the neighborhood is distantly related in some way to everyone else and has at least one close relation living nearby.

title: Fashion;   Gardening Clothes, for Digging and Now, for Discoing
description: The sap flows, the soil parts, and the green shafts burst into life. Ta-dah! Earth's very own spring style statement, mostly in conservative greens (followed by a blooming orgy of color), has inspired fashion makers in every category this season, from Ungaro to the Gap.

title: After 2d Bensonhurst Verdict, A March Amid Cries for Calm
description: The Bensonhurst and East New York sections of Brooklyn struggled to return to normal yesterday in the wake of a racially charged murder trial that ended in an outburst of raw emotion on Friday night.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

Selling a House, With Help, on Your Own
description: LEAD: THE Shannons' home on Plitt Avenue in South Farmingdale, like its well-tended neighbors, is neat, attractive and similar to thousands of others for sale on Long Island.

title: Bolivians Switch Crops as Coca Market Falls
description: Felix Lazo's harvest of coca leaves lay on the floor of his cinder-block house, unsold because actions against drug dealers and processing laboratories in Bolivia and elsewhere have destroyed the market for the raw material of cocaine.

title: Corrections
description: An air fare listing in the Travel Watch column on page 21 of the Travel section today includes erroneous entries for the New York-Chicago route. Pan Am's lowest restricted round-trip fare for the route is $250; its lowest unrestricted fare for the same route is $533. American, Continental, Northwest, TWA, United and USAir also offer the $250 fare.

title: Review/Music;   Ladysmith Black Mambazo With Oldies and Novelties
description: For most of Ladysmith Black Mambazo's late set Tuesday night at S.O.B.'s, the 10-man chorus from South Africa seemed untouched by the last few years, when it was brought to worldwide attention after its appearance on Paul Simon's ''Graceland'' album. The set included the first song written by the group's leader, Joseph Shabalala (in 1965), as well as songs from its new album, ''Two Worlds, One Heart'' (Warner Brothers). And the musical vocabulary, called isicatamiya (the stalking style, named for its dramatic dynamic contrasts), has not changed much over 25 years.

title: Poland's 'Big Bang': Too Much Too Fast?
description: I have just returned from Poland where I met with many of its leading economists and politicians. From the vantage point of the United States, it may look like that country's commitment to a quick transition to a market economy, which some call the ''big bang,'' is universal. But my discussion with economists and politicans in Warsaw, revealed that some Polish leaders think the pendulum has swung too far too fast.

title: Arms Talks: Essential, but Less Sexy
description: WHEN Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, began their talks here last week, Soviet television buried its reporting of the event in a 15-second film clip that followed agricultural news and an item about the visiting Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak.

title: ETHIOPIAN RULERS SEEN AS IMPERILED
description: After failing three times in the last two months to retake a strategic Red Sea port, and losing more than 30,000 soldiers either killed, wounded or captured, the military Government of Ethiopia is in imminent danger of collapse, Western diplomats say.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Little Mermaid

title: Why Lord Weary Was Weary
description: To the Editor:

title: A Sense of Discovery in Landscapes
description: WHAT was previously the Squibb Gallery has become the Gallery at Bristol-Myers Squibb. Titles must expand along with capitalism, it seems. Still, there is much to be grateful for: this could have been the Gallery at Bristol-Myers Beech-Nut Life Savers Squibb if the pharmaceutical company had not sold its gum and candy interests, in 1981.

title: BOMBAY: OLD AND NEW GATEWAY TO INDIA
description: By Pa and Ma I'm daily told

title: A New Career
description: For someone who won 8,833 races and $123 million in purses in a 40-year career as a jockey, Bill Shoemaker seemed surprisingly nervous before the fifth race at Hollywood Park on Friday. That was because, at the age of 58, Shoemaker was making his racing debut as a trainer.

title: English Channel Tunnel Work Facing Setbacks
description: LONDON

title: FATAL COW ILLNESS STIRS BRITISH FEAR
description: As fear widens that a disease that causes fatal brain disorders in British cows might spread to humans, Members of Parliament have announced a wide-ranging investigation into the ailment.

title: PORTS OF CALL
description: There is nothing like watching from the deck of a ship as a longed-for destination takes shape on the horison and then draws steadily closer. Lights twinkle, the harbor beckons, the anticipation heightens. The allure of port cities, languorous or bustling, remains undiminished from the days when ships came in under sail. (Nowadays, of course, cruise ships are the thing, or you can take a freighter.) But even if you touch down on an airport runway instead of dropping anchor at the pier, the charm remains: Bombay is still Bombay, teeming with life and color; the Galapagos still shelter a fantasical menagerie of friendly birds and beasts; Hawaii remains green and lush, and in Marseilles the bouillabaisse is as gutsy as ever. Being there is more than half the fun.

title: A VOYAGE THROUGH DARWIN'S GALAPAGOS
description: LEAD: Why did I cherish, for 50 years of my life, this unaccountable longing to visit the Galapagos Islands? The idea first took root when I was 7, and my mother read me C. S. Forester's stirring seafaring tale ''Brown on Resolution.'' In the half-century that followed, all my travels seemed to take me in other directions, but even though I never once set foot in South America, the thought of that strange, mysterious archipelago 650 miles off the west coast of Ecuador always remained in the back of my mind.

title: Hotels
description: To the Editor: I read Paul Hoffmann's ''Seven City Hostelries'' (Travel, March 18) with nostalgia. Born and raised in Budapest, I left Hungary in 1940. My husband and I returned many times and stayed in all of the hotels mentioned except the Atrium Hyatt.

title: TRADITION IN A TROPIC PORT
description: Veracruz is where it all began: the first settlement on the North American mainland, founded in 1519 by the conquistador Hernando Cortes. Ever since, this languid and funky tropical port on the Gulf of Mexico has regarded itself as a guardian of tradition, one of the proudest of which is a leisurely hour or two spent sipping cool drinks at El Gran Cafe de la Parroquia, shaded by the arches and portals that ring the city's regal main square.

title: LIFE STYLES OF THE RICH AND SHADY
description: MARKERS

title: As in Art, Quality Sells
description: In art as in stocks, the action is in the quality end of the spectrum, but the rest of the market seems to be alive as well.

title: Walla Walla: Bigger, Bigger
description: A little over a century ago, according to a favored and probably apocryphal story here, the territorial government gave the citizens of this city a choice between a new college and a prison. They chose the prison because they didn't like the kind of people attracted to a college.

title: HARVARD LAW SCHOOL
description: Your article implies that the professors interviewed exert great influence over students. The next time you choose to investigate Harvard Law School, I suggest you shift your focus from the ivory tower to the campus below.

title: Postings: Building in a Historic District;   11 Condo Rowhouses for Clinton Hill
description: When historic district designation comes to a neighborhood, some developers run the other way in fear of the restrictions imposed by the protective recognition. But the builder of a condominium project now under way in Brooklyn was not deterred when the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission included in the Clinton Hill historic district the site where he planned to build new rowhouses.

title: Hers;   Values Which Are Simply There
description: AT THE CHRIS BROWNLIE AIDS hospice in Los Angeles, Maria Cruz has brought soup she made for her 32-year-old son, Jose, who can no longer eat. He lies in bed curled toward the wall, a spindle of a man, nearly blind now. It is black bean soup and, untouched, it has grown cold on the tray beside him. His mother shrugs. In a little while she will put it in the refrigerator next to the paella and somosas she made him the week before, which sit on top of the chicken and rice she made the week before that. If he cannot swallow, at least he can smell.

title: Postings: Scale Model of New York;   '90 Updating
description: The site of the New York World's Fair, internationally famous for its 1939-40 ''World of Tomorrow'' exhibit, is less well known for an equally fascinating 1965 display of what may be the world's largest scale model - 9,335 square feet depicting almost every building in New York City. This mammoth model, containing 865,000 tiny structures built to a scale of 1 inch to 100 feet, has been updated for the first time in 16 years with 125 scale models representing major projects that have gone up since 1974, such as Battery Park City.

title: Corrections
description: A caption with an article last week about movies made in New York City misidentified the background of the film ''Anchors Aweigh.'' The movie was set in Los Angeles.

title: IN PORT TO STAY
description: A grand dame in retirement, the Queen Mary has given up the trans-Atlantic run for a permanent berth as a hotel-cum-tourist attraction in Long Beach, Calif. But she's still got glamour. Consider the Observation Lounge, once the First Class cocktail bar, with its burnished paneling and festive mural and glittering chrome. No wonder that visitors tend to look a little dazed, like Alice in Decoland. Who but William Powell and Myrna Loy could really feel at home here?

title: Finding a Way For Another Kind of Video
description: It's called Off-HOllywood Video: Independently produced feature films, social documentaries, videos of fine and performing arts, or any other category of special-interest programming - much of it educational - that rarely gets into video stores.

title: UP THE BLACK SEA TO BYZANTIUM
description: I sailed to the haunted kingdom of Trebizond from Istanbul, north through the Bosporus and then east along the coast of the Black Sea. It had been the route of Jason and the Argonauts when the land at the eastern end of the sea at the foot of the Caucasus was called Colchis. Now it is the way the car ferry of the Turkish Maritime Lines sails to the Turkish city of Trabzon, once known as Trebizond.

title: Maintaining Job-Search Confidentiality
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Lower Prices Luring Buyers of First Homes
description: LEAD: AFTER soaring during the mid-1980's, Long Island's real-estate resale market appears to be continuing a two-year slide, but some people in the field see signs that the decline may be leveling off as many homes now become affordable to first-time buyers.

title: HOLOCAUST MUSEUM: A TROUBLED START
description: As to Henry Kissinger's fear that a national Holocaust museum might constitute ''too high a profile'' for American Jews, I say we must remember that the lessons to be learned from Hitler's reign of terror are not about guilt or apology or remorse but about understanding that this must never again happen to any group of people anywhere, ever.

title: Camden Diocese Shuns Florio Over Abortion
description: Gov. Jim Florio and other Roman Catholic public officials in southern New Jersey who disagree with the church's teaching on abortion will not be allowed to speak at church events under a policy announced by the Diocese of Camden.

title: Postings: For 28 Eligible Buyers;   Keeping Costs Down
description: Alarmed that housing costs in Suffolk County were driving moderate-income families away, officials in the Town of Southold adopted a new zoning policy in 1986 aimed at cutting the cost of new homes. It is finally paying off: Ground was broken this month for a project offering eligible families 28 half-acre homesites in Southold Village for $30,000 each. James C. McMahon, the town's community development director, said $30,000 ''is about half the cost of comparable pieces of land.''

title:
Northeast Notebook: Westerly, R.I.;

Motels Caught In a Legal Web
description: LEAD: A FAILED condominium conversion plan has entangled several motels in this shoreline community in suits and title claims. But banks that now control the properties have hired managers to operate the motels, and their 125 or so rooms may be open this summer.

title: Forte Case And Memories
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Karen Helle Married To David S. Nemiah
description: Karen E. Helle, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert C. Helle of New Canaan, Conn., was married there yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church to David S. Nemiah, a son of Mrs. William Geist of Rehoboth Beach, Del., and Dr. John C. Nemiah of Hanover, N.H. The Rev. T. Guthrie Speers Jr. performed the ceremony. The bride graduated from St. Lawrence University and is an account executive with Grey Advertising in New York. Her father is a communications specialist with the International Business Machines Corporation in Valhalla, N.Y.

title: Clean Up New York, for Free
description: More graffiti deface walls along the West Side Drive and elsewhere. More trash fouls public space. But city officials cry poor. Cleaning up is labor-intensive, they say; New York can't afford more scrubbers, sweepers, collectors and baggers right now. They're right about the lack of money, wrong about the lack of remedies.

title: Votes in Congress;   Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: Eda Martin Wed To Charles Joyce
description: Eda Atkinson Martin, a daughter of Dr. William W. Martin Jr. of Richmond and Eda W. Martin of Williamsburg, Va., was married yesterday to Charles Hoyt Sherman Joyce, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Joyce Jr. of Washington. The Rev. Frank F. Fagan, an Episcopal priest, and Msgr. J. Joshua Mundell, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at St. James's Episcopal Church in Richmond.

title: SO LITTLE TIME TO MAKE A DIFFERENCE
description: LEAD:

title: DATA UPDATE
About Cars;   Escort Evolves Into Mainstay
description: The 1991 model Ford Escort hatchbacks and station wagons are the most significant new cars from Ford Motor Company in at least two decades. -Thomas J. Wagner

title: A KOREAN DEMAND UNSETTLES JAPAN
description: Nearly a year and a half after ascending the Chrysanthemum Throne, Emperor Akihito has become entangled in an old dispute over Japan's responsibility for World War II reminiscent of the issues that many hoped had been buried with the death of Emperor Hirohito.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title: No Headline
description: The two most obvious facts of Hawaii are the huge sluttish pleasures of its Nipponized beachfront hotels and, in great contrast, its rugged landscape of craggy volcanoes and its coastal headlands, where lava has been pounded by heavy surf into black spikes. Hawaii is smooth, but it can also be rough. I went intending to sample both.

title: Mets Are Weak Up the Middle
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Last Tango in Tangier
description: ANOTHER ROSY DUSK SETTLES OVER THE SET IN Tangier, and Bernardo Bertolucci is up to his usual tricks. In the glow of the ancient chalky walls, under a giant eucalyptus tree, a man and woman bend close, so absorbed in each other they seem unaware of the movie crew preparing to capture a scene before darkness swallows the moment. So absorbed they might be lovers, and yet . . . there's something strange about this tableau. The woman is the 36-year-old actress Debra Winger, her thick brown hair chopped short and her face haggard. Her companion, Paul Bowles, is the 79-year-old author of the semi-autobiographical novel, ''The Sheltering Sky,'' on which Bertolucci's new movie is based.

title: Talking: Pools;   Adhering To Tough New Rules By ANDREE BROOKS
description: A SWIMMING pool can be a community association's most appealing amenity, but it also can be a major source of trouble if rules are not drafted for safe use and in accordance with state and Federal requirements.

title: Lawns Need Fertilizer, but Not Too Much
description: THE more you feed, the more you mow. This is an unwritten law that home gardeners are finding to be true. Sometimes they forget what fertilizer applications will do to their turf and feed generously in early spring. They reason, after all, that it has been a long winter and the grass needs a boost.

title: METAL WORK ROOTED IN THE LAST CENTURY - AND MILLENNIUM
description: English and American examples of the turn-of-the-century Arts and Crafts style have rarely been exhibited together since the style was revived in the late 1960's, even though the movement in this country grew out of William Morris's antimachine proselytizing in mid-19th-century England.

title: Miss Gilbert Wed In North Carolina
description: Louise Melchor Gilbert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Neely Gilbert Jr. of Statesville, N.C., was married yesterday to George Clemon Freeman 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Freeman Jr. of Richmond. The Rev. Grant McGuffin Sharp officiated at the First Presbyterian Church in Statesville.

title: CARIBOU PROJECT IN MAINE ASSAILED
description: Amid demands that importing of Canadian caribou be halted, a new herd of caribou has been released in a forest near this northern town.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Latter-Day Scribe

title: Holly Ornstein to Wed Robert Carter
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Ornstein of Greenwich, Conn., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter, Holly Anne Ornstein, and Robert Mitchell Carter, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Carter of Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: MARCH FOR RACIAL PEACE MEETS JEERS AND PRAISE
description: As a group of black demonstrators marched by, chanting ''boycott'' and ''freedom fighters,'' a multiracial group of religious leaders held a prayer meeting ''to heal New York'' yesterday in the troubled Flatbush section of Brooklyn.

title: Marian Starr, Urban Designer, Marries
description: St. Patrick's Cathedral was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Marian Elizabeth Starr, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Starr of San Francisco, and Arthur Edward Imperatore Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Imperatore of Fort Lee, N.J., and New York. Bishop Mark J. Hurley, a Vatican consultor, and the Rev. Phillip Rule officiated.

title: Wellesley Students Hail Raisa Gorbachev
description: Now that Barbara Bush is bringing Raisa Gorbachev along to share the podium at the Wellesley College graduation, more students say they have someone with whom they can identify.

title: Filming The 2 Sides Of a City
description: LEAD: DRIVING from Kentucky to New York in 1983, Michael Penland was just outside Atlantic City when he decided to check into a motel for the night. Still wide awake after a long day on the road, he ventured from his room on the outskirts of the city to the large, glittering Boardwalk casinos.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Are Speeds Too Fast At the Indy 500?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or return unpublished letters.

title:
Pastimes;

Camera
description: LEAD: A reader in Maryland wants to know what my advice is about buying a state of the art auto-focusing camera that is ''the best camera for me.'' Here are her requirements:

title: Review/Dance;   A Presentation of Concepts by David Parsons
description: David Parsons is an intriguing performer with a stage presence that shifts tantalizingly between the diabolical and the angelic. Like Paul Taylor, whose company he danced with, Mr. Parsons has a big but lithe build and an extraordinary kind of grace. He has an almost indolent authority in motion, so that what he does on stage seems less a matter of dancing than the expression of a privileged relationship with the floor and air.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Now that the weather has settled down, everything can go into the ground, especially seedlings of tomatoes, peppers and eggplants; if the ground is truly warm, bean and corn seed can be planted, but if the ground is too cold, these crops will rot in the ground; wait. Last call to prune spring-blooming plants. Deadhead late tulips. Do not mow where spring bulbs are naturalized; wait until the foliage yellows. Set mowers to cut high, about two to three inches, and leave short clippings on the lawn to decay naturally and supply nitrogen.

title: 'I DID NOT STOOP. BUT I DID NOT CONQUER'
description: LEAD:

title: The End of Nature?
description: To the Editor:

title: Lithuania Debates Concession
description: The Parliament of Lithuania inconclusively debated how far the republic was willing to retreat from its declaration of independence. Page 16.

title: THE IRAN-CONTRA COMMITTEES
description: The trauma of Watergate seems to have left Congress determined to avoid the impeachment process again, at all costs. Our nation is indeed morally bankrupt when President Reagan, John Poindexter and Oliver North can virtually walk away from such irresponsible and dangerous activities - offenses far more serious than those committed by Richard M. Nixon, H. R. Haldeman, John D. Ehrlichman et al.

title: IT'S A DIFFERENT SHOW WHEN DANCE TAKES THE LEAD
description: Dancing came of age on Broadway in ''A Chorus Line,'' in 1975. It wasn't just the choreography, fluid and expressive though the dances of Michael Bennett and Bob Avian were. ''A Chorus Line'' was based on dancers' lives and portrayed them as much through dance as music or speech, elevating them in the public consciousness by becoming the longest-running hit in Broadway history.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

Big Sister Still Inspires Awe
description: LEAD: MY big sister will be 50 soon. I keep saying it over to myself, and each time it shocks again. Elaine is 50. That makes me, let's see, I've lost track in the 40's - 50 take away 6 - 44.

title: Theater Company Tries the Unusual
description: THE artistic director of an emerging small professional theater company in northern Westchester is out to prove that audiences want offbeat, visceral theater.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about how Congress works misstated the profit that Tony Coelho, a former Representative from California, made in a junk-bond transaction.

title: A THOUSAND POINTS OF BLIGHT
description: THE WORST YEARS OF OUR LIVES

title: IT'S GETTING LATE: WHERE IS YOUR SUMMER READING LIST?
description: For those of us spending the summer at home, the public library has become a kind of clubhouse. We 12-year-olds haunt the corridors, carrying staggering armloads of books, acknowledging one another grimly as we pass. The building has no air conditioner, and we are sweating under our labors, but somehow we feel purposeful here in this small suburban branch library, where the children's librarian occasionally looks up at us from her heat stupor, nodding in approval. The walls are lined with brightly colored Snoopy and Charlie Brown posters that urge us to READ!!! but we don't need any prompting. We are way beyond the point of initiation; what we are into here is volume.

title: Everybody Is a Winner At Peace Game Festival
description: TWO years ago, when Francelia Butler thought of teaching conflict resolution through a Peace Games Festival, a lot of people were skeptical. But on Wednesday, more than 1,000 students in grades 5 to 12 will attend such a festival, at the University of Connecticut's new sports arena, Gampel Pavilion, on the Storrs campus. More than 300 of the students will bring games they have designed, with names like ''The Berlin Wall.''

title: Arab Uprising Seeking New Tactics for Revival
description: As their uprising against Israeli occupation unfolds through a 30th month, Palestinians confront a range of divisive and unresolved questions that turn on a central issue: what new tactics can re-invigorate the revolt and counter Israeli assertions that its flame has dimmed?

title: In the Region: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Bayport $320,000

title: HOT TEA WITH A WHISKY CHASER
description: Beyond the want for a drink, solitude can be tricky to achieve in a Dublin pub, for even the urban Irish strive to live up to the national weakness for tending to the quiet stranger's soul. If you want to join the flow, and sample a weave of rich conversation that literally goes back to such tough customers as Parnell and Michael Collins, the Bailey on Duke Street never seems to fail, except when the singing breaks out. Better for sipping in solitude, though, is Doheny & Nesbitt's on Lower Baggot Street, a marvelously dark place of cut glass, mahogany, blue smoke and brass fixtures, where the customers tend more to live and let live, with a brief nod or not, and where you are free to watch your pint settle like the cares of tomorrow, no questions asked. The best perch of all to sip some Jameson's, for my money, has been the front parlor at the Shelbourne Hotel during afternoon tea and scones. There, amid fresh flowers and comfortable chairs, the Irish can be discreetly sketched into memory in the rich daylight that pours through Georgian windows overlooking St. Stephen's Green. They talk just as beautifully as down at the Bailey, and the side of Jamesons's cuts the strong hot tea just right, especially if rain is falling outside on Dublin.

title: Van Rental
description: To the Editor: I am afraid that you missed something in your answer to B. S. of Philadelphia regarding van rentals in Portugal (Q & A, March 11).

title: Twist And Out
description: THE BIG CHAMPAGNE HOUSES IN FRANCE KEEP these fellows around for parties - heaven knows what they do the rest of the time - to saber the tops off bottles.

title: Tech Notes;   Cramming More on the Hard Disk
description: Until now, putting extra data on a disk was accomplished by software programs that were cumbersome and sometimes lost the information they were supposed to store. Now a start-up company, Infochip Systems Inc., in Santa Clara, Calif., has developed a computer chip for high-speed data compression that can be used with personal computers and work stations. The device, developed by Bob Woo and Kai Yiu, can store 90 megabytes of information on a 30-megabyte hard disk without any alteration to the disk or loss of data.

title: THE ARCHDRUID HIMSELF
description: FOR EARTH'S SAKE

title: BLACK BASS SEASON: A QUIET FANFARE
description: Although no fanfare such as that heralding the openings of the trout seasons accompanies the start of black bass fishing in the Northeast - the date is June 15 in New York State - many anglers have high regard for those chunky, aggressive denizens of lakes, ponds and rivers.

title: MIXING WITH THE NEW HOLLYWOOD
description: Unlike most cities, Los Angeles does little to encourage the unexpected chance encounter. Geography and traffic work against ordinary social interaction. And so the notion of the gathering spot, the watering hole, is almost unknown in a city where meeting a friend for drinks often begins with a 45-minute drive and ends with an $18 parking ticket.

title: Jury Didn't See Any Intent to Kill
description: The jury that acquitted Keith Mondello in the racial murder of Yusuf K. Hawkins did so because prosecutors were unable to prove that Mr. Mondello knew a tense racial confrontation would end in the 16-year-old's death, a member of the panel said yesterday.

title: Drew University
description: George Romney, the former Michigan Governor who is now the director of the National Center of Voluntary Action in Arlington, Va., spoke to Drew University's 495 graduates yesterday on the benefits of volunteerism.

title: PLEASE STAND FOR THE 'WORM NATIONAL ANTHEM'
description: If we accept the fact that James Stevenson is not a conglomerate, the question remains, how can one man write and illustrate as many as half a dozen picture books a year - three this season - (plus illustrating one or two for other authors) while regularly turning out New Yorker cartoons, essays and covers? The answer is as obvious as it is annoying. Mr. Stevenson is simply a greatly talented, hard-working artist who probably uses writer's blocks for paperweights.

title: Waking Up to the 80's in the 90's
description: ''I have a feeling that the whole country slept through the 80's. We were all nodding off in front of the TV.'' On a recent morning in his home in New York City's East Village, the composer Philip Glass seemed anything but sleepy. Speaking briskly, he was describing the climate of ''do-nothing conservatism'' that, he said, caused him to create ''Hydrogen Jukebox,'' his new chamber opera based on poems by Allen Ginsberg.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Lamb Beyond the Ordinary: Seasonings Are the Secret
description: The seasonings - dill, coriander, cinnamon and turmeric - in this lamb and rice dish, as well as the yogurt, are what turn an otherwise prosaic recipe into something infinitely more interesting than a traditional preparation.

title: Winfield vs. the Yankees: A Case of Life and Law
description: Should it matter to us where a talented and rich and aging baseball player plies his trade? Should it matter whether a rich and controversial owner is leveling with the public when he says he opposed the player's trade despite a decade of rancorous disputes with that player? Should it matter whether the owner's aide insulted the player or merely showed insensitivity typical of employers who are ditching a once-valued employee?

title: HOPE IS THE THING WITH FEATHERS
description: TO THE BIRDHOUSE

title: Connections With Michigan
description: Gary Louie, a saxophonist with a fluent, supple technique and a lively interpretive imagination, gave a concert of contemporary works at Gould Hall on Thursday evening. The composers he chose are all associated with the University of Michigan, where Mr. Louie studied. That might seem an odd programming rationale. But the solidity of Mr. Louie's program spoke well for the strength of the school's composition department.

title: La Paz Journal;   Broadcasting Good Will, a TV Host Reaps Votes
description: Every weekday morning, they line up along the narrow halls and rickety stairs of Channel 4, mostly people wearing the frayed jackets, shawls and ballooning skirts of Bolivia's impoverished majority of Indian descent.

The music went from Handel through Grieg and Ysaye and up to Prokofiev and Szymanowski, but Ms. Chung's strong technique and fierce personality seemed the prevailing topics of the evening.

description: Rebecca Tyng Chace, a daughter of James Chace and Jean Valentine, both of New York, was married yesterday to Paul David Magid, a son of Jennie Magid of Los Gatos, Calif., and the late Dr. George J. Magid. Rabbi James Mirel officiated at the couple's home in Port Townsend, Wash.

title: Memoirs From the I.B.M. Dynasty
description: As a small boy in knee breeches, he tossed confetti made from keypunch cards, was dragged along to sales conventions, and played on the Oriental rugs in the Fifth Avenue office where his father ran the tabulating machine business that in 1924 became the International Business Machines Corporation. As an adult, Thomas J. Watson Jr. led the company to such a sweeping dominance of the computer industry that it became recognized around the world as a symbol of American technological and marketing prowess.

title: Kimmins Environmental reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Stories Keep Coming to a Late-Blooming Writer
description: William Trevor, who began to write fiction only in his 30's and who has become one of the most productive and honored short-story writers in the English language, will make a rare public appearance tomorrow night, reading from his newest collection, ''Family Sins and Other Stories,'' at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue.

title: 25,000 People Walk To Raise $4 Million In Pledges for AIDS
description: About 25,000 people marched through the streets of the West Side of Manhattan yesterday to raise nearly $4 million dollars in pledges for the fight against AIDS.

title: Army and Air Force Fix Sights On the Changing Face of War
description: Faced with a receding Soviet threat, the Air Force is focusing on potential new trouble spots in the third world and planning a force that can fight two moderate-sized wars at once.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Shift at Lintas
description: David N. Martin, who last week sold Hawley Martin Partners in Richmond, of which he is part owner, to Lintas USA, has agreed to become chairman of the Lintas subsidiary Fahlgren & Swink. He replaces H. Smoot Fahlgren, who remains chief executive. Mr. Martin's name will now be on three agencies: Hawley Martin, of which he remains chairman; Fahlgren & Swink, which will be renamed Fahlgren Martin, and the Martin Agency, the Richmond agency he founded in 1965 and left in 1988.

title: More Death, Less Justice
description: To listen to Chief Justice William Rehnquist, the only scandalous thing about capital punishment is that America takes too long to execute people. In a speech to the American Law Institute last week, the Chief Justice urged Congress to speed things along by sharply curtailing the ability of condemned prisoners to file petitions attacking their sentences. His prescription ignores the real scandals of capital punishment.

title: Old Rights Campaigner Leads a Harvard Battle
description: As a young second lieutenant in the Air Force in the early 1950's, Derrick Bell found himself stationed near a small Louisiana town where the local Presbyterian church was for whites only. Having been raised a Presbyterian, Mr. Bell one Sunday put on his uniform with its silver bars and asked to attend the service.

title: In N.Y.C. Streets Of Terror
description: As the summer of 1990 approaches, the specter of social disorder and violence hangs ominously over every part of New York City. Rich and poor alike are running out of safe passages. Neighborhoods once regarded as reasonably secure have turned into combat zones. It has become dangerous for people to walk in some neighborhoods merely because of the color of their skin.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

description: A break in a 12-inch water main at the northern tip of City Island caused disruption of service to most of the island's 4,000 residents for periods of up to three hours yesterday.

Acclimate Gradually For Optimal Sweating
description: HEAT is a runner's worst enemy, but unusually cool temperatures can also contribute to hazardous conditions by robbing runners of their most effective warm-weather weapon: sweat.

description: The T-shirts causing an uproar around the Teaneck Police Department bear the badge number of the white officer who shot a black youth to death last month and insist, ''Never A Doubt.''

description: Donald B. Ayer, who resigned May 11 as the second-highest official at the Justice Department, said today that he had quit chiefly because he thought Attorney General Dick Thornburgh had mishandled an internal investigation into the release of unauthorized information.

title: Mystery Deepens Over Chinese Aide's Visit to U.S.
description: The mystery surrounding Xu Jiatun, a senior Chinese Communist official who came to the United States almost three weeks ago, deepened today when a Taiwan-based Buddhist monk came forward to say the official was staying in the Los Angeles area as his temple's guest but would not seek political asylum in this country.

title: You Can't Sell a 'Gorgeous Mosaic' and Denounce Bigotry Too

title: Shawn Fitzgibbon Marries Elissa Birke in New Haven
description: The New Haven Lawn Club was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Elissa Beth Birke, a daughter of Malcolm Birke of Miami and Judy Birke of New Haven, to Shawn Fitzgibbon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Fitzgibbon of Grosse Pointe, Mich. Walter Lawton, a senior leader of the Society for Ethical Culture, officiated.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Font & Vaamonde
description: As part of a reorganization, Font & Vaamonde, a Hispanic advertising subsidiary of Grey Advertising, named Luis Weksler general manager of its Northern and Southern divisions, and Rochelle Newman general manager of its Western division. Font & Vaamonde also named Mauricio Vives general manager of its New York office; Susan Nassberg general manager of its Los Angeles office and Marlena Delgado general manager of its Miami office.

title: Albert A. Grobe, 81, WQXR Announcer And Journalist, Dies
description: Albert A. Grobe, who retired in 1973 as chief announcer of WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, after more than three decades with the station, died Saturday at White Plains Hospital after a long illness. He was 81 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: Disaster Status for Volcano
description: President Bush has declared this region, where 142 homes have been destroyed by lava from the Kilauea Volcano, a disaster area. Six houses were enveloped on Friday and Saturday.The volcano has been spewing lava since Jan. 3, 1983.

title: University's Choice: Stars or Squirrels
description: A dispute over plans for a mountaintop observatory has pitted astronomers who search the stars for the secrets of life against biologists who say there are clues to be found within the chormosomes of a tiny red squirrel.

description: Audrey Ellen Lawson, who is to receive an M.D. from the University of Michigan next month, and Scott Laurence Kaufman, who received a law degree last week from Duke University, were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Achim in Southfield, Mich. Rabbis Martin Berman and Milton Arm officiated.

title: Braves Beat Pirates by 13-11
description: Dale Murphy and Ron Gant hit two home runs apiece as the Atlanta Braves reached season highs in four offensive categories in a 13-11 victory over the Pittsburgh Pirates tonight.

In Changing South Africa, 5 Deaths Reveal Unrest
description: The killing of two whites at a gold mine at Welkom, about 140 miles southwest of here, and the slaying of three blacks in an adjoining township have exposed broader racial tensions between blacks and whites in South Africa. Those tensions are increasingly coming to the surface as a result of the political liberalization under way in the country.

title: Review/Dance;   Not Ordinary Women
description: Johanna Boyce's theater-dance pieces are coolly analytical, heartfelt and abandoned. They are made for women who do not, for the most part, look or behave like conventional performers. And those were the virtues of a program presented by Ms. Boyce and her Calfwomen company on Thursday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: Review/Music;   Harry Edison's Brand of Jazz Improvisation
description: Mainstream jazz can be deceptively simple, formally. The group led by the trumpter Harry (Sweets) Edison on Wednesday night at Condon's (where he played through last night) opened and closed its set with blues tunes and played standards in between. Solos followed the melody of each piece, just as they do and have in countless jazz culbs across the country. But the audience was transfixed: enough music was played during the first set to last the month.

title: American TelecommunicaFtions reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Barnes Puts 75-10 1/4 For World Record
description: Randy Barnes unleashed the longest shot-put in history today, 75 feet 10 1/4 inches that broke the world record of 75-8 held by Ulf Timmermann of East Germany.

description: Year-ago share earnings are not available. The company went public in April 1989.

Software Merger Collapses

title: Review/Ballet;   'The Sleeping Beauty' Amid Embellishments
description: With its majestic choreography by Marius Petipa and ravishing music by Tchaikovsky, ''The Sleeping Beauty'' remains one of the most sumptuous spectacles in the balletic repertory. Much of its splendor was evident on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House when American Ballet Theater gave this season's first performance of the beloved classic.

title: Low Cholesterol Is Unproved Cancer Risk

title: States Take Up New Burdens To Pay for 'New Federalism'
description: Nearly a decade after Ronald Reagan promised to return powers to the states with his ''New Federalism,'' state and local officials say their authority has instead been whittled away with a new generation of regulations giving them expensive responsibilities when there is less Federal money to help pay for them.

title: Nessa B. Wolfson, 56, Professor of Linguistics
description: Nessa Brickman Wolfson, a professor of educational linguistics at the University of Pennsylvania, died of breast cancer on Saturday at her home in the Philadelphia suburb of Huntingdon Valley. She was 56 years old.

title: Something New in Inflatable Boats
description: rrA new design for inflatable boats enables you to fold the craft for storage without removing its floorboards. The manufacturer says that the innovation makes it possible to inflate and launch the boat in half the time of conventional models.

title: Review/Art;   Effects of Men's Desires On the Lives of Women
description: Karen Finley is the latest artist to be singled out in the continued attacks on the financing policies of the National Endowment for the Arts. She is a blunt, sometimes eloquent 33-year-old performance artist who sees her art as a vehicle for social change. She is best known for using her own naked body on stage in an effort to expose and confront male phobias and desires and their effects on the lives of women.

title: FRONT IN ROMANIA SEEMS VICTORIOUS IN FREE ELECTIONS
description: The National Salvation Front, the group dominated by former Communists that has run Romania since the violent revolution last December, appeared to be headed toward a convincing victory today in the country's first free national elections in more than 50 years.

Mr. Thorner, who is 46 years old, will replace Duane Wolter, who will leave Ames in August. Mr. Thorner most recently was chief financial officer of Wheelabrator, based in Danvers, Mass.

You will find that trade requires certain measures when we have decided on those measures.''

description: Satisfied with the progress made in Moscow on arms control issues, President Bush said today that he still has a ''wide array'' of disputes to take up with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev when they meet in Washington next week.

description: The Israeli Army today said the civilian who shot and killed 7 Palestinians and wounded 11 had been discharged in 1988 because he was deemed ''unsuitable for military service.''

description: Joseph Marie Cardinal Trinh Van Can, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Hanoi, died of a heart attack on Friday, the official Vietnam News Agency reported today. He was 69 years old.

title: Lobbying for Death
description: William Rehnquist's latest call for limiting appeals by death-row inmates demonstrates again that even in capital cases the Chief Justice is more interested in speedy and ''orderly'' procedure than in fairness or full consideration of possible error.

description: Delivering the keynote address at Brandeis University's 39th commencement, Senator Daniel K. Inouye warned that while there is ''a spirit of peace and euphoria'' over the changes in Eastern Europe, the United States and Soviet Union could be drawn into a clash over tensions in the Middle East.

description: An off-duty transit police officer shot and wounded a man who reportedly had just shot another man at close range on a subway platform in the Bronx, the police said yesterday.

title: Review/Ballet;   Joys of 'Cortege Hongrois' With Dreamlike Partners
description: The New York City Ballet saved the best for last on Friday night at the New York State Theater, with a performance of George Balanchine's ''Cortege Hongrois'' that was a delight from beginning to end. The ballet is not one of Balanchine's most inspired efforts. Created in homage to Melissa Hayden on her retirement from City Ballet in 1973, it captures something of her boldness and spirit. But the piece is a bit of a mishmash, a ''cortege'' or procession of odd and oddly placed variations and ensemble numbers performed by two contingents, one classical and the other character dancers.

title: Iranians to Shun Mecca Trip
description: Iran's Foreign Ministry said today that Iranian pilgrims would stay away from the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca for the third successive year because of sharp differences with Saudi Arabia. Iran has boycotted the pilgrimage, called the haj, since 1987, when more than 400 people, mainly Shiite Iranians, were killed in clashes with security forces. The clashes came after some Iranians staged anti-Israeli and anti-Western demonstrations in defiance of a Saudi ban.

title: Oil Rig Count Up by 31
description: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States rose last week by 31, to a total of 972, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. It was the third straight increase. Previously, the count had declined for several weeks. This week's count is also well ahead of the 737 total posted a year ago, Baker Hughes said. The Houston-based company's rig count is the widely watched industry index of drilling activity. It reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells.

title: Why Not Stronger on Race Crimes?

description: Phil Simms has heard it all.

title: On Horse Racing;   Triple Crown Bonus A Flawed Proposition
description: When the promoters of the Triple Crown devised a bonus scheme three years ago, it seemed like a good and necessary idea.

title: P. Comanduras, 81, Doctor Who Began Relief Organization
description: Dr. Peter Diacoumis Comanduras, a physician who was a co-founder of Medico, a private agency that provided medical care to people of underdeveloped nations, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Silver Spring, Md. He was 81 years old. Dr. Comanduras, a graduate of Tufts University Medical School and of the University of Pennsylvania Medical School, gave up his medical practice in 1958 to become a co-founder, with Dr. Thomas A. Dooley, of Medical International Cooperation, a private, nonprofit agency that sent teams of medical personnel and supplies to underdeveloped nations. Dr. Dooley died of cancer in 1961 at the age of 34.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Media Business page on Friday about the debut of The Forward, a new national Jewish newspaper, misidentified the general manager of the Forward Association, who is also a co-chairman of the Forward Publishing Company. He is Harold Ostroff.

title: Minerva Salzman Henkin, Lawyer, 90
description: Minerva Salzman Henkin, a retired New York lawyer who specialized in immigration law, died on May 14 at the Quakertown Community Hospital in Pennsylvania. She was 90 years old and lived in Haycock Township, Pa.

title: Fairmount Chemical Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Fairmount Chemical said Phoenix Chemical Co., its majority shareholder, provided Fairmount with a $2 million credit facility for 1990; all existing debt plus future borrowings under the 1990 credit facility is payable on July 1, 1992.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Opposition in Bonn Adds A New Hurdle to Union
description: The opposition Social Democrats signaled today that they would battle Chancellor Helmut Kohl over the treaty on economic union with East Germany, threatening a delay in monetary union and adding another hurdle to the increasingly contentious path to reunification.

title: TAX APPEAL LOST BY MORMON COUPLE
description: Resolving a Federal income tax dispute that has divided the lower courts, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Mormon parents may not take a charitable deduction for the money they spend to support their children during the young people's required service as missionaries.

title: Plea Deal for Agent
description: Lance Luchnick, the agent for the linebacker Keith McCants, the top draft pick of the Tampa Bay Buccaneers, yesterday pleaded guilty to a misdemeanor charge of attempting to violate Alabama's sports-agent registration law and was fined $5,000 in Mobile. Braxton Kittrell, a Mobile County circuit judge, suspended a six-month jail sentence as part of a plea bargain. Luchnick's lawyer, Mark Kolitz of Dallas, said that under the agreement, the $5,000 fine would be given to five charities. (AP)

title: Hormel (Geo. A.) & Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: Share earnings are restated for a 2-for-1 stock split in January 1990.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: California: Giant of the Future. . .
description: With California's June 5 primary just two weeks away, national and international attention is turning to America's megastate on the Pacific. California is in the midst of an unprecedented social experiment with vast ramifications.

title: PC Etcetera Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Young as Candidate: Hard Road, Light Touch
description: Andrew Young offers little homilies of hope as he travels around Georgia in his quest for the governorship.

title: Evolution in Europe;   The Armies of Europe
description: President Bush and some of his advisers are deeply concerned about Soviet reluctance to move toward a treaty reducing conventional forces in Europe, which they see as the key to making political change in Eastern Europe irreversible by getting the Soviet Army out.

title: McMahon to Eagles?
description: The Philadelphia Eagles have made a contract offer to Jim McMahon, the oft-injured quarterback who led the Chicago Bears to a Super Bowl victory in 1986, the Eagles said yesterday.

title: By Design;   Through Rose-Colored Glasses
description: This season the coolest shades come in the hottest colors.

title: Rainfall in Tropics
description: A meteorologist has developed a novel method of predicting rainfall in tropical regions: monitoring anomalies in the temperature of the sea.

title: In Albany, Much Unfinished Business
description: New Yorkers can be excused for thinking that the State Legislature had nothing on its agenda this year other than passing a budget.

title: USAir Stirs Speculation In Promotion
description: Seth E. Schofield has been promoted to the post of president and chief operating officer of USAir Inc., the airline unit of USAir Group Inc.

title: Chiat/Day Consolidates Operations
description: IN an effort to consolidate its North American operations, Chiat/Day/ Mojo said yesterday that it would sell a majority of its San Francisco office to several agency executives. Chiat also announced changes in the management of its Canadian division, including the appointment of a new president and the departure of its creative director.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;   Law That Created Crime Victims' Fund Is Upheld
description: The Supreme Court today upheld a Federal law requiring people convicted of Federal crimes to pay a ''special assessment'' into a fund for crime victims. The assessments, ranging from $10 to $200, generate about $125 million a year for the fund set up under the law, the Victims of Crime Act of 1984.

title: Dow Rises 24.77 Points To a High
description: The Dow Jones industrial average rose 24.77 points in brisk trading yesterday to a high - its fourth since last Monday - of 2,844.68.

title: The Shame of Measles
description: The U.S. is failing a basic test of civilized societies, the provision of adequate health care for all its citizens. The latest proof lies in an epidemic of measles - 82 outbreaks in 25 states. It's not that the disease is uncontrollable. The reason is a failure of political will and public health.

title: Contras' Statements in Conflict on Disarming
description: The demobilization of the contra army remained clouded by confusion today amid conflicting declarations about whether guerrilla commanders would fulfill their commitments to disband their army.

title: Harold T. Vogel, Pediatrician, 90
description: Dr. Harold T. Vogel, a retired pediatrician in Queens, died of a heart attack on Saturday at South Nassau Community Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 90 years old and moved to Rockville Centre two years ago from Jackson Heights, Queens, after his wife, the former Madeleine Bauer, died.

title: Pretoria Looks at Township Changes
description: The South African Government announced today that it is ready to consider alternatives to the racially segregated municipalities that form a conspicuous face of apartheid.

title: Toward Even Safer Food for the U.S. Consumer
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotas That Never Were
description: President Bush threatens to veto a pending civil rights bill because his Attorney General says it would lead to hiring quotas. But nobody, including the Attorney General, has produced anything but speculation that it would. Indeed, the evidence is emphatically to the contrary.

title: A Cheyenne to Head Indian Museum
description: The Smithsonian Institution today named W. Richard West Jr., a member of the Cheyenne-Arapaho tribes of Oklahoma and a Stanford-trained lawyer, as the first director of its National Museum of the American Indian.

title: J. B. Lippincott Is Sold For Over $250 Million
description: Harper Collins, the publishing subsidiary of Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation, announced yesterday that it had sold its J. B. Lippincott unit to a leading Dutch scientific and technical publisher for more than $250 million as part of an effort to reduce its debt.

title:
Market Place;

Masco Industries' Outlook Brightens
description: LEAD: A RETURN to more normal levels of automotive production and a first-quarter profit -in contrast to the loss that some analysts expected - have touched off a 41 percent increase in the share price of Masco Industries in the last four weeks.

title: Review/Opera;   A 17th-Century Rarity, Cesti's 'Dori'
description: Reviving ancient operatic comedies like ''La Dori'' sets up a struggle between archeology and entertainment that can scarcely be avoided. The Mannes Camerata and its director, translator and adapter, Paul C. Echols, are in the midst of a five-performance run of Antonio Cesti's stage piece. To make this mid-17th-century rat's nest of love affairs and sexual confusions intelligible for late-20th-century audiences is a job in itself. Making them enjoy it is something more.

title: Telequest Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Trial Is Stopped
description: A Federal judge in Las Vegas, Nev., yesterday vacated the trial of a breach-of-contract suit brought by the heavyweight champion, James (Buster) Douglas, against the promoter Don King, setting the stage for the case to be heard in New York.

title: Bush Expected to Renew China Trade Status
description: President Bush plans to announce the renewal of most-favored-nation trade status for China this week, Administration officials said tonight.

title: Pop Concerts, Once Cheap, Now Rival Broadway in Price
description: Pop music concerts, which used to be an inexpensive alternative to Broadway shows and other performing arts events in the New York metropolitan area, have been steadily going up in price.

title: Tapping Ocean's Cold For Crops and Energy
description: ON a wind-swept point of black lava jutting into the Pacific Ocean, a small band of scientists and entrepreneurs is generating electricity, raising lobsters and growing strawberries using cold water from the depths of the sea.

title: U.S. Calls Off Brazil Inquiry
description: The United States has ended its investigation of purported unfair trade practices by Brazil, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today.

title: Bishop Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Included gains of $19,000 in the quarter and $39,000 in the 6 months on sale of lease receivables.

title: Jersey Company to Introduce Fast Chip-Making Machine
description: A semiconductor industry innovator who is highly critical of the United States' strategy for competing with Japanese chip makers will introduce a machine today that he says could dramatically improve this country's ability to keep pace with Japan in the mid-1990's. The machine is at the center of a debate over whether it is the correct technology for the 1990's.

title: Lithuania's Way Out
description: The Parliament in Vilnius is now debating a momentous issue: whether to suspend its March 11 declaration of independence. By refusing to do so, Lithuanians might well spoil the upcoming summit meeting between Presidents Bush and Gorbachev. But that would not help achieve Lithuania's independence. It would only force Soviet leaders to get tougher and weaken Washington's positive influence.

title: Telematics International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Efforts to Curb Buying By Boesky Recounted
description: A former executive who had worked for Ivan F. Boesky testified yesterday that Mr. Boesky was so unable to control his appetite for takeover stocks that executives at his New York trading firm felt compelled to lie to him about the firm's capital position.

title: Howard Whitmore, 52, Investment Executive
description: Howard Whitmore 3d, a partner in Miller, Anderson & Sherrerd, an investment management concern in Conshohocken, Pa., died of stomach cancer Sunday at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 52 years old and lived in Haverford, Pa.

title: G.O.P., Days Before Nominations, Still Hunts for Cuomo Challenger
description: With their state nominating convention starting next week, Republican leaders are still searching for a candidate to oppose Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Protests at CUNY Escalate
description: About 50 students occupied the administrative offices of the City University of New York last night and said they would remain until their dispute over budget cuts and other issues was resolved.

title: Free Flights For Investors
description: Australians will gain free air travel if they invest in Compass Holdings Ltd., which hopes to begin Australia's third big domestic airline after deregulation in November.

title: Double Helix Film reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax benefit of $19,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: Nation's Library Calls on Chemists to Stop Books From Turning to Dust
description: AT a rate of more than 200 volumes a day, books in the Library of Congress, the largest library in the world, are turning to dust. But after a decade of research, accidents and administrative delays, the library reports that it is about to take a major step toward stopping the rot.

title: Elsinore Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After provision for investment losses of $4,514,000; operating income was $968,000.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Breaking the Mold
description: By voting for a party dominated by former Communists in national elections, Romania's voters made their nation unusual in the context of Eastern Europe, where recent free elections have ousted the Communist parties that ruled Poland, Hungary and East Germany for four decades.

title: MCI-Telecom Deal Clears Big Hurdle
description: The MCI Communications Corporation and Telecom USA Inc., which announced a $1.25 billion merger agreement on April 9, said that the review period under the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act had expired.

title: Glenayre Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $15,896,000 on the sale of certain cellular assets. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dinkins Rally Tonight To Call for Tolerance
description: With labor, religious and community leaders beside him yesterday, Mayor David N. Dinkins announced plans for a rally in Manhattan tonight to show the need for tolerance, respect and unity among people of different backgrounds and beliefs.

title: Jockey Club Proxy
description: The management of the California Jockey Club and the Bay Meadows Operating Company, which trade together on a paired basis, said preliminary results showed they had won a proxy fight against a dissident shareholder group. The company operates the Bay Meadows race track. Final results of the proxy election are to be announced on June 15, but James Conn, president of Bay Meadows, said last week, ''Based on our preliminary review of the tally, we are confident that management has prevailed.''

title: Putnam Trust Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Greeks to Upgrade Israeli and P.L.O. Ties
description: Greece's new conservative Government announced today that it would establish full diplomatic relations with Israel, making it the last of the European Community's 12 members to do so.

title: Finding Stardust
description: SCIENTISTS from the University of Chicago and Washington University in St. Louis have identified microscopic grains of graphite in an Australian meteorite as examples of interstellar dust, the residue of stars.

title: Multi-Media Artist Sues Political Action Group
description: A multi-media artist filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan charging that a conservative politi-cal-action group in Mississippi had copied his work without authorization, distorting and mutilating it so as to defame him ''as being a mere pornographer and not a serious visual artist.'' The artist, David Wojnarowicz of Manhattan, provoked controversy last fall when his catalogue essay for an exhibition at Artists Space in TriBeCa about AIDS attacked prominent religious and political figures as indifferent to suffering from the disease.

title: Auction Block For Pic 'N' Save
description: The Pic 'N' Save Corporation, under pressure from an investment group trying to gain control of the company's board, said today that it had begun an auction process to sell the company.

title: Computer, Take a Letter!
description: GETTING a computer and a printer to work together should be simple, and it often is. At other times, it can be a frustrating process indeed.

title: Franklin H. Williams Dies at 72; Lawyer and Former Ambassador
description: Franklin H. Williams, a lawyer, educator and government official who was active in civil rights causes throughout a long career, died of lung cancer on Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 72 years old.

title: KMS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bombardier Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said the increase in sales is attributable to the consolidation of the accounts of the Short Brothers Plc and Anf-Industrie subsidiaries. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Portland Hangs On At Finish to Go Up, 1-0
description: Winning playoff games with last-second heroics is getting to be a habit for the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: Edward Steitz, 69, an Authority On the Rules of Basketball, Dies
description: Edward Steitz, an authority on the rules of basketball who helped introduce the 3-point shot to college and international competition, died yesterday morning at the Baystate Medical Center in Springfield, Mass., after suffering cardiac arrest at his home in East Longmeadow, Mass. Mr. Steitz, director of athletics emeritus at Springfield College, had served as grand marshal at the school's commencement on Sunday. He was 69 years old.

title: Henson Is Remembered as a Man With Artistry, Humanity and Fun
description: With Dixieland jazz, Muppet ditties and reminiscences, friends of the puppeteer Jim Henson celebrated his life yesterday as thousands of mourners nearly filled the cavernous Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

title: Ryan on Disabled List
description: Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers, nursing a sore back, was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday, retroactive to May 18.

title: Bid for D.&H. Accepted
description: The bankruptcy trustee for the Delaware & Hudson Railway accepted a $25 million bid for the carrier last week from Canadian Pacific Ltd. Under the agreement, Canadian Pacific will either run the Delaware & Hudson or underwrite its operation by the trustee, Francis P. Dicello, who has been overseeing its operation since February while trying to sell the freight line, which runs from Montreal to Washington and from Albany to Buffalo. The Delaware & Hudson, the nation's oldest continuously operated railroad, filed for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors in June 1988. It is about $100 million in debt.

title: Franklin Holding Corp. reports earnings for Year to March 31
A 'Brave Medical Experiment' Cuts Costs at Expense of the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Acne Drug May Help Block Return of Throat Tumors
description: A widely used acne drug, Accutane, appears to significantly block the growth of new tumors in people being treated for smoking-related cancer of the mouth and throat, according to a study released today.

title: Imperial Holly reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $372,000, or 4 cents a share, and after- tax ESOP amortization charge of $1,383. c-Included after-tax gain of $3,751,000, or 42 cents, from sale of securities, and a $2,212,000, or 25 cents a share, after-tax gain from restructuring of a retirement plan. The company said the latest year's share earnings included after-tax gain of $372,000, or 4 cents a share, and ESOP amortization charge of $4,412.

title: Books of The Times;   Tennessee Williams In Letters to a Friend
description: Five O'Clock Angel

title: The Japanese Secret: Low Interest Rates
description: To the Editor:

title: Ross Stores reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
Logic Devices In Litigation
description: The Cypress Semiconductor Corporation said today that it had amended its countersuit against Advanced Micro Devices Inc. about programmable logic devices.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The show went on, all right, but without MAGGIE SMITH. The star of ''Lettice and Lovage'' was hospitalized last Friday at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital with a back problem and has missed four performances. MARGARET HALL stood in for Miss Smith.

title: Auto Union to Seek Job Guarantees
description: The United Auto Workers union, meeting today to begin setting its strategy for negotiations on a new contract, is clear about its primary goal: halting the loss of members' jobs.

title: Japan Turns Away Chinese Dissidents' Radio Ship
description: Japan backed away today from its offer to harbor a group of Chinese dissidents trying to transmit pro-democracy messages to the mainland.

title: BSN Is Selling U.S. Biscuit Units
description: The French food manufacturer BSN S.A. put its United States biscuit subsidiaries on the block as part of its plan to focus on high-growth markets in Eastern Europe and Asia. The company said its Mother's and Salerno subsidiaries, with combined annual revenue of about $200 million, hold only 5.7 percent of the United States biscuit market. Further expansion would have been too costly, BSN said.

title: Careers;   A European Dean Sees M.B.A. Need
description: AFTER white wine and cheese -French, of course - Dr. Claude Rameau, dean of the Insead business school of Fontainebleau, France, spoke to 40 of the European institution's New York-based alumni one evening last week. ''You have a very bright future,'' he told them, referring to opportunities that have come about because of the changes that have taken place in Europe.

title: In Detente and Cutbacks, Navy Has Powerful Foes
description: Late last week, one American aircraft carrier and its menacing covey of warships plied the northern Arabian Sea. In the nearby Persian Gulf, several Navy frigates and destroyers monitored the traffic of oil tankers.
