title: Edberg Seeded No. 1
description: The top two seeded male players for the French Open, which starts May 28, are Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the loser in last year's final, and Boris Becker of West Germany. Ivan Lendl, a three-time French Open champion and the No. 1-ranked male player in the world, is skipping the tournament to prepare for Wimbledon. Michael Chang, the defending champion, is seeded No. 12.(AP)

title: Bull to Introduce Unix Computers
description: Bull HN Information Systems Inc. will introduce a series of commercial multi-user Unix computers today that are based on advanced microprocessors from the Motorola Corporation, the Intel Corporation and MIPS Computer Systems Inc. Part of the company's DPX/2 family of mid-range computers will be based on Motorola's 68040 chip and will have four processors in each system.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the killing of Palestinians by an apparently deranged Israeli referred inconsistently in some copies to the site of the attack. It occurred in Rishon le Zion, seven miles south of Tel Aviv, not in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip. Later developments are reported today on page A1.

title: East Europe's Sale of the Century
description: The nations of Eastern Europe are about to begin selling hundreds of state-owned enterprises to private investors, seeking to inject money and a dose of capitalism into companies that languished under Communist management for four decades.

title: Stamford Capital GRP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Avalon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $12,000. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $71,000 and an extraordinary tax benefit of $184,000.

title: Information Solutions reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Joseph R. Villano, Decorator, 50
description: Joseph R. Villano, an interior decorator and the owner of Aquarius Design, a shop in Wycoff, N.J., died on Sunday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Jamaica Savings
description: The Jamaica Savings Bank announced yesterday that Federal regulators had approved its plan to convert to a stock institution owned by shareholders from a mutual savings bank owned by depositors. As part of the conversion plan, the savings bank will offer 16 million shares of stock at a range of $7.50 to $10. The stock will be offered first to depositors and later to other investors.

title: Southmark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $104,302,000 and $109,153,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $2,170,000, or 5 cents a share for the quarter and $28,844,000, or 63 cents a share for the 9 months. The company said the revenue reductions were partially offset by a drop in general and administrative expenses and the benefit derived from the non-accrual of $100 million of interest on Southmark's unsecured debt during bankruptcy proceedings. The company continues to operate under bankruptcy court supervision.

title: NYTest Environmental Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Our Towns;   Ninja in the Aisle, Heart and Soul On the Stage
description: When Ed Napiwocki awoke on Sunday morning, it was rainy. ''Great,'' he said. ''Hope it keeps up.'' But by 3 P.M., concert time, it was beautiful. The sun was shining and the sky was a stupid blue. ''Geez,'' he said, ''who needs this?''

title: Hearx Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
M/A/R/C Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fisk's Home Run in 7th Is the Decisive Blow
description: Lance McCullers had thrown two breaking pitches to Carlton Fisk with runners on first and third and the Yankees clinging to a 4-3 lead in the seventh inning last night. Neither pitch was a strike.

title: Orbital Sciences Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Court Suspends Maddox for Refusal to Testify at Grievance Hearing
description: Alton H. Maddox Jr., who represented Tawana Brawley and other clients in racially charged cases, was suspended yesterday from practicing law in New York State.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Missing Middle-Class Black in TV News
description: New York's local television news programs have taken heat lately for their hyped-up coverage of two of the city's nastier racial encounters, both in Brooklyn, between blacks and Italian-Americans in Bensonhurst and between blacks and Korean-Americans in Flatbush. The criticism has been earned. Local TV news, a cousin of the tabloid press, tends to be more polite than its older relative - less incendiary headlines - but the choice of stories and the approach is much the same.

title: DEBATE IN HOUSE ON CLEAN AIR BILL
description: Vowing not to repeat the six weeks of Senate floor fights over an overhaul of the Clean Air Act, the House of Representatives opened debate on its own version today, and lawmakers said there was wide support for passage.

title: Phonetel Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ex-Colleagues Turn Combatants
description: TWO respected medical researchers, once close colleagues, are now locked in a bitter legal fight that raises new concerns about how scientific institutions handle cases of alleged misconduct in research and how they treat ''whistle-blowers'' who bring charges of such practices.

title: Business and Health;   Drug Industry Nervous on Prices
description: PHARMACEUTICAL company executives are watching nervously as drug prices come under growing criticism in Congress and states that are scrimping to pay for Medicaid programs for the poor.

title: Hidden Tide Of Taxes Due In New York
description: To the people who rent cars, stay in hotels or buy bottles of soda, the impact of New York State's new tax increases will be apparent immediately. But consumers will also ultimately pay more for thousands of goods and services under less obvious sections of the $1.4 billion tax plan, business leaders and some lawmakers said today.

title: Mestek Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gerber Is Selling Day-Care Centers
description: The Gerber Products Company said it would sell its 115 day-care centers in another divestiture aimed at getting the company back to the basics of baby food. Fred Schomer, Gerber's executive vice president and chief financial officer, said an affiliate of KD Equities, a New York-based private investment partnership, would buy Gerber Children's Centers Inc. Terms of the sale were not disclosed. The subsidiary provides day care and educational programs for more than 13,000 preschoolers.

title: Ivory Trading Ban Said to Force Factories to Shut
description: Major ivory carving factories in Asia that produced jewelry, figurines and tourist trinkets have virtually closed down since a world ban on ivory trading came into force this year, says an expert in the trade who just finished a survey of the ban.

title: Toward Even Safer Food for the U.S. Consumer;   Drug Abuse in the Barn
description: To the Editor:

title: A Little Frog Outleaps Some Large Outsiders
description: After a controversy over whether they should be allowed to compete in the 1990 Jumping Frog Jubilee, three African Goliath frogs fizzled in the competition on Sunday, allowing a California frog to win.

title: Hydro Flame Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Teacher Charged in Slaying
description: A high school's assistant principal was shot to death and left in a burning school building on Sunday, and a science teacher was charged today with his murder.

title: Mobile America Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
David Lynch Film Takes the Top Prize At Cannes Festival
description: In a tumultuous awards ceremony, David Lynch, the most controversial of American film makers, won the Cannes International Film Festival's highest honor last night as the boos drowned out the bravos.

title: ...Beset by Giant Problems
description: LEAD: The United States is a country in which there are fashions in states and cities just as surely as there are fashions in cars or clothing. Right now, California is being touted as America's future. While the Northeast crumbles, so the argument goes, California works. Its mood is upbeat, its economy vibrant and diversified, its prospects bright.

title: S2 Golf Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Riser Foods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 7
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $400,000, or 5 cents a share for the quarter and $1,600,000, or 20 cents a share, or 20 cents a share for the 9 months. c-Net loss Year-ago results are restated to reflect misstatement in sales reported in the first quarter of fiscal 1989.

title: Mets Meet, Then Turn The Tide
description: In the late afternoon, the Mets closed the doors to their clubhouse so they could try and sort out their differences in a season that has gone awry. In the evening, they did what their manager said they have needed to do all along. They won. It was so simple, so thorough and so convincing that it made you wonder why they hadn't held a players-only pregame meeting weeks ago.

title: Perils of Supersonics
description: To the Editor:

title: Montreal Journal;   They Speak French, but Their Language Is Money
description: Jacques Menard has a tan, a four-wheel-drive Jeep, a good golf stroke, volunteer duties at Oxfam, gold cuff links, a pool, and a watercolor of the Montreal stock exchange hanging on his office wall. But like any self-respecting executive in New York or Chicago, he bridles at the word yuppie.

title: U.S. Investors Sue Philips
description: Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics company, said today that it had been sued by American investors angered at an unexpected drop in the company's profits.

title: Ohioan Gets High Navy Post
description: The Pentagon today announced the appointment of Ben Rose, a lawyer in Lima, Ohio, and former leader of the Republican minority in the Ohio House of Representatives, as Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Navy for installations and the environment. Mr. Rose was a Navy officer from 1961 to 1966, serving on an Atlantic fleet destroyer and later in Vietnam.

title: Arpino Re-establishes His Links With the Joffrey
description: Three weeks after he resigned as artistic director and resident choreographer of the Joffrey Ballet, Gerald Arpino re-established contact with the company in Los Angeles on Sunday, attending a patrons' dinner at which he was warmly received.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Banque Nationale de Paris said that it would acquire Central Bank, Walnut Creek, Calif., for $42.5 million and that the banks would be merged under the name Bank of the West, with a combined balance sheet of about $3 billion.

title: Ballet Theater to London
description: The American Ballet Theater is to appear in London in July for the first time in 13 years. The troupe's weeklong engagement at the London Coliseum is scheduled to begin on July 9, and will include works by Antony Tudor, George Balanchine, Leonide Massine, Agnes de Mille, Twyla Tharp, Mark Morris and Clark Tippet. The tour is part of the company's 50th-anniversary season.

title: Jordan Misses a Workout, But Will Be Set for Game
description: Michael Jordan did not sleep very well Sunday night. Every time the Chicago Bulls' prolific scorer rolled over, he felt the pain from the deep bruise he sustained in the left buttocks when he fell down hours earlier during the first quarter of the playoff game against the Detroit Pistons.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Medical Data: Who Should Hear It First?
description: IMPATIENT with long waits for medical journals to publish findings that are desperately needed by sick patients, Federal health officials are now often announcing the results of decisive clinical trials long before they can be published.

title: Jacobson Stores reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Trial Date Set for 3 Suspects In Central Park Rape Case
description: Three of the six defendants in the Central Park rape case were ordered yesterday to stand trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on June 13.

title: Algorex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary tax credit of $300,000, or 11 cents a share. The company said in the year-ago results it had a one-time pretax gain of $915,000 related to the sale of a building.

title: General Communications Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Knogo Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Franklin Electronic reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Bridge
description: One reason for the popularity of the Swiss team format is that it makes possible a dramatic and improbable finale. One occurred a week ago in the Cavendish Teams event, in which 12 strong squads including some foreign stars were involved.

title: Site of Officer's Slaying Will Be a Center of Hope
description: A house in Queens that became a symbol of the murderous world of drug dealers will soon become a center of hope and help for its troubled community.

title: Century Medicorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $93,112, or 2 cents a share for the quarter and $489,857, or 12 cents a share for the 9 months. The company said all average shares and share earnings are adjusted for a 1-for-5 reverse stock split paid May 11, 1990.

title: E.P.A. Draft Report Cites Studies Linking Cancer to Electricity
description: The Environmental Protection Agency has prepared a draft report that says there may be links between cancer and electromagnetic fields created by common electrical current, an official of the agency said.

title: Rebel Neurologists Say Boxing Can Be Safe
description: THE super middleweight match for new professional boxers at Gleason's Arena in Brooklyn is raucous and bloody, the way the crowd loves it. Many of the punches glance off the boxers' sweaty bodies, but once in a while a glove hooks through the air and connects solidly with an opponent's head. As the stunned fighter regains composure, electrified fans jump to their feet with a stream of cheers, jeers and hoots.

title: Senate Begins Debate on Anti-Crime Bill
description: The Senate today began what promises to be a week of fractious debate on major anti-crime legislation that would authorize the death penalty for 30 Federal offenses, limit defendants' Federal appeals and permit the use of illegally seized evidence under certain circumstances.

title: 82 Held in Protest on Pace of AIDS Research
description: More than 500 demonstrators gathered here today at the National Institutes of Health, accusing the agency of being too slow in finding and testing drugs to treat AIDS. Eighty-two of the protesters were arrested, mostly on trespassing charges. Almost all were fined $50 and released.

title: Joel A. Reiss, Lawyer, 50
description: Joel A. Reiss, a lawyer and founding partner of the law firm of Reiss & Rosen, died of a heart attack while jogging on Sunday in Riverside Park in Manhattan. He was pronounced dead at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Surgery for McHale
description: The Boston Celtic forward Kevin McHale underwent surgery yesterday to repair ligament damage in his left thumb and was expected to be recovered by next season, the club said. McHale underwent a procedure at New England Baptist Hospital to repair the radial collateral ligament and was likely to have his hand in a cast for about six weeks. (AP)

title: Fernandez to Oversee Panel On Big-City School Problems
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, was named today to head a new national panel that will study ways to ease the problems facing big-city schools.

title: Muslim Leader of Kashmir Slain; 30 Die as Police Fire on Mourners
description: A hereditary Islamic leader, the most senior and influential opponent of Indian rule in Kashmir, was assassinated in his home in the state's capital today. When 100,000 angry mourners followed his body through the streets of the city, security forces opened fire, killing at least 30 people and wounding some 200, according to hospital doctors.

title: Editors' Note
description: A brief article by The Associated Press on Feb. 16, about the involvement of a former Republican campaign aide in a Georgia housing development, reported that the man, Edward L. Weidenfeld, and his partners had agreed to repay $720,000 to the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: City on Seneca Indian Reservation Reaches New Lease With Tribe
description: Nine months before its 99-year lease was set to expire, the city of Salamanca, the only city in the nation built on land leased from an Indian reservation, has reached a new rental agreement with the Seneca Indians, officials said today.

title: PLM Equipment Growth Fund I reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Geminex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Highway Crash Kills Family
description: A new graduate of Smith College and three of his family members were killed in a crash on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway today as they drove home from commencement ceremonies, the police said. The state police identified the dead as Bing Kwan, his wife, Miu, and their two children, Albert, 21, and Jaime, 22.

title: Falcon Cable Systems Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kidder Shift To Program Trade Tactic
description: Kidder, Peabody & Company announced yesterday that it would resume investing its own capital in a form of program trading that has been widely criticized for aggravating price declines in the market.

title: Q&A
description: Sea Monster

title: Transtech Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a gain of $2,653,000 on the sale of a joint venture.

title: American General Wins Proxy Fight
description: The American General Corporation, declaring victory in a proxy contest with the Torchmark Corporation, said its slate of directors was re-elected to the company's board by a wide margin at its annual meeting earlier this month.

title: KEY RATES
Herbalife International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Caribbean Select Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Etz Lavud Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results have been restated.

title: General Parametrics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Census Units Understaffed, House Panel Is Told
description: An official of the key investigative branch of Congress said yesterday that as of May 9, more than 70 percent of the Census Bureau's district offices in the Atlanta, San Francisco and Dallas areas did not have enough follow-up enumerators.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS

title: India's Airline Industry Regrouping After Crash
description: The Indian airline industry is going through significant changes since the crash of an Airbus A320 jetliner last February that killed more than 90 people and forced the grounding of its A320's.

title: Calet, Hirsh's Cancer Effort
description: Calet, Hirsh & Spector has prepared a new print campaign for physicians as a follow-up to its pro-bono campaign aimed at the public to promote early detection of colon cancer.

title: Computer Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Lowe's Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
New Bensonhurst Wrinkle: Secret Testimony Is Revealed
description: In a development that could complicate prosecution efforts in new Bensonhurst trials, a defense lawyer yesterday described secret testimony that he said would prove one of the defendants shouted out a warning not to shoot anyone as a crowd of whites ran after Yusuf K. Hawkins last Aug. 23.

title: Chess
description: From ignominy to achievement in three years epitomizes the recent career of top Chinese chess players. In the 1987 Asian Zonal tournament, accusations that the Chinese players were throwing points to their leader created a scandal. Some of the participants clamored for nullifying the competition, although Florencio Campomanes, president of the International Chess Federation, ultimately allowed the results to stand.

title: Bayer-Nova Deal
description: Bayer A.G., the West German chemicals company, agreed to acquire the Polysar Rubber division of the Nova Corporation of Canada for $1.06 billion (United States). The agreement must be approved by government agencies in the two countries. The Polysar unit, based in Toronto, has 3,500 employees worldwide. It is one of the leading producers of synthetic rubber, primarily for the tire industry.

title: Ships' Costs: Mechanical And Human
description: How many carriers are enough? That depends not only on their intended use, but also on the dismal arithmetic of carrier deployment.

title: Cablevision Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the increase in revenues resulted primarily from the acquisition on Feb. 17, 1989 of Cable Television Systems from Viacom Inc. and the acquisition on Dec. 6, 1989 of Cable Systems from Times Mirror Cable Television Inc.

title: Procter Sees Higher Profit
description: The Procter & Gamble Company expects to enjoy strong sales and income growth in the fiscal year ending June 30, Edwin Artzt, company chairman, said today at a rare meeting with industry analysts.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In his first act as the national chairman of the United Jewish Appeal, MARVIN LENDER, said yesterday that the organization has raised $247 million to aid Soviet Jews. Operation Exodus, the campaign to aid Soviet Jews in resettlement, has been headed by Mr. Lender.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's of great political value to show a fairly continuous presence on the high seas. Through port calls and exercises with friends in the region, the U.S. shows it is remaining engaged.''

title: Mooney Realty Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Mosbacher on World Trade
description: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher chided American companies for taking a short-term view of profits and for being slow in taking advantage of new Eastern European markets.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Furs Are Casual, but Acquire the Rich Shades of Jewels
description: The trend to casual styles developed strength as the fall fur shows continued last week. Most opened with shearlings and ended with sables; the line of demarcation between sporty and formal styles was often blurred.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Insulting Gorbachev Now Illegal, But It All Depends on the Tone
description: The Soviet Parliament enacted a law today that makes insulting the Soviet President a crime punishable by a prison term, but only if the insults are expressed ''in an indecent way'' - a legal turn of phrase that won support even from civil libertarians.

title: Pay-Fone Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Yemen Ratifies Merger With Marxist South
description: Yemen's Parliament today approved President Ali Abdullah Saleh's plan to proclaim a merger with Southern Yemen on Tuesday, official radio reports in Yemen said.

title: The Military Role
description: One way or another, the role and structure of the military is up for argument in countries around the world as the prospect of war recedes. Argentina is no exception, although its military issues are essentially of the third-world variety.

title: Father Is Found Guilty Of Poisoning Baby Son
description: A man accused of poisoning his infant son with sulfuric acid as part of a plot to sue a manufacturer of baby formula has been found guilty of first-degree murder and could face the death penalty.

title: Fernandez Removes Principal in Inquiry on Politics
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday ordered the removal of an elementary-school principal in Queens who the Inspector General of the Board of Education said had been tainted by political deals.

title: FT Capital reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $209,000, or 2 cents a share for the latest quarter and a loss of $1,561,000 a share for the year-earlier period, both from discontinued operations. Year-ago results are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Dinkins Plans Drug-Fighting Centers at 9 Schools
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins announced plans yesterday to set up community drug prevention centers at nine public schools, to increase health services for pregnant drug abusers and to create a central office to expand and coordinate the city's fragmented anti-drug efforts.

title: Plan Envisions Cleanup Work for Early Release
description: New York City's new Correction Commissioner outlined a plan yesterday for several thousand ''low-risk inmates'' to work toward early release by performing outside work like clearing litter from highways, cleaning subways and building park benches.

title: International Banknote reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included merger-related expenses of about $4.7 million on sale of substantially all of the assets of a subsidiary related to the acquisition of the company by US Banknote Co., and $1.6 million incurred in connection with the tender offer and merger agreement with US Banknote. c-Net income and included a pretax gain of $11,488,000 on sale of 20 percent interest in a subsidiary.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about proposed military spending cuts misstated a Bush Adminstration proposal in some copies. The Administration has proposed cutting military spending by 10 percent over the next five years, not 10 percent a year.

title: A 'Brave Medical Experiment' Cuts Costs at Expense of the Poor
description: To the Editor:

title: Hancock Fabrics reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Boom in Made-to-Order Building
description: With the nation's financial institutions curtailing their real estate lending, the commercial building projects with the best chances - and in some cities the only chances - of getting financing these days are those that are made to order for a specific buyer or tenant. These projects, known as build-to-suit developments, are experiencing a boom as the nation's developers, most of which build on speculation, try to compete in the custom market.

title: A's Beat Blue Jays, 4-1, As Canseco Clouts 14th
description: Jose Canseco hit a three-run homer today as the Oakland Athletics beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 4-1, in a game that included a bench-clearing incident.

title: U.S. WON'T REVEAL NORIEGA PAYMENTS
description: In what appears to be an effort to avoid publicly disclosing its past financial relationship with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Federal Government agreed today to pay, at least temporarily, the full cost of General Noriega's legal defense against drug-trafficking charges.

title: SFM Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column in Business Day on Friday about the Sara Lee Corporation's transfer of most of its domestic food advertising accounts to Lintas USA listed one agency incorrectly among those that will lose business in the move, based on information provided by a Sara Lee spokesman. The agency, Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor, had been a contender for the consolidated account, but it does not have any of Sara Lee's food advertising and it retains a part of the company's hosiery account.

title: East German Air Move
description: East Germany's national airline, Interflug, will join the International Air Transport Association on July 1, the group said last week. Interflug will become the 190th member of the association, which includes most of the world's leading airlines. The Soviet airline Aeroflot joined last year. The association recommends fares and standardizes ticketing and other airline procedures. It also channels information to member airlines on security matters.

title: International Movie Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kleer-VU Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $131,000.

title: Harnischfeger Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CHRONICLE
description: At the same time that the National Endowment for the Arts is fighting for its life, JOHN E. FROHNMAYER, its chairman, has found a diversion in his favorite hobby, singing. He made his Washington debut last night at a benefit for the Capitol Hill Choral Society at the New Zealand Embassy.

title: Barringer Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $2,000.

title: Jones Plumbing Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Women Taking On a Rough Challenge
description: Rugby, one of the roughest and most demanding of sports, has become one of the most popular among women on many college campuses.

title: United Coasts Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said written premiums rose sharply to $4.7 million from $2.8 million because of recently introduced policies for pollution liability insurance and professional liability for environmental consultants.

title: INSIDE
description: For Sale in Eastern Europe

title: Engineered Support Sytems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Greyhound Seeks to Buy Back Notes Below Face Value
description: In a sign of its deteriorating financial condition, Greyhound Lines Inc. offered today to repurchase most of its $225 million in publicly held notes for about $90 million.

title: Aspen Journal;   New Fear and Loathing: Gonzo Writer on Trial
description: Since 1972, when Hunter S. Thompson wrote ''Fear and Loathing on the Campaign Trail,'' which included accounts of his rather wild ways, the mores of the nation have become more conservative, especially about the use of illegal drugs.

title: Hanson Officer Picked For Smith Corona Post
description: The Smith Corona Corporation yesterday announced the appointment of a new president and chief operating officer, William D. Henderson, effective July 1.

title: Citizens Utilities Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SBE Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Housing Official Will Lead Board at Savings Agency
description: Peter H. Monroe, an official of the Housing and Urban Development Department, was appointed today to be president of the Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency that oversees the savings and loan bailout.

title: Atlantic Express reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Healthvest reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said 1989 results included a year-end writedown of asset values totaling $127.4 million. Healthvest said this writedown in carrying values reflects primarily the recent financial difficulties of Healthcare International Inc., the trust's principal operator.

title: Matthews & Wright Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
New York's Clamor Intrudes on Koreans' Insularity
description: The newest Koreans in New York move uneasily between two worlds - the New York where they work and the Korea they have created in its midst.

title: One Party in Mexico Still Holds All the Cards
description: Minutes after Guillermo Pizzuto Zamanillo was sworn in as Mayor last year, he learned that just 14 of the police department's cars worked properly. The other 50, he was told, had been stripped of tires, two-way radios or motors by the departing administration of the Institutional Revolutionary Party.

title: Windows, Version 3.0, Steps Out
description: FINALLY, after years of development and months of anticipation, the Microsoft Corporation is introducing a breakthrough version of its Windows operating system software today.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Are Up 5%, to a Big Board Record
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest climbed 5 percent, to a record 644.5 million shares, on the settlement date of May 15.

title: Treasury Securities Inch Higher
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher yesterday in very sluggish trading.

title: Some Doctors Deplore Move to Test for Gene For Cystic
description: A NEW test that looks for a gene defect associated with cystic fibrosis is quietly creeping into clinical practice, to the delight of some geneticists and the dismay of many others.

title: Champagneforashley Is Retired; Rhythm a Winner at Belmont
description: The 3-year-old scene lost one prominent runner but regained another yesterday when Champagne-forashley was retired from racing and Rhythm won his first start of the year.

title: PATTERNS
description: Selling Men's Suits

title: Giga-Tronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Proffitt's Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
The Nets Reward Reed As He Shows Loyalty
description: After almost a month of indecision, in which he wrestled with the idea of returning to coaching by joining the Atlanta Hawks, Willis Reed today chose instead to meet the challenge of rebuilding the downtrodden New Jersey Nets and remain in the team's front office.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Job of Chairman and Chief Is Filled by Parsons Corp.
description: LEAD: The Parsons Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest construction company, has named Leonard J. Pieroni chairman and chief executive. Mr. Pieroni, who is 51, succeeds William E. Leonhard, 75, who is retiring.

title: K Mart Profits Up 6.4%
description: The K Mart Corporation said today that its first-quarter profit rose 6.4 percent as sales increased 16.1 percent K Mart, the nation's second-largest retailer, reported net income of $100.1 million, or 50 cents a share, for the quarter that ended on April 26, up from $94.1 million, or 47 cents a share, for the first quarter of the 1989 fiscal year. Its revenue totaled $7.04 billion, up from $6.07 billion.

title: 'Twin Peaks' Is Renewed on ABC
description: The two networks expected to contend for prime-time leadership announced their new schedules yesterday, with ABC, the new challenger, relying on another season of episodes from its widely talked-about series ''Twin Peaks'' and NBC, the longtime champion, counting on new comedies and rap music.

title: Chadbourne Adds Lawyers
description: Stanley S. Arkin, a prominent trial lawyer in New York, said yesterday that he and two partners would join the firm of Chadbourne & Parke in July.

title: Magic Johnson Wins M.V.P.
description: Magic Johnson has been voted the Most Valuable Player of the National Basketball Association for the second consecutive year, the Los Angeles Lakers announced today.

title: Fortune Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Refiners Are Pushed to Clean Fuel
description: When Congress talks about clean air these days, it is focusing heavily on the refinery - the jumbled maze of pipes and tanks that stands between 7.5 million barrels of oil a day and 140 million tailpipes.

title: Shifts at Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation named Lawrence W. Baker general manager for its Jeep/Eagle division, responsible for marketing, advertising and merchandising. He switches jobs with Martin R. Levine, who becomes general manager for the Dodge car and truck division. Chrysler also appointed Ralph A. Sarotte director of multi-brand marketing programs, responsible for media budgeting and corporate advertising.

title: Journey's End Resorts reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
EXECUTIVES
description: * Cetus Corp., Emeryville, Calif., a microbiology research and product development company, appointed R. Jefferson Works senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Raid Staged in Error Still Nets $25 Million
description: Federal and local narcotics agents mistakenly seized $25 million in what they believed was one of the Dallas area's largest drug-tainted cash shipments, a newspaper reported today.

title: Visitor From Afar
description: Comet Austin, a visitor from the outer reaches of the solar system, will make its closest approach to the Earth on Friday, when it is expected to come within 22 million miles. Until its discovery last year, this comet had never been seen before, and astronomers are studying it with keen interest. Comet Austin is barely visible through binoculars in the early-morning sky.

title: The $1 Fielder's Choice
description: Not long after Cecil Fielder joined the Detroit Tigers in spring training, George (Sparky) Anderson asked how the 6-foot-3-inch, 230-pound first baseman preferred to pronounce his first name. ''Just call me Cess,'' he told the manager. That's Cess, as in success. With a major league leading 16 home runs, a .324 average and 37 runs batted in, Cess Fielder is the success story of this baseball season.

title: VIOLENCE SPREADS TO ISRAEL IN WAKE OF ARABS' SLAYINGS
description: Violent clashes between security forces and Palestinians angered over the killing of seven day laborers by a former Israeli soldier continued today, spreading from the occupied territories to a string of towns in Israel itself.

title: Griffin Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Karl Meyer, 90, Dies; A Research Biochemist
description: Dr. Karl Meyer, a research biochemist who specialized in connective tissue diseases, died on Friday at the Dunroven Nursing Home in Cresskill, N.J. He was 90 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.

title: U.S. Reports April Surplus
description: A surge in income tax payments helped the Government set a record budget surplus of $42.52 billion in April, one month after a record monthly deficit, the Treasury Department reported today.

title: Economic Growth Seen
description: The United States economy will skirt a recession through 1991 and set a postwar record for the longest period of business growth, the nation's top business economists predicted today.

title: Arafat Seeks to Attend U.N. Council Debate
description: The Palestine Liberation Organization has asked the Bush Administration to allow its leader, Yasir Arafat, to enter the United States to attend a United Nations Security Council debate on the latest violence in the Israeli-occupied territories, Arab and United Nations officials said today.

title: Hal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
International Broadcasting reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Cable Spinoff Plan Revised
description: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable television company, said yesterday that it was again altering the form of its planned spinoff of assets. Under the new plan, Tele-Communications said it would spin off part of its assets into a separate business.

title: Mr. Tisch Goes to Washington, by D. Dinkins
description: New York City, whose police force is bigger than some armies and whose mayors have long conducted foreign policy, yesterday got a new official befitting its station: an ambassador - and to Washington, no less.

title: Leveraged Investment
description: Six months ago Jiri Dienstbier was shoveling coal into a furnace for the Prague subway system. Now, as Foreign Minister of Czechoslovakia, he is putting forward a plan to help the Soviet Union and the countries of Central Europe move to market economies.

title: Montclair Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
G.M. to Link Dealers by Satellite
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it planned to link 9,700 United States dealers through what it said would be the world's largest private satellite network.

title: Toward Even Safer Food for the U.S. Consumer;   Beneficial New Farming
description: To the Editor:

title: Foreign Stocks And U.S. Rules
description: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange's president, William Brodsky, says changes are needed on how foreign securities are listed on United States exchanges so that more Japanese companies may trade on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Halsey Drug Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Book Notes
description: A Lottery

title: N.C.A.A.'s Role Isn't To Guard Amateurism
description: To the Editor:

title: Coast Guard Says It Suspects 10 of Dealing With Drug Traffickers
description: The Coast Guard said today that 10 present and former enlisted personnel were under investigation in a widening inquiry into drug corruption at a station in the Florida Keys.

title: Earl W. Seibert; Hockey Player, 79
description: Earl W. Seibert, a member of the National Hockey League Hall of Fame, died of cancer Sunday in Western Massachusetts Hospital. He was 79 years old.

title: EATING WELL
description: EATING a high-fiber breakfast may help you eat less for lunch.

title: A Reputed Bensonhurst Witness Is Wavering
description: A woman who says she saw the shooting of Yusuf K. Hawkins in Bensonhurst last August has refused to cooperate with prosecutors, the Brooklyn District Attorney said yesterday.

title: Terror Creates a Need: Better Bomb Detectors
description: A dozen companies in several countries, pushed by growing fears of terrorist attacks, are racing to build detectors capable of sniffing out even the best-concealed explosive. But the machines are not foolproof, and some technology is meeting resistance from the airlines, the biggest potential customer for the devices.

title: Increased Stake In Sansui Electric
description: Polly Peck International P.L.C. said it planned to increase its stake in the Sansui Electric Company Ltd. to 70 percent from 51 percent after merging two of its electronics subsidiaries into the Japanese group.

title: Stocking the Atomic Arsenal: How Much Deterrence to Buy?
description: The Bush Administration's plans to buy costly new long-range nuclear weapons are being challenged by a growing number of military experts and members of Congress. They say the country has a chance to save tens of billions of dollars by slowing the purchases and seeking an agreement with the Soviet Union to reduce nuclear arsenals drastically.

title: F.B.I. Search at Northrop
description: F.B.I. agents today searched two Northrop Corporation plants where parts for the Navy's FA-18 fighter-bomber are built, the company said. Ron Owens, a Northrop spokesman, said the company could not say what the agents were looking for at the plants in Hawthorne and El Segundo, Calif., or how the search might be related to an investigation. The Federal Bureau of Investigation and the United States Attorney's office also declined to comment. The McDonnell Douglas Corporation is the prime contractor.

title: Renault Told To Repay Aid
description: The European Community Executive Commission today ordered the car maker Renault S.A. to pay back half of the 12 billion francs, about $2.14 billion, in French Government subsidies it received in 1988, a European Community spokesman said.

title: Confidence and Relief At Cable TV Convention
description: The cable television industry - from the people who provide the programs to those who manufacture the cable itself -have descended on Atlanta this week, more than 11,000 strong and flushed with the confidence that a decade of nearly unbridled success ought to confer.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Where Legends Were Born, Ghosts of Glory Linger
description: The marquee at the Lyric Theater on West 42d Street often promises ''Two Horrifying Hits.'' But inside, once past the garish posters, the popcorn and video games, a theatergoer can look up at the wide arching ceiling and feel emanations of the performers who once played the Lyric and who helped to make 42d Street between Seventh and Eighth Avenues a theatrical crossroads during the early half of this century.

title: Belzbergs Consider Armstrong Plans
description: The Belzberg family of Vancouver, British Columbia, said it was evaluating its investment in Armstrong World Industries after winning a seats on the company's board.

title: BTR Plans to Buy Maker of Car Seals
description: BTR P.L.C. agreed to buy a unit of the United Technologies Corporation for $200 million in cash. Through its Schlegel Corporation subsidiary in Rochester, BTR will buy the Global Automotive Sealing Systems Group from United Technologies, an industrial conglomerate based in Hartford.

title: Plan Approved in Albany Seeks To Restore Faith in State Finances
description: Putting the finishing touches on New York's budget, the State Legislature approved a measure today aimed at restoring faith in the state's finances.

title: Hynes Dismisses Aide Over 'Insensitive' Word
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney, Charles J. Hynes, said last night that he had asked a member of his staff to resign for making a ''racially insensitive'' remark.

title: How 'Fuzzy Logic' Improves TV Clarity
description: Compared with high-definition television and its movie-like clarity, standard television technology seems a bit bland. But the Sony Corporation has recently developed a computer circuitry for its top-of-the-line set, the Trinitron XBR, that it says markedly improves screen clarity.

title: Notebook;   Win or Lose in Final 4, Gaits End as Champions
description: The era of the Gait twins, Gary and Paul, comes to an end this weekend at the National Collegiate Athletic Association's lacrosse championships, and it has been a memorable era, says their coach, Roy Simmons Jr. ''The world of lacrosse owes them a debt of gratitude,'' Simmons said of Syracuse's two senior stars from Brentwood Bay, British Columbia. Simmons cited innovative play -meaning, for example, blind, backhanded passes and goal-scoring shots between the legs or over the top of the cage - and the Gaits' appealing deportment in a variety of public situations.

title: Rocky Graziano, Ex-Ring Champion, Dead at 71
description: Rocky Graziano, the former middleweight boxing champion whose life was turned into a movie, died of cardiopulmonary failure last night at New York Hospital. He was 71 years old.

title: Shamir Warns Israeli Arabs Against Protests; Two Die in Territories
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today warned Israeli Arabs who took to the streets in protests on Monday that they had ''passed the limit of what is allowed.''

title: No Headline
description: Two weeks after some critics complained that Mayor David N. Dinkins was piping a quiet obbligato from the back rows on race relations in New York City, he now finds himself leading a brass band of parades and posters, blue ribbons and bromides, whose effectiveness remains uncertain.

title: Greyhound Bus Drivers In Back-to-Work Offer
description: The union representing the Greyhound Lines' striking drivers offered today to return to work, a step that could make the company liable for $10 million a month in back pay.

title: INSIDE
description: U.N. Moves to Hear Arafat

title: 8 Factories Called New York's Top Polluters in '88
description: Eight factories were responsible for producing most of New York City's industrial air pollution in 1988, a consumer group reported yesterday.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WHEN you look at foods that best lend themselves to quick cooking, scallops - whether sea scallops or the scarce bay scallops - rank high.

title: Black Cause Would Not Be Served by Closing Off Forums
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleric Is Buried
description: The assassinated spiritual leader of Muslims in Srinagar was buried today in ceremonies attended by hundreds of thousands of Kashmiris. Separatist guerrillas, saying that the moderate Maulvi Mohammed Farooq was one of them in death, fired rounds from automatic weapons over his tomb, according to reports from the scene.

title: HEARING ORDERED IN MEXICO ARREST
description: A Federal district judge has ordered the Government to disclose all events surrounding the abduction from Mexico to the United States of a doctor charged here with participating in the killing of an American drug agent.

title: G.M. Chairman Gets 'No' Vote
description: The California Public Employees Retirement System, a large holder of the stock of the General Motors Corporation, said today that it had voted against the re-election of the departing G.M. chairman, Roger B. Smith, to the board.

title: A Raucous Brand of Zydeco Music
description: The accordionist Boozoo Chavis is chaos on two feet. A little bullet of a man, he runs around onstage, shouting and yelling. He sings salacious songs and tunes that feature his son Wilson barking like a dog. And he plays rock-hard zydeco music that shakes the walls of a club and gets dancers moving and shaking.

title: KEY RATES
EDUCATION: About Education;   O.K., quick: Who spoke at your graduation? (And why you should have gone to Princeton.)
description: In the midst of the debate about whether Barbara Bush was an appropriate choice to give the commencement address at Wellesley College, I asked two 1950's Wellesley graduates (one of them my wife) who was the speaker at their commencement. Painful silence. Then the admission: neither of them remembered.

title: Former Editor Sues The Journal For $12 Million
description: A former editor at The Wall Street Journal filed suit yesterday against Dow Jones & Company, the paper's owner, seeking $12.6 million in damages on the ground that his reputation has been severely injured because the paper wrongfully dismissed him on May 2.

title: Moody's Cuts Citicorp Rating
description: The rating of some Citicorp debt was reduced yesterday by Moody's Investors Service. The action came nearly three weeks after the banking company's long-term ratings were cut by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: An Organic Chevre As a Labor of Love
description: LEAD: SHORTLY after 4 P.M. a procession of about 40 female goats and kids makes its commute home to the milking barn from the pasture after a hard day's work grazing. It has been a blazing hot spring day in this Appalachian hollow, a minivalley created by a swift stream, the Brier Run.

title: Bank Offering to Exchange Some Brazil Debt for Stock
description: Moving to take advantage of Brazil's plan to sell state-owned companies to private investors, Midland Bank P.L.C. is setting up a $1.5 billion fund of Brazilain bank debt to trade for shares in these converted enterprises.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   G.E.L.W.R.&C. Wins Contest
description: While the Trump Shuttle did not take its account away from Scali, McCabe, Sloves, the airline nevertheless gave the assignment yesterday to Gordon, Elman, Lesk, Wolff, Rooney & Camp - an agency that does not even exist.

title: About New York;   How a Coach Gets Housing Named for Him By DOUGLAS MARTIN
description: The city so often seems all flash, splash and split-second obsolescence. But the truth is that it is the quieter, more unobtrusive sorts who get things done in New York City. They know and care for others. They put in exactly a lifetime of work without complaint. At their funerals, they are remembered as nice people.

title: The Persistence of Pork
description: Never mind the new taxes and cuts in basic services forced by New York State's deficit.

title: Education Chief Suggests Schools Minimize Tests
description: New York State's Education Commissioner said today that the state's public schools should adopt a far broader measure than standardized tests in assessing student performance.

title: In Search Of Respect For Judiciary
description: Around the Capitol in Trenton some people have been calling the Chief Justice of the state ''Cecil B. Wilentz'' since his decision to block the producers of ''The Bonfire of the Vanities'' from filming a scene at the Essex County Courthouse here.

title: U.N. AND U.S. REACH ACCORD ON ARAFAT
description: The Security Council agreed on a face-saving formula tonight that would spare the Bush Administration the political hazards of allowing Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, to enter the United States, or barring him.

title: Sierra Pacific Promotes President to Chairman
description: Sierra Pacific Resources, a utility holding company operating in northern Nevada and the Lake Tahoe region of California, yesterday named Austin W. Stedham chairman and chief executive.

title: Duckworth Taking Success in Stride
description: Kevin Duckworth has made it clear that his broken right hand will not keep him from giving the Portland Trail Blazers a helping hand in the playoffs.

title: The Pitfalls of U.S. Strictures on China Trade;   Dialogue Is Essential
description: To the Editor:

title: Stares and Whispers As Boesky Testifies
description: For the first time in nearly four years since he admitted to insider trading, Ivan F. Boesky testified in public yesterday, providing details of the crimes he committed with an array of investment bankers and traders.

title: Economic Scene;   War Is No Way To Start a Career
description: WAR, as everyone knows, is not good for children and other living things. What is more debatable, however, is war's long-term effect on adults who make it back to civilian life.

title: Regulators See Mistake By Bush Son
description: When Neil Bush, the President's son, was on the board of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver, he voted to approve loans worth $106 million to a business partner while failing to disclose their relationship, Federal regulators said today.

title: Chronicle
description: After weeks of avoiding the press and the public, MARLA MAPLES has a new role: spokeswoman for a jeans manufacturer. She will follow DONNA RICE and JOAN RIVERS in making television commercials and print advertisements for No Excuses jeans.

title: Wine World On the Offensive
description: The word is ''neoprohibitionism,'' and when those who make their living or take pleasure in food and wine say it they see red.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about French Canadian business leaders in Montreal misstated the year that the separatist government of Rene Levesque took power in Quebec. It was 1976. In some copies, a picture caption with the article misstated the age of Jacques Menard, a vice chairman and managing director of a brokerage firm. He is 44 years old.

title: INDIA IS ACCUSED IN CLERIC'S KILLING
description: A senior official of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Government accused India today of direct responsibility for the assassination in Indian-ruled Kashmir on Monday of the territory's most senior Muslim cleric, Maulvi Mohammed Farooq. His death was followed by those of at least several dozen mourners reportedly shot by Indian security forces as they followed Mr. Farooq's coffin to his home.

title: McMahon to Eagles?
description: Jim McMahon, the often-injured, charismatic and controversial quarterback who was released by the San Diego Chargers last month, is intrigued by a recent contract offer from the Philadelphia Eagles, according to Steve Zucker, his agent.

title: Sock Shop Sets Closings
description: Sock Shop International P.L.C. will close 58 stores, more than half its British outlets, to try to save the business, its administrators said today. The company closed its 17 United States stores in December. Closing 58 British stores out of 109 will mean cutting 150 jobs, the administrators said. The administrators are looking for investors to bail out the company, which was founded in 1982 by a former typist, Sophie Mirman, and her husband, Richard Ross.

title: Zabriski Trails Albus by 2 Shots in Dodge Open
description: Bruce Zabriski changed clubs this year, moving from Oyster Bay to Fresh Meadow on Long Island, but his golf game has remained constant and at a high level.

title: The Sausage, Newly Gracing Summer Grills
description: SAUSAGES have always seasoned the American melting pot, and this summer why not try them on the grill for a change?

title: For a Census Lottery
description: To the Editor:

title: Graf Is Top-Seeded
description: Steffi Graf, the top-ranked female player in the world, and 16-year-old Monica Seles of Yugoslavia, who has won her last 24 matches, will be top-seeded at the $5.35 million French Open tournament beginning Monday, according to Women's International Tennis Association rankings.

title: Bernstein Withdraws From Spoleto U.S.A.
description: Leonard Bernstein, who was to have conducted the opening concert on Friday at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C., has canceled his appearance because of illness. The 71-year-old conductor said yesterday, in a statement, that he was ''recovering from a brush with pneumonia.''

title: Gene Transfer Test Opens New Strategy For Fighting Cancer
description: Experiments have shown for the first time that human blood cells carrying foreign genes will zero in on tumors, researchers said today. The findings could open a new strategy for treating cancer.

title: In Shift, Dump Fees May Be Lowered
description: New York City is proposing to lower the fee it charges private garbage haulers to use the Fresh Kills landfill, reversing its commitment to prolong the life of the huge dump, while possibly giving the carting industry a windfall.

title: Garrison R. Corwin, Executive, 81
description: Garrison R. Corwin, an insurance broker and a transportation executive for more than 50 years, died of heart failure on Sunday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 81 years old.

title: Chronicle
description: KATHLEEN TURNER, whose Broadway portrayal of Maggie in ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' has earned her a Tony Award nomination, will play the role again next season - on television. She will appear in an ABC version of the Tennessee Williams play, the network said yesterday.(AP)

title: Review/Pop;   Like Jagger, Or Could It Be Dylan?
description: Kurt Wallinger, the talented lead singer and songwriter of the British pop group World Party, is a musician who is deeply enamored of late-1960's rock icons like the Beatles, the Rolling Stones and Bob Dylan. And on the group's second album, ''Goodbye Jumbo,'' these influences have been blended into melodious, thoughtful songs that poke around in the embers of 60's pop utopianism seeking to stir up a few sparks.

title: GORBACHEV PLANS TO DOUBLE PRICES OF FOOD NEXT YEAR
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and his Cabinet today approved plans to double average food prices as part of a gradual, five-year transition to a ''regulated market economy.''

title: New York State Mortgage Bonds
description: The New York State Mortgage Agency offered a total of $130.74 million of homeowners mortgage revenue bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: Review/Ballet;   A Soviet Ballerina Steps In as Aurora
description: ''The Sleeping Beauty,'' the Petipa-Tchaikovsky classic that is the jewel in the diadem of 19th-century ballet, is also one of the most difficult works in the international dance repertory.

title: Betti S. Whaley, 60; Led Children's Unit And Urban League
description: Betti S. Whaley, president of the Washington Urban League and a former commissioner of the New York City Agency for Child Development, died of the effects of diabetes and septicemia on Sunday at Howard University Hospital in Washington. She was 60 years old and lived in Washington.

title: Bush Isn't A Shoo-In For '92
description: LEAD: George Bush is widely regarded as a shoo-in for re-election in 1992 unless there is a recession. This assumption may be false.

title: Legislator Drops Proposal For Unrestricted Grants
description: The chairman of the House subcommittee that oversees the National Endowment for the Arts said at a news conference on Capitol Hill today that he has withdrawn his bill proposing to extend the life of the arts agency without restricting the grants it makes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Ramada International Hotels & Resorts, to Ketchum Advertising in Los Angeles, for its North America account.

title: M.V.P. Controversy
description: The Lakers' Magic Johnson was voted the most valuable player in the National Basketball Association for a third time, but the first-place balloting created some controversy.

title: Anthony F. Barry; Principal, 59
description: Anthony F. Barry, the principal of Public School 42 in Chinatown for the last 15 years, died of cancer on Sunday at his home on Staten Island. He was 59 years old.

title: Getting the Most Out of Byproducts
description: General Mills Inc. took Benefit cereal off the market last December when it did not catch on with consumers, leaving the company with 50 tons of unwanted flakes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Oops, There Goes Another Soviet Set
description: THE gravest problem facing Western companies hoping to advertise on television in the Soviet Union may not be Government bureaucracy, consumer apathy or the lack of programming. It seems to be exploding television sets.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Taylor Seeks a Raise to $2 Million
description: Lawrence Taylor of the Giants, who earns more than any other linebacker in pro football history, wants to become the first defensive player to make $2 million a year. He says he will not report to the Giants this season until he gets it.

title: 'Baby Bell' Expansion Is Backed
description: A Senate panel approved by a voice vote yesterday a bill that would allow the seven regional Bell operating companies to design, manufacture and sell home telephones and other equipment.

title: Dinkins Calls for Racial Unity at 'Town Meeting'
description: Their voices echoing through the cavernous vaults of a cathedral, the top leaders of New York State and City joined last night in urging citizens not to let the city drown in racial hatred and intolerance.

title: Bush Aides Increase Estimate of Projected Deficit
description: Bush Administration officials told Congressional budget negotiators today that costs for bailing out the savings and loan industry could add $61 billion to the Federal deficit in the next fiscal year, which is about $11 billion more than the bailout cost estimated by the Administration just a week ago.

title: Review/Music;   New Works For Chorale's Anniversary
description: The Metropolitan Greek Chorale, though missing a key element planned for its 25th-anniversary concert on Saturday evening at Alice Tully Hall, managed to pull together plenty of music anyway. The program offered one new work, Stabat Mater, by George Tsontakis, the chorus's conductor, and a new movement of another, ''The God Abandons Antony,'' by Nicolas Roussakis. A third announced premiere had to be postponed, Mr. Tsontakis explained, because the score of ''Eros I,'' by the Greek composer Theodore Antoniou, was not finished in time to allow for adequate preparation.

title: Procedure Is Upheld For Staten Islanders To Vote on Secession
description: A lengthy process under which Staten Islanders could seek state approval to secede from New York City was upheld yesterday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about an agreement on a New York State budget described aid reductions to colleges of the City University of New York incorrectly. The John Jay College of Criminal Justice will lose $3 million and New York City Technical College will lose $17 million.

title: Metropolitan's Policy on Private Collections
description: To the Editor:

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Sushi by Machine

title: New Xerox Fax
description: The Xerox Corporation introduced a line of facsimile machines that use plain paper and double as copiers. John P. Lafferty of the company's information products division said many users prefer receiving facsimiles on plain paper. The machines are all made in Japan by the Fuji Xerox Corporation, although they were developed by Xerox engineers in the United States.

title: Belt-Tightening in Brazil Brings Anguished Gasps
description: For Dalva Ferreira da Vitoria, wife of a building superintendent, Brazil's radical new economic plan means frozen prices in supermarkets here, a welcome respite after prices jumped 84 percent in March.

title: Pinnacle West Bid
description: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation rejected a $1.82 billion offer from Pacificorp, saying the bid was too low. It was the fourth time Pinnacle rejected a Pacificorp bid for the holding company or for its Arizona Public Service Company subsidiary. Pacificorp, a utility company based in Portland, Ore., said it might make an offer to Pinnacle West's shareholders. Pinnacle West shares fell 12.5 cents to close at $15.875 in New York Stock Exchange trading. Pacificorp shares fell 25 cents to close at $21.75.

title: Morris Levy Is Dead; Power in Recording And Club Owner, 62
description: Morris Levy, an owner of record companies and nightclubs who was under a Federal sentence of 10 years in prison on an extortion conviction, died of liver cancer on Monday at his home in Ghent, N.Y. He was 62 years old.

title: Stocks Fluctuate Widely as Dow Rises 7.55
description: Buoyed by a strong dollar and, for a time, by reports that the Government might have $50 billion in unspent appropriations to slash the deficit, stocks fluctuated broadly yesterday before ending with a modest gain, and a record.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: YACHTING

title: Voter Referendums Bypass Legislative Gridlock
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times;   Barthelme Weaves King Arthur Into World War II
description: The King

title: The Pop Life
description: Billy Idol's Changes

title: Safety Board Urges F.A.A. To Order Use of Child Seats
description: The National Transportation Safety Board today called on the Federal Government to require that infants and small children sit in safety seats during airline flights.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;

Summer Interns: Slave Labor
description: LEAD: In the past few months, I received several summer job offers. I was elated - until I spoke with my potential employers and discovered that none expected to pay me. What they were offering weren't really summer jobs, they told me, but ''internships.''

title: Former Top Executive Is Returning to Ames
description: In an unusual twist, Gerald L. Kanter, who resigned as president and chief operating officer of Ames Department Stores in 1985 in a policy dispute, was rehired yesterday as its executive vice president for merchandising. Last month Ames, which runs 600 discount stores with sales of $4.8 billion, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: For New Foreign Policy...
description: LEAD: The end of the cold war is bringing dramatic changes in policies. But the point of greatest interest to people in Washington is the change in careers.

title: Indictment Cites Discrimination In Street Attack
description: An 18-year-old man was indicted yesterday on discrimination and assault charges stemming from a May 13 melee in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn that left a Vietnamese immigrant seriously injured.

title: U.S. Investigating Iraq's Purchases of Farm Commodities
description: The United States Government has found ''possible irregularities,'' which may include kickbacks, in the Iraqi Government's purchases of American agricultural commodities, jeopardizing a $500 million payment guarantee that Iraq has requested from the Commodity Credit Corporation.

title: President Told He Can Lift AIDS Travel Ban
description: The Acting Comptroller General, the legal adviser to Congress, says the Bush Administration has the legal authority to drop immigration restrictions on people infected with the AIDS virus.

title: Barbara H. Talbot; Executive, 61
description: Barbara H. Talbot, vice president of KST International Inc., consultants in Ridgewood, N.J., died of cancer on Monday at her house in Ridgewood. She was 61 years old. Surviving are her husband, Kenneth; a son, John, of Manhattan; a daughter, Claire, of Saunderstown, R.I., and her parents, Darwin and Lucille Hagan of Ridgewood.

title: Protest at Israeli Mission
description: Angered by the renewed violence in the Israeli-occupied territories, about 350 people demonstrated outside the Israeli Mission to the United Nations yesterday afternoon. A police spokesman, Sgt. Edward Burns, said the demonstration, outside 800 Second Avenue at 42d Street, began at about 2 P.M. and led to confrontations with the police, during which four officers suffered minor injuries and nine protesters were arrested.

title: New Microsoft Item Gains Strong Backing
description: About 30 manufacturers of personal computers said today that they would include the Microsoft Corporation's new Windows 3.0 program with computers they sell, a move that will help push the program toward becoming a standard.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Ascension Thursday, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Four Indicted In Sex Attack In New Jersey
description: Four former high school football teammates from Glen Ridge, N.J., were indicted today on charges that they sexually assaulted a retarded teen-age girl on March 1, 1989.

title: Fight Drugs With 'Community Schools'
description: One of New York City's larger capital investments may also be one of its most underused: 1,000 school buildings open only part of the day, part of the week. A creative suggestion from a mayoral study panel would use them better to rebuild communities and fight drugs.

title: How to Help Dolphins Avoid the Net
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Arabs, Feeling Adrift, Talk of Rising Identity Crisis
description: After a brief and violent outpouring of rage on Monday at the killings of seven Palestinians in a town about 50 miles to the south, the hills and Arab villages of Galilee that form an Arab pocket in Israel seemed spent of their passion today.

title: Work Stops as Students Remain in CUNY Offices
description: About 25 student protesters remained in the headquarters of he City University of New said they would not end their occupation until the university had met their demands.

title: U.S. Sees Possible Cancer Tie to Electromagnetism
description: A draft report by the Environmental Protection Agency says there is a possible link between cancer and low-level electromagnetic fields generated by common appliances and power lines.

title: Chronicle
description: When BERNARD PIVOT announced that he was ending ''Apostrophes,'' France's most popular and influential television talk show, millions of viewers were stunned and disappointed. For more than 15 years every Friday in prime time Mr. Pivot (pronounced pea-VOH) engaged the world's leading writers in lively, often edgy encounters.

title: Hippolyte Kamenka, Architect, Dies at 94
description: Hippolyte Kamenka, a Russian-born architect who worked in Paris, New York and New Jersey, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 94 years old.

title: Rule One in the Noriega Case
description: When the U.S. swooped down on Panama last Christmas and captured Manuel Noriega, it pledged a model criminal trial. Prosecutors and defense lawyers have just struck a deal that fits another kind of model. It insures that his lawyers will be paid, apparently in return for agreeing not to demand evidence that might help their client and hurt the Government.

title: Hawks Name Weiss To Replace Fratello
description: Saying he was ''very, very confident that this is the right choice for this team at this time,'' Stan Kasten, president of the Atlanta Hawks, announced yesterday that Bob Weiss was the Hawks' new coach. Weiss replaced Mike Fratello, who resigned last month after the Hawks finished the regular season with a 41-41 record and missed the playoffs for the first time since 1985.

title: Unhappy Yankee Tradition;   Pitching Deals of the 1980's Were Disappointing
description: In acquiring Mike Witt, the Yankees have once again tried to find a legitimate pitching leader, or at least bolster their starting corps. Even with his strong start last Saturday, though, Witt must still prove that he is not yet another part of the team's decadelong practice of finding pitchers whose success is behind them or nonexistent.

title: Federal Judge Bars Seniority As Basis for Teacher Layoffs
description: Widespread teacher layoffs proposed for Boston's public school system cannot be based on reverse seniority alone because court-ordered racial hiring quotas must be met, Federal District Judge W. Arthur Garrity Jr. has ruled.

title: Exercise Rated as Good as Drugs for Blood Pressure
description: Regular physical exercise can be as effective as medication in treating moderately high blood pressure, a new study has found.

title: Messier Wakes Up, And Oilers Go Up, 3-1
description: Just about everyone - players, coaches, fans and reporters - agreed that for the Edmonton Oilers to succeed tonight, they needed more hitting and offensive production from Mark Messier.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Ross Roy's Alfa Spots Take a Poke at Car Ads
description: Ross Roy Advertising takes a poke at conventional automobile commercials in its new television campaign for the Alfa Romeo 164, the first broadcast advertising for the luxury sedan.

title: Boston Journal;   Adversity Can Help A Garden To Grow
description: On a four-block lot in Boston's South End, Kai Fok Lai crouches behind a wall of bedsprings, sticks and refrigerator shelving, working the soil with a spatula.

title: Bridge
description: The American Contract Bridge League defines a senior player as one who is 55 years old or more. On Feb. 27 more than 9200 seniors competed in a special event in clubs all across North America and one of the oldest players - perhaps the oldest - was the winner.

title: Eastern Route Transfer Is Set
description: American Airlines will take over Eastern Airlines' Latin American routes in four phases and at a lower price than originally announced, Eastern said.

title: Antoine's Celebrates 150 Years of Cuisine
description: It's already too late to book the Japanese Room at Antoine's Restaurant for the evening of Dec. 31, 1999. The room is being held for a client who is throwing a turn-of-the-century party.

title: Bush Called Ready to Renew China Trade Status for a Year
description: President Bush has decided to renew China's trade benefits for another year, concluding that the potential harm to American companies and to reform-minded Chinese outweighed a desire to register disapproval of Beijing's human-rights record, Administration officials said today.

title: Kabul Journal;   Across the Suffering Land, the Caravans Still Roll
description: In a country destroyed by war, there are always melancholy voices to recall how things were before the bombs and the rockets started falling. But there are still glimpses of the magnificent things that stir an Afghan's heart, and one of these can be seen as the country's nomads begin their spring migration from their lowland winter pastures into the cooling altitudes of the Hindu Kush.

title: Orzo's 15 Minutes Of Culinary Fame
description: WHY do certain foods, long known in their own countries, suddenly pop up on the American culinary landscape? Who anoints them as the fad of the year?

title: House Approves Bill Establishing Broad Rights for Disabled People
description: The House of Representatives overwhelmingly approved legislation today that would guarantee millions of disabled Americans access to employment, transportation, public accommodations and communications services.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * BankAmerica Corp., San Francisco, appointed Martin A. Stein head of BankAmerica Systems Engineering. Bankamerica also promoted Eric Von Pingel, the director of the appraisal department of its real estate division, to senior vice president.

title: Ethiopia Executes 12 Who Attempted Coup
description: The Ethiopian authorities have announced that 12 senior military officers found guilty last Saturday of being involved in a coup attempt to overthrow Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam have been executed.

title: Chronicle
description: JIMMY BRESLIN returns in print tomorrow in Newsday. But he will be minus at least one newspaper that carries his syndicated column. The Oregonian in Portland has dropped the column because of the racial slurs Mr. Breslin aimed at a Korean-American woman, a Newsday reporter, who criticized one of his columns as sexist.

title: New Ranger-Islander Fuss: Let's (Not) Go to the Replay
description: A high-tech issue matching the Rangers against the Islanders is expected to be on the agenda next month when the general managers of the National Hockey League meet again.

title: Correction
description: An editorial notebook Monday incorrectly reported that the Sabre Foundation, which sends books to Eastern Europe, has an associated foundation in Czechoslovakia. Its associated groups are in Poland and Hungary.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   New Unit Established By Time Inc. Magazine
description: The Time Inc. Magazine Company said yesterday that it had established a new unit - Time Publishing Ventures - which includes the company's regional and special interest magazines, as well as worldwide development activity. Christopher Meigher was named president and chief executive of the unit, and he will remain an executive vice president of Time Inc. Magazine, a unit of Time Warner Inc..

title: Chrysler Cancels Plan To Sell 3 Subsidiaries
description: The Chrysler Corporation said today that it would keep three military electronics subsidiaries that it put up for sale in December, because no one had made an acceptable offer.

title: Arkansas Republicans Facing a Rarity: A Contested Primary
description: The antique conventions of Arkansas politics seemed durable enough at a recent Chamber of Commerce dinner here. Catfish and fiddle music were devoured in the warm twilight, and a state legislator handed out yardsticks emblazoned with his campaign slogans.

title: The Pitfalls of U.S. Strictures on China Trade
description: To the Editor:

title: Douglas Manager Plays A Big Guessing Game
description: Is John Johnson, the manager of the heavyweight champion, James (Buster) Douglas, a maverick who may radically alter the boxing business?

title: Herman Finkelstein; Ascap Counsel, 87
description: Herman Finkelstein, the former general counsel of the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers, died of a heart attack on Sunday in Grandview Hospital in Sellersville, Pa. He was 87 years old and lived in Sellersville.

title: U.S. Wheat Rise Seen
description: An Agriculture Department report projected on Monday that total United States wheat output would jump to more than 2.69 billion bushels this year, a rise of more than 650 million bushels from the weather-reduced 1989 harvest. It would be the biggest year-to-year increase on record, resulting in the nation's third-largest wheat harvest, the report said.

title: My Chip is Better Than Your Chip
description: THERE is probably no food more American. Not even apple pie.

title: Council Approves Bill on Homeless Shelters
description: After months of negotiations and hearings, the New York City Council yesterday unanimously approved a bill intended to force the city to stop housing homeless families in barracks-style shelters in 16 months.

title: Cubs Foil Strategy By Reds In 16th
