description: Dave Clark, given a chance with the bases loaded after a record-setting fifth intentional walk to Andre Dawson, singled in the winning run in the 16th inning today as the Chicago Cubs outlasted the Cincinnati Reds, 2-1.

title: 2d Lap Is First Goal at Indianapolis
description: On Saturday, in the final drivers' meeting before the Indianapolis 500, the chief steward, Tom Binford, will give the 33 starters his traditional warning that the race is never won on the first lap.

title: Beirut Crossings Open In Christian Enclaves
description: Thousands of Christians returned to their shell-pocked homes today as new measures were taken to stabilize a week-old cease-fire.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Data General Corp., Westboro, Mass., a computer company, sold its precision sheet metal fabrication operation to Precismetals Inc. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Another Slam, More Renewal For the Mets
description: By the time their charter flight rose into the afternoon sky today, the only thing the Mets could remember about the trip was its conclusion. They had dismissed being swept in San Francisco and being in disarray in San Diego, and when they left for home, all they seemed to have packed away was sudden contentment.

title: Police to Cede Ticket Writing to Transit Unit
description: New York City police officers will write fewer parking tickets, shifting the burden to Transportation Department agents, under a Dinkins administration plan to put more officers on the street to fight crime, city officials said yesterday.

title: NATO Considering Multinational Units
description: Western nations are giving serious consideration to a West German proposal to combine divisions from different allied armies into new multinational units, officials at a meeting of NATO Defense Ministers in Brussels said yesterday.

title: Review/Music;   Moods of a Soul Singer
description: Every few years a white English singer is touted as a full-fledged soul singer, worthy of comparison to black American compeers. The 23-year-old Lisa Stansfield is the latest such contender, and by far the best. At the Ritz last Wednesday night, she proved to a packed house that the sinuous, husky, emotionally supple singing on her debut album, ''Affection'' (Arista), was no studio confection. Her songs held on to their shadings of languor, melancholy, sweetness and rapture, and for the hit ''All Around the World,'' the crowd added a sense of triumph, joyfully singing the chorus.

title: Mexico Asks For Trade Pact
description: President Carlos Salinas de Gortari called today for a free-trade agreement with the United States and said Mexico would also consider a similar accord with Canada.

title: Atari Is Seeking Soviet Chip Deal
description: The Atari Corporation has begun talks to acquire computer chips from the Soviet Union. Gregory Pratt, Atari's chief financial officer, said the company had obtained and tested dynamic random access memories, or D-RAM's, produced in the Soviet Union. The chips can store 256,000 bits of information.

title: Treasuries Rise in Busy Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose in active trading yesterday, as retail accounts purchased securities after fairly large price declines in recent days.

title: Cincinnati Prosecutors Seek To Alter Obscenity Charges
description: Prosecutors today sought to modify charges against an art gallery being accused of obscenity for exhibiting photographs by Robert Mapplethorpe.

title: 2 Yemens Become One, and Celebrate
description: Pro-Western Yemen and pro-Soviet Southern Yemen merged today to form a new republic dominating the entrance to the Red Sea.

title: Golden Red-Ink Oldie
description: Speaking of death and ruination, has it been generally observed that the Democratic Party is now worried about the budget deficit? There is no surer sign of a party drifting toward the ultimate coma.

title: How They Voted On Bill for Disabled
description: The House of Representatives approved the Americans With Disabilities Act today by a vote of 403 to 20; following are listings of the Representatives who voted against the measure and the Representatives who did not vote.

title: Ribbons for Racial Harmony
description: If a blue ribbon means first prize, then Gerard Papa certainly deserves one for coming up with the idea of using blue ribbons to confront New York City's most explosive issue: race relations.

title: Schools Chief Learns About Politics
description: In a city where politics is everything and everything is political, the can't-lose issue these days is education. Last year Mayor Richard M. Daley campaigned on it, won partly because of it and thought it so important that he created the position of deputy mayor to focus on nothing but the schools.

title: For Troubled Bobby, Half-Hour a Week
description: Bobby Manso, a sixth grader at Public School 94 in the north Bronx, was in trouble - again. He had been fighting with his classmates, cursing at teachers and making another play for attention by threatening to burn down the school and kill himself.

title: A 'Toast' to Gorbachev
description: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev won't get a chance to see billboards that portray him promoting a Minnesota-made vodka when he visits here on June 3.

title: House Rebuffs Bush on Aid To El Salvador, but Bill Dies
description: In a rebuff to the Bush Administration, the House of Representatives voted tonight to cut military aid to El Salvador by 50 percent. But minutes later the decision was voided when the House defeated the overall bill authorizing funds for El Salvador and other countries.

title: Lithuanian Compromise With Moscow Unravels
description: Movement toward compromise on the Baltic republics' campaign for independence stopped today, as Lithuania rejected demands to suspend its declaration of independence and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned all three Baltic republics that they must abide by Soviet law.

title: BANK DEPOSIT FUND HITS A RECORD LOW
description: For the second year, the fund that insures the nation's bank deposits declined, the Government said today. And at the end of last year less money was available to insure each dollar deposited than at any time since the fund began in the early 1930's.

title: GlenFed Picks New Chairman
description: Completing a long-planned succession, GlenFed Inc., parent company of Glendale Federal Bank, the nation's fifth-largest savings and loan association, said today that its chairman, Raymond D. Edwards, who is 71 years old, will retire on June 30 and be succeeded by Norman M. Coulson.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12

title: Federal Courts May Lift Ban on TV
description: The longtime ban on cameras in Federal courts is being reconsidered, and Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist says he is amenable to experimenting with television coverage of Federal trial and appellate proceedings.

title: Charles Polk; Physician, 98
description: Dr. Charles Polk, a physician in New Jersey for more than 60 years, died of pneumonia on Friday at St. Elizabeth Hospital, Elizabeth, N.J. He was 98 years old and lived in Roselle, N.J.

title: WINE TALK
description: THE wine on the table was Chateau Bois de Notre Dame, 1970, a Haut-Medoc. Never heard of it? Neither had I. Neither had Orley Ashenfelter, who brought it to the noisy little West Village restaurant.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: A SHORT friend writes from Brooklyn Heights:

title: White House Defends Main Points of Arms Control Deal Against Right-Wing Critics
description: The White House today defended the key elements of the arms control deal that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d struck with Moscow last week, dismissing as groundless criticism from the Republican right wing that Mr. Baker made too many concessions.

title: C.D. and Bank Fund Yields Show Slight Drop in Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts edged downward nationally in the week ended yesterday.

title: Geren Ends Slump With Home Run
description: The hits have been coming like paychecks lately for Bob Geren: about once a week. Unless there are a string of rainouts, that is a distressing notion for a starter in the major leagues.

title: DISPUTE SETTLED AT WEAPONS LAB
description: A seven-year scientific battle came to a peaceable end yesterday for a Federal researcher who had asserted that high Government officials were misled about the feasibility of a proposed anti-missile laser and that he had faced reprisals for his outspokenness.

title: A German Quid for a Moscow Quo
description: Two out of three isn't good enough for Secretary of State Baker's critics. He has returned from Moscow having made welcome progress toward agreements on strategic arms and also on chemical weapons, but little progress on cutting conventional forces in Europe. Though he offered new and accommodating ideas, Moscow proved unresponsive.

title: 768 Graduate at New School
description: Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Childrens Defense Fund, told graduates of the New School for Social Research yesterday that with the end of the Cold War, the United States has ''a great opportunity to push children to the top of national concern.''

title: Detroit Seizes 2-0 Lead
description: The best the Chicago Bulls could offer the Detroit Pistons tonight was a third-period scare. The rest of the way, there was too much Piston defense, too much Joe Dumars and not enough Michael Jordan, and the Pistons came away with a 102-93 victory at The Palace.

title: A Farm That Goes Beyond Farming
description: In this unusual urban classroom, there are no walls, desks or blackboards. Instead, students roam over five acres, washing wool, raking hay, collecting eggs and planting collard greens.

title: Connecticut Sets $250 Million Offer
description: The State of Connecticut offered $250 million worth of special tax-obligation bonds to investors in the tax-exempt municipal bond market.

title: Market Place;   House Bill Fuels Cable TV Stocks
description: AFTER a year of seeing its stocks hammered by the market, the cable television industry is at last getting some good news. Since Friday, when a draft of a bill that would only mildly regulate the industry was made available, cable stocks have suddenly taken off, rising roughly 10 percent in the last three trading days.

title: Brando's Son Is Denied Bail
description: A judge rebuffed defense pleas today and ordered that Christian Brando remain in jail on a murder charge. ''The court finds there is no basis for setting bail,'' Municipal Judge Rosemary Shumsky said. The defendant's father, Marlon Brando, sat stony-faced in the front row as William Kunstler, the civil rights lawyer, argued that the shooting of a house guest last week at the actor's home was an accident and that Christian Brando was drunk at the time. A prosecutor argued that evidence indicated it was not an accident.

title: NATO Weighing New Look With Mixed Allied Forces
description: Western nations are giving serious consideration to a West German proposal to combine divisions from different allied armies into new multinational units, officials at a meeting of NATO Defense Ministers said today.

title: Hungary Plans to Seek Entry To the European Community
description: Prime Minister-designate Jozsef Antall said today that Hungary's first post-Communist Government would open talks on the country's membership of the Warsaw Pact and seek entry to the European Community.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Hard Times for Pretoria's Police
description: The impartiality and competence of the South African police are being subjected to public scrutiny after violence Sunday in a gold-mining area that left 11 people dead and 91 wounded, according to latest reports today.

title: Water Bug Bites Spitz
description: rrThe question was, Did Mark Spitz get his power in the pool from his toes?

title: Ann K. Soskis; Lawyer, 85
description: Ann K. Soskis, a retired lawyer and social work administrator, died of cancer on Sunday at her home in Philadelphia. She was 85 years old and had lived in Brooklyn.

title: Bennett Hammond; Rancher, 80
description: Bennett Hammond, who led a varied career as a rancher, model, tutor, insurance salesman and land developer, died of a ruptured blood vessel on Monday at the Deep River (Conn.) Convalescent Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Old Saybrook, Conn.

title: German Ex-Official Charged
description: East Germany today accused a former top Communist official of squandering Government money, the first formal criminal charges to be brought against a member of the old regime. The official, 61-year-old Werner Krolikowski, a former Deputy Prime Minister, faces trial in an East Berlin city court on charges of abuse of trust, said Peter Przbylski, a spokesman for the state prosecutor's office. He said no trial date had been set.

title: Real Estate;   Pressures In the Flower District
description: NEW YORK CITY'S flower market district, a bright spot since the 1890's in the often dour countenance of midtown Manhattan, is fighting for its life under pressure from urban planners, developers and the high value of midtown land.

title: 3 Film Awards in a Day for a Student
description: It was quite a day for Adam Davidson, a 25-year-old graduate student in the film division of the Columbia University School of the Arts. On Monday, his first film, a black-and-white, 10 1/2-minute movie called ''The Lunch Date,'' won the prize for best short film at the Cannes International Film Festival in France.

title: Accounting Vote Setup Is Changed
description: Responding to mounting criticism from the business community, the trustees who oversee the Financial Accounting Standards Board agreed yesterday to make it harder for the board to create new accounting rules.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The American people and the American Congress have been played for fools by the Salvadoran military and forces from both the left and the right who need war to continue in order to sustain their power in that troubled land.''

title: Idaho Congressman to Face Businessman for Senate Seat
description: Representative Larry E. Craig won the Republican primary tonight in the race to succeed Senator James A. McClure, who is retiring, while Democrats picked a Boise businessman to seek to gain control of the seat.

title: Strober Organization reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included an accounting adjustment gain of $100,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: R. S. Amdursky, 52, Lawyer Who Served In State Government
description: Robert Sidney Amdursky, a lawyer, educator and specialist in public finance law, died of Hodgkin's disease on Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 52 years old and lived in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Buell Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
In Thailand, a Sense of Japan's Exploitation
description: To the Editor:

title: Assemblyman Withdraws
description: Assemblyman Mark Alan Siegel, who had announced a challenge to Republican Representative Bill Green in the East Side's 15th Congressional District, withdrew from the race yesterday. The move may end his political career; Mr. Siegel had already announced he would not seek re-election to the Assembly.

title: Washington Talk;   Political Advisers: Hired Guns Under Fire
description: America is a country of rich diversity, but almost everywhere you go there are McDonald's, the Holiday Inn and the same small corps of political consultants.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column yesterday, about Mark Spitz, misidentified the event in which Al Oerter won four Olympic gold medals. It was the discus throw, not the shot put.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Lithuanians Endorse An Offer to Gorbachev
description: The Lithuanian Parliament formally offered today to suspend some of the laws it passed after its independence declaration if the Kremlin agreed to open talks on sovereignty, a parliamentary spokeswoman in Vilnius said.

title: Slotnick Rejects Chance to Run For House Seat
description: Barry I. Slotnick, the defense lawyer best known for representing Bernhard H. Goetz, said today that he had decided not to seek the Republican nomination for Congress in Westchester, but would concentrate instead on helping to resolve the ''terrible turmoil'' in New York City.

title: NATO TO CUT BACK TRAINING PROGRAM
description: NATO defense ministers announced today that the alliance is reducing the readiness of some of its units and scaling back its military training programs in response to the decline of the Soviet military threat to Europe.

title: Hydro Flame Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kaneb Pipe Line Partners reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results unavailable; partnership was formed on Oct. 3, 1989.

title: Japan Forms Space Group
description: Thirteen Japanese companies formally announced today that they had formed the nation's first consortium to produce rockets and compete in the international satellite-launching business.

title: For Baseball Fans Who Live the Game
description: FOR sports fans who happen to be in a redecorating frame of mind, Village, an F. Schumacher line, offers its Major League Baseball Collection of wall coverings and borders that celebrate every American and National League team.

title: Helping the Homeless
description: WHEN Laurie Rosenwald was asked to be one of the 21 designers in ''Interior Objects: New Decade'' at Gallery 91, she decided to develop an idea for bed linens she had been working on. ''I wanted to use my talents as a graphic designer to help raise money for the homeless,'' she said.

title: Adage Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lechters Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Shareholders Seek New K Mart Rule
description: Shareholders of the K Mart Corporation approved a proposal asking management to allow shareholders to vote before the company activates its ''poison pill'' anti-takeover defense. The request was approved 83.6 million shares to 64.1 million at the company's annual meeting on Tuesday.

title: U.S. Says It Will Consider U.N. Observers for Occupied Territories
description: The United States is ready to consider an Arab plan to send United Nations observers to the Israeli-occupied territories to monitor the treatment of Palestinians by Israeli security forces, Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today.

title: Loan Plan Set Up for McDonald's
description: The hamburger may seem like an unlikely subject for high finance, but the business of selling America's favorite sandwich is the heart of a new financing arrangement announced yesterday by the Chemical Banking Corporation.

title: Caesars World reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
SENATE BACKS CURB ON ASSAULT RIFLES BY A VOTE OF 50-49
description: In a vote that surprised both opponents and supporters of gun control, the Senate today approved a measure that would ban for three years the manufacture and sale of nine types of semiautomatic assault weapons.

title: Unitronix Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflects income tax benefits of $203,000. c-Net income

Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: Leonard Friedlander, TV Producer, 48
description: Leonard Friedlander, an award-winning television producer, died of a heart attack on May 15 at his home in Marina del Rey, Calif. He was 48 years old.

title: After the Quake, Older Chinese Fear Crumbling Lives, Not Falling Bricks
description: For thousands of Chinatown residents, the violent shaking of their old brick buildings during the earthquake last October was so terrifying that three days afterward, many remained in shock or immobilized by fear.

description: Coleridge

description: Here are the names of House members who voted against final passage of the clean air clean air bill or did not vote. The representatives who did not vote are denoted by xxx. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House.

title: House, 401-21, Votes to Widen Clean Air Curbs
description: The House of Representatives late tonight overwhelmingly approved the first major overhaul of environmental laws in 13 years, rebuffing warnings from the White House that some provisions were ''unnecessarily costly.''

title: Synex International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Heins Takes Lead With 69-136
description: Seventy-six professional golfers and 180 amateurs had plenty of difficulty today when the Rockaway River Country Club course was returned to its usual yardage for the second round of the $100,000 Dodge Open tournament.

title: House Moves to Free Nicaragua and Panama Aid
description: The House of Representatives took steps today to make sure the United States could soon provide economic aid to Nicaragua and Panama, despite uncertainty over the future of military aid to El Salvador.

title: Atlanta Gets '94 Super Bowl
description: Atlanta was awarded the 1994 Super Bowl by National Football League owners today.

title: DEVELOPER TELLS OF DEAL AT H.U.D.
description: A Florida housing developer says he will tell Congress that an influential Washington lobbying firm with close ties to the national Republican Party boasted of its ability to obtain Federal housing grants to win support for the 1986 re-election campaign of Senator Paula Hawkins of Florida.

title: Conundrum in Queens: Oh, Those Mets
description: Perhaps the Mets should change their vowel and call themselves the Mats, short for the Enigmatics. If nothing else, the Mets are, in the definition of the word, inexplicable and puzzling.

Where Fat Is Problem, Heredity Is the Answer, Studies Find
description: Investigators studying identical twins have found what experts call the most convincing evidence yet that heredity is destiny, as far as body fat is concerned.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CARL A. ELLIOTT, a former Congressman from Alabama who sacrificed his political career fighting for equal rights, has won the first JOHN F. KENNEDY Profiles in Courage Award. ''He risked his career by adhering to principles,'' said PAUL G. KIRK JR., chairman of the John F. Kennedy Library Foundation, which administers the award. Its name derives from President Kennedy's book.

title: That Prolific, Ubiquitous David Martin
description: IF David N. Martin were a month, he'd probably be June. Advertising agencies bearing his name are busting out all over.

title: Ted Tinling, Designer, Dies at 79; A Combiner of Tennis and Lace
description: Ted Tinling, the British-born couturier who parlayed a pair of lace tennis panties into a tour-de-force fashion career that all but overshadowed his reputation as one of the sport's most astute observers and historians, died yesterday at Evelyn Hospital in Cambridge, England.

title: Andree Putman: Behind the Scenes
description: ''Andree Putman: A Designer Apart'' (Rizzoli, $100) is a hefty monograph on the life and work of the French designer whose name is synonymous with style. Of course, it's a handsome tome, with commentary by Francois Olivier Rousseau and a foreword by Jose Alvarez, and of course the Putman-trademarked black and white check pattern is very much in evidence on its cover.

title: Terratech Resources reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: European Resignations At Ogilvy & Mather
description: Ogilvy & Mather announced yesterday that Peter Warren and Hans Lange - the chairman and vice chairman of Ogilvy & Mather Europe, respectively - had submitted their resignations. They will leave Ogilvy in the fall. The agency said the moves were not related. Harry Reid will replace Mr. Warren as chairman.

title: Concessioners at National Parks To Pay Higher Fees, Lujan Says
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. plans to make changes in contracts with private businesses that run concessions in national parks when the contracts come up for renewal, saying he wants to obtain a larger share of their revenue for the parks.

title: President Is Appointed At Revamped Carbide
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said yesterday that it had named a new president and chief operating officer, H. William Lichtenberger.

title: Corchiani Will Stay
description: Chris Corchiani, the North Carolina State guard, said yesterday that he would remain at the school for his senior year and play basketball for Coach Les Robinson, who replaced Jim Valvano.

title: Blazers Fall Behind by 22, Then Stun Suns
description: For the Portland Trail Blazers, it was a memorable victory. For the Phoenix Suns it was a nightmare.

title: Smoke Bomb Disrupts Kirkpatrick Speech
description: A smoke bomb went off in an empty ballroom of the New York Hilton in mid-Manhattan last night, disrupting a speech on Israel by Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the former United States Ambassador to the United Nations, but causing no damage or injuries, the police said.

description: * Arizona Public Service Co., Phoenix, rejected a proposal by Salt River Project, Phoenix, an electric utility, to acquire certain Arizona Public Service service areas in Phoenix.

title: ANEMIA IS STEMMED IN AIDS PATIENTS
description: A synthesized kidney hormone can correct debilitating anemia in people with AIDS and cancer, researchers have found.

description: b-Included a tax credit of $309,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Jazz;   A Complementary Team
description: Two avid explorers of arcane pop music and jazz styles - Terry Waldo and Dick Sudhalter - have formed a team that expands on each one's particular specialties. Mr. Waldo is a pianist and singer with a vast repertory of old vaudeville songs, while Mr. Sudhalter is a trumpeter and fluegelhornist whose primary focus is jazz of the 1920's and 30's. On Tuesday at Jan Wallman's, their paths crossed happily in the music of Fats Waller, but otherwise each contributed very effective support to the expertise of the other.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: John Deere Capital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company attributed the higher income mainly to a larger volume of receivables acquired and financed this year and gains on sales of retail notes to other financial institutions during the first two quarters of 1990. Total net credit receivables and leases of John Deere were $2,921,000,000 at April 30, compared with $2,705,000,000 a year-ago.

title: Panel in House Revises Dairy Support Plan
description: A revision of Government support for dairy farmers and new regulations for the seafood industry are being included in the 1990 farm bill.

title: CHRONICLE
description: RICHARD E. BERENDZEN, who has resigned as president of American University, pleaded guilty yesterday to two misdemeanor charges of making obscene telephone calls from his office. Judge J. CONRAD WATERS JR. of Fairfax County General District Court sentenced Mr. Berendzen to 30 days in jail on each charge. But he suspended the jail time provided that he stays out of trouble for one year.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: Stephen Shadegg, Goldwater Adviser And Alter Ego, 80
description: Stephen Shadegg, a political campaign manager who was regarded as the alter ego of Senator Barry Goldwater in the Senator's unsuccessful quest for the Presidency in 1964, died after a long illness on April 16 at his home in Phoenix. He was 80 years old.

title: Harvard and CUNY Shedding Stocks in Tobacco
description: Harvard University and the City University of New York have decided to eliminate stocks of tobacco companies from their investment portfolios, in what may be harbingers of a new tactic to highlight the dangers of smoking.

title: Events: Recalling a Lost S.I. Landmark
description: Landmark Lost, Richmondtown Restoration, 441 Clarke Avenue, near Arthur Kill Road, Staten Island; 718-351-1611.

title: City and Sea At Front Door All Year Long
description: THIS weekend many New Yorkers will spend their first days at the beach, as well as their first hours in trains, buses or cars getting there.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Moscow Favors Speedy Talks
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said today that Moscow favors speeding up work at the conventional arms reduction talks in Vienna.

title: Violence Avoided at Korean Student's Burial
description: Tears, anti-American chants and some emotional outbursts marked the funeral today for a student who died Saturday during protests commemorating the killing of hundreds of demonstrators here 10 years ago.

title: Unit of Southmark Is Called Insolvent
description: The Southmark Corporation said its San Jacinto Savings Association was insolvent and would not be able to meet the minimum capital levels required by regulations despite a plan to add more than $100 million in assets. The disclosure this week in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing casts doubt on Southmark's ability to retain control of San Jacinto after Southmark emerges from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.

title: SAVINGS FAILURES EXPECTED TO SOAR, THE TREASURY SAYS
description: The Administration told Congress today that more than 1,000 savings and loan associations - 40 percent of the industry - might eventually have to be seized by the Government, twice the number it had initially projected.

title: Empty, and Unjust, Posturing on Crime
description: In their zeal for law and order, members of the Senate this week are posturing with familiar responses of no proven effect: extension of the death penalty to numerous Federal crimes and willingness to allow courtroom use of evidence seized in warrantless searches.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

Earnings also reflect an $11.6 million expense primarily for year-to-date interest on financing for the acquisition and shares repurchase, and amortization of the acquisition purchase price.

title: Arpino to Return to the Joffrey Ballet
description: Gerald Arpino will return as artistic director of the Joffrey Ballet, the company said in a statement yesterday.

description: After three years of study, the National Commission on Testing and Public Policy has added its voice to the chorus of criticism of standardized testing.

title: Girard Given Offer From Pic 'N' Save
description: The Pic 'N' Save Corporation said it had offered to add two seats to its board for Girard Partners L.P., the investment group trying to gain control of the retailer's board. Pic 'N' Save said accepting the seats would enable Girard to participate in selling the company. Pic 'N' Save, under pressure from Girard, which wants to gain control of the company and either buy or sell it, has put itself up for sale.

Items to Add Homeyness In Summer
description: LEAD: STILL packing for a trip over Memorial Day weekend? Don't forget to bring a few items that will make a summer rental feel more like home: additional towels, more deck chairs, some rugs and extra closet space.

title: Kirov Dancer to Boston
description: Aleksandr Lunev, a leading dancer with the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad, will join the Boston Ballet as a principal for the 1990-91 season. Mr. Lunev, who is 35 years old, appeared this month as Siegfried in the Boston company's new production of ''Swan Lake.''

description: The company said its net loss narrowed in first quarter 1990 due to a $719,000 increase in operating income and $15,000 decrease in interest expense.

When Children Marry

title: Afghan-Relief Agencies Report Intimidation
description: Western aid agencies, which for a decade have provided assistance to the 3.2 million Afghan refugees in this country, have been the targets of a series of attacks in recent weeks that have raised concern among aid administrators about the safety of their operations.

title: $224 Million Bond Offering Priced by Battery Park City
description: The Battery Park City Authority yesterday priced a $224 million offering of revenue bonds.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Ascension Thursday, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City today. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Reviews/Theater;   Buying Out Aristocrats
description: Anton Chekhov's dramas are easier to ruin in performance than those of most other major playwrights because so much depends upon finding and sustaining a delicate balance between pathos and humor. ''The Cherry Orchard,'' the last of his comedies, is especially challenging because its effete, self-deluded characters are so easily turned into cartoons. Unless their angst is given a social and historical dimension, the play doesn't convey much resonance.

title: Ciao, Milano! Furniture Finds A New World
description: IN a show twice as big as last year's, more than 200 exhibitors presented their newest designs this week at the second International Contemporary Furniture Fair, the fledgling forum for modern design. Its four-day run at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center left many wondering whether New York isn't wrenching the honor of being the unofficial capital of the furniture design world from Milan, which has reigned as such since World War II. The postponement of the annual Milan furniture fair from this September to next April, as well as the hope of conquering new American territories, encouraged many European companies to cross the Atlantic and join American exhibitors at this year's show.

title: Gene Engineering Used to Lower Fat and Caffeine
description: Calgene Inc., a plant biotechnology company, says it has isolated and inserted into plants a gene that can help reduce the saturated fat in vegetable oils.

title: National Security Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
International Broadcasting reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Senate Roll-Call on Assault Weapons
description: Following is the 50-49 roll-call vote by which the Senate today agreed to retain curbs on nine types of semiautomatic assault weapons as part of a larger anti-crime bill. A yes vote was a vote in favor of reconsidering the provision while a no vote was in favor of maintaining the restrictions as part of the bill. Voting yes were 12 Democrats and 37 Republicans. Voting no were 43 Democrats and 7 Republicans. Senator Chafee, R-R.I., did not vote because he is in the hospital for surgery.

title: New Cable Network Plans To Cover Jogger Trial Live
description: A new cable network is planning to offer extensive live coverage of the trial of three men accused of the rape and attempted murder of a jogger in Central Park to New York City viewers and possibly to others with cable television.

title: Purse Bids Postponed
description: The purse bids for the first title defense of the heavyweight champion, James (Buster) Douglas, against Evander Holyfield, have been postponed.

title: INSIDE
description: NATO to Cut Back Training

title: Fighting Kashmir's Fire
description: The armed confrontation between India and Pakistan over Kashmir has grown even more dangerous following the assassination Monday of a senior Muslim cleric and political leader, Maulvi Mohammed Farooq. It's urgent that Washington and Moscow intervene as peacemakers.

title: Evangelist Gets Probation
description: The evangelist John Wesley Fletcher was sentenced to three years' probation Tuesday after pleading guilty to charges of lying to a grand jury about the reason he introduced Jim Bakker to Jessica Hahn. Mr. Fletcher said after leaving the courtroom, ''I feel fortunate not to have to go to prison.'' He had told a grand jury that he did not introduce Mr. Bakker and Ms. Hahn with the idea that they would have sexual relations. But in another appearance before the grand jury, Mr. Fletcher said sex was the motive behind the introduction.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: Even as growing numbers of adults discover the value of exercise to whip their bodies into better shape, relieve stress, prevent chronic disease and delay the ravages of age, the youth of America are going to seed.

title: Europeans Come to Aid of English Cathedral
description: John Lang, Dean of Lichfield, tells visitors that his red sandstone Cathedral of St. Mary and St. Chad crumbles so easily after seven centuries that tiny pieces of it flake off in every downpour.

description: Nuclear arms experts said today that more than 300 nuclear artillery shells deployed in Europe were brought back to this country and secretly repaired over the last 18 months because of design defects that could have led to accidental non-nuclear explosions.

description: Eighty people were arrested yesterday afternoon after two groups seeking construction jobs fought at the site of a new police station house in the Bronx and turned on the police when officers arrived, the authorities said.

title: Defying the N.R.A.: 2 Paths to the Vote Against Assault Guns

So gun-control supporters were surprised and elated today when Senators John W. Warner of Virginia and Bob Packwood of Oregon, both Republicans, voted for limits on semiautomatic assault weapons.

title: Problems Pop Up in Coke Promotion
description: The Coca-Cola Company earlier this month introduced its costliest summer promotion ever. But instead of winning more fans, the $100 million campaign has bought the world's biggest soft-drink company a world of trouble, including the potential for product liability suits, some lawyers contend.

title: Market Place;   Military Contract Haunts Intermec
description: TO the list of casualties of military spending cutbacks, add the shares of the Intermec Corporation.

title: Reviews/Theater;   A Beaver Living A Dog's Life
description: After Lee Breuer's imposing ''Warrior Ant'' and his ''King Lear,'' in which Lear was played by a woman, it is refreshing to return to Breuer past, to the modesty and the crazy-quilt humor of ''The B. Beaver Animation.'' Originally produced in 1974, this work is having a brief revival at the Public Theater as part of the Mabou Mines' 20th-anniversary season.

title: Max Wall, 82, Is Dead; Acted in Beckett Plays
description: Max Wall, the music hall dancer and comedian who became an acclaimed stage actor in the plays of Samuel Beckett, died of a fractured skull on Tuesday after a fall. He was 82 years old. Mr. Wall fell at Simpson's Restaurant in central London on Monday afternoon, said his agent, Joan Prichard. He never regained consciousness, and died early the next morning at Westminster Hospital.

description: Although no accidental nuclear explosion has ever occurred, nuclear weapons, like conventional shells, bombs and rockets, pose accident hazards. But weapons designers say the risks are small.

description: An Ohio man was sentenced yesterday to 48 years in prison in State Supreme Court in Manhattan on charges of swindling $150 million from more than 2,200 investors in fraudulent real-estate schemes, Robert M. Morgenthau, the Manhattan District Attorney, said.

description: Neil Bush went before Congress today to defend his role as a director of a failed Denver savings institution, saying he had not violated any rules when he approved and sought loans for two real estate developers with whom he had other business dealings.

title: Canadian Gas Bid
description: A Canadian group opposing the sale of the Consumers' Gas Company to foreigners said it would match a bid of $1.1 billion Canadian ($932 million United States) made for the company by British Gas P.L.C. The move by Pronational Gas Inc. would return the West's largest integrated gas business to public ownership by allowing customers to buy stock through their gas bills. The British Gas offer had been accepted by GW Utilities Ltd., which owns 82 percent of Consumers' and is controlled by the Reichmann family, but had not received Government approval.

title: Simard Beaudry reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Screen Writer Turns to the Novel To Tell of Race and Class in London
description: ''The real problem when I was growing up was that racism just wasn't a topic of understanding in England,'' Hanif Kureishi was saying on a recent afternoon. ''If I'd been a black growing up in Detroit, say, there would have been a structure for me to comprehend: the institution of slavery and the history of segregation. But in England, there was no wider understanding of racism. You felt it was your own personal psychological problem.''

title: New Yorkers Trying to Outwit Shrub Rustlers
description: It is that time of year for the community gardeners in Greenwich Village: time to plant, mulch, prune and adjust the chains around the shrubs. Growing things sometimes need a little extra slack. But not too much.

Impulsively, she reached out and plucked at random one book among the hundreds of volumes on the shelves. Her selection, which was on sale for $1.50, turned out to be a short novel, ''My Love, My Love,'' by Rosa Guy, an author and playwright from Trinidad who now lives in New York and whose work Ms. Ahrens knew and liked.

title: New Chips Shown For Imaging Jobs

Rather than processing data, as in a personal computer, the chips allow the integration of many imaging devices as well as voice mail into single, multifunction systems. ''The personal computer is no longer the only site for processing power,'' Giora Yaron, vice president of National's imaging group, said.

The authors charge that Bantam Books turned down the book because of pressure from Government officials, while Bantam officials insist they turned it down because it was editorially flawed and vulnerable to lawsuits from Government officials named in the manuscript.

description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $114,000 from a reversal of tax loss carryforward for the quarter and the 9 months included an extraordinary credit of $4,623,000, or 47 cents a share, which included a gain of $4,361,000 from debt extinguishment, and $262,000 from tax loss carryforward. c-Included an extraordinary charge of $1,716,000 from a reversal of tax loss carryforward for the quarter and the 9 months included an extraordinary tax credit of $146,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: 500 Lincoln Center Events For Mozart Bicentennial
description: Lincoln Center yesterday announced some details of its daunting plan to celebrate the bicentennial of Mozart's death with performances of everything the composer wrote.

title: A Civic Leader
description: Last fall, New York City voters rejected their combative incumbent Mayor, Ed Koch, for the calmer, quieter David Dinkins. The vote, held with fresh memories of an ugly racial killing in Bensonhurst, distilled yearnings for a leader who could unify. Now Mayor Dinkins handsomely vindicates that support.

title: Thornburgh Denies Squelching Inquiry at Justice
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh denied today that he had suppressed an internal inquiry in which two close aides failed lie-detector tests.

title: Money-Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields on money market funds surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report remained mixed in the week ended yesterday.

title: What the Brady Gun Bill Cannot Control
description: To the Editor:

title: Fix the Budget, Once
description: Congress would have to whack more than $100 billion off next year's deficit to meet the target under the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget law. That would be three times larger than recent budget cuts and would come when the economy is limp, possibly verging on recession.

title: Foe of Abortions Is Nominated To Run Against Idaho Governor
description: Republicans have nominated a former state lawmaker who is an opponent of abortion to challenge Gov. Cecil D. Andrus, a Democrat who two months ago vetoed what would have been the nation's most restrictive state abortion law.

title: WSMP Inc. reports earnings for Year to Feb 23
description: b-Net income and included one-time net gain from disposals of about $1,050,000.

title: In Fur, an Emphasis On Sporty Designs
description: VALENTINO'S name is a synonym for luxury and extravagance. For years in his couture shows in Rome you could see Sophia Loren or Audrey Hepburn in the front row exuding that old-time glamour. Jacqueline Kennedy would show up at the occasional charity ball in a simple but elegant Valentino dress.

title: Taking Family Feuds to Court
description: DO parents have the right to keep grandparents out of their children's lives?

title: Graphic Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Payment Backed In SmithKline Suit
description: A judge has approved a $13 million settlement for shareholders of the SmithKline Beckman Corporation who sued the company last year after it announced a merger with the Beecham Group P.L.C. The $13 million will be paid to those who held SmithKline shares between April 10, 1989, when the merger was announced, and July 26, 1989, when the deal was consummated and SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. was formed.

title: Cyanotech Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Oil-Dri Corp. of America reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Year-ago periods' share earnings reflected a 5-for-4 stock split effected March 15, 1990.

title: Hills Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
Camden School District Accepts Uniform Option
description: Students in seven Camden public schools may be trading in their sneakers and jeans next year for blue-and-white uniforms in an effort to relieve fashion pressure in the economically depressed district.

title: Spar Aerospace reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $510,000, or 5 cents a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Trico Products Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $433,000.

title: Folly to Scrap Plan to Improve J.F.K. Airport
description: To the Editor:

title: Brady (W.H.) Co.  (O) reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $4,625,000, or 62 cents a share and income of $1,233,000, or 16 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. Year-ago 9 months accounting adjustment due to the cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change. The company said extraordinary credit is due to proceeds from an insurance policy on the life of W.H. Brady, founder.

title: Hadco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Lendl and Navratilova To Miss French Open
description: Ivan Lendl, top-ranked internationally among men, and Martina Navratilova, second in women's competition, are both passing up the French Open to prepare instead for the grass courts at Wimbledon.

title: Metro Matters;   In a Bias Case, A Family's Quest For Vindication
description: Monday marks four years since the name of Samuel B. Spencer 3d was indelibly inscribed on New York City's roster of black victims of racially motivated violence, though his name was written in lower-case letters.

title: Bridge
description: Last year the American Contract Bridge League bowed to legal pressure from Jill and Bob Blanchard of Manhattan and removed men's events from the national calendar. Many local organizations have followed suit, including the Greater New York Bridge Association. The traditional opening of the Eastern Regionals, with Men's Pairs and Women's Pairs, has therefore disappeared.

title: A Head Testimony By Boesky
description: Under a blistering cross-examination, Ivan F. Boesky testified yesterday that he had lied more times under oath than he could remember before he admitted to illegal insider trading in 1986 and began cooperating with the Government's investigation of crimes on Wall Street.

title: Eagle Food Centers reports earnings for Qtr to May 5
description: The company said net earnings reflect provisions for income taxes on a pro forma basis as if the company were liable as a taxable corporate entity for the period from Jan. 30, 1989 through Aug. 3, 1989 when it became a public corporation.

title: U.S. PANEL SEEKS TIGHTER SPY LAWS
description: A special advisory panel to the Senate Intelligence Committee today recommended tightening Federal espionage laws, including allowing investigators wide access to financial and travel records of people with the highest security clearances.

title: Oil Deal By Soviets And French
description: In a move that seemed to reflect Moscow's concern about falling energy exports, the Soviet Union today signed its first oil exploration and production agreement with a Western company, the state-owned Elf Aquitaine of France.

title: Hormel (Geo. A.) & Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: Share earnings are restated for a 2-for-1 stock split in January 1990.

title: Canlan Investment reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: National Technical Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago first quarter was restated.

title: Boeing and McDonnell Joining Concorde Study
description: The nation's two major commercial aircraft manufacturers, the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, said today that they would join with the major European plane makers to study the feasibility of developing a new generation of supersonic airliners.

title: Dollar Coin Gets Support
description: The General Accounting Office said today that the United States could save $318 million over a 30-year period if a dollar coin replaced the dollar bill.

title: Hunter Thompson Told to Stand Trial On Felony Charges
description: The journalist and author Hunter S. Thompson has been ordered to stand trial on four felony drug and explosives charges.

title: Home Improvement
description: STUCCO is a plaster that differs from conventional wall plaster chiefly in that it contains Portland cement instead of gypsum. Because cement is virtually waterproof when cured, it can be used outdoors where it provides a hard, durable surface that is fire-resistant and impervious to rot and fungus.

title: Wyndham Baking Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The net income figures represented operating income. The company does not report per share results.

title: Synercom Technology reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and included benefits from net operating loss carryforwards of $154,000, or 2 cents a share, and $381,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Review/Music;   Romance-Enhancing Songs
description: Between songs, Anita Baker asked the sold-out house at Radio City Music Hall on Tuesday night for a show of hands. ''Is anybody here playing kissy-face tonight?'' she inquired, and hundreds of arms were raised. Ms. Baker's music is designed for just one thing - to enhance romance - and her concert audience, almost all of it in couples, basked in songs about fidelity and lifelong passion. One couple sent a note onstage, requesting the song ''Sweet Love,'' because the man had just proposed and been accepted.

title: Genesco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss on retirement of debt of $1,173,000.

title: Nordson Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Foyt Seeks His 5th Title In His 33d Start at Indy
description: What scares a man who drives a race car on a narrow, concrete-lined oval at speeds up to 235 miles per hour? Not much. A. J. Foyt, a four-time winner, first qualified for the Indianapolis 500 at 143.130 m.p.h. in 1958. For the race Sunday, his record 33d consecutive start at Indy, his qualification speed was a comparatively astronomical 220.425.

title: New Haven Plans to Give Drug Addicts New Needles
description: On Dixwell Avenue, where addicts have congregated for years to buy and sell drugs, health workers are poised to begin giving users new needles for old ones as a way to try to slow the spread of AIDS.

title: Intermec Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Raven Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Millicom Wins U.S. Approval
description: Millicom Inc., a small communications company in New York, announced on Tuesday that it had received permission from the Federal Communications Commission to try to expand its radio communications systems for dispatching taxis and delivery vehicles. The expanded system would also provide for facsimile and computer data transmission.

title: Fielder Hits 17th As Tigers Win, 5-1
description: Cecil Fielder hit his major-league-leading 17th home run tonight, a two-run shot in the third inning, and Tracy Jones also hit a homer as the Detroit Tigers won for the eighth time in their last nine games, defeating the Texas Rangers, 5-1.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Con Edison Plans Power Test
description: Con Edison plans to test its emergency voltage-reduction system today in preparation for the summer season, when electrical demand reaches its peak. The test will begin at 2 P.M. with an 8 percent power reduction throughout the system. The company will slowly return to full power around 3:30 P.M., said Martha Liipfert, a spokeswoman for the utility. ''All electrical equipment will still function, and this includes computers,'' she said, adding that Con Edison had notified those people who might feel some impact from the test.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Prime to Sell Interest in Inns to Blackstone
description: Prime Motor Inns Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell a 65 percent interest in its Ramada and Howard Johnson franchises to Blackstone Capital Partners L.P.

title: Coverage by Walls Provides Insurance
description: Everson Walls grew up in the Dallas suburb of Richardson, Tex., two miles from the Cowboys' old practice field. For the last nine years, he was a bargain, a free agent who won a job with the Cowboys and became one of the leading cornerbacks in the National Football League.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions on Monday, about morale in the Teaneck, N.J., police department after the shooting of a black youth by a white officer, misidentified members of the force. In editions that showed two officers, the one at the top was Ray Talarico and at the bottom Phil Lavigne. In copies that pictured only one officer, he was Phil Lavigne.

title: More Than Ever, You Are There
description: With a camera lens no larger than a matchbook, and microphones that can pick up a whisper in stereo, ABC will be an attentive visitor along for the ride Sunday in the Indianapolis 500.

title: From the Vanguard Of English Design
description: THEY represent the vanguard of contemporary English design, and bit by bit their international reputations are growing. Last week, Jasper Morrison and Matthew Hilton came to New York to celebrate the introduction of some of their furniture at Palazzetti, 246 West 80th Street.

title: Charlie Keller, 73, an Outfielder And Slugger for Yanks in the 40's
description: Charlie Keller, who for much of 10 American League baseball seasons from 1939 through 1948 formed with Joe DiMaggio and Tommy Henrich one of the finest outfields in New York Yankee history, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Frederick, Md. He was 73 years old.

title: Lots of Ships, but Not One Barnacle
description: MADISON AVENUE is normally a bit narrow for dry-docking a flotilla, but 70 or so vessels can usually be found, high and dry, in the vicinity of 82d Street. One recent morning, the fleet included Stars and Stripes, the America's Cup winner sailed by Dennis Conner in 1987; Thames River racing shells with custom-painted oars, and La Couronne, a Ship of the line commissioned by Charles I in 1629 (some 10,000 tiny nails held her planking in place).

title: Royal Palm Beach Colony L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Hearx Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dataphaz Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss The company said that year-ago quarter included $5 million in sales and revenues from the Albuquerque and Dallas/Fort Worth Computerland stores. These stores were sold during the fourth quarter of fiscal 1990; accordingly, the current quarter only included activity from the company's Phoenix, Las Vegas, Tucson and Denver stores. The company attributed the net income to its aggressive focus on the sale of high-margin service and support offerings, and a decrease in same store selling, general and administrative expenses of $775,000, or 15 percent, between periods.

title: Stocks Edge Up as Dow Rises 4.03 Points
description: Despite extensive profit taking, stocks edged slightly higher by late yesterday in the wake of weaker-than-expected car sales and sluggish orders for durable goods - both of which are bullish for stocks.

title: Cermetek Microelectronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A Capella Sound With a Soul-Stirring Message
description: Alvin Chea walks the bass line. Cedric Dent keeps the beat. David Thomas supplies the guitar rhythms, and the horn section - Claude V. McKnight 3d, Mervyn E. Warren and Mark Kibble - pulls it all together. But there are no instruments in sight. They are hidden in the voices of the young men of Take 6.

title: A Bright New Number Beyond Lotus's 1-2-3
description: After years of searching for a second successful program, the Lotus Development Corporation may have finally found its 4-5-6.

title: One Goal Unmet as Clausen Retires From BankAmerica
description: Sometime Thursday afternoon at the BankAmerica Corporation's annual meeting here, A. W. Clausen, the chairman and chief executive, will hand over the gavel of leadership to Richard M. Rosenberg, ending an era - or more correctly two eras - at the nation's third-largest banking company.

title: Bulls' Loss in Game 2 Has Jordan Seething
description: The Chicago Bulls are still a one-man gang and Michael Jordan is it. And he is not happy. Coach Phil Jackson and the Bulls' front office might have thought the team's offense had grown to the point where the Bulls could win without Jordan. But that impression was dispelled by the 77 and 93 points the Bulls scored against the Detroit Pistons in the first two games of the Eastern Conference final.

title: Capucino's Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Reflected interest expense and deferred financing costs incurred in connection with its acquisition in September 1989 of two restaurants; second quarter 1990 results also reflected the company's private placement of its promissory notes in 1989. It said it did not expect such interest expense and deferred expenses to have a material impact on future results for both the quarter and 6 months, and the 6 months also included tax benefit of $155,000. c-Net income The company did not release share earnings for the year-ago periods, saying they would not be comparable with the present periods, since the current owners bought Capucino's in September 1989. The company said it changed its fiscal year end from Sept. 30 to April 30.

title: Frederick C. Mosher; Government Expert And Teacher Was 76
description: Frederick C. Mosher, a retired professor of government and foreign affairs at the University of Virginia and a former government administrator, died of emphysema on Monday at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 76 years old.

title: International Consumer Brands reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Focus at Marcos Trial Turns to Khashoggi
description: For seven weeks Adnan Khashoggi has sat at a far table in the courtroom, a kind of orphan defendant, mostly watching Imelda Marcos's lawyers fight the charges against her. At times, his head has swayed back and forth between the lawyer's podium and the witness stand as if he were a casual spectator at a tennis match.

title: Continental Mortgage reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Evolution in Europe;   Baker Snaps at Critics Of Moscow Arms Deals
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today defended his handling of arms control negotiations with Moscow, saying that those who have accused him of giving too much to the Soviets are people who were never interested in arms reduction agreements with the Kremlin in the first place.

title: Review/Ballet;   A Tin Soldier's Love
description: The New York City Ballet presented two charming pas de deux on Saturday night at the New York State Theater. In ''The Steadfast Tin Solder,'' a ballet inspired by Hans Christian Andersen's story of the same name that is danced to music from Bizet's ''Jeux d'Enfants,'' George Balanchine tells the tale of a pretty little ballerina doll and the tin soldier who falls in love with her on a Christmas night. When the ballerina tumbles into the fireplace and burns, the soldier sadly retrieves the little tin heart he had given her and returns to his battalion.

title: Services for Graziano
description: A Mass for Rocky Graziano, the former middleweight boxing champion who died Tuesday, will be celebrated tomorrow at St. Patrick's Cathedral at 9:45 A.M.

title: Mythology at Wellesley
description: LEAD: The controversy over the invitation to Barbara Bush to speak at the Wellesley College commencement has created a great deal of confusion, quite aside from the embarrassment it has caused the college and the First Lady. The young protestors are confused, and so are those who chastise them for lacking a proper respect for women who choose to be homemakers and mothers.

title: G.M. Holders Likely to Back Rise in Executive Pensions
description: Despite the debate surrounding a proposed pension increase for executives of General Motors Corporation, the change is likely to be endorsed by shareholders at the company's annual meeting in Detroit tomorrow, even though their approval is not required.

title: Mandela Conciliatory in Talk to Business Leaders
description: Building on the success of its political talks with the Government three weeks ago, the African National Congress opened another discussion today with white business leaders on the economic shape of a future South Africa.

title: Tridel Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,200,000, or 10 cents a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Parent & Child
description: IN mid-March the woman who took care of Susan Rozakis' son on workdays told her that she would be moving away in two weeks. ''I was devastated,'' Mrs. Rozakis said. The woman, who cared for several children in her home, had looked after Mrs. Rozakis' 18-month-old son, Dan, since he was an infant.

title: Health-Chem Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $141,000, or 2 cents a share, from the repurchase of debentures. c-After an extraordinary gain of $169,000, or 2 cents a share.

title: Burned Boy Is Said to Have Identified His Attacker
description: David Opont, the 12-year-old Brooklyn boy who was set on fire and critically burned in an assault on March 7, identified his assailant from an array of photographs, a police detective testified yesterday.

title: CUNY Students Defy Order to Evacuate
description: Defying a temporary restraining order, 25 students continued to occupy the City University headquarters yesterday. About 300 employees who work in the building stayed home or found alternative offices at other university buildings for the second day.

title: Gerald Fitzgerald, An Opera Magazine Associate Editor, 57
description: Gerald Fitzgerald, an associate editor of Opera News magazine since 1960 and a well-known figure in American opera, died of AIDS on Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: Interntional Recovery Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Oilers' Tikkanen Overcomes an Old Prejudice
description: Ethnic stereotypes, seldom friendly and rarely fair, exist in North American hockey, just as they occur in life.

title: Chicago Commodities Exchanges in Pact
description: The Chicago Board of Trade and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, setting aside their traditional rivalry, have agreed after a year of negotiations to combine their efforts to develop an international after-hours electronic trading system. The move was hailed by the futures industry.

title: Ambassador Financial Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''A couple of nights this spring the thieves went after a rhododendron and some azaleas, but the chains held.''

title: Report Assails Crew of Crane That Killed 5 in San Francisco
description: The 16-story crane that killed five people when it collapsed here last November was being operated by a crew that lacked proper training, said a report issued today by the state.

title: Cookie Maker In Taiwan Sale
description: The nation's third-largest cookie company, Wyndham Foods Inc., has been sold to a huge Taiwan company for $335 million.

title: Eastover Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company siad its 1989 earnings included a large gain on investments through the sale of properties by Eastgroup Properties.

title: No Headline
description: Forget Batman. Dick Tracy, the Simpsons and Andy Warhol's images are the cultural icons that will appear on wrapping paper, bags, postcards, stickers, balloons and paper plates in the coming year, if the 44th National Stationery Show is an indication.

title: Westvaco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
KEY RATES
Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day yesterday about a new division at Time Inc. misidentified one job held by Robert L. Miller at the Time Inc. Magazine Company.

title: Minding Our Business
description: Here we are right in the spot where the trouble that is bruising the soul of a city is taking place, getting headlines around the country, right in the middle of it all.

title: Harken Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to correct the accounting for certain commodity futures options.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Some say quality of life is best defined by spotless parks and litter-free roadways. But for me it is best exemplified by a happy, healthy baby or by a teen-ager with a diploma in hand and a sparkle in the eye.''

title: Medtronic-Soviets
description: Medtronic Inc., a manufacturer of medical-service products, said it had received an order from the Soviet Union's Ministry of Health for 20,000 Maxima blood oxygenators valued at $6 million. Medtronic's Maxima membrane oxygenator acts as lungs when a patient's blood is routed outside the body during open-heart surgery. The first shipment of 4,000 units will begin in June, Medtronic said.

title: GORBACHEV OFFERS DEAL TO LITHUANIA
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that Lithuania could be independent in two years if the republic suspended its declaration of independence, Lithuanian officials said tonight.

title: Ogden Shifts 2 Posts From Father to Son
description: The Ogden Corporation, which took a curious but successful route from heavy industry to the service field under Ralph E. Ablon, said yesterday that Mr. Ablon had relinquished the posts of president and chief executive to his son, Richard.

title: Augie Donatelli, 76, Ex-Baseball Umpire
description: Augie Donatelli, a National League umpire for 24 years and the founder in 1964 of the Major League Umpires Association, died today. He was 76 years old. Mr. Donatelli died in his sleep at home, his wife, Mary, said.

title: Western Union Revises Swap
description: The Western Union Corporation, which is restructuring its debt in a move to avoid bankruptcy, said today that it had revised the terms of a plan to exchange up to $530 million of its debt for stock and new notes.

title: Soviet Economic Plan Unveiled
description: The Soviet Prime Minister detailed the Kremlin's plan for a ''regulated market economy'' that has little to do with market principles. Page A8.

title: Review/Music;   A New Jersey Homecoming
description: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's concert in the Richardson Auditorium at Princeton University this evening, conducted by Hugh Wolff and featuring a new Viola Concerto by John Harbison, represented a homecoming for the composer.

title: Curbs on Execution Appeals Are Voted
description: In votes on a series of amendments to anti-crime legislation, the Senate today took a generally tough stance in favor of capital punishment.

title: Top Regulators Clash On Stock Index Futures
description: The war of words between the Securities and Exchange Commission and the Commodity Futures Trading Commission heated up today as Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the S.E.C., and Wendy L. Gramm, the chairwoman of the futures commission, appeared before the House Energy and Commerce Committee's telecommunications and finance subcommittee.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Guinness Import Co., to Carroll Raj Stagliano, for Bass Ale.

title: On Stage
description: Sales for 'Miss Saigon'

title: Protest in Canada Cuts Auto Output
description: Canada's two largest auto makers -General Motors of Canada Ltd. and the Ford Motor Company of Canada Ltd. - reduced production at their plants because of a blockade by Canadian truckers at several Canada-United States border crossings. The truckers have blocked commercial traffic at various crossings in Ontario to protest what they call the unfair advantage American truckers have under the Free Trade Act.

title: Charles J. Mason; Banker, 90
description: Charles J. Mason, a retired vice president of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, died on Monday at his home in Stonington, Conn. He was 90 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Sunday about the California governorship campaign of Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp omitted part of his statement explaining the appearance of contradictions in his position on the death penalty.

title: Zabriski, 14 Under, Wins the Dodge
description: Bruce Zabriski today justified his reputation as one of the best professional golfers in the New York metropolitan area by winning the $100,000 Dodge Open for the second consecutive year.

title: Open Private Colleges To Part-Time Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Continental Adds Flight
description: Continental will start flying nonstop from El Paso to Mexico City on July 1, becoming the first major airline to fly directly from the border city into Mexico since the early 1980's. Travelers now have to go through Dallas, Houston or Los Angeles to get to Mexico City. Round-trip fares will range from $334 for a seven-day advance purchase for a weekday flight to $337 for a full-fare weekend flight.

title: CHRONICLE
description: An exhibition and sale of works by leading artists, including JASPER JOHNS, ROBERT RAUSCHENBERG and ANNETTE LEMIEUX, that has begun in Washington is expected to raise about $800,000 for AIDS research. The ROBERT MAPPLETHORPE Foundation's representative, MICHAEL STOUT, gave $250,000 to the cause. One of the late Mr. Mapplethorpe's photographs is for sale, with a $10,000 price tag.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Ted Chin: Candid and Respected
description: POKING fun at an old stereotype, Ted Chin, a rare Chinese-American advertising executive, likes to refer to himself as inscrutable. His friends laugh when he says it, for Mr. Chin is one of the most candid individuals in advertising. In an industry where criticism is usually given privately, Mr. Chin goes public. ''I think the ad business lacks real ideas,'' said the president and creative director of Ted Chin & Company in a recent interview. ''You can't tell me that placing a celebrity in a Coke or Pepsi commercial is an idea.''

title: People
description: * Stewart Alter, the managing editor of Adweek magazine and the editor of its Eastern edition, is joining McCann-Erickson as senior vice president and director of corporate communications worldwide.

title: Suit Over Carter Sale
description: The VPI Group P.L.C. said yesterday that it had been deceived by Donald C. Carter, founder and former chief executive of the Carter Organization, about the value of Mr. Carter's proxy solicitation firm when VPI acquired it in 1987. VPI made the claims in a lawsuit seeking unspecified damages filed in United States District Court in New York. VPI, a financial public relations company based in London, said Mr. Carter failed to disclose that he overcharged clients and evaded taxes, inflating the value of the company. A spokeswoman for Mr. Carter said he had no comment.

title: LATIN AID PACKAGE VOTED BY CONGRESS
description: The Congress, eager to leave town for a Memorial Day recess, today gave final approval to a long-delayed emergency spending bill that includes $720 million in aid President Bush requested for the fledgling democracies in Panama and Nicaragua.

title: So Who Needs Gretzky? Oilers Win the Cup
description: The Edmonton Oilers, in a move that provoked tears and loathing, traded Wayne Gretzky on Aug. 9, 1988. The date and the deal, of course, changed the Oilers forever. Tonight, though, the Oilers demonstrated that the change had not necessarily been for the worse.

title: Movie Rental Business Is Still Thriving
description: To the Editor:

title: JAPANESE EXPRESS REMORSE TO KOREA
description: Emperor Akihito apologized tonight for Japan's brutal subjugation of Korea nearly a half century ago. It was the first time that unambiguous acceptance of responsibility for Japanese wartime aggression had ever been expressed at such a high level.

title: Review/Art;   Drawings by Masters Visit From Rotterdam
description: Among the harbor cities of Europe, Rotterdam does not have a high profile in the travel industry. People do not boast of having been there, the way they boast of having been to Hamburg, Marseilles or Genoa. Largely destroyed early in World War II, Rotterdam does not tempt the tourist.

title: Celebrations in a 3-State Region
description: A combination of high-energy activities, tranquil outings and somber commemorations should entice people out of doors in Westchester County over the Memorial Day weekend. There will be flamenco dancing at Playland Park, pig racing at a county fair in Yonkers and an early-morning bird walk through a nature preserve on Long Island Sound. And in remembrance of war veterans, a rifle salute and taps will punctuate a Memorial Day parade.

title: Review/Art;   Bright Collage-Paintings Animated by the Spiral
description: Al Loving was born in Detroit in 1935 and studied art at the University of Illinois at Champaign, which he has called ''an academy kind of school - it was drawing and painting all day long, every day,'' and then at the University of Michigan. By the time he moved to New York in 1968, he was looking at influential abstract modernists like Frank Stella and Kenneth Noland.

title: Irving Jacobson; Clothier, 65
description: Irving Jacobson, chairman of the Jacobson and Quails chains of men's clothing stores in New York, New Jersey and Pennsylvania, died of liver disease yesterday at the Somerset Medical Center in Somerville, N.J. He was 65 years old and lived in Bridgewater, N.J.

title: Offshore Oil Drilling: A Mistake
description: To the Editor:

title: What to Consider Before Joining an H.M.O.
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Film;   A Trilogy Whose Future Has Passed
description: The thing you have to remember about time travel is that it's notoriously unreliable. Baggage is always being sent on to the wrong epoch, and return tickets are never guaranteed.

title: Political Violence Erupts in Chile, Darkening Return to Democracy
description: Hopes for a smooth re-entry into democratic life in Chile have been dashed by a wave of political violence, including one assassination and two attempted killings, in the 11 weeks since President Patricio Aylwin took office.

title: Review/Film;   Choppers vs. Pushers
description: ''Fire Birds'' is a ludicrous action-romance about the United States Army's attack helicopters known as Apaches, and the heroic men and women who fly them in peace and in war.

title: Owner of Exco Seeking Bidders
description: British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C. said it was seeking buyers for its Exco International P.L.C. subsidiary. Exco is a financial services firm specializing in wholesale markets, including money brokering and stock lending. The sale is part of British and Commonwealth's plan to raise $:750 million, or $12.6 million, by selling assets.

title: Review/Dance;   Swinging From Wires In a Night's Celebration
description: Dancers floated happily on air Wednesday night when Dance Theater Workshop celebrated its 25th anniversary with a gala performance at the Joyce Theater. The levitation and levity were justified, for D.T.W., as the organization is familiarly known, has been a major producer and supporter of dance attractions since 1965.

title: Our Towns;   Shopping Siren Sings This Song: IKEA! IKEA!
description: People worry that America doesn't produce anything useful. Trade deficits persist, savings and loans fail, junk-bond wizards can afford $600 million fines. Yet there's a bright spot: The economy still churns out world-class shoppers.

title: Washington Arts Group Gets Director
description: The Washington Project for the Arts has announced the appointment of Marilyn A. Zeitlin, curator at the Contemporary Arts Museum of Houston, as its new director. She succeeds Jock Reynolds, who resigned in December to head the Addison Gallery of American Art at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.

title: Soviets Seeking Revival Of Talks on Air Travel
description: In an attempt to revive stalemated talks on expanding air travel between the United States and the Soviet Union, the Soviets requested today that the negotiations be resumed in Washington this weekend, American officials said.

title: Review/Ballet;   A 'Sleeping Beauty' Not Acted, but Danced
description: The role of Aurora in ''The Sleeping Beauty'' does not lend itself to imaginative acting. Aurora is a symbol of awakening womanhood and the pretext for one of the classical ballet's most beloved spectacles. Cheryl Yeager chose not to act the role but to dance it - triumphantly - when American Ballet Theater presented the Petipa-Tchaikovsky classic on Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Padres Rock Viola Again As Mets' Rally Falls Short
description: Frank Viola was invincible for the Mets in his first seven starts this year. His changeup was baffling, making his fastball seem faster, and the results were staggering: seven straight victories and only five earned runs allowed.

title: Resorts Plan Gets Backing
description: The financial restructuring proposed by Resorts International Inc. to shed most of its $927 million debt has been approved by committees representing its two groups of bondholders, the casino company said today.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday recounting 60 years of major Federal firearms legislation omitted one measure. It was a 1988 Congressional ban on ''plastic'' guns, or firearms consisting of less than 3.7 ounces of steel; it required that all guns be detectable by airport X-ray machines.

title: Rinfret Portrayed as a Fiery Foe for Cuomo
