description: Pierre Andre Rinfret, the almost certain Republican candidate for governor of New York, has little state governmental and political experience but could be an oratorical match for Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on the stump, many economists and business executives agreed yesterday.

title: Bracing for Service Cuts And Increasing Taxes
description: The average homeowner will pay $33 more in New York City property taxes, services at the city's branch libraries will be cut and the streets and parks will become dirtier if the $28 billion budget presented yesterday by Mayor David N. Dinkins is adopted.

title: Roberta Soble Is Married
description: Roberta Soble, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Soble of Lido Beach, L.I., was married yesterday to Eric M. Dochter, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ivan Dochter of Roslyn, L.I. Cantor Richard Botton officiated at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Mrs. Dochter, 30 years old, graduated from the Fashion Institute of Technology. She is the president of RARE Accessories, a manufacturers' representative in New York. Mr. Dochter, 30, is a real-estate broker with the Williams Real Estate Company in New York. He graduated from Syracuse University.

title: Stewart Wins No. 8 as A's Romp, 13-1
description: Dave Stewart became the American League's first eight-game winner this season, and Jose Canseco had four hits, including two home runs, as the Oakland Athletics defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 13-1.

title: Florio Proposes New Spending Plans
description: Gov. Jim Florio today sent the Legislature 15 bills intended to make far-reaching changes in the way New Jersey raises and spends money.

title: Trouble in the Trial Bar: a Lawyers' Group Chases After Ambulance Chasers
description: Russ M. Herman of New Orleans is a man enchanted with his work, as a recent ''president's page'' in Trial magazine amply attests.

title: Ex-Fugitive Pleads Guilty to Bail Jumping
description: Herman B. Ferguson, a former radical in New York City who spent 19 years as a fugitive abroad to avoid prison for conspiring to kill moderate civil rights leaders, pleaded guilty yesterday to bail jumping.

title: Celebrations in a 3-State Region
description: LEAD: Events both grand and intimate, and ranging from the refined to the raucous, crowd a Memorial Day weekend schedule on Long Island that will be splashed with fireworks.

title: Economic Scene;   A Bad Mixture For Policy Makers
description: THE Commerce Department's revision of the gross national product data for the first quarter of 1990 heightens the picture of an economy suffering from slugflation, a mixture of sluggish growth and inflation that is a kissing cousin to stagflation.

title: 'Those Outsiders'
description: To the Editor:

title: Flight Blowout Injures Man
description: One passenger was injured and almost sucked out when a window in the passenger cabin of a Horizon Air Industries commuter plane blew out Wednesday on a flight from Portland to Seattle. The plane landed safely at nearby Seattle-Tacoma Airport. The passenger, Gayle Sears, suffered minor injuries.

title: Hold Your Tongue: Introducing No-Lick Stamps
description: The Postal Service has introduced what it calls a revolutionary innovation: a plastic postage stamp that not only needs no licking, but also can be purchased at banks' automated teller machines.

title: Margaret Sedlis, Architect, Weds
description: Margaret J. Sedlis, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward G. Sedlis of New York, was married yesterday to Matthew Goldstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Goldstein of New York. Rabbi Balfour Brickner performed the ceremony at the Stephen Wise Free Synagogue in New York.

title: Albanians in No Hurry to Change Their Communist Ways
description: President Ramiz Alia will move gradually in changing an orthodox Stalinist system in a country virtually sealed off to the world for four decades, two of his senior advisers say.

title: Corrections
description: The Our Towns column on Tuesday, about the decline of many community orchestras, referred incorrectly to the Nutley (N.J.) Symphony. It did complete its 1990 concert schedule, and is preparing for its next season.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ADELA HOLZER, the former Broadway producer who was an original backer of ''Hair,'' was sentenced yesterday to four to eight years in state prison for defrauding investors. She pleaded guilty to bilking one investor of $400,000. The original indictment put the figure at $4 million.

title:
Towers in Manhattan;

A Residential High-Rise Goes Up on Midblock Lot
description: LEAD: Neighborhood groups on the Upper East Side of Manhattan have been battling since 1982 for zoning changes that would discourage the construction of tall residential towers in favor of buildings that are shorter and considered to be more in context with surrounding structures.

title: Japanese Computer Rated The Fastest by One Measure
description: A Japanese supercomputer has for the first time taken the title of the world's fastest single-processor computer, according to a study released yesterday by a researcher at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, an Energy Department research center.

title: Chilmark Stake In UJB Financial
description: The Chilmark Management Corporation, an investment management firm in Woodcliff Lake, N.J., said it had bought more than 2.2 million shares, or more than 5 percent, of the UJB Financial Corporation, a banking company in Princeton, N.J. UJB, which owns United Jersey Bank, has been hurt by the slowdown in the New Jersey economy, but has remained profitable. In the first quarter, despite a sharp rise in its reserve for loan losses and troubled loans, UJB earned $24.7 million. A year earlier, the company earned $31.9 million.

title: INSIDE
description: Congress Backs Latin Aid

title: Intrigues of Gorbachev
description: In the Kremlin corridors where the apprentices of the new Soviet politics roam, the question of questions today was why Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the putative master pol, seemed to be almost recklessly courting public rejection.

title: New G.M. Concept: Thinking Small
description: The General Motors Corporation did not grow into the world's No. 1 auto maker by thinking small or bucking the economies of assembly-line manufacturing. But G.M. has been trying to do both at the factory that assembles the Buick Reatta coupe, and G.M. executives now seem pleased enough with the result to consider using the system for other models.

title: Holiday Afoot or Afloat: Food, Fairs and Music
description: SPRING, rarely a season to dally in New York, has already come and gone, as the arrival of Memorial Day weekend heralds the season of beaches, barbecues and sweltering streets. During the next few days, the coming of summer will be duly noted with fireworks, outdoor concerts, fairs and parades throughout the city.

title: GTE Discussions On Unit of Thorn
description: The GTE Corporation said it was negotiating to buy the lighting division of Thorn EMC P.L.C. of Britain to get a larger share of the global lighting market. Thorn's profits from the company's lighting and Kenwood appliances unit totaled $72 million in the fiscal year that ended on March 31, 1989, on sales of $868 million. It has nearly 13,000 employees. GTE's electrical products and precision materials division had a net income of $222 million, on revenues of $2.2 billion, last year. The division has 28,000 workers.

title: 5 Global TV Rules Are Set
description: A global broadcasting watchdog has set five basic rules for a sharper, brighter television system of the future, but failed to agree on two crucial standards.

title: Charles M. Wiltse; Historian, 83
description: Charles M. Wiltse, a historian and an editor of the papers of Daniel Webster, died on Tuesday at Dartmouth-Hitchcock Medical Center in Hanover, N.H. He was 83 years old and lived in Hanover.

title: Federal Aid To Amtrak Is Vetoed
description: President Bush vetoed legislation today that would continue the Federal subsidy for Amtrak, the national passenger railroad system, saying he objected to a provision that would subject certain takeovers of freight railroad lines to Government review.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Clarinet Festival

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-12

title: Why Turn Genius Into 'Everykid'?
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Television;   One More Thing, Diane: Buy Me Some Insurance
description: Diane, I'm up Twin Peaks without a clue.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Stocks Ease As Dow Dips 0.71 Point
description: Stocks weakened a bit yesterday amid signs that inflation is too strong for the Federal Reserve to act to bring down interest rates.

title: Half Right on China Trade
description: President Bush is right to propose renewing China's trade privileges. But he would have sent a sounder message if he had expressed outrage over Beijing's continued gross abuse of human rights. Congress, which has 30 days to review the proposal, again will have to make clear that approving it in no sense approves repression.

title: Pop/Jazz;   Bill Frisell's Progress In Music's Avant-Garde
description: When the guitarist Bill Frisell, who is performing at the Village Vanguard this weekend, first arrived in New York in 1978, nothing happened. ''It was a little rough at first,'' Mr. Frisell recalled. ''After Berklee music school in Boston, I went to Europe for a year to play. That was where I first recorded with Eberhard Weber, and I did a tour with Mike Gibbs, so I was playing a lot in Europe.

title: U.S. Indicts Hare Krishna Leader
description: The founder and leader of a Hare Krishna community was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of scheming to murder, kidnap and beat various followers.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Summer Squall Ran By Following Rules
description: The rules of racing in many states require that a horse who bleeds from the nose after a race or morning exercise is ineligible to race for at least 10 days.

title: Detectives Kept Secret Reports On Some Crimes
description: Confidential memorandums about crimes were sent by New York City detectives to high-ranking police officials, a Police Department spokeswoman said yesterday.

title: At Rutgers, a Call to End Intolerance
description: Gov. Jim Florio urged graduates of Rutgers University today to actively fight incidents of bias and intolerance.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   On Clean Air, Smiles in Public, Frowns in Private
description: In its overwhelming passage of a comprehensive clean air measure after only a single day of floor debate, the House of Representatives seemed the model of legislative efficiency.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Rhythm From Zaire

title: Pennsylvania Ballet Names New Director
description: Christopher d'Amboise, a former principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, has been named artistic director of the Pennsylvania Ballet, effective in August. Mr. d'Amboise, who is 30 years old, is also the founder, director and choreographer of the Off Center Ballet and a Tony Award-winning Broadway dancer.

title: Fiber-Optics Executive Is Moving Up at ADC
description: ADC Telecommunications Inc. said yesterday that it had named William J. Cadogan as its next president and chief operating officer. Mr. Cadogan, 41, led the company's recent expansion into fiber optics from the core business of providing telephone equipment.

title: Conviction in Water Pollution
description: In what may be the first conviction of its kind, a Federal jury has found a company in Burlington, Mass., and its president guilty of knowingly violating the nation's Clean Water Act and endangering company employees as a result.

title: BUSH WITHHOLDING NORMAL TRADE TIES FROM THE SOVIETS
description: President Bush indicated today that he would withhold normal trade status from the Soviet Union as long as the Lithuanian question remained unresolved. At the same time he confirmed that he was renewing such economic benefits for China despite Beijing's hard-line policies.

title: Lavoro Unfolds
description: ''The Lavoro affair'' is what some of us call the Government of Iraq's manipulation of the American and Italian banking systems to help Dictator Saddam Hussein finance the building of a missile with a nuclear warhead.

title: Turner Plans Latin Network
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. will start an entertainment-oriented cable television network in Latin America next January, Ted Turner, the company's chairman, said Wednesday.

title: Terrapin Mulls Transfer
description: Walt Williams, a University of Maryland guard, said he had contacted Georgia Tech and St. John's regarding a transfer, The Baltimore Sun reported yesterday.

title: Market Place;   Funds See Silver In Buyout Clouds
description: DESPITE lenders' growing reluctance to finance leveraged acquisitions, two investment firms are betting that they can profit by buying stocks of companies involved in buyouts.

title: Romania Chief's Supporters And Rivals Jeer Each Other
description: Supporters and opponents of Romania's President-elect, Ion Iliescu, jeered at each other in central Bucharest today in a tense confrontation that came close to violence.

title: Treasury Securities Dip in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in thin trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities after an unexpectedly poor auction of $8.5 billion worth of new five-year notes.

title: The Man Who Has His Own
description: For several weeks now Drew Pearson has monitored with some amusement the current debate involving inner-city violence, brand-name sneakers and suggestions that highly visible black athletes should curb their endorsements of overpriced sneakers.

title: Restaurants
description: If you have any doubts that New Yorkers are in a thrifty mood these days, just drop into the teeming dining room of Rose Cafe, an upbeat American restaurant on lower Fifth Avenue that serves single-digit appetizers and main courses that peak at $19. The success of this six-month-old effort is even more impressive considering it occupies a space that has seen two higher-priced flops in the past three years, Mosaico and 24 Fifth Avenue.

title: House Roll-Call Approving Measure to Clean the Nation's Air
description: Following is the roll-call vote of 401 to 21 by which the House of Representatives approved the clean air bill on Wednesday night. A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the bill. Voting ''yes'' were 246 Democrats and 155 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 5 Democrats and 16 Republicans. Y is a ''yes'' vote. N is a ''no'' vote. X denotes those not voting. Present denotes those who voted they were ''present'' at the time of the vote but did not vote ''yes'' or ''no'' on the issue. There are two vacancies in the 435-member House.

title: Albert Kindler; Real-Estate Broker, 77
description: Albert Kindler, a real-estate broker and an investor, died of congestive heart failure on Wednesday at Tisch Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in White Plains.

title: ABC Last in 'Sweep' Rating Despite 'Twin Peaks' Finale
description: The last episode of ABC's widely publicized series ''Twin Peaks'' resolved none of its mysteries Wednesday night, including its future ratings prospects, as the May sweep rating month concluded with an unexpected storyline: vulnerability for NBC and viability for CBS.

title: Rail and Subway Riders Get Free Concerts
description: Music to commute by will be offered today at three popular sites of transportation. At Grand Central Terminal, from noon to 4 P.M., the Music Under New York Big Band will play jazz pieces by Roy Campbell, Cal and Zane Massey and others. At Penn Station, also from noon to 2 P.M., rock music from the 1950's and 60's will be offered by Doc Rock and the Transports.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASEBALL

title: Boone on Disabled List
description: Bob Boone, the Kansas City catcher, has been put on the disabled list for the first time in his 17-year career.

title: Fine of $3,500 For Edwards
description: James Edwards, the Detroit Pistons' power forward, was fined $3,500 by the National Basketball Association yesterday for his confrontation with Ed Nealy of the Chicago Bulls in Game 2 of the Eastern Conference championship series on Tuesday night.

title: Sparring Starts Over Demise Of Shoreham as Panels Meet
description: Officials of the Long Island Power Authority met with officials of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission today to discuss together, for the first time, the fate of the Shoreham Nuclear Power Station.

title: CHILDREN OF CRACK: ARE THE SCHOOLS READY? - A SPECIAL REPORT:   Crack Babies Turn 5, and Schools Brace
description: The nation's inner-city schools, already strained by the collapse of families and the wounds of poverty, will face another onslaught this fall -the first big wave of children prenatally exposed to crack.

title: Auctions
description: Below Par

title: Florio Urges Added Aid In City Schools
description: The Florio administration today proposed an overhaul of the school-financing law that would transfer tens of millions of dollars in state aid from wealthy suburban districts to middle-class and poor urban schools beginning in the 1991-92 school year.

title: Stephenson Confident of Comeback From Injury
description: Jan Stephenson, who suffered a severe fracture of her left ring finger in January, is back in competition and eager to prove that her career is far from over.

title: Navy Reopens Iowa Blast Inquiry After Ignition in Gunpowder Test
description: The Navy today reopened its investigation into the explosion on the battleship Iowa after an ''unexplained ignition'' of gunpowder bags in a test earlier in the day raised the possibility that the Iowa blast was accidental.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Memorial Day will be celebrated on Monday. Here are holiday schedules.

title: Girard Wants Sale Of Pic 'N' Save
description: Girard Parnters L.P., the investment group seeking to gain control of the board of the Pic 'N' Save Corporation, said that if its nominees are elected they would create an advisory committee of representatives of institutional shareholders to recommend how to sell the company.

title: Music at a Museum
description: Judith Gordon is to play Haydn's Sonata in C minor (Hob. XVI:20), Ravel's ''Valses Nobles et Sentimentales,'' Bartok's Improvisations (Op. 20) and Liszt's Sonata in B minor at 2:30 P.M. tomorrow at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Tickets are $10. Information: 570-3949.

title: 49ers Face a Hearing
description: The National Football League will examine the financial structure of the San Francisco 49ers at a hearing in mid-June to determine if the structure gives the 1990 Super Bowl champions an unfair edge. No specific hearing date has been set.

title: DEMOCRATS IRATE OVER BUSH SILENCE
description: President Bush ignited Democratic tempers in Congress today when he refused once again to address the public on the severity of the deficit problem or to offer proposals to solve it.

title: Giants' Morris, Feeling Fit, Hopes to Win Spot
description: Last September, Joe Morris broke his right foot in the Giants' final preseason game and sat out the entire season. Today, when most of the Giants' veterans reported for a minicamp, Morris returned to the field and learned that people had short memories.

title: Review/Blues;   Making the Piano Jump and Wail
description: Two pianists who were in on the birth of rock-and-roll headlined the first two nights of the Piano Blues Who's Who, a three-part series presented at the Church of St. Ann and the Holy Trinity in Brooklyn Heights.

title: Rockefeller Center Plans 55-Story Building
description: The New York City Board of Estimate yesterday cleared the way for the construction of a 55-story office building that will be part of the Rockefeller Center complex in mid-Manhattan. The new tower - tentatively called Rockefeller Plaza West - would be on the east side of Seventh Avenue between West 49th and 50th Streets.

title: Reviews/Film;   Leda and the Dead Swans
description: ''A Zed and Two Noughts'' was shown as part of the 1986 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Sept. 20, 1986. The film opens today at the Public Theater, 425 Lafayette Street.

title: People or Monsters?
description: As we approach the first anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre, China tugs at our understanding and our conscience. In a world of spreading democracy, how can so vast and talented a nation remain under authoritarian rule? Is there reason to hope for change? What should we on the outside do to help?

title: Stanley J. Sarnoff, 72, Cardiologist and Inventor
description: Dr. Stanley J. Sarnoff, a cardiologist who was an inventor of emergency medical devices, died of heart failure on Wednesday while undergoing surgery at University Hospital in Salt Lake City. He was 72 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

title: KEY RATES
Shoemaker Honored
description: Bill Shoemaker, who won five Belmont Stakes in his record-setting career, is the winner of the Mike Venezia Memorial Award, voted on by New York racing fans, racing writers and jockeys.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Graf Bertel Dominique
description: Graf Bertel Dominique has resigned the advertising account of Paul Stuart Inc., after handling the Madison Avenue clothier for just several weeks. The agency said it had resigned the $2 million account because of creative differences.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article on Monday about a House clean air bill carried an incomplete listing in some copies for the areas where service stations and their suppliers would be required to sell cleaner-burning gasoline. The areas are Los Angeles, Houston, New York, Baltimore, Chicago, Milwaukee, Philadelphia, San Diego and most of Connecticut.

title: How Restoring Books Is (and Is Not) Like Love
description: The characters in Sherry Kramer's ''What a Man Weighs'' are employees in a book conservation laboratory devoted to insuring the continuing life of words in print. The playwright provides the audience with intriguing details of this profession, raising questions that apply to art as well as literature. She describes, for example, how the pursuit of perfect restoration can lead to forgery. But books and the conservation of books are not the principal subjects of her play at Second Stage.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Joffrey Board Makes Panel With Arpino
description: The board of the Joffrey Ballet voted last night to have Gerald Arpino continue as artistic director of the financially troubled company, from which he resigned as director and resident choreographer on May 1. His resignation was not accepted by the board.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Chiat/Day in Venture With Stockholm Agency
description: Chiat/Day/Mojo and Hans Brindfors Advertising, a Stockholm ad agency with which Chiat has had an informal personnel exchange program, yesterday announced plans to develop a network of jointly owned agencies in Europe.

title: Sakowitz Stores To Be Auctioned
description: The L. J. Hooker Corporation's Sakowitz Inc. department store chain will be auctioned after an investor group, which had agreed to buy the Houston unit, said it now favored open bidding for the retailer. Sakowitz Acquisition Partners Inc., the investment group, said it hoped to be the highest bidder. If successful, the group said it would streamline operations and focus on exclusive merchandise.

title: Air Fares Are Cut, but Restrictions Apply
description: Continental Airlines yesterday matched fare cuts made by other carriers and said it would honor United Airlines coupons that take an additional $35 off round-trip prices.

title: Celebrations in a 3-State Region
description: The rains of May have transformed the Hudson Valley into an ocean of green -green alfalfa waving in the breeze awaiting its first cutting for hay, green apple leaves, green tips of emerging corn, green leaves of strawberry plants. But if the soothing sight of pastoral green is not sufficient for visitors, the valley offers a variety of things to do this weekend, ranging from walking on the Appalachian Trail to attending an arts and crafts fair or visiting a bucolic museum.

title: Vote Ends Wine Commission in California
description: The California Wine Commission was voted out of existence today, the victim of a rebellion by the state's small wineries.

title: Revised Figures Shows Economy Is Still Sluggish
description: Deflating a recent impression that the economy was chugging along quite nicely, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that the sluggish economic growth that had set in last September had continued through the first quarter.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Soprano at St. Michael's
description: The soprano Julianne Baird and the fortepianist Steven Lubin are to perform with the Classical Quartet in an all-Beethoven program at 8 tonight at St. Michael's Church, 225 West 99th Street. The program includes the Piano Quartet in E flat (Op. 16), the String Quartet in D (Op. 18, No. 4) and a group of folk-song settings. Tickets are $10. Information: (201) 941-4906.

title: Prague to Cut Food Subsidies
description: Food prices in Czechoslovakia will rise by almost 25 percent in July when the Government starts withdrawing state subsidies as part of a general revision of prices, Prague announced today. The head of the Federal Price Bureau, Ladislav Dvorak, told a news conference that $1.7 billion in subsidies would be removed beginning July 9. He described the ensuing price rises as the biggest since 1953. A quart of milk, which now costs 19 cents, would go up to 29 cents. ''This is the first step toward a central price reform whose objective is to balance price relationships which are already outdated,'' Mr. Dvorak said.

title: 2 in an 'Earth' Group Hurt as Car Explodes
description: An explosion in a car today injured two members of a militant environmental group, and a member of the group said tonight police planned to file charges of carrying explosives against the two.

title: Affandi; Painter, 83
description: Mr. Affandi, an Expressionist painter whose works were exhibited worldwide, died Wednesday after a long illness. He was 83 years old.

title: Court Rules Out A Noriega Deal Over Legal Fees
description: Just three days after it was reached, an unusual agreement for the Federal Government to finance the legal defense of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega collapsed today when the judge in the case determined that it would be illegal.

title: Strikes and Lack of Investors Threaten Polish Austerity Plan
description: Poland's ambitious program to force-feed this country free-market capitalism has reached its most crucial juncture to date, with the Government simultaneously confronting serious labor unrest and skittishness among foreign investors.

title: Soviets Unveil Limited Plan Toward 'Regulated Market'
description: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov proposed a package of changes for the Soviet economy today that combine a small dose of free-market liberalization with continued heavy Government regulation.

title: For Seekers of Truth, A Class on How to Hide
description: The next time somebody on the street is whispering urgently into a fast-food hamburger wrapper, think again. He or she may be a graduate of Learning Annex Course No. 523, ''How to Get Anything on Anybody.''

title: New York Loses Badly With New Hotel Tax
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art;   3 Museums Collaborate To Sum Up a Decade
description: What happened to American art during the tumultuous, combative 1980's is a large and multi-faceted subject that will undoubtedly be debated for some time. But less than six months into the 90's, one of the first assessments has already arrived, in the form of the messy, provocative exhibition titled ''The Decade Show: Frameworks of Identity in the 1980's.''

title: Laborites Fire Opening Shot In British Election Campaign
description: The next British election campaign has already begun, though nobody knows when the vote will take place - a year from now, or even two, when the mandate of the Parliament that was elected in 1987 will expire.

title: Robert Turell; Physician, 88
description: Dr. Robert Turell, a physician and an educator at Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan for more than 50 years, died on Saturday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Waste Recycling Executives Indicted in '89 Garbage Fire
description: A grand jury yesterday indicted Hub Recycling Inc. and two affiliated companies in connection with a wide range of environmental and financial crimes relating to the August 1989 garbage fire that buckled parts of Interstate 78 in Newark.

title: U.S. Says P.L.O. Not Engaged in Terror
description: The Bush Administration reaffirmed its view today that the Palestine Liberation Organization has kept its promise not to engage in terrorism.

title:
LAW;

Texas Courts Opened to Foreign Damage Cases
description: LEAD: To the alarm of many corporations, the Texas Supreme Court has made it easier for foreigners harmed overseas by American chemicals or other products to sue the manufacturer in the courts of Texas.

title: Dang Viet Chau; Vietnamese Official
description: Dang Viet Chau, a former Deputy Prime Minister of Vietnam, died of a brain hemorrhage on Monday in Hanoi, the official Hanoi radio said. No age was given.

title: Review/Film;   A Modern Passion Play In Montreal
description: Denys Arcand's intelligent, audacious ''Jesus of Montreal'' attempts to shake up stale religious assumptions, undermine religiosity with wit, and question the Gospels with a new reverence that springs from our modern, commercial world. Creating a band of actors hired to modernize a Passion play within the film, Mr. Arcand needs to balance satire and seriousness with the greatest daring and delicacy. And for the first hour, before it gives in to leaden, self-conscious Christ imagery, ''Jesus of Montreal'' succeeds.

title: Celebrations in a 3-State Region
description: Memorial Day weekend in Connecticut promises several untraditional events, including a hot-air balloon regatta in Bristol, a frog-jumping contest in Cornwall and sports-car racing in Lime Rock, as well as such traditional celebrations as a lobster festival in Mystic, train and boat rides in Essex and a parade in Fairfield.

title: Reviews/Film;   Mock Documentaries Drenched in Absurdity
description: Since ''The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover'' opened, Peter Greenaway has come to be known as the artist of sex, cannibalism and disputed X ratings. But long before that, he was making esoteric, witty, little-seen films. Samuel Beckett, Monty Python, Jorge Luis Borges and musical Minimalism are just a few of the influences that echo through the five shorts, made in the mid- to late 1970's, that open today for a three-week run at the Public Theater under the title ''Tastings of Greenaway.''

title: For Ivan Boesky, Punishment Was Tax-Deductible
description: Ivan F. Boesky testified yesterday that he had deducted from his income taxes half of the $100 million he paid to settle insider trading charges, kept millions in ill-gotten gains and illegally paid fellow prisoners to do his laundry.

title: Review/Photography;   Jan Dibbets Studies the Vicissitudes of Perspective
description: The Dutch artist Jan Dibbets is best known for a series of panoramas of land, sea and sky done in the early 1970's, at a time when Earth Art, Conceptual Art and photography seemed natural allies. These large, arcing images, made up of a number of color photographs butted together to produce a continuous landscape, were at once thoughtful and playful; one series, called ''Dutch Mountains,'' gave the illusion that the Netherlands' topography rivaled the Rockies.

title: Apple Settlement
description: Apple Computer Inc. agreed to pay $5.6 million to settle two class-action lawsuits filed by stockholders who contended that the company had given misleading information about its future performance. Apple said it still denied all allegations in the complaints but settled to avoid the expense of further legal proceedings. The suits charged that damages occurred to parties that bought Apple common stock from Jan. 17 to Jan. 29, 1989. The preliminary settlement must be approved in Federal District Court. Apple's shares were unchanged today at $42 in over-the-counter trading.

title: A Sound - but Dirty - City Budget
description: The Dinkins administration's new budget for New York City laudably strives to maintain a commitment to compassion despite falling revenues. There is one glaring lapse: a willingness to sacrifice clean streets. Otherwise, Mayor David Dinkins offers the State Legislature and City Council an example of reason and responsibility.

title: McFarlane Says Weinberger Libeled Him in Recent Book
description: In an unusually outspoken clash between two Reagan Administration officials, Robert C. McFarlane has accused former Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger of slander, libel and mean-spiritedness.

title: Judge Grants Request By Spira to Move Trial
description: A Federal judge in Tampa, Fla., granted a defense motion yesterday that moved the extortion case of Howard Spira to New York.

title: TV Weekend;   Bach the Man, Not the Mythical Being
description: Television portraits of composers, however well intended, usually walk an awkward line between being an introduction for the uninitiated and a brush-up course for aficionados. Time constraints militate in favor of musical snippets rather than uninterrupted performances. Careers and accomplishments are condensed, and analysis is rare.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Japan Air Lines Orders 20 Boeing 747-400 Jets
description: Japan Air Lines, Japan's largest airline and the Boeing Company's largest customer, said today that it had ordered 20 Boeing 747-400 jets and had taken options to buy 34 more.

title: In Alaska, New Season Of Cleanup (and Debate)
description: The Exxon Corporation oil-cleaners are back on the beaches of Prince William Sound, amid continuing disagreement about the extent of damage to the sea and the shoreline from the nation's worst oil spill.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Acustar Inc., Troy, Mich., the parts unit of Chrysler Corp., said it would invest $31.9 million in its McGraw Glass and Detroit Axle operations.

title: Power, of a Sort, to the People
description: A referendum to put policy to a popular test? It's a familiar idea in this country, especially California, but in the Soviet Union? Not for centuries, in czarist or Communist times, have the people been consulted about fundamental issues of government. But now, in another remarkable departure, that's exactly what Mikhail Gorbachev proposes.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Argentina's favorite soap opera is bubbling furiously as news reports say that divorce is imminent for President CARLOS SAUL MENEM and his wife, ZULEMA YOMA de MENEM. Recently, Mr. Menem moved out of the official residence in the Buenos Aires suburb of Olivos and into the home of his private secretary, MIGUEL ANGEL VICO.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 503 money market mutual funds increased by $94.70 million, to $381.41 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 159 institutional funds increased by $141.40 million, to $92.80 billion. The assets of the 242 general-purpose funds were down by $750.10 million, to $129.48 billion. The 102 broker-dealer funds increased by $703.40 million, to $159.13 billion, the institute said.

title: ITT Financial's $100 Million Notes
description: The ITT Financial Corporation offered $100 million of senior notes yesterday through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Morgan Gets Extension
description: The status of Manager Joe Morgan of the Boston Red Sox was settled yesterday when he was rewarded with another one-year contract extension through 1991.

title: Health Secretary Proposes State Licensing to Keep Cigarettes Away From Children
description: The nation's top health official said today that states should license the sale of cigarettes in the same strict fashion as alcohol and that they should ban cigarette vending machines.

title: CUNY Acts to Penalize Students Holding Headquarters in Protest
description: The City University of New York yesterday began disciplinary proceedings against a group of 25 to 50 students who have been occupying the university's administrative headquarters for more than three days.

title: Gabon Crowds, Angered by Death Of Dissident, Rampage in 2 Cities
description: Anti-Government protesters rioted in Gabon's two biggest cities on Wednesday, burning public buildings and property belonging to President Omar Bongo and aides, witnesses said today.

title: Major Harris Signs With British Columbia
description: The British Columbia Lions finally got their man with the arrival of a long-awaited document.

title: Washington at Work;   Wife of Aide Cut Down With Reagan Scoring Hits Against the Gun Lobby
description: When the shorthand history of gun control legislation is written, it may say that the moment when the National Rifle Association began to lose its iron grip was the moment when Sarah Brady emerged.

title: Diner's Journal
description: At Caffe Bondi

title: Macy Bonds Fall; Credit Worries Rise
description: Bond prices for R. H. Macy & Company weakened yesterday on Wall Street speculation that its merchandise shipments might be affected by new credit caution and by a ripple effect from other financially depressed companies.

title: Education's Most Serious Illness Is Poverty
description: To the Editor:

title: Research Set on New Plane
description: The Government today named a team of aerospace companies to do research and development work on a revolutionary aircraft intended to fly between New York and Tokyo in a few hours.

title: Bank of Boston Is Downgraded
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation's debt ratings were reduced by Moody's Investors Service yesterday because of loan problems and a weak regional economy. The senior debt was reduced to a speculative-grade, ''junk bond'' category of Ba-1, from the investment grade of Baa-3.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co., New York, the diversified travel, financial and information services company, appointed Daniel T. Henry senior vice president and comptroller.

title: John M. Kingsland; Investment Banker, 58
description: John Michael Kingsland, an investment banker, died of a heart attack on Monday at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 58 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Track Makes Indianapolis 500 No Sunday Drive
description: No matter who runs up front and who brings up the rear on Sunday, each of the 33 drivers in the Indianapolis 500 will pursue a common opponent. Everyone, as they say here, will be chasing the race track.

title: DINKINS PROPOSES INCREASES IN TAXES IN HIS FIRST BUDGET
description: Striving to put his stamp on New York City's spending in tough times, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday proposed a restrained budget calling for nearly $1 billion in new taxes, deep cuts in services from street cleaning to school aides and a few modest new social and health programs.

title: Vito Battista, 81, Architect, Dies; Colorful New York Political Figure
description: Vito P. Battista, an architect from Brooklyn, a former Assemblyman and a colorful perennial candidate for elective office, died yesterday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 81 years old.

title: Trail Blazers Turning To Porter for Results
description: In the final minute of a dramatic victory on Wednesday, the Portland Trail Blazers did something they have done throughout the playoffs. They turned over their offense to Terry Porter. And Porter responded, again. ''Terry was incredible down the stretch,'' said Clyde Drexler, Porter's teammate. ''Absolutely incredible.''

title: Grand Met Shifts; It Will Keep Alpo
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said it now planned to retain Alpo Petfoods Inc. as part of its worldwide food business because it was not able to reach agreement on the value of Alpo's new cat-food business. The company said it had received several bids after saying it would explore the sale of Alpo. The unit reported sales of more than $400 million for the year that ended on Sept. 30, 1989.

title: London Journal;   Lavender! Lavender! Who's for a Fresh Subway?
description: Just when riders of the East London line had resigned themselves to the pungent sweat-and-crush endurance test of subway travel, their noses sniffed roses.

title: Burt J. Siris; Manufacturer, 71
description: Burt J. Siris, a manufacturer of handbags, accessories and luggage, died of emphysema Wednesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 71 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about a lawyer who was a founder of the New York Liberal Party rendered his name incorrectly. He was Marx Lewis.

title: CHRONICLE
description: JIMMY BRESLIN'S column made its first appearance yesterday since Newsday suspended him without pay over racial slurs against a colleague, a Korean-American woman, JI-YEON YUH, who had criticized one of his columns as sexist. Reached yesterday at the newspaper's Queens office where she is a reporter, Ms. Yuh said she really had nothing to say about Mr. Breslin's return. Of the suspension, she said, ''I think two weeks is adequate in that it's more than just a token gesture.''

title: Short Positions in Active Nasdaq Stocks Off 1.7%
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a decline of 1.7 percent in the short interest in actively traded over-the-counter securities in its national market system for the four weeks that ended on May 15.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Annapolis and Karen Finley
description: Last Dec. 8, some male Annapolis midshipmen carried a female colleague into a bathroom and handcuffed her to a urinal. Then, laughing all the while, they photographed her. She was smiling. It was either that or cry, which is about the last thing a woman who wants to be accepted in a man's world (there are 400 women and 4,000 men at the academy) would do in public.

title: Liberia Capital Fearful as War Nears
description: This is a city awaiting the unknown. From the main roads to the east and the north, after five months of often-brutal fighting in the countryside, a rebel army is advancing.

title: The First Post-Cold War Summit
description: LEAD: The Memorial Day summit meeting between George Bush and Mikhail Gorbachev will be the first since the end of the cold war. As such, it provides the first real opportunity to pick up the thread lost at Yalta and Potsdam in 1945.

title: 'Jazz India' Program
description: The Badal Roy Quintet is to open the Improvisations IV Festival with a program called ''Jazz India'' at 8 tonight at Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street. Mr. Roy, a tabla player, formed his ensemble last year to perform music that draws upon American jazz and African and Indian idioms. The other players are to be Geoffrey Gordon, percussionist; Amit Chaterjee, guitarist and sitarist; Andy Harkin, bassist, and Steve Gorn, who doubles on bansuri (an Indian flute) and soprano saxophone. Tickets are $10. Information: 545-7536.

title: Reviews/Theater;   A Spoof of the 1950's Moves to Off Broadway
description: When the Plaids, a mythical 1950's male quartet from eastern Pennsylvania, perform a piece of vintage kitsch like ''Three Coins in the Fountain,'' they don't merely sing it in smooth four-part harmonies that echo the Four Aces; they physically illustrate the lyrics with a painstaking literalness. A line like ''See the ripples, how they shine'' is accompanied by hilariously synchronized arm wrigglings meant to simulate little wavelets.

title: Books of The Times;   The Good Teacher: Accumulating Small Victories
description: Small Victories

title: Eleanor Alexander Jackson; Research Scientist, 85
description: Dr. Eleanor Alexander Jackson, a research scientist in medical bacteriology, died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness. She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: At the Movies
description: Finney on Screen

title: Yanks Belt 3 More but Fall Short
description: The night ended in the unlikeliest of ways. After two games produced nine home runs and a succession of line drives, this is what finally beat the Yankees tonight: a high bouncer in front of the plate on a check swing. Strange but true. When Gary Gaetti knocked the pitch into the dirt and sent it high above the head of the Yankee pitcher, Jeff Robinson, it allowed the Minnesota Twins to send in the winning run with one out in the ninth inning for a 5-4 victory.

title: Adobe Expects Lower Profits
description: Adobe Systems Inc., which supplies software that controls laser printers, said its revenues and earnings in its second quarter would be sharply lower than anticipated, largely because of a decline in sales to Apple Computer Inc., its largest customer.

title: Excerpts From Bush's News Session on China's Trade Status With U.S.
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's White House news conference today, as recorded by the Federal News Service:

title: A Savings Rescue Falls Short
description: Lone Star Technologies had grand plans for turning around the American Federal Bank of Dallas after it bought the savings institution from the Government in late 1988.

title: Arizona Utility's $125 Million Bonds
description: The Arizona Public Service Company offered $125 million of first mortgage bonds yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Celebrations in a 3-State Region
description: In addition to marking the unofficial opening of the vacation season along the Jersey Shore, the Memorial Day weekend offers a variety of activities for those who want to watch unusual contests or just browse, buy and bet.

title: MERCHANTS' REQUESTS MAKE SHOPPERS BALK
description: More and more customer are rebelling when they make a purchase with a check or credit card and the merchant asks for certain types of personal identification.

title: Winnie Mandela Aide Guilty of Murder
description: The chief bodyguard of Winnie Mandela, wife of the South African nationalist leader Nelson Mandela, was found guilty today of murdering a 14-year-old youth who had been abducted with three men and held in her home in late 1988.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Romanian Election Is Valid Despite Flaws, U.S. Declares
description: Organized violence and voting irregularities in favor of the ruling National Salvation Front marred but did not invalidate Sunday's elections in Romania, the State Department said today.

title: 2 Brokers Win Shearson Case
description: Two former employees of Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. in Winter Park, Fla., have won a $570,000 award against the company, their lawyer said today.

title: Leave Your Worry on The Doorstep
description: ''On the Sunny Side of the Street,'' sung by Louis Armstrong, was playing on a tape recorder beside the laid-out body of Rocky Graziano in a room in the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel in Manhattan.

title: Private Pension System Is Alive and Well
description: To the Editor:

title: Edgar Conradson, Tourism Official, 58
description: Edgar Conradson, the former manager of the Swedish Tourist Board in Manhattan, died on Thursday at Bellevue Hospital Center after a fall in March that left him paralyzed. He was 58 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Flaws in a Voucher Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: Quarterly Trade Deficit A 6-Year Low
description: The United States trade deficit shrank to $26.4 billion in the first quarter, the smallest quarterly imbalance in more than six years, the Government said today.

title: KEY RATES
U.S. Delays Thai Action
description: The United States has extended its deadline for action on a complaint that Thailand is unfairly restricting the sale of American cigarettes, the Office of the United States Trade Representative said today.

title: Thomas M. Waller, Horseman, 86
description: Thomas Mercer Waller, long a prominent figure in New York thoroughbred racing, died on Thursday at his home in Bedford Hills, N.Y., after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Charles Coe, 83, Dies; Advertising Executive
description: Charles E. Coe, a former advertising executive, died of cancer on May 18 at the Virginia (Minn.) Regional Medical Center. He was 83 years old and lived in Virginia.

title: Evolution in Europe;   For Ottawa, A Gorbachev On the Run
description: Janis Zealand, a controller at the All Nations Flag Company in Toronto, was thinking about the flag business. But her mind was not on the 150 Soviet flags she had just dispatched to Ottawa for official use during the state visit of Mikhail S. Gorbachev there next week.

title: Lacrosse Test for No. 1 Syracuse
description: When the Syracuse Orangemen (11-0) take the field Saturday at Rutgers Stadium against North Carolina (12-3) in the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse championships, they will be trying to stretch a winning streak to 26 games.

title: Books of The Times;   Comrades in Arms: A U.S.-Soviet Memoir
description: Remembering War

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Beliefs
description: The University of Notre Dame gave its prestigious Laetare Medal to Sister Thea Bowman at its commencement on Sunday, but she was not there to receive it. Seven weeks earlier, at the age of 52, she had died.

title: Deal for Sail Magazine
description: The Meredith Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell Sail magazine to Cahners Publishing, which already produces Power & Motoryacht, Motor Boat and Motoryacht International magazines. The price was not disclosed.

title: Students End Occupation of CUNY Building
description: Protesting students agreed in court yesterday to end their occupation of the administrative headquarters of the City University of New York in return for negotiations on their demands for amnesty and a stronger voice in CUNY's minority hiring and tuition policies.

title: COMMENCEMENTS 7-Year-Old Law School Graduates 132
description: As 132 students graduated yesterday from the City University of New York Law School, they and administrators and faculty members took stock of the seven-year-old institution, which is struggling through its own rites of passage.

title: Finish Start at the Summit
description: Presidents Bush and Gorbachev are poised to announce agreement in principle at their summit meeting next week in Washington on a vital treaty to reduce strategic nuclear arms. But that won't be possible if caterwauling right-wing critics have their way.

title: Scientists Urge Rapid Action on Global Warming
description: A panel of scientists warned today that unless emissions of carbon dioxide and other harmful gases were immediately cut by more than 60 percent, global temperatures would rise sharply over the next century, with unforeseeable consequences for humanity.

title: New Jersey Suburbs Attack Florio's Plan to Shift Their School Aid
description: Gov. Jim Florio's proposed plan to shift tens of millions of dollars in state education aid from prosperous suburban school systems to poorer urban and rural districts was sharply criticized by surburban school officials today as unfair, divisive and shortsighted.

title: Diversco Outlook
description: Diversco Inc. said it had hired J. C. Bradford & Company as its investment banking adviser to examine the possibility of a merger with another organization and other alternatives to enhance shareholder value. Diversco is a diversified service company providing supervised skilled and unskilled labor to the industrial, commercial and institutional markets throughout the Southeast. Diversco's stock rose 37.5 cents today, to $4.50, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Fordham Wins in Upset
description: Kevin Secor, a junior catcher, hit a grand slam in a five-run first inning and Fordham went on to upset Arkansas, 8-5, today in a first-round game of the Midwest Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: Review/Music;   A Testing of Mettle Balanced by Novelty
description: Conductors who take their orchestras on tour have a mandate to choose programs that make an interesting and perhaps slightly novel two hours' listening while also offering a thorough test of the ensemble's mettle. Edo de Waart achieved something close to an ideal balance of those virtues in the program he and the Minnesota Orchestra brought to Carnegie Hall last Saturday evening.

title: Georgia Judge Rule Klan Is Persecuted
description: Calling the Ku Klux Klan ''a persecuted group,'' a Georgia state court judge ruled today that a state ban on the wearing of masks illegally restricted the group's free speech.

title: About New York;   Pediatrics Vans: House Calls For the Homeless
description: Cynthia O.'s 15th birthday present came exactly one week early. It was a fat baby boy, her first. Seventeen months later, on a spring day rinsed in gray, she and the baby, Ronnell, are making their periodic visit to their pediatrician on wheels.

title: WITH ELECTRONIC TRANSLATORS
description: Even languages you think you speak can leave you at a loss for words. Pocket dictionaries remain the richest source of portable help this side of a native traveling companion, but they do not help with syntax, and it can take what seems like forever to look up a word you want.

title: Tests by Experts Challenge Navy Over Iowa Blast
description: Government experts on explosives presented new evidence today challenging the Navy's conclusion that the explosion on the battleship Iowa last year was probably an act of suicidal sabotage by a desperate young sailor.

title: U.S. Judge Refuses to Dismiss Charges Facing Mayor Barry
description: A Federal district judge refused today to dismiss 14 drug-related charges against Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., clearing the way for a trial to begin on June 4.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Dr. Stanley J. Sarnoff, a cardiologist and inventor, misstated his age and the circumstances of his death. He was 73 and died of heart disease. He was not undergoing surgery.

title: Patents;   Electronic Data Stored On Crystals
description: Researchers affiliated with the Microelectronics and Computer Technology Corporation, the electronics research consortium in Austin, Tex., obtained the first of two patents this week for a method of storing computer data as images on light-sensitive crystal particles.

title: Environmentalists Hurt, Then Held, in Blast
description: When a bomb went off here Thursday night in a car carrying two leaders of a radical environmental group, their supporters were quick to blame opponents of a protest aimed at stopping the logging of redwoods in northern California.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Talk on Arms Seen as Summit Focus
description: After briefing Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d on his talks with the Soviet Foreign Minister, the West German Foreign Minister predicted today that conventional weapons would be a major topic at next week's Washington summit meeting.

title: 2 Chicagoans Return But Think as Visitors
description: Isiah Thomas and Mark Aguirre, inseparable friends, grew up within a few blocks of each other in Chicago. Today, they will be back home with the Detroit Pistons, who are looking for a second consecutive National Basketball Association title.

title: Candice C. Baker Weds M. E. Leit
description: Candice C. Baker, a doughter of Mrs. Nicholas M. Zumas of Bethlehem Pa., and Charles S. Baker of Augusta, Me., was married yesterday to Dr. Michael E. Leit, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barton H. Leit of Boca Raton Fla. The Rev. Dr. Alan C. Mermann officiated at Yale University.

title: A Two-Eyed Summit
description: The customary deliberate downbeat so as not to risk bloated expectations from an imminent Soviet-American summit meeting is the current Washington sound. And there almost surely won't be the grand agreements on arms reductions that President Bush optimistically anticipated last year.

title: Endowment Gets Backing Of Arts Panel
description: An advisory group of representatives from major arts organizations unanimously declared its support today for extending the life of the National Endowment for the Arts for another five years without legislative restrictions on the kind of art the endowment supports.

title: Few Candidates From Minorities Lead Fire Exam
description: The results of the recent civil service examination for firefighters were released yesterday, and officials said they were concerned about how few minority candidates are now eligible for appointment.

title: Review/Theater;   A Bit of 30's Seediness
description: The House of Candles Theater, the ramshackle storefront site on the Lower East Side of Manhattan where the Irondale Ensemble Project is performing the 1929 Brecht-Weill show, ''Happy End,'' is an appropriately atmospheric space in which to stage the team's followup to ''Three Penny Opera.''

title: New Tactic For Yanks: No Homers
description: When he hit the ball and saw it skip lazily inside the bag at first, the one thing that came to Jesse Barfield's mind was Minnesota.

title: Marsh Destroyed, Owner Is Fined
description: A New York commodities dealer pleaded guilty in Federal District Court today to destroying 86 acres of wetlands on his hunting retreat and was ordered to pay a $1 million fine and $1 million as restitution.

title: Your Money;   Retirees Need Investing Acumen
description: For retirees, making the right investment decisions can be crucial because the income from investments must often replace earned income for living expenses. Consequently, most retirees feel they cannot afford to risk any loss of capital.

title: Ethel Stafford Masland Marries Peter Wolcott
description: Ethel Stafford Masland, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William Stafford Masland of Tucson Ariz., and West Chop, Mass.,was marries yesterday to Peter Wolcott, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Calvin Wolcott of San Rafael, Calif. The Rev. Thomas E. Copps performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Vineyard Christian Community Church in Tucson.

title: In Africa, the Term 'Tribe' Is Worse Than Useless
description: To the Editor:

title: Excerpts From Report to Congress on the Iowa Explosion
description: The following is an excerpt from a report commissioned by the General Accounting Office, based largely on testing by the Sandia National Laboratory, about the Navy's investigation of the explosion aboard the battleship Iowa. The report was submitted today to the Senate Armed Services Committee.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 26, 1990
description: Companies

title: Oilers Revel Over Return To the Top
description: The embrace lasted at least a minute, from its hesitant start through a near-topple off the podium at the center of a locker room dizzy from euphoria and the thick aroma of champagne.

title: Legal Fight Goes On as Disputed Exhibit Ends
description: A photography exhibition that set off a ferocious debate here about artistic freedom and pornography and led to criminal indictments against a museum will end its seven-week run on Saturday with essential legal questions still unresolved.

title: The Ultimate Golf Hazard
description: The United States Golf Association's ''Rules of Golf'' states that a golfer may discontinue play if he believes there is danger from lightning. It's a sensible rule that all golfers should follow.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   When a Pool Is Dirty
description: The Memorial Day weekend is the unofficial beginning of summer, but before you dive into that pool for the first swim of the season take a moment to see if it's clean. Otherwise, you could suffer from a number of ailments, among them eye and ear infections. The cleaning instructions provided by your pool manufacturer and/or installer should give you a cure for most problems. Many pool centers will test your pool water for pollutants. Here are some signs that indicate a cleaning or repair is in order.

title: Arafat, in Geneva, Calls on U.N. To Send Force to Occupied Areas
description: Yasir Arafat, the leader of the Palestine Liberation Organization, urged the United Nations Security Council today to send a new international force to the Israel-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip to protect Palestinians and pave the way for eventual Israeli withdrawal.

title: Rise in April Spending Topped Income Increase
description: Americans spent more last month despite a slump in income gains, the Commerce Department said today, providing a continuing stimulus for the economy at the start of the second quarter.

title: Rose Case Proceeding
description: A required presentencing report in the Pete Rose tax-evasion case was made available yesterday in Cincinnati to prosecutors, Rose and Rose's lawyers. The parties have 10 days to object to any factual statements in the report. The report will then go to United States District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel, who will decide the sentence.

title: Thornburgh Took Polygraph Test in Leak Inquiry
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh submitted to a polygraph examination during an internal criminal investigation at the Justice Department that led to the reassignment of his two closest aides, senior Bush Administration officials disclosed today.

title: B.P. in Accord On Coal Unit Sales
description: The British Petroleum Company said it had reached an agreement to sell substantially all its remaining United States coal operations to the Zeigler Coal Holding Company for $115 million. The agreement is subject to United States approval.

title: Home Resales Fell in April
description: Sales of existing homes fell by 2.1 percent in April, the third drop in four months as mortgage rates remained high, a real estate trade group reported today.

title: Blown Open: the Navy's Need to Blame
description: When the Navy managed to ignite five bags of gunpowder Thursday at its Dahlgren, Va., weapons station, it exploded more than the official story that a gunner's mate had sabotaged the battleship Iowa, killing himself and 46 other sailors. It blew open a tight naval mindset that demands blame. It's a mindset so incapable of accepting uncertainty that the Navy couldn't let that baffling tragedy go unexplained but had to smear a crewman's memory on flimsy evidence.

title: Dr. Schweitzer on the Use of Lab Animals
description: To the Editor:

title: Conservatives Threaten To Upset G.O.P. Ticket
description: The choosing of a Republican state ticket verged on becoming chaotic yesterday as the party's traditional ally, the Conservative Party, threatened to oppose the Republicans' likely choice for governor.

title: 'Crash! (Tinkle)' to Join 'Thud' on Upper West Side
description: New York City's effort to get its trash under control will take a big step forward on Tuesday when recycling of metal and glass becomes mandatory for the first time in a Manhattan neighborhood - the Upper West Side.

title: It's Not Gracie Mansion, but It's Not Bad
description: Ed Koch, former resident of Gracie Mansion, doesn't read decorating magazines. He doesn't have to. In furnishing the central living area of his new apartment overlooking Washington Square Park, he simply followed the lead of Julius Caesar.

title: Georgetown Journal;   Popularity Is Bringing Hot Spot To a Boil
description: The residents call it ''Ground Zero.''

title: Koito Rejects Pickens's List
description: Directors of the Japanese auto parts maker Koito Manufacturing Company decided on Thursday to oppose a list of requests submitted by T. Boone Pickens, Koito's largest shareholder.

title: Giants Win on 3 Homers by Mitchell
description: Kevin Mitchell hit three home runs in a game for the first time in his career and drove in five runs tonight as the San Francisco Giants outdueled Pittsburgh, 9-8, to knock the Pirates out of first place in the National League East.

title: CHRONICLE
description: For nearly 20 years ROBERT REDFORD has used his fame to fight for the environment. Next Saturday, the University of Massachusetts in Boston is to give him an honorary doctor of science degree for his efforts.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS

title: JUDGING WHICH BIKE HELMETS ARE SAFEST
description: In a cinder-block warehouse near the Long Island village of Stony Brook, bicycle helmets come to die. The headgear is smashed, split, snapped and yanked, all to determine whether it can be sold bearing a green label that means added safety.

title: Reagan's Doctors Find Scars in Small Intestine
description: Former President Ronald Reagan's doctors have discovered several small areas of scar tissue in his small intestine that they believe are a result of his surgery for bowel cancer in 1985, Mr. Reagan's office said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANTHONY HARVEY AND KATHERINE HEPBURN had a skirmish with a traffic officer yesterday in midtown Manhattan. It ended with the film director getting a summons for harassment and the officer gettng X-Rays as Bellevue Hospital.

title: Cooper Union
description: Charlayne Hunter-Gault, national correspondent for ''The MacNeil- Lehrer News Hour,'' urged members of Cooper Union's class of 1990 yesterday to become ''ambassadors of humanity through your work'' and to combat racism by striving to make diverse voices heard.

title: Evolution in Europe;   RISING FOOD PRICES STIR PANIC BUYING IN SOVIET MARKETS
description: Government plans to raise prices sharply set off panic buying and opposition in the country today, causing the Moscow authorities to order restrictions on food shopping in the city and prompting the Ukrainian Prime Minister to vow resistance.

title: Vic Tayback Dies; Actor, 60, Was Mel In the 'Alice' Series
description: Vic Tayback, a film, television and theater actor best known for playing Mel the diner owner in the television series ''Alice,'' died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Glendale, Calif. He was 60 years old.

title: Patents;   Tamper-Proof Bottle Relies on Optical Fiber
description: Ever since containers of Tylenol pain relievers were laced with cyanide in 1982, hundreds of patents have been issued for tamper-proof medicine bottles. This week a New Jersey inventor, Edward P. Diehl, patented an idea that may be the most unusual yet.

title: Maureen McGovern Show
description: Maureen McGovern will sing at a benefit for the York Theater Company at 8 P.M. on June 6 at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue at 90th Street. The benefit marks the 21st anniversary of the company, which is presenting Chekhov's ''Cherry Orchard'' until June 3. Benefit tickets are $25 to $500. Information: 534-5366.

title: Patents;   Antibody Method Used To Locate Infections
description: Immunomedics Inc., a small biotechnology concern in Warren, N.J., has obtained a patent on a method of pinpointing infections and inflammations.

title: Domino's Pizza Suitors Cited
description: Domino's Pizza Inc., the nation's second-largest pizza maker, which is up for sale, said today that several parties were interested in purchasing it and talks had been held with one potential buyer.

title: After 2 Near Misses, Phoenix Hits It Big
description: Frustrated by a pair of last-second defeats in Portland, the Phoenix Suns left nothing to chance tonight. They did not settle for beating the Trail Blazers. They embarrassed them. Leading by as many as 46 points in the third quarter, Phoenix waltzed to a 123-89 victory at Veterans Memorial Coliseum in the third game of the Western Conference final. Portland leads the four-of-seven-game series, 2-1, with the next game to be played Sunday afternoon in Phoenix.

title: Mets Seek Inquiry
description: The Mets have asked the commissioner's office to investigate whether improper contacts with Darryl Strawberry's agent might have been made by other National League teams.

title: Review/Dance;   The Ballet Must Go On (and Does)
description: Dance-drama other than the kind customarily identified with Antony Tudor's ballets was the order of the evening on Thursday when American Ballet Theater presented its first all-Tudor program of the season.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CARLA A. HILLS and LOUIS RUKEYSER have received the Women's Economic Roundtable's award, which was given for only the second time in the organization's 12-year history. The award was established to honor people who make outstanding contributions in financial policy and to education on economic issues.

title: Bavaro Catching His Stride in Return to Giants
description: Mark Bavaro is alive and almost well. Today, for the first time since he tore a ligament in his left knee last November and underwent surgery in January, he stepped onto a football field and caught passes.

title: Elliott Galkin, 69; Music Critic Led Peabody Institute
description: Dr. Elliott W. Galkin, who had been a music critic for The Baltimore Sun and a director of the Peabody Institute, died at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore on Thursday after a long illness. He was 69 years old and lived in Timonium, Md.

title: HOLIDAY ON MONDAY
description: Memorial Day will be observed on Monday. Here are holiday schedules.

title: Former Official Surrenders In Dumping Body of Friend
description: Responding to a warrant for his arrest, a former New York City official who had placed the body of a woman outside his town house on the Upper East Side last month turned himself in to the police last night, to be charged with a misdemeanor, the police said.

title: Augie Donatelli, 76, Ex-Baseball Umpire
description: Augie Donatelli, a National League umpire for 24 years and the founder of the Major League Umpires Association in 1964, died Thursday. He was 76 years old. Mr. Donatelli died in his sleep at home, his wife, Mary, said.

title: Science Gives Nature a Hand in Purging the Hudson of PCB's
description: To the Editor:

title: Liberian Talks of an Early Vote
description: The President of Liberia, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, said today that he would consider holding early elections if it would bring a peaceful settlement to the West African nation's insurgency.

title: Campbell Plans Sale Of Units
description: The Campbell Soup Company said today that it planned to sell several of its European food units to focus on its more profitable businesses. Campbell, whose board approved the divestiture on Thursday, said that the total sales of the businesses to be sold exceeded $200 million a year and that it expected the sale to result in a $55 million charge against fourth-quarter earnings.

title: Tour of 'Aida' Canceled
description: The International Opera Festival announced yesterday that the American tour of its production of ''Aida'' had been canceled. The tour, with the soprano Grace Bumbry heading a cast of 1,200 in an elaborate production featuring numerous animals and huge props, was to have begun next Friday at Giants Stadium in the New Jersey Meadowlands and to have moved on to Los Angeles and San Francisco.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, an article in Business Day yesterday about manufacturing innovations at General Motors appeared in some editions with paragraphs misplaced.

title: Dr. Nahum Winer, 82, A Cardiologist, Is Dead
description: Dr. Nahum J. Winer, a cardiologist, died on Thursday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Moscow and Market Theory
description: Western analysts view the new Soviet economic plan as too little, too late. Some see it as an attempt to legitimize a rapid drive to free markets. News analysis, page 4.

title: Adobe Stock Falls by Nearly a Third
description: The share price of Adobe Systems Inc., which supplies software that controls many laser printers, plunged by nearly a third today after the company's announcement of bad news late Thursday. It hardly mattered that the news turned out to be not quite so bad after all.

title: Doctors Faulted In 1984 Death Of 18-Year-Old
description: The State Board of Regents today faulted two doctors with gross negligence in their care of Libby Zion, who was 18 years old when she died at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in 1984.

title: Easy Goer Tunes Up
description: Easy Goer quelled any questions about his fitness by working five furlongs in 59 3/5 yesterday morning at Belmont Park.

title: Review/Jazz;   In the Coltrane Groove
description: Last Saturday's show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Coltrane Legacy, was a good idea on several fronts. For one thing, John Coltrane's music is rarely played anymore. The contributions of the saxophonist, who died in 1967, are taken for granted now, and the concert allowed the audience to examine exactly how well arranged his later works were and how carefully he constructed his pieces to evoke certain moods that on records sound deceptively natural and improvised. And for another, the show allowed four exceptional and overlooked saxophonists - Billy Harper, Odean Pope, Andrew White and Sonny Fortune - to stretch out on material that had obviously been a major influence on their development.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Serbs to Expel 17 Albanians
description: The Serbian authorities have ordered the expulsion of 17 Albanian refugees accused of provoking ethnic unrest in the troubled province of Kosovo, official news reports say. The Albanians, mostly the offspring of defectors who escaped Albania's harsh Stalinist rulers after 1945, were given 30 days to leave Yugoslavia and find a new country in which to settle, the official reports said today.

title: Once Movie Trash, Now Collectible
description: In the mid-1970's, M-G-M Studios hired a salvage crew to haul away and dispose of the waste material stored on one of its back lots, which included the background painting of the Emerald City used in ''The Wizard of Oz.'' Recently, that same matte painting, which the cartage company recognized and held in storage, sold for $44,000 at an auction here.

title: TRAFFIC ALERT
description: The west side of Broadway will be closed today from 76th to 86th Street from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. for the Livable West Side Festival.

title: Democrats Identify Sources of Unregulated Money
description: Responding to criticism for not identifying its biggest donors, the Democratic Party has released a listing of organizations and individuals who have contributed a total of $3.6 million to the party since the beginning of 1989.

title: Schuler to Clippers As Head Coach
description: Mike Schuler, who was honored as the National Basketball Association's coach of the year after his 1986-87 season with the Portland Trail Blazers, was hired yesterday as the Los Angeles Clippers' head coach. He replaced Don Casey, who had a 41-85 record in a season and a half of coaching before being dismissed last month.

title: Dow Drops 34.63 in High-Tech Selloff
description: Stocks tumbled yesterday in the wake of a drop in bond prices, a rise in interest rates and increasing nervousness that high-flying technology stocks may be overdue for what Wall Street calls ''a sharp correction.''

title: Evolution in Europe;   Gorbachev Issues New Vow Against Germany in NATO
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that the Soviet Union would review its policies on European arms control and security negotiations if a reunited Germany was a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Moderate Arabs, Israelis Must Talk
description: LEAD: The killings of innocent Palestinians by an Israeli in the occupied territories and the subsequent popular uproar and agitation underscore the need for the Arabs and Israelis urgently to fashion their own special glasnost - an accommodation that would seriously tackle the festering issues that have haunted the Middle

title:
COMMENCEMENTS;

Sarah Lawrence College
description: LEAD: Paul Newman today urged the graduating class of Sarah Lawrence College, which includes his wife, Joanne Woodward, and a daughter, to be part of the response, not the silence, in dealing with problems today.

title: G.M. Vote Backs Rise In Pensions
description: Shareholders approved by a wide margin today a sharp increase in pension benefits for the General Motors Corporation's top executives.

title: David Levine, 79, Dies; A Landscape Architect
description: David Levine, a New York landscape architect, died of pneumonia on Tuesday at Los Gatos, Calif. He was 79 years old and moved to Los Gatos from the Bronx when he retired two years ago.

title: Evolution in Europe: Moscow Journal;   His Only Crime Was Being the First
description: At a time when everyone in the Soviet Union from President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on down is bracing for the conversion to a market-oriented economy, Ramiz Shabanov sits in jail, serving a 15-year term for ''private entrepreneurial activities.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the effect of the savings and loan bailout on the Federal deficit described effects of accounting differences incorrectly in some copies. The deficit projected by the Bush Administration for the 1991 fiscal year would reach $199 billion if $61 billion in bailout costs were included in the deficit calculations. If those costs were not included, and surpluses in the Social Security and other trust funds were also not counted, the deficit would reach $276 billion.

title: Chinese Thanks Bush on Trade
description: Prime Minister Li Peng said today that he welcomed President Bush's recommendation to extend most-favored-nation trading status to China for another year, and he suggested that Beijing would try to improve relations with Washington.

title: City College
description: Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, was booed loudly at the City College commencement ceremonies yesterday when it was announced that he could not appear as scheduled to receive an honorary degree because of a time conflict with his military duties.

title: Bush Signs Bill to Provide Aid to Panama and Managua
description: President Bush tonight signed a spending bill that includes $720 million in aid for Panama and Nicaragua after he arrived here for a four-day holiday.

title: INSIDE
description: Lie Detector for Thornburgh

title: I'm a Bike Messenger, and I Break the Law
description: LEAD: I am a bike messenger, and I violate the law every day I go to work.

title: David I. Arbuse, Psychiatrist, 89
description: Dr. David I. Arbuse, a psychiatrist and neurosurgeon, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 years old.

title: Evolution in Europe;   YELTSIN IS AHEAD IN RUSSIAN VOTING
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, a rival and fierce critic of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, took the lead early this morning in the contest for the presidency of the Russian republic - a job that would give him an important power base.

title: A Many-Faceted Author Is Named Poet Laureate
description: Mark Strand, a poet, a translator of Spanish literature and a short-story writer, was named today the nation's fourth poet laureate.
