title: Beech-Nut Recalling 2 Types of Baby Food
description: The Beech-Nut Nutrition Corporation said today that it was recalling two types of baby food distributed in 22 states because small stones had been found in them.

title: Governor of Kashmir Resigns
description: The Governor of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, who oversaw the four-month crackdown against Muslim militants here, resigned today and is likely to be replaced by a top security official. The resignation of the Governor, Jagmohan, came as members of Parliament in New Delhi demanded his removal over the killing of at least 50 people by paramilitary troops on Monday after the assassination of a top religious leader here.

title: Sewer-Main Ban in Westchester Is Lifted
description: New York State's Department of Environmental Conservation today lifted a two-and-one-half-old year ban on the construction of new sewer mains in much of Westchester County that had halted an estimated $80 million worth of housing and other projects.

title: Patients' Grades Help to Set Pay for Health-Plan Doctors
description: A growing number of large health-care plans are asking patients to grade their doctors: How long are they kept waiting in the office? Can the doctor be reached at night and on weekends? Does the doctor listen as patients describe symptoms? How well is a treatment explained?

title: An Heirloom 2 1/2 Miles Around
description: Tony George, who has taken over the presidency of the Indianapolis Motor Speedway at the age of 30, is a young man in a job that very much requires an old frame of mind.

title: Meridian Oil to Get Unicon Reserves
description: Burlington Resources Inc. said its energy subsidiary Meridian Oil Inc. had agreed to acquire all of the producing properties of the Unicon Producing Company for $399 million. The properties contain reserves equivalent to about half a trillion cubic feet of natural gas.

title: Banks' Drive On Laundering
description: Banks spent more than $129 million last year on Government-required reports aimed at catching money launderers, the American Bankers Association said this week.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column of Business Day on May 11 misidentified the group that honored Richard V. Benson as Direct Marketer of the Year. It was Direct Marketing Day in New York Inc., a nonprofit organization, not the Direct Marketing Association.

title: Ex-Chicago Merc Chief Is Barred
description: A former chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange was permanently barred from the futures industry today after an administrative law judge found he had failed to impose adequate supervision on two brokers who were found to have bilked customers out of thousands of dollars.

title: Prices of Long-Term U.S. Bonds Decline
description: Prices of long-term Treasury bonds tumbled yesterday in a shortened pre-Memorial Day weekend session. The Treasury securities market, which normally does not have fixed trading hours, closed at 2 P.M., Eastern daylight time.

title: Officials See Census Failing In New York
description: New York City and Congressional officials say the crucial second phase of the 1990 census, the door-to-door canvass of households, is failing as badly as the mail responses.

title: Evolution in Europe;   The Kremlin Takes a Shot
description: The Kremlin's latest proposals to rejuvenate the Soviet economy, unveiled to an incredulous citizenry this week, are widely viewed by Western analysts as too little, too late. The Government's concept of a ''regulated market economy,'' they believe, will exact much of the political pain of more radical approaches without generating much economic gain.

title: WITNESS SAYS U.S. OFFERED REWARD TO GET A SUSPECT
description: A Federal drug agent testified in court today that top officials of the Drug Enforcement Administration authorized plans, including a $50,000 reward, for the capture of a Mexican doctor who the agency believed was involved in the murder of an American drug agent in Mexico.

title: Competitive Race on Tap In L'eggs Mini Marathon
description: The date is a bit earlier than usual, the weather should be a bit cooler, and the field, reduced by the Memorial Day weekend scheduling, will be smaller. But when 6,000 or so women take off from the West Drive at 61st Street in Central Park at 9:30 this morning to begin the 1990 L'eggs Mini Marathon, those at the head of the pack should be about as fast and just as competitive as ever over the 6.2-mile course.

title: Review/Music;   A New York Home for Soviet Jazz
description: The opening of Vartan's Bluebird, a new venture by the Soviet impresario Vartan Tonoian at Irving Plaza, was a celebratory affair, drawing a hall full of emigres along with the merely curious and a smattering of jazz cognoscenti hoping to learn about Soviet jazz. Introducing Soviet jazz musicians to New York is a bit like shipping snow to Alaska in January: not only are they redundant, but they have also probably lost some meaning in the trip. But Mr. Tonoian (who plans to present concerts every Thursday at Irving Plaza, on Irving Place at East 15th Street) obviously loves his compatriots, and the opening concert on May 18 was meant to be a trade show for their wares.

title: Romania's Halfway House
description: The party isn't over in Romania, where former Communists have managed to hang on to power in an election skewed against their underdog rivals. Yet a fairer campaign might well have had the same outcome, if by a smaller margin.

title: Black Unionists Cheer Dinkins in New Orleans
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins was loudly cheered today as he arrived to address the Coalition of Black Trade Unionists meeting here.

title: Subpoena on Centrust
description: A subcommittee of the House Banking Comittee voted this week to subpoena David L. Paul, the ousted chairman of Centrust Savings Bank, as part of its investigation into the failure of the huge Miami savings institution. In March, Mr. Paul declined to appear at a panel hearing investigating Centrust's failure. Federal regulators took over Centrust on Feb. 2, immediately dismissing Mr. Paul. Some experts say it will cost $2 billion or more to bail out the institution.

title: Topics of the Times;   The World (Cup) Beckons
description: Chris Henderson's parents will skip his kid brother's high school graduation next month so they can watch Chris play World Cup soccer in Italy. Chris himself is still in college - at 19, he's the youngest member of America's inexperienced squad. That's American soccer. All of this year's team members were schoolboys when Pele and other foreign stars gave soccer a brief moment as a big-time U.S. sport in the 1970's. Now they're about to brave the rough and tumble of world competition.

title: What if They Ran Indy And Japan Came, Too?
description: None of the 33 cars in the Indianapolis 500 on Sunday will have a Japanese engine, but future races may be very different. The event, as much a noisy reunion for car-crazy Americans as a test of speed and endurance, is attracting new attention from Japanese auto makers eager to increase their appeal in the United States and Japan.

title: Topics of the Times;   Why Do So Many Kids Die?
description: The National Commission on Child and Youth Deaths was created in 1988 to make the first systematic analysis of mortality among Americans under 18. The group hasn't received money and hasn't met. It's time Congress and the President rectified that.

title: Drug War at Stake in Colombia Vote
description: When Colombians vote for president on Sunday, their ballots will constitute a referendum on the nation's nine-month war with cocaine traffickers.

title: In Africa, the Term 'Tribe' Is Worse Than Useless;   One-Party Democracy
description: To the Editor Your May 6 news article on the political debate over whether Kenya should adopt a multiparty system implies that instituting such a system would assure democracy and respect for human and civil liberties, and that such guarantees would be absent in a one-party state. Democracy is not a function of political parties but rather a product of effective government policy and programs. Kenya enjoys one of the most open and democratic societies on the African continent.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Savings Bank, a unit of Hawaiian Electric Industries Inc., Honolulu, signed a definitive agreement to acquire the Hawaii deposits and branches of First Nationwide Bank, San Francisco. First Nationwide had $242 million in deposits and 18 branches in Hawaii as of March 2.

title: After 4 Days in Road Median, Wreck Victim Is Recovering
description: A badly injured hit-and-run victim spent four days and nights in the brushy median of a freeway, trying to signal for help from any of the 128,000 vehicles that pass by every day.

title: Midway to Add Flights
description: Midway Airlines Inc. said it would increase service from Chicago's Midway Airport by adding one daily round-trip flight each to Los Angeles, Cleveland, Omaha and Minneapolis-St. Paul starting next Friday. Midway also said it would add one daily round-trip flight to Denver beginning June 15.

title: The Right and Duty To Kill a Murderer
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I said you can get used to posh very quickly, and I did.'' -Edward I. Koch, on hid postmayoral apartment

title: Jenrette Reported to Decline Chairman's Job at Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange recently approached Richard H. Jenrette, the chairman of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, about the possibility of taking the top position at the Big Board, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: Hiss, Cackle And Purr
description: Fictional villains of my childhood usually cackled, hissed or purred. One line they were especially fond of cackling, hissing or purring was addressed to heroes about to suffer unbearably slow, agonizing deaths:

title: Mets Fail Again In Clutch
description: A routine fly ball would have tied the game in the sixth inning. A simple ground ball to one of the middle infielders would have done the same in the seventh. The Mets did not get either and so they lost to the Padres, 5-4, last night at Shea Stadium.

title: Award for Barkley
description: His fellow N.B.A. players have voted Charles Barkley, the powerful forward for the Philadelphia 76ers, as The Sporting News player of the year. In balloting by 180 players, Barkley received 57 1/2 votes to 44 1/2 for Magic Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers and 44 for Michael Jordan of the Chicago Bulls.

title: Abortion, Still the Key to the Senate
description: LEAD: As the 1990 Senate elections approach, the idea is taking hold that Republicans will avoid the normal off-year losses suffered by the party in the White House. Some predict that Republicans may even gain five seats and win control of the Senate. But observers should look more closely at the impact of the most potent issue in American politics: abortion.

title: Avery and Dennison In Merger Agreement
description: Two office products companies - the Avery International Corporation and the Dennison Manufacturing Company - agreed today to merge in a deal worth about $500 million.

title: Aid Resumed Too Argentina; Debt Talk Set
description: The International Monetary Fund approved the resumption of aid to Argentina yesterday and, at the same time, Argentina and its commercial bankers said they will start debt negotiations on June 7.

title: Young Love Gone Wrong Is Key To Trial in a Murder Conspiracy
description: A confessed killer took the witness stand here this week to tell a Superior Court jury the tale of an impassioned teen-age love affair that went ''beyond obsession'' to murder and, ultimately, betrayal.

title: Telling On Himself
description: Ivan F. Boesky was supposed to be implicating somebody else, as usual, but when he took the witness stand last week, some of the most damaging disclosures he made concerned Ivan Boesky.

title: Miss Sarkisian to Wed Mark Denesuk in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Norman Sarkisian of West Hartford, Conn., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Pamela R. Sarkisian and Mark Denesuk, a son of Mr. and Mrs. G. Gregory Denesuk of Palisades Park, N.J.

title: Campus Life: Texas;   Band on the Rise: Twang Twang Shock-a-Boom
description: If college music provides an indication of the future, twang tunes, a new rage at the University of Texas, may catch on.

title: Jennifer Kuhn Weds Charles Irwin 4th
description: Jennifer Sherburne Kuhn, the daughter of Jay Carlton Kuhn of Belvedere, Calif., and Mrs. John Fiske Raynolds 3d of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Charles Parson Irwin 4th, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin 3d of Fort Lauderdale, Fla. The Rev. Merton Rymph officiated at the Second Congregational Church in Greenwich, Conn.

title: Publisher Victorious on Hubbard Biography
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that a publisher is not required to delete material from a coming biography of L. Ron Hubbard, founder of the Church of Scientology.

title: Vietnam Memorial Centerpiece Picked
description: LEAD: THE centerpiece for New Jersey's Vietnam Veterans Memorial will be a trio of bronze figures by a Trenton sculptor. The state's Vietnam Veterans Memorial Committee recently selected the work of the sculptor, Jay Warren, because it would offer a variety of perspectives within the open-air pavilion that encircles the sculpture.

title: Dr. Emslander Is Wed to Dr. Ryan
description: Dr. Hildegard C. Emslander, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Richard Emslander of Rochester, Minn., and Dr. Michael H. Ryan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Ryan of New Haven, Conn., were married yesterday. The Rev. Timothy L. Hodapp performed the ceremony at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Rochester.

title: Ann I. Whitehead Becomes the Wife Of Vincent Moore
description: Ann Irma Whitehead and Vincent Carl Moore were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel of Columbia University. The Rev. Derrick Harkins of the Abyssinian Baptist Church performed the ceremony.

title: Utility Loses Nassau Water Dispute
description: LEAD: THE Long Island Water Corporation, the largest private supplier in Nassau - it serves the southwestern section of the county - has lost its legal battle with the state to remove limits, or ''caps,'' on its pumping.

title: Beach-Cleaning Armies Await Debris of Summer
description: As the metropolitan area's beach season gets under way this rainy Memorial Day weekend, government officials and environmental groups say there is no way to predict whether beaches will remain clean this summer.

title: In Defense of Liberation Theology
description: To the Editor:

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Even if you are, as Sue Wartur put it, ''something of a sailor,'' how long do you keep the sail from your first little sailboat? Years, of course, a lot of years. And then one day you think to yourself, ''It's ridiculous; what am I keeping this for?'' and you get rid of it. In fact, you're pretty pleased with yourself about finally taking some decisive action.

title: In Bensonhurst, Marchers Meet Quiet, Empty Streets
description: For the second week in a row, the Rev. Al Sharpton led a march through Bensonhurst to protest the acquittal on murder charges of a defendant in the racial killing of 16-year-old Yusuf K. Hawkins.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: The oldest regional event in the world is being played this weekend at the New York Penta Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street. It is the 62d Goldman Open Pairs, which began in 1929 and has been played in Manhattan at the Eastern Regionals every May since then.

title: Organizing Force
description: Here's Larry Csonka's chance to run interference again: he wants to be a union leader. While the National Football League owners met last week, Csonka, son of Joe Csonka, union man at Goodyear Tire and Rubber in Akron, Ohio, was trying to persuade the players to make him their agent. Since the N.F.L. Players Association has not had a contract since 1986 and says it has decertified itself as a union so that players can take free-agency fights to court, the job is evidently open. Csonka has no particular background for it, aside from listening to his father and uncles (who would lapse into Hungarian when the shop talk sped up), but says that as a former general manager of a United States Football League team, he knows how management thinks. The former Dolphins and Giants fullback also has a plan for new free-agency rules. What he needs is signatures from 751 of the 1,200 players he mailed packets to. Then, he says, he needs 90 days to negotiate. ''Just sign the card and I'll have a go at it,'' he said. ''If not, I'll get out of the way.''

title: ROSES ARE RED, ROSES ARE BLUE ...
description: There's the yellow rose of Texas. Next there might be the blue rose of Australia.

title: Review/Music;   Take 6 and Friends Give a Benefit for Special Olympics Africa
description: It was entirely fitting that the a capella sextet Take 6 should be the hosts and headline act for two concerts benefiting the Special Olympics Africa on Wednesday and Thursday at Carnegie Hall. The Christian music group from Alabama has developed a vocal blend of such extraordinary precision and harmonic richness that its best singing commands the same kind of respect one gives to Olympic athletes at the peak of their form. One is left awestruck at the level of technical perfection.

title: Island Festivals Echoing to the Sound of Mozart
description: LEAD: WHEN it comes to music festivals, a lot of Mozart goes a long way, especially this spring on Long Island, where Planting Fields Arborteum in Oyster Bay is the setting for two Mozart festivals within a month of each other.

title: Troubled Co-ops
description: To the Editor:

title: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN
description: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products. Business executives, members of Congress, academics and other experts on American industrial policy said in the article that such financial engineering often reflects short-term thinking and is sapping American competitiveness. G.E. officials defended the plan to buy back $10 billion of its stock over the next five years, pointing out that the company is a world leader in those fields in which it has chosen to compete and that its research and development is adequately funded.

title: Stella Madrid Wins The Acorn Stakes
description: Stella Madrid won the opening leg of the New York filly triple crown yesterday at Belmont Park in a style suggesting that the next two legs will be much tougher.

title:
ART;

Viewers Are Coaxed Up Ramps To Puzzle Over Spare Paintings
description: LEAD: FOR several decades, Shusaka Arakawa, who goes by the single name Arakawa, has been an art world conundrum. The reasons why are forcefully exhibited at the Joseloff Gallery in West Hartford, on the campus of the University of Hartford. Arakawa, who created some work especially for the gallery, has never seemed so viewer-friendly.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 27, 1990
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 2 6 SEPTEMBER, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dunne/St. Martin's, $22.95.) Guests from many parts of the world encounter their often unexpected destinies during a get-together in a small Scottish town. 2 1 3 THE STAND, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $24.95.) Doomsday brings horrors to America; the uncut version of a novel first published in 1978. 3 3 14 OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures. 4 4 3 DRAGON, by Clive Cussler. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) In 1993, Dirk Pitt moves fast to save America from a Japanese extremist. 5 5 11 THE BOURNE ULTIMATUM, by Robert Ludlum. (Random House, $21.95.) Jason Bourne plans to infiltrate the ruthless Medusa Brigade. 6 6 6 SKINNY LEGS AND ALL, by Tom Robbins. (Bantam, $19.95.) The horror and humor of the upcoming apocalypse are played out at a restaurant near the United Nations. 7 8 3 AN INCONVENIENT WOMAN, by Dominick Dunne. (Crown, $19.95.) Manners, morals and murder in Los Angeles's high society. 8 9 3 FAMILY PICTURES, by Sue Miller. (Harper & Row, $19.95.) The good and bad times of a large Chicago clan during the past 40 years. 9 15 2 THE GOLDEN ORANGE, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Perigord/Morrow, $19.95.) title: Mutual Funds;   How to Pick a Newsletter
description: Dan F. Sullivan, who edits The Chartist Mutual Fund Timer newsletter, invests his own money in the funds he recommends to subscribers - and sends out his brokerage statements to prove it.

title: Skating and Putting
description: Roller-skating demonstrations and putting contests are among the weekend's outdoor activities at Wollman Skating Rink in Central Park. Skaters can whizz around the rink and golfers can play a round on a miniature course that features such New York landmarks as the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge, the Statue of Liberty and the Bronx Zoo. The rink is open today from 10 A.M. to 9:30 P.M. and tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Information: 517-4800.

title: Dawn L. Johnson Marries T. J. Rice in Dobbs Ferry
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Pompeii in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., Dawn L. Johnson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Johnson of Elmhurst, Ill., was married yesterday to Thomas J. Rice, the son of Thomas J. Rice of White Plains and Mrs. Charles Macellaro of Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. James Kavanagh performed the ceremony.

title: Wedding in Italy For Lisa Phillips
description: The marriage of Lisa Phillips, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Warren H. Phillips of Bridgehampton, L.I., to Meyer Vaisman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Vaisman of Caracas, Venezuela, took place yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the Villa Pisani-Ferri in Vicenza, Italy, by Magistrate Francesco Rimini.

title: And Now, Fantasy Baseball Widows
description: THE 7:24 A.M. Metro-North express commuter train from this Hudson River village to Manhattan transports the usual assortment of silent card players, deep sleepers and serious readers of the business page. But in the middle of this library-like setting, Brian Scholl and Bruce Gorman pursue a different pastime, scanning sports pages and furiously scribbling down notes.

title: Graziano: Champion for Life's Underdogs
description: They, the participants or observers who describe a sporting event as a war, have never been in one. On the night of March 29, 1946, however, as the old Garden shook with the sound that always filled it whenever he fought, I watched from ringside as Rocky Graziano held Marty Servo's head up with his open left glove under Servo's chin and, almost in a frenzy, clubbed him again and again with his right until, finally, Servo went down for the third and last time.

title: LOOKING AHEAD
description: MONDAY: Memorial Day, Banks, government offices, stock exchange ans many businesses are closed.

title: The Importance Of Reading
description: Why do teachers and parents find it so hard to stress the importance of reading to our young? Thank you, Lori Negridge Allen, for putting in writing what many people are complaining about in faculty rooms and around dinner tables (''Why Students Don't Read,'' Opinion page, May 6). Whom do we really blame? The children, the parents, the teachers, the movie industry, video games, television? I sit, sometimes, and watch my second-grade class devour books. I am so taken aback that I wish their parents could see them. It is so enormously gratifying to see these 7- and 8-year-old children instilled with a thirst for knowledge, their hunger for approval, and their need for a friendly supporting ear to hear their questions and share their joy of discovery. What's so hard about it?

title: Children Are Taught Ways Toward a Healthy Life
description: LEAD: SEATED in a circle around the room of the Total Workout Studio, a group of 6-year-olds intently observes Jan St. John as she measures out lard and sugar into a jar. Wide-eyed with amazement, the children grimace when Mrs. St. John, co-founder of the studio and its Kidfit program, explains that this is what goes into their bodies when they eat a chocolate cream-filled cookie.

title: Effort on Affordable Housing Is Falling Short of Goal
description: LEAD: AFTER 15 years of spirited debate and heated court battles, New Jersey's effort to provide housing for low- and moderate-income residents is far short of its goal. And state officials and housing advocates say the state's economic slump poses a further obstacle to the development of such housing.

title: Yes, There Are Other Ways to Prepare Artichokes
description: FOR many Americans there is only one way to serve an artichoke: boiled, with a Hollandaise or vinaigrette sauce. The notion of cutting off the leaves beforehand and using only the heart or bottom seems wasteful. But now that large artichokes cost less than $1 each and the medium-sized ones are selling for 20 cents apiece in some stores, it is possible to use them in a variety of ways without feeling guilty.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis

title: If You're Thinking of Living in:;   Prospect Heights
description: Although it takes in less than a quarter of a square mile, Prospect Heights in Brooklyn is a microcosm of New York City's housing situation.

title: Will Oil Gush Again? Ask the Saudis
description: Do the Saudis know something that American oil traders are only beginning to suspect?

title: Campus Life: UC, Davis;   Hunger Strike Ends With Vows To Fight Racism
description: After a hunger strike by four students, administrators at the University of California at Davis have agreed to take steps to improve the racial climate.

title: Mary Cavallaro Becomes a Bride
description: Mary D. Cavallaro, a daughter of Ann M. Cavallaro of Alexandria, Va., and Augustine L. Cavallaro of San Juan, P.R., was married yesterday to Anthony D. McCann, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David A. McCann of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. The Rev. Christopher Mould officiated at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church in Alexandria.

title: Today's NATO - and Tomorrow's
description: Many American officials and strategic analysts seem to be making the preservation of NATO the principal objective of American policy in Europe. This goal makes sense in the short run. NATO is still the only organization that gives the U.S. a preponderant role in Europe, and it remains critical to preserving stability and balance there. But for the longer run, we need new institutions, and we had better begin thinking about them now.

title: Cooking The Words?
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Cinderellas' Broke a Trust
description: The women portrayed in ''Stepmothers Fight the 'Evil' Image'' (Long Island Weekly, April 29) contribute precious little to their cause by revealing for publication the intimate problems and anxieties faced by their stepchildren, without the protection of anonymity.

title:
DINING OUT;

Hearty Dishes With Fresh Ingredients
description: LEAD: CAFE LOUIS in Hoboken may not have the best food or be the most elegant restaurant in New Jersey, but I would happily eat there on a day off if it were only in my neighborhood.

title: Amid Doubts, Cambodian Factions Agree to Truce
description: Cambodia's four warring factions have signed a cease-fire that is to take effect next month, but one guerrilla official today called the agreement a mere ''play on words.''

title: Dr. Kotoski Wed To H. D. Ressler

Ressler, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Ressler of New York. Rabbi Burt A. Siegel and the Rev. Patrick J. Frawley, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the interfaith ceremony at the Harmonie Club in New York.

title: New Taxes Without Fear
description: Your taxes are going up. President Bush knows that. Congress knows that. And according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll, taxpayers know it too. Politicians might not admit that until after the November elections. But there is no other way to control the yawning deficit and still pay for needed Federal programs.

title: Soccer's Little Big Man
description: THE WHOLE WORLD WAS WATCHING ON JUNE 22, 1986 , when, in Aztec Stadium in Mexico City, during a quarterfinal match in the most recent World Cup soccer tournament, Diego Armando Maradona of Argentina flew into the air and punched the ball into the goal of England.

title: FICTION
description: ILIAS. By Jim Sakkas. (Salem House/Harper & Row, $17.95.) The long voyage from Greece to Australia begins hopefully enough for Ilias Verginis, the title character of this first novel by a writer born in Greece who also left his native island to find a new life on the other side of the world. It is 1928, and Ilias arrives in Melbourne with a simple five-year plan: he will work hard, save money and return home to buy his own fishing boat. This is not a triumphant story, however; good-hearted though Ilias may be, he is destined for mediocrity and frustration. He never becomes fully assimilated in the new culture, even though in time he has a devoted Australian wife and three fine children. When his grocery store fails, he moves inland to work in a timber mill, and as the years pass, like it or not, he becomes part of this foreign land. Gambling and drinking take their toll, alienate him further from his wife and provoke the inevitable separation. In ''Ilias,'' Jim Sakkas reveals another side of the immigrant experience, and he does so with admirable and deceptive simplicity. At the end, Ilias is alone but not broken, for as long as there is life, there is hope. His flaw is the flaw of many other damaged souls: ''There had been too much change for him in one lifetime.''

title: Evolution in Europe;   GERMAN RIGHTISTS QUITS AFTER PARTY SUFFERS SETBACK
description: Franz Schonhuber, the burly former Waffen SS sergeant who brought his far-right Republican Party briefly into the national limelight, has quit as leader of a badly battered and divided organization.

title: A Medieval Gem in Provence Page 15 and 16 By Edward Harper; EDWARD HARPER is the author of ''The Heracles Commando'' (Pocket Books), writes fiction under the name Edward McGhee; he lives near Uzes, France, several months a year. Mary Lee Townsend, a member of the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J., contributed to this article.
description: LEAD: THE history of southern France from the fall of Rome in the fifth century A.D. to the Bourbon Restoration in 1815 is one of unrelieved rapine, pillage and pestilence. The sunflower fields of van Gogh and idealized landscapes of Cezanne and Gauguin were watered mostly by blood. As the Roman defenses crumbled before successive waves of Vandals, Visigoths and

Daniele Grault, Rose MerchanT
description: LEAD: Daniele Grault is better known throughout France as Dani, a pop singer of the 60's who made headlines in the 70's with her drug problems and who wrote a book about her life. Now, she cultivates her passion for roses.

description: Judging from interviews, the young people of this country, where the median age is 26, are divided between those who are solidly behind the President's program of ''democratization'' and those who are more restless and discontented.

title: Tensions on Campus: Hope Amid the Rage
description: WHEN Edgar Beckham arrived on the Middletown campus of Wesleyan University as a freshman 39 years ago, he was one of four blacks in a student body of 700. The idea of recruiting minority students to colleges was just beginning to stir. Mr. Beckham recalls that by his junior year, he and a handful of other student leaders decided it was time to raise the issue with the university's president, Victor Butterfield.

The pollution, from inadequate sewer and septic systems, could also force the closing of beaches along Long Island

description: WITH a vacancy rate around 10 percent, the Portland office market has come through a period of extensive new development in good shape. But brokers say the worst may be yet to come. In the next 18 months, three companies will move from downtown buildings to new suburban office parks.

Celebrations are various and splendid; each region has its own version with its own local flavor. St.-Remy-de-Provence, in the south, produces a robust quinze-aout, a rich mixture of the religious and secular, hearty, salubrious and entirely unique.

title: Review/Music;   Madrigals by the Y Chorale, From Gesualdo to Gershwin
description: The Y Chorale under Amy Kaiser is not a big ensemble - a little over 25 singers, ranging from five to eight voices on a part. Yet their concert at the 92d Street Y last Sunday night, made up largely of madrigals old and new, put special pressures on this collection of nicely trained amateurs. For whether or not they were explicitly intended to be so, the pieces by Weelkes, Gesualdo, de Wert and Monteverdi have the kind of specificity better suited to interacting single voices than polyphony en masse.

title: FOR VANGUARD: TO THE REAR, MARCH!
description: The restless Seymour Solomon, who sold his Vanguard Recording Society catalogue to the Welk Record Group in California in 1986, has bought back most of the classical part of the catalogue (for an undisclosed amount) and plans to issue digitally remastered compact disks, digital audio tapes and cassettes of the material. To insure the best sound possible, he said he would be using the original analogue tapes as masters rather than the later-generation tapes he said Welk had been using for its limited output of classical releases.

title: Kathlyn M. Kim Weds Jody Shilan
description: Dr. Kathlyn Meekyung Kim was married to Jody Blair Shilan yesterday at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y. The Rev. Jim Covington performed the nondenominational ceremony. The bride, 26 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Unsup Kim of Teaneck, N.J. She graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and the Mount Sinai School of Medicine and will become a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in July. Her father is the director of surgery at the Elmhurst (Queens) Hospital Center. Her mother, Myungsoon Kim, teaches at the Korean School in Tenafly, N.J.

title: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN
description: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products. Business executives, members of Congress, academics and other experts on American industrial policy said in the article that such financial engineering often reflects short-term thinking and is sapping American competitiveness. G.E. officials defended the plan to buy back $10 billion of its stock over the next five years, pointing out that the company is a world leader in those fields in which it has chosen to compete and that its research and development is adequately funded.

title: At This Carnival, the Prize Is Fresh Air for Youngsters
description: When Christine Eastman took her daughter Jurine to register for summer camp last week, they both did paper work. Ms. Eastman used a pen. Jurine used scissors. They were among a dozen parents and children who signed up for the Fresh Air Fund's summer programs Tuesday afternoon at the Children's Art Carnival in East Harlem. The fund offers free summer camping to more than 3,000 New York City children every year, inviting youngsters to one of the fund's four camps in Fishkill, N.Y.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Those who ply their trades at newspapers know only too well what a stylebook is. It's a comprehensive and usually exhausting compilation of all the rules of spelling, punctuation and usage that a publication tries to follow. It tells you whether to write ''ten'' as a word or as a number. It dictates whether ''catalog'' ends with a ''g'' or ''gue.''

title: NONFICTION
description: THE FRANCHISE: Building a Winner With the World Champion Detroit Pistons, Basketball's Bad Boys. By Cameron Stauth. (Morrow, $19.95.) If you truly, truly care to know every single detail of the Detroit Pistons' 1988-89 championship season, then Cameron Stauth's book ''The Franchise'' is for you. If, however, you're a basketball fan but only mildly interested in the Pistons, it's highly unlikely you'll make it past February in this chronological account of ''basketball's bad boys.'' The author's fatal mistake is taking the fly-on-the-wall approach to the nth degree; the unceasing accumulation of detail about the Pistons' general manager Jack McCloskey, the coach Chuck Daly and players such as Isiah Thomas, Bill Laimbeer and Dennis Rodman soon becomes trivia instead of insightful information. It's a shame, because Mr. Stauth is a tireless reporter and a talented, graceful writer. By not widening his horizons to give the reader a more rounded picture of the state of professional basketball outside Detroit, Mr. Stauth paints himself into a well-researched but claustrophobic corner. The author's other miscalculation is mistaking moderately interesting personalities for genuinely fascinating ones. Mr. Stauth's heroes, principally Jack McCloskey, are hard-working basketball professionals with rather ordinary careers now highlighted by one championship. And one championship doesn't turn the prosaic travails of the N.B.A. grind into poetry. By the time the Pistons do get their coveted rings, ''The Franchise'' has exhausted the reader.

title: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN

Business executives, members of Congress, academics and other experts on American industrial policy said in the article that such financial engineering often reflects short-term thinking and is sapping American competitiveness. G.E. officials defended the plan to buy back $10 billion of its stock over the next five years, pointing out that the company is a world leader in those fields in which it has chosen to compete and that its research and development is adequately funded.

title:
Belmar Journal;

A Beach Fee Dispute and a Question: Is Tourism Necessary?
description: LEAD: WHEN temperatures climbed into the high 80's one recent weekend, more than 15,000 tourists basked in the unseasonable warmth on Belmar's beaches. No one paid an admission charge before stepping onto the sand because the borough's 1.25-mile public beachfront is free from Labor Day to Memorial Day.

title: LILITH CASTS HER SHADOW OVER IMAGES BY KIEFER
description: At the Marian GoodmaN Gallery, 24 West 57th Street, in Manhattan, there is an exhibition of very large paintings and an equally large construction in which spectacular and unexpected events are continually to the fore. In one of the paintings we seem to be hang-gliding toward an immense and limitless space. In the far downward distance is a long narrow lake, but the general tone is that of a universe newly created and as yet unformed.

title: NATURE'S WAY OF RECYCLING MEN
description: MY LIFE AND DR. JOYCE BROTHERS: A Novel in Stories. By Kelly Cherry. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $14.95.) Kelly Cherry has managed a rare accomplishment: she has transmuted the annoying jargon common to psychological support groups into prose of outstanding lyrical strength. Who would have thought it could be done, especially in a book with the cutesy-wootsie title ''My Life and Dr. Joyce Brothers''? Well, forget the title and the classification of the book as ''a novel in stories,'' which sounds as if Ms. Cherry is trying to have things both ways. This whatchamacallit is about Nina, a woman alone trying to make sense of things in a time of shifting, befuddling mores. She is attempting to overcome her incestuous past (her brother was the victimizer) and make a happy life for herself - if not by securing a suitable man from her parade of inappropriate suitors, then at least by raising a child. In ''My Life and Dr. Joyce Brothers,'' Nina not only talks about her own past but also recapitulates the quirky biographies of her perfectly imperfect brother and of her father and mother, musicians who settled for less and whose talent and lives atrophied. Ms. Cherry is spot on with the one-liners. (''Divorce,'' Nina remarks, ''is nature's way of recycling men.'') And she also has an ability to zero in on a heartbreaking scene, like the one in which Nina comes upon her father, beset by Alzheimer's disease, as he stares at a grandfather clock: ''After a while I realize that he is not trying to tell time; he is trying to figure out why anyone would put numbers in a circle, making it difficult to add or subtract them.'' Kelly Cherry's fifth novel is so unexpectedly idiosyncratic and fresh that you forgive the occasional comment that trips over the line into whimsy. In this slim but rich work, the promise of her earlier fiction is bountifully fulfilled.

title: Food;   AT WEEK'S END
description: NEW YORKERS HAVE THEIRJU own way of clocking the seasons. Spring is here when crowds gather on the steps of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, and winter arrives when smoke from roasting chestnuts smarts the eyes. But for now, summer has another marker: streets that are eerily deserted every weekend between Memorial Day and Labor Day.

Others will come just to sit or sleep or sip in the Long Meadow -six times the size of the Sheep Meadow in Central Park and said to be the longest continuous open space in any American urban park.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: If iris did not bloom well, the rhizomes may need dividing; wait until late June or early July to dig up, separate and replant the rhizomes. Plant beans, especially limas, and set out seedlings of tomato, pepper and eggplant; be sure the soil is enriched with organic material so it holds moisture; water then mulch the plants to hold moisture in and keep weeds out. Allow columbines to set seed and resow themselves if the cultivar appeals. Plant 'mum cuttings, Japanese anemones and asters for fall bloom.

How embarrassing for a first-time guest to confess at the breakfast table the next morning that half the lumpy mattress accidentally fell through the rustic wood frame.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: 1999: Victory Without War, by Richard Nixon. (Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $10.95.) Much has already changed in the two years since the former President called for a more international and less isolationist approach to world politics. ''The style and tone of the book suggest that Mr. Nixon has set himself the task of reaching a broad mass audience,'' Marshall D. Shulman said here in 1988, ''and if he succeeds in bringing home to that audience the logic of the imperatives imposed by a world of nuclear weapons and turbulent international politics, he will have made an important contribution to the maturation of American foreign policy.'' This book is part of a special Richard Nixon Library Edition, which also includes reprints of REAL PEACE/NO MORE VIETNAMS ($12.95), LEADERS ($12.95), THE REAL WAR ($12.95), SIX CRISES ($12.95) and R.N.: The Memoirs of Richard Nixon ($17.95), all updated with new introductions.

title: THE PYRAMID AND THE WEB
description: Over lunch one day with Frances Hesselbein, the national executive director of the Girl Scouts, I listened as she described the ''circular management system'' she had devised. ''Here's me, in the center,'' she explained, setting her glass of iced tea in the middle of the table, then surrounding it with a circle of cups, more glasses, a pepper mill, ''and this is my first management team.'' She constructed more circles, building outward concentrically, then began linking them, using knives and forks as radials. ''The great thing about the circle is it does not box you in. You can connect with any other point. As the circles extend outward, the fabric becomes more interwoven.''

title: Net Game
description: Steffi Graf isn't used to losing, but every young tennis player's life is subject to disruption by a an even younger tennis player. So it happened last weekend, at the German Open final in Berlin, that 20-year-old Graf lost to 16-year-old Monica Seles of Yugoslavia. The 6-3, 6-4 victory gave Seles her fifth tournament title in a row. More important, it ended the West German's winning streak of 66 matches, which started last June and was interrupted only for a few months earlier this year while she recovered from a thumb injury that she suffered when she tried to escape from photographers while she was cross-country skiing in Switzerland. She was uncharacteristically shaky on a few occasions after her return to the courts. After her loss to Seles, Graf said: ''I was so far away from playing my best tennis, it was difficult to get into it. If I play like that, I can't expect to win.'' But in Paris on Friday, drawing opponents for the French Open this week, Graf began to do better. Her opponents for the first and second matches are ranked 127th and 30th, and even before that Graf was still ranked the best women's tennis player in the world.

title:
DANCE;

'Bluebeard,' a Turn as Comedy
description: LEAD: ''BLUEBEARD,'' one of the darkest, most Gothic stories in the fairy tale canon, will receive a comedic interpretation in a production by the Moscow Chamber Ballet on Saturday and next Sunday at Glassboro State College and on June 12 at Rutgers University in New Brunswick. The performances conclude the Hollybush Festival and open the Rutgers Summe

title: Betsy A. Licht to Wed Wallace R. Turner in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence W. Licht of Upper Brookville, L.I., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Betsy A. Licht and Wallace R. Turner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard B. Turner of Bay Shore, L.I.

title: POSTING: Chiseled in Stone;   Partnership
description: There are not many cathedrals under construction these days but the master masons and apprentices who are building one on Morningside Heights have discovered a considerable demand for their craft and expertise. The demand, in fact, is great enough that the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and a New York City developer, David M. Teitelbaum, have created a partnership called Cathedral Stoneworks, which employs more than 60 people and specializes in construction, restoration and fabrication. Profits from the enterprise are split equally, with the cathedral's half being applied to its own building project, which has been going for almost a century. ''What this is really about is an effort by a nonprofit to help itself,'' Mr. Teitelbaum said. ''What we're trying to provide is a service to the architectural world where we can resurrect the lost art of stone cutting.''

title: The High Art Of Horror Films Can Cut Deep Into the Psyche
description: I grew up in a family that was nothing like the Addams family except in one respect. When I was small, I would go with my favorite aunt and uncle and a cousin just my age to drive-in horror movies every week. Better not to ask whether this was healthy for children under 10. We loved being scared. But ''The Premature Burial,'' Roger Corman's cheap, trashy version of Poe, was more frightening than anyone had expected. When Ray Milland, buried while he was merely in a coma, woke up and started gasping for air and struggling to push the lid off his coffin, my cousin jumped in the front seat with his father, and my aunt climbed in back with me. We hadn't even done that during ''Psycho.'' It was then that my aunt demystified the film maker's art. ''Remember,'' she said in a reassuring voice, ''there are lights and cameras and makeup people and a director standing all around, just off the screen where you can't see them.'' In other words, it's only make-believe, but a make-believe real enough to rattle your bones.

title: Lawyers Make a Case For Women as Partners
description: LEAD: WHEN four women became partners in a new law firm in Bridgeport last year, none of them viewed the move as a feminist undertaking.

title: Atlantic Beach Upset By Beach Club Project
description: LEAD: THE Inwood Beach Club, one of nine privately owned oceanfront clubs in the small village of Atlantic Beach, is causing quite a stir since it began renovating its facilities and built a 12-foot-high triangular facade atop its two-story building.

title: New Test of Students' Skills Stirs Debate at State Colleges
description: LEAD: A SOPHISTICATED new test to measure how well New Jersey college students can reason has provoked enthusiastic support on some campuses and a boycott effort from a union representing college instructors.

title: Complete Everything, or Is More Enough?
description: If the overseers of our musical life have their way, the days of the simple, single classical music concert - a morceau of modernity followed by a concerto, an intermission and then something earnest, long and uplifting - may be numbered. The trend these days is toward thematic inclusivity, not to say all-inclusivity. Three elephantine examples of that trend have been in the news of late, and they call into question their underlying maximalist presumption that more is more.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Cablevision vs. Newsday

description: 3. Death Penalty: Vote to delete a provision of a major anti-crime bill that would have barred the imposition of a death sentence if a defendant proves that the sentence was part of a pattern of racial discrimination. Approved 58 to 38 on May 24. $ 1 2 3 connecticut Dodd (D) N N N Lieberman (D) Y N Y New Jersey Bradley (D) N N N Lautenberg (D) N N N New York D'Amato (R) Y N Y Moynihan (D) N N N

title: 'Dracula, Prince of Many Faces'
description: A Proper Dostoyevskian Penance

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: AN elm called Harmony stands defiant and tall before Maplewood's Municipal Building, bearing a message of hope and an implicit warning.

title: California
description: To the Editor: While vacationing on the Monterey peninsula in California, I recently took my car on the Seventeen Mile Drive. It turned out to be quite a pretty drive, with some interesting woodland parts mixed with beach vistas. However, I have seen countless (and longer) expanses of coast in other parts of California and throughout the United States that are at least as pretty.

title: A Reward in Shooting of Policeman
description: The shooting of a Scarsdale police officer - the first such shooting in that village in almost 35 years - has stunned the community, and one resident has offered a $10,000 reward for information leading to the arrest and conviction of the assailant.

title: TRYING TO SOLVE THE SIDE EFFECTS OF CONVERTING TRASH TO ENERGY
description: Less than a year after it started operation, Detroit's giant trash incinerator, the largest in the nation, was abruptly shut down last month by state regulators. Environmental officials said the behemoth plant, which converts waste into energy, was emitting much higher levels of mercury than are permissible under state law.

title: Tinling: Patrician Sage for the World of Tennis
description: It was just like Ted Tinling to plan his own memorial service. He dictated to John Parsons, a British sportswriter, the exact instructions, whom he wanted notified and who would speak. He told John, ''I just want you to know I won't go out with a whimper.''

title: INSIDE
description: Bogota Leader Speaks Out

title: Royals Give Hawkins An Early Pounding
description: By the time he walked off the mound and into the dugout tonight, Andy Hawkins had put the Yankees into a spot from which they couldn't recover. But can Hawkins recover? Hawkins's latest start was clearly his least impressive in a season full of disappointment. He lasted just one and two-thirds innings, left with a five-run deficit, and sent the Yankees on their way to a 9-4 loss to the Kansas City Royals.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   The Errors of Nazi Science
description: Can data obtained by unethical means be permitted in science? The issue is raised pointedly by Nazi experiments in concentration camps. Some of these exercises, like Josef Mengele's experiments on twins, were brutish and demented. Others were brutish but aimed at scientific goals. A study at Dachau on methods for reviving people numbed by icy water has been cited often in the scientific literature. Are these results too tainted to be relied on?

title: Moira Bailey and Thomas Duffy to Wed in August
description: August wedding plans for Moira Bailey and Thomas William Duffy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis J. Duffy of Valley Stream, L.I., have been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Alan Bailey of Springfield, Mo.

title: Liv Holemans Is Married To Edward D. Mansfield
description: Liv Holemans, the daughter of Agnes Huysegoms-Holemans of Wallingford, Pa., and the late Dr. Rudolf Holemans, was married yesterday to Dr. Edward D. Mansfield, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edwin Mansfield of Wallingford. The Rev. Melanie Hammond Clark and the Rev. David R. Drain performed the ceremony at the Wallingford Presbyterian Church.

title: Walking In Jefferson Country
description: LEAD: ''WALKING is the best possible exercise,'' Thomas Jefferson wrote to a friend in 1790. ''You should . . . not permit yourself even to think while you walk, but divert yourself by the objects surrounding you.'' And well Jefferson might have thought, living in the idyllic Virginia countryside close to

title: Oars, Sails and Motors Reign Over the Waves
description: THE migration back to Westchester's waters is in full swing. Like flocks of birds, flotillas of recreational mariners return each spring to the Hudson River and Long Island Sound. Sailboats and powerboats come down from their cradles and out of winter storage.

title: Two Small Companies With Big Ideas
description: DANIEL VAN STARRENBURG'S fascination with nature began during childhood and eventually led him to a career as an arborist. In 1985, with the financial backing of a former customer, Mr. Van Starrenburg started a business caring for trees and shrubs in Westchester and surrounding areas. He began his company, Sav-a-Tree, with six employees; he now has 90, and as the business grows and thrives, so do his plans for expansion.

title: Question Of the Week;   Are Speeds Too Fast At the Indy 500?
description: It is human nature to push for new limits, to go to the very edge. There is no end in sight as, once again this month, records were set during qualifications.

title: HONG KONG'S BOUNDLESS OPTIMISM
description: You would not expect Karl Otto Pohl, the president of the West German Bundesbank, to say that the economic union with East Germany will be inflationary and force interest rates higher, even if he fears that could happen. That would just become a self-fulfilling prophecy.

title: On Language;   Pundit-Bashing
description: A USEFUL LINGUIS tic scapegoat or whipping boy has been created in time for the Presidential campaign of 1992.

title: Burmese Vote Today, or Do They?
description: The people of Myanmar, formerly Burma, vote on Sunday in the first multiparty election in almost 30 years, but Western diplomats based there and human-rights organizations say that the voting will not be free or fair and that the military will continue to rule.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   In Flushing Meadows-Corona Park
description: The traffic-ridden expressways may be a few hundred yards away, but within the green expanse of Flushing Meadows-Corona Park you'd never know it.

title: LIFE AMONG THE 'THICKHEADS'
description: LEAD:

title: TELLING THE TRUTH, TAKING THE PUNISHMENT
description: A HIGHER KIND OF LOYALTY

title: Campus Life: Chicago;   A Tough Teacher Whose Classes Are a Big Draw
description: ''According to Marx, everything in society rests on what?'' Prof. Karl Weintraub asks his class, calling on students before they have a chance to raise their hands. After cutting several of their answers off with a curt ''no,'' Mr. Weintraub turns to one student and says, ''Are you thinking, or just pouring out phrases which come to your mind?''
