title: What's Doing In;   Seattle
description: Every city likes to show off after a major remodeling, and Seattle is no exception, despite lingering traits of Scandinavian bashfulness. For the last four years Seattle has been under almost constant construction, but now virtually everything - the new skyscrapers, the pocket-park in the center of town, the underground bus tunnel - is finished, or in the final stages.

title: 'Dracula, Prince of Many Faces' Overeducated Moms and Pops
description: To the Editor:

title: Regina M. Reilly Becomes a Bride
description: Regina M. Reilly, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Reilly of Locust, N.J., was married yesterday to Lieut. James R. Cochrane, U.S.N., at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York by Msgr. Herbert K. Tillyer. The bridegroom is the son of Assemblyman and Mrs. John C. Cochrane of Brightwaters, L.I.

title: East Hartford Officers Are Pedaling the Beat
description: LEAD: WHEN Officer Robert Kornfeld of the East Hartford Police Department begins his shift, he heads to the back of the station house, where the police cruisers are parked. But instead of getting into a car, he mounts a 22-speed mountain bicycle.

title: Cab Service, Still Shabby
description: Taxi service is one of New York City's more persistent shames: cabs are often filthy and uncomfortable; drivers often don't know English, don't know the city, behave rudely and drive recklessly.

title: Buying the Baby Bells
description: To the Editor:

title: Appreciating the Choreographer's Palette
description: The inventive choreographer often makes much out of only a few steps.

title: Commercial Property: The Rihga Royal Hotel;   A Tower Long in Conception Is Finally Realized
description: THE swimming pool 610 feet over midtown had to go. As Mal Seymourian recalled it, ''We said, 'People don't come to Manhattan to swim.' ''

title: Campaign to Oust English Is Revived in India
description: Voters in India who have been turning state-level Congress Party governments out of office in a series of elections now find that they are getting more than just new faces. In several of India's largest states, recently elected governments are declaring war on the English language, reversing the trend toward the spread of English as a common link for a multilingual country.

title: China
description: To the Editor: China's airline, Air China (C.A.A.C.), has never been particularly user friendly, but judging by my experience the carrier has given a whole new meaning to the concept of nonrefundable ticket. We are accustomed to thinking that this means that if the passenger's plans change, the fare paid is lost. However, to Air China it means that if their plans change (a common enough occurrence), the passenger receives no refund. This is so, for example, when they have labeled the flight chartered, which is often the case.

title: Hamlet's Age
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Optimistic As Minicamp Ends
description: Are the Giants as good as they think they can be? Last year's division champions ended a five-day minicamp today, and like every other team at this time of year they were unbeaten, upbeat and anxious to get on to training camp eight weeks from now and real games 15 weeks hence.

title: Clockmaker's Legacy Preserves Lost Time
description: EDWARD INGRAHAM died in 1972, but part of his legacy remains unopened - literally. Mr. Ingraham, president of a company that produced clocks and watches, left some timepieces stored in time capsules, each with a designated date for opening.

title: Miss Chapman Becomes a Bride
description: C. Donna Chapman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Chapman of Plainview, Va., was married yesterday to Joseph T. Wilson Jr., a son of Maude Wilson of Colerain, N.C., and the late Mr. Wilson, at the Hampton (Va.) University Memorial Chapel by the Rev. Dr. Leonard Chapman, a Congregational minister.

title: Spaghetti Hamlet
description: To the Editor:

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: One of the more famous collections of ancient coins will be auctioned this summer by Sotheby's. The first part is scheduled to be sold on June 19th in New York City. The coins are part of the Nelson Bunker Hunt collection that contains some great scarcity and exceptional preservation.

title: ALL VERY GRAND, BUT SHE COULDN'T SIT DOWN
description: Madame de Pompadour is remembered historically for her romance with Louis XV and her impact on the rococo style's tapestries, gilded clocks, lacquered furniture, engravings, floral-decorated porcelains and precious gold boxes embellished with cupids and hunting scenes. About 80 examples of the type of flamboyant artworks and decorations she favored have been assembled in the exhibition ''Louis XV and Madame de Pompadour: A Love Affair With Style,'' at the Manhattan gallery of Rosenberg & Stiebel, 32 East 57th Street, through June 15.

title: Amy Schlott Is Engaged
description: Amy J. Schlott, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. D. William Schlott of Baltimore, and Dr. Stephen W. Downing, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin G. Downing of Buffalo, plan to be married in June. Both are 29 years old. The prospective bride, a Princeton University graduate, received an M.A. in international studies and an M.B.A. in finance this month from the University of Pennsylvania. Dr. Downing, a surgical resident at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania in Philadelphia, graduated from Georgetown University and received his M.D. there.

title: About Men;   Back at the Ranch
description: A YOUNG BOY MOLTS. Tender skin falls off, or gets scraped off, and is replaced by a tougher, more permanent crust. The transition happens in moments, in events. All of a sudden, something is gone and something else is in its place. I made a change like that standing in the back of a pickup truck when I was 15.

title: The Executive Life;   Down on the Ranch Tycoons Crunch Fat
description: It looks like the set for the filming of ''The Magic Mountain'': Stucco buildings amid a grove of cactus, the large, cloudless sky and low-ranging mountains looming on the horizon. People are wandering around in white, terry-cloth robes.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

We Have Met the Enemy and It's Them
description: LEAD: MORE than 20 years ago I was at the beach and heard a man make a statement that has stayed with me for these past two decades. The man said: ''These local people marry their cousins. That's why they're all so slow.''

title: Dressing Up a Garden
description: A CHIC lady, wearing long, dangling earrings and a short skirt, is seated so primly in the Kornbluth Gallery that it's hard to imagine sitting on her lap. But don't hesitate; she is a garden chair. What's more, it is comfortable.

title: Reviews/Music;   Zesty 'Don Giovanni' By Vienna State Opera
description: Next year, Gerard Mortier takes over as artistic director of the Salzburg Festival. Mr. Mortier is committed to musical theater. He has a close professional association with the innovative stage director Luc Bondy and the innovative designer Erich Wonder. The musical backbone of the Salzburg Festival is the Vienna State Opera. Given all that, a new production of Mozart's ''Don Giovanni'' at this year's Vienna Festival, jointly presented by the festival and the State Opera and conducted by Claudio Abbado, who runs the State Opera, was of special interest to international opera lovers. Who knows? Mr. Bondy and Mr. Wonder and Mr. Abbado could dominate Salzburg in the 1990's as Jean-Pierre Ponnelle and James Levine dominated it in the 80's.

title: Question Of the Week;   Are Speeds Too Fast At the Indy 500?
description: The men who race at Indy know what they're doing, and part of the thrill of the race is watching the veterans like Mario Andretti and Al Unser Sr., who have such tremendous control over their cars at these speeds that they've lasted long enough to be racing against their sons today.

title: TIME TO DEAL?
description: As he meets with President Bush this week, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has an overriding interest in more trade with the United States as the key to restructuring the Soviet economy and integrating it into the world economy.

title: Novel Casting for 'Three Sisters' - Three Sisters
description: On screen, it's not a novelty: Beau and Jeff Bridges play brothers in ''The Fabulous Baker Boys,'' Henry and Jane Fonda are father and daughter in ''On Golden Pond.'' But the casting of relatives is rare in the American theater, particularly since the number of stage families - the Cronyns excepted - is small to nonexistent.

title: Patrice Close Marries Jefferson Kise
description: Patrice Jean Close, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin B. Close of Kankakee, Ill., was married in Philadelphia yesterday to Jefferson Bok Kise, a son of Mrs. Allen S. Goldman of Chicago and James Nelson Kise of Philadelphia. The Rev. Edward Jarvis performed the ceremony at Old St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: THE SEEDS OF OUR OWN DESTRUCTION?
description: THE GENOCIDAL MENTALITY

title: BIG SCIENCE: IS IT WORTH THE PRICE?    A periodic look at the largest new research projects.;   Heavy Costs of Major Projects Pose a Threat to Basic Science
description: The Federal Government has embarked on the most ambitious array of big science projects ever, with some experts saying they herald a new age of discovery while others are warning that their great cost could cripple vital parts of the nation's scientific effort and eventually the American economy.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION IN TRANSLATION
description: LEAD:

title: Two for the Road
description: This will be a busy day for the Brabham brothers.

title: Jazz Finds a Following In Fairfield County
description: LEAD: WHEN the Westport Arts Center announced its first series of jazz concerts in 1987, no one was sure if this very American art form would find a following in the area. From the moment the foot-tapping, cheering audience greeted the first performer - the pianist Brooks Kerr, who played works by Duke Ellington and Fats Waller - it was clear that jazz was indeed welcome in Fairfield

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

With Friends Like This...
description: LEAD: THE peaceful early-morning sound of the robins chirping in the front yard was interrupted by the violent crash of a garbage can being knocked over by a wandering dog. The noise inspired one of the neighbors' dogs to launch a series of howls that had to be matched by the mutt that barreled over the can; then a third dog down the street decided to join in.

title: Auto Dealer's 'Christian Plan' Is Called Bias
description: One night last August the letters C, M, B and P popped into Freddy (Action) Jackson's head. Business at his car dealership has never been the same since.

title: THE TENDER YEARS AND SORE ARMS
description: Kirk Dressendorfer was in the trainer's room again. Last weekend, as he approached the most significant moments of his third and presumably final season as a pitcher for the University of Texas, Dressendorfer had become a regular occupant of the trainer's room and doctor's offices.

title: GLOBAL TRADE: THE SECRETS OF SUCCESS
description: THE COMPETITIVE ADVANTAGE OF NATIONS

title: Travel Advisory
description: Talks Stumble On Expanding Soviet Flights

title: Fashion: On the Street;   In College, Some Laboratories Are Just for the Adventurous
description: It seems somehow appropriate that a good portion of the college-age population in Manhattan makes up a sort of walking fashion experimentation lab, where all sorts of combinations and permutations of dress can be studied. There is a boldness among this group, a sense of adventure that makes this endeavor a lot more fun than organic chemistry ever was.

title: Question Of the Week;   Are Speeds Too Fast At the Indy 500?
description: Too fast relative to what? A stable 225-m.p.h. car is much safer than an unstable 200-m.p.h. car. The real question at Indy this year is whether the diffuser plates on the pre-1990 chassis cars are making the cars unstable.

title: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN
description: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products. Business executives, members of Congress, academics and other experts on American industrial policy said in the article that such financial engineering often reflects short-term thinking and is sapping American competitiveness. G.E. officials defended the plan to buy back $10 billion of its stock over the next five years, pointing out that the company is a world leader in those fields in which it has chosen to compete and that its research and development is adequately funded.

title: Leather Concern Cited For Dumping of Skins
description: A Newark leather company owned by a Port Authority commissioner faces possible fines after receiving two citations for dumping scraps of animal skins into sewers, officials said.

title: Mimi Mackay to Wed L. D. Bartimer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey B. Mackay of Shorewood, Minn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Miriam G. Mackay to Lawrence D. Bartimer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herman Bartimer of New York. A July wedding is planned.

title: POSTING: 3-Families in Queens;   Thinking Small as a Marketing Concept
description: At a time when the New York City housing market is in the doldrums, three Queens developers are taking a novel approach: They are thinking small.

title: EUROPE STRUGGLES TO ADMIT GERMANS
description: With the economic and monetary unification of the two Germanys now planned for early July, the European Community is struggling to find ways of absorbing East Germany without disrupting the 12-nation Common Market.

title: Going to the Mall
description: In one of the few decisions about the new national Indian museum that seemed to be easy, the Smithsonian Institution has named a director. W. Richard West Jr. of Albuquerque, N.M., is a lawyer, not a museum professional. But Mr. West, 47 years old, a member of the Cheyenne-Arapaho tribe, has represented Indian tribes and organizations since graduating from Stanford Law School. When he grew up in Muskogee, Okla., the son of an artist, he said, ''I learned much concerning Cheyenne art, history, ceremonial life and legend - in other words, many of those elements that coalesce to form culture.'' The National Museum of the American Indian will be on the Mall in Washington, the result of a long struggle between New York and Washington over relocating the collection of the Museum of the American Indian in Manhattan. (Part will go to the new building and part to the Customs House near the Battery.) Mr. West has worked in Washington before, for a Wall Street-based law firm, and is on the Smithsonian's cultural education committee.

title: Glasnost Byproduct: Virulent Anti-Semitism
description: To the Editor:

title: Hurdles Hasten a Greenwich Triathlete
description: NOT many women in Greenwich have a poster of the triathlon champion Mark Allen hanging near a doorway. But each morning at 7, when Barbara Norman returns from an hourlong run or swim or both, she walks by the words of the champion triathlete: ''Eat right. Get lots of sleep. Drink plenty of fluids. Go like hell.''

title: Haitian Leader Visits Victim of Burning, 12
description: David Opont, the 12-year-old Brooklyn boy recovering from a March 7 assault in which he was set on fire, was visited yesterday by the president of his native country, Ertha Pascal-Trouillot of Haiti.

title: Hanging Up No. 20
description: The Philadelphia Phillies retired Mike Schmidt's No. 20 last night in an emotional tribute to the team's greatest slugger.

title: Review/Music;   A Specialist in New Music Sings of the Amazon Forest
description: Thomas Buckner, a baritone who has specialized in new music since the early 1960's, explored the gentler side of contemporary vocal literature in his Monday evening recital at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: Dr. Cindy Char to Wed Peter A. Gilbert in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Walter F. Char of Honolulu have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Cynthia A. Char and Peter A. Gilbert, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James H. Gilbert of Dorset, Vt.

title: No Headline
description: IN THE WAKE OF THE EXXON VALDEZ

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Dinner;   Variety of Fare, Up and Down East Side
description: This listing is compiled by Bryan Miller from his restaurant visits, his reviews and articles in The Times and entries in his Diner's Journal column. Review and article dates are in parentheses. Prices are current.

title: Question Of the Week;   Are Speeds Too Fast At the Indy 500?
description: It is my layman's opinion that designers and mechanics will always find more speed with advancing technology. If you curtail the engines, then the body will evolve for more speed. They cut the down force this year and still there's more speed.

title: Fashion;   The Chic Sneak: Neon Colors and Even Sequins
description: The chichi sneaker may seem a contradiction in terms, but not to dozens of designers and manufacturers who are dusting otherwise mundane canvas shoes with sequins and seed pearls or turning them out in high-voltage neons and dazzling prints.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: DECORATION DAY

title: Miss Bezuhly Weds Gregory Galterio
description: Maureen Bezuhly, an associate at the law firm of Milbank, Tweed, Hadley & McCloy, and Gregory E. Galterio, an associate at the law firm of Jaffee & Asher, both in New York, were married yesterday in a Russian Orthodox ceremony at the Protection of the Holy Virgin Cathedral in New York. The Orthodox Church in America's Archbishop of New York and New Jersey, Peter L'Huillier, officiated, assisted by Archimandrite Makary Rosello-Rigo.

title: Recycling Makes Sense, and Here's a Way to Encourage It
description: IN paying your municipal taxes, you're literally throwing away more than half of the money you send your local government. Outside of funds that go toward school budgets, more than 50 percent of local tax revenue goes to garbage disposal.

title: One-on-One Counseling For Bereaved Is Gaining
description: SOON after her parents died within a year of each other, Mrs. L gained almost 20 pounds, developed chronic infections in her mouth and new allergies to foods and medications.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Time Held Close, Like Lightning Bugs in a Mayonnaise Jar
description: LEAD: WHENEVER I find myself with a spare moment, I like to play a little memory game. I close my eyes, relax and let my thoughts drift, searching for long-forgotten images and sensations once seen through my now rapidly fading child's eye. Each time I look back I rediscover something small and glorious - that tug on the line from the first fish

title: A Novel Idea: Customer Satisfaction
description: Even in a region known for its overnight millionaires, Finis F. Conner turns heads. With homes in Pebble Beach and Palm Springs, a collection of classic cars, private planes, yacht, speedboat and a near-professional golf game, Mr. Conner has become the epitome, or perhaps the caricature, of the Silicon Valley executive made good. He even commutes by plane.

title: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN
description: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products. Business executives, members of Congress, academics and other experts on American industrial policy said in the article that such financial engineering often reflects short-term thinking and is sapping American competitiveness. G.E. officials defended the plan to buy back $10 billion of its stock over the next five years, pointing out that the company is a world leader in those fields in which it has chosen to compete and that its research and development is adequately funded.

title: Close to the Vest
description: So much is still not known about Special Agent Dale Cooper. It is not even a sure thing that is he still alive, although the betting is that the dark splotches that those bullets pasted all over the pleats of his white shirt were only Kevlar, the stuff that bulletproof vests are made of. After all, even though he was just expecting room service when he opened the door to the barrel of a gun, Agent Cooper had not changed out of the F.B.I. agent costume, a tuxedo in this case, that he had put on for an especially dangerous evening. The shooting was the final moment of two months of drama for the 22 percent of the television audience that saw Kyle MacLachlin and ''Twin Peaks'' Wednesday night and probably discussed it Thursday. To the rest of the world, the references to Leo and Hank and the Log Lady do not make any sense. But since ABC announced last week that it would renew the series, anyone who cares to can catch the late-summer reruns, join Agent Cooper in the fall, if there still is an Agent Cooper, and then decide whether the whole thing has been overdone.

title: Letitia Mallin to Marry James Hanson
description: Letitia J. Mallin and James K. Hanson, the son of Donald W. Hanson of Salt Lake City and Jeanne Morrison of Jamestown, R.I., plan to be married in July. Their engagement has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Joel M. Mallin of New York and Janice P. Mallin of Chappaqua, N.Y.

title: MORE MEA CULPAS FOR THE ANNUAL REPORT
description: For several years, many of the companies that consider themselves in the vanguard of financial reporting, like Boeing and Chrysler, have been reserving a little-noticed section in their annual reports for something called the ''management report.'' In it, members of top management acknowledge their responsibility for presentation of the numbers in the financial statements, affirm their commitment to maintaining adequate internal controls and sometimes even sign their names for emphasis.

title: JIM HENSON: A PROFESSOR OF GROWING UP
description: What will happen now?

title: Signa Vernon Merrill Plans to Marry Robert Ringen Hermann Jr. in June
description: June wedding plans for Signa Vernon Merrill and Robert Ringen Hermann Jr. have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Gordon Merrill of Locust Valley, L.I. Mr. Hermann is the son of Lilly Busch Hermann and Mr. Hermann, both of St. Louis.

title: U.S. Bars Security Council Team for the West Bank
description: In a development likely to heighten tensions at next Monday's Arab summit meeting in Baghdad, the United States today blocked an attempt by the United Nations Security Council to send a mission to investigate the treatment of Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about increasing Congressional support for helping cities hit hard by AIDS rendered the name of a California Congressman incorrectly in some copies.

title: New Injury for Clark
description: The San Diego Padre first baseman Jack Clark, who is on the 15-day disabled list with a strained lower back, was X-rayed yesterday after a mishap in batting practice and was found to have a fractured left cheekbone.

title: Review/Theater;   James and Nora Joyce Marking Time in 1940
description: Nora Barnacle Joyce, the wife of James Joyce, has gradually grown in critical esteem. In Brenda Maddox's authoritative 1988 biography, ''Nora,'' she is depicted as a person of considerable distinction and importance in her husband's life and art. Not only was she the inspiration for Molly Bloom; her voice, as the voice of Irish women, resonates throughout Joyce's work.

title: Review/Theater;   Isolated From a New Country's Culture, In 'Spanish Eyes'
description: After seeing Eduardo Ivan Lopez's ''Spanish Eyes'' at the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater, an audience could conclude that love and loyalty, if they are virtues at all, are very dangerous ones. The play has some laughs and a few poignant moments, but it is emotionally exhausting and more than a little bewildering.

title:
Style Makers;

Dominic J. La Ferla, Plasterer
description: LEAD: Dominic J. La Ferla dropped out of school at the age of 14 to learn his great-grandfather's trade, and he grew up with a strong appreciation for the Italian-style carved domed ceilings his father and grandfather built. But Mr. La Ferla was disappointed by the consistently flawed domes created by Old

title: The Thin-Mint Theory
description: To the Editor:

title: Gorbachev's Need: To Still Matter
description: What President Mikhail S. Gorbachev seems to need most of all from the Washington summit meeting that begins on Wednesday is not arms control or economic aid, not agreement on Germany or sympathy on Lithuania, but proof that he still matters.

title: Student Volunteers Join Elderly in Combined Fair
description: LEAD: STUDENTS at Burroughs Junior High School in Yonkers who participated in volunteer work during school hours will celebrate their program with a cross-generational fair at the school on Thursday from 11:30 A.M. to 2 P.M.

title: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN
description: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products. Business executives, members of Congress, academics and other experts on American industrial policy said in the article that such financial engineering often reflects short-term thinking and is sapping American competitiveness. G.E. officials defended the plan to buy back $10 billion of its stock over the next five years, pointing out that the company is a world leader in those fields in which it has chosen to compete and that its research and development is adequately funded.

title: A NEW POOL OF TALENT
description: I was delighted to read Phillip Hoose's article ''A New Pool of Talent'' (April 29), about Jim Ellis and his Philadelphia Department of Recreation team. I wish there had been a Jim Ellis in my Harlem community when I was a growing up in the 1950's. In those days, the boys were given swimming lessons at the local Y after school and the girls were left home. Most of the girls didn't care, but I was desperate to learn to swim. I remember once sneaking off to the Y pool after school, against the wishes of my mother. But she had only to see my wet hair and smell the chlorine to guess, and I was punished. I was almost 30 years old before I mastered the crawl, back, side and breast strokes and the correct breathing technique that permitted me to do lap after lap in the pool. Thanks to people like Jim Ellis, young black boys and girls no longer have to wait so long for the opportunity to train and compete. I can't wait to see some of those swimmers at the 1992 Olympics.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: There is a leak in a very secret United States agency, a leak that may threaten a carefully planned operation. An admiral with extensive intelligence experience is called in to plug the leak. So far, standard. But then comes the surprise - flashbacks to a spy in the Revolutionary War. The flashbacks thread their way through the entire novel, and that makes THE ONCE AND FUTURE SPY by Robert Littell (Bantam, $18.95) different from most espionage novels.

title: Genscher Discusses Germanies at Georgetown
description: Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher of West Germany said yesterday that German reunification would help create a better Europe and closer bonds between his nation's European and American allies.

title: Evolution in Europe;   As Soviet Union Grows Tense, U.S. Tourists Start to Shy Away
description: American tourists, who flocked to the Soviet Union in record numbers in 1988 and 1989, are thinking twice this year, travel companies and agents specializing in Soviet tours say.

title: IN SEARCH OF A MEANINGFUL RELATIONSHIP WITH COMPUTERS
description: Despite its phenomenal penetration into society, the personal computer is only now beginning to mature. Early personal computers required the user to learn strings of esoteric commands that differed from system to system, which limited their appeal and made them difficult to use. While that is still largely the case, common standards are beginning to emerge. The clearest and most colorful signal of this evolutionary change came last week when the Microsoft Corporation introduced a software that makes it easier to use the most common type of personal computer.

title: Fashion/Men's Style;   The Pajama Game
description: ADAM PENNINGTON SAYS HE SLEEPSJU in nothing but his boxer shorts. Pajamas? ''They're a little old-fashioned,'' demurs Pennington, an executive with a sports-marketing firm in New York City. ''My father was the only person I knew who ever wore them religiously.''

title:
MUSIC;

String Quartets Putting New Wine In Old Bottles
description: LEAD: Think string quartet, and thoughts of Beethoven, Brahms, Haydn and Mozart can't be far behind. The union of two violins, viola and cello is in many ways the quintessence of the European classical tradition - chamber music at its height. But through the 20th century the quartet, like the symphony orchestra, gradually began to recede into museum status; until recently most quartet programming only occasionally ventured past Bartok.

title: Priscilla Altmaier Wed in Delaware To E. B. duPont Jr.
description: Priscilla Hullihen Altmaier, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Worth Altmaier of Chadds Ford, Pa., was married yesterday to Edward Bradford duPont Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. duPont of Greenville, Del.The Rev. Luis Leon officiated at Trinity Episcopal Church in Wilmington, Del.

title: WHICH WAY TO THE MARKET?
description: THE ROAD TO A FREE ECONOMY

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;

Expect the Unexpected in Laughter and Love
description: LEAD: ''DON'T take yourself so seriously. Laugh a little.'' A friend said this to me when I was in my teens - long before Norman Cousins popularized the notion that laughter is good for your health.

title: A Horse, O'Course
description: FIRST you hear the faint skirling of the bagpipes, and then into the old, Victorian stadium they march: the massed pipes of the Irish defense forces, their orange kilts swinging in the breeze, their wild music setting hearts to racing. Behind them come four, five, maybe six or more teams of riders, some in bright red jackets, some in Army uniforms, the coats of all their horses burnished to a high shine.

title: Rightists Urge Whites to Oppose de Klerk
description: The leader of the right-wing Conservative Party called on whites today to rally for ''all-encompassing action'' against President F. W. de Klerk's plans to dismantle apartheid.

title: Assault Of the Barbarians
description: To the Editor:

title: League Steal Mark Tied by Henderson
description: Rickey Henderson tied Ty Cobb's 62-year-old American League record for career stolen bases today and the Oakland Athletics won their sixth game in a row, defeating the Cleveland Indians by 6-3.

title: HOLIDAY TOMORROW
description: Memorial Day will be observed tomorrow. Here are holiday schedules.

title: Police Interference in Drug Enforcement Charged in Hudson, N.Y.
description: Chief of Police James J. Dolan Jr., called Fingers by his friends, has been the subject of several grand juries during his 11 years on the force. One investigated his role in a barroom brawl. Another focused on his shooting of a fleeing crime suspect.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL

title: THE CUSTOM-MADE SUPERCOMPUTER
description: A team of scientists at Columbia University led by physics professor Norman H. Christ has built one of the fastest computers in the world. It can perform 6.5 billion operations per second, three times as many as the largest supercomputer built by Cray Research Inc.

title: Colorful Folk Motifs In Mexico's Lacquerware
description: I JUST go imagining,'' said 45-year-old Reynaldo Guerrero, when asked to explain the magnificent parade of rabbits, squirrels, butterflies and beasts that graces the laquerware he creates in Olinala, in the southern Mexican state whose name Mr. Guerrero shares.

title: Disabled Children Get A Chance to Play
description: LEAD: TWO groups of Westchester County parents are stepping outside the bounds of typicaltreatment programs to carve out new areas of play for physically disabled and emotionally impaired children.

title: GIVE SHAREHOLDERS SOME REAL STOCK
description: This year, institutional investor involvement in governance issues is reflected in the changing nature of contests for corporate control.

title: Bavaria
description: To the Editor: I read Olivier Bernier's article ''Bavaria's Rococo Splendor'' (Travel, March 25) with great interest but was surprised that he did not mention my favorite rococo splendor, which is at Kloster Schaftlarn, about 18 miles south of Munich, just east of the main road to Garmisch. Designed also by Francois Cuvillies (not, by the way, Cuvillies, as spelled in the article) and, though simpler and more austere perhaps than the other examples given, this small church is a rococo jewel.

title: Dr. J. V. Bono Weds Marguerite Bohan
description: Marguerite M. Bohan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Bohan of Greenwich, Conn., and Stuart Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. James V. Bono, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Rudolph F. Bono of Englewood, N.J., at St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn. Msgr. Thomas P. Guinan and the Rev. Kevin Royal officiated.

title: THE RUSH TO GOLD, AND A RETREAT
description: Gold investment reached record highs in Latin America, Asia and the Middle East last year, according to the annual report issued by Gold Fields Mineral Services Ltd. But there was net selling of gold in North America and Europe. After the supression of the democracy movement in China, gold purchases soared in Hong Kong and rose 57.9 percent for the year. In Brazil, gold buying was sparked by the decline of the country's economy and currency, pushing net purchases up 136.2 percent. These increases, along with a rise in Saudia Arabia after the Iran-Iraq war, more than offset sharp declines of 29.3 percent in Japan and 8.3 percent in Taiwan. In Japan, some gold buying may have shifted to London to avoid the new 3 percent consumption tax. In Taiwan, the stock market and new investment opportunites the Government encouraged abroad offered nice alternatives. In North America and Europe, where precise data is not available, the study estimates a net selling of gold because inflation was relatively low and higher interest rates made other investments more attractive.

title: AFTER A DECADE OF CONSOLIDATION, HARD TIMES AWAIT CARPET MAKERS
description: For the American carpet companies that survived waves of consolidation during the 1980's, the real challenge is just beginning. Now they face an era of slack demand from their customers in real estate and the automobile industry. New products are at best a distant promise. And the growth of Shaw Industries Inc. threatens its rivals.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-17

title: Lifestyle;   Sad Thursday for Magazine Crowd
description: Thursday will be the last gathering of the Last Thursday of the Month Club at the Zig Zag Bar and Grill in Manhattan. For the past year or so young magazine editors, writers, art directors and photographers have been flocking to these industry parties where the conversation, like the configuration of the bar at the Zig Zag, has a way of veering off at crazy angles.

title: PAPAL ENVOY TELLS OF LEBANESE TRUCE
description: The Papal Nuncio announced today that the Christian army commander, Gen. Michel Aoun, and a rival militia chief, Samir Geagea, had agreed to a permanent truce. But their forces continued to fight. The police said General Aoun's troops and Mr. Geagea's Lebanese Forces militia exchanged sniper fire in East Beirut, killing three people and wounding one.

title: The Force Of Conviction Stirred by the 80's
description: The decade under scrutiny in ''The Decade Show'' - on view through Aug. 19 at three of New York's most innovative museums - is the one that recently ended. But this exhibition could not be more timely. Among its roughly 200 paintings, sculptures, photographs, installations and works on paper is a large-scale drawing from 1987 by a young artist named Y. David Chung that depicts a Korean grocery store in a predominantly black neighborhood, the sort of establishment now so much in the local headlines. Mr. Chung's subject is racial misunderstanding and economic inequality, which he represents by giving to the image an edgy, uneasy and vertiginous feel.

title: William W. Perry Marries Leisa Little in San Antonio
description: Leisa M. Little, a daughter of Col. Oliver W. Little, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Little of San Antonio, was married there yesterday to William W. Perry, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Perry of Delray Beach, Fla. The Rev. J. Paul Worley performed the Episcopal ceremony at the chapel of the Southwest Craft Center.

title: Parents and Educators Face Tough Choices on Kindergarten
description: LEAD: PARENTS of 4-year-olds with birthdays in late summer or fall must soon decide whether they will send the children to kindergarten in September or wait a year, hoping that added maturity will assure academic success. For a growing for number of parents, the decision is becoming more difficult.

title:
In the Region: Westchester and Connecticut;

Prices Tumble, but Co-ops Move Slowly
description: LEAD: LAWRENCE W. BRIGATI, a New York City firefighter, looked for a house for several years but the most he was able to afford was a lot on which to build one, far north in Ulster County. Then he discovered building a house on it might cost $175,000.

title: Fashion;   Winter's Wooly Tights Lead To Cool and Colorful Leggings
description: Never mind skirt lengths. For summer, many women will be leaving their skirts in their closets and just wearing tights - with a big shirt or sweater, of course. It's the natural evolution of the long-jacket-and-heavy-tights style sported by the avant-garde last winter and spring (and suggested for next winter by designers on both sides of the Atlantic).

title: Deficit Reduction, Phase 1: The Staring
description: For all the hand-wringing on Capitol Hill and at the White House over how to cut the budget deficit, the truth is that are infinite possibilities.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: WENDY WATSON'S MOTHER GOOSE

title: Arab Anger at Israel: Has Mubarak Caught It Too?
description: When President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt warned of a slide toward war caused by Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel, some took his words as evidence that a new wave of Arab anger toward Israel had swept him up, too.

title: A New Hand at the Tiller for Landmarks
description: Although much of her preservation work has been done building by building, Laurie Beckelman hopes to bring a wider perspective - that of whole neighborhoods - to her new job as chairwoman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: The Executive Computer;   Fresh Windows of Opportunity for PC Users
description: Windows 3.0, the graphical operating system released last week by the Microsoft Corporation, does not transform an I.B.M.-style personal computer into an operational ''clone'' of the easy-to-use Apple Macintosh. Although Windows 3.0 finally allows a PC to operate in ways similar to a Mac - similar enough to have prompted Apple Computer Inc. to sue Microsoft - there are still significant differences.

title: Their Hearts Said Navy Erred About Iowa Blast
description: Through it all, Earl Hartwig never wavered in his belief that his son, Clayton, had been wrongly accused of intentionally causing the explosion that killed him and 46 other sailors aboard the battleship Iowa last spring.

title: Nancy Adams Becomes Bride of Craig P. Taylor
description: Nancy J. Adams, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Adams of Centerport, L.I., was married yesterday to Craig P. Taylor, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan Taylor of Coventry, Conn. The Rev. Joseph D. Casaclang officiated at St. Matthew Roman Catholic Church in Bristol, Conn.

title: Handling Growth In Somerset County
description: The fine article ''In Morris County, a Changing Outlook on Development'' (April 15) summarized the impact of growth and increased employment opportunities on one central New Jersey county. Somerset County was noted as having enjoyed the same kind of economic growth and prosperity in recent years.

title: THE FABULOUS BUSH AND BAKER BOYS
description: After reading ''The Fabulous Bush and Baker Boys'' (by Maureen Dowd and Thomas L. Friedman, May 6), I would vote George Bush and James Baker the two guys I'd most like to go on a working vacation with. I'm just sorry that these two bright and engaging men have given us nothing to date but all-talk-no-action domestic policies. When it comes to taking forceful, timely measures in such critical areas as education, the environment, crime and drugs, George Bush's ''vision thing'' can be summed up in four words: Read my lip service.

title: The Other Side Of Welfare Debate
description: It is entirely appropriate that Ruth Brandwein, Suffolk's Commissioner of Social Services, should express her concern for all those receiving welfare benefits on Long Island and to explain the reasons, in her opinion, for their inability to leave the welfare role. (''Freedom From Welfare, the Best Hope Yet,'' Opinion, April 29).

title: Paradise, of a Kind, Lost
description: ''WHERE choice begins, Paradise ends,'' Arthur Miller once said. For me, paradise ended on the island I loved when the post office added on a bar and restaurant. But maybe I'd better start at the beginning.

title: Alison F. Rosenfeld Is Wed
description: Alison Fern Rosenfeld, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Rosenfeld of Chappaqua, N.Y., was married last evening to James Desmarais, a son of Mary Desmarais of Paso Robles, Calif., and the late Alfred Desmarais. Judge Morris E. Lasker of Federal District Court in New York officiated at the Pegasus Room at Rockefeller Center. Mrs. Desmarais, 36 years old, graduated from Syracuse University and is a television writer in Hollywood. Mr. Desmarais, 39, graduated from California State University at Fullerton. He is a screen writer, director and historian in Los Angeles. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Abilene Remembers: Celebrating Ike
description: THOUGH Dwight D. Eisenhower was born while his parents were sojourning in Texas - on Oct. 14, 1890 - Abilenians have always regarded him as their favorite native son. And Ike, who spent his boyhood here before departing for West Point, always took pride in Abilene as his hometown. The city is feting the 34th President of the United States in a yearlong celebration of the Eisenhower Centennial, the 100th year since his birth.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: Sharon Kaye Britt Becomes a Bride
description: Sharon Kaye Britt, a daughter of Jean G. Brown of Dunedin, Fla., and Malcolm V. Britt of Rockledge, Fla., was married yesterday to Gardner Mark Harrison, a son of Lois Cowles Harrison of Lakeland, Fla., and John R. Harrison of Atlanta. The Rev. Emmett C. Johnson, a Methodist minister, officiated at the non-denominational ceremony on the beach at Longboat Key, Fla.

title:
FOCUS: CHESAPEAKE BAY;

A Marina for a Depressed River Town
description: LEAD: A MARINA with as many as 800 slips has been proposed for the economically devastated Susquehanna River town of Port Deposit, 40 miles northeast of here, following in the wake of several in the Northeast that have revived depressed industrial or commercial waterfront sites.

title: SEEKING GREENER GRASS BEYOND FAMILIAR FENCES
description: All artists have personalities and skills that shape their art; no one is equally expert at everything. Thus artists who attempt to stretch beyond their innate strengths command respect but risk failure.

title: Community Hospitals Adapt to Changes
description: ON a stroll through the corridors of any one of Long Island's community hospitals 30 years ago, a visitor might have seen heart attack victims in their third week of recuperation, a new mother taking her first halting steps days after her baby's birth and a few affluent members of the community on a kind of rest and rehabilitation program, compliments of good insurance coverage.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My glass shower doors have accumulated a layer of soap scum that has built up on the glass for a considerable length of time. The glass has a textured, uneven surface, so it is difficult to scrape off this scum. I have tried various household cleansers, but none worked. Anything you can suggest?

title: Campus Life: Mount Vernon;   Students and Staff Join Faculty in Bid To Oust President
description: Members of the faculty, staff and student body at Mount Vernon College have joined forces to try to oust the school's president who has served for the last decade.

title: Pandora Duke Biddle Is Engaged To Marry Yves Hentic in October
description: Nicholas D. Biddle of Madrid has announced the engagement of his daughter, Pandora Duke Biddle, to Yves F. M. Hentic, the son of Dorothy Smith Hentic of New Brighton, S.I., and Pierre Hentic of Montpelier, France. The prospective bride is also the daughter of Paula Denckla Watriss of Sparks, Md. An October wedding is planned.

title: Justice Dept. Scrambles to Explain Abduction Plot
description: The Drug Enforcement Administration scrambled today to explain the payment of at least $20,000 to capture a Mexican doctor and bring him to the United States to face criminal charges in the murder of a Federal narcotics agent.

title: An Artist Traces Her Life in Quilts
description: FAITH RINGGOLD is a black feminist artist, a doting grandmother and a proud loser of more than 100 pounds.

title: Medical Care
description: To the Editor: I am writing to thank the Israeli people for saving my husband's life. On Feb. 5 he suffered a ''sudden death'' heart attack at the Ben-Gurion Airport in Tel Aviv as we were boarding El Al Flight 001 to return home to New York. As he fell, his head hit a metal object and he was bleeding profusely. An Israeli doctor boarding the plane immediately started C.P.R. Within minutes an airport medical team was on the spot. Within eight minutes the Red Magen David ambulance team was administering electric shock and my husband was revived. He was then transported to the Heart Institute at Chaim Sheba Medical Center, Tel-Hashomer, where he received the most up-to-date medical care.

title: Bronx Church Honors a 'Role Model'
description: When he was 14 years old, Ronnie Jones walked in off the street and found a refuge at St. Peter's-in-the-Bronx. He was given a home and encouraged to study and to stay away from the drugs that plagued his family and neighborhood.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Swordfish With Some Kick
description: If you have been following food trends, you know that salsas and relishes and chutneys have taken over from beurre blanc as accompaniments to fish, poultry and meat. It's all part of a continuing interest in health and in intensely flavored foods. And it provides proof that you don't have to have butter and cream to make something taste wonderful.

title: Books From The Times
description: OUTDOORS: A Personal Selection From 20 Years of Columns From The New York Times. By Nelson Bryant. Illustrated by Glen Wolff. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, Cloth, $22.95; Paper, $10.95.) The well-rounded outdoorsman knows his way around a fly rod and a shotgun, but the gifted one is also on intimate terms with snowshoes, planisphere (star wheel), frying pan, beachcombing, canoeing and the best places to pick bayberries. In ''Outdoors,'' a collection of pieces written for the paper during the past two decades, the New York Times sports columnist Nelson Bryant shares his fascination with the outdoor life and chronicles the big catches as well as the ones that got away.

title: An 800-Slip Marina for a Depressed River Town
description: LEAD: A marina with as many as 800 slips has been proposed for the economically devastated Susquehanna River town of Port Deposit, 40 miles northeast of here, following in the wake of several in the Northeast that have revived depressed industrial or commercial waterfront sites.

title: For Yanks, Wait Until Next Year
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: GETTING OFF THE STAGE
description: ACTING IN FILM: An Actor's Take on Movie Making. By Michael Caine. (Applause Theater Books, $14.95.) Few other leading film actors in the last quarter-century have delivered as many good performances as Michael Caine; certainly no other actor, with the possible exception of Gene Hackman, has been so consistently good in otherwise unwatchable films. Thus, no one is more qualified to discuss the craft and business of film acting. Wisely, Mr. Caine does not talk about the art of acting - he assumes that even a stage actor must be remade for film. ''Acting in Film,'' the edited transcript of a BBC program, is largely a book on what stage-trained actors need to unlearn. ''On stage, the basic premise is action; you have to sell your attitudes to the audience. In movies, the microphone can always hear you. . . . In movies, it is reaction that gives every moment its potency.'' Mr. Caine skewers the stage snob's disdain toward film acting. ''Film acting is about danger. . . . If you rehearse a risk, it is no longer a risk.'' In fact, he occasionally reverses the old argument that a film performance is largely the result of such artificial elements as editing and amplification. ''On stage, technique can often fool an audience,'' Mr. Caine says, ''but in film, you cannot fool the camera with technique.'' However, ''Acting in Film'' is not a stage-versus-film debate. It is an insider's look at the difference between the two, of as much interest to members of the audience as to actors. Mr. Caine advises the film actor to learn to direct himself: ''Plays are performed. Movies are made.'' The English often have difficulty adjusting to film making in the United States, he says, because ''the British make talking pictures; Americans make moving pictures.'' And, finally, Mr. Caine says it pays to steal: ''If you see Vivien Leigh do something, or Marlon Brando or Robert de Niro or Meryl Streep do something that fits your character, steal it. Because what you're seeing them do, they stole.''

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Sunday about a party honoring Thomas N. Armstrong, the former director of the Whitney Museum of American Art, misidentified two people playing with plastic clappers. They were Ryder Ziebath and Alfred (Chappy) Morris.

BTR raised its cash through traditional bank loans, not ''junk bonds,'' and pledged that it had absolutely no plans to sell off parts of the company, close plants or even move Norton's headquarters from its hometown of Worcester, Mass.

So they signed a contract to buy in Clearbrook contingent on the sale of their

description: Did you hear the story about the man who bought a $100,000 boat on Friday, set sail on Saturday without the foggiest idea of how to operate the thing, and ended up adrift on Long Island Sound out of gas?

description: More than 200 years ago, a wealthy Pennsylvania merchant named Jacob DeHaven lent $450,000 to the Continental Congress to rescue the troops at Valley Forge. That loan was apparently never repaid.

title: AND THE WINNING - SCHOOL IS - SMALLER
description: Architecture cannot solve the crisis of the schools, and no one pretends that it can. But if good buildings cannot guarantee good education, they can play a subtle and powerful role in it. School is the most nurturing and stable presence some children have in their lives; for many children it is the only positive connection they have to society at large. The school building is the link between children and the larger world, the place where children first experience life outside their homes, and the impression they form from it lasts forever.

description: LEAD:

description: WHEN builders start explaining how we're all going to profit from their business ventures, taxpayers had better hold on to their wallets.

title: FICTION IN TRANSLATION
description: THE FALSE YEARS. By Josefina Vicens. Translated by Peter G. Earle. (Latin American Literary Review Press, 2300 Palmer Street, Pittsburgh, Pa. 15218; Paper, $11.50.) ''We've all come to see me,'' begins this strange, dense story of life entangled with death, first published in Spanish in 1982. It is the fourth anniversary of the day that a small-time rural wheeler-dealer named Poncho Fernandez accidentally blew his brains out, and the family has come to tend the grave. While the widow and her daughters busy themselves, 19-year-old Luis Alfonso remains aloof. The son has put on his father's dark suit, taken his father's old job and mistress, stuck the fatal Colt revolver in his belt and become Poncho's representative among the living. ''I could tell you what it's like to be down there with you, in your presumed death,'' he informs the grave, ''and what it's like up here with you, in my presumed life.'' In the course of Luis Alfonso's intense monologue, which has been smoothly translated by Peter G. Earle, resentment builds toward this identity that is shared so the dead might be kept alive. ''I had transformed myself into you,'' he says, ''so you could go on living.'' But what is left now of Luis Alfonso himself? ''Am I sick of being your accomplice?'' he asks the memory that inhabits him. And if so, what can he do about it? The answers come gradually, if at all, and in an Oedipal form that only invites more questions: ''I wanted to kill you, Papa, for if you're still living, Papa, it's only because I wanted and decided it that way.'' This brief example of what Mr. Earle, in his introduction, calls ''necrophiliac'' fiction, by the novelist and screenwriter Josefina Vicens (1911-88), continues a powerful strain in Mexican literature most famously represented by the work of Juan Rulfo (who sometimes collaborated with Vicens on film scripts), an odd but inventive school that has had a major influence on modern Latin American writing. In ''The False Years,'' the dislocations, the strange blending of personality, the overwhelming presence of ghosts all create a magical fictional environment, one that illuminates Luis's most tortured question: ''Do you know what it is to remain at the edge of yourself,'' he asks his father's shade, ''just looking at yourself?''

title: The Unser Book Of Hard Knocks
description: Al Unser Jr. was asked this week if his 7-year-old son, also named Al, would follow his father and grandfather into auto racing. Unser said he had planned to put the boy into a kart in a few months, but that he had recently hurt his arm in a minibike crash.

title: Naturalism at Lehman Gallery
description: ONE of the many fables written and illustrated by Leo Lionni tells of a mouse named Frederick who, like Jiminy Cricket, does not prepare for winter. Where other mice are collecting food, Frederick is off by himself, gathering, he says, ''sunshine,'' ''colors'' and ''words.'' Come winter, the odd-mouse-out nests with his brethren, sharing their supplies and, when they look to him for a contribution, he has only his food for the soul to offer.

title: Kelly Ashton Weds Carlo Sant Albano
description: Kelly E. Ashton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Harris J. Ashton of Greenwich, Conn., and New York, was married yesterday to the Marchese Carlo Barel di Sant Albano e Lucinge, the son of the Marchese and Marchesa Umberto Sant Albano e Lucinge of Torino, Italy, and Sao Paulo, Brazil. The Rev. Walter F. Modrys officiated at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: PLAYLAND;

A Landmark Primps, Polishes and Paints for Another Season
description: LEAD: THIS is Memorial Day weekend, a time for ball games, the beach and backyard barbecues, a time for the yearly greeting of the summer season.

title: Leslie Schumacher and Dana Burke, Lawyers, Wed
description: Leslie Karen Schumacher, a daughter of Brig. Gen. and Mrs. William J. Schumacher of Alexandria, Va., was married yesterday to Gilman Dana S. Burke, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilman S. Burke of New York. The Rev. Rosemary A. Smith officiated at the United Methodist Church in Cold Spring, N.Y.

title: In Moscow's Food Stores, Grumbles, Panic and Then Empty Shelves
description: Moscovites are used to complaining about empty stores, but today their worst exaggerations became a reality as nervous weekend shoppers from within and without the city raided stores, leaving shelves bare.

title: Streetscapes: 179 West Street;   A Lonely Reminder of the Days of Waterfront Glory
description: For 20 years, the little building at 179 West Street, which went up in 1845 between Warren and Chambers Street, has been a lonely holdout on an urban-renewal site, bypassed by the growth around it. Now the city is trying to sell or lease the largely cleared four-block area for development. A community group, the TriBeCa Task Force, is calling for a park.

title: THE 'ONEGIN' OF CHOICE - OR AT LEAST COMPROMISE
description: Record collectors regularly find themselves strapped to a Procrustean bed, agonizingly tugged in several directions at once. If one wants the most dramaticaly compelling account of Tchaikovsky's ''Eugene Onegin'' on CD, for instance, the decision appears simple enough: Acquire the new Legato Classics issue (LCD 163-2; two CD's), whose Tatyana is the gripping actress Galina Vishnevskaya in her vocal prime. That performance, however, happens to be the oldest of four complete versions now available, a monaural issue dating from 1956. Fanciers of this opera may already own the complete performance in one of its LP manifestations: it appeared on Parlophone and Bruno, and possibly other labels abroad.

title: School Budgets Overcome Tax Protests
description: LEAD: ONE after another, school budgets have been winning approval on Long Island this spring, laying one notion to rest. A taxpayer revolt said to have begun in early 1988 has not resulted in a higher rate of defeat for the budgets, which account for more than half the total of a typical property-tax bill.

title: Ray Atkeson, 83, Dies; A Noted Photographer
description: Ray Atkeson, considered the dean of Northwest nature photography for his landscape images of Oregon, Washington and the Pacific coast, died of colon cancer on Friday at his home in Portland, Ore. He was 83 years old.

title: Sexist Alert
description: To the Editor:

title: NURTURING THE NEXT WORK FORCE
description: Frank Stoler said he is using ''crackerjack'' computer programs written by students at H. D. Woodson High School in Washington. But Mr. Stoler, senior vice president for mortgage operations at the Federal National Home Mortgage Association, said the mentor program at Woodson, sponsored by his employer, provides something even more valuable to him.

title: 'Junk Bond' Anxiety Shakes the G.I.C.
description: The collapse of the ''junk bond'' market and the well-publicized troubles of the First Executive Corporation, whose California insurance unit has the largest investment portfolio of the high-risk, high-yield bonds, have prompted employers and employees to stop and take a closer look at what has been a popular vehicle for retirement plans.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: STEPHEN P. BANK;

Risks and Benefits in Having Siblings
description: LEAD: The relationships people have with brothers and sisters are usually the longest lasting of their lives and can have profound effects on behavior, says Stephen P. Bank, a clinical psychologist in Middletown.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My glass shower doors have accumulated a layer of soap scum that has built up on the glass for a considerable length of time. The glass has a textured, uneven surface, so it is difficult to scrape off this scum. I have tried various household cleansers, but none worked. Anything you can suggest?

title: South Korean Leader Accepts Japanese Emperor's Apology
description: President Roh Tae Woo said today that Japan's expressions of regret for its brutal colonization of Korea were the basis for a new relationship.

title: Derring-Do And Daring Escapes
description: THE Maharajah of Gwalior nearly blasted Edward Rice's head off with a double-barreled shotgun while hunting peacock in India. In Bangladesh, peasants stoned him. Bedouin nomads held Mr. Rice prisoner in the Arabian desert while debating his possible execution.

title: Fordham on Brink of Elimination
description: A day after upsetting Arkansas, the top-seeded team in the Midwest Regional, Fordham found itself a defeat away from elimination in the National Collegiate Athletic Association baseball tournament.

title: Q AND A
description: Illegal Alterations

title: Sheldon Kendall to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Kennett R. Kendall Jr. of Rochester, N.H., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Sheldon L. Kendall, and Jay C. Hardy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas C. Hardy of Lookout Mountain, Tenn. Both are Dartmouth College graduates. Ms. Kendall, 24 years old, is a paralegal at the Chicago law firm of Mayer, Brown & Platt. Mr. Hardy, 23, is an assistant floor manager for Cargill Investor Services at the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: POSTINGS: 27 One-Family Houses;   Clustering Advantages
description: Having obtained a change in zoning, a development team in Woodbury, Conn., proposes to build a cluster of 27 one-family homes near Middle Quarter Road, on a 37-acre parcel that would otherwise have accommodated as few as 15 dwellings.

title: Summer Outlook: Fewer Jobs, Fewer Youths
description: SEASONAL jobs as lifeguards, park attendants, beachcombers and camp counselors have traditionally been held by Long Island's high school and college students and filled by Memorial Day, the holiday weekend that marks the beginning of summer.

title: Building to Suit Small Tenants
description: WORK is now under way on the second of seven levels of a 364-space parking garage that will form the base of the 39-story Savings of America Tower in the financial district at 120 North LaSalle across the street from City Hall. It is the latest of three new downtown office projects catering to smaller tenants in the last two years.

title: New Times Ahead?
description: It has been six years since Alberto Salazar ran a high-quality race and almost eight years since he won the New York City Marathon for a third consecutive time. But next Friday night, at the Prefontaine Classic in Eugene, Ore., the 31-year-old Salazar hopes he can move closer to regaining the competitive form that once made him the United States' premier long-distance runner.

title: Currency Psychology and the Yen
description: It was a milestone of sorts for the Japanese. The dollar fell below 150 to the yen on Friday, a key psychological break for the Japanese currency. Although still weak, the yen has risen 5.9 percent against the dollar in three weeks and is at its strongest point since the beginning of March. If the dollar remains below 150, the yen could gain more momentum as the Japanese switch their hedges, which would mean buying more yen. The Tokyo stock market, as it has on other recent signs of strength in the yen, rallied 482.13 points on Friday, nearing the 33,000 level on the Nikkei 225 index. At the same time, the dollar rose against the West German mark, which has been troubled by the uncertainty and costs surrounding the pending economic union of the two Germanys.

title: Priscilla Reed to Wed
description: June wedding plans for Priscilla S. Reed and Jerome W. Anderson have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Reed of Amherst, Mass. Miss Reed graduated cum laude from Boston University. Mr. Anderson, a son of Duane B. Anderson of Tucson, Ariz., and the late Lois G. Anderson, received B.A. and J.D. degrees from Stanford University. He is a vice president of the Citicorp Investment Bank in London.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;

Beef-Up Time For the New Jets
description: LEAD: NOW that the annual furor surrounding the Jets' annual spring mini-camp has subsided, it is work as usual for the players, trainers and coaches who have buckled back down in serious preparation for a comeback 1990 season.

title: Alysen Dellomo Plans A Wedding in October
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Dellomo of Old Brookville and Southampton, L.I., have announced October wedding plans for their daughter Alysen M. Dellomo and Marcus J. Lodovico, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles M. Lodovico of Palm Coast, Fla.

title: Courts Take a Growing Role In Setting Policies for the State
description: STATE agencies that provide services for the poor, children and the mentally disabled are facing challenges in court that could dramatically alter their policies and the allocation of taxpayers' money. Legal experts say that courts in Connecticut are increasingly being asked to settle issues that the other two branches of government cannot, or will not, address.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If the Parliament cannot decide, the decision must be made by the people.''

title: ON G.E. AND EATING OUR SEED CORN
description: An article May 13 (''Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?'') discussed the extent to which many large American corporations, and the General Electric Company in particular, are buying back their stock and thus spending less on research and development and missing opportunities to develop innovative products. Business executives, members of Congress, academics and other experts on American industrial policy said in the article that such financial engineering often reflects short-term thinking and is sapping American competitiveness. G.E. officials defended the plan to buy back $10 billion of its stock over the next five years, pointing out that the company is a world leader in those fields in which it has chosen to compete and that its research and development is adequately funded.

title: Kimberly Esmay To Wed in June
description: Dr. Richard F. Esmay of Troy, N.Y., and Mrs. Esmay of Guilderland, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Kimberly J. Esmay and Macauley R. Taylor, a son of June Irmiger Taylor of Chicago and Macauley W. Taylor of Washington, Conn.

title: Campus Life: Sarah Lawrence;   Debate Persists Over a Professor Accused of Bias
description: The late Joseph Campbell, the teacher and philosopher, continues to make his presence felt at Sarah Lawrence College, where he taught for 38 years. Mr. Campbell was known for his work on mythology.

title: Works in Progress;   The Art of Emulation
description: AN EXAMPLE OF SUSIE RAY'S work is hanging in the British Museum, though Ray doesn't much care for the exhibition's title. It's called ''Fake?''; her painting is a duplicate of Manet's ''Vase of Peonies.'' Ray, 31 years old, is a copy artist. In her London gallery - called Susie Ray Originals - she replicates masterworks for collectors not keen on prints. They're neither fakes nor forgeries, she contends. Each is sold with her signature. ''My commissions come from people who want specific paintings in their houses,'' says Ray, who gets up to $26,000 per painting. ''But they can't afford the original, or it isn't for sale.''

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

Some Herbs Have Lemony Flavor
description: LEAD: I am a pushover for anything lemon . . . lemon pie, lemonade, candied lemon peel, lemon lilies and lemon marinades . . . just anything!

title: Maris Ross to Wed in June
description: Maris M. Ross, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Ross of Kings Point, L.I., and Peter S. Gordon, the son of Lewis Gordon of New York and Cecile Weiss of Dallas, are planning a June wedding. Miss Ross, 23 years old, graduated from Boston University and is studying law at Queens College. Mr. Gordon, 25, graduated from the State University of New York at Stony Brook and the New York Law School. He is an associate at the New York law firm of Jacobson & Colfin.

title: Board Control
description: To the Editor:

title: A Surge of Racism in France Brings a Search for Answers
description: With immigrant children crowding school playgrounds and with nearby apartment blocks gradually turning into high-rise slums, French residents of this dormitory town outside Paris talk of little else but the ''colonization'' of Clichy-sous-Bois.

title: NOSES PRESSED AGAINST THE GLASS
description: THE PEOPLE I KNOW

title: Voices At The Wall
description: IN THE EARLY MORNING DARK, WHEN THE AIR IS A fine mist, I stand on a deserted walkway at the Vietnam Veterans Memorial, listening for the footfalls of comrades long gone and waiting for the strangers who daily come to visit.

title: . . . And Now a Message From an Advocacy Group
description: Joey Harris, one of the title characters in the NBC comedy series ''My Two Dads,'' revealed himself during the past television season to be a dedicated environmentalist. In one episode, Joey, played by Greg Evigan, threw away all the aerosol sprays in the house. He lectured his daughter about using Styrofoam containers. He even went to jail for dumping sludge from a polluted beach into the toilets of an oil company's headquarters.

title: Israel Looks Around, and Finds New Cause to Worry
description: Israelis are casting a wary eye on the summit meeting of Arab leaders that begins Monday in Baghdad, conscious of a resurgent mood of belligerence that Israel has not had to face in more than a decade.

title: Two Series Of Concerts Fill Void For June
description: NOT that long ago, concert music virtually went into hibernation between the end of the spring season in May and the start of summer festivals a month or so later.

title: Bug Wars
description: I'm not sure how many gypsy moth caterpillars are in the yard. The term a million billion zillion -coined by a younger member of this family - comes to mind. They sashay onto your clothes, flail about on your shoulders, fall into your soda and do a mad fandango. Some people say they can hear them chewing, but entomologists say that is not true. What you hear is the sound of them expelling what they've already chewed. They look like this only not so cute and a tad hairier.

title: RUSSIAN MAVERICK AGAIN FAILS TO WIN TOP REPUBLIC POST
description: Boris N. Yeltsin narrowly failed today in a second round of voting for the presidency of Russia, after a day of political passions and intrigues that left the fates of the outspoken candidate and the largest Soviet republic in doubt.

description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Style Makers;   Bill Whitten; Designer and Retailer
description: The man who designed Michael Jackson's white glove and Elton John's feathered gorilla suit and boots that lit up with electric lights is Bill Whitten, a Los Angeles designer and as of March, also a retailer. On March 4, he opened his store, Bill Whitten.

title: Just What Mets Need: Dykstra, McDowell
description: Behind the batting cage at Veterans Stadium, chewing tobacco was spilling out of Lenny Dykstra's chubby fingers as he stuffed a wad inside his left cheek. In the outfield, Roger McDowell, with a white bandana under his burgundy cap and his peppermint pin-striped pants stretched down around the top of his burgundy shoes, was shagging fly balls.

title: Words to Survive Life With: None of This, None of That
description: ''Non'' is more than a prefix. It has become a life style.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;

Memorial Day Memories: Parades of Time and Meaning
description: LEAD: I WAS standing on the sidewalk at an intersection in a small town just south of Albany, watching the Memorial Day Parade. At the age of 6 (I was one entity in the baby boom, born in 1957), I watched the legs of many soldiers march by. When I looked up, I observed the proud smiling faces of men about my father's age.

title:
In the Region: Long Island;

Adjusting Developments to a Soft Market
description: LEAD: LAST July, when the Strathmore Organization of Coram tried to boost lagging sales with a new and less expensive model at its 205-unit homeowners association in Middle Island called Strathmore on the Green, the response was encouraging.

title: Another Meeting Pays Off for Mets
description: Another team meeting, another convincing victory. Maybe these team meetings should become a permanent part of the Mets' daily schedule, just like batting practice and running sprints. If they work, why not?

title: Children View Their Hometowns
description: YOUNGSTERS who captured their world in pictures and words are the winners of a student photography competition conducted by the Bushnell Children's Theater in Hartford.

title: Jonathan Case to Wed Rebecca Clothier
description: Mr. and Mrs. Isaac Hallowell Clothier 4th of Bryn Mawr, Pa., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Rebecca Clark Clothier and Jonathan David Damien Case, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James Thornton Case of Holliston, Mass.

title: A Sampling of the sounds and sights of summer in the south of France
description: From the shores of the Mediterranean to the arid hills of the Mont-Ventoux, the town squares, medieval castles, antique arenas and Roman cloisters of Provence come alive under the summer sun. The region plays host to many of France's major summer music festivals.

title: POSTINGS: 34 Units on City Island;   Nautical Condominiums as 'Retreats'
description: A former sailmaking loft on City Island in the Bronx, facing Long Island Sound, has been converted into 34 units of something that is not quite housing - at least, not yet. Instead, the Sailmaker project is described by its developers as a ''resort condominium'' or ''weekend retreat.'' The studio and one-bedroom units have kitchens, fireplaces, whirlpool baths and large closets, but the site, at the end of Schofield Street, is not zoned for residential use.

title: On Radiation, A Need for Facts
description: The Nimby-obsessed ladies of West Sayville, who are trying to block the National Weather Service from installing one of its new Nexrad weather radar stations on Federal property in the community because of possible health effects from electromagnetic radiation, bring to mind the similar arguments being used by environmental groups upstate in opposition to the Marcy South power transmission line.

title: Louisa Wright Is Married
description: Louisa Weightman Wright, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Spencer D. Wright 3d of Philadelphia, was married yesterday to Coleman Sellers 6th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Sellers of Wayne, Pa. The Rev. Charles A. Carter 3d and the Rev. James R. MacColl 3d performed the ceremony at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia. Mrs. Sellers, a graduate of the Hotchkiss School and Trinity College in Hartford, is a sales assistant at Morgan Stanley & Company in New York. The bridegroom, a freelance photographer, graduated from Ithaca College.

title: Abortion as a Crime Fails a Basic Test
description: To the Editor:

title: Grand Amour At Cannes Is Love of Movies
description: On the next-to-last day of his year's Cannes International Film Festival, an unidentified French actress was seen on local television peeling down to a bathing suit and diving into a pool, all the while discussing her admiration for the work of Alain Resnais.

description: A Boston organization has said three Hartford-area insurance companies will be the next targets of its campaign to convince large institutional investors to rid their portfolios of tobacco company stocks.

IN SHORT;

FICTION IN TRANSLATION

description: OFF and running since last November, Saratoga Restaurant and Bar is a recent addition to the restaurant scene in Westport. The look of the dining room and its separate bar is so ordinary that one is hardly prepared for the interesting menu.

title: For Them, Racial Harmony Is Work
description: Whenever a customer asks him why he works so hard or why so few black people are employed at his shopping center, Paul Cho, a local Korean entrepreneur, says he calls out, ''Charlie, come and explain.''

description: The Soviet delegation to the Washington summit meeting is hawking a glossy magazine with a smiling couple on the cover and the legend ''The Gorbachevs: Mikhail and Raisa at Home and Abroad.''

title: How to Repoint Brickwork
description: MORTAR joints in brickwork require yearly inspection. Cracked, loose and crumbling joints should be restored whenever discovered, else moisture can seep between bricks and cause damage.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on April 29 with a listing of music festivals misstated the opera in which the character Boris Godunov, performed by Yevgeny Nesterenko, appears. Mr. Nesterenko was performing the role in ''Boris Godunov,'' not in ''A Life for the Czar.''

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Poetry as an Exact Science

title: Campus Life: Northwestern;   Community Considers Tax on Student Tuition
description: To gain added financial support from this city's largest property owners, several aldermen have proposed taxing the tuition of all students at the colleges and universities, including Northwestern, in this northern suburb of Chicago.

title: MARCOS STRATEGY DESCRIBED AT TRIAL
description: Imelda Marcos had one basic strategy as she pursued exclusive real estate in Manhattan, prosecutors say. She did whatever she had to do to stay in the background. She used aliases, created fake organizations and used friends and associates as fronts. Even so, the prosecution has argued at her trial, Mrs. Marcos occasionally let down the facade.

title:
DANCE;

Twyla Tharp Reckons With Ballet Theater
description: LEAD: Twyla Tharp gazes at the clear sky from the sidewalk near the American Ballet Theater studios on lower Broadway in Manhattan and says of her new ballet ''Brief Fling,'' ''I just kept upping the ante. That's what I do - up the ante and take a risk.'' She could as easily be referring to herself and her association with Ballet

title: Mural on Space Travel Is Meant to Raise Sights
description: BEFORE Hilda Green Demsky's mural - ''From Earth to Space'' - was installed last week, there was little reason to look up in the entry hall of the Thomas H. Slater Center, a United Way-affiliated agency here. There was nothing on the walls except for an incongruous piece of pseudo-Grecian wallpaper in one small area.

title:
DINING OUT;

Daily French Specials in South Salem
description: LEAD: OVER the last 10 years rarely have we visited Le Chateau without feeling cared for. The warm greeting, the tempting menu, the attentive service, the carefully wrought dishes - all contributed to a feeling of well being. The grand proportions of the richly paneled dining spaces, the lovely terrace and the spectacular view added rare luxury.
