title: A Society's 'Salutary Checks and Pauses'
description: To the Editor:

title: Lisa M. Hulshizer To Marry in July
description: The engagement of Lisa M. Hulshizer to Eric N. Swats, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Swats of Sanibel, Fla., has been announced by her parents, Mrs. John L. Lesher of Greenwich, Conn., and Henry M. Hulshizer of Short Hills, N.J. A July wedding is planned.

title: Elliot Willensky, Writer of Guide To New York Buildings, Dies at 56
description: Elliot Willensky, whose opinionated and exhaustive ''AIA Guide to New York City'' has been a standard architectural reference work for more than two decades, died suddenly Friday at his home in Brooklyn Heights. He was 56 years old.

title: Where Genghis Khan Is In
description: MACHOL SIPPED DEEPLY FROM THE BOWL OF FERMENTED MARE'S milk and pondered democracy. Machol knew all about horses and sheep and wolves, but now this unfamiliar concept was sweeping Mongolia. His wife and five children hovered silently in the rear of the gur, the white felt tent that is a herdsman's home, waiting for his judgment. Sunlight peeked through the smoke hole at the top of the gur and dappled his leathery features but brought no inspiration.

title: How A.T.&T. Tosses a Lifeline To the Arts
description: Ralph Zachary Manna has an enviable job - he figures out ways to spend money - and an office to match. It's a corner one with a panoramic view of Manhattan, of course, and it is filled with theatrical mementos, stacks of expensive art catalogues and framed posters, all tastefully arranged. Twenty-five years ago, Mr. Manna, who goes by the name Zack, joined A.T.&.T. as a public relations copywriter. He is now the company's director of corporate advertising and events marketing. As such, he may be one of the most influential people in the American theater.

title: Exploring Classic Castillian Cooking
description: CUISINE confusion causes many Long Islanders to think of hot, spicy Latin American food as being Spanish. Mention Spain and they reply tortillas, tacos and tamales instead of paellas, mariscadas or chorizos.

title: The Next Best Thing To Two on the Aisle
description: If Broadway shows were judged solely by their original cast albums, the history of the American musical would be quite a different story than it is. Since cast albums don't provide scenery, costumes, dancing and spoken text (except sometimes in a printed libretto), the music becomes the whole show. Musicals with flawed books and strong scores (like Stephen Sondheim's ''Merrily We Roll Along'') would be remembered as masterpieces, while those shows whose scores efficiently but unobtrusively serve a larger concept (like Marvin Hamlisch and Edward Kleban's ''Chorus Line'') would be downgraded in importance.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: CONCORD, N.H.;

Transfer Tax Draws Fire
description: LEAD: THE recent 11 percent increase in New Hampshire's real estate transfer tax has jolted agents and brokers in a state with the third highest state transfer tax in the nation, behind Delaware and Pennsylvania.

title: Plan for New Yugoslav Party
description: Prime Minister Ante Markovic of Yugoslavia said on Friday that he and his Government planned to form a party separate from the ruling Communists to compete in a free general election expected later this year. Mr. Markovic, a Communist who advocates Western-style economic and political systems, is considered the person most capable of uniting Yugoslavia's ethnic groups under one banner.

title: Bogota Chief Tells of Drug War's Toll
description: On the eve of the presidential election here, President Virgilio Barco Vargas said Colombia's cocaine traffickers had widened their goal and were determined to bring down the nation's democracy.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

At the Public Library's Sale, Book Hunters Stalk the Prey
description: LEAD: YOU can have your basketball, your bowling, your jai alai, your squash, even your curling. For me, the indoor sporting event of the year in Simsbury, where I live, is the Friends of the Library book sale. This is a pure hunt, not a competition; the only prizes are the books.

title: SINCERELY THEIRS: LETTERS AS LITERATURE
description: FRANCOIS TRUFFAUT: CORRESPONDENCE 1945-1984

title: SISTERHOOD IS INTIMIDATING
description: A FEARFUL FREEDOM

title: Context Is All
description: To the Editor:

title: Evolution in Europe;   Polish Local Leaderships Facing Ouster
description: The polls open on Sunday in Poland's first fully free elections since the Communists gave up power a year ago, with voters poised to throw out the Communist officials who have dominated local government here since the end of World War II.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My glass shower doors have accumulated a layer of soap scum that has built up on the glass for a considerable length of time. The glass has a textured, uneven surface, so it is difficult to scrape off this scum. I have tried various household cleansers, but none worked. Anything you can suggest?

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My glass shower doors have accumulated a layer of soap scum that has built up on the glass for a considerable length of time. The glass has a textured, uneven surface, so it is difficult to scrape off this scum. I have tried various household cleansers, but none worked. Anything you can suggest?

title: Focus on Upper-Class Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Rape Is a Bias Crime
description: LEAD: Last month, President Bush signed into law the Federal Hate Crimes Statistics Act, which directs the Justice Department to collect statistics on crimes motivated by the victim's race, religion, ethnicity or sexual orientation. Sadly, sex or gender is specificially excluded from the list of categories for analysis.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 6 about television detectives' sidekicks incorrectly described Kate Miskin, Adam Dalgliesh's assistant in the P. D. James series ''A Taste for Death.'' She is her grandmother's caretaker, not her mother's.

title: Borough to Pay for Disclosing Man Had AIDS
description: A borough found liable because a police officer disclosed that a resident had AIDS will pay $55,000 to the victim's family, a borough lawyer said on Friday.

title: New Rules Tighten Mortgage Process
description: Shaky real estate values and tougher Federal banking rules are causing mortgage lenders to take a much harder look at loan applications than they once did.

title: Talking: Shortfalls;   Selling A House In Debt
description: What happens when the best price a home can fetch is less than the seller needs to cover all outstanding debts on the property, such as the balance of the mortgage, an equity loan and commissions due to the broker?

title: Michael C. Neus Weds Karen Farris in Jersey
description: The First Presbyterian Church in Englewood, N.J., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Karen A. Farris, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. R. Linsy Farris of Tenafly, N.J., to Michael C. Neus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald J. Neus of Manlius, N.Y. The Rev. James Steele and the Rev. Lukas Schmidt, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: Gorbachev Rules Out Leading Role for NATO
description: The Soviet Union will never agree to allow the North Atlantic Treaty Organization to play the leading role in building a new European security order, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev says in an interview to be published by Time magazine on Sunday.

title: Trudy M. Zohn Wed To David J. Schwartz
description: At the Carlyle Hotel, Trudy M. Zohn, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Herman Zohn, was married yesterday to David J. Schwartz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius Schwartz of Bloomfield Hills, N.J. Rabbi Steven Klein officiated.

title: Question Box
description: Expanded Success

title: Tiny Village Welcomes U.S.
description: To say that it is quiet around here almost disturbs the calm. Church bells ring at the appropriate times. Horses pulling wagons of tourists neigh now and again. Somewhere off in the distance, a dog barks and a rooster crows.

title: Ellen Ablow, Student, Weds in Connecticut
description: Ellen B. Ablow and Alan D. Norman, graduates of Stanford University, were married yesterday at the Guilford, Conn., home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Ronald C. Ablow. Rabbi Esther Adler officiated.

title: Debt Is Squeezing Hotels in China
description: Crippled by the collapse of the tourism industry, foreign-financed hotels across the country are struggling to meet their debt payments.

title: Eager Loyola Set To Face Syracuse
description: Aboard the team bus en route to Rutgers Stadium on Saturday, Brian Kroneberger of Loyola College was listening to a radio account of the first semifinal game of the national collegiate lacrosse championship between Syracuse and North Carolina.

title: Average Californians
description: To the Editor:

title: STRONG DRUG FOE WINS IN COLOMBIA BY A WIDE MARGIN
description: Ignoring terrorist threats by cocaine traffickers, millions of Colombians voted for president today and elected Cesar Gaviria Trujillo, the candidate who advocated the toughest line on the traffickers.

title: Emily White Marries
description: Emily White, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. White of Larchmont, N.Y., was married last evening at her parents' home to Walter Klores, a son of Samuel C. Klores of Ardsley, N.Y., and the late Francine Brown Klores. Cantor Edward Graham officiated. The bride, 42 years old, will keep her name. She is an educational consultant in New York. The bridegroom, 50, is the president and a founder of Lifespan Communications, a marketing concern in New York. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: Article 017690 -- No Title
description: For more than 20 years, Dr. John A. Grant has spent more hours than he cares to remember worrying about how to help teen-agers stop unwanted pregnancies.

title: Colby College
description: Colby College barred 16 seniors from attending commencement exercises yesterday on the Waterville, Me., campus as part of their punishment for participating in an underground fraternity.

title: 2d Loss Eliminates Fordham
description: Fordham's surprising season ended in disappointing fashion this afternoon as the Rams could not hold a 5-0 lead and ended up losing, 6-5, to South Alabama to be eliminated from the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs.

title: Sheffield Is Older and Better
description: Gary Sheffield, once a prospect and a project for the Milwaukee Brewers, no longer fits in either category. And both parties could not be happier.

title: Chronicle
description: Commemorating the first anniversary of the student demonstrations in Tiananmen Square, LI LU is scheduled to talk to some 500 lawyers Wednesday at a benefit in New York for the Lawyers Committee for Human Rights. Mr. Li, who escaped from Beijing after hundreds of students were killed in the square, is on the Chinese Government's list of 21 most wanted people.

title: Critics of Rights Law Fear A Flood of Suits Over Jobs
description: Although much of the public debate over the civil rights bill now before Congress has focused on the issue of quotas in hiring and promoting minority workers, the opposition of business to the legislation centers on a different concern - monetary damages.

title: Eva Grayzel Is Married
description: Eva R. Grayzel, a daughter of Elinor Sager Grayzel and Dr. Joseph Grayzel, both of Englewood, N.J., was married last evening to Dr. Kenneth A. Cohen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Cohen of Merion, Pa. Rabbi David C. Levy officiated at Temple B'nai Jeshurun in Short Hills, N.J. The bride, 25 years old, performs children's shows as the ''Story Theater.'' The bridegroom, 37, is a radiologist in Phillipsburg, N.J.

title: Traveling Gorbachevs: It's All Work, No Play
description: When Mikhail and Raisa Gorbachev agreed to visit Camp David next weekend, the Soviet Embassy was asked what pastimes the couple would enjoy. The answer was no to recreation. A senior Bush adviser said, ''Gorbachev doesn't like to do anything except work.''

title: 82 Killed and 275 Wounded In Pakistani Ethnic Violence
description: Ethnic violence intensified in Sind Province today, leaving at least 82 people dead and more than 275 wounded in two cities, the authorities and witnesses said.

title: Emil Konopinski, 78, Atomic Bomb Scientist
description: Prof. Emil J. Konopinski, who helped design the first atomic bomb and made testing of the first hydrogen bomb possible by showing that it would not destroy the world, died Saturday at Bloomington Hospital after a long illness. He was 78 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed.

title: Man Kills Wife, Then Himself After a Dispute in Hyde Park
description: A Hyde Park man killed his wife, wounded a neighbor and then killed himself after a domestic argument yesterday, the Dutchess County sheriff said.

title: New Daily's Radical Idea For Afternoon Success
description: A two-week-old tabloid in Kansas City, Mo., is trying to solve the long-standing riddle of how to make a profit with an afternoon newspaper.

title: HEAD OF LOBSTER COMPANY FACES TRIAL IN FRAUD CASE
description: The president of one of the state's largest lobster businesses is scheduled to go on trial here next week, accused of insurance fraud under a rarely invoked Federal maritime law.

title: Review/Music;   Boozoo Chavis's Zydeco
description: For New York fans of Louisiana zydeco, last Monday's show at Tramps was something like having the mountain come to Mohammed. Boozoo Chavis, the 59-year-old accordionist and songwriter from Lake Charles, La., whose band is the biggest thing on the Texas and Louisiana ''crawfish circuit,'' had taken his first commercial airplane flight to make his New York City debut in a four-day engagement, which ended Thursday.

title: Mets Show Some Spirit But Lose Main Event
description: Joe Carter, with a two-run single against Dwight Gooden, and Phil Stephenson, with a three-run triple against John Franco two batters later, delivered the eighth-inning hits that produced San Diego's 8-4 victory over the Mets yesterday. It was Greg Harris's eighth-inning pitch that hit Kevin Elster, however, that produced some of the more telling comments of the Mets' struggling season.

title: Drug Inquiry Involving a Former Aide Adds to Thornburgh's Woes
description: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh, who is enmeshed in a controversy involving two of his closest aides, may face a similar problem as a Federal grand jury in Pennsylvania investigates another former longtime assistant on cocaine charges.

title: Don Wallance, 80, Designer of Furniture
description: Don Wallance, a designer of furniture, flatware and cooking utensils, died Friday of congestive heart failure at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 80 years old and lived in Croton-on-Hudson.

title: GORBACHEV ISSUES APPEAL FOR CALM AMID PANIC BUYING
description: Faced with deep popular anxiety over a Government proposal to more than double food prices, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev made a nationally televised appeal to Soviet citizens tonight to stay calm during a ''tense, difficult and frankly speaking, dangerous'' period.

title: Review/Art;   Venice Biennale Opens With Surprises
description: For all the excitement and anticipation that each Venice Biennale occasions in art circles, this most prestigious of international exhibitions has rarely been more than a mixed affair. The 44th version of the nearly century-old event, which opened today and which is to remain on view in this city's gracious Public Gardens through September, proves no exception.

title: Philip V. White, 46, New Jersey Educator
description: Philip V. White, a former associate dean at the City University of New York who was about to become New Jersey's acting Chancellor of Education, died Thursday night at his home in Princeton Township. The police said the death was apparently a suicide. He was 46 years old.

title: Hungarian at Brokerage
description: Hungary's Deputy Finance Minister, Zsigmond Jarai, will leave his post to join the James Capel brokerage house in London in September to help with its activities in Eastern Europe, the firm said last week. Mr. Jarai, who is 39 years old, has been the Finance Ministry's head of state banking and securities supervision since April 1989, when Hungary was under Communist rule. Before joining the Finance Ministry, Mr. Jarai was chairman of the Budapest Stock Exchange and deputy managing director of Budapest Bank Ltd., one of Hungary's first commercial banks.

title: Julia M. Lichtblau Becomes a Bride
description: Julia M. Lichtblau, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George E. Lichtblau of Cabin John, Md., was married yesterday to David T. Moldenhauer, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Moldenhauer of Austin, Tex. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel performed the ceremony at the bridegroom's home in Manhattan.

title: U. of Massachusetts
description: Senator John Kerry challenged the members of the graduating class at the University of Massachusetts yesterday to emulate those who are seeking to impart democracy to Eastern Europe, China, South Africa and Central America.

title: Fake Fat: Another Sweet Deal?
description: This summer, the Nutrasweet Company will attempt to do what few packaged-goods companies have ever done: introduce a consumer product so successful that it becomes ubiquitous.

title: Critic's Notebook WATCHDOG GROUP CRITICIZES 2 NEWS PROGRAMS
description: Smugness being the vice of the virtuous, a recent assault on the ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' and ''Nightline'' must be welcomed, if only to keep their makers from dozing in the warmth of their reviews. The criticism comes from Fairness and Accuracy in Reporting, a left-wing watchdog group, which has documented the reliance of both programs on guests identified with the Establishment.

title: Freed Hostage Urges U.S. to Remember the Others
description: Frank Reed, freed from captivity in the Middle East, paused in his joyous reunion with his 91-year-old mother today to make a plea for the release of the six remaining American hostages.

title: Where St. Paul Ran Aground, A Pope Finally Makes a Visit
description: This will long be remembered by Maltese as the week when the Pope paid them a visit and their tiny archipelago got its only traffic light.

title: Sally Jo Krupman Weds E. E. Revel
description: Sally Jo Krupman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Krupman of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Enrico E. Revel, the son of Sherry Revel of Honolulu and the late Enrico R. Revel, were married yesterday by Cantor Raymond Smolover at Abigail Kirsch at Tappan Hill in Tarrytown, N.Y.

title: Robin L. Shaffert Weds in Washington
description: Robin L. Shaffert, a daughter of Kurt and Judith Shaffert of Chevy Chase, Md., was married yesterday to Dean R. Brenner, a son of Marilyn Brenner of Aberdeen, N.J., and the late Norman K. Brenner. Rabbi Fred N. Reiner officiated at Temple Sinai in Washington. Ms. Shaffert, who is 29 years old and will keep her name, is an associate in the Washington office of the law firm of Latham & Watkins. She graduated magna cum laude from both Dartmouth College and the University of Michigan Law School, where she was an editor of The Law Review. Her father is a senior trial lawyer at the Justice Department in Washington.

title: Israeli Is Given 3 Years For Desecrating Graves
description: A court today sentenced a Jew to three years in prison after he confessed to desecrating more than 300 Jewish graves in the hope that Arabs would be blamed.

title: After 26 Years, a Lawmaker's Fight Is Recognized as a Profile in Courage
description: As a member of Congress from northwest Alabama more than 30 years ago, Carl Elliott was an uncommon Deep South politician, championing revolutionary social legislation, eschewing racial demagoguery and more often than not finding himself casting a crucial vote to advance Federal initiatives in education, health care or civil rights.

title: Gerson T. Hirsch, Architect, 84
description: Gerson T. Hirsch, a retired New York architect, died of pneumonia on Thursday at a nursing home in Walnut Creek, Calif. He was 84 years old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: MONDAY, MAY 28, 1990
description: International

title: The Worth of Women's Colleges
description: To the Editor:

title: Brazil Shakes Up Its Steel Industry
description: Dominating Brazil's ''Steel City'' for half a century, the smokestacks and blast furnaces of the Companhia Siderurgica Nacional have long symbolized Brazil's state-led industrialization.

title: What Kind of Policy?
description: In a Harvard lecture on what he called ''the American Romance,'' Richard Darman recently declared that America ''was founded by risk-takers, expanded by risk-takers and led to the highest standard of living on earth by risk-takers.''

title: Susan K. Ullman Becomes a Bride
description: Susan K. Ullman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leo S. Ullman of Sands Point, L.I., and Arik M. Levinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen R. Levinson of San Francisco, were married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University. Judge John R. Bartels of Federal District Court for the Eastern District of New York officiated.

title: Bored With the Usual Fireworks? Try This
description: The sound of machine-gun fire echoed off the dusty hills all day as hundreds of thousands of bullets shredded the refrigerators, washing machines, automobiles and empty oil drums that were scattered about as targets.

title: Liberian Rebels Move To Isolate the Capital
description: Rebel forces began an offensive today apparently aimed at cutting off Liberia's capital from the rest of the country.

title: Ms. Seiler Weds Stephen Margulis
description: Randy E. Seiler, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Seiler of New Rochelle, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Stephen J. Margulis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Margulis of Williston Park, L.I. Rabbis Jack Stern and Myron Fenster officiated at Westchester Reform Temple in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Troops Kill 6 in Armenian Capital
description: Soviet troops sent to Armenia to control local nationalism shot six people to death at the central railway station in Yerevan today, the official press agency Tass said.

title: SOME HELP FOR WHEN GOLF BALLS GO ASTRAY
description: Dennco Inc., a company based in Haverhill, Mass., has produced a new device for picking up golf balls from streams, thick grasslands and other hard-to-reach places. The Hazardmaster is designed with a head unit that contains two overlapping hoops.

title: Toward the Summit;   NEW ARMS ACCORD SLOWLY EMERGES
description: Top American and Soviet arms control negotiators began an intensive effort today to resolve the main issues holding up a new pact cutting long-range nuclear arms.

title: To Call Consumption Taxes Regressive Is Just a Lame Excuse
description: To the Editor:

title: Dr. Ruth Rosenberg Weds Jacob C. Cohn
description: Dr. Ruth Rosenberg, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Rosenberg of Maplewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Jacob C. Cohn, a son of Gertrude Cohn of Pittsburgh and the late Arthur Cohn. Rabbi Debra Orenstein performed the ceremony at the Regency in New York.

title: A LEANER MACMILLAN PROFITS IN BEST SELLERS
description: For almost two months, the best-selling hardcover nonfiction book in America has been ''Men At Work,'' a baseball book by George Will.

title: Review/Music;   Vivaldi Choral Works
description: The Vivaldi juggernaut gained momentum on Wednesday evening, when Dino Anagnost and his Little Orchestra Society presented the second of this season's three concerts in a projected five-year festival, Vivaldi's Venice. In contrast to the first concert at Alice Tully Hall, which trotted out ''The Four Seasons'' yet again along with some opera excerpts, this one, at the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of the Holy Trinity, presented some important and little-known sacred works in their entirety. The Metropolitan Singers and the Greek Choral Society joined in the great ''Beatus Vir'' (RV 597) for two choirs and a pleasant ''Magnificat'' (RV 610), and the mezzo-soprano Kathryn Cowdrick sang the lovely ''Stabat Mater'' (RV 627).

title: Folly of Preemptive Mideast Arms Strikes
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Ballet;   A Cowgirl Spirited and Sure
description: Ballerinas sometimes approach the Cowgirl, the lovelorn tomboy of Agnes de Mille's ''Rodeo,'' in much the same spirit as glamorous actresses used to portray women with spectacles and their hair in buns. In cowboy boots and a braid, a dancer can act, and the Cowgirl seemed to grow mousier and more gamely pathetic as years went by.

title: Mitchell Rosenthal Weds Miss Simms
description: The wedding of Sarah Simms and Dr. Mitchell S. Rosenthal took place yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in New York. Rabbi David M. Posner performed the ceremony.

title: A Man Dies and One Is Hurt In Manhattan Bar Shooting
description: One man was killed and another wounded when a gunman opened fire at a bar in upper Manhattan early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Remember More
description: The whole last half of the 20th century has been clouded by the cold war, a war of deadly sparks if not of conflagration. That somber fact warrants note on this day set aside to commemorate the valor of those who lost their lives in hot wars.

title: Books of The Times;   A Man Who Feared No Extravaganza
description: Hype and Glory

title: Seoul Journal;   After All the Tear Gas, Just the Tears Remain
description: The kind of student demonstrations that filled the streets with protesters and tear gas here over the last week have become an unofficial fixture of the South Korean university curriculum and, at times, a genuine catalyst for change. In 1987, students helped force the military-dominated Government to hold its first free elections.

title: Taking a Detour From the Indy 500
description: The big motor race yesterday, which I wouldn't watch, reminded me that as a driver I was on my way to Indy the first time I got behind the wheel of a car. This is a true story.

title: Demand in U.S. Lifts Machine Tool Orders
description: Orders for American-made machine tools increased 8.9 percent in April from March, rising to their highest level since September, according to a trade association.

title: Stephanie Adler Becomes a Bride
description: Stephanie L. Adler, a daughter of James L. Adler Jr. of Phoenix and Audrey R. Wolf of Washington, was married yesterday to William S. Harrison, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Harrison of Haddonfield, N.J. Rabbi Rayfield Hellman officiated at the Adler home in Edgartown, Mass. Ms. Adler, who will keep her name, is a Williams College graduate and a project planner in the Mayor's Office of Special Projects and Events in New York. Her father is a partner at the Phoenix law firm of Squire, Sanders and Dempsey. Her mother is a literary agent in Washington.

title: Markets Closed For Holiday
description: In observance of Memorial Day, all financial markets in the United States are closed today. The financial markets in Britain are closed in observance of a bank holiday.

title: Officer Sees Beat Transform Over 38 Years in Chinatown
description: When Police Officer Andrew Siano began patrolling lower Manhattan, he would pause for handshakes, crackers and tea with Jewish shopkeepers and then sit in the kitchens of Chinese restaurants, learning from the waiters how to use chopsticks.

title: Evolution in Europe;   The Poles Vote for Local Offices: 52,000 Races Are Contested
description: Poles voted today for community councils nationwide and were expected to push forward democratic changes by ousting holdover Communists from their last bastions of power.

title: Cornell University
description: Frank H. T. Rhodes, the president of Cornell University, told 5,600 graduates and their guests in Ithaca, N.Y., yesterday that to score A's in life, you must have ''commitment and courage of your convictions.'' He told the graduation audience: ''Flunking life is failure to recognize that from those to whom much is given, much is required. Flunking life is to ignore the link between professional practice and personal commitment.''

title: Keating Files Third Lawsuit
description: Charles H. Keating Jr. has filed a new lawsuit contending that Federal banking regulators waged a vendetta against him, destroying the American Continental Corporation and his personal fortunes.

title: Interest Rises in Studies of Atomic Shells
description: The disclosure of a flaw in the design of nuclear artillery shells deployed in Europe has generated new interest in a number of Government studies that said 14 types of nuclear weapons had been temporarily withdrawn from the American arsenal since 1961 for repairs.

title: Basketball Talent Search Brings Schoolboys to U.S.
description: When Sergio Luyk began playing basketball as an 8-year-old growing up in Spain, he dreamed of playing in the National Basketball Association someday.

title: The Death Penalty's Shaky Support
description: LEAD: BOSTON

title: Sports World Specials: BASEBALL;   Sign and Sketch
description: Charles Hamilton, an autograph dealer and handwriting expert who has sold his share of sketches over the years, is the first to tell you that a signed sketch by the noted muralist and poster artist, Howard Chandler Christy, a portrait of a beautiful woman or a noted society matron done in ink on the finest white stock in pristine condition, would sell for no more than $5,000.

title: Trinity College
description: Seven honorary degrees, including one to a Chinese dissident writer who spent 20 years in forced labor and exile, were awarded at Trinity College's 164th commencement yesterday in Hartford.

title: Bridge
description: One of the world's greatest players was in the lead yesterday in New York's most prestigious pair contest. Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash., a winner of three world titles, headed the standings in the 62d Goldman Pairs qualifying, playing with Steve Zolotow of Manhattan. Second were a father-and-son combination, Art Weinstein of San Mateo, Calif., and Steve Weinstein of Montclair, N.J.

title: Faye J. Ringel, Professor, Weds Paul Hazel, Novelist
description: Faye J. Ringel, an associate professor of humanities at the United States Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn., was married yesterday to E. Paul Hazel, a novelist and the personnel director of the Ridgefield (Conn.) public schools. Rabbi Milton Rosenfeld officiated at the Harkness Chapel of Connecticut College in New London.

title: Immigrants and Welfare
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: Celebrating the 30th anniversary of his transition from Valentino Garavani to VALENTINO, the Italian couturier has transformed a splendiferous 15th-century building in the heart of Rome into a center for the arts. Named after himself, of course, first name only.

title: Amherst College
description: The 420 members of the class of 1990 at Amherst College heard speeches yesterday by Peter R. Pouncey, the president of the college, and Christopher R. Miller, a graduating senior from Pasadena, Calif.

title: Suns Tie Series, Beating Blazers
description: The Suns may have difficulty winning in Portland, but they sure didn't have much trouble with the Trail Blazers here at home.

title: Burmese Turn Out Heavily In First Free Vote in 30 Years
description: The people of Myanmar, formerly Burma, turned out in large numbers today for the first multiparty parliamentary elections in 30 years, and many of them told Western diplomats in the capital that they had cast their votes for the main opposition party, the National League for Democracy.

title: Old Battles Shaping Up On Air Bill
description: As the House and Senate prepare to go to conference on their separate versions of the Clean Air Act, lobbyists for the auto, oil, steel and utilities industries are planning to reopen some battles they lost in one or even both houses, including a dispute over creating cleaner automobile fuels for nine large cities.

title: Business and the Law;   Critics Say Bill Threatens Privacy
description: In their rush to toughen the nation's laws against money laundering, Congress and the Bush Administration may be stepping on the civil liberties of bank customers, the American Civil Liberties Union and some lobbying groups representing bankers assert.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Golf

title: Ruth Richman Weds
description: At Temple Sholom in Chicago, Ruth Richman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Richman of Glencoe, Ill., was married yesterday to Kenneth Kornbluh, a son of Alan Kornbluh of Miami and Leah Poller of Washington. Rabbi Dov Taylor officiated. Mrs. Kornbluh, a writer, graduated magna cum laude from Brandeis University, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and received a master's degree in journalism from Northwestern University. Mr. Kornbluh, a graduate of Tufts University, is a marketing manager for the International Business Machines Corporation in Boston.

title: Review/Theater;   When Families Feud
description: Familial quarrels, especially those incited by greed, sometimes degenerate into bloodletting, and in ''German Requiem,'' Eric Bentley's new play at the Living Theater, they may even portend the end of the world.

title: Leslie Kautz and Jack Weiss Married
description: The marriage of Leslie Barnes Kautz and Jack Stephen Weiss took place yesterday at the Beacon Hill Club in Summit, N.J. Judge Paul A. Lowengrub of New Jersey Superior Court officiated. The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James C. Kautz of Summit. Her husband is a son of Jacqueline Levit Weisberg and Walter S. Weiss of Los Angeles.

title: Chrysler Treasurer Quitting
description: The Chrysler Corporation said Friday that Frederick W. Zuckerman, its treasurer for 11 years, had decided to leave the company. A spokesman said that Mr. Zuckerman would probably leave this summer and that a replacement had not been named.

title: Review/Television;   A Re-examination of Stalin: New Views of Old Crimes
description: There was a time, tonight's opening episode of ''Stalin'' reminds viewers, when the Soviet dictator was treated as an avuncular figure by many Western journalists. The distance between that period and the present can be measured by the absorbing three-part documentary that begins at 9 tonight on Channel 13.

title: Beatrice Zenzie Wed in Princeton
description: The marriage of Beatrice Wistar Zenzie, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Zenzie of Princeton, N.J., to George Bradford Gregory, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George G. Gregory of Los Angeles, took place yesterday at the American Boychoir School in Princeton. Mayor Cathleen R. Litvack of Princeton Township officiated.

title: Catherine S. Jordi Weds in Princeton
description: The marriage of Catherine Sophie Jordi, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edouard Jordi of Princeton, N.J., to Andrew William Marcus, a son of Peter F. Marcus of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Mrs. Steven B. Geffen of Armonk, N.Y., took place in Princeton yesterday. Marvin Reed, the Deputy Mayor of Princeton, officiated at Mountain Lakes House.

title: Miss Tracy Wed To Mark W. Shea
description: Megan Anne Tracy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gerard B. Tracy of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Mark William Shea, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mortimer C. Shea of West Brighton, S.I. Msgr. James P. Haggarty officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in Crestwood, N.Y.

title: Democracy Doesn't Begin With Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: An art review in Weekend on Friday about ''The Decade Show'' misidentified one museum. It is the Museum of Contemporary Hispanic Art.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've got grandchildren and he's got family and we can talk about it as human beings. 'Hey, what are we going to do to make things a little safer?' '' -President Bush. [6:1.]

title: Graf Cultivating Outside Interests
description: Since she has inarguably mastered the tennis racquet, Steffi Graf wants to learn to play the piano. It is the latest twist to her conviction that, no matter how much she reveres it, tennis can get a bit monolithic.

title: U.S. Accuses Ohio of Overcharging at Base
description: In a rare civil suit, the Justice Department accuses the State of Ohio of overcharging the Army for the use of a National Guard training camp.

title: Erica Mass Is Married
description: Erica J. Mass, a daughter of Marvin Mass of New York and Cynthia Magaril of Valley Stream, L.I., was married at the Metropolitan Club in Manhattan yesterday to Kevin Scott Penn, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Penn of Dix Hills, L.I. Rabbi Harvey Tattelbaum officiated. Mrs. Penn, 27 years old, is an assistant brand manager at Richardson-Vicks in Shelton, Conn. A graduate of Clark University, she received an M.B.A. from New York University. Mr. Penn, 29, graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and received an M.B.A. from Harvard University. He is a principal in the New York investing firm of Adler & Shaykin.

title: Political Memo;   Incumbents Fear That Incumbency May Become a Campaign Liability
description: Representative John P. Murtha is one of the most influential power brokers in Congress, but in a Democratic primary two weeks ago the voters of his Pennsylvania district nearly turned him out of office.

title: After the Mills Balloons Float Away
description: When the seniors at Mills College loosed yellow balloons and let them float toward the sky a week ago, they were celebrating more than their graduation. They were celebrating the continuance of the kind of education they had chosen for themselves, and that Mills had been offering its students for 138 years. Mills is a women's college, one of only 94 (down from nearly 300 in 1960), and its students want it to remain so.

title: No Headline
description: Because of holiday produciton requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections. Business Day begins onpage 27,Sports Monday on page 33.

title: Metro Matters;   Sacrificial Lambs Are Hard to Find. Wonder Why?
description: Now, as the night

title: U.S. Aid to Israel: Behind the Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Luyendyk Wins in Fastest Indianapolis 500 Ever
description: What was fine weather for Arie Luyendyk and about 350,000 fans who watched him win the Indianapolis 500 today turned out to be miserable conditions for Emerson Fittipaldi, Al Unser Jr. and a bunch of Goodyear tires.

title: Your Honor, the Government Calls Ivan Boesky
description: In his first public testimony since agreeing to settle charges of insider trading, Ivan F. Boesky last week painted a detailed portrait of the intertwined relationships among investment bankers, traders and other executives that contributed to the Wall Street scandals.

title: Faces of the Summit: 30 Years of High Drama
description: September 1959: President Eisenhower and Nikita S. Khrushchev meet at Camp David, Md. The talks result in the ''spirit of Camp David,'' an effort to press for scientific and cultural exchanges and disarmament.

title: Profit Key Wins
description: Two of the most promising 3-year-olds in the country will be racing at Belmont Park on June 9, but not in the Belmont Stakes.

title: Boston Journal;   Did a Snare For Crime Drag Down
description: Once upon a time, in the 1980's, the residents of Dorchester thought their neighborhood had survived the drugs and crime that had been taking hold of the streets.

title: Japanese Challenge, I.B.M. Response
description: The Japanese Government has built up a vigorous computer and semiconductor industry that now challenges that of the United States. Washington is not responding to Tokyo's challenge; the Administration believes industries ought to sink or swim on their own.

title: INSIDE
description: Burmese Turn Out to Vote

title: Powerboat Racers Pick Sides
description: The recent split among offshore powerboat racers has polarized the circuit into two distinct factions: one is in search of national attention and the other is after grass-roots patronage.

title: Vincent Carson, 90, Manager of Airports In New York, Is Dead
description: Vincent A. Carson, who managed all three major airports in the New York metropolitan area, died of cancer on Friday at his home in Livingston, N.J. He was 90 years old.

title: Review/Dance;   A Community Festival With Roots in Africa
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's annual Dance Africa festival can be relied on for exciting and provocative dance and a warm glow of community. And this year was no different.

title: Bruce Chalmers, 82, Metallurgy Professor
description: Bruce Chalmers, a retired professor of metallurgy and former master of John Winthrop House at Harvard University, died of bone marrow cancer Friday at his home in Falmouth, Mass. He was 82 years old. Born and trained in London, Dr. Chalmers was a senior researcher in physics and atomic energy during and after World War II in Britain. He joined the Harvard faculty as Gordon McKay Professor of Metallurgy in 1953.

title: Mount Holyoke College
description: Wendy Wasserstein, the playwright who won a Pulitzer Prize for ''The Heidi Chronicles,'' told the graduating class at Mount Holyoke College yesterday not to be afraid to chart unique courses for their lives.

title: Sports World Specials: AUTO RACING;   Stylish Andrettis
description: MARIO ANDRETTI and his son Michael were forced to face the television interviewers earlier than they wanted to yesterday at the Indianapolis 500. But at least they presented a stylish look to the cameras.

title: BANK OF ISRAEL EASING RULES ON CURRENCY
description: The Bank of Israel said today that it would relax its tough currency restrictions to allow companies to strengthen their trade ties through foreign investments.

title: YANKEES' BIG BATS FIZZLE
description: It was the eighth inning that Bucky Dent couldn't quite wipe from his mind. Not the first or the third or the fourth, not the way that Dave LaPoint pitched, not the sudden turn for the worse that the trip has taken.

title: Koop Addresses Graduating Class at Vassar
description: Dr. C. Everett Koop, the Surgeon General of the United States from 1981 to 1989, gave the commencement address yesterday to Vassar's 550 degree candidates. In a speech covering many topics but returning to the need for graduates to concentrate on raising families well, Dr. Koop said he had seen ''too many people determined to be right there for the initial phases of a new project at the office, but absent for the initial phases of a new child at home.''

title: Creator of Companies Builds Profit by Region
description: Ten years ago, Ian R. Wilson was a vice chairman of the Coca-Cola Company when, as he put it the other day, ''they chose the wrong guy as chairman, and I left.''

title: MEMORIAL DAY
description: NEW YORK

title: Jails Face New Crises As Inmates Grow Old By ANTHONY DePALMA
description: When he passed through the dark walls of the New Jersey state prison here recently, John E. List joined the swelling ranks of inmates who are growing old behind bars and need medical care and compassion from those charged with punishing and rehabilitating them.

title: Chavie N. Kahn, Lawyer, Has Wedding in Chicago
description: Chavie N. Kahn, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Solomon Kahn of Chicago, was married yesterday to Yaakov J. Stark, the son of Sonia Kraus Stark of Brooklyn. Rabbi Emanuel Gettinger officiated at the Swiss Grand Hotel in Chicago.

title: Toward the Summit;   At Summit Talks, the Great Indoors Is the Only Setting Gorbachev Needs
description: The news was a bit of a blow to Mr. Bush, who has been trying eagerly to do a little casual bonding with his more reserved Soviet counterpart.

title: Iran Plans Spending on Oil
description: Iran will direct $5 billion in hard currency credits to its oil industry this year, its Oil Minister, Gholamreza Aqazadeh, said.

title: Prostitution Inquiry Prompts A Resignation and a Suicide
description: A sheriff's deputy resigned and an Ohio restaurateur killed himself after their names turned up on a list of a male prostitution ring that the authorities say involved customers from 39 states.

title: Cheryl Bayer Is Married
description: Cheryl G. Bayer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mitchell J. Bayer of New York, was married yesterday at the Water Club in New York to Jordan Brady, a son of Suellen Brady of Columbus, Ohio, and the late Jerald L. Brady. Rabbi Seth Bernstein officiated. Mrs. Bayer-Brady, 25 years old, is to become the casting director for the NBC television show ''A Different World'' next month. Mr. Brady, 25, will be the host of ''Turn It Up,'' a television show to premiere this fall on the cable channel MTV.

title: Judith Wilner and D. P. Lawrence, Students, Wed
description: Judith A. Wilner, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Milton Wilner of Long Island City, Queens, was married last evening to Donald P. Lawrence, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy B. Lawrence of San Diego. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon performed the ceremony at the Brooklyn Botanic Garden.

title: Black Assault on 2 Hispanic Men Reported
description: Two Hispanic men were assaulted and one was severely beaten by three black men who shouted racial slurs at them as they waited for a taxi early yesterday in the Bronx, the police said.

title: New Rochelle
description: Mart Susi, founder of the Estonian Institute of Human Sciences - the first independently organized university in the Soviet Union - told the graduates of the College of New Rochelle yesterday that the success of reforms in Eastern Europe depend largely on the ''seriousness and depth to which these countries can reform their educational systems.''

title: A Summit Without Maps
description: This week's summit conference between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, the first such meeting of the post-cold war era, promises to be different from any other.

title: LISTEN TO YOUR BODY FOR TOP PERFORMANCE
description: C. J. Mueller hummed softly to himself as he paced around the tent at the top of the course. He felt a loosening in his shoulders and a tingling in his body; occasionally he recreated the sensation of holding a perfect tuck through the speed zone while rocketing down the hill at a speed of over 130 miles per hour.

title: Pay Cable Channels Are Losing Their Momentum
description: It is just 15 years old, but pay television is already a mature business.

title: Christina M. Berti Weds Peter Litwin
description: Christina Maria Berti, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniele Berti of the Bronx, was married yesterday to Peter John Litwin, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gordon N. Litwin of Little Silver, N.J. The Rev. Henry Fehrenbacher, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Burt A. Siegel performed the interfaith ceremony at the Marina del Rey in the Bronx.

title: Thornburgh at Bay
description: This is the story of a double-standard in the great government power called ''prosecutorial discretion.''

title: Elisa Neary Is Married
description: Elisa Anne Neary, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Francis Neary of Merrick, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Gustavo Adolfo San Roman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Guillermo A. San Roman of Hempstead, L.I. Msgr. Edward A. Sweeney officiated at Cure of Ars Roman Catholic Church in Merrick. Mrs. San Roman, 29 years old, graduated from Adelphi College. She is an operations account executive for Chemical Bank in Jericho, L.I. Dr. San Roman, 28, graduated magna cum laude from Adelphi and received an M.D. from Pennsylvania State University. He is a chief resident in obstetrics and gynecology at University Hospital in Stony Brook, L.I.

title: Daffy's Now on Madison Ave.'s Elite Retail Row
description: For years, Madison Avenue between 43d and 46th Streets has been a quiet haven for full-price retailers of conservative men's clothing. In stores like Brooks Brothers, Paul Stuart, J. Press and Chipp, customers expect to pay $500 to $2,000 for a suit.

title: Weicker as an Independent: Low-Key, Out in Front
description: Gone is the big white Winnebago-like bus covered with campaign banners. So is the endless entourage wearing ''Nobody's Man But Yours'' T-shirts. Even the trademark jar-grippers that Lowell P. Weicker Jr. passed out across Connecticut during his four Senate races have disappeared.

title: Johanna I. Dim Wed To Richard G. Rosman
description: The marriage of Johanna I. Dim, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Dim of New York, to Richard G. Rosman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Rosman of Tucson, Ariz., took place yesterday at the Village Temple in Manhattan. Rabbi Barbara Penzner, the bridegroom's sister-in-law, performed the ceremony.

title: Evolution in Europe;   SOVIET EXCHANGES WITH U.S. BOOMING
description: Only five years ago, when American organizers of exchange programs submitted proposals to Moscow, they could wait up to two years for a reply. In most cases, they were turned down.

title: The Smiles and Chills In the Poetry Of Charles Simic
description: Charles Simic, who won the Pulitzer Prize for poetry this year with a collection of prose poems, ''The World Doesn't End,'' credits the military police with having helped in the formation of his work. Mr. Simic had begun writing verse in his youth, only a couple of years after he acquired English when he came to this country from Yugoslavia. But his early work was largely imitative.

title: Smoltz's No-Hit Bid Spoiled by Dykstra
description: John Smoltz came within two outs of pitching Atlanta's first no-hitter in 17 years as the Braves beat the Philadelphia Phillies today, 6-1.

title: M. G. Dinerstein Weds Ms. Allyn
description: Angela Allyn, a daughter of Christina Adamson of Glencoe, Ill., and the late Thomas Tilden Adamson, was married last evening to Matt Gordon Dinerstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred Dinerstein of East Hills, L.I. Rabbi Mordecai Rosen performed the ceremony at the Glencoe Women's Library Club.

title: Ellen Friedman Weds Samuel Bender
description: Ellen Faith Friedman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph N. Friedman of New York and Neponsit, Queens, was married last evening at the Pierre in New York to Samuel David Bender, a son of Dr. Eileen T. Bender and Dr. Harvey A. Bender of South Bend, Ind. Rabbi Alan Blaine performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Dennis Waldman.

title: Review/Revue;   A Chorus Line Plus, in the Leningrad Tradition
description: The music-hall tradition has died out in this country, supplanted by television specials. But with the best dog act in decades, creative aerialists and acrobat-contortionists, a brilliant Michael Jackson impersonator-cum-juggler and its one-sketch comedians, the Leningrad State Music Hall declares that there is still room for a beplumed chorus line and the old variety show.

title: Cleaner Air, Almost
description: For years, Americans demanded cleaner air and Washington did nothing. Now that the House has joined the Senate in passing legislation, a major overhaul of the air pollution laws - little more than a distant dream one year ago - seems well within reach.

title: Accountant Is Dismissed
description: PLM International Inc., a transportation equipment and financial services concern, has dismissed Ernst & Young as its principal accounting firm because of a potential conflict of interest.

title: Sports World Specials: GOLF;   Using Golf Clubs To Prove a Point
description: Greg Norman is fed up. Here he is an acclaimed golf champion, a master of his sport, yet every time he gets together with his buddies, Wayne Gretzky, Ivan Lendl and Larry Bird, they make him feel like some third-rate tiddlywinks player.

title: Divisive Abortion Politics Bring Iowa Democrats' Primary to a Boil
description: The rough new politics of abortion has descended on Iowa, straining old alliances, roiling the race for governor and mobilizing both sides of the issue for a battle being waged from church parking lots to the airwaves.

title: News Summary
description: International 2-7

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Karate and Judo Just the Beginning
description: LEAD: Priscilla Dabbs'S companion thinks she's seeing another man when she leaves her Westchester County home almost every morning before dawn. Maybe imagining a clandestine rendezvous is easier for him than imagining the kind of battle she wages at her 7:30 A.M. karate class at Midtown Karate in Manhattan.

title:
OUTDOORS;

OUTDOORS: FOR BIG TROUT, HEXAGENIA LIMBATA AT YOUR SERVICE
description: LEAD: TROUT fishermen are a hopeful lot, brimming with optimism even when there seems little cause for it. Too often the biggest trout, the ones we dream of, are maddeningly indifferent to the baubles and tidbits we toss around with fly rods.

title: A Strong American Military . . .
description: LEAD: Our nation has played a major ideological role during the 20th century in making ''the world safe for democracy'' while at the same time protecting our strategic interests. As agents of our Government, the armed forces have carried the major burden and deserve a major share of the credit.

title: Ellen Kennelly Weds John N. Brown 3d
description: Ellen Lee Kennelly, the daughter of Eve Williams Puloka of Nukualofa, Tonga, and Richard Bayard Kennelly of Claremont, Calif., was married yesterday to John Nicholas Brown 3d, a son of Capt. Nicholas Brown and Mrs. Brown of Baltimore and Middleburg, Va. The Rev. Scott I. Paradise and the Rev. Margaret B. Gunness officiated at Trinity Episcopal Church in Boston.

title: Iraqi Leader Sees Arabs' Meeting As a Spur for His Regional
description: On the broad highway at Baghdad's approaches, a sculpture depicts two monumental hands holding aloft crossed swords in soaring, heroic splendor. The swords symbolize the victory that Iraq says it won in the war with Iran.

title: Lois Shannon and Thomas Virden Are Married
description: Lois McCain Shannon, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Edgar Finley Shannon Jr. of Charlottesville, Va., was married there yesterday at Westminster Presbyterian Church to Thomas William Virden, a son of Mrs. Prospere S. Virden of Wellesley, Mass., and the late Mr. Virden. The Rev. James J. Baker officiated.

title: Howard Hosbach, 59; Led Standard & Poor's
description: Howard D. Hosbach, a former president of the Standard & Poor's Corporation and former executive vice president of operations for McGraw-Hill, died of cancer on Friday at his home in Allendale, N.J. He was 59 years old.

title: Minority Issues Lie Behind Protest Over Cutting of Budget at CUNY
description: Almost 20 years after the City University of New York began guaranteeing admission to any city high school graduate, a policy that eventually transformed the university from mostly white to mostly black and Hispanic, the university is engaged in a tug-of-war with minority students who want more than classroom seats.

title: Chronicle
description: Guests staying in Helmsley hotels are being treated to a glossy color brochure showing LEONA HELMSLEY writing a check for her taxes. For $42.06 million, to be precise, to the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Unsung Nealy Helps the Bulls
description: In the National Basketball Association, trades for ''future considerations'' seldom involve notable names, but the players in such deals occasionally go on to reveal hidden value.

title: Homeless Get New Start In Westchester Program
description: After eight years of shuffling in and out of welfare motels, Valerie Covel and her three children, ages 11, 13 and 15, are ready to rejoin society. Their launch pad is a transitional housing program designed to help homeless families find the skills, the courage and ultimately the permanent housing to end the cycle of despair.

title: Jeannine Anticaglia Weds
description: Jeannine V. Anticaglia, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Anticaglia of Hockessin, Del., was married at Tavern on the Green in New York yesterday to Stephen Scalcione, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Scalcione of Irvington, N.Y. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, officiated. Mrs. Scalcione, 26 years old, is an assistant account executive at the New York advertising agency of Lowe Marschalk. She graduated from Sarah Lawrence College. Mr. Scalcione, 29, attended New York University and is a television cameraman.

title: AUTHORS TAKE BOOK TOURS, ON A LEASH
description: Karen Hebert drives cars for a living. But she also knows which restaurant closest to ABC's studio in Hollywood serves the best enchiladas and where to buy a pair of jogging shorts near the Beverly Hilton Hotel.

title: Colgate
description: Nearly 700 seniors received bachelor of arts degrees yesterday at Colgate University's 169th commencement.

title: University of Rochester
description: The University of Rochester yesterday conferred its 5,000th doctor of philosophy degree, one of 2,341 degrees awarded during its 140th commencement.

title: New Wiley President To Focus on Strengths
description: John Wiley & Sons Inc., a publisher of textbooks and educational and scientific books and journals, has named Charles R. Ellis its president and chief executive.

title: Review/Piano;   Judith Gordon in Her Debut
description: In the 150-odd years of their existence, Liszt's B-minor Sonata and Chopin's 24 Preludes have become major industries for performing pianists. Literally thousands have stepped before the public and had their say about both pieces. Stronger personalities manage to reflect images of themselves in these shopworn masterpieces; lesser musicians use the allure of their familiarity to attract audiences. Manufacturers do the same, having learned that a shoe attached to an athletic star seems to sell a little better than one held up by you or me.

title: Tokyo Stock Tumult Cuts Earnings of Banks
description: Japan's major banks announced their earnings today for the just-ended fiscal year, and, as had been expected, most reported lower profits and margins because of the tumultuous changes affecting the financial markets here.

title: Beer Opponents Start Their Engines
description: Rusty Wallace, hard-charging at an average of 137 miles an hour over more than four hours, crossed the finish line of the Coca-Cola 600 in first place on Sunday, earning $151,000 for himself and inestimable millions in recognition for his sponsor, the Miller Brewing Company.

title: Chief for American National
description: Ronald J. Grayheck has been elected chief executive of the American National Corporation and its principal subsidiary, the American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, which are units of the First Chicago Corporation.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week.

title: 20 Groups Bid for Cup
description: A record total of 20 syndicates from 15 foreign nations have entered bids to challenge the San Diego Yacht Club for the America's Cup in 1992. The foreign syndicates had 30 days from the April 26 filing of the New York Court of Appeals' decision upholding the San Diego Yacht Club victory over New Zealand in 1988 to challenge for the 1992 event from off Point Loma, Calif.

title: McDonnell Dismisses 150
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation has dismissed more than 150 employees who the military contractor said had misused interest-free company loans.

title: Review/Music;   Light Side of Leinsdorf
description: Erich Leinsdorf, who is conducting the current concerts of the New York Philharmonic at Avery Fisher Hall, has produced more than his share of thought-provoking programs over the years. So one had to wonder, before Thursday's opening performance, precisely what he had in mind with this one.

title: Sending Ashes to Final Resting Ground From a Long Way Up
description: It's not funereal in the traditional sense, but that is precisely the point of an aerial burial.

title: Canadians Will Give Gorbachev a Preview of U.S., Starting Today
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will take time to rest during his state visit to Canada that begins today, leading some Canadians to call the 30-hour stay on the eve of the Washington summit meeting the equivalent of a ''refueling stop in Gander.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Wolves at Park's DoorSet a Test for Wildlife
description: Just as the wolf's extermination was among the last violent acts marking the taming of the American West, the predator's return marks a new stage in the often harsh debate over how to manage America's wildlife.

title: Belly Dancer's Appeal Sways Israeli Court
description: An Israeli belly dancer won a Supreme Court appeal against the Orthodox hierarchy today when the court ruled that kosher licenses could be issued or revoked only on the basis of preparation and serving of food, and not because of other factors, among them her presence as a performer in a restaurant.

title: Why Single Out Art for the Taxpayers' Veto?
description: To the Editor:

title: Bombing in Jerusalem Kills Jewish Man
description: A bomb planted near a restaurant on a busy market street in the Jewish sector of Jerusalem exploded today, killing a 72-year-old man and wounding nine others, including a 6-year-old boy.

title: The Real Red Squirrel Peril
description: The Sierra Club and several other environmental groups have got themselves on the wrong side of a silly debate. They oppose putting telescopes on Mount Graham in Arizona, contending that the observatory will endanger a population of red squirrels. The greater risk is to the health of the Endangered Species Act.

title: Yale Honors Chief, Singer And Giamatti
description: Yale University awarded honorary degrees yesterday to Wilma P. Mankiller, the chief of the Cherokee Nation, and to the soprano Jessye Norman at its 289th commencement ceremony, held on the New Haven campus.

title: Criminal Type Outruns Housebuster and Easy Goer at Belmont
description: A rich son of Alydar won the $595,000 Metropolitan Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park, but it was not the millionaire that almost everyone expected. Criminal Type ran down Housebuster in the final strides to win the Met by a neck as Easy Goer finished 1 1/2 lengths back in third as the 2-5 favorite, the worst finish of his career.

title: Last-Minute Repairs for Shuttle
description: An electronics problem with a display unit in the space shuttle Columbia resulted in extra last-minute work for technicians today, but the malfunction was not expected to delay the scheduled launching on Wednesday.

title: Killebrew Hospitalized
description: A collapsed lung is expected to keep Harmon Killebrew hospitalized for at least 10 days. Killebrew, 53 years old, underwent surgery last Friday at a Scottsdale, Ariz., hospital.

title: Shearson Is Expected to Name Units' Head
description: Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is expected to announce today that Jonathan S. Linen, an executive with its parent, the American Express Company, will be named to head its brokerage and asset management divisions, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

title: A Sneak Attack on Scenery
description: When a man in upstate New York chose to advertise his truck stop by hoisting an 18-wheeler atop a fuel tank tower above the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, it turned out to be more than an eyesore. The truck violates the Thruway Authority's requirement that such advertising be at least 660 feet from the highway.

title: 2 Shot Dead in Poughkeepsie
description: Two women were shot to death Sunday by a man who then turned the gun on himself after an argument in the parking lot of a Y.M.C.A. here, the police said. The shooting occurred about 6 P.M. at a meeting to transfer custody of a child after the Memorial Day weekend, Lieut. Arthur Regula of the Poughkeepsie Police said. He said two women were dead and a man was taken to Vassar Brothers Hospital after he apparently shot himself.

title: Lockheed Unit in Pact
description: The Lockheed Missiles and Space Company has won a $550 million contract to design and build a solid-rocket booster plant in Mississippi.

title: Bridge
description: A new partnership scored a major victory in the final of the 62d Goldman Pair Sunday night. Playing at the New York Penta Hotel in Manhattan, Paul Morris of Brooklyn and Jim Sampson of Manhattan headed a field that included many world-renowned stars. Second were Bob and Jill Blanchard of Manhattan.

title: Los Angeles? Tailored? Structured? Yes.
description: A handful of young designers here are making clothes that are sophisticated, structured and impeccably tailored.

title: Chess
description: The greatest shield the defender has at his disposal is the one that so often makes it unnecessary for him to resort to heroic measures - a timely sense of danger.

title: Australia Blocks Bank-Insurer Link
description: Australia's Treasurer, Paul Keating, blocked a plan last week by the country's second-largest bank, Australia and New Zealand Banking Group, to create the country's biggest financial institution through a $2.6 billion merger with one of the country's biggest life insurers.

title: President Urged to Increase Funds for Savings Inquiry
description: One hundred seventy Democratic members of Congress have asked President Bush to seek $100 million in additional money for the Justice Department to investigate and prosecute fraud in the savings and loan industry.

title: Review/Music;   Posthumous Premiere of a One-Act Opera
description: Ron Whyte, who died last September, wrote the libretto for ''Mother and Child,'' a new one-act opera that had its first showing at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Wednesday night. Rarely is the author the first matter of consideration in an opera review, but Mr. Whyte's life and this stage piece are inseparable.

title: 9 Hurt in Amtrak Wreck
description: An Amtrak passenger train struck a tanker truck loaded with sewage sludge today and 9 people were injured. None of the injuries were serious, the authorities said. The accident occurred about noon at a rural crossing between Indiantown and Okeechobee in southeast Florida. Lieut. Jim Howell of the Florida Highway Patrol said the truck driver was ticketed for failure to stop at a railroad crossing.

title: Racial Unity and Dissent in Brooklyn
description: Demonstrating for racial harmony, a small group wended its way through Prospect Park in Brooklyn today, handing out ''unity'' buttons and tying blue ribbons to lampposts and trees.

title: Brushbacks Mar Victory by Pirates
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates, held to one hit in eight innings by Tim Belcher, rallied for five runs in the ninth today to beat Los Angeles, 6-5, ending the Dodgers' five game-winning streak in a game marred by brushbacks.

title: IN MOSCOW SHOPS, STOICISM APLENTY
description: Moscow stores featured fresh supplies of stoicism today, with shoppers forced to brandish their domestic passports and face a ration list rapidly growing to include everything from light bulbs to socks.

title: Why Single Out Art for the Taxpayers' Veto?;   Lethal Weapon?
description: To the Editor:

title: Procter Talks With MTV
description: The Procter & Gamble Company, one of the nation's largest television advertisers, is negotiating a multimillion-dollar contract to advertise on the MTV cable network.

title: Dollar Is Mixed in Europe
description: The dollar finished mixed in quiet European trading today, affected by the Memorial Day holiday in the United States and a bank holiday in Britain.

title: Ms. Nussbaum Weds Joseph Rothman
description: Judith Elana Nussbaum, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Moses Nussbaum of New York, was married yesterday to Joseph Dov Rothman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Rothman of Brooklyn. Rabbi Dr. Manfred Fulda officiated at the Sheraton Meadowlands Hotel in East Rutherford, N.J.

title: As Bias Crime Seems to Rise, Scientists Study Roots of Racism
description: AS racial and ethnic violence erupts throughout the world, psychologists are striving to understand what impels people to acts of hatred, particularly when they act in groups.

title: Why Single Out Art for the Taxpayers' Veto?;   Checkbook vs. Badge
description: To the Editor:

title: Fashion: By Design;   Ballet Slippers
description: In the 1950's flat shoes shaped like ballet slippers were a must. They were the perfect accessory for mid-calf-length skirts propped up with petticoats. For spring 1990, ballet slippers can be seen finishing off a suit look composed of stove-pipe leggings or stirrup pants worn with colorful longer jackets. Or they balance off short skirts stretched over suntanned legs.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Burger King Spots On Staying in School
description: When Whittle Communications announced plans for Channel One, an advertiser-sponsored news program for high school students, critics assailed the inclusion of commercials. The program has been running since March, and with a single exception, the commercials have been standard-product advertising.

title: Johnson Criticism Hits Close To Home
description: Davey Johnson wore gray sweat pants, no socks, no shirt and an occasional frown as he sat in a spartan office in the visitors' clubhouse at Riverfront Stadium this afternoon before the game between the Mets and the Reds was rained out.

title: California Car Sales Report
description: Sales of imported cars in California have rebounded after several months of declines and now account for 56 percent of new-car sales in the state, according to the California Report on Automotive Marketing.

title: Gait Twins Spur Syracuse To Victory in Title Game
description: The era of the Gait twins, the Syracuse lacrosse luminaries, came to an end today in expected and glorious ways. The Orangemen routed Loyola College of Baltimore, 21-9, and thus won the national championship for a third consecutive year, before a crowd of 19,075 that overflowed Rutgers Stadium.

title: Effect of Banning Supplementary Nominations
description: rrThe demise of the New Shooter went unnoticed four years ago, but this season his absence is glaring.

title: Banks Try to Oust Homeless From Their Lobbies
description: On a recent Sunday morning on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, three different banks within blocks of each other had a homeless person sleeping soundly in their 24-hour vestibules.

title: Ceausescu's Son Implicated
description: A Romanian colonel today blamed the son of the executed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu for 89 killings here in the central city of Sibiu during Romania's revolution last December.

title: Pension Fund Loses on LTV
description: The Federal pension insurance fund's $2.2 billion claim against the LTV Corporation should be reduced, a Federal bankruptcy judge has ruled. He also rejected an effort by the fund, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporation, to push its claim ahead of others in the company's bankruptcy case.

title: Metrodome Visit Just a Fond Memory As Yanks Lose Docilely to White Sox
description: There are no answers. Not from Bucky Dent. Not from any of the Yankees, who sat passively at their lockers tonight.

title: Conservatives Balk as G.O.P. Prepares to Back Rinfret
description: The New York State Republican Party suffered a serious setback today when a traditional ally, the Conservative Party, prepared to field its own candidate for governor rather than endorse the Republican leaders' choice.

title: A Sneak Attack on History
description: The Thruway Authority's respect for the environment is not matched by a similar respect for history. The Authority removed Thomas E. Dewey's name from signs welcoming motorists to the Thruway and replaced them with signs reading: ''Welcome to the New York Thruway -Mario M. Cuomo, Governor. Peter M. Tufo, Chairman.''

title: Trail Blazers' Ramos Watches Team Practice
description: Ramon Ramos of the Portland Trail Blazers came back to practice yesterday. Five months after suffering a severe brain injury in a car accident, Ramos watched as his teammates prepared for Game 5 of the Western Conference finals, which will be played tonight in Portland, Ore.

title: Talking Business; with Morton of Hewlett-Packard;   Looking Ahead At Computers
description: Dean O. Morton is executive vice president and chief operating officer of the Hewlett-Packard Company. His main responsibility is the company's computer business, which generated roughly $8 billion in revenues last year. That ranked Hewlett, which is based in Palo Alto, Calif., third among American computer makers after the International Business Machines Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation. The company's computer lines include minicomputers, work stations and personal computers. It is a leading maker of printers and also produces calculators, test equipment and medical systems.

title: Japan Steel Profit Mixed
description: Three of Japan's leading steelmakers had higher earnings last year, thanks to a robust economy and steady demand from the country's auto makers and other manufacturing industries, the companies said last week. But two other steel companies reported drops in profits.

title: Chronicle
description: If you think the census counters have a monumental task, consider what's going on at 97 Orchard Street on the Lower East Side. The six-story building, built in 1863 near Delancey Street, is the home of the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, which chronicles the urban immigrant experience and which is trying to find the names of all the people who lived in the building's 20 apartments. That is an especially laborious task since the building has not been used as a residence since 1935.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''As we move further and further from our last war, we have smaller and smaller percentages of Americans who actually fought. Memories recede, and fewer and fewer of us now have relatives who died in wars.''

title: U.S. and Soviets Negotiate a Pact Tripling Air Links, Adding Cities
description: American and Soviet negotiators have reached an agreement that would triple airline capacity between the two countries, a United States official said today, and the pact is to be signed at the summit meeting this week of President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Q&A
description: Bird Navigation

title: Markets Closed For Holiday
description: In observance of Memorial Day, all financial markets in the United States were closed yesterday. The financial markets in Britain were closed in observance of a bank holiday.

title: A Ban Is Sought on Charges To Use Directory Assistance
description: Saying that charging for directory assistance hurts consumers, New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs has petitioned the state agency that regulates telephone service to forbid independent pay telephones from levying such charges.

title: What Is Windows 3.0 Really Like?
description: WINDOWS 3.0, the new software that the Microsoft Corporation describes as a ''graphical environment'' for I.B.M. PC and compatible computers, really hides the Phantom of the Operating System behind an attractive mask. The true face of DOS, the Disk Operating System, resides in dark, hidden chambers deep within tens of millions of PC's.

title: Stake Is Sold By Alleghany
description: After nearly three years of seeking permission to raise its 8.9 percent stake in the St. Paul Companies, the Alleghany Corporation is selling its 4.4 million shares back to St. Paul for a market value of $260.7 million, plus $5 million in expenses.

title: Shipper of Food for A.I.D. Investigated Over Unfit Milk
description: The affidavit portrays AMG as having a history of fraud. It cited a Federal Maritime Commission ruling in 1987 that accused AMG of defrauding the Government and commercial shippers by mislabeling cargo to obtain a cheaper rate. The document said AMG was embroiled in more than 60 suits in New York with shippers.

title: Soviets Are Dismantling Big Asia Radar Station
description: The Soviet Union has begun to dismantle its huge radar station at Krasnoyarsk, which the United States has long said was a violation of the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, a Bush Administration official said tonight.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Stereotyping Your Assailant Only Perpetuates the Prejudice
description: To the Editor:

title: Moscow's New Ambassador An Old Hand in Washington
description: The new Soviet ambassador to the United States is itching to unpack his bags, browse in Washington's bookstores and practice his rusty tennis serve.

title: Chronicle
description: May in academia is a month of praise for graduating students and administrators alike, and so VARTAN GREGORIAN, president of Brown University, has been busy receiving honorary degrees from Skidmore College, Hebrew Union College and the City University of New York. But it's always nice to receive a letter from an old friend, with praise to match any accompanying a degree.

title: Joseph H. Braverman; Executive, 72
description: Joseph H. Braverman, a retired vice president of the Tishman Realty and Construction Company, died of lymphoma on Saturday at University Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived on Staten Island.

title: Washington Talk;   Taxes: Pitfall or a Leg Up for Bush?
description: Is President Bush, who built an imposing victory in 1988 and imposing poll ratings in 1989 and 1990 at least partly on his ''no new taxes'' pledge, starting to fade politically because he has softened that pledge?

title: The Right Engine, A Touch Of Luck
description: It is arguable that once Arie Luyendyk got the right engine, he didn't need much luck to win the Indianapolis 500. Nonetheless, he had the benefit of a couple of factors any oracle would read the right way.

title: Question Raised on Amniocentesis
description: CHILDREN whose mothers had amniocentesis, a commonly used prenatal test for genetic defects, seem to have more frequent ear infections than those whose mothers did not, according to a study published in a British scientific journal earlier this year.

title: UNEQUAL BURDEN: NEW YORK CITY PROPERTY TAXES - A SPECIAL REPORT:   Some of the Rich Pay Less Tax Than the Other Homeowners
description: New York City's property-tax system, which has been criticized for a decade for placing a heavier burden on less-affluent homeowners than on wealthier ones, appears to have grown more inequitable.

title: Harry Bachrach; Necktie Maker, 79
description: Harry Bachrach, the president of Harry Bachrach Inc., a Manhattan textile company specializing in neckties, died of heart disease on Friday at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 79 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Walesa Settles a Rail Strike, but the Workers Remain Discontented
description: Two nights of impassioned, predawn persuasion from Lech Walesa today halted the crippling rail strike that had posed the most serious threat to date to the Government's ambitious economic reform program.

title: Gorbachev in Canada: Today's Schedule
description: Noon - President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and his wife, Raisa, arrive at Uplands International Airport in Ottawa, where they are to be met by Governor General Ramon John Hnatyshyn and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney for a 30-minute ceremony.

title: Scaffold Collapse Injures 27
description: A thunderstorm's winds toppled stage speakers at a music and arts festival Sunday, injuring 27 people. Several thousand at the Baton Rouge Fest for All were watching a warm-up band and waiting for a performance by the Temptations when scaffolding about seven feet high on the sides of the two-story-tall stage collapsed.
