title: France and Iraq
description: To the Editor:

title: Constituent Lobby Calls For Yeltsin's Election
description: Members of the Russian Parliament returned today to the task of choosing a president of the republic, and reported that they were being inundated by telegrams and phone calls from angry, impatient voters urging them to stop stalling and elect Boris N. Yeltsin, a rival of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Colombian on the Spot
description: Cesar Gaviria's campaign poster showed him in shirtsleeves, grinning giddily and wiggling his fingers in the victory salute. To create the pose, a studio photographer had to loosen up the candidate by playing a Beatles album full blast.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Flag Bill Gains in Louisiana
description: The Louisiana House passed a bill today that would lower to $25 the fine against those who assault people who burn the American flag. The House voted, 54 to 39, to waive the normal aggravated-battery penalties of six months in jail and a $500 fine in cases in which flag-desecrators are attacked. The bill now goes to the Senate. Representative David Duke, a Republican and former Ku Klux Klan leader, led the fight for the bill, saying, ''This is not a question of freedom of speech, it is a question of protecting the American flag.''

title: Results Plus
description: HORSE RACING

title: Silicon Valley Group Names Leader for Unit
description: Vahe Sarkissian has been named president and chief executive of SVG Lithography Systems Inc. A division of Silicon Valley Group Inc., SVG was formed by the recent acquisition of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation's optical lithography unit, a maker of sophisticated equipment for the development of advanced computer chips.

title: Sulfur in Stratosphere
description: MUCH of the sulfuric gas pumped into the atmosphere by man and nature falls out in acid rain, but some molecules can penetrate the upper reaches and hover like an impenetrable cloud.

title: U.S. Group Accuses China of Violating Rights of Tibetans
description: The Chinese authorities in Tibet have increasingly relied on political repression and torture to suppress Tibetans who oppose their rule, according to a report made public today by Asia Watch, a United States-based human rights group.

title: National Gallery to Show Rubens It Bought Recently
description: The National Gallery of Art will put on public view on Wednesday its latest acquisition, an early-17th-century painting by Peter Paul Rubens titled ''The Fall of Phaeton.''

title: Armenia Fighting Levels Off; Toll Is 23
description: The death toll from the savage clashes Sunday in the Armenian capital, Yerevan, rose to 23 today, as people in the city reported that a few sporadic clashes between Government troops and civilian bands continued.

title: Ms. Ferziger Wed To Clifford Felig
description: Minna Ferziger, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Ferziger of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Clifford M. J. Felig, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Philip Felig of New York. Rabbi Adam S. Ferziger, a brother of the bride, officiated at the Rye Town Hilton in Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: In Canton, Investors See Hong Kong After 1997
description: Throughout the 1980's, China's hottest growth area, and its biggest experiment in capitalism, was in Hong Kong's backyard: Guangdong province, a hotbed of entrepreneurial activity, economic experimentation and hundreds of Hong Kong-financed factories.

title: Iraqi Takes Harsh Line at Meeting
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq set a bellicose and anti-American tone for the Arab summit meeting here today, despite efforts by Egypt and Saudi Arabia to mute inflammatory oratory.

title: Papp Reorganizes Shakespeare Festival
description: Joseph Papp has made major changes in the artistic structure of the New York Shakespeare Festival, which he created 35 years ago.

title: An Opener in Tokyo
description: Although National Basketball Association teams have played a number of exhibition games in foreign arenas, including a barnstorming series by the Atlanta Hawks in the Soviet Union in 1988, no American pro sports league has had an official game outside of North America.

title: Abundance of Krill
description: The use of high-frequency sound waves to measure the population of krill, a tiny, shrimp-like crustacean that forms a base of the ocean food chain, has yielded less accurate estimates than previously thought because the krill reflect less of the sound than expected, researchers say. But the research resulted in a correction that allows a correct interpretation of the sound readings.

title: Review/Music;   The Order of the Evening: Chaos
description: If composing music used to be the creation of order out of chaos, the trio of performers called First Avenue seemed to be telling its Thursday-night audience that things have changed. In most of the music that came out of this long evening at Merkin Concert Hall, the composer became if anything a master of ceremonies, someone who announces the attractions of other forces and then steps aside.

title: Legal Threat Disrupts Rerun Talks
description: With deadlines next month for resolving a longstanding dispute, negotiations between Hollywood producers and the broadcast networks over financial ownership of television reruns have been thrown into ''turmoil and chaos'' by the producers' threat to seek Federal antitrust charges against the networks, a senior network executive said last week.

title: Sharpton Trial Papers Stolen From Maddox's Car
description: Two briefcases stuffed with evidence from the fraud trial of the Rev. Al Sharpton were stolen from the car of Alton H. Maddox Jr., Mr. Sharpton's lawyer, in midtown over the weekend, Mr. Maddox and the police said yesterday.

title: Chang Back to Form With Victory in Paris
description: Perhaps it happened when he stopped to smell the roses that ring Roland Garros Stadium, or when he nipped into his first baguette, but Michael Chang, the unassuming defending champion of the French Open, felt the spell of Paris upon him once again today.

title: Why Single Out Art for the Taxpayers' Veto?;   End Federal Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Market Place;   Disparity in Stock Of Alberto-Culver
description: THE Alberto-Culver Company seems an unlikely character in a takeover story, but in the last few weeks its shares have been trading as if someone was expecting an offer.

title: Corrections A Day to Sun, Sell and Even Remember
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the Memorial Day parade in New York misidentified the marchers. They were Chinese-American veterans from the American Legion's Kim Lau Post, not Korean-Americans. Another Memorial Day caption, about women performing folk dances, misidentifed the monument in the picture. It was the World War II memorial in Battery Park, not the Vietnam memorial.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: We'd Like to Cut Our Forces More . . .
description: LEAD: The Soviet Union seeks to insure its defense at the lowest possible military balance for both sides - a parity that has the goal of eliminating all nuclear and other weapons of mass destruction. We invite the U.S. and NATO to follow suit.

title: Police and Crowd Clash After Arrests of 4 Men
description: The arrests of four men for drinking alcohol at a street picnic in Jersey City yesterday afternoon led to a clash between the police and neighborhood residents, who said the police had handcuffed one of the men and beat him.

title: Fashion: Patterns
description: Scents Without Spritz

title: Ex-Hostage Hints at a Key To Surviving
description: Frank Reed says his emotional equilibrium may have carried him through his 44 months as a captive in Lebanon.

title: Company-Financed Pensions Are Failing to Fulfill Promise
description: The company-financed pension, once envisioned as a principal source of retirement income for millions of Americans, is instead an ever-shrinking portion of the money they receive in later years. The trend could force today's generation of wage earners to rely heavily on Social Security and savings.

title: Kicking The Habit Without Help
description: People who try to quit smoking on their own succeed twice as often as those who enroll in programs, researchers say. The reason may be that those who seek help are largely hard-core smokers, they said.

title: South Korean Growth
description: South Korea's economy grew strongly in the first three months of the year despite talk by Government officials of an economic crisis, the Bank of Korea reports. The central bank said gross national product in the three months expanded an inflation-adjusted 10.3 percent from a year earlier.

title: De Klerk Calls Far-Right Party Dangerous
description: President F. W. de Klerk, turning his attention to domestic problems after an 18-day tour of Western Europe, has called the right-wing Conservative Party ''irresponsible, undemocratic and dangerous'' for urging whites to resist his efforts to move away from apartheid.

title: Our Towns;   Home Bargains in Niagara: Just Forget the Toxic Image
description: Within weeks, abandoned homes at Love Canal are expected to go on sale. Willie Mason, a janitor, and his wife, Esther, a census worker, can't wait for the chance to buy their Love Canal dream home. They've already set their sights on a handsome abandoned ranch at 37 Mason Court. ''Any time we have nothing to do we drive out and look at it,'' said Mr. Mason.

title: Texas Woman and Ex-Spouse Are Indicted in Child's Death
description: In a child-abuse case that has sparked an outcry from advocates for battered women, a woman and her former husband have been indicted in the beating death of the woman's 2-year-old son.

title: New Products Clog Food Stores
description: New products are the lifeblood of the food business. But the large numbers being produced have begun to clog the industry's arteries, creating new strains between manufacturers and supermarket retailers.

title: Frank M. Adams, 64, President Of Heavy Construction
description: Frank M. Adams, the president of the Morrison Knudsen Company, and his wife, Novella, were killed on Sunday morning when a single-engine plane he was flying crashed near Naylor, Mo. Both were 64 years old and lived in Boise, Idaho, where Morrison Knudsen, one of the world's largest heavy-construction concerns, has its headquarters.

title: 1,300 Taken Off Stranded Ship
description: More than 1,300 passengers were stranded for two days on board a luxury liner stuck on a sand bar in Delaware Bay until they were carried to shore today on a ferry.

title: As Wars Grow Distant, Holiday Turns Gray
description: The sentiments here were as strong as ever, and Delmas E. Green voiced them in words that were surely echoed 10,000 times as Americans paid tribute to fallen heroes of all the nation's wars on this Memorial Day.

title: Rams' Baseball Coach Not Resting on Laurels
description: A few hours after his team was eliminated from the college baseball playoffs, Dan Gallagher, the Fordham Rams' barrel-chested coach, sat in his hotel room reflecting on the squad's 6-5 loss to South Alabama.

title: Ethnic Strife Goes On In Pakistani Province
description: Renewed fighting between ethnic groups in Sind province killed at least 15 people today. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan criticized the police for their role in unrest, in which at least 152 people have died in three days.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Sosa Takes The Off Path To Success
description: ONLY days away from completing the sale of 49 percent of his agency to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, Lionel Sosa was overflowing with enthusiasm. From his San Antonio home, he came to New York last week to meet his new partner's Latin American executives.

title: Workers Win Airline Ruling
description: Employees of Continental Airlines who lost wages and benefits in 1983 when the company was allowed to reject its labor contracts are entitled to damages, a Federal appeals court said last week.

title: Robert B. Meyner Is Dead at 81; Flamboyant New Jersey Governor
description: Robert B. Meyner, who revitalized the Democratic Party in New Jersey and rose to national prominence during two terms as Governor in the 1950's and early 60's, died Sunday at his home in Captiva, Fla., after a long illness. He was 81 years old and had been in declining health since suffering a stroke in 1986.

title: Dining Chain, S.E.C. Settle
description: Bombay Palace Restaurants Inc. and two of its executives have settled Federal civil charges that they falsified the company's books in 1987.

title: MANY STATES CUT FOOD ALLOTMENTS FOR POOR FAMILIES
description: Because of unexpected increases in food prices in the last eight months, at least half the states have moved to cut government food allotments for poor women and children or to stop the aid altogether for thousands of these people.

title: Books of The Times;   Back in the Cold War, When Innocence Was Sin
description: The Innocent

title: Chambers Puts Suns in the Running
description: Like sunshine and 90-degree temperatures, Tom Chambers's scoring ability is a constant in Phoenix.

title: Review/Ballet;   Delayed Debut for Ruzimatov, Former Kirov Star
description: Dancing too well and too hard? American Ballet Theater's otherwise splendid season has been marked by a notable number of injuries, some even sustained in rehearsal before the opening at the Metropolitan Opera House three and a half weeks ago.

title: Scientists Link Protein Fragments to Alzheimer's
description: A TINY shard of a protein so biochemically tough that it can hardly be dissolved, even in a test tube, may be at the heart of the extreme neurological degeneration and related symptoms of Alzheimer's disease.

title: Nursing Homes Seen Lagging On Rules for Food and Drugs
description: More than a third of the nation's nursing homes offering skilled care failed to meet standards for clean food in surprise inspections in 1988 and 1989, and nearly a quarter did not administer drugs properly, according to the Government's latest consumer guide.

title: Negotiations Concluded Over U.S.-Soviet Trade
description: American and Soviet negotiators have concluded the remaining details of a trade agreement under which enterprises of the two countries would establish deeper footholds in each other's markets.

title: Using the Familiar Macintosh For Literary Purposes
description: WRITENOW version 2.2 is a lean and mean word-processing program for the Apple Computer Inc. Macintosh. It has all the features needed to create simple documents and many of the features needed to create more complex ones, and it zips right along.

title: As Hong Kong Elite Are Leaving, Japanese Investors Are Moving In
description: At a time when thousands of Hong Kong's elite are vying for Canadian passports and its oldest companies are registering in the Bahamas, something unexpected is happening. The Japanese, usually among the world's most cautious investors, are moving into town.

title: Root of Liberia's Crisis Stems From Its President
description: To the Editor:

title: Forecasting Without the Weather
description: In coming weeks, the bond market is likely to get a clearer view of whether the economy is deteriorating, analysts say, as the Government releases economic data that have not been distorted by abnormal weather.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Federal Paper Board Co., Montvale, N.J., promoted W. Mark Massey Jr. to senior vice president for manufacturing at its forest products division. He was also named a director.

title: Trevino's Dream: 18 Aces
description: In the months before Lee Trevino joined the Senior PGA Tour, he would smile and say, ''I can't wait to play against the round bellies instead of the flat bellies.'' And play he has. Awaiting the Nynex/Golf Digest Commemorative that starts Friday at Sleepy Hollow in Scarborough, N.Y., he is the money leader with $340,133 and the scoring leader with a 69.29-stroke average.

title: Careers;   Balancing Teaching and Research
description: GRADUATE business schools are wrestling with the dilemma of how faculty members should divide their time between research and teaching.

title: Lori F. Tauber Weds
description: Lori F. Tauber, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alvin M. Tauber of Emerson, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. James R. Marcus, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Daniel H. Marcus of New City, N.Y. Rabbi George M. Stern officiated at the Woodcliff Lake (N.J.) Hilton. The bride, 27 years old, will keep her name. She is a marketing manager at the Pepsi-Cola Company in Somers, N.Y. She graduated cum laude from the University of Pennsylvania. The bridegroom, 29, is an electrical engineer at Pitney Bowes in Norwalk, Conn. He graduated magna cum laude from Tufts University, where he also received M.S. and Ph.D degrees in electrical engineering.

title: Defense By Bulls Is Spark To Victory
description: The game began with the Bulls employing a harrowing pressure defense that stopped the Pistons' offense from getting started. It ended with a big finish from Michael Jordan, who scored 19 of his 42 points in the fourth quarter, and the Bulls held on for a 108-101 victory here at noisy Chicago Stadium.

title: Santa Marta Journal;   The Road Lies Unpaved, in Spite of All Intentions
description: When the army came to this isolated town last month and declared an early Christmas, the residents asked for a better road.

title: Japan's Big Banks Shift Strategies
description: Japanese banks, which earned a reputation for price-cutting as they become the colossuses of the financial world in the 1980's, are adjusting their strategies to improve profits, an area in which they lag behind American and European banks.

title: Henson Death Shows Danger of Pneumonia
description: THE untimely death of Jim Henson, the creator of the Muppets, from pneumonia this month at the age of 53 may have shocked many Americans who believed that bacterial infections no longer could kill with such swiftness.

title: Bari and Mindy Brandt Become Brides
description: Dr. Bari Michele Brandt and Dr. Lee G. Gonshor were married yesterday in a double ceremony with Dr. Brandt's sister Mindy Sue Brandt and Allan J. Weiner. Cantor Wayne S. Siet of Marlboro, N.J., officiated at the Grand Marquis in Old Bridge, N.J. The brides, who will keep their names, are daughters of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford D. Brandt of Woodbridge, N.J.

title: Big Science; Is It Worth the Price? - A periodic look at the largest new research projects.;   Supercollider's Rising Cost Provokes Opposition
description: IF America eventually decides it can spare the $8 billion or so needed to build the Superconducting Supercollider, the county-size machine might turn out to be a key to the meaning of physical reality, or it might be a dud. But either way, the project is raising intense debate among scientists and politicians as to whether the new knowledge it generates will be commensurate with the enormous cost.

title: Farm Subsidies and Textiles Top Trade Meeting Agenda
description: Concerned about slow progress in world trade talks, the finance ministers of the industrial world are expected to try to provide some momentum when they gather here on Wednesday.

title: Review/Television;   Bringing a Black Sensibility to Comedy in a Series
description: ''Do what you want to do,'' the show's theme song urges, ''in living color.'' And that is clearly what Keenen Ivory Wayans is trying to do as the executive producer, writer and star of ''In Living Color,'' a weekly explosion of energy and exuberant sass on the Fox Broadcasting schedule. The half-hour show can now be seen at 9:30 on Sunday nights.

title: North Korea Turns Over Remains of 5 G.I.'s
description: In a solemn Memorial Day ceremony, North Korea today turned over to a United States Congressional delegation the remains of five American servicemen killed in the Korean War.

title: Bond Plans to Sell Breweries
description: Alan Bond's struggling flagship company, Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., struck a deal last week with its bankers and an independent subsidiary that will cost it control of its Australian breweries, its biggest asset.

title: Variety of Treasury Bill Sales This Week
description: Treasury financings in this holiday-shortened week include today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, followed on Wednesday by the Treasury's auctions of $6 billion each of cash management bills due on June 21 and Sept. 20. On Thursday, the Treasury will auction $10 billion of one-year bills.

title: Chronicle
description: For three days and most of the nights, the small town of Taormina in eastern Sicily resounded with theater talk by performers, critics, playwrights, directors and fans from around the world, culminating Sunday with tributes and a $30,000 award to GIORGIO STREHLER, the Italian stage director. A master of ancient and modern classics and founder of Milan's Piccolo Teatro, Mr. Strehler, 69 years old, said he was planning to dedicate the rest of his life to acting.

title: Standing Up for the Arts
description: Pat Williams is taking no chances. The Montana Democrat heads the House subcommittee that oversees the National Endowment for the Arts. That's why he has convened 30 representatives of arts institutions and the public to debate the future of the beleaguered agency.

title: As Oil Bounty Drains, Alaska Becomes Uneasy
description: Alaskans are used to coping with the cycles of boom and bust inherent in the state's oil-based economy. But now, companies and politicians here are coming to terms with a much more uncertain and unsettling future.

title: Burmese Vote Rejects Army Rule With Big Victory for Opposition
description: Voters in Myanmar, formerly Burma, appeared today to have sharply repudiated their military rulers and to have given a landslide victory to the main opposition party, whose leadership remains in jail or under house arrest.

title: Vision at the Summit
description: George Bush comes to this week's summit meeting with every political advantage over a Mikhail Gorbachev beset by internal conflict. But in a sense it will be as much of a test for Mr. Bush. It will show whether he can develop a long-term view of policy for a crucial part of the world - and explain his vision to the American people.

title: Little Icons of Texas' Past Are Auctioned Off
description: An auctioneer spent the weekend selling off half of this town. The residents are delighted.

title: Triumph's Challenge
description: This capital is still picking at the frayed edges of the vast, historical meaning of the collapse of the Communist vision. But so is Mikhail Gorbachev, who arrives tomorrow to seek assurance that America is willing to accept a transformation of the world that leaves room and hope for his country.

title: Shows in St. Mark's Park
description: A performance by the Harbor Brass Quintet will open a series of shows in St. Mark's Park, 10th Street and Second Avenue. A variety of entertainers will be featured during the free outdoor series, which will run on Thursdays at 12:30 P.M. from June 14 to July 26. The shows, sponsored by the Third Street Music School Settlement and local block associations, will go on rain or shine.

title: Rudolf Firkusny Once Again Plays In Czechoslovakia
description: The pianist Rudolf Firkusny, who last played publicly in his native Czechoslovakia 44 years ago, returned to Prague's principal concert hall tonight to a joyous reception.

title: INSIDE
description: Walesa Wins Halt to Strike

title: Gorbachev Is 'Pretty Darn Strong,' Bush Declares
description: President Bush gave President Mikhail S. Gorbachev another vote of confidence today, disagreeing with those who think that the Soviet leader's position is growing more tenuous.

title: Chronicle
description: When the American Civil Liberties Union supported the right of American Nazis to march through Skokie, Ill., a largely Jewish suburb of Chicago, in 1977, 10,000 members of the A.C.L.U. were so angered that they resigned from the group.

title: 'The Innocent'
description: In Ian McEwan's grisly fictional world, civilization is collapsing and innocence has become a hazardous state of mind, closely akin to amorality on one hand, stupidity on the other. In his first novel, ''The Cement Garden'' (1978), a group of heartless children bury their mother in the basement and cover her over with cement. In ''The Comfort of Strangers'' (1981), a pair of naive tourists get lost in Venice and allow themselves to be victimized by a menacing stranger.

title: Sheets Catch Fire in Surgery, Killing Patient in Los Angeles
description: Sheets covering a patient caught fire during surgery today, filling an operating room with smoke so thick that staff members could not extinguish the flames. The patient died.

title: Mine Wounds 10 G.I.'s
description: A mine exploded during a United States Army training exercise today, and 10 American soldiers were wounded, two seriously, a military spokesman said. Lieut. Col. Jim Gleisberg, spokesman for the VII Corps, said the accident occurred at the rural Wildflecken training area, 55 miles east of Frankfurt.

title: California Redistricting Battle Is Casting Shadows Across the U.S.
description: While the voters and news organizations focus on the heated race for the Democratic nomination for governor of California, political professionals from the White House to Los Angeles are riveted on how Californians will vote on two ballot measures that could eventually help to alter the balance of power in Congress.

title: Two Sisters Die in Home In L.I. Blaze
description: Two young sisters were killed and their grandmother was critically injured before dawn today when their house was swept by a fire that the authorities believe was deliberately set.

title: The Evidence Mounts On Passive Smoking
description: AFTER years of questioning the potential health hazards of secondhand cigarette smoke, a growing number of scientists and health officials are becoming persuaded that the dangers are real, broader than once believed and parallel those of direct smoke.

title: A Specter Is Haunting Europe: Its Past
description: LEAD: Now that the euphoria of liberation in the East has ebbed, what kind of Europe do we have in store? Is apprehension slowly mixing with pride and joy?

title: The Biggest Scandal Ever
description: No less an authority than the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, says the eventual cost of the savings and loan bailout could exceed a half- trillion dollars. A half-trillion. And Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady admits that taxpayers will bear most of that burden.

title: High Price for Energy Freedom
description: For the nations of Eastern Europe, freedom may be far dirtier than they expected.

title: Lag in Official Burmese Vote Tally Worries Some Diplomats
description: As results continued to trickle in today from the first multiparty elections in 30 years in Myanmar, formerly Burma, Western diplomats said the main opposition party had already won at least 66 percent of the seats in a new National Assembly.

title: Marguerite Church, Ex-Congresswoman, Dies at the Age of 97
description: Marguerite Stitt Church, an Illinois Republican who was a member of the House of Representatives from 1950 to 1962, died in her sleep on Saturday at her home in Evanston, Ill. She was 97 years old.

title: Toward the Summit;   How the Poll Was Taken
description: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted from May 22 to 24 with a total of 1,140 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: The Pop Life
description: Back With an Album

title: Bradley, Though Popular, Chases Re-election on Tiptoe
description: After two terms in the United States Senate and years of speculation about running for President sometime, Bill Bradley has gained extraordinary popularity in New Jersey, politicians of both parties say. But as he runs for re-election, he is showing a distinct strain of caution.

title: Ryan Not Ready Yet
description: The eagerly awaited return of Nolan Ryan to the pitching mound for the struggling Texas Rangers will be delayed an additional six days, team officials said yesterday.

title: Evolution in Europe;   A NEW BANK PLANS EAST EUROPEAN AID
description: After months of fighting over where the bank should be situated, who should head it and which countries should be able to receive loans from it, representatives of 40 nations signed a treaty today to establish the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, a $12 billion institution that will provide aid to help revive Eastern Europe's economy.

title: Poindexter Is Denied a New Trial
description: The judge in the Iran-contra case of John M. Poindexter today denied a request for a new trial for the former national security adviser, who was convicted of five criminal charges last month for his role in the affair.

title: New Center to Study Gifted
description: A new National Research Center on the Gifted and Talented, to be based at the University of Connecticut and operated by a group of four universities, will be established with a $7.5 million grant awarded this month by the Federal Department of Education.

title: Wine Talk
description: ''SOME wine labels say that the wine contains sulfites; some don't. How do I find wine without sulfites?''

title: Food Notes
description: Class at the Waldorf

title: CHRONICLE
description: ELLA FITZGERALD was named a Commander of Arts and Letters in Paris yesterday, France's top award for excellence in the arts. The bronze medal on a green-and-white striped ribbon was presented by the Culture Minister, JACK LANG. Miss Fitzgerald, 72 years old, is in Paris to give a concert this evening. The jazz and blues singer has long enjoyed immense popularity in France, which boasts countless jazz buffs, jazz radio programs and many small jazz clubs.

title: Oilers' Rozier Arrested In Weapon Incident
description: After an off-duty police officer reported seeing a shot fired from a truck on Interstate 45 in which one of two passengers was Mike Rozier, the Houston Oilers' running back, Rozier and a friend were arrested early yesterday in Dickinson, Tex. Phil Tracy, the police officer who reported seeing the shot as the truck passed him at 12:30 A.M., pursued and stopped the vehicle.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Justice HAROLD BAER JR. of the New York State Supreme Court was sworn in by his father in December 1982. As a newcomer, he was assigned to one of the small chambers in the state courthouse on Foley Square in Manhattan, where his father, Justice Harold Baer, had served for 22 years before retiring in 1977.

title: M.A.C. to the City's Rescue
description: The New York State and New York City governments, faced with disappointing tax revenues, have been scavenging everywhere for money with which to plug big holes in their budgets. Some of these forays threaten the state's and city's ability to carry on their work. An offer by the Municipal Assistance Corporation to give New York City $1.5 billion in fiscal 1991 poses no such threat and ought to be accepted in Albany with thanks.

title: Nintendo Account
description: Nintendo of America, the video game company, is ''talking to a number of agencies'' about its advertising account, an advertising executive said yesterday. The incumbent, McCann-Erickson/ New York, is participating in the review, the executive said. The account bills about $15 million. Nintendo officials did not return telephone calls for comment.

title: Airbus Selling Jets To Mexican Airline
description: Compania Mexicana de Aviacion signed a $1.1 billion deal with the European air consortium Airbus Industrie to buy up to 30 passenger jets. The Mexican airline said the deal was part of a plan to almost triple its fleet. Mexicana said it was also considering buying 20 more of the same aircraft, the 130- to 169-seat A320-200, in a separate deal.

title: Memorial for Richard Stein
description: A memorial meeting for Richard G. Stein, a Manhattan architect whose ideas on energy conservation influenced architectural design, is to be held at 12:30 P.M. on Sunday at the United Nations Chapel, First Avenue at 44th Street. The speakers are to include the environmentalist Barry Commoner. Mr. Stein died on April 18 at the age of 73.

title: Review/Theater;   Pat Carroll as Falstaff in 'Merry Wives' at Folger
description: Not even the metamorphosis of Robert Morse into Truman Capote can match that of the comic actress Pat Carroll into Sir John Falstaff for ''The Merry Wives of Windsor.'' When Ms. Carroll makes her first entrance, a nervous silence falls over the audience at the Shakespeare Theater at the Folger here, as hundreds of eyes search for some trace of the woman they've seen in a thousand television reruns. What they find instead is a Falstaff who could have stepped out of a formal painted portrait: a balding, aged knight with scattered tufts of silver hair and whiskers, an enormous belly, pink cheeks and squinting, froggy eyes that peer out through boozy mists. The sight is so eerie you grab onto your seat.

title: Easy Goer a Puzzle
description: Easy Goer came out of his surprising defeat in the Metropolitan Handicap on Monday healthy and uninjured, but his handlers said yesterday they were baffled by the colt's performance.

title: Abram J. Shorin, 91; Baseball Card Creator
description: Abram J. Shorin, one of four brothers who founded the Topps Chewing Gum Company and its ubiquitous line of baseball cards, died of a heart attack on Monday at St. Francis Hospital in Miami Beach, Fla. He was 91 years old and lived in Miami Beach.

title: Digital Introduces Its New Software
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said it would introduce on Wednesday a broad range of electronic data interchange software and its first document management products, which would allow businesses to exchange and update data, text, graphics, and still and moving pictures between computers.

title: Economic Scene;   Deficits Quack, Politicians Duck
description: IT walks like a budget duck, and it quacks like a budget duck. But should next year's outlay of $50 billion to $60 billion for the savings and loan bailout count as part of the Federal budget?

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: CHARLOTTE BRUNDAGE is on a cash machine line at 73d Street and Madison Avenue. The fellow in front of her, she can't help but notice, is pretty snazzy looking. He is on the far side of 40 - though not too far; his tan is golden; his blond hair curls over his shirt collar and, Ms. Brundage muses, it has been bleached by either the Beverly Hills or Mediterranean sun.

title: Radio Stations May Be Sold
description: The Great American Communications Company may sell some but not all of its 18 radio stations, its new president and chief operations officer said at the company's annual meeting last week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We voted so that things would change, but nothing has changed. We had hope. Everyone had hope. But look what has become of it. Every day, our lives get worse.''

title: Review/Ballet;   Fairy Tale Using Dance, Not Mime
description: Two young dancers took on the roles of the little ballerina and soldier this season in ''The Steadfast Tin Soldier,'' a charming duet by George Balanchine. And their performance of the ballet on Sunday afternoon, when it was presented by the New York City Ballet at the New York State Theater, was a treasure that promises to be a highlight of the season.

title: Evolution in Europe;   Poland to Let Soviet Jews Fly to Israel From Warsaw
description: Charter flights carrying 500 Soviet Jews a week to Israel will begin moving through Poland next month, marking a new chapter in the complex relationship between Warsaw and Jerusalem.

title: Corrections
description: Picture captions on Sunday with a fashion article about tights omitted the names of stores where they are available. Hue's leggings are at Barneys New York. Roberto Robledo's tights are at Charivari. The Pucci leggings are at Bergdorf Goodman.

title: Let's Stop Messing With Social Security
description: To the Editor:

title: The Citadel Wins a Place In N.C.A.A. History
description: Brad Stowell and Hank Kraft combined on a four-hitter today as The Citadel earned its first trip to the College World Series, beating the top-seeded Miami Hurricanes, 4-1, in the National Collegiate Athletic Association Atlantic Regional tournament.

title: Shuttle Launching Is Delayed by a Fuel Leak
description: The countdown for the launching of the space shuttle Columbia was abruptly halted this evening when sensors detected abnormally high levels of fuel vapors in the engine compartment of the spaceship, indicating a leak in the propulsion system.

title: Tyco Labs Acquiring Wormald of Australia
description: Tyco Laboratories Inc., a maker of sprinkler systems and other fire protection equipment, said today that it had agreed to acquire all of the operating assets of Wormald International Ltd. of Australia in a cash and stock deal worth more than $600 million.

title: Arts Endowment's Opponents Are Fighting Fire With Fire
description: On a cluttered desk at the office of the Coalition for Traditional Values here, next to a bronze eagle, are photocopies of what the minister who heads the organization calls blasphemous and pornographic images and what some other people call art.

title: Toward the Summit;   Gorbachev's Trip: Today's Schedule
description: 10:15 A.M. - Prime Minister Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada lay a wreath at the War Memorial monument just outside Parliament. Shortly before that, Raisa M. Gorbachev and Mila Mulroney start out on a separate itinerary, visiting the National Museum of Natural Sciences and the Museum of Civilization.

title: INSIDE
description: De Klerk Delays U.S. Visit

title: Movie Theater Sound in the Home
description: Dissatisfied with the way intricate and elaborate sound tracks came across on the antiquated sound systems in most theaters, Lucasfilm Ltd. seven years ago introduced a system that matched the quality heard on the dubbing stage at the studio. Now, with a greater percentage of movie revenues coming from home video than from theaters, the company is about to announce home versions that will vastly improve the sound from the typical videocassette or laser disk.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Shabuoth, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended today and tomorrow.

title: Arab Leaders, Seeking One Voice, Extend Talks
description: Arab leaders seeking a common response to Soviet Jewish migration to Israel and other issues extended a two-day summit meeting here today as Egypt and other nations looked for a consensus of moderation in the face of increasing anti-American sentiment.

title: U.S. Informs Iran on 4 Missing in Lebanon
description: The United States has obtained new information on Iranians who disappeared in Lebanon and turned the details over to Teheran as a good-will gesture, the White House said today.

title: Drug Hope for Cystic Fibrosis
description: A biotechnology company said today that it had developed a drug that helps break up the mucus that clogs the lungs of people with cystic fibrosis.

title: Juan Antonio, 45, International Figure In the Dance World
description: Juan Antonio, a dancer, choreographer and co-founder of the Louis Falco Dance Company, died of AIDS last Thursday at Doctors Hospital in Toronto, where he lived. He was 45 years old.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15

title: Becker and Edberg Are Upset in Opening Round in Paris
description: Boris Becker went out without answering the bang of his opponent's backhand and Stefan Edberg provided little more than a whimper as the top two top-seeded players, neither of them clay-court aficionados, were ambushed today by teen-agers in the opening round of the French Open.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS

title: Ilondola Journal;   Old Rites Bring New Hopes to Zambian Marriages
description: Among the Bemba people, who farm on a high rugged plateau in northern Zambia, sacred clay emblems were traditionally used in initiation ceremonies for women about to be married.

title: L.I. Cabby Stabbed And Hit With an Uzi In a Bronx Robbery
description: A Long Island taxicab driver was stabbed eight times and beaten with an Uzi-style submachine gun Monday during a robbery in the Bronx, the police said yesterday.

title: Guilty Plea for Blazer
description: Cliff Robinson, a 6-foot-10-inch, 225-pound rookie forward with the Portland Trail Blazers, pleaded guilty yesterday to punching a policewoman outside a Portland bar at about 3 A.M. on April 29 and was sentenced to a year of probation and fined $250 for fourth-degree assault, a misdemeanor.

title: Cecil J. Roberts, 76, Alabama Arts Patron
description: Cecil Johnson Roberts, a patron of the arts and a colorful liberal in conservative Alabama, died yesterday at a hospital in Birmingham, Ala., after suffering an embolism. She was 76 years old.

title: Thomson Buying Unit of Bicoastal
description: The state-controlled military electronics company Thomson-CSF said it would buy Link-Miles Ltd. from the Bicoastal Corporation for $100 million. Link-Miles, based in England, operates in the military and commercial simulation sectors. It has annual revenues of about $44.4 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Suffolk Bill Requires Newspapers To Use Recycled Paper by 1996
description: The Suffolk County Legislature approved a bill today that would require all newspapers with circulations of more than 20,000 in the county to print on recycled paper by the end of 1996.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: CALF'S liver, which is one of my favorite, budget-priced meats, turns up in countless fine preparations in cuisines of the world. Among the classic French recipes are calf's liver Lyonnaise, which involves sauteeing slices of liver with onions, or a l'Anglaise, made by combining it with onions, bacon and lemon juice.

title: U.S. Securities Advance in Price
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in light trading yesterday, as a rebound in the dollar against the Japanese yen and a drop in commodity prices gave investors reasons to buy notes and bonds.

title: Review/Reggae;   Sugar Minott's Fusion of Past and Present
description: Sugar Minott's show at S.O.B.'s on Thursday night took a couple of hours to settle down. And even when it did, not much happened. Mr. Minott, who is one of reggae's better singers, works in a slightly dated style; the thrill that comes from a new and vital genre wasn't there. Backed by a decent band made up partly of Brooklynites and partly of Jamaicans, Mr. Minott mostly sang, though he occasionally moved into the part rap, part singing, dance-hall style of reggae that is generating the most hits in the Jamaican market.

title: Berlin Shouldn't Be New German Capital;   The Work of Wannsee
description: To the Editor:

title: The Highly Gifted Child: Hidden and Often Ignored
description: LEAD: Ellie Ferguson said her first word (''ink'' for ''drink'') when she was 4 months old, and spoke in complete sentences before her first birthday. At 18 months she could recognize the letters of the alphabet and knew the sounds they stood for. By the time she entered kindergarten, Ellie was reading books like ''Little House on the

title: China Gets One Loan, but Another Is Put Off
description: The World Bank today approved a $300 million loan to help China combat deforestation but indefinitely postponed a second loan of $150 million for roads and waterways that had been opposed by the Bush Administration.

title: North Pacific Poaching Arrests Have Tokyo Squirming
description: The seizure of a fleet of North Korean fishing boats by the Soviet Union in the Pacific Ocean last week has turned into a major diplomatic embarrassment for Tokyo, with the discovery that the fleet and more than 140 fishermen now in Soviet custody are actually Japanese.

title: C.D. Yields Are Off in Week; Money Accounts Are Stable
description: Yields on certificates of deposit were lower for the week that ended yesterday, while money market accounts were mostly unchanged.

title: Decency Standards Needed for Holding Pens
description: To the Editor:

title: Pleas by Insurance Officials
description: Five of the six family members controlling the Champion Insurance Company have pleaded guilty to mail fraud charges in a plea bargain with the Federal Government.

title: To Combat the Growing Iraqi Threat . . .
description: LEAD: The Arab summit conference, which ends today in Baghdad, underlines Iraq's new centrality in Arab politics and the turn for the worse in Arab-Israeli relations. It also has provided Iraq's ruler, Saddam Hussein, with an opportunity to reiterate on center stage the main elements of a new Iraqi and Arab national security doctrine concerning

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption yesterday about the Memorial Day parade in New York misidentified the marchers. They were Chinese-American veterans from the American Legion's Kim Lau Post, not Korean-Americans. Another Memorial Day caption, about women performing folk dances, misidentifed the monument in the picture. It was the World War II memorial in Battery Park, not the Vietnam memorial.

title: DHL Air Unit Stake Acquired
description: DHL International Ltd. said today that Japan Air Lines, Lufthansa and the Japanese trading company Nissho Iwai would acquire a minority stake in the air express service company.

title: Hussein Onn, 68, Leader of Malaysia From 1976-81, Dies
description: Hussein Onn, Prime Minister of Malaysia from 1976 to 1981, died at a California hospital after a second heart attack in six weeks. He was 68 years old.

title: Abrams Running for 4th Term
description: Robert Abrams announced today that he would seek a fourth four-year term as state attorney general.

title: Supreme Court Roundup;   Abandoning 1932 Test, Justices Expand Protection Against Double Jeopardy
description: Giving an expansive interpretation to the Constitution's protection against double jeopardy, the Supreme Court today barred officials from prosecuting a man for homicide after he had pleaded guilty to drunken driving in the accident that caused the death.

title: American Goalies Wait For the Decisive Word
description: With the United States' opening game of the World Cup finals in Italy just 12 days away, the team's three goalkeepers are still uncertain which of them will be named the starter.

title: Henry A. Keller, Manufacturer, 70
description: Henry A. Keller, who helped pioneer the use of prefabricated aluminum products in the home-building industry, died at his home on Sunday after a long illness. He was 70 years old.

title: Perrier to Sell Non-Cola Units
description: Cadbury Schweppes P.L.C., the British soft-drink and candy maker, agreed today to buy most of the non-cola soft drinks business of Source Perrier of France for $211 million.

title: Don't Mention It
description: The racial diversity of Americans creates a lot of funny language problems, but you can't laugh about them, of course, because it's dangerous these days to laugh about anything that touches on our racial diversity. When the subject is race and somebody laughs, that somebody is inviting denunciation for ''insensitivity.''

title: Liberia's Leader Finds Himself With Few Allies
description: The small circle of confidants with whom President Samuel K. Doe has surrounded himself was notably smaller today with many of the palace regulars having left this capital in the face of an approaching insurgency.

title: Sports of The Times;   Mets Now Without a Crutch
description: As the New York Mets failed to play .500 baseball this season, Davey Johnson was again on the bubble as their manager. And now, finally, the bubble has burst. He's out and Bud Harrelson is in.

title: A Tempest in a Portrait: Was That Lady a Lord?
description: For 38 years, an old portrait of a jowly person in women's garb has reposed in the collection of the New-York Historical Society, serene in the decidedly unconventional wisdom about its subject.

title: Protesters in Gabon Battle for an Oil Depot
description: Soldiers and anti-Government demonstrators battled today for control of an oil production center in this West African country, and at least five people were reported wounded, including a soldier.

title: Moscow Hotel Venture Is Set
description: Two American companies announced today that they would open the first United States-operated hotel and business center in Moscow next December.

title: Manila's Report On Economy
description: The Philippine economy grew in the first three months of 1990 despite power blackouts and the negative effects of a failed coup in December, the Finance Secretary, Jesus Estanislao, said today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ANNE BOGART has resigned after less than a year as artistic director of the Trinity Repertory Company in Providence, R.I. The resignation was announced by JOHN HOWLAND, chairman of the board.

title: Jovanovich Resigns Harcourt Post
description: William I. Jovanovich, who slowly built Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. into one of America's great publishing houses before abruptly miring it in overwhelming debt, resigned yesterday as chairman.

title: Berlin Shouldn't Be New German Capital
description: To the Editor:

title: Advanced Micro Moves To Fill President's Post
description: Advanced Micro Devices Inc. yesterday named Richard Previte president and chief operating officer, and a member of its board. Mr. Previte, who was executive vice president and chief operating officer, joined Advanced Micro as chief financial officer in September 1969, four months after the company was founded.

title: In Managua, New Rulers and Never-Ending Battles
description: When striking Sandinista workers chained themselves inside state buildings this month and set barricades on fire, forcing the new Government to a halt, Yolanda Navarro Castro came to a bitter conclusion about her country.

title: This Month: Rosalind Creasy, Los Altos, Calif.;   Where a Front Yard Is Part of the Pantry
description: ROSALIND CREASY has made a reputation as a proponent of edible landscaping, using the yard to grow food for the table. Her half-acre in this community near Palo Alto looks like a California epiphany: a gorgeous array of colors, textures and decidedly unorthodox plantings.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Ayer has created a campaign against teen-age alcoholism for the Advertising Council, the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence and the National Citizens Commission on Alcoholism.

title: Justices Order Review In Citibank Liability Suit
description: Six months after accepting an appeal by Citibank in an important international banking dispute, the Supreme Court announced today that it would not decide the case without further review by the lower courts.

title: Dinkins Shifts And Restores Broom Squad
description: Five days after saying that the city could not afford it, Mayor David N. Dinkins moved yesterday to restore money in his proposed budget to maintain the Sanitation Department Clean Team, a group responsible for manually sweeping streets and emptying trash cans.

title: Blazers Grab Lead In Series
description: No matter how grim the situation, the Portland Trail Blazers have kept the poise, maintained the willpower and made the clutch plays to remain unbeaten (9-0) at home during the playoffs.

title: No Time More Exciting to Practice Psychiatry;   Science, Not Turf
description: To the Editor:

title: No Time More Exciting to Practice Psychiatry;   Other Satisfactions
description: To the Editor:

title: Shareholder Sues Adobe Systems
description: A shareholder filed a class-action lawsuit against Adobe Systems Inc. today, contending that the software maker had failed to comply fully with security regulations. Adobe's share price fell $15.25 Friday, to $34.25, after the company said earnings for the present quarter would probably be much lower than previously expected. The stock rose $2.625 today, to $37.875, on the over-the-counter market, where it was the second-most-active issue.

title: Inquiry at Todd Shipyards
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission has begun a formal investigation into at least two contracts obtained by the Todd Shipyards Corporation between June 1985 and August 1987, the company disclosed today.

title: One Attacker Tied to 7 Rapes in Rockaways
description: At least seven girls and women have been raped in and near Far Rockaway, Queens, since Jan. 31, and the police said yesterday that they believed one man was responsible for the attacks.

title: Toward the Summit;   Problems Back in Moscow Greet Gorbachev in Canada
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in Canada today, but it was the problems he left behind in Moscow, not those he came to discuss in summit meetings here and in Washington, that confronted him almost as soon as he set foot on Canadian soil.

title: New Safety Questions Raised on A-Waste Site
description: A technical expert with the Environmental Protection Agency has raised new questions about the safety of the Waste Isolation Pilot Plant in New Mexico, which is planned as the nation's first permanent nuclear waste repository.

title: Toward the Summit;   U.S. Aides See Shackles On Their Soviet Guest
description: The Bush Administration believes that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's domestic problems will not prevent him from completing pending arms control treaties, but it is increasingly concerned that they might become an obstacle on broader issues like the future of Germany, Administration officials said today.

title: A Crowd Pleaser, Harrelson Has a Bit of Fire
description: If his style as a player is any measure of the man as a manager, don't be surprised if the sluggish and somewhat dispirited 1990 Mets suddenly break out in hustle and elan.

title: No Time More Exciting to Practice Psychiatry
description: To the Editor:

title: Teleport Partners Sought
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it was looking for new partners in Teleport Communications Group, which operates municipal fiber-optic telephone networks for corporate customers.

title: Southwestern Bell
description: New Zealand's Commerce Commission gave the Southwestern Bell Corporation clearance to bid for the state-owned Telecom Corporation. Bids close next Wednesday. The Government hopes to raise at least $1.7 billion (American) in what will be the biggest sale ever under New Zealand's privatization program. The St. Louis-based Southwestern Bell said it planned to team with OTC, Australia's state-owned international telecommunications company, on a posssible bid for Telecom. The result of the bidding is expected by July.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: FOR decades, Chicago's Northwest Side has included an enclave of German immigrants, so it is no surprise on just about any weekday afternoon to hear German spoken at the Lutz Continental Cafe and Pastry Shop.

title: Infused Vinegars: Depth and Punch Without Fat and Sugar
description: LEAD: VINEGAR has long been a bridesmaid in the American kitchen, never a bride. Cooks have counted on vinegar as a counterpoint in rich sauces, to add zest to marinades and, of course, to make pickles. Even in the classic vinaigrette, oil dominates vinegar by a two-thirds majority. But a vinegar revolution is brewing.

title: Victor Wolfson Dead; Wrote Broadway Plays
description: Victor Wolfson, a dramatist, died in a fire at his home in Wellfleet, Mass., last Wednesday. A spokesman for the family said he was either 81 or 82 years old.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Acton Corp, Raleigh, N.C., an insurance and real estate concern, agreed to purchase the furniture operations of Hickory Furniture Co., High Point, N.C., for $44.5 million. The operations will continue under the name of Hickory White.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * CS First Boston Inc., New York, the investment banking firm, named Anthony P. Grassi chief financial and administrative officer. Robert M. Raziano was also named head of finance, administration, systems and operations at First Boston Corp., its American operating unit.

title: Bok to Step Aside at Harvard, Ending 20 Years as President
description: Derek C. Bok announced today that he would step down next spring as president of Harvard University, ending his 20-year tenure in perhaps the most prestigious post in American higher education.

title: KEY RATES
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the Arab meeting in Baghdad misstated the starting date of the Palestinian uprising in the Israeli-occupied territories. It was December 1987, not 1988.

title: Book Notes
description: In Defense of 'Garbo'

title: The U.N Today
description: General Assembly

title: Evolution in Europe;   Soviet Stage: Is 2 a Crowd?
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev may not yet face a full-fledged political opposition in this deeply troubled land, but he now certainly has a personal nemesis to haunt his days of power.

title: Breaking the Packaged Goods Mold
description: LEVINE, HUNTLEY, SCHMIDT & BEAVER is out to test one of advertising's hoariest theories: that an agency cannot handle packaged-goods accounts and remain creative.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Fiat Expands Dealings With Soviets and Poles
description: The Fiat Group, racing ahead of its competitors to set up shop in Eastern Europe, has agreed to work with the Soviet Union to produce 900,000 cars a year there and with Polish auto makers to assemble 270,000 cars a year.

title: Inquiry Ordered In Man's Arrest In Jersey City
description: A grand jury investigation was ordered today into an arrest here on Monday that prompted about 100 protesters to hurl rocks and bottles at police officers outside the West District police station.

title: When Johnson's mets Started to Stumble, An Alliance With Cashen Turned to Conflict
description: In six seasons as the most successful manager of his time, Davey Johnson gave the Mets the most precious of resources in the marketplace, the same thing that Gil Hodges gave them a generation earlier: credibility.

title: Paul Nichols, 50, Dies; Was Baptist Executive
description: The Rev. Paul Nichols, a Baptist minister who was executive director of the Board of National Ministries of the American Baptist Churches, died of a cerebral hemorrhage on Sunday at Mary Washington Hospital in Fredericksburg, Va. He was 50 years old and lived in Richmond and King of Prussia, Pa.

title: Toward the Summit;   Arms and Armies: Pacts and Sticking Points
description: STRATEGIC ARMS REDUCTION TREATY - This treaty would make overall cuts of about 30 percent in the number of Soviet and American long-range nuclear arms. The agreement would lead to greater cuts in the number of warheads on Soviet ballistic missiles, deemed the most threatening by the United States because of their short flight time and accuracy. The treaty would halve the number of warheads on Soviet land-and sea-based ballistic missiles, and would also halve the Soviet force of 308 SS-18 missiles.

title: Louvre Curator Cleared In Stolen-Painting Case
description: A French judge has dismissed an indictment for receiving a stolen painting that had been brought against the Louvre's chief curator of paintings in a case in which a personal nurse has been accused of swindling an aging heiress.

title: Topics of The Times;   Naked Cheating in the House
description: The Postal Service now estimates that this election year, the House will spend a record $79 million on free mailings to constituents. That's $40 million more than it has just budgeted. And if that's not bad enough, consider the way the House now responds to this embarrassment.

title: Evolution in Europe;   ARMENIANS MOURN STRIFE CASUALTIES
description: Armenians flew their republic's flag and wore black ribbons today to mourn 24 people killed in clashes between Soviet troops and militants, a local journalist said.

title: Books of The Times;   Many Faces of Love, Most of Them Unhappy
description: Lantern Slides

title: Terriers Name Coach
description: Boston University announced yesterday that Bob Brown, an alumnus whose coaching career spans 30 years, had been named head basketball coach.

title: Worry Over Soviets Declines
description: Americans no longer worry about a Soviet military threat very much, according to a New York Times/CBS News Poll. Less than 20 percent expect a nuclear war. Page A12.

title: At Many Weddings, Charity Is a Guest
description: LEAD: IN most ways, the wedding of Barbara Schwartz and Abraham Gutman on Sunday in Manhattan will be a traditional affair, complete with a white silk gown, a multi-tiered cake and lots of champagne in an elegant hotel. But after the fanfare is over, the couple plan to share their happiness with those less fortunate.

title: In Health Care, U.S. Is Best
description: LEAD: Critics such as Lee Iacocca and Joseph Califano blame the high cost of medical care in the U.S. on avaricious physicians, unnecessary testing and treatment and the waste and inefficiencies of poorly run hospitals. But these critics are wrong. And recent reforms, driven by such misguided assumptions, have failed.

title: PRETORIA'S LEADER PUTS OFF U.S. TRIP
description: President F. W. de Klerk today postponed his trip to the United States next month after complaints from American critics that he was being received by President Bush before Nelson Mandela.

title: Educators Advocate Steps To Lure Minority Teachers
description: The nation's elementary and secondary schoolteachers could be virtually all-white by the end of this decade if measures to push recruitment of minorities are not taken, a group of top educators has warned.

title:
Real Estate;

A Big Project In Rundown Linden Area
description: LEAD: FOR more than half a century a group of rundown warehouses has lined a 70-acre tract in the southeastern section of Linden, an old industrial city within a 20-minute drive of Manhattan. Now Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus plans to transform the site fronting the combined Routes 1 and 9, surrounded by oil refineries and manufacturing plants, into a new neighborhood with up to 1.1 million square feet of retail, commercial and light industrial space.

title: Dow Up By 49.57 To a High
description: Taking most traders by surprise, both the Dow Jones industrial average and the broader Standard & Poor's 500 stock index rebounded sharply yesterday to set new highs.

title: Remembering Tennessee Williams As a Gentle Genius of Empathy
description: She was a young actress, the daughter of a White Russian family that had fled to London after the Bolshevik revolution. As a child in the 1930's, she had been a dancer with the Ballet Russe of Monte Carlo, but a foot operation ended her dancing career and she got a scholarship to the Old Vic acting school in London.

title: Jack J. Jorgensen, Union Leader, 75
description: Jack J. Jorgensen, a teamsters union leader who was convicted in 1955 of taking payoffs to help break a strike, died of pancreatic cancer on Sunday at his home. He was 75 years old.

title: Immigrants Strain Chinatown's Resources
description: Jenny Zeng left her home in the southern Chinese city of Guangzhou 18 months ago. She was a teacher in an elementary school there. Now she works in a Chinatown garment factory, stitching together dresses that she later sees for sale along Canal Street.

title: New Shearson Official Expects Brighter Days
description: Jonathan S. Linen, named yesterday, as expected, to oversee Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.'s brokerage and investment management divisions, said he was too new to the job to say how the securities firm might be rejuvenated. But imbued with the optimisim that came with his succcess as a top executive at the American Express Company, Mr. Linen said he was convinced that better days lie ahead for Shearson, the nation's second-largest securities firm in terms of numbers of brokers after Merrill Lynch & Company.

title: New Kind of Mail, New Kind of Mailbox
description: The race is on to develop the complete telecommunications ''mailbox.'' Telephone companies envision a day when customers will receive voice messages, text from computers and facsimile documents in their own private file in a telephone-company computer.

title: Judge Denies Barry 2 Trials on Drug Counts
description: A Federal district judge today refused a request by Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. that he have two separate trials on 14 drug-related charges he faces, and he ordered a single trial to begin June 4.

title: Pistons Grasping for Their Image of Old
description: Somewhere along the way, the Detroit Pistons decided to give up the bad-boy image that helped bring them the championship a year ago.

title: People
description: * Daniel H. Dolgins has been appointed director of strategy and planning at Baron & Zaretsky Advertising.

title: Johnson Dismissed by Mets; Harrelson Named Manager
description: Davey Johnson, who won more games than any other manager in major league baseball over the last six seasons, was dismissed by the New York Mets today and replaced by Bud Harrelson, his third-base coach.

title: Henderson Passes Cobb But A's Can't Pass Jays
description: Rickey Henderson broke Ty Cobb's 62-year-old American League record for stolen bases, but the achievement played no part in the scoring tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Oakland Athletics, 2-1.

title: Leaders Set House Pace for Outside Fees
description: While members of the House of Representatives have voted to stop accepting speaking fees at the start of next year, many lawmakers are traveling around the world this year, collecting the maximum amounts permitted from corporations and other groups that have interests in legislation.

title: CHRONICLE
description: In the four years since his ouster as dictator of Haiti, JEAN-CLAUDE DUVALIER has been living on the French Riviera in a house owned by ADNAN KHASHOGGI, the Saudi Arabian arms merchant. But Mr. Khashoggi, who is on trial in New York with Imelda Marcos over allegations that she stole from the Phillipines treasury, has decided to sell the villa, Mohamedia. And so ''Baby Doc,'' as Mr. Duvalier is known to distinguish him from his father, ''Papa Doc,'' who ruled Haiti for decades, has moved up the coast to another villa in Vallauris, France, with his wife and two children. The new Duvalier home is owned by THEODORE DEMEL, a former French Ambassador to the Ivory Coast.

title: Accounts
description: * Association of Exporters of Spanish Table Olives, Seville, Spain, to Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: TO walk through the door of Nam Kang restaurant is to leave southern California for the bustle of contemporary industrial Seoul. Waitresses in green dresses and white aprons patrol the crowded dining room, clanging dishes and shouting in Korean, as customers order from one of the longest and best menus in Korea Town, the busy Los Angeles

title: Drexel's Brokerage In Chapter 11
description: Taking a step described as the first toward giving the firm a new life, Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. filed for bankruptcy protection yesterday as Frederick H. Joseph stepped down from his post as chief executive.

title: Price-Blind Smoker Loyalty Defies Economics and Critics
description: About two weeks ago, something happened that may subtly undermine the recent efforts of antismoking advocates: the tobacco industry raised cigarette prices and most smokers went along.

title: Dukakis Seeks to Bar State From Investing in Tobacco
description: Gov. Michael S. Dukakis has decided to seek a ban on the investment of public funds in tobacco companies, a move that would make Massachusetts the first state to divest itself of tobacco stocks.

title: Toward the Summit;   American Fear of Soviets Declines, Survey Finds
description: As President Bush prepares for his summit meeting with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union, Americans no longer worry very much about the Soviet Union as a military threat.

title: The Burmese Shout for Democracy
description: With astounding courage, the people of Myanmar have defied a bullying military regime and voted overwhelmingly for a pro-democracy movement whose leaders are in jail or under house arrest. Another wall has fallen, and the Burmese did it on their own.

title: Toward the Summit: Reporter's Notebook;   The Gorbachev Show Must Go On
description: Despite all the down-to-the-second planning of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's supposedly spontaneous walkabout today, the Soviet President briefly confounded the plans of security guards and well-wishers alike. He was 20 minutes late, didn't stop in the designated spot, and then just stayed and stayed.

title: New York State G.O.P. Supports Abortion Rights for First Time
description: The New York Republican Party, for the first time in its history, approved an abortion platform today that supports ''reproductive rights for women.''

title: Oil and Gas Drilling Up
description: The number of United States rigs drilling for oil and gas rose by 29 last week, to a total of 1,001, Baker Hughes Inc. said today. It was the fourth straight weekly increase. A year earlier, the count was 749. The weekly rig count reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and gas, not those producing oil and gas.

title: Europe-Japan Talks Held
description: The European Community and Japan held high-level talks today for the first time in three and a half years to try to clear the air between the two trading giants, European Community officials and diplomats said.

title: Ammirati Buyback
description: Ammirati & Puris said yesterday that it had completed its buyback from the Omnicom Group, which acquired the agency last year when it bought Ammirati's former parent, the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership. Ammirati had sold itself to Boase Massimi Pollitt in 1987.

title: Toward the Summit;   Obstacles Remain on Gas Accord With Soviets
description: After months of intensive negotiation, the United States and the Soviet Union plan to sign a path-breaking agreement this week to slash their arsenals of poison gas.

title: Stirring a Debate on Breaking Racism's Shackles
description: Among those who have read or heard his views on race, it is very hard to find anyone, black or white, with a neutral reaction to Shelby Steele.

title: Stinson Beach Journal;   The Road That Persists In Falling Into the Sea
description: The western edge of the continent has never been an ideal place for a highway, what with the pounding surf eroding the shore from below and the cliffs washing down from above. Repair crews of the state Department of Transportation face a Sisyphean labor keeping California Route 1 open under the best of circumstances.

title: Hunt Brothers to Sell Antiquities
description: Nelson Bunker Hunt and William Herbert Hunt, the former Dallas billionaires, said yesterday that they were selling their wide-ranging collections of Greek and Roman antiquities in court-ordered sales to help pay the Internal Revenue Service and creditors. The collections include ancient Greek vases, Roman bronzes and coins, and have been valued by Sotheby's at more than $20 million.

title: Topics of The Times;   Sins of the Children
description: Secondhand smoke, it becomes increasingly clear, endangers the second generation. But which generation is that? Yes, there's a strong link between smoking by parents and respiratory damage in their children. But in many families, it's now the young people who are most likely to smoke. That could be called visiting the sins of the children upon the fathers and mothers.

title: In Missouri, a Battle Over Burying a Toxic Town
description: More than seven years after it was pronounced dead, a casualty of toxic contamination, Times Beach still haunts the rolling hills southwest of St. Louis. It is a ghost town of empty, tumbledown houses and vacant stores, wildly overgrown with weeds.

title: Market Place;   Bargains Among Apparel Makers?
description: WHEN retailing sneezes, the nation's apparel industry reaches for its cold tablets.

title: Tektronix Cuts Staff by 1,300
description: Tektronix Inc., the largest non-government employer in Oregon, said today that it would cut its work force by about 1,300 employees, to about 13,000, by August.

title: Yankees Drop Fourth Straight
description: As the night unfolded below him, the owner of the Yankees sat and watched from a private box on the third level of Comiskey Park, his attention drawn to another unbearable Yankee loss.

title: Review/Music;   A Farewell From Bach Lives On
description: ''The Art of Fugue'' is Bach at his most abstract and cerebral. A compendium of contrapuntal techniques demonstrated in 20 increasingly complex fugues and canons, the work was conceived more as a valedictory than as a performance piece. Bach did not specify instrumentation, but the work is too glorious to live only on paper.

title: About New York;   A Chess Match, Of Sorts, Using Tokens as Pieces
description: Vincent Paletta spends much of his working day thinking of ways to steal tokens from subway turnstiles. But he is no criminal.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about the growing number of old inmates in prisons referred incompletely in some copies to Dr. Julia G. Hall, who counsels elderly inmates at Graterford Prison in Pennsylvania. She is an associate professor of sociology at Drexel University.

title: Hearings on Neglect Upheld In Newborn Cocaine Cases
description: A New York State appeals court ruled yesterday that the presence of cocaine in a newborn's system, and the mother's admission of drug use, were enough justification for New York City to ask for a Family Court hearing on child neglect.

title: Cost of Color Ads
description: In its first study of print production costs, the American Association of Advertising Agencies found that color ads are about two and a half times as expensive as black-and-white ones. In 1989, the average four-color, one-page magazine ad cost $15,660 to produce; the average black-and-white ad cost $6,224.

title: Flavors That Herald Summer's Sun
description: IT will be almost a month before summer starts to ripen. In most parts of the country, tomatoes are still green and stern, herbs are pale and shy, the corn is low, and the charcoal bag is still at significant risk of being drenched by a late spring rain. But on Memorial Day, summer arrives in spirit, if not in fact. And cooks are in a quandary. What to do when the spirit is willing but the harvest is weak?

title: Stores Acquired By Computerland
description: The Computerland Corporation, a leading personal computer franchise chain based in Pleasanton, Calif., acquired certain assets of the Computer Shoppe Inc., a chain of eight computer stores in the Southeast and Midwest with 1989 sales of about $55 million. The purchase price of the acquisition was not disclosed.

title: A New Kind of Summit
description: President Gorbachev looks to his meeting with President Bush to strengthen his position at home, demonstrating that the United States supports his efforts to promote reform in the Soviet Union and reduce conflicts abroad. Conscientiously, Mr. Bush can cooperate; most of Mr. Gorbachev's goals are America's goals too.

title: New Manager but Old Problems for the Mets
description: The Mets unveiled a new manager here tonight as Bud Harrelson replaced Davey Johnson, and then the team went out on the field and played like nothing had ever changed.

title: Review/Television;   Stones' Tour Revisited
description: Perhaps one or two Rolling Stones fans missed last fall's blitz: the ''Steel Wheels'' album, the sold-out stadium tour and the pay-per-view broadcast on cable television of the tour's last North American stop, in Atlantic City. Now there's another chance: ''Steel Wheels,'' the edited version of the broadcast, to be shown tonight at 8 on the Fox network. For those who have seen it all already, three songs are broadcast with an added feature: a three-dimensional process, using glasses that have been given away at 7-Eleven stores and that have been highly promoted themselves.

title: Eating Well
description: THIS is the Federal Government's version of a riddle: When is fresh not fresh?

title: Man Sentenced for Helping Fugitive in Drug Agent Death
description: A Staten Island man was sentenced yesterday to 33 months in prison and fined $20,000 for harboring a fugitive in the killing of a Federal drug agent on Staten Island in February 1989.

title: Evolution in Europe;   YELTSIN IS ELECTED RUSSIAN PRESIDENT ON 3D-ROUND VOTE
description: Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick politician who has spent three years fighting the Communist Party establishment, today became President of the Russian republic, overcoming a last-ditch effort by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to block his election before departing for visits to Canada and the United States.

title: Pizza Hut Executive Named To Kentucky Fried Team
description: Allan S. Huston, moving from pizza to fried chicken, yesterday was named president of Kentucky Fried Chicken's international unit, where he will be responsible for 3,000 company-owned and franchised restaurants in 57 countries.

title: Joe M. Ingraham Dies; Federal Judge Was 86
description: Joe McDonald Ingraham, a Federal judge for 36 years, died of complications from heart disease on Sunday at Memorial Southwest Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Houston.

title: Graduates At Baruch Hear Pole
description: The economist who is the Minister of the Office of Central Planning in Poland's Solidarity-led Government told more than 2,300 graduating students of Bernard M. Baruch College yesterday that they should ''go beyond symbols and work to integrate the free world - East and West.''

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: LIKE the Central Intelligence Agency, Pat Brink will neither confirm nor deny the existence of certain materials when she is asked certain questions. In the case of Mrs. Brink, the Pat of Pat's Kountry Kitchen here, the closely held secret is the recipe for what she calls her ''signature dish,'' clam hash.

title: 'Simpsons' to Compete With 'Cosby'
description: In a bold move, the expanding Fox network announced yesterday that it was moving its hit show, the animated comedy ''The Simpsons,'' to compete against NBC's top-rated ''Cosby Show.''

title: Bank Trial Starts in Italy
description: The trial of 35 people charged with fraudulent bankruptcy in the 1982 collapse of Banco Ambrosiano, one of Europe's biggest bank failures, began today, but only six of the accused appeared in court.

title: Special Prosecutor Is Urged to Expand Inquiry of Ex-Housing Chief
description: The Justice Department announced today that it had requested a broad expansion of a special prosecutor's investigation of Samuel R. Pierce Jr., the Housing Secretary in the Reagan Administration.

title: Bridge
description: Nearly all the top-ranked players from the New York metropolitan area, together with a few stars from farther afield, are in contention this week in the Reisinger Knockout, perhaps the most prized of all regional team events played anywhere. The defending champions are Henry Bethe, Brian Glubok, Edgar Kaplan, Bill Root, all of Manhattan, Chuck Lamprey of White Plains and Tom Smith of Greenwich, Conn.
