Also in the field is Piotr Gawrys, a Pole who in mid-May won the Cavendish Invitational Pairs, playing with Sam Lev of Israel.

title: For Herring Set, It's New Year's All Over
description: THERE are people who live for the molt of the Chesapeake Bay crab. Others await shad from the Hudson, the June run of bass off Cape Cod, or open season on Nantucket's bay scallops in the fall. And then there are those who live for fresh herring.

title: Court to Rule on Law That Bars Abortion Advice
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal Government can prohibit federally financed family planning programs from giving information or advice about abortion.

title: Must Charities Scorn Small Donations?
description: To the Editor:

title: The President of Harvard
description: Late-summer sun filtered through the elm trees and historical echoes. The bright flags of Harvard's 26 schools and houses fluttered. It was September 1986, the university's 350th anniversary celebration, and it was time for the closing address from the president of Harvard.

title: Midway Air's Gamble on Expansion
description: Long esteemed on Wall Street as a scrappy little airline that thrived in a business dominated by Goliaths, Midway Airlines Inc. now finds itself in a brutal competitive struggle that has dealt the carrier heavy losses. The outcome, industry experts agree, will be decisive: Either Midway will become a larger and more profitable airline or a badly wounded also-ran.

title: BESIEGED AT HOME, GORBACHEV ARRIVES IN U.S. FOR SUMMIT
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union arrived in Washington tonight for his third visit to the United States and his second summit conference with President Bush, as American officials searched for formulas to persuade him to accept Western plans for a unified Germany and a restructured Europe.

title: Teach for America
description: Amid all the gale-force commencement wind, some members of the Class of '90 already know that they can make a living and make a difference. They are among the first volunteers in Teach for America, a program that, starting in September, will inject new teachers and new energy into American schools. The program, a testament to the power of one person's idea, could become a powerful force for education reform.

title: Contras Promise to Give Up Arms As Managua Vows to Yield Land
description: The Nicaraguan rebels agreed today to resume disbanding after the new Government promised to set aside rural areas where they can live, police themselves and join town councils.

title: Mets' Move Might Wake Them Up
description: rrIn this Age of Steinbrenner, sacking the manager is so often a frivolous or cruel maneuver that it is refreshing to see a baseball club slow to push the button.

title: Twins Re-sign Aguilera
description: Rick Aguilera, a Minnesota Twins pitcher, has signed a three-year, $6 million contract extension, which will make him the third-highest-paid player on the team next season.

title: Chicago Journal;   In Which a Tradition Faces Eviction
description: Frank Lloyd Wright was a charter member of the Cliff Dwellers Club, overlooking Lake Michigan's long horizon. George Ade, the humorist, was a patron and member too, and so were the poets Carl Sandburg and James Whitcomb Riley.

title: Waterford Talks Seek End to Strike
description: Striking workers at Waterford Wedgewood P.L.C., Ireland's prestigious glass maker, voted to resume talks with the management after almost eight weeks off the job. The 2,300 workers at Waterford's three plants began the company's first all-out strike on April 5 over cost cuts.

title: High-Rise Neon in Hong Kong
description: HONG KONG glows with neon signs that dangle in front of stores and perch on top of roofs, advertising restaurants, hotels and tailors.

title: 14-Year-Old Held in Killing
description: An 18-year-old man was shot in the head and killed yesterday morning at 152-51 Jewel Avenue in Hillcrest, Queens, the police said. The victim was not identified, but the police arrested a 14-year-old, Henry Moy, of 51-24 97th Street in Elmhurst, Queens, and charged him with second-degree murder and criminal possession of a weapon. Mr. Moy knew the victim, but no motive for the killing was determined, said Sgt. Steven Marks, the commander of the 107th Precinct detective squad.

title: Gavitt New Celtics Chief
description: Dave Gavitt, architect of the Big East Conference and the leader of amateur basketball in the United States, was named today as the director of basketball operations for the Boston Celtics.

title: P.L.O. Link to Speedboat Raid Leaves U.S. in a Tight Corner
description: Bush Administration officials said today that the speedboat attack for which a Palestine Liberation Organization group has taken responsibility could leave the Administration with no choice but to sever its 18-month-old discussion with Yasir Arafat's organization.

title: Surprising Javelin Champ Savors Unexpected Record
description: Patrik Boden is a 22-year-old Texas sophomore from Sweden trying to survive a season of highs and lows.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Shabuoth, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended today.

title: Ravitch to Begin Career As Investment Banker
description: Richard Ravitch, who has run through several New York careers in public service, banking, construction, real estate and politics, is beginning a new one - Wall Street investment banker.

title: Honda Increasing Ohio Operations
description: The Honda Motor Company said it would nearly double the size of its research and development operations in Marysville, Ohio. The Japanese auto maker said the expansion would provide additional capacity to design and develop new vehicles for the North American market.

title: Colombia Votes for Courage
description: Cesar Gaviria Trujillo's victory in Colombia's presidential election sends a brave message to the drug cartels, and to Washington.

title: Soviet Leader's News Conference in Ottawa and His Arrival in Washington
description: Following are excerpts from a news conference by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union and Prime Minister Brian Mulroney of Canada in Ottawa yesterday, and a transcript of statements by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Mr. Gorbachev after the Soviet President's arrival in Washington. All the remarks were recorded through the facilities of the Cable News Network. Mr. Gorbachev spoke through a translator.

title: Prisoners Find Poor Medical Care the Norm
description: To the Editor:

title: John Jay College Moves to Evict Protesters
description: After three weeks of negotiations, the John Jay College of Criminal Justice has decided to file disciplinary charges and seek a court order against students who have occupied a campus building since early this month.

title: Trade Talks Stalemated After U.S.-Europe Clash
description: After a heated clash, the United States and the European Community remained deadlocked today in talks to reduce subsidies in farm trade, raising fears that the stalemate would endanger the success of the current four-year round of world trade talks.

title: Arthur Woodley, 84, An Aviation Executive
description: Arthur Woodley, an aviation pioneer who brought air shuttle service to Alaska when dog teams were used to transport supplies there, died on Monday at his home here. He was 84 years old.

title: Corrections
description: The list of credits with a television review on Friday about ''Twin Peaks'' reversed two names. Ed Hurley is the character played by Everett McGill.

title: Klan Figure's Bill Approved by Louisiana House
description: The Louisiana House of Representatives has passed a bill sponsored by David Duke, a former Ku Klux Klan leader, to weaken affirmative-action efforts.

title: Dimitri de Grunwald; Film Producer, 76
description: Dimitri de Grunwald, the producer of ''The Millionairess,'' a 1960 film starring Peter Sellers and Sophia Loren, died Saturday at his home. He was 76 years old.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: N.J. Transit to Raise Bus and Train Fares 9%
description: For the third year in a row and the fourth time in five years, N.J. Transit is raising bus and train fares, this time an average of 9 percent.

title: A World of Differences On a Unified Continent
description: Despite the similarities among Europeans that marketers are now trying to exploit, cultural differences must still be taken into consideration.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Bridge
description: Though no relation to the long-retired Charles Goren, Joel Goren of Manhattan, returned the name to prominence this weekend by helping defeat the top-seeded squad in the Reisinger Knockout Team Championship.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   JanklowBender Gets 3 New Accounts
description: The Walt Disney Company has assigned the advertising account for Jim Henson's Muppet characters to JanklowBender Inc. The agency already handles the licensed merchandise of other Disney characters, as well as Disney's computer software division. The Muppets account will bill about $1 million.

title: Colombia Rebels Shun Arms and Win Votes
description: A surprise winner in Colombia's elections on Sunday was a guerrilla group that only two months ago traded in its guns for the ballot box.

title: Home Sales Down 1.6%; Lowest Level Since '82
description: Sales of new single-family homes fell for the fifth straight month in April to their lowest level in more than seven years, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Jeans Makers Settle 7-Year Fraud Case
description: A seven-year legal battle between two highly successful jeans companies, Guess and Jordache, and the families that run them ended today when the sides reached an out-of-court settlement returning all of Guess to its founders.

title: YELTSIN TAKES AIM AT CENTRAL RULE
description: In his first day as President of the Russian republic, Boris N. Yeltsin put the Kremlin on notice today with an aggressive program to free Russia from ''the dictates of the center.''

title: Trenton Assails Florio Proposal For School Aid
description: Gov. Jim Florio's plan for a major redistribution of state spending for New Jersey's public schools drew sharp opposition today from a key State Senator and statewide representatives of local school boards and teachers.

title: KEY RATES
Man in the News;   Blunt G.O.P. Nominee for Governor: Pierre Andre Rinfret
description: Pierre A. Rinfret, the New York City economist who received the Republican nomination for governor today, is so politically anonymous that his name has been spelled phonetically (Rin-FRAY) in party news releases.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: MARTIN FORD was fooled by his 4-year-old son. Every day Dr. Ford or his wife would methodically dress their child, guiding his small arms through shirtsleeves, snapping the snaps and buttoning the buttons. One day he walked into his son's room to discover that the boy had put on all his clothes by himself.

title: Arraignment Is Delayed for 2 in Explosion
description: Prosecutors have postponed the arraignment of two leaders of the radical environmental group Earth First who were arrested Friday after they were injured in the explosion of a pipe bomb.

title: Talking Deals;   Why B.A.T. Units' Managers Lost
description: BEYOND the flush of elation shown by victors in takeover auctions are other investors whose entrepreneurial ambitions were doomed because of tenuous financial backing. Lately, company managements attempting leveraged buyouts seem especially prone to this fate.

title: Review/Music;   Combining Jazz With the Classical Tradition
description: American composers continue to scratch their heads and ponder the ways they might adapt their country's powerful popular culture to the classical traditions imported from Europe and replanted here. Paul Knopf, a jazz pianist with considerable conservatory training, has been at it since 1944, and on Sunday night, he and a collection of colleagues presented a survey of his work at St. Peter's Church.

title: Seabrook Nuclear Generator Supplies Power to Customers
description: Four years after it was completed and 14 years after construction began, the Seabrook nuclear power plant has supplied electricity to customers for the first time.

title: Energy of Rebirth In Hamilton Heights
description: ON Sunday, the third annual Hamilton Heights House Tour once again will offer an unexpected and invigorating glimpse into the lives of some of New York's most energetic homemakers.

title: Nordiques' New Coach
description: Michel Bergeron, who coached the Quebec Nordiques to the National Hockey League's worst record last season, will be replaced by Dave Chambers, the former Minnesota North Stars assistant coach, radio station CJRP of Quebec reported yesterday.(AP)

title: Favorite Stocks chart;   Stocks Edge Ahead as Dow Rises by 8.07
description: Stock prices edged slightly higher yesterday amid active program trading. Both the Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index eked out new highs with strong leadership from I.B.M., Procter & Gamble and Walt Disney.

title: Icelandic Island Is Youngest Spot on Earth
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Selects Last Six for Planning Commission
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins has chosen his remaining six appointees to the City Planning Commission, rounding out the new 13-member panel that will review major public and private building projects beginning on July 1.

title: U.S. Has Sluggish Victory Over Little Liechtenstein
description: It is hard to imagine a more quaint setting for an international soccer match. The Sportpark lies nestled alongside the Central Alps and not far from the Rhine and has a seating capacity for no more than 200, Others must stand around a waist-high railing that rings the field.

title: Liberian Soldiers Reportedly Attack U.N. Center
description: Liberian Government soldiers were reported today to have entered a United Nations compound here and abducted about 40 refugees who had taken shelter there in the face of a continuing advance by rebels toward this nervous capital.

title: The Cruel Delusion
description: And now the great delusion is being played out here, the Soviet and American actors walking about and reciting their lines, hoping that the world believes the play is reality.

title: 30 Years for Drug Trafficking
description: A Federal district judge has sentenced a man reputed to be a high-ranking member of a Colombian drug ring to 30 years in prison and fined him $5 million. The man, Jose Rafael Abello Silva. was convicted May 19 on one count of conspiracy to import cocaine and marijuana into the United States and one count of conspiracy to possess drugs with the intent to distribute. In passing sentence Tuesday, Judge Thomas Brett said the treaty under which the defendant was extradited from Colombia last fall provided a maximum sentence of 30 years.

title: Selling in Europe: Borders Fade
description: The single market of 325 million consumers that the 12 nations of the European Community are trying to create is at least two and a half years away, but consumer-products companies are acting as if it were already here.

title: SmithKline Is Selling 2 Units to Germans
description: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the giant pharmaceutical company, said today that it would sell two of its cosmetics businesses to a West German company for $358 million.

title: What a Team! K.G.B. Plus U.S. Skill
description: When the Soviet advance team was here a couple of weeks ago, scarfing down dozens of hot dogs and savoring fifths of Jack Daniels at a Washington Capitals hockey game, it all looked so easy.

title: Treasury Securities Inch Higher
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in slow trading yesterday, as dealers began to position themselves for tomorrow's release of May employment data.

title: INSIDE
description: Quakes on Two Continents

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-17

title: Wolcott Andrews, 87, A Landscape Architect
description: Wolcott Andrews, a retired New York City landscape architect, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at Miles Memorial Hospital in Damariscotta, Me. He was 87 years old and lived in Wiscasset, Me.

title: Disney's Shares Jump by $6
description: The stock of the Walt Disney Company jumped today as investors apparently realized that the company's tremendous growth prospects were not diminished by concerns about its theme parks and movie businesses, analysts said.

title: June Arriving With House Tours Galore
description: In June, house tour devotees have a choice of visiting historic house museums scattered in the city's five boroughs, Victorian brownstones in Brooklyn, a mansion in Yonkers and 19th-century houses in Roslyn, L.I. There are also a garden tour and a show house in Connecticut.

title: A Handbag And a Cap To Tickle Your Toes
description: TO Kim Baker, a 22-year-old artist, black rubber ''welcome'' mats and synthetic turf don't necessarily belong underfoot.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: LOW-VOLTAGE outdoor lighting is an easy, safe, efficient and inexpensive way to light a yard or terrace - not brilliantly, but enough for nighttime entertaining or extra security. No knowledge of electricity is needed, and kits with all the necessary components and instructions are available at hardware stores, home and garden centers and discount department stores.

title: Publisher Receives Eastman Music Medal
description: Gilbert Kaplan, a publisher and conductor, is the recipient of the first George Eastman Medal, given by the Eastman School of Music at the University of Rochester for contributions to music. The medal, named for the founder of the Eastman Kodak Company and the music school, was given to Mr. Kaplan at a graduation ceremony on Sunday at the school.

title: Defense Lawyer Battles Judge at Marcos Trial
description: For two months, they have glared at each other and occasionally bickered, the famous defense lawyer and the judge at Imelda Marcos's trial, on the edge of an all-out confrontation.

title: White's Advice Is Proving Expensive
description: Several years ago, when Dennis Rasmussen pitched for the Yankees, he received some advice from Bill White, one of the team's broadcasters.

title: Ranger Aide Out
description: Gord Stellick, the assistant general manager of the Rangers last year, will not return next season, according to several people in the organization.

title: Screens That Don't Fill The Obvious Function
description: Not all screens are designed to conceal people or objects. Neither are all boxes rectangular. In ''Screens and Boxes'' at the Gallery of Functional Art in Santa Monica, Calif., 32 artists have designed screens that are three-dimensional airy abstract sculpture, painted solid panels of wood or steel with translucent panes of glass, and boxes shaped like classical columns.

title: Metro Matters;   Missing Parolee Seems Shunted To Least Wanted
description: Dwayne Gosso, call your parole officer.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: ON a day, one of many recently, on which New York was supposed to have blown up and gone to hell, I sauntered forth for the first street fair of the season. At least it was the first street fair of the season in my neighborhood: I am pretty parochial about these events.

title: Building Codes Compliance System in New York City Works
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, appointed Zoe Baird vice president and general counsel. She replaces Stephen B. Middlebrook, who was named senior vice president and executive counsel to the office of the chairman.

title: You Can Make A-Bombs Even Without Uranium
description: To the Editor:

title: Fonteyn Is Honored By the Royal Ballet
description: Like Juliet playing the balcony scene yet again, Dame Margot Fonteyn sat in the royal box of the Royal Opera House in Covent Garden tonight as the tenor Placido Domingo, a not unlikely Romeo, opened the Royal Ballet's special tribute to her with a serenade.

title: 115 Die in Earthquake in Northern Peru
description: A strong earthquake killed at least 115 people, injured more than 800 and almost destroyed several towns in Peru's northern jungle, Civil Defense officials said today.

title: Israel Reports Foiling Speedboat Attack on Beach
description: Israeli forces foiled an attack this morning by Palestinian guerrillas in speedboats on the beaches around this city, killing 4 and capturing 12 of the raiders, the Israeli military said. There were no Israeli military or civilian casualties.

title: Prisoners Find Poor Medical Care the Norm;   Community Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Barton L. Weller, 74, Inventor and Executive
description: Barton L. Weller, an inventor and electronics company executive, died on Friday following a fall from a ladder as he inspected a home being built for him and his wife in Cape Breton, Nova Scotia. He was 74 years old and lived in Easton, Conn.

title: Dream Houses With No Lawn to Mow
description: FIFTEEN years ago, when Ned Kellogg was 30 years old and working as a bass soloist, he started selling dollhouse kits, and then making dollhouses, for extra income. Today, he makes more than 3,000 styles, from a pagoda to a 20th-century Queen Anne Tudor.

title: Bally Revamping
description: The Bally Manufacturing Corporation said it was considering several restructuring moves to raise shareholder value. As a first step, Bally offered an exchange of common stock for its 13 5/8 percent subordinated debentures due on Jan. 2, 2001. Shares in Bally, which makes game machines and operates casinos, fell $1.50 today, to $10.625, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its 12.4 percent drop was the day's worst.

title: The Face in the Window Won't Be a Stranger's
description: IN March, Scott and Noreen Sanders discovered two old barns with 100 windows in Long Valley, N.J. The barns were about to be demolished, so the Sanderses took the windows to their Blue Studio in Glen Ridge, N.J., where they began turning them into mirrors ''Just as mirrors open up a room, a window as a mirror also creates that illusion,'' Mr. Sanders said.

title: As Focus on Ethics Sharpened, 19 Senators Spurned Fees in 1989
description: Reflecting the growing sensitivity over ethics and the appearance of impropriety, 19 senators refused to accept speaking fees from outside groups in 1989, seven more than the year before.

title: A Major Operation On a Fetus Works For the First Time
description: In an operation that may open a new era in fetal medicine, doctors have performed lifesaving major surgery on a fetus and delivered a healthy baby seven weeks later.

title: Pinstripes May Suit Johnson's Future
description: On the day after he was dismissed, Davey Johnson said that he expected to return to the big leagues, perhaps even this season, and he did not rule out the possibility that he might surface in New York someday in the pinstripes of the Yankees.

title: Effort to Speed Arraignments
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins announced a series of measures yesterday intended to speed up the arrest-to-arraignment process.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Friday about the Rutgers University commencement misidentified the woman seated next to Gov. Jim Florio. She was Dr. Deborah T. Wolfe, chairwoman of the New Jersey Board of Higher Education, not a Rutgers trustee.

title: Shrubs Chosen by the Experts: More Than a Moment of Glory
description: SOME call them ''garden bones.'' Others prefer the term ''living furniture.'' Whatever their label, shrubs add structure and texture to the landscape. With the hues of forsythia and azalea now a memory, it is time to ponder some less commonly grown species that experts use to expand their own gardens' diversity.

title: Rinfret Picked Amid a Split On Abortion
description: New York State Republicans nominated Pierre A. Rinfret as their gubernatorial candidate today, but the party's disarray continued to spread, this time over abortion.

title: Services Identifying Caller Held Illegal in Pennsylvania
description: A Pennsylvania court ruled yesterday that services that identify the telephone numbers of callers represent an illegal invasion of privacy.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Chronicle
description: ALLEN GINSBERG and MILES DAVIS are among the 22 recipients of the 11th annual American Book Awards, announced yesterday in Miami. The winners are chosen by the Before Columbus Foundation for their ''contributions to literary excellence in America,'' a foundation spokesman said.

title: In the Land of Referenda
description: Should the California mountain lion be protected from hound dogs and hunters? Should the state spend $30 million a year to buy and preserve habitat for lions, deer and other wildlife?

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Amersham International P.L.C., a British health-care and medical research group, said it would pay no more than $45.85 million for Media-Physics Inc., the radio-pharmaceuticals subsidiary of Hoffman-La Roche Inc., instead of the previously agreed $61 million.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: Youth Held in Cabby Attack
description: A Bronx youth was arrested yesterday and charged in the robbery of a Long Island cabdriver who was stabbed eight times and beaten with a submachine gun in the Bronx on Monday night. Christopher Perez, 16 years old, of 870 Morris Park Avenue, was charged with robbery, assault and possession of a weapon. The victim, Gary Schultz, 44, was attacked in the Pelham Gardens section after he had picked up four men and three women going from Northport, L.I., to the Bronx.

title: Gorbachevs' Trip: Today's Schedule
description: 10:30 A.M.-noon. President Bush and President Gorbachev hold their first meeting, in the Oval Office. Barbara Bush and Raisa Gorbachev meet in White House residence.

title: Yanks Expecting Some Changes
description: The night was sort of methodical. The Yankees played, lost, packed and left for home, taking with them a five-game losing streak after another disheartening road trip. There are changes coming, but even though it is only May, they may be too late.

title: 990 ARE GRADUATED AT NAVAL ACADEMY
description: In a ceremony shadowed by a recent incident of sexual harassment and allegations of physical abuse among classmates, the United States Naval Academy today graduated its 140th class of midshipmen, including the largest number of women ever.

title: Kemper Corp. Reorganizing Brokerages
description: The Kemper Corporation announced today that a restructuring of its troubled regional brokerage operations would result in a $126.5 million charge against second-quarter earnings. The company plans to reduce the number of its brokerage firm employees by more than 600, or about 12 percent of its work force of 5,200, by the end of the year.

title: Baldness Seen as a Link to Risk Factors in Heart Disease
description: Men who have male pattern baldness, with a receding hairline and hair loss at the crown of the head, may also develop higher cholesterol levels and higher blood pressure as they age than men who have more hair, research suggests.

title: Ersatz Masterpieces for Your Home
description: WHILE some people were unable to meet the $78.1 million auction price for Pierre Auguste Renoir's ''Au Moulin de la Galette'' a few weeks ago, they can still hang the painting in their living rooms: The Ethan Allen art collection sells a reproduction of it for $885.

title: Chrysler's No. 2 Officer Quits Post
description: Gerald Greenwald, vice chairman of the Chrysler Corporation and heir apparent to Lee A. Iacocca, resigned today and is expected to become chief executive of UAL Inc., owner of United Airlines.

title: Lucy Boston, 97, English Author Of Illustrated Stories for Children
description: Lucy Boston, a leading writer of children's fiction, died on Friday at her home, the Manor, a 12th-century Norman house at Hemingford Grey in Huntingdonshire, England, which provided the inspiration and setting for her influential ''Green Knowe'' books. She was 97 years old.

title: Esther V. Foley; Athletic Director, 85
description: Esther V. Foley, the director of the women's athletic program at New York University from 1951 to 1971, died on Monday at her home in Katonah, N.Y., after a long illness. She was 85 years old.

title: Amritsar Journal;   Sikh Bears a Sword, Prison Scars and a Grudge
description: Along the border with Pakistan, there are many tales to tell of Punjabi villagers who risked their lives to help India provision its army for three wars between these two countries. The stories have a ring of nostalgia about them now.

title: Celebrities Lose Federal Round In Pipeline Fight
description: After allegations of ''celebrity routing,'' the staff of a Federal regulatory agency has recommended moving the path of a proposed natural-gas pipeline back onto property owned by Dr. Joyce Brothers, the psychologist, and Arnold Fisher, a Manhattan real-estate executive.

title: Money-Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields on taxable and tax-exempt money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were narrowly mixed for the week ended yesterday.

title: Critic's Notebook;   Characters From the Screen Are Invading the Printed Page
description: ''What's your favorite 'I Love Lucy?' '' someone asked, for reasons now long forgotten, at a college party in the 1970's. Instantly the room was flooded with answers: ''Lucy meets Harpo Marx,'' ''Lucy stomps the grapes'' or ''Lucy and Ethel in the chocolate factory.'' Everyone could conjure mental images to match episodes more familiar to this generation than Mother Goose rhymes.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Derek Bok's plan to leave the presidency of Harvard misstated the number of the university's presidents who were not graduates of Harvard College. Mr. Bok was the third; the others were Harvard's first two presidents, Henry Dunster and Charles Chauncy.

title: Gorbachev Reaffirms Stand On German Role in NATO
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev today reaffirmed Soviet opposition to a unified Germany being part of NATO. But after likening Western insistence on the matter to ''an old record'' and warning the West against sliding back into ''cold war'' attitudes, he suggested that the two sides may yet succeed in finding a compromise.

title: Blazers' Drexler Too Hard to Guard
description: Because of his immense talent, Clyde Drexler has grown accustomed to setting high standards for himself.

title: Prague Stepping Up the Hunt for Its Fallen Spies
description: In the Prague Castle, where the sun had lit up the large carpets and golden curlicues on the walls, an official was saying the President's offices at last seemed to be free of electronic bugs.

title: Mainline Protestant Ministers Turning From the Inner City
description: The Rev. Robert B. Lepley, a United Church of Christ minister, had set out with the idealism of the uninitiated to serve in the East New York section of Brooklyn.

title: High Court Backs Brokers
description: The Supreme Court on Tuesday upheld a ruling that blocks states from forcing securities brokers to give investors the option of suing, rather than seeking arbitration, to settle alleged broker fraud.

title: Walter Allyn Rogers; Priest, 76
description: The Rev. Walter Allyn Rogers, an Episcopal priest and the former priest in charge of St. Simeons Episcopal Church in the Bronx, died on Tuesday at Brattleboro (Vt.) Memorial Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in East Dover, Vt.

title: Indicators Fall 0.2% on Drop in Building Permits
description: The Government index intended to predict the course of the economy eased two-tenths of 1 percent in April, largely reflecting the third straight decline in the number of permits for new buildings, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Beloit Acquiring Stake in Measurex
description: Harnischfeger Industries said its 80 percent-owned Beloit Corporation unit had agreed to acquire up to a 20 percent stake in the Measurex Corporation by buying shares on the open market. Measurex's stock jump $2.25 today, to $21.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Its 11.5 percent rise was the fourth best of the day.

title: Democrats Eye Convention: New York, and New Format
description: The 1992 Democratic National Convention will probably be held in New York City, party officials said today.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Herald Center to AC&R Advertising for its shopping mall in Herald Square in Manhattan.

title: U.S. and Soviets Agree to Resume Ocean Traffic
description: At the summit meeting, President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev will sign a new shipping agreement that will open up 42 ports in each country to ships flying the other nation's flag, restoring widespread ocean traffic between the two countries for the first time since 1981.

title: As Grain Reserves Drop, Prices May Rise
description: For the first time in years, the nation's wheat and corn reserves have fallen below the levels necessary to offset a severe drought or some other damage to this year's grain crop. The dwindling reserves help to reduce the budget deficit by shrinking farm subsidies, but they leave the nation vulnerable to food price inflation.

title: Leak Eludes Shuttle Team; Liftoff Date Uncertain
description: The launching of the space shuttle Columbia was delayed at least until early next week, and possibly for weeks, as engineers here worked round the clock today to pinpoint the site of the fuel leak that abruptly halted the countdown on Tuesday.

title: It Took a Fight to Win Pregnancy Leave
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Dealers' Discount Cut
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to offer customer incentives instead of a discount to dealers this fall to spur sales at the end of the 1990 model year, the company said today.

title: Transit Police to Eject Subway Panhandlers
description: All panhandlers, including people who are silently extending a cup, would be ejected from the subway system under stringent guidelines announced yesterday by the new chief of the New York City transit police.

title: Appliance Shipments
description: Shipments of large home appliances, an important indicator for manufacturers, declined 2.7 percent in April from a year earlier, the Association of Home Appliance Manufacturers said today. The shipments declined to 3.9 million units in April from 4 million in 1989.

title: Edward Louie Is Dead; Cookie Pioneer Was 69
description: Edward Louie, creator of the fortune cookie folding machine and a line of risque fortune cookies, died on Friday shortly after returning from a visit to his ancestral village in China. He was 69 years old.

title: Obstacles Delay Chilean Inquiry Into '76 Slaying
description: Although the new Chilean Government has agreed to pay compensation for the assassination of former Foreign Minister Orlando Letelier in Washington in 1976, efforts to reopen the criminal investigation of the case here continue to encounter roadblocks.

title: Review/Theater;   Last Days Of 3 Gay Men With AIDS
description: ''A Quiet End,'' Robin Swados's drama of three gay men suffering through the final stages of AIDS, is suffused with an anguished tenderness toward its characters. Unlike other recent plays dealing with the impact of AIDS on homosexual life in New York, it eschews the history and politics of the epidemic to explore at some depth the inner lives of desperately ill men from varying backgrounds. Impending death forces men - two are Catholic and one is Jewish - to confront their fears and to grapple with the meaning of existence.

title: HEALTH: Personal Health;   Children in sports: tailoring activities to their abilities and needs will avoid pitfalls.
description: Children are getting involved in competitive sports at ever younger ages. A talent for sports like gymnastics, tennis, skating and dancing is sometimes detected in preschoolers, who may then be pressured by parents and trainers to spend childhood preparing for possible greatness.

title: Limos and Fine Food: Ah, It's a Dog's Life
description: RHETT eats only high-protein food, and never considers leftovers. Every week, he visits a salon for a long, soothing bath and to have his hair done. To stay fit, he frolics in a glass-enclosed, air-conditioned exercise area in his roomy Atlanta home. Alternate weekends, he hops into the Jeep and zooms to a mountain cabin in Cashiers, N.C. Five or six times a year, he cavorts at a beach house in Hilton Head, S.C. Not a bad life. But don't think Rhett is the only dog who has it so good. Never before have so many pet owners shamelessly doused their animals with luxuries. Dogs and cats are reveling in a highly pampered life unfamiliar to their forebears: premium foods, lavish clothes, smart furniture, weekly groomings at the best salons and the comprehensive medical care pet owners might think twice about for their mothers.

title: Quirk, in a Rare Start, Helps the Athletics Set Back the Blue Jays, 8-5
description: Jamie Quirk drove in two runs with a double and a triple in only his second start of the season today as the Oakland Athletics defeated the Blue Jays, 8-5, ending Toronto's streak of five consecutive victories.

title: Syrians Raid Beirut Offices Trying to End Muslim Battle
description: Syrian troops raided militia offices and reinforced checkpoints today in an attempt to end a new wave of violence in mainly Muslim West Beirut.

title: Some British Designers Say Pshaw to Frills
description: A rotunda book room that draws heavily on the Doric order stands at the heart of the British Interior Design Exhibition at Chelsea Old Town Hall here. The room has a perfectly proportioned rotunda, fluted columns, a floor design that echoes the dome above and painted panels showing ancient symbols of wisdom and enlightenment.

title: ERRORS ARE FEARED IN CARBON DATING
description: Since 1947, scientists have reckoned the ages of many old objects by measuring the amounts of radioactive carbon they contain. New research shows, however, that some estimates based on carbon may have erred by thousands of years.

title: Gay and Lesbian Festival Widens Its Film Horizons
description: When the 18-day New York International Festival of Lesbian and Gay Film opens tonight at the Biograph Theater, it is expected to be the largest event of its kind yet held in the United States. Over the next three and a half weeks the festival will have 92 shows and 108 films and videos from around the world. Three series within the festival will focus on films from Asia, films directed by women and films dealing with AIDS. A fourth will look back at the 1980's and compare the images of gay men and lesbians in mainstream and independent films during the last decade.

title: New York City School Ouster Policy Curbed
description: State Education Commissioner Thomas Sobol declared New York City's school expulsion policy illegal in a ruling released today.

title: Borden Appointment Seen As Prelude to Job as Chief
description: Borden Inc. yesterday named Anthony S. D'Amato as president and chief operating officer, making him the likely next leader of the $7.6 billion company.

title: Law Allows Banks to Sell Insurance
description: Efforts by large banks to expand into the insurance business were rewarded yesterday as Delaware enacted laws allowing banks in the state to sell insurance nationwide.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You have the same explosive mixture you had in Germany in the 1930's. The humiliation of a great power. Economic troubles. The rise of nationalism.

title: Ending Meeting, Arabs Strike Harsher Tone
description: Ending a three-day summit meeting here, Arab leaders today denounced Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel as a grave threat to their security and condemned what they called United States support for Israel's policies of ''aggression, terrorism and expansionism.''

title: Taiichi Ohno, Whose Car System Aided Toyota's Climb, Dies at 78
description: Taiichi Ohno, a self-taught engineer who developed the manufacturing system that helped make the Toyota Motor Company one of the most powerful automobile producers in the world, died of heart failure on Monday in Toyota City, Japan. He was 78 years old.

title: Jane Breed Fleming; Volunteer, 56
description: Jane Breed Fleming, the founder of Neighbor to Neighbor, a volunteer social-service organization in Greenwich, Conn., died of renal cancer on Tuesday at her home in Greenwich. She was 56 years old.

title: Mets Hope Harrelson Works Some Magic
description: The Mets do not have a Joe Morgan at the helm, but they wouldn't mind a variation of the ''Morgan Magic'' he brought to the Boston Red Sox in 1988. Nor do they have Cito Gaston, who took over an underachieving Toronto Blue Jays team last season and led it to a division championship.

title: Agassi and Chang Are Winners in Paris
description: It was children'sday at the French Open, a noisy tradition that liberated 8,000 students from the classroom and let them loose to prowl Roland Garros where they howled for their favorites - Michael Chang and the neon-hued Andre Agassi - and hissed at their hero's opponents.

title: Now, on Talk Radio, Remodeling Tips
description: THE radio call-in show is a national institution, wellspring of lively political debates and Dr. Ruth. This week a new program will examine different sorts of burning issues in the American psyche - like how aluminum siding compares with vinyl.

title: Prisoners Find Poor Medical Care the Norm;   Alternatives to Jailing
description: To the Editor:

title: Fremont C. Peck, 92, Ex-Brooklyn Publisher
description: Fremont C. Peck, publisher of The Brooklyn Daily Times and The Brooklyn Times-Union in the 1920's and 1930's, died on Tuesday at his home in Locust Valley, L.I. He was 92 years old.

title: Pistons Regroup And Gain An Edge
description: Detroit's tough, aggressive defense, featuring the hard fouls the Pistons are noted for, was back tonight. Missing for the Chicago Bulls were heroics by Michael Jordan.

title: Polish Train Fares to Double
description: The state-run railroad, recently hit by a crippling strike, will double passenger fares on Friday, the official news agency reported. The increases were planned before the labor strife broke out May 20, a railroad spokesman said today.

title: Angels File Complaint
description: The California Angels said yesterday that they had filed complaints against George Steinbrenner over the Yankee owner's comments after the trade of Dave Winfield.

title: Armstrong Stake Is Sold
description: The Belzberg family today sold its entire 11.7 percent stake in Armstrong World Industries, according to a family spokesman.

title: Fernandez, Ill, Misses Marymount Ceremony
description: A few hours before the 41st commencement at Marymount Manhattan College last night, the main speaker, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez, canceled because he was suffering from the flu.

title: Layman Is Chosen to Head the Presbyterian Church
description: The 614 delegates to the annual convention of the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) elected a layman today to lead the 2.9-million-member denomination for the next year.

title: Westinghouse Elects Engineer to Top Posts
description: As expected, directors of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation yesterday elected Paul E. Lego, a soft-spoken, deliberate career engineer, as chairman and chief executive, effective July 1.

title: Gorbachev's Last Summit?
description: Mikhail Gorbachev used to defy gravity: his power expanded while his policies failed. But no longer. His inability to block the election of Boris Yeltsin as president of the Russian Republic is only one of many setbacks. Political tension in the Soviet Union is, in fact, so high that the summit meeting this week could be the last one the hero of perestroika attends.

title: Victory for Hunter Thompson
description: Prosecutors asked today for dismissal of charges of drug possession, explosives possession and sexual assault against Hunter S. Thompson, saying their case against the journalist and author was not strong enough.

title: Review/Pop;   Australians Take Message to Exxon
description: Midnight Oil yesterday added a New York show to its three-night stand at Radio City Music Hall - a lunchtime mini-concert on the Avenue of the Americas facing the Exxon Building. Playing in front of a banner reading, ''Midnight Oil Makes You Dance, Exxon Oil Makes Us Sick,'' the Australian band played songs about pollution, exploitation of workers and general defiance; the opener declared, ''Your dream world is about to end.''

title: William T. Overgard; Artist, 64
description: William T. Overgard, an artist and novelist who drew the ''Steve Roper and Mike Nomad'' comic strip, died of a heart condition on Friday at his home in Stony Point, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

title: British Beef Banned by Paris
description: France announced a ban today on all imports of British beef to protect against an outbreak of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, the ''mad cow'' disease that has killed 13,000 head of British cattle. Agriculture Minister Henri Nallet said the ban would take effect Thursday. Austria imposed a similar ban Tuesday, and European Community countries have already banned imports of British live cattle more than 6 months old.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Fear in the Bargaining;   Specters of the Past Are the Chips of Today As Gorbachev Deals on Germany's Status
description: When Soviet analysts anticipate the Soviet-American talks this week on the future of Europe, they sometimes draw an ominous analogy between President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Soviet Union and Germany after World War I. Once again, they say, a great power's ambitions for world influence lie in tatters. Again, a failed economy has caused panic and pessimism. Again, a surly nationalism is on the rise. Again, rival powers are tempted to press their advantage.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Whittle Explains Media Shift
description: WHEN Whittle Communications announced two weeks ago the introduction of a television program for doctors' offices, another news item received far less attention. The Knoxville, Tenn., company, which specializes in putting new media in unconventional places, also said it was curtailing the publication of Special Reports, the ballyhooed magazine series Whittle created two years ago.

title: TV Networks Gamble to Win In the Prime-Time Stakes for Fall
description: The chess game of prime-time television scheduling reached a new level of intricacy in the last 2 weeks as 4 networks announced 33 new programs for next September.

title: Joseph E. Parisi; Legislator, 77
description: Joseph E. Parisi, a State Senator from Brooklyn from 1945 to 1948, died on Tuesday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 77 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: Florence MacWilliams, A Mathematician, 73
description: Florence Jessie MacWilliams, a mathematician and a developer of the digital coding used in computers and telecommunications, died of an embolism on Sunday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived in Bernardsville, N.J.

title: The Censor's Follies
description: To the Editor:

title: Mr. Dinkins Cleans Up His Budget
description: Barely a week after declaring it was ''out of business,'' Mayor David Dinkins has found money to save the ''clean team'' that sweeps and empties litter baskets on New York City's busiest streets.

title: Review/Music;   Last Gasps of an Empire
description: The Battery Maritime Building, on Whitehall Street near the Staten Island Ferry, is to become the home of Dance Theater Workshop and Creative Time in 1995, after the building is renovated. Until then the two companies will present occasional performances and temporary exhibitions there.

title: 4 Westchester Children Found Stabbed to Death
description: Four children, from 3 1/2 to 11 years old, were found stabbed to death in their apartment here today, the police said.

title: Calendar: Of Garlic And Roses
description: Scents, Delicate and Powerful, Brooklyn Botanic Garden, 1000 Washington Avenue off Eastern Parkway, Prospect Heights; 718-622-4433.

title: Wage Gap Between Sexes Is Cut in Test, but at a Price
description: Four years ago the State of Washington, prodded by its biggest public employee union, struck a celebrated blow for women when it began a program intended to raise the pay for government jobs typically considered women's work.

title: Audio-Video Chain Reports 1989 Loss
description: Wall to Wall Sound and Video Inc. disclosed that it had a net loss of $3.67 million for 1989 and that it was negotiating with creditor banks for waivers of default. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Wall to Wall blamed increased costs, expansion expenses, inventory adjustments and disappointing sales for its loss.

title: New Mexico Split Over Where Sheep May Graze
description: It could be a Hollywood script. A group of sheep ranchers, scratching out a livelihood in New Mexico's scenic but dirt-poor Chama Valley, want their flocks to graze on government lands. But state and Federal agencies, joined by an uncommon alliance of hunting and environmental groups, oppose the grazing as a threat to the land and the wildlife.

title: On the Table: Knots to Untie, Deals to Strike
description: ARMS

title: Gorbachev Plans to Meet South Korean, U.S. Says
description: In a major step toward improving relations with South Korea, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has agreed to meet with President Roh Tae Woo of South Korea during his visit to the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: Old Soldiers Never Die
description: THREE years ago Eva Thompson, a toy dealer in Dallas, decided it was time to have a convention devoted to G.I. Joe, the dress-up action doll for boys, which Hasbro Inc. introduced in 1964. Tomorrow and Saturday in Dallas, she will hold the third G.I. Joe Convention. For Mrs. Thompson, who paid $5 in 1980 for a foot locker with two G.I. Joes, assorted toy guns and uniforms at a garage sale, the immediate appeal was the uniforms. ''To me, you can learn a lot about the military and about its relationship to history,'' she said. ''Most collectors - 80 percent - are men, and they like G.I. Joe because they had him as kids.''

title: Chronicle
description: Remembering:

title: Penalty for N.C. State
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association has ordered North Carolina State University to pay it $405,756, representing 90 percent of the school's net earnings from men's basketball tournaments during the two seasons in which Charles Shackleford, a former Wolfpack player, admitted accepting money in violation of collegiate rules.

title: Market Place;   Buyers of Funds Grow Confident
description: RISING stock prices and declining interest rates are propelling cash into stock and bond mutual funds at rising rates, setting records for some companies, fund managers say.

title: Soviet-South Korean Summit
description: President Gorbachev plans to meet President Roh Tae Woo in San Francisco, the first such meeting between the countries, which have been adversaries for 40 years. Page A14.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Message Sticks In HDM's Ads
description: The first campaign for the TDK Corporation's audio tapes from its new agency, HDM New York, looks a bit like the old campaign for Krazy Glue.

title: Quake Jolts Wide Arc of East Europe
description: A strong earthquake centered about 20 miles east of here killed at least eight people in Romania today and caused hundreds of injuries and property damage along an arc that spanned the Carpathian Mountains from Romania to parts of the Soviet Union and Bulgaria.

title: California Grower Charged With Enslaving Illegal Aliens
description: A Federal grand jury has indicted a flower grower and seven other people on charges of enslaving more than 100 undocumented workers from Mexicobeating them if they tried to escape.

title: Mets' Fun and Games Are Over
description: Howard Johnson and Kevin Elster like to play cards in the clubhouse before and after games. Ron Darling and Bob Ojeda sometimes bring golf clubs on the road and squeeze in 18 holes when the opportunity arises.

title: Orioles' Robinson Suspended for 3 Games
description: Frank Robinson, the manager of the Baltimore Orioles, was suspended for three games yesterday as a result of an argument Monday with Drew Coble, an umpire whom Robinson later called a liar and ''a no-good human being.''

title: Feld Ballet Is to Open Lehman Center Season
description: A performance by the Feld Ballet will open the new season on Oct. 6 at 8 P.M. at the Lehman Center for the Performing Arts at Lehman College, Bedford Park Boulevard and Goulden Avenue, the Bronx.

title: Millicent Miller; Actress, 81
description: Millicent Miller, who worked as Vivien Leigh's stand-in during the filming of ''Gone With the Wind,'' died on Tuesday. She was 81 years old.

title: Lawyer to Challenge Gov. Clinton in Arkansas
description: Arkansas Republicans have chosen a prominent Little Rock lawyer and businessman to challenge Gov. Bill Clinton this November in his bid for a fifth term.

title: Washington Talk;   High Court Still Groping To Define Due Process
description: At first glance, the obscure divorce case the Supreme Court decided this week might have fit more comfortably on daytime television than on the Court's docket.

title: Digital Reveals Software Plan
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation yesterday announced a series of products and a set of business partnerships aimed at the expanding market for computerized-forms processing.

title: Q&A
description: Stained Tiles

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Billboards Win Obie
description: The Institute of Outdoor Advertising awarded Crowley Webb & Associates, Buffalo, the Best of Show Obie Award last night. The agency won for a billboard campaign for Garcia's Irish Pub that featured whimsical personal ads.

title: 2 CHINA DISSIDENTS DETAINED IN MAY
description: The Chinese authorities have recently detained at least two democracy advocates, including one who spent a decade in prison for political beliefs, Chinese familiar with the cases say.

title: Con Ed Electric Rate Freeze Is Extended for 2 More Years
description: Basic electric rates for Con Edison's 2.9 million customers in New York City and Westchester County will remain frozen for the next two years under an agreement announced yesterday by the utility and Gov. Mario M. Cuomo.

title: Suspected New York Mob Leaders Are Indicted in Contract Rigging
description: Several suspected leaders in four crime families were among 15 men indicted yesterday on Federal charges that they skimmed ''tens of millions'' of dollars through a conspiracy to control awarding of window contracts at the New York City Housing Authority.

title: Books of The Times;   When the Logic of a Lawyer's World Unravels
description: The Burden of Proof

title: Chronicle
description: The Soviet Union's pre-eminent glasnost journalist, VITALY A. KOROTICH, is one of 14 Gannett Center Fellows for 1990-91. He is the editor of the newsweekly Ogonyok and a member of the Soviet Congress of People's Deputies. Fellows work on individual projects at the Gannett Center for Media Studies at Columbia University. Mr. Korotich will study models of coverage for press freedom.

title: U.S. Bases to Stay in Greece Under New Eight-Year Pact
description: The United States and Greece initialed an eight-year military cooperation agreement today insuring the continued operation of American military bases in Greece in exchange for military aid, the Greek Government announced.

title: Quakes Are Unrelated
description: Despite the nearness in time of the quakes that struck Peru and Romania late Tuesday and early yesterday, one earthquake rarely, if ever, touches off a quake in some other part of the globe, according to Lynne Sykes, an earthquake specialist at Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory.

title: Paribas and Mixte Reach Agreement
description: Paribas, the French investment bank, and the diversified holding company Navigation Mixte ended a long standoff after a failed takeover bid by Paribas. Compagnie Financiere de Paribas said it would cut its 40.5 percent stake in Mixte to 30 percent, and Mixte will cut its 12 pecent stake in the bank to 9.5 percent.

title: Review/Television;   Merging Zhivago With His Creator
description: Born 100 years ago, the Russian poet, novelist and translator Boris Pasternak died in 1960, two years after he was forced by the Khrushchev Government to refuse the Nobel Prize for literature. ''Doctor Zhivago,'' which first appeared in the West in 1957, was finally allowed to be published in the Soviet Union in 1988. A 90-minute British-Soviet production called ''Pasternak'' intertwines the writer's life with scenes from his novel. A passionate celebration of the Russian soul, it may be seen tonight at 9 on Channel 13.
